headline: Mayor de Blasio Meets With Parents Opposed to State Testing
abstract: An Education Department official said that although the mayor continued to believe the tests were important, he wanted to hear the parents’ views.
lead_paragraph: It has been a sore point for the leaders of New York City’s opt-out movement that Mayor Bill de Blasio, who promised to be an advocate for public-school parents, has not fully embraced their protest against state tests.

headline: A Futuristic Suit That Gives You a Taste of Old Age
abstract: An exhibit at Liberty Science Center in Jersey City uses data-collecting gear to simulate the vision, hearing and mobility of an 85-year-old person.
lead_paragraph: What could it possibly be like to be old? The stooped shuffle, the halting speech, the dimming senses.

headline: Virginia State Trooper Killed in Bus Station Shooting
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: Two civilians were injured in the shooting at the Greyhound station in Richmond, Va., and the gunman was fatally wounded.
lead_paragraph: A Virginia police trooper was killed in the midst of a training exercise at a Greyhound bus station in Richmond, Va., on Thursday after a man he had been talking to pulled out a handgun and shot him, the authorities said.

headline: A $200,000 Ballot Error and Other Misprints at New York City’s Board of Elections
abstract: Mistakes on an absentee ballot and an elections notice led to costly corrections and to concerns from voter advocacy groups.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Board of Elections has a proofreading problem — and even small mistakes are turning out to be costly.

headline: Donald Trump Acknowledges Misstep on Abortion Question
abstract: Donald J. Trump allowed that he might have misspoken about abortion when he told the MSNBC host Chris Matthews that women who have abortions should face some form of punishment if the procedure is banned.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump on Thursday allowed that he might have misspoken on the topic of abortion when he told the MSNBC host Chris Matthews that women who have abortions should face some form of punishment if the procedure is banned.

headline: A Dance Between Dealer and Carmaker on Lifting Sales
abstract: Kia, BMW and Nissan have encouraged dealers to buy cars, raising sales, then offer the virtually new vehicles as used models, company memos show.
lead_paragraph: Auto sales hit an all-time high last year in the United States, and many analysts expect another record this year.

headline: FanDuel and DraftKings Suspend College Sports Contests
abstract: The two largest daily fantasy sports sites announced an agreement with the N.C.A.A. to indefinitely suspend contests involving college sports.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Two days before the Final Four was to begin, the two largest daily fantasy sports sites, FanDuel and DraftKings, announced an agreement with the N.C.A.A. to indefinitely suspend contests involving college sports, bowing to pressure from college sports’ governing body.

headline: Obama and President Xi of China Vow to Sign Paris Climate Accord Promptly
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'United States International Relations', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: Officials cast the announcement as a statement of resolve by the world’s two largest greenhouse gas polluters, even though there are doubts about whether the United States can meet its obligations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama and President Xi Jinping of China said Thursday that they would sign the Paris Agreement on climate change on April 22, the first day the United Nations accord will be open for government signatures.

headline: New York Budget Deal With Higher Minimum Wage Is Reached
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders said the agreement would lift the hourly pay in New York City to $15 by the end of 2018, with slower increases elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and state legislative leaders announced on Thursday that they had reached a budget agreement that would raise the minimum wage in New York City to $15 by the end of 2018, but initiate slower increases elsewhere, even in the city’s wealthy suburbs.

headline: Tim Howard Says Women’s Team Should Fight for Rights
abstract: In an interview with The Times, Howard said of the pay dispute involving the United States women’s team, “I feel they should fight for their rights, no matter what.”
lead_paragraph: Goalkeeper Tim Howard does not spend much time in the United States, but that will change in May when he leaves Everton, his Premier League club for a decade, to join the Colorado Rapids in M.L.S. Howard, 37, figures that is where his career will end, perhaps after a fourth trip to the World Cup, in Russia in 2018. In an interview with The New York Times on Thursday, Howard discussed his career, the pay dispute between U.S. Soccer and the women’s national team, and why he took a year off from the national team.

headline: A Manhattan Clock Tower Will Keep What Makes It Tick
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Buildings (Structures)', 'Watches and Clocks', 'Supreme Courts (State)', 'Privatization']
abstract: A State Supreme Court justice has blocked a plan by developers to convert the tower into a private luxury apartment and electrify the clock.
lead_paragraph: A developer’s plan to silence one of the last great mechanical tower clocks in New York City — an officially designated landmark, at that — has been thwarted.

headline: Fans Back Brooke Henderson at ANA Inspiration
abstract: The large contingent following the 18-year-old Henderson, who grew up in eastern Ontario, turned Mission Hills Country Club into Canada’s fourth territory.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — In the morning group ahead of Brooke Henderson, Ai Miyazato birdied the par-5 18th hole at Mission Hills Country Club to take the early lead Thursday in the ANA Inspiration, the women’s first major, at five-under-par 67. In the group behind Henderson, Lydia Ko, the women’s world No. 1, also birdied 18 to post a 70, her best opening score in four starts in this event.

headline: Cup Stacking: A Sport Whose Growth Runneth Over
abstract: Cup stacking, a casual game that started at a Boys & Girls Club in Oceanside, Calif., more than 30 years ago, is evolving into a fast-growing global sport.
lead_paragraph: William Orrell is the best in the world in his sport. A 17-year-old from North Carolina, Orrell is ranked No. 1 and is the reigning junior Olympic and world champion. He has a popular YouTube channel, a product line named after him, and legions of admiring fans in dozens of countries.

headline: In College Basketball, Cavernous Stadiums Tend to Dampen Shooting
abstract: N.C.A.A. statistics show that shooting percentages fall slightly in domes like NRG Stadium, where the Final Four will be held this weekend, compared with arenas.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — For a long time, the most famous — and probably the first — college basketball game played in a large domed stadium was between No. 2 Houston and No. 1 U.C.L.A. in January 1968 at the Astrodome. Despite the presence of center Lew Alcindor, later known as Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the Bruins shot 26 of 77 from the field — a paltry 34 percent, held down by Alcindor’s eye injury — in their 71-69 loss.

headline: Shirley Hufstedler, Judge and Cabinet’s First Education Secretary, Dies at 90
abstract: At the newly established Education Department, she set as her goal giving more help to the disadvantaged and the disabled.
lead_paragraph: Shirley Hufstedler, a pathbreaking former federal judge who became the nation’s first cabinet-level secretary of education, nominated by President Jimmy Carter, died on Wednesday in Glendale, Calif. She was 90.

headline: N.C.A.A. May Act More Forcefully Against Laws Seen as Discriminatory
abstract: The N.C.A.A. may soon take a more proactive role in using its power to withhold athletic events, an official said.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The N.C.A.A. may soon take a more proactive role in using its power to withhold athletic events from states whose laws are seen as discriminatory, the chairman of the Division I board of directors said Thursday.

headline: A Message to Our Loyal Fans
abstract: A sad message for our solvers.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — High on my list of Things I Would Rather Not Have To Do is give people bad news, but in all likelihood, you’ve already solved the puzzle and gotten the sad message.

headline: Review: In Arthur Miller’s ‘Crucible,’ First They Came for the Witches
abstract: Arthur Miller’s endlessly revived historical drama from 1953 suddenly feels like the freshest, scariest play in town.
lead_paragraph: The Devil has returned to Broadway, with the power to make the strong tremble. It is time to be afraid, very afraid, of a play that seemed perhaps merely worthy when you studied it in high school English class.

headline: Bernie Sanders Seeks to Win Over New York by Stressing Brooklyn Roots
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The Vermont senator will try to persuade voters he is a better choice than Hillary Clinton, who is highlighting her years in the Senate for New York.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont kicked off his effort to win the April 19 New York Democratic presidential primary with a large, boisterous rally in the Bronx on Thursday night, highlighting his local roots and telling New Yorkers that he would work to make sure people have well-paying jobs, affordable housing and access to good public education.

headline: Brazil: Judge Removed From Inquiry Into Ex-President
abstract: The Supreme Federal Tribunal’s decision, which is not its final ruling, transfers the inquiry into the finances of former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva to the high court from Judge Sérgio Moro.
lead_paragraph: Brazil’s highest court, the Supreme Federal Tribunal, ruled Thursday that a federal investigation into the finances of former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva should be removed from a crusading anticorruption judge. The interim decision, which is not the court’s final ruling and can still be amended by the justices, transfers the jurisdiction for the inquiry to the high court from Judge Sérgio Moro, who has overseen the investigation into the graft scandal at Petrobras, the national oil company. The ruling established that intercepts of Mr. da Silva’s phone calls should be reviewed by the court because some of the calls included conversations with senior officials who enjoy special judicial standing. The court has still not ruled on whether President Dilma Rousseff’s nomination of Mr. da Silva to her cabinet, a move suspended in March by Justice Gilmar Mendes, should be allowed.

headline: Don’t Be Fooled by a Climate Change ‘Pause’
abstract: Does a possible global warming pause tell us anything about the science of climate change?
lead_paragraph: Actually: That’s like saying a temporary dip in the stock market means that the best long-term investment strategy is keeping your cash under the mattress.

headline: Obama’s Clemency Problem
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Yes, he is showing mercy. But it’s not as much as he promised.
lead_paragraph: Edina, Minn. — IN my pocket is something ancient: a 1,700-year-old Roman coin. It bears three human images and the word “Clementia.” That was the name of the Roman goddess of mercy, who was often depicted standing beside (and holding the hand of) the Roman emperor. The message was clear: Mercy was a virtue not only of individuals but also of governments. The framers of the United States Constitution embraced that tradition when they preserved for the president one of the traditional powers of kings: the pardon power.

headline: Learning From Obama
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'Environment', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: The president has had a lot of success addressing America’s problems, which may surprise many on the left and the right.
lead_paragraph: Like many political junkies, I’ve been spending far too much time looking at polls and trying to understand their implications. Can Donald Trump really win his party’s nomination? (Yes.) Can Bernie Sanders? (No.) But the primaries aren’t the only things being polled; we’re still getting updates on President Obama’s overall approval. And something striking has happened on that front.

headline: Dude, Where’s My City?
abstract: In Seattle, job growth is steroidal. But I ignore the usual measurements of what makes a city robust. Could Kramer from ‘Seinfeld’ live here?
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — I tend to ignore the usual measurements of what makes a city robust and healthy, the urban bragging points. Along the West Coast, these superlatives roll out with regularity. Seattle, two years ago, was proclaimed the fastest growing city in the United States. San Francisco usually tops the list of most expensive places to live. And Portland, Ore., just posted the highest percentage rise in home prices among major cities.

headline: Hints of an End to the Fighting in Yemen
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Civilian Casualties', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A cease-fire could lead to progress toward peace in a civil war that has become a proxy struggle over influence in the region.
lead_paragraph: After a year of civil war, there is a glimmer of hope for long-suffering Yemen. The main combatants, Iranian-backed Houthi rebels and Saudi-backed government forces, have agreed to a cease-fire  starting April 10, and the United Nations plans to revive peace talks a week later.

headline: My Banished Brother
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Down Syndrome', 'Families and Family Life', 'Group Homes and Supportive Housing']
abstract: My family sent him away because he had Down syndrome, but he created another family for himself in his group home.
lead_paragraph: The first time I saw my brother, Jimmy, he was 60 years old, and I was standing at his hospital bedside in the town of Dunkirk, N.Y. He was intubated with intractable pneumonia and lay in a drug-induced sleep, his sparse ginger hair so different from the rest of my brunette family. His ID bracelet showed his birth date: June 26, 1953, exactly 18 months after mine. Until that moment, I hadn’t known his birthday.

headline: Advice on Boys and Sex, From the Author of ‘Girls and Sex’
abstract: The author of a new book about girls and sex answers readers’ questions, mostly about boys and sex.
lead_paragraph: “Girls and Sex: Navigating the Complicated New Landscape” is a book for both young women and their parents — but primarily their parents — about what’s changed for girls with respect to sex. The author, Peggy Orenstein, looks at every aspect of that evolving world in the hope of helping girls learn to develop satisfying intimate relationships, and helping their families offer guidance.

headline: After a Rough Week, Donald Trump Refocuses on Wisconsin
abstract: The dust around Mr. Trump’s campaign appeared to settle somewhat, as he went to Washington for his first gathering with his foreign-policy team and met with Reince Priebus, the Republican National Committee chairman, in an effort to smooth the rough patches that have emerged between them in recent weeks.
lead_paragraph: For a while on Thursday, after a deeply volatile week, the dust around Donald J. Trump’s campaign appeared to settle.

headline: Construction Firm Accused in India Overpass Collapse

lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, India — The police in Kolkata on Friday filed a criminal complaint of culpable homicide and criminal breach of trust against the company that was building an elevated highway that collapsed on Thursday, and then detained eight of the company’s executives.

headline: How to Grow More Than One Kind of Fruit on a Tree
abstract: Start in late summer. Get a sharp knife.
lead_paragraph: “You’ll need a very sharp knife,” says Paul Barnett, a horticulturalist. Outside his home in southern England, 250 different apple varieties ripen on a single tree — everything from the common Golden Delicious to the rare and bitter cultivars bred for making cider. You could create what’s sometimes called a fruit-­cocktail tree by grafting a nectarine together with, say, a peach, a plum and an apricot, or manipulating a lemon tree to also grow grapefruits. But Barnett prefers a more traditional approach. “Keep apples with apples and pears with pears,” he says.

headline: The Gentle Assassin in Brazil
abstract: When a gesture made in Portuguese sounds like an offer you can’t refuse.
lead_paragraph: Deep are the world’s oceans. Deeper still are our fears. And fear is what I felt crossing the Atlantic on my way to Brazil. Adding to my longstanding fear of plane travel was the ludicrous discomfort created by not flying above solid ground.

lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Westtown School’s basketball team had an oddity a few years ago: a high school player nearly 7 feet tall who sometimes played point guard. His name was Daniel Ochefu, and his coach described him as a playmaker in a center’s body, so he granted Ochefu a bit more freedom than might have been expected for the tallest player on just about any court he crossed.

abstract: Teenagers in the Times presents all the news about young people that has appeared in The New York Times in the past month.
lead_paragraph: Our latest roundup of articles about young people that have appeared in The Times includes news from all over the world. We learned from the United Nations Population Fund that a fourth of humanity is now between the ages of 10 and 24, most of whom live in the developing world. We also learned about teenagers and adults who are working to ensure safety on campus, in neighborhoods and on the gridiron.

headline: 1941: Germans Accuse Yugoslavs
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Germans Accuse Yugoslavs of committing atrocities against ‘‘Volksdeutscher’’, in 1941.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE – Their army at full war strength, Yugoslavia’s military leaders marked time today [April 1] resolutely ready for war or peace. They were prepared for honorable peace and continued to do everything to refrain from provoking Germany. From the powerful Berlin shortwave radio station and from other German transmitters in Munich and Vienna poured words of invective against Yugoslavia.

He’d lived there for years, most recently in Battery Park City, where he owned a studio apartment. And his husband (and longtime literary agent), Christopher Schelling, had had a rent-regulated apartment on the Upper West Side for 30 years.

There was a vague plan to hole them up on the coast in the home of a mysterious wealthy character named Victor Strand as the zombie apocalypse unfolded. But from there … what? Drive north? South? Head for the desert?

headline: 1966: Soviet Pact  Stalls Over ‘Dolly’
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Soviet Pact stalls over the musical ‘Dolly’ going to Moscow, in 1966.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON – At the heart of the embarrassing and, until now, unexplained delay in signing the new cultural exchange agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union was President Johnson’s insistence on sending a Broadway musical to Russia. Both State Department and Soviet embassy officials fretted nervously, waiting for an explanation when the signing ceremony for the pact was suddenly canceled on March 16. The reason was an angry president.

headline: Before Bernie Sanders, There Was Zeidler, a Religious Socialist
keywords: ['Socialism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Religion and Belief', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Lutheran Churches']
abstract: As Mr. Sanders brings his quest for a “political revolution” to his campaign, Frank Zeidler’s legacy lives on in public conversations held by his church.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — One night in April 1948, when Bernie Sanders was a 6-year-old boy in Brooklyn, Frank Zeidler was elected mayor of Milwaukee on the Socialist Party line. He would hold the office for a dozen years. Until Mr. Sanders undertook his presidential campaign, Mr. Zeidler had been the last prominent and successful Socialist politician in America.

headline: The Poor Creatures
abstract: “Melancholy Accidents” reprints newspaper reports, spanning the years 1739 to 1916, about firearm-related deaths in this country.
lead_paragraph: With the issue of guns in America a hot topic on social media, op-ed pages and presidential debate stages, a new book shows how much of this is in fact old news. Peter Manseau’s “Melancholy Accidents” reprints newspaper reports, spanning the years 1739 to 1916, about accidental shootings, inadvertent suicides and other firearm-related deaths in this country. The book takes its title from the phrase that was regularly used to describe these incidents.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Cynthia D’Aprix Sweeney’s debut novel, “The Nest,” sold for seven figures, but the author says: “I was just hoping someone would want it.”
lead_paragraph: Where There’s a Will: Cynthia D’Aprix Sweeney, a former copywriter who returned to school in her 50s, made news a couple of years ago when her debut novel, “The Nest,” sold for seven figures. (Interviewing her for The Los Angeles Times recently, the author Meredith Maran began, “Tell me why I shouldn’t hate you.”) But in publishing as in politics, a big war chest alone doesn’t necessarily ensure success. “Money is very important,” the eminent publisher Howard Kaminsky told this newspaper in 1985, in an article headlined “Why Best Sellers Sell Best, and Other Publishing Secrets.” (The short version: Nobody knows.) “But there’s no guarantee of money making something happen. You need a book with intrinsic value, even if it’s frivolous intrinsic value.” Now Sweeney’s novel is out, and early reviews confirm that “The Nest” — a dark comedy about adult siblings squabbling over their lost inheritance — is worth the buzz. Still, Sweeney has maintained a sense of perspective. “We’re not people who are flashily trying to get attention,” she said of herself and her writer friends in a recent profile in New York magazine. “Whatever props we get, it’s just because we’re diligent workers.” Or, as she put it in her interview with Maran: “It’s not like I went out there saying, ‘I’ll only accept a million dollars for this book.’ It’s lunacy, that much money. On the other hand, I wish the publishing world was structured differently, so an author getting paid a lot for her book wasn’t such a rare thing that it’s news. I wrote the book I wanted to write. I was just hoping someone would want it.” She can stop worrying on that count: “The Nest” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 3.

headline: Bernie Sanders Hauls In $44 Million in March Fund-Raising
abstract: The strong fund-raising numbers followed a string of victories in Democratic voting contests last week and hint at the seemingly limitless well of small dollars that Senator Bernie Sanders has been able to tap.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont raised $44 million in March, his campaign announced Friday, beating his previous best monthly haul.

headline: For Extraordinary Flavor, Add a Few Drops of Squid Ink
abstract: The important thing to know about squid ink is that it is extraordinarily delicious.
lead_paragraph: Black rice with squid ink may sound like the epitome of hip cuisine, something trendy to post on social media, but in fact risotto nero has been on the menu in Italy for quite a long time. The same goes for black spaghetti, pasta al nero. In Spain, arroz negro and black paella have long been standard fare, too.

headline: Royals Poised for a Third Run
abstract: The Royals will try to make it to the World Series for the third time in three years, and repeat as champions.
lead_paragraph: Up on the third floor of the museum at the Baseball Hall of Fame, in front of an oversize photograph of giddy players in championship caps and Champagne goggles, is a gray Kansas City Royals jersey. Actually, it used to be gray. Now, preserved for ages, it is caked in Citi Field dirt, smeared from the bottom of the buttons up through the script across the chest.

headline: Philip Kerr’s ‘The Other Side of Silence,’ and More
abstract: Philip Kerr’s new novel involves bridge, blackmail and spies.
lead_paragraph: “Yesterday I tried to kill myself.” That sour sneer of a voice belongs to Bernie Gunther, the Prussian homicide cop who survived World War II as the house detective at Berlin’s fashionable Adlon Hotel. The war has been over for more than 10 years in Philip Kerr’s new book, THE OTHER SIDE OF SILENCE (Marian Wood/Putnam, $27). Bernie is currently a concierge at the Grand Hôtel du Saint-Jean-Cap-Ferrat, just another “deracinated wanted man living quietly and under a false name,” like so many other expat denizens of the French Riviera. He even has a wonderful cover story for anyone impolite enough to ask how he spent the war — as a captain in the army “Catering Corps,” he swears.

headline: ‘The Dig,’ by John Preston
abstract: In a novel based on the excavations at Sutton Hoo, the searchers expose as much about themselves as they do the past.
lead_paragraph: You dig things up at your peril, and a thousand movies tell you why: Buried scandals come back, along with half-dead monsters, jewels with curses and far too many Egyptian queens. John Preston’s subtle novel “The Dig” imagines something even more remarkable: an excavation that carefully, gently exposes the searchers’ own lives and feelings to the light, just as they brush sand away from buried treasure. He has written a kind of site report that shimmers with longing and regret.

abstract: The celebrity chef Michael Mina’s take on New American food is polished yet playful at his newest restaurant in Florida.
lead_paragraph: Pull up to the curb outside Sundial St. Pete, a shopping, dining and entertainment megaplex that crash-landed, Wizard of Oz style, in quaint downtown St. Petersburg. Bypass its beckoning entranceway for the adjacent door to Locale Market, a sprawling two-story emporium that makes Zabar’s look like a walk-in closet. Pass the glossy hillocks of organic honeycrisp apples, find your way upstairs and, voilà!, you have arrived at FarmTable Kitchen, the celebrity chef Michael Mina’s fresh take on New American fare that’s as polished-yet-playful as its name is generic.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: STOKELY: A Life, by Peniel E. Joseph. ­(BasicCivitas, $18.99.) After the deaths of Malcolm X and Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Stokely Carmichael, who embodied the black power movement, was considered an heir apparent in the battle for civil rights. His life is a crucial, if sometimes overlooked, part of the “route black America took to its present understanding of itself and its complex relationship to this country,” our reviewer, William Jelani Cobb, wrote.

headline: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
abstract: This week’s properties are in Greenwich Village, Union Square and Windsor Terrace, Brooklyn.

headline: Subtle Shifts at Boutique Fairs in Paris
abstract: The Paris art market, known for its specialty events that bring in connoisseur collectors, faces the task of responding to the tastes of the next generation of collectors.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Paris art market, though far smaller than that of New York and London, is where collectors go for speciality events and dealers they cannot find anywhere else.

headline: As Floor Fight Looms, G.O.P. Convention Delegates Become a Hot Commodity
abstract: Small gatherings of obscure state and county leaders can overrule the popular will of voters. So much for rubber-stamping the party’s nomination process.
lead_paragraph: The chairman of the Republican Party in American Samoa, Utu Abe Malae, began feeling the pressure almost immediately: phone calls, commitment forms, anything the presidential campaigns could do, say or send to nail down his support as a delegate.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Nine new books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.
lead_paragraph: GIRLS AND SEX: Navigating the Complicated New Landscape, by Peggy Orenstein. (Harper, $26.99.) In Orenstein’s thought-provoking study, more than 70 interviews with teenagers shed light on their experience of sexuality.

headline: Review: Shiki Sushi & Yakitori, in White Plains, Focuses on Fresh Fish Flavors
abstract: The restaurant keeps its sushi free of intense spices and serves up meat grilled on skewers.
lead_paragraph: Shiki Sushi & Yakitori is a welcome addition to the many sushi restaurants that have found an enthusiastic audience in Westchester.

headline: Poetic Justice
abstract: Reimagining light verse, free verse and more.
lead_paragraph: Reimagining light verse, free verse and more.

headline: Artist Says Brazilian Protesters Copied His Giant Rubber Duck
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Art', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations']
abstract: The duck displayed in Brazil bears too much of a resemblance to a six story-tall one created by the Dutch artist Florentijn Hofman, his team said.
lead_paragraph: As Brazilians have protested  corruption scandals in their government and called for the impeachment of their president, a Dutch artist has mounted a singular protest of his own. He says the giant yellow rubber duck that protesters have hauled into the streets as a makeshift mascot in the past month is too similar to his own creation.

headline: The Dirty Old Men of Pakistan
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Domestic Violence', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: They don’t want to beat up their wives. They just want to make sure they have the right to do so.
lead_paragraph: Karachi, Pakistan — IN the world we live in, there is no dearth of pious men who believe that most of the world’s problems can be fixed by giving their women a little thrashing. And this business of a man’s God-given right to give a woman a little thrashing has brought together all of Pakistan’s pious men.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Spar Over Fossil Fuel Donations
abstract: A day after Hillary Clinton said she was “sick of the Sanders campaign lying” about her taking money from the fossil fuel industry, Senator Bernie Sanders and his campaign manager are pushing back against the accusation.

headline: Satellite Images Can Pinpoint Poverty Where Surveys Can’t
abstract: Information that can be gathered from novel sources, using algorithms, can help determine the best places to spend limited resources.
lead_paragraph: An explosion of data has already changed how we market products and politicians. Now a similar innovation is beginning to change how we combat poverty around the world.

headline: Helen Mirren and Allison Williams Celebrate David O. Russell
abstract: This year’s SAG-Aftra dinner honored the work of the “Joy” director and the Ghetto Film School, which introduces minority students to filmmaking.
lead_paragraph: This year’s SAG-Aftra dinner honored the work of the “Joy” director and the Ghetto Film School, which introduces minority students to filmmaking.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘Spain in Our Hearts’
abstract: This week, Adam Hochschild talks about “Spain in Our Hearts”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Anna Quindlen discusses “Miller’s Valley”; John Williams talks about James McBride and his new biography of James Brown; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Adam Hochschild talks about “Spain in Our Hearts”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Anna Quindlen discusses “Miller’s Valley”; John Williams talks about James McBride and his new biography of James Brown; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: How the $15 Minimum Wage Went From Laughable to Viable
keywords: ['Minimum Wage', 'Income Inequality', 'States (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Organized Labor', 'Fast Food Industry', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Led by New York and California, several states are planning the increase.
lead_paragraph: BACK in November 2012, when Alterique Hall, an $8-an-hour McDonald’s cashier in New York, joined 200 fast-food workers in the first one-day strike for the Fight for $15 campaign, many scoffed at their demand for $15 an hour as pie in the sky. Frustrated with his meager pay, Mr. Hall said, “It’s time for a change.”

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Rufus Wainwright
abstract: The singer shares the titles he’d most want with him on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the singer Rufus Wainwright, whose new album, “Take All My Loves: 9 Shakespeare Sonnets,” is out on April 22. He shares his list exclusively with T.

headline: Chinese Phrase Adds Mystery to Anbang’s About-Face on Starwood
abstract: A vague Chinese regulation allows insurance companies to make overseas investments of less than 15 percent of their assets, but it has wiggle room.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — An obscure phrase on foreign investment tucked into China’s insurance regulations is being viewed as stunningly cryptic by Western standards. But the collection of words — not even a full sentence — adds to the mystery surrounding the sudden decision by the Chinese insurer Anbang Insurance Group to walk away from  a $14 billion bid for the Starwood hotel chain.

headline: Bruce Baillie, a Film-Poet Collapsing Inner and Outer Space
abstract: A part of the “Art of the Real” documentary series at Film Society of Lincoln Center showcases this avant-garde Canyon Cinema innovator.
lead_paragraph: One of the most perfect films that I’ve ever seen runs a total of three minutes. Shot in 1966, Bruce Baillie’s “All My Life” opens on a pan of an old picket fence framed by the blue sky above and a stretch of summer-brown grass below. On the soundtrack, you can hear the crackle and hiss of an old record that’s soon filled with the sounds of Ella Fitzgerald singing “All My Life” in a 1936 session with the pianist Teddy Wilson.

headline: Brussels Airport’s Reopening Delayed by Security Dispute
abstract: The airport was closed Friday, and it was unclear whether it would be able to open on Saturday morning, an airport spokeswoman said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Concerns over security at Brussels Airport have delayed its reopening, the airport operator said on Friday, more than a week after two suicide bombers heavily damaged the departure terminal.

headline: Three Bedrooms on Park Avenue for $26.6 Million
abstract: Two nearly identical apartments more than midway up the super-tall 432 Park Avenue are the sales of the week.
lead_paragraph: Two nearly identical apartments more than midway up 432 Park Avenue, the tallest residential tower in the Western Hemisphere, topping out at 1,396 feet, have sold, according to city records, and were the most expensive transactions of the week.

headline: Pro-Trump Chalk Messages Cause Conflicts on College Campuses
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Episodes at several universities illustrate how so-called chalking can turn a low-budget advertising tool into a political lightning rod.
lead_paragraph: Students at several college campuses are clashing with their administrations and debating the limits of free speech after finding chalk messages voicing support for Donald J. Trump scrawled on campus property.

headline: Review: Brick Farm Tavern Brings in the Porcinis, Then Readies the Dirt
abstract: A restaurant in Hopewell, N.J., offers unusual approaches to farm-to-table ingredients, fresh from two of the partners’ nearby farm and slaughterhouse.
lead_paragraph: The temptation to sculpt our food is primordial. I have seen ice swans necking atop a pond of cubed cheese, a cake with breasts, radish art. Still, I was surprised to find at Brick Farm Tavern in Hopewell an edible representation of its very landscape, the farm next door, in the form of a crushed porcini “soil,” from which I could harvest tiny root vegetables right there on my plate. The enthusiastic description from my waiter had been worthy of an eye roll.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Review: The Grill in Hauppauge Pairs Sound Fundamentals and Worldly Ambitions
abstract: The restaurant’s chef, Michael Heinlein, serves tried-and-true international dishes, and nails nearly all of them.
lead_paragraph: For 13 years, Michael Silva was a waiter at the Grill Room in Hauppauge. Last November, following the arc of a classic American success story, Mr. Silva took over as owner, along with three business partners, of the restaurant, now simply called the Grill.

headline: Managed by Q, an On-Demand Start-Up, Raises $25 Million
abstract: The investors GV, formerly Google Ventures, and Kapor Capital provided the financing for the office cleaning and management company.
lead_paragraph: Managed by Q began two years ago during a boom in on-demand start-ups, offering a service to clean offices in New York City whenever clients needed it.

headline: Chocolate Babka
abstract: A fudge center and chocolate crumb topping give this babka a serious upgrade.
lead_paragraph: A fudge center and chocolate crumb topping give this babka a serious upgrade.

headline: A Better Chocolate Babka
abstract: This buttery, yeast-risen cake from the old country is having a moment with pastry chefs and food blogs. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: A chocolate babka has charms that aren’t always apparent from its dowdy exterior.

headline: New Ebola Case Confirmed in Liberia; Guinea Tries a Vaccine
abstract: Although the World Health Organization no longer considers Ebola an international emergency, new cases in Liberia and Guinea show the disease’s resilience.
lead_paragraph: A new case of Ebola was confirmed Friday in Liberia, less than three months after that country was declared free of the deadly virus and only three days after the World Health Organization announced the end of an international emergency to contain and eliminate it.

headline: The Two Men Producing Some of the Most Exciting Home Design Today
abstract: Meet Adam Blackman and David Cruz.
lead_paragraph: Meet Adam Blackman and David Cruz.

headline: Blackman Cruz: Rebels of the Design World
abstract: Adam Blackman and David Cruz prove that the best things come out of opposing aesthetics.
lead_paragraph: Adam Blackman and David Cruz prove that the best work comes from the union of two wildly different visions.

headline: Alternative Lenders Turn to Seasoned Insiders for Help
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Facing growing pressure from regulators, financial tech companies have tapped Wall Street executives to bolster business.
lead_paragraph: Alternative lenders are bracing for a regulatory onslaught.

headline: Popular Quartz Countertops Pose a Risk to Workers
abstract: The government has issued new rules on “engineered stone” containing silica, a mineral linked to silicosis and other diseases among workers.
lead_paragraph: As sleek “engineered stone” countertops grow in popularity, safety experts are warning that workers who handle them are at particularly high risk from an old workplace hazard — silica, the mineral tied to silicosis, a debilitating and potentially deadly lung disease.

headline: Review: The Cottage Aims for Complex Food in a Simple Setting
abstract: The Westport restaurant is the latest effort from the owner and chef Brian Lewis, who tries to create a sense of home in the cozy space.
lead_paragraph: The Cottage, a new restaurant in Westport, is well named. It is small, cozy and very homey, very much like a New England seaside cottage, with sprays of pussy willows on counters and duck motifs wandering along the walls.

headline: Obama Rebukes Donald Trump’s Comments on Nuclear Weapons
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: The president questioned Mr. Trump’s fitness for office in comments made after a meeting of more than 50 world leaders to discuss nuclear security.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday questioned Donald J. Trump’s fitness for office after statements from the Republican front-runner that the United States and its allies should move away from decades of constraints on the use of nuclear weapons. “We don’t want somebody in the Oval Office who doesn’t recognize how important that is,” Mr. Obama said.

headline: The Female Identity, Discussed in Art
abstract: An exhibition at ArtsWestchester in White Plains explores the struggle of women to redefine themselves in a changing world.
lead_paragraph: The Barbie doll and her brand of ideal beauty debuted in 1959, and since then she sometimes has been at the center of a debate about society’s depictions of women. Critics have complained that Barbie conveys harmful messages about body image to impressionable girls, while others have defended the petite blonde as a miniature representation of an adult woman who breaks glass ceilings.

headline: Tech Start-Ups Choose to Stay Private in I.P.O. Standoff
abstract: For only the fourth time since the early 1990s, there were no tech company I.P.O.s in a quarter.
lead_paragraph: Over the last several decades, there were two distinctly dark periods for American technology companies – the bursting of the dot-com bubble in 2000 and the 2008 financial crisis. In those periods, investors had such distaste for risk that technology companies shied away from initial public offerings of stock.

headline: At Ethical Brew in Teaneck, Live Folk Music Meets Social Action
abstract: Ethical Brew, where some of the ticket sales are intended to raise money for various charities, has become a favorite local venue for fans of thoughtful, mellow folk music.
lead_paragraph: Paul Goldman was not trying to show off his big-heartedness when he took a first date to an Ethical Brew concert in Teaneck. But he figured demonstrating an interest in charity wouldn’t hurt.

keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership']

abstract: The Fortune Society commends the Brooklyn district attorney, Ken Thompson, for giving people “a real chance to rebuild their lives.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Feel the Math
abstract: Time for Sanders to act responsibly.
lead_paragraph: The Sanders campaign has come much further than almost anyone expected, to the point where Sanders can have a lot of influence on the shape of the race. But with influence comes responsibility, and it’s time to lay out some guidelines for good and bad behavior.

headline: Review: Race and Rock ’n’ Roll in ‘Memphis’
abstract: The Tony-winning musical, now at the Engeman Theater at Northport, explores racial tensions in the 1950s music industry in the South.
lead_paragraph: A goofy white guy who has trouble keeping a job as a stock boy finds success as a radio D.J. A gifted black singer stuck in her brother’s underground club gains mainstream recognition and a glossy new life as a star. The two share a tender, bittersweet romance. And all around them, dancers flip and kick their way through songs that evoke the early days of rock ’n’ roll: the 1950s.

headline: Implausible Supreme Court Scenario
abstract: A former deputy counsel to President Bush says the idea that he might have chosen a judge like Merrick B. Garland for the Supreme Court is far-fetched.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: At the Owl Shop in New Haven, Smoking Is Encouraged
abstract: A cigar shop turned music lounge has the thick, hazy atmosphere of bygone jazz clubs.
lead_paragraph: Cool jazz, fine whiskey and smoke-filled rooms used to go together. Then smoking bans arrived, literally changing the atmosphere in jazz clubs. But those bans bypassed establishments like the Owl Shop, a cigar store in the heart of New Haven, and a decade after a major renovation, the shop has transformed itself into a music lounge where the smoke-filled past lives on.

headline: In ‘Revenge Porn’ Case, Criminal Court Decision May Affect Lawsuit
abstract: Prosecutors dropped a criminal case against a woman’s former boyfriend, who is accused for posting sexually explicit images of her online, which may complicate a civil suit.
lead_paragraph: A big law firm’s novel lawsuit filed on behalf of a woman who says she was a victim of revenge pornography may be complicated by a decision in a related criminal case.

headline: Slack, a Leading Unicorn, Raises $200 Million in New Financing
abstract: The round, which brings Slack’s venture financing to $540 million, was led by the new investors Thrive Capital with participation from GGV and Comcast Ventures.
lead_paragraph: Some unicorns are still galloping.

headline: Review: ‘Saving the Media’ Seeks Remedy for Ailing Fourth Estate
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media']
abstract: A new book argues that not only is there a news crisis, but, less persuasively, that there is a need for government to remedy that.
lead_paragraph: The emergence of the Internet and various forms of digital production and distribution have had a profound and well-documented impact on the media business.

headline: Review: Remembering David Bowie, With One Artist and One Song at a Time
abstract: Musicians including Michael Stipe, Laurie Anderson, Cat Power and Perry Farrell performed a song each in a tribute concert on Thursday at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: A tribute is not a resurrection. “The Music of David Bowie,” at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, manifested Mr. Bowie’s absence as much as his legacy, in a concert featuring Michael Stipe, Laurie Anderson, Cat Power, Perry Farrell, the Pixies, the Flaming Lips and Heart’s lead singer, Ann Wilson.

headline: Orange and Bouygues Telecom Call Off Takeover Talks
abstract: The deal would have consolidated the French telecom market, but both sides failed to agree on terms for the proposed $11.4 billion deal.
lead_paragraph: Another telecommunications deal in Europe has fallen apart.

headline: Were You Influenced by Zaha Hadid’s Work?
abstract: The New York Times would like to hear from women in the architecture field about what Zaha Hadid meant to them.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times would like to hear from women in the architecture field about what Zaha Hadid meant to them.

headline: California and New York Lead the Way Toward a Decent Wage
abstract: Progress, caveats and concerns aside, was unthinkable only a few years ago.
lead_paragraph: California has won the race with New York to become the first state to enact a statewide minimum wage of $15.

headline: Jacob Zuma Says He’ll Repay South Africa for Home Improvements
abstract: Mr. Zuma said that the upgrade of his private home had caused “frustration and confusion,” but that he never meant to subvert the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — A day after South Africa’s highest court ruled that he had violated the Constitution in a long-running scandal involving government money spent on upgrades to his homestead, President Jacob G. Zuma said Friday that he would pay back part of it in accordance with the ruling, but that he had never meant to undermine the Constitution.

headline: Facebook Live, Annoying and Intrusive, Seems to Be Paying Off
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media']
abstract: The service’s new live video notifications are suddenly outstripping the regular news feed and zapping maybe millions of extra pockets.
lead_paragraph: Facebook says it thinks live video is a big deal. Media companies and amateurs have found validation in surprisingly large audiences by posting on Facebook’s new video product, Live. Thousands of people show up to watch whenever a major Facebook page “goes live,” seemingly out of nowhere. Hundreds leave comments and ask questions. Facebook Live — the product — is working.

headline: San Francisco Joins the Growing World of Small Operas
abstract: Several large companies are finding aesthetic and economic advantages to sometimes going small.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The War Memorial Opera House, a majestic Beaux-Arts landmark here that seats more than 3,100, is perfectly suited to the spectacle of grand operas like Verdi’s “Don Carlo,” which the San Francisco Opera will perform in June. But it would completely overwhelm “Svadba-Wedding,” Ana Sokolovic’s intimate a cappella work for six women, whose harmonies are only occasionally punctuated by glockenspiel or rain stick.

headline: Andrew Sullivan, Political Blogging Pioneer, Joins New York Magazine
abstract: A prolific political commentator in blogging’s early days but an infrequently heard voice in this election cycle, he will be a contributing editor.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Sullivan, a pioneer in political commentary during the early days of blogging but an infrequently heard voice in the current election cycle, has joined New York Magazine as a contributing editor.

headline: Underground Parties in Paris
abstract: A group called We Are the Oracle hosts semi-secret parties at elusive sites throughout the French capital, including abandoned chateaus and the catacombs.
lead_paragraph: A group called We Are the Oracle hosts semi-secret parties at elusive sites throughout the French capital, including abandoned chateaus and the catacombs.

headline: Partying Underground in Paris’s Secret Corners
abstract: We Are the Oracle has been holding semi-secret parties in elusive sites throughout the French capital, including the catacombs and abandoned chateaus.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Inside an abandoned seven-floor, 70-room house near the Arc de Triomphe, more than 650 revelers in floor-length gowns, curly white wigs and feathered masks gathered on a Friday night in January.

headline: Condos Rise Where an East Village Church Stood
abstract: Steiner East Village, a seven-story condo with 82 units, is being built on the site where the Mary Help of Christians Church complex once stood.
lead_paragraph: In the East Village, it became something of a guessing game: What would happen at Avenue A and East 12th Street, which languished as a dusty lot after the Mary Help of Christians Church complex was razed in 2013?

headline: An ‘Exemplary’ Foster Father, a String of Suspicions and Sexual-Abuse Charges
abstract: Interviews and child-protection records document a failure of oversight by government agencies that shared responsibility for the welfare of children placed in the care of Cesar Gonzales-Mugaburu on Long Island.
lead_paragraph: When New York City needed foster care for vulnerable boys with emotional problems, the answer was often the Long Island home of Cesar Gonzales-Mugaburu.

headline: Pabst Raids Dad’s Beer Fridge as It Looks to the Future
abstract: A businessman who made a name for himself reviving Eastern European breweries has taken on an American project: Pabst Blue Ribbon.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Eugene Kashper looks the part of someone who likes to throw back a few P.B.R.s from time to time — hipster glasses, scruffy facial hair, faded T-shirts and jeans and well-worn sneakers.

headline: Turkey Has Forcibly Returned Thousands of Refugees to Syria, Amnesty International Says
abstract: The report exposes the perils of a deal reached last month that allows Greece to send migrants back to Turkey, and reflects shifting attitudes toward refugees in the countries bordering Syria.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Turkey’s government has forced thousands of Syrian refugees to return to their war-torn country in recent months, exposing the perils of an agreement that allows Greece to send refugees arriving by boat back to Turkey, Amnesty International said in a report issued Friday.

headline: With College Transfer Rules, Hypocrisy Never Sits Out a Year
abstract: It can be argued that the transfer rule, which restricts player movement, even as coaches come and go freely, is another way college sports strip athletes of their rights.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Have you heard the one about Spike Albrecht, the University of Michigan’s senior point guard? He is seeking medical redshirt status because he missed most of this season after double hip surgery. Assuming he gets it, he’ll have a year of athletic eligibility left after he graduates. But if he is going to play college basketball as a graduate student, he will have to do it somewhere besides Michigan. Last year, his coach, John Beilein, told Albrecht and his father, Chuck, that “we’re one over for scholarships next year, and we’re recruiting a top point guard,” according to an article  this week by Pat Forde of Yahoo Sports.

headline: Seeing Red
abstract: When the photographer Frank Fournier revisited his work from New York in the late 1970s, he noticed a surprising recurrence of red shades.
lead_paragraph: When the photographer Frank Fournier revisited his work from New York in the late 1970s, he noticed a surprising recurrence of red shades.

headline: Seeing Red
abstract: For the French photographer Frank Fournier, who began shooting New York in 1976, the color red emerged as a surprise message from the city’s fabric.
lead_paragraph: In 1965, the French director Jean-Luc Godard was asked about the amount of blood in his movie “Pierrot le Fou.” Godard objected. “Not blood,” he said. “Red.” For Frank Fournier, 68, who began photographing in New York in 1976 after moving from France, the color red emerged as a surprise message rising from the city’s fabric. At the time, he was just learning to work with color film, walking the city and experimenting with the sensual properties of Kodachrome stock. “I was following the light,” he said the other morning. “I didn’t realize I was following red.” Decades later, when he was editing images from that period, he noticed the recurrence of red shades. Red could be flashy or low-key, as bright as neon or as staid and solid as faded bricks. “It really popped out intensely,” Mr. Fournier said. “You would think in New York yellow was the color to catch, because of the cabs.”

headline: Helen Mirren, Chris Tucker and Allison Williams Talk About Race at SAG-Aftra Dinner
abstract: David O. Russell and the Ghetto Film School are honored by a Screen Actors Guild dinner.
lead_paragraph: Parker Posey couldn’t recall the last time she worked opposite a black or minority actor. “Isn’t that terrible?” she said.

headline: New York’s Age of Genius
abstract: David Reid’s book, “The Brazen Age,” examines the city’s cultural iconography in the mid-20th century.
lead_paragraph: David Reid borrows the title of his rambling “interpretive historical essay” about 20th-century New York cultural iconography from an observation Gore Vidal made in The New York Review of Books decades ago.

headline: To Buy or Rent a Home? Weighing Which Is Better
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Personal Finances', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Arguments can be made for each option, but it’s impossible to know in advance which will provide better financial returns over time.
lead_paragraph: Rob Austin and his wife, Natalia, have a 10-month-old son, healthy incomes and plenty of cash in the bank for a down payment on a house. But they are happily renting a townhouse in Pasadena, Calif., with no plans to buy for now, given the frothy prices in their area.

headline: How Are New York City Taxi Plates Assigned?
abstract: A cab’s medallion number is the same as a vehicle’s plate number, but that’s not all.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is there any formula to the way New York City taxi plates are assigned? Can they be identified by borough? Also, what is the significance of the small letter after the license number? I have seen A to H.

headline: Our Natural History, Endangered
abstract: Museums play a critical role in protecting what’s left of nature.
lead_paragraph: When people talk about natural history museums, they almost always roll out the well-worn descriptive “dusty,” to the great exasperation of a curator I know. Maybe he’s annoyed because he’s spent large sums of his museum’s money building decidedly un-dusty climate-controlled storage sites, and the word implies neglect. (“Let me know,” the curator advises by email, “if you want to hear me rant for an hour or so on this topic.”)

headline: The Winter Flounder, a Master of Disguise With a Wandering Eye
abstract: A search for warmer waters bring the fish closer to humans, who have found them to be good eating.
lead_paragraph: Nothing suits a winter flounder like cold water. Unlike most local fish, winter flounder enter shallow bays and coves in midwinter to spawn and stay until the sun warms the water to temperatures above what they prefer. This habit earned these flatfish their name. It also brought them closer to humans, who found that they were fine eating.

headline: Review: For Roomful of Teeth, It’s All About the Polyphony
abstract: The vocal octet, which incorporates Inuit throat singing, yodeling and other traditions into its music, performed at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: “Prima la musica, e poi le parole” (“First the music, then the words”) — the title of a Salieri opera — often seems to be the ethos of Roomful of Teeth, a remarkable vocal octet that incorporates Inuit throat singing, yodeling and traditions from Georgia, Korea and India into its concerts.

headline: TV’s Genealogy Craze Yields Game Shows and Paper Chases but Also Interesting Lessons
abstract: Amid the tear-shedding, bickering and celebrity appearances, sociological insights emerge on these shows.
lead_paragraph: All sorts of people are swabbing inside their cheeks and spitting into collection tubes these days in the interest of researching their ancestry. Yet an old-fashioned paper chase remains far more telegenic, as TLC’s “Who Do You Think You Are?” demonstrates once again when it returns for a new season on Sunday.

headline: A Palestinian Teacher’s Method
abstract: Hanan Hroub, an elementary-school teacher, with her students in the West Bank city of Ramallah in February. She recently won a $1 million global education prize.
lead_paragraph: Hanan Hroub, an elementary-school teacher, with her students in the West Bank city of Ramallah in February. She recently won a $1 million global education prize.

headline: A Restaurant Where Soil Ends Up on the Plate
abstract: Two New Yorkers relocated to Hopewell, N.J., to farm. In 2015, they added a restaurant, with an avant garde take on farm-to-table staples.
lead_paragraph: Two New Yorkers relocated to Hopewell, N.J., to farm. In 2015, they added a restaurant, with an avant garde take on farm-to-table staples.

headline: Review: ‘Spanish Nights’ of Falla and Massenet
abstract: The New York Philharmonic performed “Nights in the Gardens of Spain,” ballet music from “Le Cid” and a concert performance of “The Three-Cornered Hat.”
lead_paragraph: With a triumvirate of cultural power players behind its creation, the 1919 premiere of “The Three-Cornered Hat” was virtually assured of success. Produced by the superstar impresario Diaghilev, with music by Manuel de Falla and sets by Picasso, the ballet tells a tale of adultery narrowly — and comically — averted in an Andalusian village.

headline: Zaha Hadid: More Than a ‘Female Architect’
abstract: The focus on the architect’s gender obscures her real achievements.
lead_paragraph: London — WHEN I was still an architecture student at Yale, I got stuck in New York City traffic with one of my professors, Zaha Hadid, and her chauffeur. I asked her whether she had any advice for me, a young female architecture student graduating into a depressed market dominated by men. She simply said, “Come work for me.”

headline: The ‘Soviet Style’ for the Upper Class
abstract: Ivo Lupis has trained New York’s rich and famous in a European-style fitness system since the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning, Ivo Lupis commanded an 87-year-old woman up to the swinging rings, then the trapeze, and then to the mat for some forward rolls.

headline: Unable to Pay $100 Bail, Homeless Man Dies in New Hampshire Jail
keywords: ['Bail', 'Homeless Persons', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The state medical examiner said the autopsy report for Jeffrey Pendleton, 26, was inconclusive and needs toxicology results.
lead_paragraph: In their last conversation, Jeffrey Pendleton told his father that he was doing well, living in New Hampshire with a woman and working at a Burger King restaurant.

headline: Amid Clashes, Greece Presses On With Plan to Deport Migrants
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Several refugees were hospitalized after hundreds broke out of a detention center to protest a European Union deal allowing Greece to send refugees back to Turkey.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Violent clashes erupted in Greek refugee camps among panicked migrants as Greece and the European Union pressed ahead on Friday with their intention to expel them from Europe and deport thousands back to Turkey, despite strong objections from rights groups and United Nations relief officials who say the plan is illegal and inhumane.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review Podcast: ‘Spain in Our Hearts’
abstract: Adam Hochschild talks about “Spain in Our Hearts”; Anna Quindlen discusses “Miller’s Valley”; and John Williams talks about James McBride and James Brown.
lead_paragraph: Listen to this week’s podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Vanessa Friedman, Michael Barbaro and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Friday Night Music: Quilt at Kennedy Center
abstract: Psychedelic rock for the 21st century.
lead_paragraph: In my not-so-secret identity as 60-something wannabe hipster, I have an overwhelming preference for live performances; I go to concerts as often as schedule allows (which isn’t often enough — but going tonight!), but videos are often a pretty good second best. And I ran across this concert video of a band I still hope to see one of these days. So much great music, so little time.

headline: From the Archives: Martha Graham and Her Dancers
abstract: Photographs of Graham and her works as the Martha Graham Dance Company celebrates its 90th-anniversary season.
lead_paragraph: Photographs of Graham and her works as the Martha Graham Dance Company celebrates its 90th-anniversary season.

headline: Of Stew and Soju
abstract: Pocha 32, in Koreatown, is modeled after the humble street stalls in South Korea that serve comfort food and stiff drinks to late-night revelers.
lead_paragraph: Pocha 32, in Koreatown, is modeled after the humble street stalls in South Korea that serve comfort food and stiff drinks to late-night revelers.

headline: Tented Walls and Family-Style Korean Dishes at Pocha 32
abstract: The décor of the Koreatown restaurant evokes the makeshift taverns in South Korea called pojangmacha (“covered wagons”), or pocha for short.
lead_paragraph: If many customers don’t fully remember their evening at Pocha 32, where dinner frequently begins after 2 a.m. and nearly always includes the Korean spirit soju, they can at least leave behind proof that they were there.

headline: Living and Breathing Martha Graham
abstract: The company, celebrating its 90th anniversary, includes dancers from all over the world who have had varying entry points into the organization.
lead_paragraph: It was 1943 at Schrafft’s, and Agnes de Mille, full of self-doubt in spite of the successful opening of “Oklahoma!,” was having a rough day. She spilled her worries to Martha Graham, who told her: “You have to keep yourself open and aware to the urges that motivate you. Keep the channel open.”

headline: Choreographers Who Dare to Risk Boredom in the Name of Insight
abstract: The Adham Hafez Company and Raduoan Mriziga presented works as part of New York Live Arts’ Live Ideas series.
lead_paragraph: At the Berlin Conference of 1884-85, European powers met to divvy up Africa. In “2065 BC,” the Adham Hafez Company imagines a similar conference, decades from now, in which power is reversed and African queens set out a new world order.

headline: How DJ Ruckus, Also Known as Greg Andrews, Spends His Sundays
abstract: The in-demand D.J. is on the road most of the year, so a Sunday at home in New York with his fiancée, Shanina Shaik, is devoted to simple pleasures.
lead_paragraph: DJ Ruckus (Greg Andrews) travels the world, from Paris to Beijing, spinning at more than 200 events a year, including private parties for high-profile clients like his cousin Lenny Kravitz, and runway shows for designers like Alexander Wang and Louis Vuitton. “If I manage to catch a break, it’s always on a Sunday,” said Mr. Andrews, 32, who lives in Alphabet City in Manhattan. He usually spends the day with his fiancée, the Australian model Shanina Shaik, 25. SHIVANI VORA

headline: Libya’s U.N.-Backed Government Ventures Farther Into Tripoli
abstract: The unity government, which landed by boat on Wednesday, appears to be getting some support from other factions.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The leaders of Libya’s fragile new unity government cautiously expanded their authority in Tripoli on Friday, venturing from their fortified base in the city port to make public appearances in a downtown mosque and square, while political factions from nearby towns pledged their allegiance.

headline: Police Say Woman Lied About Slashing in Manhattan
abstract: The woman, a student from Egypt, claimed that a man calling her a terrorist attacked her; the authorities say she has emotional issues and will not be charged.
lead_paragraph: A woman wearing a headscarf lied when she claimed she was slashed in Lower Manhattan by a man who called her a terrorist, the police said on Friday.

headline: Brave Testimony Helps Convict Costa Rican Slayers of a Turtle Conservationist
keywords: ['Beaches', 'Eco-Tourism', 'Environment', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Turtles and Tortoises']
abstract: A Spanish veterinarian who was attacked by thugs as they also murdered a turtle conservationist provided vital testimony at a Costa Rican trial.
lead_paragraph: There is seemingly no end to the violence against environmentalists and community-rights campaigners on the world’s loosely-governed resource frontiers. The murder last month of Berta Cáceres, a much-lauded Honduran indigenous activist, was just the most prominent recent example.

headline: As China Evolves, the Artist Cao Fei Is Watching
abstract: Ms. Cao’s first United States museum retrospective opens at MoMA PS1, with works that encapsulate China’s societal shifts.
lead_paragraph: Fresh off the plane from Art Basel Hong Kong this week, the Chinese artist Cao Fei was stationed at MoMA PS1, ready to supervise the installation of her first United States museum retrospective. At 37, she seemed too young to warrant an extensive survey. Dressed in a black hoodie and fashionable striped pants, Ms. Cao could have been one of the characters in her early videos, teenagers influenced by hip-hop culture or 20-somethings costumed as Japanese manga characters.

headline: Memo to Kia Dealers
abstract: In a memo sent to dealers on March 14, Kia instructed them to hold those cars for a minimum of 15 days as “test drive” models.
lead_paragraph: In a memo sent to dealers on March 14, Kia instructed them to hold those cars for a minimum of 15 days as “test drive” models.

headline: Why New York City’s Waterworks Works
abstract: A matchless delivery system that began nearly 200 years ago delivers safe, delicious water to the 9.5 million people of the five boroughs and surrounding counties.
lead_paragraph: One hundred years ago, mountain water from the Catskills began flowing into the cupped hands of New York City.

headline: Memo to Nissan Dealers
abstract: Nissan Motor has dealers buy cars for use in what it calls dealer rental fleets. The cars are supposed to remain in rental service for 90 days, and some are in fact rented by dealership customers. But occasionally, Nissan waives the 90-day rule.
lead_paragraph: Nissan Motor has dealers buy cars for use in what it calls dealer rental fleets. The cars are supposed to remain in rental service for 90 days, and some are in fact rented by dealership customers. But occasionally, Nissan waives the 90-day rule.

headline: John Kasich Presses Super PAC to Pull Ad Assailing Ted Cruz
abstract: An insult deployed by Donald J. Trump becomes the subject of some consternation in the Kasich camp when it appears in a super PAC ad targeting Ted Cruz.
lead_paragraph: Gov. John Kasich is no fan of Senator Ted Cruz, but he does not want his allies borrowing one of Donald J. Trump’s go-to insults.

headline: Rupert Murdoch and Jerry Hall? The Fascination of Odd Couples
abstract: When unlikely lovers pair up, onlookers are rarely without an opinion.
lead_paragraph: The cackling can sound like a chicken who is facing his certain death; the eye rolling suggests that vaudeville is not dead.

headline: Review: ‘House Rules’ and All Kinds of Games
abstract: In A. Rey Pamatmat’s play at Here, two Filipino families living in New York try to master Monopoly, mah-jongg, affection, aversion and assimilation.
lead_paragraph: People play a lot of games in A. Rey Pamatmat’s intriguing, untidy “House Rules,” produced by Ma-Yi Theater Company. They compete at gin rummy and Monopoly, arguing over whether to leave money on the Free Parking space. They try to learn a variation of mah-jongg and battle over sungka, a traditional Filipino pastime played with cowrie shells.

headline: Female Architects on the Significance of Zaha Hadid
abstract: The death of Ms. Hadid has reverberated throughout the architecture world, but the sense of loss has appeared most pronounced among women.
lead_paragraph: The death of Zaha Hadid at 65 on Thursday has reverberated through quarters of the architecture world from Baghdad, where she was born, to New York, London and Guangzhou, China, where she built. But the sense of loss, mounting online, has been most pronounced among female architects, who saw Ms. Hadid as a rare beacon of hope for their own success in a male-dominated field and a barometer of its continuing sexism.

headline: Cirque Replaces Lead Actor in Broadway-Bound ‘Paramour’
abstract: The show is the international troupe’s first foray on Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Cirque du Soleil, citing creative differences, said it had made a late-in-the-game decision to replace one of the lead actors in its first Broadway show, the musical “Paramour.”

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Nuclear Security, Donald Trump, Saudi Arabia
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Tesla’s New Model 3 Jump-Starts Demand for Electric Cars
abstract: Tesla said nearly 200,000 people booked reservations for the first Model 3 sedans, due out in 2017, demonstrating the potential market for electric vehicles.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Despite a steady stream of new models from a number of automakers, sales this year of electric and hybrid vehicles have failed to keep pace with the growth in the overall American market.

headline: Evening Hours | Easter
abstract: Bill Cunningham covers Easter services and festivities around New York.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cunningham covers Easter services and festivities around New York.

headline: More Details on Banker’s Tragic Death, but Questions Persist
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Work-Life Balance', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: Official reports and the last emails sent by a young Wall Street banker make the reasons for his suicide less cloudy, but still not clear.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street has always had a problem balancing the staffing equation: having the right number of people around to give those employed a meaningful work experience but also free time to unwind and recharge.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Hopping
keywords: ['Hats and Caps', 'Easter and Holy Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: Fashion at the Fifth Avenue Easter/spring promenade.
lead_paragraph: At the Fifth Avenue Easter/spring promenade: a suit from when Hollywood led the fashion world in World War II and two men in a symphony of gray, white and black. Also, men in outfits paved in candy corn and in jellybeans.

headline: Gov. Doug Ducey of Arizona Signs Abortion Drug Bill That Skirts New F.D.A. Protocol
abstract: Governor Ducey approved the bill on the day after the federal agency eased its recommendations on the use of mifepristone. He said he knew that changes in the legislation might be necessary.
lead_paragraph: One day after the Food and Drug Administration relaxed its guidelines for use of an abortion-inducing drug, Arizona’s Republican governor, Doug Ducey, signed a bill on Thursday requiring abortion clinics to follow the earlier protocol, which medical experts have described as outdated, overly restrictive and less healthy for women.

headline: Sikh Captain Says Keeping Beard and Turban Lets Him Serve U.S. and Faith
keywords: ['Sikhs and Sikhism', 'Religion and Belief', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Turbans', 'Beards and Mustaches']
abstract: Capt. Simratpal Singh says the Army’s granting of a permanent accommodation for a turban and a religious beard means that he can finally fit “two parts of my world together.”
lead_paragraph: The Army has granted a decorated officer, who is Sikh, permission to wear a religious beard and turban in uniform, ending a protracted battle that pitted individual religious freedom rights against what the military said was a need for uniformity and strict safety standards.

headline: Daniel Berehulak Named Photojournalist of the Year
abstract: Daniel Berehulak was named Photojournalist of the Year and The New York Times dominated the awards in the National Press Photographers Association’s Best of Photojournalism 2016 contest.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Berehulak was named Photojournalist of the Year and The New York Times dominated the awards in the National Press Photographers Association’s Best of Photojournalism 2016 contest.

headline: Daniel Berehulak Named Photojournalist of the Year
abstract: Daniel Berehulak was named Photojournalist of the Year and The New York Times dominated the awards in the National Press Photographers Association’s Best of Photojournalism 2016 contest.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Berehulak has been named the Photojournalist of the Year for large-circulation publications in the National Press Photographers Association’s Best of Photojournalism 2016 contest. Scott McIntyre of The Naples Daily News in Florida was selected as the Photojournalist of the Year for smaller-circulation publications.

headline: New York State Steps Up Arrests of Parole Violators
abstract: Law enforcement sought 165 repeat offenders in March, the third major sweep by the state in the past three months.
lead_paragraph: The police and parole officers of Team 7 took up positions around the Harlem apartment building — a few at the fire escape, some out front on 140th Street, the rest in the lobby — in case Cynthia Garrett turned out to be a runner.

headline: Review: Enrico D. Wey, Transcending Boundaries at Danspace Project
abstract: Mr. Wey’s solo, titled “to warring states, a useless tool,” builds on his explorations of Asian male identity.
lead_paragraph: During the premiere of his new solo at Danspace Project on Thursday, Enrico D. Wey began to drip sweat. That’s not unusual for a dancer, but here it felt momentous. Mr. Wey stood firmly in the center of a square white floor, his torso bent forward in a passage of slow, muscular, trembling movement. Though on display, surrounded by the audience on all sides, he was also hidden, his long black hair veiling his face. His body coursed with tension, and the drops of sweat, pooling at his feet, confirmed that he was working hard. Or were they tears? Either way, he seemed suddenly vulnerable, a shift that narrowed the distance between him and us.

headline: Steven Soderbergh on Rebooting ‘The Girlfriend Experience’ for TV
abstract: What changes when you turn a 2009 film about prostitution into a series on Starz? A lot.
lead_paragraph: What do “The Girlfriend Experience,” the new Starz television show about prostitution, and “The Girlfriend Experience,” the 2009 Steven Soderbergh film about prostitution, have in common?

headline: Does a Video Glimpse Into Chicago’s Year of Violence?
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Gangs']
abstract: It is a jarring, disturbing, highly cinematic video, and the police are trying to determine whether it really is what it looks like: a selfie video that inadvertently recorded the man’s own shooting.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As the video begins, a man in a baseball cap and sweatshirt is on a street, moving in a circle as he talks into a camera he seems to be holding. Suddenly the sounds of pops, one after the next, interrupt. The camera flips to different views, then lands face up, pointed to the sky, as a gunman steps into clear view, still shooting.

headline: Somali Militant Leader Believed Killed in Drone Strike
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Targeted Killings', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Hassan Ali Dhoore, considered an important member of the Shabab security and intelligence wing, had been under U.S. surveillance for some time.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American drone strike in Somalia is believed to have killed a key leader of the Shabab militant group, a United States government official said Friday, as the Obama administration continued its intensified air campaign against the group.

headline: Bull in Queens Is Captured, and Jon Stewart Chauffeurs It to Freedom
