abstract: The black and white Angus, the second bovine to escape in Queens in recent months, got out of a holding area and wandered the streets before it was corralled at York College in Jamaica.
lead_paragraph: For a bull lost in a bustling stretch of Jamaica, Queens, the green lawn outside a school building was probably the closest thing to a pasture.

headline: Supreme Court Fight Rescues a Justice From Obscurity
abstract: Justice Rufus W. Peckham was the last Supreme Court justice nominated by a Democratic president and approved by a Senate under Republican control, a step taken in 1895.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are the legal giants of the Supreme Court, justices such as John Marshall, Louis D. Brandeis and Earl Warren. Then there is Rufus W. Peckham.

headline: Ronnie Corbett, of ‘The Two Ronnies’ British Comedy Team, Dies at 85
abstract: “All those who believe in psychokinesis, raise my right hand,” Mr. Corbett would say in his routine with Ronnie Barker.
lead_paragraph: Ronnie Corbett, the diminutive comedian who teamed with Ronnie Barker to delight audiences for almost two decades on the hit BBC comedy show “The Two Ronnies,” died on Thursday. He was 85.

headline: A Yoga Master, the King of ‘Baba Cool,’ Stretches Out an Empire
keywords: ['Hinduism', 'Alternative and Complementary Medicine', 'Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Yoga', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Baba Ramdev has emerged as the leader of the “Baba Cool Movement” — a group of spiritual men who are marketing health-based products based on the ancient Indian medicinal system.
lead_paragraph: HARIDWAR, India — Sitting on an orange sofa set over a Persian carpet, in a gated office park of freshly painted tan buildings and manicured lawns, Baba Ramdev is surrounded by the trappings of any major corporate leader almost anywhere in the world.

headline: F.D.A. Proposes a Limit on Arsenic in Rice Cereal for Babies
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'ARSENIC', 'Food', 'Baby Foods', 'Rice', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: In a risk assessment, the agency tested 76 infant rice cereals and found that about half had more inorganic arsenic than the proposed limit of 100 parts per billion.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration proposed on Friday a limit for inorganic arsenic in infant rice cereal, saying that this common starter food is a leading source of exposure to the toxin.

headline: The Power of C.E.O. Activism
keywords: ['Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: How politically outspoken executives sway public (and consumer) opinion.
lead_paragraph: OVER the past few years, chief executives — including prominent figures like Lloyd Blankfein of Goldman Sachs and Howard Schultz of Starbucks — have been taking public stances on controversial issues like race relations and gender equality that are unrelated to their core businesses. It’s headline-grabbing stuff. But is it politically effective?

headline: Thousands Could Lose Food Stamps as States Restore Pre-Recession Requirements
abstract: More than 500,000 people are estimated to soon lose food stamps as states reimpose time limits and work requirements that were suspended in recent years because of high unemployment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hundreds of thousands of people could soon lose food stamps as states reimpose time limits and work requirements that were suspended in recent years because of high unemployment, state officials and advocates for the poor said Friday.

headline: Police Officer in Mail Carrier’s Arrest Is Stripped of His Badge
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Postal Service and Post Offices']
abstract: Lt. Luis D. Machado has been placed on administrative duty until an internal police investigation of the March 17 episode is completed.
lead_paragraph: A lieutenant with the New York Police Department who oversaw the arrest of an on-duty mail carrier in Brooklyn has been stripped of his gun and badge and placed on administrative duty.

headline: A Showdown Between Mohaymen and Nyquist Before the Kentucky Derby
abstract: Mohaymen and Nyquist, unbeaten 3-year-olds, will not wait until the Derby to square off. They’ll race against each other on Saturday in Florida.
lead_paragraph: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — The showdown is billed as East vs. West, harking back to a golden era of horse racing when War Admiral and Seabiscuit ruled opposite coasts and fans clamored for a meeting to settle the score once and for all.

headline: Yankees Pick C.C. Sabathia for 5th Rotation Slot
abstract: Sabathia edged out Ivan Nova for the final starting spot on the roster, but the decision may not be final.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Sixteen coaches, scouts and executives convened late Thursday afternoon as the Yankees prepared to break camp in Tampa, Fla., and board a flight to Miami for their final two exhibition games. For an hour, they debated, dissected and discussed the merits of the two candidates for the final spot in their starting rotation.

headline: North Carolina Law May Risk Federal Aid
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Discrimination', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Billions of dollars for schools, highways and housing could be at risk as the Obama administration reviews the state’s new “bathroom law.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is considering whether North Carolina’s new law on gay and transgender rights makes the state ineligible for billions of dollars in federal aid for schools, highways and housing, officials said Friday.

headline: New York’s Path to $15 Minimum Wage: Uneven, and Bumpy
abstract: By the end of this year, there will be six different hourly minimum wages in the state, as increases take effect.
lead_paragraph: With the budget agreement worked out in Albany this week, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo can say he has steered New York onto the road to a statewide minimum wage of $15 an hour. But the trip will be uneven, probably quite bumpy in spots, and its duration remains uncertain.

headline: Mike Hopkins, Boeheim’s Successor, Is Learning to Ride Waves as Head Coach
abstract: Hopkins, the designated successor to Coach Jim Boeheim, was blindsided by the five games Syracuse lost on his watch while Boeheim served a nine-game suspension.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Mike Hopkins, the longtime Syracuse assistant and the designated successor to Coach Jim Boeheim, went bodysurfing with his family late last summer in the waters off the Southern California coast. Bodysurfing is generally benign, but even experienced watermen like Hopkins can be surprised once in a while. When a wave caught him unprepared, his board slipped and smacked him in the face.

headline: Eric Engberg, CBS Newsman, Dies at 74; Pioneered Political Fact-Checking
abstract: “Reality Check,” Mr. Engberg’s segment on the “CBS Evening News,” was a precursor to websites like Politifact.com and Factcheck.org.
lead_paragraph: Eric Engberg, a former CBS News correspondent who hosted the “CBS Evening News” segment “Reality Check,” which was aimed at keeping politicians honest, died last Sunday at his home in Palmetto, Fla. He was 74.

headline: Islanders Play for Home Ice, Be It Ever So Slushy
abstract: Despite complaints about the conditions of the playing surface at Barclays Center, the Islanders are pursuing home-ice advantage in the first round of the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: EAST MEADOW, N.Y. — The Islanders gathered Friday for their annual team photo at their new practice center, which is close to Nassau Coliseum, their former rink. They were all smiles, though their mood was surely tempered by the knowledge that they would be without their top defenseman, Travis Hamonic, who was injured during Thursday’s win over Columbus. The Islanders are also concerned about a key element where they now play — namely, poor ice conditions at Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

headline: Second Member of Amateur Crew Dies During Round-the-World Race
abstract: The death of a British businesswoman raises questions about the safety of a race that uses mostly amateur sailors.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The amateur sailors aboard the yacht IchorCoal had already had to deal with death and mourning in September, when their crew mate Andrew Ashman was killed in an onboard accident near the Portuguese coast shortly after the start of the Clipper Round the World Race.

headline: Man Dies After Construction Site Fall in Brooklyn
abstract: Alex Santizo of Queens was struck by debris and fell in a shaft, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A construction worker died after he was struck by debris and fell in a shaft at a site in Brooklyn on Friday, the police said.

headline: Angela Merkel’s Unpopular Goodness
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Politics and Government']
abstract: Germany faces a new reality, with terror elsewhere in Europe and the refugee crisis at its doors.
lead_paragraph: Berlin — WHEN I returned to Berlin recently after a few months away, a friend asked me to try a new Chinese restaurant in Kreuzberg, a hip multiethnic neighborhood in the city. “It’s close to the subway station Kottbusser Tor,” he texted. “But take a cab, otherwise it’s too dangerous.”

headline: In Miami, Facing Risk of Zika With Resolve but Limited Resources
abstract: Stopping the virus’s spread, health experts say, requires vigorous control of the mosquitoes that carry it. But the quality of services varies wildly.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — One recent sunny morning, Chalmers Vasquez, Miami-Dade County’s mosquito control manager, peered into a rain-filled Miller High Life bottle in a weedy backyard.

headline: Why Should ‘Never Trump’ Mean Ted Cruz?
abstract: Panicky, self-interested Republicans seek shortcuts on the route to thwarting Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: With more than half of the 2016 presidential primary races in the history books, Republicans desperate to deny Donald Trump their party’s nomination now say Wisconsin, where Ted Cruz is leading, will show that their effort has turned the tide. They shouldn’t start bragging yet.

headline: Donald Trump Steps Awkwardly Into Abortion Debate for Second Time This Week
abstract: Mr. Trump said that current laws on abortion should remain intact. Then his spokeswoman said he meant that the laws should remain intact only until he seeks to change them as president.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said on Friday that current laws on abortion should remain intact, but also agreed with those who see abortion as “murder” in an interview taped for CBS’s “Face the Nation.”

headline: Crib Note
abstract: Brad Wilber and Doug Peterson offer us a Saturday challenge.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — It’s a RED LETTER day when we get a Brad Wilber/Doug Peterson puzzle. They are consistently well-filled, well-clued and really good at tripping me up.

headline: Trump, Truth and Abortion
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: You can learn things from a candidate who has no idea what he’s talking about.
lead_paragraph: Maybe Donald Trump did everyone a favor with his famous jail-the-women comment. When he blurted out that “there has to be some form of punishment” for anyone who has an abortion, he blew the cover off the carefully constructed public face of the anti-choice movement.

headline: With Skid Over, Mets Decide on Roster for Opener
abstract: Breaking a 14-game winless streak on Friday, the Mets also set their opening day roster, which included a few surprising names like Logan Verrett.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — When the Mets’ pitchers, including perhaps the best rotation in baseball, convened for their first meeting this spring, Manager Terry Collins singled out Logan Verrett for providing maybe the best start of 2015. Collins’s point? Even if the rotation is set, the Mets need contributions from everyone.

headline: Why Texas Is Deep in My Heart
abstract: The lone star state has a P.R. problem these days. But it’s still my home.
lead_paragraph: Houston — MARCH was not a good month for a certain kind of Texas loyalist. There was the State Board of Education candidate, Mary Lou Bruner of Mineola, who insisted that President Obama had been a male prostitute in his youth.

headline: A Nuclear Job Half Done
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: Even with considerable progress, President Obama has not fulfilled his goal of securing all nuclear materials in four years.
lead_paragraph: As he ended the Nuclear Security Summit on Friday, President Obama could claim some success in leading the international community to curb the amount of nuclear materials that could fall into terrorists’ hands.

headline: Budget Deadline Keeps New York Legislators Up All Night
abstract: Even in a capital accustomed to marathon sessions, the overnight legislating that led to the passage of a budget on Friday left lawmakers grumbling.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — There was an impromptu round of salsa dancing on the Assembly floor, a spirited exchange of hostilities in the Senate and an untold number of last-minute trips to the Dunkin’ Donuts — the nearest purveyor of decent caffeine — on the first floor of the State Capitol.

headline: Hamas Releases Photographs Said to Show Captured Israelis
abstract: The militant group also made public images of two Israeli soldiers killed in 2014.
lead_paragraph: JAFFA, Israel — The armed wing of the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas showed photographs on Friday of four Israelis, two of whom it said were captives being held in Gaza. Two others were Israeli soldiers who were killed during the 2014 conflict in Gaza, Hadar Goldin and Oron Shaul.

headline: Time for South Africa’s Jacob Zuma to Step Down
abstract: The party of Nelson Mandela is allowing its moral authority to be eroded by its scandal-plagued leader.
lead_paragraph: Cronyism, corruption and scandal have swirled around Jacob Zuma since before he became president of South Africa in May 2009, and the muck has only deepened since. On Thursday the country’s highest court ruled that he had violated the Constitution by refusing to pay back millions that the government spent improving his home.

headline: Abortion and Punishment
abstract: Donald Trump stumbles onto the true logic of the case against legal abortion: Murder has consequences.
lead_paragraph: DONALD J. TRUMP gave his primary opponents a gift when he said this week that if abortion is outlawed, “there has to be some form of punishment” for the woman. He let them look as if they cared about women.

headline: Judge Cancels Pretrial Hearing at Guantánamo in Sept. 11 Case
abstract: A Pentagon spokesman said that the judge had received a filing that affected the case against Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other detainees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A military judge on Friday abruptly canceled a two-week pretrial hearing scheduled to open on Monday at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, in the case against Khalid Shaikh Mohammed and four other detainees accused of aiding the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Tests on Knife Rule Out Link to O.J. Simpson Case, Police Say
abstract: The knife, reportedly found at a home that once belonged to Mr. Simpson, has no connection to the 1994 killings of Mr. Simpson’s ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald L. Goldman.
lead_paragraph: A knife reportedly found at a home that once belonged to O. J. Simpson is not connected to the 1994 killings of Mr. Simpson’s ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ronald L. Goldman, the Los Angeles Police Department said on Friday.

headline: Frank De Felitta, ‘Audrey Rose’ Horror Novelist and Documentarian, Dies at 94
abstract: His tale of reincarnation sold 3.5 million copies. His documentary for NBC about the Deep South had tragic consequences.
lead_paragraph: Frank De Felitta, who wrote “Audrey Rose,” a best-selling horror novel about reincarnation, because, he said, he suspected that his own son might be channeling a dead pianist, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 94.

headline: Despite Protests on State Testing, Some New York City Parents Are Happy to Opt In
abstract: The principal of Public School 124 Yung Wing, in Manhattan’s Chinatown, said that none of its students were opting out of the state’s reading and math tests this year.
lead_paragraph: With the New York State math and reading tests set to begin next week, the opt-out movement has made noise from the State Education Department to City Hall, with opponents of the tests pushing for even more students to sit them out this year.

headline: Harold Morowitz, 88, Biophysicist, Dies; Tackled Enigmas Big and Small
abstract: Trained in philosophy and physics, no topic was too trivial for Professor Morowitz to tease profound meaning from, including the thermodynamics of pizza.
lead_paragraph: Harold J. Morowitz, a boundlessly curious biophysicist who tackled mind-boggling enigmas ranging from the origin of life to the thermodynamics of pizza, died on March 22 in Falls Church, Va. He was 88.

headline: On the Trail: The Week of March 27
abstract: Candidates campaigned across New York, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin this week.
lead_paragraph: Candidates campaigned across New York, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin this week.

headline: City Began Inquiry Into Sale of Nursing Home to Developer Before Mayor de Blasio Knew of Deal
abstract: The sale, which will allow condos to be built on the site, was the subject of reviews by the Department of Investigation and the comptroller’s office.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio has said he knew nothing about how his administration had allowed a Lower East Side nursing home, once protected from development by a restrictive deed, to be sold to make way for luxury condominiums.

headline: With Little Up for Grabs, Knicks Defeat Nets
abstract: The Knicks won at the Garden in a game between two teams going nowhere.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks jogged onto the court at Madison Square Garden on Friday night to the song “Trophies” by Drake that is often used by teams to inspire their chase to attain significant goals.

headline: Anti-Vaccine Film, Pulled From Tribeca Film Festival, Draws Crowd at Showing
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Autism', 'Movies', 'Tribeca Film Festival (NYC)', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: “Vaxxed: From Cover-Up to Catastrophe,” about the roundly dismissed connection between autism and vaccines, was shown at the Angelika Film Center on Friday.
lead_paragraph: A roiling controversy over the truthfulness and intent of a documentary about the widely debunked link between vaccines and autism did not keep theatergoers away from its premiere on Friday. Several dozen people (and more than a handful of reporters) arrived for the first showing of “Vaxxed: From Cover-Up to Catastrophe” at the Angelika Film Center in Manhattan, along with a producer and co-writer of the film, and some of its distributors.

headline: Man’s Confession in Transgender Woman’s Death Is Admissible, Judge Rules
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Confessions']
abstract: In a taped confession played in court on Friday, James Dixon said, “I just remember lashing out” in August 2013 before he punched Islan Nettles, resulting in what proved to be fatal head injuries.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man charged with manslaughter in the beating death of a transgender woman in Harlem told prosecutors and detectives he had been flirting with her just moments before the attack, unaware that she was transgender.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” lands on iTunes. “Trainwreck” makes its way to cable. And Peter Dinklage hosts “S.N.L.”
lead_paragraph: For those in another universe who still haven’t caught the latest “Star Wars” installment, iTunes provides it for less than the price of a movie ticket. “Trainwreck,” the Amy Schumer vehicle, makes its way to cable. And Peter Dinklage — Tyrion Lannister to “Game of Thrones” fans — hosts “Saturday Night Live.”

headline: Corrections: April 2, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, April 2, 2016.
lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 2, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “This is close to a Goldilocks scenario.”

headline: ‘Every Woman Who’s Ever Been Labeled Crazy’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers debate Donald Trump’s views, wage discrimination in soccer, unlocking iPhones and more.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: And the Awards for Best Audio Fiction Go to …
abstract: Sarah Lawrence College on Friday hosted the inaugural Sarah Awards, billed as the first award ceremony for audio fiction, and handed out four prizes.
lead_paragraph: First came the Oscars, then the Tonys. Now, get ready for the Sarahs.

headline: High Times Wants to Be the Playboy of Pot
abstract: The Yippie-era magazine devoted to marijuana culture seeks to go mainstream, with branded socks, furniture and, eventually, bars and casinos.
lead_paragraph: Picture a mood-lit Las Vegas casino, at first glance indistinguishable from any other pleasure palace on the Strip: salarymen hunch over $20 blackjack tables as waitresses with plunging necklines circle the floor.

headline: The Story of Their Life
abstract: Gloria Vanderbilt and Anderson Cooper chart their family landscape in a new documentary and a memoir.
lead_paragraph: Gloria Vanderbilt and Anderson Cooper chart their family landscape in a new documentary and a memoir.

headline: At Home With Gloria Vanderbilt
abstract: Ms. Vanderbilt covers the familiar terrain of her colorful life in a new documentary and a memoir with her son Anderson Cooper.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes Anderson Cooper imagines himself as the Thomas Cromwell to his mother’s Henry VIII, the voice of reason — the tether — to her buoyant impulsiveness. And sometimes he pictures Gloria Vanderbilt, who has been in the public eye since her birth 92 years ago, as an emissary from a distant star, marooned on this planet and trying to make sense of it all.

headline: Third Man Is Charged in Belgium Over Foiled Plot in France
abstract: The 33-year-old Belgian was charged with participation in the activities of a terrorist group, the federal prosecutor’s office said Saturday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A third man has been charged in Belgium in connection with a foiled plot to stage a major terrorist attack in France, officials said Saturday.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2016: The Fun Begins
abstract: Join us throughout the weekend for coverage of the 39th annual American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — Deep inside the Ballroom at the Stamford, Connecticut Marriott Hotel, puzzle creator Eric Berlin paces the floor, going over the myriad last-minute details in his head. One forgotten clue, one slip-up in planning and the whole exercise — a multi-puzzle, interactive escape room where solvers have to join forces to put the clues together in order to be released — falls apart. Fortunately for the hundreds of people who willingly locked themselves into a hotel ballroom just to solve puzzles, everything went off without a hitch.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from an island inhabited by pigs in the Bahamas to a chess tournament in Moscow.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from an island inhabited by pigs in the Bahamas to a chess tournament in Moscow.

headline: American Anger: It’s Not the Economy. It’s the Other Party.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'ANGER (EMOTION)', 'Happiness', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Research shows that Americans are deeply split because of a partisanship that is increasingly based on racial attitudes.
lead_paragraph: Americans are angry. That’s the sentiment that many believe is driving the 2016 election. They are angry because the rich are getting richer, the average guy is struggling and the government in Washington hasn’t done anything to stop the trend.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss your experience with the “A Little Variety” puzzles.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Rift Among Navy SEALs Over Members Who Cash In on Brand
abstract: The SEALs face a widening split over what many in the ranks describe as personal exploitation of a brotherhood that once prized discretion.
lead_paragraph: Eric Greitens’s bid for governor of Missouri hinges on his experience as a Navy SEALs member, which he has chronicled in three books and promotes on his campaign web site, where he is pictured wearing his combat uniform, holding a rifle. “In the SEALs we learned, ‘there is no prize for second place in a gunfight,’ ” he said recently on Twitter.

headline: Mike and John on Annotation Terror and Annoying Video Alerts
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Some discussion of an app that can post criticism of one’s work and of Facebook’s new live video push and how users are pushing back.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mr. Manjoo is off this week, so John Herrman, a David Carr fellow, is filling in.

headline: When Your Dog Meets the Co-op Board
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Dogs', 'Cooperatives', 'Heating', 'Noise', 'Carpets and Rugs']
abstract: A pet’s behavior on display; an apartment that gets noisy; and utilities not covered by rent.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Fighting Between Azerbaijan and Armenia Flares Up in Nagorno-Karabakh
abstract: The heaviest fighting in years broke out in the Armenian separatist enclave, involving tanks, artillery and aircraft.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Heavy fighting broke out Saturday in Nagorno-Karabakh, an Armenian separatist enclave in Azerbaijan and a longtime ethnic tinderbox in the South Caucasus region.

headline: Bill Green, Who Dissected Washington Post Scandal, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Green wrote an unflinching 18,000-word indictment of the process that allowed a fabricated 1980 article by Janet Cooke to win, then lose, a Pulitzer Prize.
lead_paragraph: Bill Green, who as the ombudsman for The Washington Post in 1981 delivered a blistering verdict on journalistic lapses in response to a Post article about an 8-year-old heroin addict that was debunked the day after it won a Pulitzer Prize, died on Monday in Durham, N.C. He was 91.

headline: Obama Gets Scant Credit in Indiana Region Where Recovery Was Robust
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Few people are thanking the president for low unemployment. Instead, many discouraged workers are attracted to Donald J. Trump’s economic message.
lead_paragraph: ELKHART, Ind. — Seven years ago President Obama came to this northern Indiana city, where unemployment was heading past 20 percent, for his first trip as president. Ed Neufeldt, the jobless man picked to introduce him, afterward donned three green rubber bracelets, each to be removed in turn as joblessness fell to 5 percent in the county, the state and the nation.

headline: Big Love for Little Monkeys That Help People With Limited Mobility
abstract: Alison Payne directs training for Helping Hands, a nonprofit that trains capuchin monkeys to assist with tasks like turning pages and flipping light switches.
lead_paragraph: Q. What does Helping Hands do, and what does your job involve?

headline: Variety: A Playful Acrostic
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon highlight an author who likes to get playful.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Put another book on the pile for me. “WORD WATCHING,” by British comedian ALEX HORNE, looks like a fabulously funny exploration of wordplay and it’s no secret that I use the acrostic to decide which books to read more often than I use the Book Review.

headline: Trump Does It His Way
abstract: Donald Trump has an all-new sensation: He admits he was wrong.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — YOU could hear how hard it was for Donald Trump to say the words.

headline: Guatemalan Women’s Claims Put Focus on Canadian Firms’ Conduct Abroad
keywords: ['Mines and Mining', 'Sex Crimes', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Overseas subsidiaries have long acted as a shield for extractive companies, but cases describing negligence and rape could lead to new scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: LOTE OCHO, Guatemala — Her husband was away in the fields, she said, when the truckloads of soldiers, police officers and mining security officials arrived. A half-dozen armed men swarmed into her one-room house, blocking her exit and helping themselves to the meal she had made for her children.

headline: Electoral Map Is a Reality Check to Donald Trump’s Bid
abstract: As Donald J. Trump moves closer to the Republican nomination, his unpopularity with large groups of voters suggests a potentially staggering loss in a general election.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s presidential candidacy has stunned the Republican Party. But if he survives a late revolt by his rivals and other leaders to become the party’s standard-bearer in the general election, the electoral map now coming into view is positively forbidding.

headline: After WikiLeaks Revelation, Greece Asks I.M.F. to Clarify Bailout Plan
abstract: A leaked conversation between two I.M.F. officials exposed a widening rift between Greece and its European creditors that could jeopardize the nation’s bailout.
lead_paragraph: Greece called on the International Monetary Fund on Saturday to explain whether it was seeking to usher Athens toward bankruptcy ahead of a pivotal referendum in June on Britain’s membership in Europe. Greece’s comments came after I.M.F. officials raised questions in a private discussion published by WikiLeaks about what it would take to get Greece’s creditors to agree to debt relief.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2016: Ready? GO
abstract: Why the “whoosh” of nearly 600 pages turning over is so thrilling.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — There’s a special part of the American Crossword Tournament that I find particularly thrilling, and I want to share it with you. It’s not necessarily the Championship rounds, although those are definitely exciting. The entertainment is great. But that’s not what thrills me.

headline: Even in a Warming World, It Will Still Snow Somewhere
abstract: If global warming is real, how can it be so cold in my backyard? Hint: That’s weather, not climate.
lead_paragraph: Actually: Anyone who utters an argument like this is mixing up climate and weather.

headline: Why Slaves’ Graves Matter
abstract: Those who lived through slavery were human beings, not abstractions.
lead_paragraph: I GREW up in a small rural town in West Tennessee. My family is rooted in that region, where my ancestors were once enslaved. In the 1970s, when I was a teenager, we regularly attended an old country church that was located in the curve of a gravel road and surrounded by undeveloped Southern land. The church had rustic wooden floors, handmade pews and a piano that was often missing an accompanist. The congregation didn’t mind though; they made their own music, tapping the pews and the floor as they sang.

headline: Philadelphia Is in the Final Four ... and in the Cellar
abstract: Villanova and the N.B.A.’s Sixers represent the highs and lows of basketball in a city known for it.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — It is the best of times, it is the worst of times. It is the spring of hope, it is the winter of despair. They may have the best basketball team in the country, and they definitely have the worst basketball team in the country.

headline: Claims of a Ponzi Scheme in the Collapse of a Rare-Wine Seller
keywords: ['Wines', 'Ponzi and Pyramid Schemes', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The F.B.I. is investigating complaints that Premier Cru, a Bay Area store favored by the rich, bilked collectors of expensive wines out of millions.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, the Premier Cru wine store in Berkeley, Calif., looked like a traditional, upscale wine seller. The 29,000-square-foot store was lined with tapestries, wood shelves and a “rare wine room” stocked with trophy Bordeaux and Burgundies.

headline: A Spring of Discontent for Canadian Hockey
abstract: With all seven Canada-based teams in the N.H.L. eliminated from playoff contention, fans in places like Montreal or Vancouver will soon head for the golf course.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Canada, where hockey passion is so intense that weddings on rinks are a thing, will not have a single team in the N.H.L.’s Stanley Cup playoffs. It’s as if Argentina were shut out of the world’s premier tango competition, or France had no representation in the Michelin Guide.

headline: As Warriors Near a Record, the Bulls Offer a Model for a Dynasty
abstract: Golden State may want to look to the years immediately before Chicago’s finest season for a blueprint of how to turn its domination of the N.B.A. into a full-fledged dynasty.
lead_paragraph: With the Golden State Warriors sitting four wins shy of tying the N.B.A. regular-season record — with six games to play — the comparisons to the 1995-96 Chicago Bulls will continue to crescendo. And while the Warriors could certainly look to that team for inspiration in how to remain dominant once the playoffs roll around, the executives who make Golden State’s personnel decisions may want to look to the years immediately before Chicago’s finest season for a blueprint of how to turn their domination of the N.B.A. into a full-fledged dynasty.

headline: Coca Crystal, Avatar of Counterculture and Provocateur, Dies at 68
abstract: With an anarchist past that included a well-aimed apple pie and lab rats at a luncheon, Ms. Crystal hosted the public-access channel variety show “If I Can’t Dance, You Can Keep Your Revolution.”
lead_paragraph: In April 1977, the conservative activist Phyllis Schlafly was about to be honored by the Women’s National Republican Club at the Waldorf Astoria hotel in Manhattan when she was hit by a well-aimed apple pie.

headline: Gender Divide in Tournaments Shortchanges Fans and the Sport
abstract: If golf, as in tennis or the Olympics, held more mixed-gender events, “it would be great for the game,” Rory McIlroy said.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — Lexi Thompson and Jordan Spieth represented the United States as teenagers in a mixed four-ball match at the 2008 Junior Ryder Cup. As Spieth remembered it, Thompson carried the pair. He described her as “almost unbeatable.” Eight years later, Thompson and Spieth are carrying American golf as the highest-ranked American players in the world.

headline: When Whites Just Don’t Get It, Part 6
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Education (K-12)', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Research', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Income Inequality', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Education', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Racial disparities persist, and they aren’t only in police shootings.
lead_paragraph: LET’S start with a quiz. When researchers sent young whites and blacks out to interview for low-wage jobs in New York City armed with equivalent résumés, the result was:

headline: Faith and Doubt
abstract: Readers discuss whether one can express certainty about the existence of God.
lead_paragraph: Should we avoid claiming with certainty whether or not God exists?

headline: Jobs and Trade on the Campaign Trail
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Candidates are calling attention to workers who have been hurt by globalization, but some of the policies being offered are unrealistic.
lead_paragraph: The campaigns of Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders have tapped into a deep well of anger and anxiety about international trade. While their ideas for changing American trade policy are unrealistic — and, in Mr. Trump’s case, nonsensical — their campaigns are doing something important by calling attention to the government’s failure to help workers who have been hurt by globalization.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: A Trans-Atlantic Role Reversal
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Politics and Government', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: In matters of war and peace, Europeans move toward Mars, Americans flirt with Venus.
lead_paragraph: AMERICANS are from Mars and Europeans are from Venus.” With one pithy line 14 years ago, the foreign policy theorist Robert Kagan captured what seemed like obvious differences between the United States and Europe in the post-Cold War, post-9/11 age.

headline: Why Trump Can’t Break the G.O.P.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans have turned presidential defeat into political power in Congress and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: Everywhere you look, in the year of Donald J. Trump, observers are talking about a national party realignment or a Republican death spiral. Our two-party system has not undergone a major realignment since the South became solidly Republican. There has not been a major-party demise since the Whigs collapsed on the eve of the Civil War.

headline: How a Great City Could Survive Even Rob Ford
abstract: The flamboyant mayor may have embarrassed some with his antics, but he was proof of how a city can thrive.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Rob Ford’s time as mayor of Toronto became a reality show that lurched from one cringe-inducing revelation to another, one question loomed: How did he come to lead Canada’s largest city? His rumpled suits, fondness for profanity, racist and homophobic remarks, public drunkenness, admitted drug use and general boorishness made Mr. Ford seem like an outlier in a city that had carefully cultivated a reputation for multiculturalism, tolerance and sophistication.

headline: Race and the Death Penalty in Texas
abstract: Duane Buck was sentenced to die at least in part because he is black. He has one more chance at the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: This month, the Supreme Court will consider whether to hear the appeal of Duane Buck, a black man from Texas who was sentenced to die for the 1995 murder of his ex-girlfriend and a man who was with her. There is no dispute about his guilt; the issue is how he ended up on death row.

headline: Locked Up for Seeking Asylum
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Immigration Detention', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Traumatized people who have been persecuted for helping Americans deserve to be heard.
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY received a phone call from Alabama. It was Samey Honaryar, an Afghan who had worked as an interpreter with the United States military and had fled Taliban persecution hoping to find asylum here. Samey is not accused of committing any crime. Yet for nearly a year, he’s been locked up in Etowah County Detention Center, among the worst and most remote of immigration detention centers, with little access to lawyers or medical attention.

headline: The Republicans’ Gay Freakout
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In North Carolina and elsewhere, the G.O.P. is playing an ugly, shortsighted and losing game.
lead_paragraph: OUR infrastructure is inexcusable, much of our public education is miserable and one of our leading presidential candidates is a know-nothing, say-anything egomaniac who yanks harder every day at the tattered fabric of civil discourse and fundamental decency in this country.

headline: Remembrances of Depression Economics
abstract: Slumping like it’s 1999.
lead_paragraph: A bit more musing inspired by Brad DeLong’s decision to repost his old, rather negative review of my 1999 “The Return of Depression Economics” — which I think he means to imply was a review that got it mostly wrong, while I got it much more right than he realized at the time.

headline: Uncertain Economics Influence ‘Brexit’ Talk
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Proponents of Britain’s exit from the European Union are trying to convince the country that any freedom it gains would not be offset by the risks to prosperity.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain is one of Europe’s strongest economic performers, having emerged from the financial crisis of the last decade faster and less burdened by debt than competitors like France, Italy and Spain. Unemployment is at a 10-year low of 5.1 percent. London, vibrant and second only to New York as a global financial hub, hums a siren song to the young and ambitious across Europe.

headline: Medicare Is Often Overbilled by Hospices, and Pays Twice for Some Drugs
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Hospice Care', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Medicare has been overpaying more than $260 million a year, including bills from hospices for inpatient care that patients did not need, investigators said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hospices often bill Medicare for a higher level of care than patients need, and Medicare often pays twice for the prescription drugs provided to people who are terminally ill, federal investigators say in a new report. The extra cost to Medicare was put at more than $260 million a year.

headline: Are Some Terrorism Deaths More Equal Than Others?
abstract: It sometimes seems that where people are killed plays too big a role in how much news coverage their deaths are given.
lead_paragraph: KELLY VAUGHAN of Brooklyn, a Times reader, lived in Istanbul for a year, and so has followed the media coverage of the violence in Turkey with great interest.

headline: Trombone Shorty
abstract: A musician on the parallels between playing basketball and playing in a band, looking to the clouds for inspiration, and his grandma’s cooking.
lead_paragraph: Troy Andrews, perhaps better known as Trombone Shorty, is a multi-instrumentalist and music producer from New Orleans. In addition to leading his own band, Orleans Avenue, he has played or recorded with a range of performers, including Dierks Bentley, Lenny Kravitz and the Foo Fighters.

headline: Hillary Clinton Appeals to New Yorkers by Going After One: Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Advertising', 'Endorsements', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)']
abstract: In her first ad in New York, Mrs. Clinton embraces the diversity of her adopted state to contrast with a native son running for office.
lead_paragraph: Clinton New York Ad

headline: Less Disinfectant, More Rioja
abstract: A few years in Spain, and my mother’s last days, helped me see the futility of a sterilized life.
lead_paragraph: NOT long ago, I listened to a couple of radio talk-show hosts taking calls about a study showing that, despite airlines’ best sterilization efforts, potentially deadly bacteria thrived on plane surfaces. Tray tables, armrests, window shades, the kangaroo-pouch depths of a seat pocket — the very few things I thought I could safely manipulate inside my designated clutch of personal space — could be the death of me or anyone on the plane.

headline: Golden State’s Quest to Break Bulls’ Record Grows Harder
abstract: After a home loss to the Celtics, the Warriors must win five of their last six games to eclipse the Bulls’ record of 72 wins.
lead_paragraph: The Golden State Warriors absorbed a blow in their pursuit of history when they lost to the Boston Celtics on Friday night at Oracle Arena. The defeat dropped the Warriors’ record to 68-8, which means that they will need to win five of their final six games to eclipse the 1995-96 Chicago Bulls, who went 72-10, for the best regular-season record in N.B.A. history.

headline: Standings After Puzzle 3
abstract: The standings after Puzzle 3 at the 2016 A.C.P.T.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — The standings after Puzzle 3 are up, and besides Dr. Fill, who is ranked first but doesn’t really count because he resides inside Matt Ginsburg’s laptop, we have (say it with me now) Dan Feyer in the human lead with a score of 4400, followed by David Plotkin in third place with 4375, Howard Barkin, Anne Ellison and Tyler Hinman tied for 4th place with scores of 4375 (Mr. Plotkin might have had all perfect puzzles).

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: Concussions, the N.F.L.’s Profits and Priorities

headline: Alaska Airlines Said to Be Near $2 Billion Deal for Virgin America
abstract: Alaska Airlines squared off against JetBlue in a final round of bidding for the popular small airline.
lead_paragraph: Virgin America, founded on the premise of being a cool airline shuttling people from New York to California in style, is near a deal to sell itself to a competitor originally created to ferry people 330 miles across Alaska.

headline: Victoria Azarenka Wins Miami Open, Completing a Rare Feat
abstract: Azarenka struggled with her serve but captured her third title at the event, becoming the third woman to win back-to-back titles at Indian Wells and Key Biscayne.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — Victoria Azarenka captured her third Miami Open title and her first since 2011 with a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Svetlana Kuznetsova on Saturday.

headline: Penguins Pour It On Against Islanders
abstract: With the victory, the Penguins, who clinched a playoff berth, moved 5 points ahead of the Islanders in the Metropolitan Division.
lead_paragraph: There was plenty of palpable playoff race tension Saturday afternoon on top of the heightened atmosphere present whenever the Pittsburgh Penguins and the Islanders meet.

headline: Oklahoma Has a Familiar Look, Now Rarely Seen
abstract: The Sooners played their way into the Final Four by relying on four upperclassmen who started 105 straight games together, unusual in the one-and-done era.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — It’s been hard to miss Buddy Hield.

headline: Donald Trump Says NATO is ‘Obsolete,’ UN is ‘Political Game’
abstract: Trump, whose foreign policy qualifications have recently been under fire, on Saturday reiterated his criticism that NATO countries were “not paying their fair share.”
lead_paragraph: RACINE, Wis. — Donald J. Trump on Saturday went further than ever before in his criticism of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, telling a crowd here that he would be fine if NATO broke up.

headline: UConn’s Seniors Are 2 Wins From a Feat Never Accomplished
abstract: Connecticut’s seniors are bidding to become the only women’s or men’s class in Division I history to win four consecutive N.C.A.A. titles.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Put aside for the moment the women’s sports revolution and its ever-accompanying and sometimes distressing social commentary. On Saturday at the women’s Final Four, the day before the national semifinals, it was time to reflect on the 80 basketball minutes impeding Connecticut’s bid for an unprecedented fourth consecutive national championship.

headline: E.U. Suspects Russian Agenda in Migrants’ Shifting Arctic Route
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: The flow of refugees and migrants on the Arctic route through Russia is tiny, compared with other routes. But it has added anxiety, not to mention intrigue, to a crisis that is tearing the European Union apart.
lead_paragraph: KANDALAKSHA, Russia — So many decrepit Soviet-era cars carried migrants into Europe from this frozen Russian town in recent months that border officials in Finland, who confiscate the rust-bucket vehicles as soon as they cross the frontier, watched in dismay as their parking lot turned into a scrapyard.

headline: Standings After the Infamous Puzzle 5
abstract: Joon Pahk rises to third place after Patrick Berry’s Puzzle 5.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — After the nefarious Puzzle 5 by Patrick Berry, “Jeopardy!” champion Joon Pahk has risen to third place in the 2016 A.C.P.T. rankings.

headline: Jumping to Conclusions
abstract: No, you’re not insane. But this puzzle by Natan Last is, in a good way.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Hi there. No, you’re not insane. I’ll explain what just happened to you, but first, take the time to read the title of the puzzle.

headline: Crime Spike in St. Louis Traced to Cheap Heroin and Mexican Cartels
keywords: ['Heroin', 'Gangs', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Drug Cartels', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: In recent years, Mexican drug traffickers have inundated the St. Louis area with a new, potent form of heroin, drastically reducing prices to lure suburban users.
lead_paragraph: ST. LOUIS — Clara Walker, a mother of nine and grandmother of eight, was peering out the window of her home three years ago after hearing what she initially thought were gunshots from a television crime show.

headline: ‘They Cannot Remove Me by Force’: A Strongman on Afghan Infighting
abstract: In a rare interview, Atta Muhammad Noor, the most powerful Tajik politician in northern Afghanistan, discussed his take on factional tensions.
lead_paragraph: MAZAR-I-SHARIF, Afghanistan — One of the most powerful players in Afghanistan, Atta Muhammad Noor, says he would be willing to step down from his post as a northern provincial governor — as soon as the central government reappoints him to the spot.

headline: Nyquist Wins in Florida, Establishing Himself as the Favorite in Kentucky
abstract: Nyquist pushed his record to 7-0, running past the previously undefeated Mohaymen to romp to a victory in the $1 million Florida Derby.
lead_paragraph: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — The race was billed as East versus West, an unprecedented clash between undefeated Triple Crown heavyweights from opposite coasts, but it did not quite live up to the hype. It did, however, produce an undisputed favorite heading into the Kentucky Derby on May 7.

headline: 2 Republican Senators Revoke Support for Garland Hearings
abstract: As a wall of opposition grows, only two Republican senators now call for hearings on the nomination of Judge Merrick B. Garland to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The wall of Republican opposition to the nomination of Judge Merrick B. Garland to the Supreme Court has been shored up by two Republican senators revoking their support for holding confirmation hearings.

headline: Villanova Wipes Out Oklahoma and a Record to Reach the Title Game
abstract: The Wildcats shot 71 percent from the field, securing the most lopsided win in Final Four history and advancing to their first N.C.A.A. tournament final since 1985.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — In a 95-51 demolition of Oklahoma on Saturday night, Villanova not only punched its ticket to the national title game but also set a standard for Final Four blowouts. Through 78 Final Fours — dating to the first, in 1939, which also featured the Wildcats and the Sooners — 44 points is the largest margin of victory.

headline: Jesse Webster, an Inmate Serving Life, Turned to His Last Hope: President Obama
keywords: ['Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Mandatory Sentencing']
abstract: A model prisoner for years, Mr. Webster knew he wasn’t in trouble when he heard his name over the prison intercom. But was it the call he’d been waiting for?
lead_paragraph: Wednesday was another in an endless blur of Wednesdays at the Greenville federal prison in Southern Illinois. An inmate named Jesse Webster, serving a life sentence without parole for a nonviolent first offense, was poised to take a typing test, his fingers hovering over the keyboard — when his name resounded over the intercom.

headline: Delegate Fight Casts North Dakota in New Campaign Role: Relevance
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: The sudden importance of North Dakota, where Republicans will select delegates on Sunday, is a sign that the G.O.P. could be headed to its first contested national convention in 40 years.
lead_paragraph: FARGO, N.D. — North Dakota is not accustomed to being one of the way stations on the path to the White House. Given its meager number of delegates and its tiny, remote media markets, it is rare for a presidential campaign to give this state the time of day.

headline: North Carolina Tops Syracuse in Battle of Teams With Stature and Stigma
abstract: The Tar Heels wore down the 10th-seeded Orange to earn their fifth straight win by least 14 points and earn a chance to play for their sixth national title.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Renegades, that’s what they were, banding together in opposition and commiseration Saturday night, like enemies slowly realizing that their differences were outweighed by what they had in common.

headline: Suspicious Truck Prompts Evacuation in Times Square
abstract: The unattended rental truck had wires protruding from its dashboard and gas canisters behind its seats, the police said.
lead_paragraph: An unattended rental truck with wires protruding from its dashboard and gas canisters behind its seats touched off a brief evacuation in a part of Times Square on Saturday night, the police said.

headline: Mikhail Lesin’s Strange Death in U.S. Follows a Fall From Russia’s Elite
abstract: Mikhail Y. Lesin, once a player in the Kremlin’s media apparatus, was found dead from “blunt force injuries” in Washington, fueling speculation of murder.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As happens sometimes with wealthy Russians, Mikhail Y. Lesin found his business and political fortunes in Vladimir Putin’s Russia crumbling. Once an influential player in Mr. Putin’s rise to power, he was abruptly dismissed from his position in the Kremlin’s powerful media apparatus. Perhaps sensing that things could get worse, he seemed to be preparing for a new life in America.

headline: Poised to Celebrate, Rangers Fall to Lowly Sabres
abstract: With a chance to clinch a playoff berth, the Rangers lost their second straight game to a team out of the hunt for the Stanley Cup.
lead_paragraph: Midway through what could have been a happy night for the Rangers, goaltender Henrik Lundqvist, with a gray cap low on his head and a towel around his neck, hunched in the far corner of his team’s bench, glumly staring at the floor. His ice time had amounted to less than 21 minutes.

headline: Gato Barbieri, Latin Jazz Trailblazer With a Saxophone, Is Dead at 83
abstract: Mr. Barbieri, whose career began in Argentina in the 1940s, recorded dozens of albums and received a Latin Grammy lifetime award in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Gato Barbieri, a saxophonist whose highly emotional playing helped expand the audience for Latin jazz, and whose music for the film “Last Tango in Paris” won a Grammy Award, died on Saturday in New York. He was 83.

headline: Fiancée of Sean Bell, Killed in 2006 Police Shooting, Endorses Hillary Clinton
abstract: Nicole Bell, whose fiancé was killed when the police fired 50 times into his car in 2006, is endorsing Hillary Clinton as she and Senator Bernie Sanders vie for the support of black voters before New York’s April 19 primary.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Bell, whose fiancé, Sean Bell, became a symbol of tensions between black communities and the police after he was shot and killed by New York officers on the morning of their wedding day, has endorsed Hillary Clinton two weeks before the New York primary.

headline: Our Man in Gadgetland
abstract: Gregory Schmidt doesn’t need a wristband to tell him how he slept. But a running sock that monitors foot landing and cadence? Sure!
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares insights into how we work at The New York Times. In this piece, Gregory Schmidt, who writes for The Times’s Gadgetwise column, explains which products excite him and which he relegates to the trash heap.

headline: Prianca Naik, Meelan Patel

lead_paragraph: Dr. Prianca Ashok Naik and Dr. Meelan Nick Patel were married April 2 at Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J. Pandit Prabhakar Sharma, a Hindu priest, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Samantha Douglas Baer, a daughter of Carla M. Baer and William L. Baer of Merritt Island, Fla., was married there on April 2 to Peter Charles Dumoulin, a son of Shelley E. Dumoulin and Charles L. Dumoulin of Cincinnati. The bride’s maternal grandfather, Arthur D. Moore of St. Augustine, Fla., a notary public, officiated at the home of Skippy Lober, a neighbor of the bride’s parents.

Geiger and Ronald L. Geiger of East Brunswick, N.J. Pastor Glenroy Clarke, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Round Hill Hotel and Villas in Montego Bay, Jamaica, with David Karraker, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, taking part.

lead_paragraph: Jaime Leigh Blanc and Derek Phillip Feinman were married April 2 at Pier Sixty at Chelsea Piers in New York. Rabbi Dennis Math officiated.

Meyer of Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. Sally H. Hubbell, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul’s Church in Healdsburg, Calif.

lead_paragraph: Sydney Elizabeth McCutcheon, the daughter of Heather L. McCutcheon and the stepdaughter of Daniel P. Hitchcock of Montclair, N.J., was married April 2 to Timothy William Hirsch, the son of Deborah Walsh Hirsch and Peter B. Hirsch, also of Montclair. The Rev. Brenda G. Husson performed the ceremony at St. James’ Episcopal Church in New York, where she is the rector.

abstract: The bride, a publicist for ABC, and groom, who works for E! News, met backstage on the set the ABC show.
lead_paragraph: Makena Kate Coscarelli and William Eugene Marfuggi III were married April 2 at the Fig House, an event space in Los Angeles. P. J. Byrne, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

abstract: A courtroom adversary helped a lawyer find his wife.
lead_paragraph: Sabrina Denise Ashjian and Sean Michael Brunton were married April 2 at the Four Seasons Hotel Los Angeles at Beverly Hills. Armand Arabian, a retired justice for the Supreme Court of California, officiated.

lead_paragraph: Allison Beth Magier, the daughter of Dr. Carol P. Magier and Dr. David P. Magier of Roslyn, N.Y., was married April 2 to Travis Daniel Stier, a son of Shirley A. Stier and Lesley H. Stier of Old Westbury, N.Y. Rabbi Susan Mitrani Knapp officiated at Fresh Meadow Country Club in Lake Success, N.Y.

Dr. Andrew Engel, who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated; Hannah Smotrich, a cousin of the groom, assisted in a ceremony with Jewish influences by reading the wedding contract.

Brian Considine, a friend of the groom who became a minister of American Marriage Ministries for the event, officiated.

headline: Ebony Allen, Etienne Toussaint
abstract: The couple met through a mutual friend in Washington in October 2012.
lead_paragraph: Ebony Allen, a daughter of Lisa M. Allen of Charlotte, N.C., and Ronald V. Sumpter Sr. of Ridgeland, S.C., is to be married April 3 to Etienne Clement Toussaint, a son of Bernadette F. Myler of the Bronx, and the late Raymond Toussaint, who lived in Valley Stream, N.Y. The Rev. Alfred A. Owens, Jr., a Pentecostal minister, is to officiate at the Pawleys Plantation Golf and Country Club on Pawleys Island, S.C.

abstract: The bride and groom met at in law school at N.Y.U.
lead_paragraph: Eva Pascale Smith Bibi and Oliver James Board were married April 2 at a private beach residence belonging to Jason Harel, a friend of the bride and her father, in Poste Lafayette, Mauritius. Wahid Lalloo, a principal civil status officer for the Republic of Mauritius, officiated.

abstract: The couple were introduced through OkCupid in 2012.

Philson of Grove City, Pa., and Ronald E. Philson of Mercer, Pa. Matthew Beck, a friend of Ms. Espiritu who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at Deity, an event space in Brooklyn.

abstract: The bride and groom met during college on a day of lacrosse scrimmages. She was playing for Adelphi and he for Manhattan College.
lead_paragraph: Mariel Anne Wenzel, a daughter of Margaret M. Wenzel and William C. Wenzel of Bay Shore, N.Y., was married there April 1 to Justin Clifford Jensen, a son of Lisa A. Jensen and Herman C. Jensen, also of Bay Shore. The Rev. David Atanasio, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick Roman Catholic Church.

headline: Erica Kochi, Gabor Cselle
abstract: The bride is a director of Unicef’s technology programs. Until February, the groom was a group product manager for Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Erica Mae Kochi and Gabor Cselle were married April 2 at the deYoung Museum in San Francisco. Dorian M. Needham, a friend of the couple who was appointed a deputy marriage commissioner for the occasion by the City and County of San Francisco, officiated.

abstract: The couple, who each received a degree from Harvard, were introduced through the dating app Hinge.
lead_paragraph: Katharine Elizabeth Jackson and Wilbert Cecyl Hobbs were married April 2 at Old South Church in Boston. The Rev. Nancy S. Taylor, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

headline: Francesca Gilberti, Ryan Burke
abstract: The bride and groom met in 2011 on a dinner date in San Francisco set up by a mutual friend.
lead_paragraph: Francesca Tobie Gilberti, the daughter of Ellen Tobie Gilberti and Lawrence F. Gilberti of Philadelphia, was married April 2 to Ryan James Burke, a son of Pamela S. Burke and Brendan J. Burke of Salisbury, Mass. The Rev. Claire Dietrich Ranna, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in San Francisco, with the Rev. Elizabeth Irvine, a Presbyterian minister and an aunt of the bride, taking part.

headline: For the Mets, a Pitching Coach Who Loves Walks
abstract: Dan Warthen uses long constitutionals to ponder how best to handle his young staff, which may be the best in baseball.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — It was still dark when Dan Warthen emerged from the Mets’ spring training complex around 6:45 a.m. Tuesday. He wore a track suit and sneakers and had a Fitbit watch on his right hand. Spring training was winding down, and Warthen thought he should spend his morning walk picking up a treat for the coaches’ room, something that everyone would enjoy.

lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 3, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “He gets very, very little credit, and I think that’s too bad because we got quite a bit of help. I don’t know what we would have done without it.”

headline: The Keys to Happiness
abstract: There may not be a magic formula, but here’s what we know about how to get there, according to recent research and expert advice.
lead_paragraph: There may not be a magic formula, but here’s what we know about how to get there, according to recent research and expert advice.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: Malaysian Sailors Abducted Near Philippines in Latest Act of Piracy
abstract: Four crewmen on a cargo ship were kidnapped by armed men, according to police officials, less than a week after 10 Indonesian crewmen were taken.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — Four sailors from Malaysia were kidnapped off a cargo ship passing close to the southern Philippines on Friday night, less than a week after 10 sailors from Indonesia were abducted nearby, according to police officials from the three countries.

headline: Making a Soda Tax More Politically Palatable
keywords: ['Sales and Excise Taxes', 'Soft Drinks', 'Sugar', 'Obesity', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The mayor of Philadelphia thinks a tax will go down easier when it’s about raising money for something, not just about making people drink less soda.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Jim Kenney was elected in Philadelphia last year after promising to bring the city universal prekindergarten, but he needed a way to pay for it.
