headline: Shape-Shifting Wind
abstract: A photographer inspired by “The Gates” in Central Park found a similar scene to shoot when the wind lifted up a bicyclist’s slicker.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: 1941: Virginia Woolf Believed Drowned
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Virginia Woolf missing, believed drowned in 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The disappearance of Virginia Woolf, British novelist, was revealed tonight [April 2] by members of her family, who believed she had drowned.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2016: Meet the Judges
abstract: Meet the super-human team that powers the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST  — Even though I’m working, it’s no secret that I come to the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament to see friends, and many of them can be found in the Judges’s Room. This is the team that keeps the tournament chugging along, getting the standings up as quickly as humanly possible.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2016: Standings After Puzzle 6
abstract: “Jeopardy!” champion Joon Pahk roars into second place as we go into Puzzle 7 at the 2016 American Crossword Tournament.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — Would you like to know what’s exciting, from a totally nerdy, crossword-solving point of view? What’s exciting is when a competitor — top-shelf for sure, but who hasn’t been in the top standings for a while — inches up into second place to nip at the six-time champion’s ankles. I might have to delete my pre-written Finals headline [Haha! That’s a totally false and humorous joke, Copy Desk. I don’t really do that. –D.A.]

headline: Amtrak Train Crash Leaves 2 Dead, Officials Say
abstract: The train, headed to Savannah, Ga., from New York City, partially derailed when it crashed into a railroad backhoe, killing two Amtrak workers who were not on board.
lead_paragraph: CHESTER, Pa. — An Amtrak train, southbound at high speed on Sunday morning, slammed into construction equipment on the tracks near Philadelphia, killing two track workers and wounding more than 30 passengers, the authorities said.

headline: 1966: Gromyko Tells U.S. To Get Out Of Europe
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Andrei Gromyko tells the United States to leave Europe to the Europeans, in 1966.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei Gromyko told the United States yesterday [Apr. 2] to get out of Europe. In a long, hard-hitting speech that often echoed the words of President Charles de Gaulle, Mr. Gromyko said the United States was a ‘‘non-European power’’ and must leave Europe to the Europeans.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Plan an adventure to an Asian supermarket and make gothlike Korean noodles and more for the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Work, Life, and Everything
abstract: Celebrating the end of ambition.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Avent has a lovely essay about the reasons modern professionals tend to put in such long hours. As he says, it’s not just drudgery: for many people work is satisfying, a source of a lot more than just money. It can, of course, also be a form of avoidance, a way to avoid the messiness of real life. But anyway, for those lucky enough to have the right kind of work, it’s much more than a paycheck.

headline: Sanders’s Message Stands to Resonate Long After Election
abstract: Despite his presidential bid looking improbable, Senator Bernie Sanders has galvanized public outrage that will hold sway over the next president.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders, the democratic socialist from Vermont, is waging an improbable presidential campaign, but he won’t disappear after this election. Nor will his followers.

headline: Investigating the Minds of Mass Killers
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Lone killers usually don’t fit into any existing category of mental illness, and there’s little evidence that early treatment would have helped.
lead_paragraph: Actually: These lone killers usually don’t fit into an existing category of mental illness, and there’s usually little evidence that early treatment would have helped.

headline: Caitlyn Jenner to Appear on ‘Transparent’
abstract: Ms. Jenner will be part of the third season of the Amazon show, which follows the lives of Maura Pfefferman, a transgender woman, and her family.
lead_paragraph: Caitlyn Jenner will appear on the next season of “Transparent.” Jill Soloway, the creator and executive producer of the Amazon series, announced the casting at the GLAAD Media Awards on Saturday, according to The Associated Press.

headline: High Winds Leave Thousands Across the East Without Power
abstract: Strong winds whipped across the region on Sunday, tearing down trees, damaging buildings and even forcing the Statue of Liberty to close.
lead_paragraph: Fierce winds, snow, lightning and hail stomped across the East on Saturday and early Sunday, downing trees, damaging buildings and cutting power to more than 250,000 homes across 14 states.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
abstract: The winds of change blow through “Call the Midwife.” And “The Walking Dead” ends its sixth season with a bang.
lead_paragraph: The times they are a-changin’ on “Call the Midwife.” Morgan Freeman ponders the meaning of life in “The Story of God.” And “The Walking Dead” closes out its sixth season with an extra-long shocker.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2016: Missing Merl Reagle and Going Into the Finals
abstract: Going into the Finals of the 2016 A.C.P.T. and the winner of the first MERL Memorial Award.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — The only thing I can think of to say about the loss of superstar constructor Merl Reagle in 2015 is that it was palpable this year at the American Crossword Tournament. There is a Merl-shaped hole in the universe and a gathering like this is where you feel it the most, second to his widow Marie Haley’s heart.

headline: A Bronx Church Where Landmark Status Would Be More Burden Than Honor
abstract: The Immaculate Conception Church could soon be given official landmark status, which church leaders say would create an extra hardship for a poor parish that already struggles to pay for repairs.
lead_paragraph: The bronze doors of Immaculate Conception Church are always open during the day, a welcoming gesture to the surrounding Melrose neighborhood in the South Bronx. Decorated with figures of the Virgin Mary, the doors are graceful — and heavy. “My main issue is trying to open them in the morning,” the Rev. Francis Skelly, the church’s pastor, said. “They keep me in shape.”

headline: Azerbaijan Claims to Halt Violence in Nagorno-Karabakh, but Warns Armenia
abstract: Azerbaijan laid the seeds for continued fighting over the long-disputed enclave by saying that it would keep the territory seized by its forces.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Azerbaijan announced on Sunday that it had halted combat operations in the sudden, bloody clashes with Armenia over the long-disputed enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh, but it laid the seeds for continued fighting by saying it would keep the slice of territory seized by its forces.

headline: A.C.P.T. 2016: And the Winner Is …
abstract: Congratulations to …
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — Congratulations to Howard Barkin of New Jersey, first-time winner of the A.C.P.T. and slayer of six-time champion Dan Feyer!

headline: China’s Carbon Emissions May Have Peaked, but It’s Hazy
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Coal', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Air Pollution', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: There could be important consequences if such emissions are falling more than a decade earlier than expected, but finding the answer is difficult.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A year and a half ago, negotiators from the United States persuaded the Chinese government to commit to a deadline for reversing the growth in greenhouse gas emissions from China.

headline: ‘Batman v Superman’ Stumbles, but Stays at No. 1
abstract: The double super hero film saw its box office take drop 68 percent from its opening weekend.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — And then came the superplunge.

headline: A Student of ‘Cultural Environmentalism’ Explores the Many Views of Earth’s Anthropocene ‘Age of Us’
abstract: A writer who explores the meanings of nature takes a tour of the growing array of views of the proposed Anthropocene epoch of Earth history.
lead_paragraph: I’ve found it impossible to keep up with the many books and monographs that have accrued around the emerging idea that Earth and its inhabitants have entered a geological epoch shaped by humans — the Anthropocene.

headline: Oscar Isaac to Star in a ‘Hamlet’ Staged by Theater for a New Audience
abstract: The actor will play Shakespeare’s brooding prince in a June 2017 production planned by the company at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: From Shakespeare to “Star Wars” and back again: Oscar Isaac will play the title role in a new production of “Hamlet,” staged by Theater for a New Audience at the Polonsky Shakespeare Center in Brooklyn in June 2017. Sam Gold, who won a Tony for “Fun Home,” will direct.

headline: Martin Puryear to Receive Yaddo Artist Medal
abstract: The artist colony in Saratoga Springs is honoring the sculptor, whose latest work will debut in Madison Square Park in May.
lead_paragraph: The sculptor Martin Puryear will receive the third annual Yaddo Artist Medal. Yaddo, the artist colony in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., will celebrate Mr. Puryear at a benefit on May 18, which will also include a performance from musicians Jason Moran and Alicia Hall Moran.

headline: The New Day, a British Upstart, Casts Its Fate to the Newsstand
abstract: Britain’s newest newspaper doesn’t have a website or an app. Instead, its publisher believes that readers haven’t yet lost their appetite for newsprint.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The New Day, Britain’s youngest media start-up, has a little something for everyone: a digest of the day’s top news, human-interest features, coverage of popular culture, sports, health and travel, and even advice columnists.

headline: A Cravath Partner Moves to Paul, Weiss
abstract: Scott Barshay, who has been with Cravath for 25 years, will become Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison’s global head of mergers and acquisitions.
lead_paragraph: In a move unusual for the highest echelons of American corporate law, one of Wall Street’s top deal makers is defecting to a rival after a 25-year career at the white-shoe law firm Cravath, Swaine and Moore.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Continue Back-and-Forth Over Debate Date
abstract: Mrs. Clinton told a TV news station she would attend a debate in New York on April 14, but Mr. Sanders’ campaign is pushing for a different day.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton on Sunday sought to put an end to the debate over the debate.

headline: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 1
abstract: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times weigh in on the contenders for the 142nd running of the Kentucky Derby.
lead_paragraph: Top contenders for the 142nd running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of preference, with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Churchill Downs has adopted a points system to determine the Derby field, with points being earned by the top four finishers in designated prep races. The odds are from the Churchill Downs futures pool, and the records are starts-win-place-show. An article on Saturday’s Florida Derby can be found here.

headline: Israel Expands Palestinian Fishing Zone Off Gaza’s Coast
abstract: A change to nine nautical miles of the Mediterranean, from six, will allow access to areas that had been off limits for a decade.
lead_paragraph: GAZA — Israel on Sunday expanded the Palestinian fishing zone off the southern portion of Gaza’s coast to nine nautical miles from six, allowing fishing in areas that had been off limits for a decade.

headline: Donald Trump Calls for John Kasich to Drop Out
abstract: Mr. Trump on Sunday said Mr. Kasich was siphoning votes from him and called on the Republican National Committee to urge him to drop out of the primary contest.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Donald J. Trump called for Gov. John Kasich of Ohio to drop out of the Republican primary contest, saying that Mr. Kasich “should not be allowed to run.”

headline: Review: ‘Mapplethorpe: Look at the Pictures’ on HBO Gives Context to Controversy
abstract: This documentary puts Robert Mapplethorpe’s photographs, which included graphic depictions of sex and S-and-M, in the framework of a life and artistic vision.
lead_paragraph: Every generation gets its own “New York values” panic. Monday’s HBO documentary on the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe begins in 1989, months after his death, with Senator Jesse Helms decrying his work on the floor of the United States Senate. The senator had started a crusade against the National Endowment for the Arts’ funding of an exhibition by “a known homosexual who died of AIDS,” whose work included graphic depictions of sex and S-and-M. “Look at the pictures!” he cried.

headline: Nuclear Winter
abstract: Carl Sagan and other Cold War scientists once feared that a nuclear war could plunge the world into a deadly ice age. Three decades later, does this theory still resonate?
lead_paragraph: Carl Sagan and other Cold War scientists once feared that a nuclear war could plunge the world into a deadly ice age. Three decades later, does this theory still resonate?

headline: Global Warming Gives Science Behind Nuclear Winter a New Purpose
abstract: In what once was considered a potential civilization-ending cataclysm lie the seeds, some researchers think, of a potential solution to climate change.
lead_paragraph: With global temperatures rising inexorably, some scientists and national security theorists have pondered cooling things down by tinkering mechanically with the planet’s climate.

headline: After Loss, Warriors Take Aim at Problems Masked by Victories
abstract: Even before Golden State lost to Boston on Friday, Coach Steve Kerr had noticed “slippage” among his players. Now the team is refocusing, with the playoffs in mind.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Coach Steve Kerr of the Golden State Warriors could sense what he described as “slippage” among his players. Loose passes. Undisciplined defense. Wayward focus.

headline: Condé Nast Goes Into Show Business
abstract: The company is aiming to capitalize on the blockbuster success spawned by articles from its glossy magazine pages.
lead_paragraph: The company is aiming to capitalize on the blockbuster success spawned by articles from its glossy magazine pages.

headline: Big Ears, a Music Festival With a Rare Vision
abstract: The festival in Knoxville, Tenn., is presented with purpose and first-rate sound to a growing audience that isn’t even close to jaded about it.
lead_paragraph: The festival in Knoxville, Tenn., is presented with purpose and first-rate sound to a growing audience that isn’t even close to jaded about it.

headline: Big Ears Festival Resists Commercial and Genre Constraints
abstract: This music festival in Knoxville, Tenn., in its fifth iteration, doesn’t suffer the formulaic stasis of so many festivals.
lead_paragraph: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. — At the Big Ears Festival over the weekend here, I heard a great array of music, created by orchestras and groups of electric guitars and single flutes and hard drives, aggressive and enveloping, rhythmic and ambient. You’re probably making an assumption now: O.K., an anything-goes festival. Got it. And your next thought might be: Who’d go to that?

headline: Rural Area
abstract: David Kwong gets us one step closer to solving a mystery.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — In the NBC television show “Blindspot,” every tattoo on the body of the protagonist Jane Doe tells a story. Found naked in Times Square, Jane Doe has no memory of who she is or how she got there, but she attracts the attention of the F.B.I., which links her tattoos to a larger crime conspiracy.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of April 4
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Review: ‘Charlie Parker’s Yardbird’ at the Apollo Hails a Bebop Giant
abstract: An opera traces the life of the definitive bebop composer and saxophonist: his childhood, addictions, love life and collaborators.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Parker came into his own in the jazz clubs of Harlem, so there was undeniable poetry in his return to the neighborhood in operatic form. But “Charlie Parker’s Yardbird,” given its New York premiere on Friday at the Apollo Theater, evoked none of that masterly saxophonist and composer’s wild beauty and mesmerizing focus.

headline: In TV Ad, Ted Cruz Accuses John Kasich of Cronyism
abstract: Ahead of Tuesday’s primary in Wisconsin, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is targeting Gov. John Kasich with a TV attack ad for the first time, suggesting that Mr. Kasich engaged in cronyism as Ohio’s governor.
lead_paragraph: Ahead of Tuesday’s primary in Wisconsin, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is targeting John Kasich with a TV attack ad for the first time, suggesting that Mr. Kasich engaged in cronyism as Ohio’s governor.

headline: In Charles Bock’s ‘Alice & Oliver,’ Cancer Is a Highly Personal Villain
abstract: Mr. Bock used his first wife’s death and her journals to shape the template for his latest novel.
lead_paragraph: After Diana Colbert died of leukemia in 2011, her husband, the novelist Charles Bock, began reading through the journals she kept when she was sick. Ms. Colbert had hoped to write an inspirational book about her experience, and she took notes while she was undergoing grueling chemotherapy and transplant procedures, often through the haze of medication.

headline: Review: Verdi’s ‘Simon Boccanegra’ at the Met, and a Question of Career Timing
abstract: When is it time for a great artist to retire? This delicate question hovers over this revival, conducted by James Levine, and starring Plácido Domingo.
lead_paragraph: When is it time for a great artist to retire? This delicate question hovers over the Metropolitan Opera’s revival of Verdi’s “Simon Boccanegra,” conducted by James Levine and starring Plácido Domingo in the title role.

headline: Review: ‘Catastrophic Happiness,’ a Comedy of Manners About Bumpy Child-Rearing
abstract: Catherine Newman’s memoir takes a less amusing tone when it moves past the toddler years.
lead_paragraph: What do you do when a book suddenly, abruptly, becomes a photo negative of itself? When it turns from a thing of beauty into its unlovely obverse?

headline: Jim James of My Morning Jacket on Lifting a ‘Wet Blanket’ Off a 2003 Album
abstract: The singer talks about his dissatisfaction with the initial mix of the band’s “It Still Moves,” and the factors that fed its new, remixed edition.
lead_paragraph: My Morning Jacket was an earnest yet mysterious rock band reaching for daylight when it released “It Still Moves,” its third album, on ATO in 2003. Rich with reverberant guitars and the high, chiming voice of Jim James, it suggested a searching twist on psychedelic rock without settling into a rigid style. But because of a rushed mixing job, the album has never really been heard the way it was intended to be.

headline: Review: American Composers Orchestra Concert Tilts Eastward
abstract: This group’s premiere-heavy event at Zankel Hall drew on several sources for inspiration, including Ottoman techniques and North Indian rhythms.
lead_paragraph: Middle Eastern and Indian traditions filtered through a Western lens were the theme of “Eastern Wind,” a program heavy in world premieres, which the American Composers Orchestra offered at Zankel Hall on Friday. With sources of inspiration encompassing Ottoman composition techniques, North Indian rhythmic cycles, biblical Hebrew, and the songs of the Egyptian megastar Umm Kulthum, the concert, conducted by George Manahan, made for a refreshingly multifaceted evening of new music.

headline: Review: Wynton Marsalis’s ‘Spaces,’ a Kinetic Series of Zoological Portraits
abstract: In this premiere, the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra moved from buzzing kazoos for bees to clucking reeds to an elephantine harrumph by clarinets and trombones.
lead_paragraph: The kazoos cropped up in the 10th and final movement of “Spaces,” an episodic suite by Wynton Marsalis that had its world premiere at the Rose Theater on Friday. The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra was swinging light and fast as it happened, bzz-bzz-bzz-bzz-bzz, in a busy rush. It was a cute and clever flourish, in a piece titled “Bees Bees Bees.” And it was also an act of evocation that reflected the larger theme of the suite.

headline: Review: Jared Grimes and Lil Buck Embody Their Animal Muses in ‘Spaces’
abstract: Their astoundingly complex footwork at Jazz at Lincoln Center ranged from loping to waddling to slithering.
lead_paragraph: Dancing like an animal — a chicken, say, or an elephant, monkey, snake or frog — may sound like a surefire way to look ridiculous in front of a large audience. But not if you’re the tapper Jared Grimes or the Memphis jooker Charles Riley (better known as Lil Buck) and you’re backed by Wynton Marsalis and the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra.

headline: Insider’s Account of How Graft Fed Brazil’s Political Crisis
abstract: A leftist party led by Dilma Rousseff that rose to power vowing to stamp out the corruption of a privileged political elite ended up embracing its predecessors’ practices.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — The silver-haired senator from Brazil’s western frontier was still in his pajamas when federal police agents banged on the door of his suite at the Royal Tulip, the futuristic luxury hotel that serves as a bastion for much of Brazil’s political elite. It was 6 a.m.

headline: Review: Lucius, a Band Willing to Test Itself
abstract: Lucius, anchored by Holly Laessig and Jess Wolfe, played at Webster Hall.
lead_paragraph: Holly Laessig and Jess Wolfe stood at the center of the Webster Hall stage on Friday night, each poised behind a keyboard and a drum in a tight cluster — part face-off, part huddle. They are the duo that anchors the band Lucius, which is built on the intimacy and (occasional) tension they create with their voices.

headline: The ‘Detectorists’ Are Back With Their Existential Divining Rods
abstract: The comedy’s second season opens at Acorn.tv with a hunt for a medieval heirloom and the discovery that one hapless protagonist is now a father.
lead_paragraph: The BBC series “Detectorists” is a mournful comedy, a sneakily funny celebration of futility and stasis. But don’t get the wrong impression. It’s not angsty and serious, in the vein of recent American comedies like “Transparent” or “Togetherness.” It’s as light and joyous as a show about a pair of melancholy British losers can be.

headline: Cartoon Network’s Powerpuff Girls Fight Evil on TV and Beyond
abstract: Eleven years after their television series ended, Blossom, Bubbles and Buttercup are returning to Cartoon Network on multiple digital platforms.
lead_paragraph: The Powerpuff Girls have battled a rogue’s gallery of evil lab monkeys, hillbilly monsters and androgynous devils. But for the first time, they face a new challenge: a fight for relevancy.

headline: Brazil Impeachment: The Process for Removing the President
abstract: Dilma Rousseff, Brazil’s president, is facing removal from office. Here is a step-by-step explanation of the proceedings.
lead_paragraph: Dilma Rousseff, Brazil’s president, is facing removal from office. Here is a step-by-step explanation of the proceedings.

headline: A Contentious Vote by North Dakota Republicans Yields 25 Unaligned Delegates
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: No candidates for delegate had to declare whether they would support Donald J. Trump, Senator Ted Cruz or Gov. John Kasich at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland.
lead_paragraph: FARGO, N.D. — After a contentious vote on Sunday, North Dakota Republicans elected 25 unaligned delegates to send to the Republican National Convention this summer in Cleveland, offering a presage of the confusion and chaos that seems certain to unfold there if the party remains unable to unite behind a nominee.

headline: Outshone by Smaller Screens, PCs Aim to Be Seen as Cool Again
abstract: With the onslaught of smartphones and tablets, even people who depend on PCs now lack passion for these onetime miracle products.
lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif. — Dion Weisler, the chief executive of HP Inc., recently held out a bulky laptop that was the pride of 2012. “This is the laptop we had when I came here,” he said.

headline: Overpass Project in Kolkata ‘Made Our Lives Hell’ for Years Before Collapse
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Building (Construction)', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Irritation with the faltering project, unfinished after seven years, has turned into a sort of focused hatred for the people who live beneath it.
lead_paragraph: KOLKATA, India — When Sonali Mehrotra realized that a hulking overpass would come within arm’s length of her third-floor balcony, she took refuge in black humor, telling relatives to look at the bright side: Instead of lugging suitcases up the stairs when they came to visit, they could toss them into a bedroom as they drove in from the airport.

headline: Technology Upgrades Get White House Out of the 20th Century
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'AIR FORCE ONE (JET)', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As President Obama prepares to leave the White House, one of his legacies will be the office information technology upgrade that his staff has finally begun.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Can you run the country with spotty Wi-Fi, computers that power on and off randomly and desktop speakerphones from Radio Shack, circa 1985?

headline: UConn Routs Oregon State to Advance to Title Game
abstract: Connecticut easily defeated Oregon State for its 74th consecutive win, and the Huskies will play for their fourth consecutive national title on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Twenty-five years ago, when Connecticut began its ascent to the summit of women’s college basketball, the program resembled the current Oregon State team, which unexpectedly captured the Dallas Region this season to reach its first Final Four.

headline: Largely Forgotten and Hugely Influential: The Race for Marco Rubio’s Senate Seat
abstract: Florida is again likely to play a crucial role in who wins the White House, but the wild, wide-open and largely forgotten race to replace Mr. Rubio could also determine which party controls the Senate.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Representative Patrick Murphy, a two-term Democrat now running for United States Senate, looked exultant, maybe even a bit star-struck, as he greeted patrons and posed for selfies with Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at Jackson Soul Food Restaurant in the city’s Overtown neighborhood.

headline: Months After a Brash Challenge, Noah Syndergaard Is Again Displaying Confidence
abstract: Not backing down has been a theme throughout the young career of Syndergaard, a Mets starter who nearly hit a Royal with a pitch in last year’s World Series.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — After last year’s World Series ended, Mets pitcher Noah Syndergaard spent some time taking in New York in a way he could not during the season. He attended sporting events, tried restaurants and roamed neighborhoods. Mets fans often stopped him and complimented him on one thing: his first pitch in Game 3 of the World Series.

headline: In the Path of Nicaragua’s Planned Canal
abstract: Some of the people and places that could be affected if a vast canal is built.
lead_paragraph: Some of the people and places that could be affected if a vast canal is built.

headline: Lost in Nicaragua, a Chinese Tycoon’s Canal Project
abstract: Sixteen months after ground was broken, a plan by a Chinese billionaire that would link the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans and greatly alter a country is shrouded in mystery and controversy.
lead_paragraph: BRITO, Nicaragua — A Spanish explorer conducted the first survey to connect the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans here in the 16th century. Napoleon III of France dreamed about it. The railroad magnate Cornelius Vanderbilt briefly had rights to do it. Nicaragua’s history is littered with dozens of failed canal schemes.

headline: Ruling on Coach’s Challenge: Inconclusive
abstract: Some N.H.L. players and coaches trust the review process, which can alter the outcome of a game, but others question its integrity.
lead_paragraph: Among the rule changes that have shaken up the N.H.L. this season, nothing has been as constructive and confounding as the coach’s challenge.

headline: Weather Could Force Yankees to Wait One More Day for Opener
abstract: Rainy, chilly weather may force the postponement of the Yankees’ opener against Houston, the team which ended their season last year in a wild-card playoff.
lead_paragraph: Editor’s note: On Monday, the Yankees postponed their opening game to Tuesday afternoon.

headline: Experts See Risks, and Logic, in Skeloses’ Appeal for No Prison Time
abstract: Prosecutors are likely to seek stiff prison sentences for Dean G. Skelos, the former majority leader of the New York State Senate, and his son, Adam, who were both convicted on corruption charges.
lead_paragraph: The requests, at once, seemed obvious and yet somewhat counterintuitive: Lawyers for Dean G. Skelos and his son, Adam B. Skelos, suggested that their clients should avoid prison time, despite their convictions on corruption charges.

headline: Donald Trump and Ted Cruz Shift Into High Gear as Wisconsin Primary Looms
abstract: As the state prepares to vote on Tuesday, the candidates are at it again, circling and prodding each other in a final sprint before the high-profile contest.
lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — A bastion of “Midwestern nice.” An opening for Senator Ted Cruz. Swelling doubts about the go-it-alone approach of Donald J. Trump.

headline: World Series Rematch Means Reliving Pain
abstract: The Royals planned to unveil their championship banner before facing the Mets in the first opening-day game in history between the previous year’s World Series opponents.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — It seemed like a sports marketer’s invention, this opening series between the Kansas City Royals and the Mets. What better way to celebrate the new season than a rematch of the reigning league champions?

headline: Dashing Hopes, Study Shows a Cholesterol Drug Had No Effect on Heart Health
abstract: Experts were stunned by a study of 12,000 patients that showed the drug, evacetrapib, had no effect in preventing heart attacks, strokes or death from heart disease.
lead_paragraph: It is a drug that reduces levels of LDL cholesterol, the dangerous kind, as much as statins do. And it more than doubles levels of HDL cholesterol, the good kind, which is linked to protection from heart disease. As a result, heart experts had high hopes for it as an alternative for the many patients who cannot or will not take statins.

headline: With Victory at Miami Open, Djokovic Adds to His Records
abstract: Novak Djokovic passed Roger Federer in career prize money, with nearly $98.2 million, and passed his coach, Boris Becker, in career wins, with 714.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — As tennis’s Big Four (Djokovic, Nadal, Federer, Murray) has been reduced to the Big One (Djokovic), the measures of that one’s greatness have become ever more striking.

headline: Victim in Wall St. Scheme Was a Classmate of Its Accused Architect
abstract: James McIntyre, the previously unidentified person who federal prosecutors said invested $400,000 in Andrew Caspersen’s scheme, went to college with him.
lead_paragraph: When Andrew Caspersen sought money for an investment that federal authorities said duped investors out of tens of millions of dollars, one of the people the former Wall Street executive turned to was a college classmate at Princeton University.

headline: Strategy on Garland: Act as Though He’ll Get Senate Hearing
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: President Obama’s aides and Judge Merrick B. Garland’s allies have concluded that acting as if the Supreme Court nomination is going ahead is the best way to pressure adversaries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Merrick B. Garland, chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals here, has been sequestered in a kind of alternate reality in a small conference room in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building next to the White House, cramming for questions from senators as if hearings on his nomination to the Supreme Court will happen this year.

headline: A New Libor Trial, Trade Data and Fed Leaders Onstage
abstract: On Monday, five former Barclays employees are expected in court in London. Also this week: A report from the Commerce Department along with new details from the Fed.
lead_paragraph: Five former Barclays employees are expected in court in London on Monday as their trial begins over criminal charges that they conspired to manipulate the London interbank offered rate, a global benchmark interest rate known as Libor. —Chad Bray

headline: In Five Months, Villanova Wildcats Have Matured Beyond Their Years
abstract: Villanova achieved an astounding 67-point swing as it traveled from a 23-point loss to Oklahoma in December to a record-setting 44-point victory over Oklahoma on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Daniel Ochefu, Villanova’s senior forward, learned the game before there were nylon nets, when peach baskets were fastened to trees. Ryan Arcidiacono, a senior guard, has been playing since the Wildcats’ home court was the Palestra. One of Villanova’s walk-ons was a teenager in 1985 when Villanova won its only (so far) national title in men’s basketball.

headline: China’s Companies Poised to Take Leap in Developing a Driverless Car
abstract: Conditions for the technology may actually be more favorable in China than in the United States because of aggressive support from the government.
lead_paragraph: Gansha Wu was a veteran engineering manager at Intel Corporation and director of Intel Labs China when two events upended his world last year.

headline: Brothers Prepare for N.C.A.A. Title Face-Off
abstract: Guards Nate Britt of North Carolina and Kris Jenkins of Villanova, who grew up as brothers in Maryland, will oppose each other in the final of the N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — North Carolina guard Nate Britt said he had no idea where his parents were going to be seated inside NRG Stadium for the national title game Monday night, or what colors they intended to wear. It will be a carefully thought out decision.

headline: Panama Law Firm’s Leaked Files Detail Offshore Accounts Tied to World Leaders
keywords: ['Panama Papers', 'Tax Evasion', 'Tax Shelters', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'Money Laundering', 'News and News Media', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes']
abstract: News media outlets said the documents revealed the accounts of 140 politicians, including figures with close ties to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A group of news media outlets published articles on Sunday based on what they said were 11.5 million leaked documents from a Panama law firm that helped some of the world’s wealthiest people — including politicians, athletes and business moguls — establish offshore bank accounts.

headline: Drawing the Line on Gossip After the Gawker Trial
abstract: Does the $140 million civil award against Gawker for its posting of a sex tape starring the retired wrestler Hulk Hogan mean that the culture as a whole is saying “Enough”?
lead_paragraph: The brand-new Gawker Media offices in downtown Manhattan are the bomb, as in great. They’re all glass and steel, clean lines and modern fixtures. They were paid for in secrets, exposed with a joyful ferocity that enriched Gawker’s founders and helped redefine how far our reality-TV culture could go to satisfy its appetite for gossip and news about the famous, the powerful and, increasingly, just the mildly interesting.

headline: A Workhorse on the Hudson River, Now Retired From Fighting Fires, Chugs Toward a Second Act
abstract: After decades of service as a fireboat in the New York Fire Department, the John D. McKean was sold at auction to two restaurateurs who envision a floating museum.
lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE JOHN D. McKEAN, in Tarrytown, N.Y. — On a gleaming Thursday morning in March, a candy red fireboat rattled awake and set forth from its station in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. As the ship voyaged north along the Hudson River at nine knots, it left more than half a century of history in its wake.

headline: A Fireboat’s Second Life on the Hudson
abstract: After being bought by restaurateurs, the John D. McKean, a former New York City fireboat, is being prepared for a new role: that of floating museum.
lead_paragraph: After being bought by restaurateurs, the John D. McKean, a former New York City fireboat, is being prepared for a new role: that of floating museum.

headline: Washington Metro, 40 and Creaking, Stares at a Midlife Crisis
abstract: Years of safety lapses as well as petty annoyances reveal how a grand vision of American liberalism has collided with reality.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jack Evans was a summer intern here in 1976, the year Metro, the capital region’s subway system, opened to rave reviews. It was an architectural triumph, with escalators that plunged into clean, well-lit stations — a mass transit marvel “like ‘The Jetsons,’ ” he says — a far cry from the graffiti-scarred, decrepit system of that era in New York.

headline: No Corrections: April 4, 2016
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 4, 2016.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 4, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It’s a system that’s maybe safe, somewhat unreliable, and that is being complained about by everybody.”

headline: With New Effort, Group Hopes to Show Donald Trump Has a Multicultural Appeal
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Supporters of Donald J. Trump, who has been criticized for months for his comments on race, are planning to create a website that will showcase other supporters of Mr. Trump — who is a native of a diverse city but who is running in a party primary dominated by older, whiter voters — in an effort to tell a different side of his story.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, criticized for months for his comments on race, is about to be bolstered by a multi-cultural network of supporters hoping to tell a different side of his story.

headline: Ryan Arcidiacono May Talk Villanova to a Title
abstract: Ryan Arcidiacono, the Wildcats’ captain, motivates his teammates with passionate speeches, a contribution at least as important as his play on the court.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — At halftime of their national semifinal game against Oklahoma on Saturday, the Villanova Wildcats huddled together, leaning close, some on their tiptoes, to hear their team preacher, Ryan Arcidiacono.

headline: Yankees’ Brian Cashman and Joe Girardi Are Opposites Who Agree
abstract: Something of an odd couple — a thrill-seeking general manager and a reticent manager — Cashman and Girardi are beginning their ninth season together.
lead_paragraph: When the Yankees played at Toronto in August, their general manager, Brian Cashman, took a trip up the CN Tower, which rises like a giraffe’s neck above the downtown skyline. His purpose: to lean out over a ledge, 1,168 feet above terra firma, tethered only by a cable and a sense of adventure.

headline: Armies Used by U.N. Fail Watchdog Group’s Test
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'International Relations']
abstract: A new study found that the armed forces that provide the most United Nations peacekeepers are also among the world’s most susceptible to corruption.
lead_paragraph: The militaries of the 30 countries that provide the most soldiers and police officers to United Nations peacekeeping operations also are among those most susceptible to corruption, according to a study released Sunday by an anti-corruption monitoring organization.

headline: 2 N.B.A. Prospects, 2 Competing Visions
abstract: While Villanova’s Jalen Brunson is the hotshot recruit, North Carolina’s Marcus Paige is a billboard for staying in college for four years.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Marcus Paige and Jalen Brunson represent two sides of college basketball’s most vexing issue: How old should a college player be before having an opportunity to play in the N.B.A.?

headline: TBS Acquires N.C.A.A. Final and Fewer Eyeballs
abstract: The N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament championship game between Villanova and North Carolina in Houston will be broadcast on TBS.
lead_paragraph: Major sports events have been televised by broadcast networks for so long that when a title game moves to cable, it registers a small jolt, but no longer much surprise. The College Football Playoff is entirely an ESPN affair, as are the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament and the tennis majors Wimbledon and the United States Open, from the opening match to the finals.

headline: ‘Vinyl’ Season 1, Episode 8: The History of Rock
abstract: Lester and the Nasty Bits have a great scene in this week’s episode.
lead_paragraph: “Vinyl” has featured lots of rock history lessons, but none as good as the moment when Lester decides to strap on a guitar and give the Nasty Bits a succinct history of the E-A-B chord progression. The Bits desperately need to write some new material, having gotten becalmed in the recording of a proto-punk sea shanty, but singer Kip Stevens complains that “there’s no more notes!”

headline: Review: ‘Death for Five Voices,’ About a Vanguard Composer
abstract: This new musical from the Prospect Theater Company is about the early modern composer Carlo Gesualdo.
lead_paragraph: You can’t fault the composer Peter Mills or the director and Mr. Mills’s co-writer Cara Reichel for lacking ambition. It took nerve to write the new musical “Death for Five Voices,” playing at the Sheen Center, about a vanguard composer, and it took further brio to begin that work with the line, “It is finished,” Jesus’s final words on the cross. And as members of the Prospect Theater Company, Mr. Mills and Ms. Reichel also demonstrate no little audacity in producing elaborate musical theater works on what seems to be a negligible budget.

headline: Syracuse Defeats Washington; Connecticut Awaits in Title Game
abstract: Syracuse continued its unexpected run in the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament, easily defeating Washington. The Orange will play UConn for the championship on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Dapper in a navy blue vest and pants, with the collar unbuttoned on his striped blue dress shirt, Syracuse Coach Quentin Hillsman watched his team play swarming defense against Washington, throwing his arms up, hunching low to the ground and looking ready to jump on the floor for every loose ball that his team caused.

headline: Skating Slowly Tries Regaining Its Edge
abstract: The sport’s popularity has eroded. But the world championships in Boston last week demonstrated that the quality of skating has not.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Figure skating is not nearly what it used to be — not globally, not in the United States.

headline: Early Missteps Seen as a Drag on Bernie Sanders’s Campaign
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Hillary Clinton appeared beatable in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination. But Mr. Sanders has failed to fully take advantage.
lead_paragraph: The morning after he lost the Nevada caucuses in February, Bernie Sanders held a painful conference call with his top advisers.

headline: A New Yorker, Long Caught in Immigration Limbo, Comes Home to Start His Job
keywords: ['Mexican-Americans', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Foreign Workers', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Visas', 'Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals']
abstract: Angelo Cabrera, who came to the United States from Mexico in 1990, was offered a post at Baruch College in Manhattan more than two years ago. This month, he will finally be able to show up to work.
lead_paragraph: Angelo Cabrera was offered a job administering a program for Mexican immigrants at Baruch College in Manhattan more than two years ago.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 1, Episode 11: The Doctor Is In
abstract: The season’s next-to-last episode turns out to be an atypically somber affair.
lead_paragraph: So we’ve reached the penultimate episode of “Billions” (oh, that special time in every season when TV critics get to bust out the word “penultimate”) and it turns out to be an atypically somber affair for a show that might be expected to step on the gas before the finale. In the wake of Donnie’s death and the resultant dissolution of the case against Bobby Axelrod, however, we instead get a dark-night-of-the-soul episode, filled with somber reflection, scenes of regret and reconciliation, and the crossing of a new set of lines. A few literal fireworks were set off this week; the metaphorical ones are sure to follow.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 6 Finale: Negan Arrives, and Then... ?
abstract: The character, a favorite from the comic book, made his long-awaited arrival into the AMC series on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: So now “The Walking Dead” is just messing with us.

headline: As Messaging Apps Boom, Brands Tiptoe In
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Instant Messaging', 'Online Advertising', 'Mobile Applications', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments']
abstract: Marketers are taking restrained approaches to advertising in apps to avoid antagonizing users, focusing less on overt promotion.
lead_paragraph: Gatorade owns one of the iconic television moments of the Super Bowl, the dousing of the winning coach with a huge bucket of the sport drink, ice included. For the 2016 game, though, the brand wanted to reach more younger people, who tend to watch less TV.

headline: Federal Housing Officials Warn Against Blanket Bans of Ex-Offenders
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Discrimination', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Minorities']
abstract: Julián Castro, the secretary of housing and urban development, said landlords cannot deny housing just because an applicant has a criminal history.
lead_paragraph: Private landlords who have blanket bans on renting to people with criminal records are in violation of the Fair Housing Act and can be sued and face penalties for discrimination, the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development said.

abstract: This word has appeared in 47 New York Times articles in the past year.

headline: Royals Recreate History, Stifling the Mets in a World Series Rematch
abstract: The Royals beat the Mets on opening night the same way they had in the fall: with a combination of strong pitching, steady defense and pesky offense.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — The first time the Mets took the field for the 2016 season, they lined up along the third-base line and were forced to watch a replay of the way their previous season had ended. They fidgeted and rocked back and forth, holding their hands behind their backs, as the Kansas City Royals played highlights from the 2015 World Series.

headline: Anthony Vaccarello Succeeds Hedi Slimane at Yves Saint Laurent
abstract: Rumors had swirled for months that Mr. Vaccarello would take over as creative director. The move was made official on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The fashion world’s game of musical chairs continues. Anthony Vaccarello, most recently the creative director of Versus Versace — the younger, funkier sibling brand of Versace and, of late, an incubator of up-and-coming designers — has been named the new creative director of Yves Saint Laurent.

headline: What to Watch Monday
abstract: “Mapplethorpe: Look at the Pictures” examines the controversy surrounding the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe. “The Powerpuff Girls” grow up. And “Nova” explores what could be a new Viking site.
lead_paragraph: “Mapplethorpe: Look at the Pictures” sheds light on the life of Robert Mapplethorpe and his sexually frank photographs. “The Powerpuff Girls” grow up. And “Nova” streams its exploration of what could be a new Viking site in North America.

headline: The Rolling Stones on the Brink of Stardom
abstract: A new book looks at the early years of the Rolling Stones, capturing the naïveté and – yes – innocence of that era.
lead_paragraph: A new book looks at the early years of the Rolling Stones, capturing the naïveté and – yes – innocence of that era.

headline: The Rolling Stones on the Brink of Stardom
abstract: A new book looks at the early years of the Rolling Stones, capturing the naïveté and — yes — innocence of that era.
lead_paragraph: When two fledgling British photographers, Terry O’Neill and Gered Mankowitz, got their respective jobs shooting the Rolling Stones in the mid-1960s, the group itself was an emerging act: a raw-sounding, roguish-looking blues band whose repertoire was stacked with cover songs.

headline: Cities for Everyone
keywords: ['Urban Areas', 'Zoning', 'Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Income Inequality', 'Buildings (Structures)']
abstract: In New York, trying to do something about spreading the new urban bounty.
lead_paragraph: Remember when Ted Cruz tried to take Donald Trump down by accusing him of having “New York values”? It didn’t work, of course, mainly because it addressed the wrong form of hatred. Mr. Cruz was trying to associate his rival with social liberalism — but among Republican voters distaste for, say, gay marriage runs a distant second to racial enmity, which the Trump campaign is catering to quite nicely, thank you.

headline: MetLife and the Threat to Dodd-Frank
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The regulatory reform law needs defending and strengthening, not weakening.
lead_paragraph: The federal court decision last week to remove the “too big to fail” label from MetLife, the insurance giant, may or may not turn out to be a factor in a future financial crisis. But it is a setback to regulation intended to protect the economy from the inherent risks of an undersupervised financial system.

headline: Remembering a 1916 Irish Uprising
keywords: ['Easter and Holy Week', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']

headline: Why Trump’s Antiwar Message Resonates with White America
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: They bore the brunt of our failure in Iraq. Now someone is finally standing up for them.
lead_paragraph: MY grandma — we called her Mamaw — loved her country. Born in eastern Kentucky coal country at the beginning of the Great Depression, she credited so much of the good in her life to America’s bounty. When I interviewed her about her life for a school project, she spent most of the time talking about World War II: her dad’s love letters from the Pacific; how her younger brother lied about his age in an effort to enlist. “We did it,” she told me, still beaming with pride more than a half-century later. “We freed the whole world from tyranny.”

headline: Gay Pride and Prejudice in Dominican Republic
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations', 'Editorial Observer']
abstract: An openly gay ambassador and his husband have galvanized a fledgling gay rights movement, outraging church leaders in a conservative nation.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after taking up his post as American ambassador to the Dominican Republic in November 2013, Wally Brewster got a bit of unsolicited advice from the Vatican’s envoy to the Caribbean nation.

headline: Teenage Sexting Is Not Child Porn
keywords: ['Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Sex', 'Text Messaging', 'Child Pornography', 'Sexting', 'Law and Legislation', 'Photography']
abstract: Decriminalize consensual behavior. That way we can focus on real digital harm.
lead_paragraph: TEENAGERS who sext are in a precarious legal position. Though in most states teenagers who are close in age can legally have consensual sex, if they create and share sexually explicit images of themselves, they are technically producing, distributing or possessing child pornography. The laws that cover this situation, passed decades ago, were meant to apply to adults who exploited children and require those convicted under them to register as sex offenders.

headline: The (Un)Democratic Party
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Superdelegates and caucuses contribute to the skewed political structure of the party.
lead_paragraph: There are two prominent features of the Democratic Party’s presidential selection process that are thoroughly undemocratic and undermine faith in the party: superdelegates (which favor Hillary Clinton) and caucuses (which favor Bernie Sanders).

headline: A Renewable Energy Boom
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Global Warming', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Solar Energy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Wind Power', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: With wind and solar power becoming much more affordable, world leaders have no excuse for failing to press for clean energy.
lead_paragraph: Some world leaders, especially in developing countries like India, have long said it’s hard to reduce the emissions that are warming the planet because they need to use relatively inexpensive — but highly carbon-intensive — fuels like coal to keep energy affordable. That argument is losing its salience as the cost of renewable energy sources like wind and solar continues to fall.

headline: Socrates, Cynics and Flat-Nailed, Featherless Bipeds
abstract: Should philosophy be systematic or subversive? For a very long time, it’s been both.

headline: Is Anti-Zionism Merely Anti-Semitism in Disguise?
abstract: When does criticism of Israel become bigotry? Is rejection of the Jewish state a rejection of Jews?

headline: News Q’s | Hearing the Music of Vanishing Languages
abstract: How are today’s composers finding inspiration in vanishing languages from around the world?
lead_paragraph: The following lesson activities are based on the article “Vanishing Languages, Reincarnated as Music.”

headline: Teaching Men to Be Emotionally Honest
abstract: With so much research showing that young males suffer beneath the gravity of conventional masculinity, why isn’t there more help for them on campus?
lead_paragraph: Last semester, a student in the masculinity course I teach showed a video clip she had found online of a toddler getting what appeared to be his first vaccinations. Off camera, we hear his father’s voice. “I’ll hold your hand, O.K.?” Then, as his son becomes increasingly agitated: “Don’t cry!… Aw, big boy! High five, high five! Say you’re a man: ‘I’m a man!’ ” The video ends with the whimpering toddler screwing up his face in anger and pounding his chest. “I’m a man!” he barks through tears and gritted teeth.

headline: For a Golf Tinkerer, a Strategy Just Crazy Enough to Work
abstract: Bryson DeChambeau, a 22-year-old amateur, will play the Masters with equipment that some observers find baffling: His irons and wedges are the same length and weight.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — How to improve one’s game? It is the eternal question for golfers, as predictable as their next shank. When planted in Bryson DeChambeau’s fertile mind, the query flourished like the grape vines climbing vines from the rich soil of the San Joaquin Valley in California, where he grew into one of the world’s top amateurs.

headline: Undercover Officers Ask Addicts to Buy Drugs, Snaring Them but Not Dealers
abstract: Defense lawyers and jurors have vigorously questioned a strategy by the New York Police Department that prizes the pursuit of the addicts who use drugs over the people who supply them.
lead_paragraph: The 55-year-old crack addict counted his change outside a Harlem liquor store. He had just over a dollar, leaving him 35 cents short of the cheapest mini-bottle.

headline: ‘Fractivists’ Increase Pressure on Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders in New York
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Global Warming', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Water Pollution', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Climate change has especially inspired grass-roots progressives upstate, who fought — and won — a yearslong battle against fracking for natural gas.
lead_paragraph: A nasty row that erupted between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders over oil and gas industry donors last week is catapulting the issue of climate change into the race for the Democratic presidential nomination as it moves to New York, where an army of activists upstate is driven by opposition to drilling.

headline: Health Scare at Malibu School Sets Off Media War
abstract: A debate over window caulking with the toxic chemical compounds has divided a California school district and parents like Cindy Crawford.
lead_paragraph: MALIBU, Calif. — The high school here is ranked among the best in the country, with students each year moving on to Ivy League colleges. The location, on a hill down the block from the beach where “Baywatch” was filmed, offers a multimillion-dollar view of the Pacific Ocean.

headline: Student Question | Where Do You Think You Will Live When You Are an Adult?
abstract: What are the benefits and drawbacks of living in the same place your whole life?
lead_paragraph: When you are on your own, where do you see yourself living?

abstract: In this post, English Language learners investigate presidential candidates and the words and phrases they frequently use, then write about what interests them about the candidates.
lead_paragraph: Note: We invite any English-language-learner student 13 years or older to post comments in response to the writing prompts in this post.

abstract: A game of free association between the critical comedian and the comedic critic ricochets between kale, the Kardashians and presidential hopefuls.
lead_paragraph: A game of free association between the critical comedian and the comedic critic ricochets between kale, the Kardashians and presidential hopefuls.

abstract: The critical comedian and the comedic critic discuss unconditional love, American politics and the danger of self-censorship.
lead_paragraph: In this new column, T brings together two people for the very first time — to see what happens.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | April 4, 2016
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by commenting on what you see and why. A live discussion is offered that day from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern.
lead_paragraph: Updated: April 8, 2016

headline: A Teachable Moment on the Need for Colon Cancer Screening
abstract: Traditional colonoscopy is best at finding cancer. Less invasive screenings are not as definitive, but they’re better than nothing.
lead_paragraph: As an alumna of Cornell who had been thrilled by the selection of the university’s first female president, Elizabeth Garrett, last fall, I was deeply pained to learn of her untimely death from colon cancer at age 52 last month. May it be a teachable moment that could save many from a disease that will be diagnosed in an estimated 134,000 people and claim 49,000 lives in the United States this year.

headline: When Parents Have a Favorite Child
abstract: It’s impossible not to have favorites, and the perception of favoritism is one of the biggest factors in sibling rivalry.
lead_paragraph: To my own mother, it was an article of faith to show no favoritism. If two of us asked her whose drawing she liked best, the answer was predetermined: I like them just the same. When I tried to trick my mother by saying I had done both drawings myself, she saw right through me; she understood that children are constantly trying to elicit evidence of who is ahead and who is behind. And to the end of her life, if someone tried to draw my mother out in public praise, by saying, with reference to some particular milestone or achievement, oh, you must be so proud of your child, she would respond, firmly, yes, I’m proud of all my children.

headline: Chaos of Cultural Revolution Echoes at a Lonely Cemetery, 50 Years Later
abstract: The tension between official silence and grass-roots remembrance is palpable at the last sizable resting place solely for victims of the Cultural Revolution.
lead_paragraph: CHONGQING, China — During China’s traditional festival for honoring the dead, Zheng Zhisheng usually visits a vine-draped cemetery where pillars declare the dead’s eternal loyalty to Mao Zedong. He walks among the mass graves, sharing memories, and sometimes tears, with mourners who greet him as their “corpse commander.”

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Panama Papers, Amtrak, Kansas City Royals
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New York Today: Yankees’ Opening Day Rescheduled
abstract: Monday: Baseball’s return is now Tuesday, new food at the stadium and refrigerated cherry blossoms.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:40 a.m.

headline: Handcrafted Sausages to Take Home
abstract: A brisket burned-end version, a Tokyo chicken, a lamb with cumin and a Cubano from Jake’s Handcrafted.
lead_paragraph: Yes, Jake Klein’s bratwurst has snap, but it was some of his other sausages, including one from brisket burned ends and a Tokyo chicken version with spice to spare, that impressed Pete Wells, the New York Times restaurant critic, at Jake’s Handcrafted, Mr. Klein’s Park Slope tavern, last year. Now the sausages are available by the pound to take home. There is a lamb sausage seasoned with cumin, and a Cubano featuring the ingredients you’d expect in a Cuban sandwich. The accompanying banana mustard will make you forget any honey mustard you have ever tried: Sausages, $12 to $18 a pound, Jake’s Handcrafted, 559 Fifth Avenue (15th Street), Park Slope, Brooklyn, 718-788-0789, jakeshandcrafted.com.

headline: To Herald Spring, Nettle Bread From Bien Cuit
abstract: A new loaf with a sturdy crust and a deep beige crumb streaked with green.
lead_paragraph: Stinging nettles suggest spring as much as ramps or fiddleheads. They are featured in an unusual bread from Zachary Golper, who owns the bakery Bien Cuit with his wife, Kate Wheatcroft, collaborating with Justin Binnie, the executive chef. The loaf is pointy at the ends with a sturdy crust verdantly streaked with pulverized dried nettles. Moist and earthy, the deep beige crumb has an alluring tang from the goat’s milk used in the dough: Nettle Bread, $6 at Bien Cuit, 120 Smith Street (Pacific Street),  Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, 718-852-0200, biencuit.com.

headline: A Spice Rub Better Than What You’d Make Yourself
abstract: A blend from chef Vivian Howard’s restaurant, Chef & the Farmer.
lead_paragraph: Premade spice rubs mostly belong in some dark, forgotten corner of the pantry, alongside bottled salad dressings. I’ll make my own, thank you. But every now and then, an exception shows up, like this piquant mixture of ground coffee, Turkish cumin, smoked paprika, garlic and brown sugar to give heft and depth to pork chops caramelizing on the grill. Dust it on bacon or add it to the darkening jus for a slab of ham. The recipe comes from Vivian Howard’s restaurant, Chef & the Farmer, in Kinston, N.C.: Vivian Howard’s Rub It In Red Eye Coffee Rub, $10.95 for 3 ounces, williams-sonoma.com.

headline: Allowed to Visit Her Baby’s Grave After 12 Years, a Woman Is Told: Your Son Isn’t Here
abstract: When Katrina DeJesus couldn’t afford a burial for her son, who lived only 90 minutes, she let New York City bury him. Now the city says it doesn’t know where his body is.
lead_paragraph: The baby boy lived only 90 minutes after he was born on Oct. 23, 2003. Without money to bury him, his mother, Katrina DeJesus, reluctantly signed papers letting New York City lay him to rest. She would not be allowed to visit the city cemetery where the baby was buried, officials told her, because it was off limits, under the jurisdiction of the Correction Department.

headline: DEET Seen as Safe for Pregnant Women to Avoid Zika Despite Few Studies
abstract: Research indicates that the insect repellent, if not overapplied, is fine to use to avoid being bitten by mosquitoes that could be carrying Zika.
lead_paragraph: This summer, some yellow-fever mosquitoes carrying the Zika virus are expected to arrive along the Gulf Coast and elsewhere in the continental United States. Health officials are urging people to use insect repellents with DEET to avoid being bitten.

headline: ScienceTake | Wings That Sing
abstract: Male African broadbills use their wings, not their voices, to make sounds that attract females.
lead_paragraph: Male African broadbills use their wings, not their voices, to make sounds that attract females.

headline: For African Broadbills, Seduction to the Sound of Feathers
abstract: Males of the species use their wings, not their voices, to make sounds to attract females.
lead_paragraph: It’s called wing song. And it is not new age harp music or the latest calming aromatherapy. It is, oddly enough, a song that a bird makes with its wings.

headline: On Mondays at Bâtard, No Corkage Fee
abstract: Drew Nieporent revives a practice he began at Montrachet years ago.
lead_paragraph: In May 2003, Drew Nieporent started letting customers bring their own wines to his TriBeCa restaurant, Montrachet, on Monday nights with no corkage fee. It was a resounding success that also helped the restaurant recover from Sept. 11. Now at Bâtard, his second replacement for Montrachet, he has restored the policy. “Many guests asked about it,” he said. “People collect wines and want to drink them with friends but not necessarily at home. The idea has been hanging around for some time.” At Montrachet on Mondays, there was almost a party atmosphere as prized bottles were shared from one table to the next. At the end of the evening, the empties were lined up on the bar. The sommelier in charge these days, Jason Jacobeit, will have his work cut out for him. “My sommeliers hate it,” Mr. Nieporent said: No Corkage Mondays, Bâtard, 239 West Broadway (White Street), 212-219-2777, batardtribeca.com.

headline: Goat Cheese Bathed in Sour Beer and Loving Care
abstract: From Coach Farm to the Crown Finish caves to Mekelburg’s in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: So much time, care and attention have been lavished on this single tiny cheese, a 4-ounce goat button from Coach Farm in Pine Plains, N.Y., that has a velvety rind enclosing a creamy layer with a soft paste inside. It graduates from the farm to the Crown Finish caves in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, where it is gently bathed in Finback Red Shift, a sour beer brewed with cranberries and yuzu in Queens, giving it a tart, briny complexity. Then it goes to Mekelburg’s, a food store and bar in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, where it is lovingly wrapped and labeled. Worth the trip, as they say in Michelin, but Mekelburg’s will also ship the cheese: MekelMaster, $12.95 at Mekelburg’s, 293 Grand Avenue (Greene Avenue), Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, 718-399-2337, mekelburgs.com.

headline: When Only Snail Mail Will Do
abstract: Postcards with food art, and a touch of whimsy.
lead_paragraph: A collection of 100 postcards pretty enough to use as gift inserts or notecards includes paintings of ramen bowls, old-school illustrations of fruits and vegetables, and even a nice dose of whimsy, with a spaghetti-infused picture from the movie “Hell Bent for Leather.” This one comes from a graphic design collective called Brest Brest Brest. All the cards are packaged in a bright box indexed by the 10 artists, mostly women, who designed them. An accompanying booklet profiles the artists, taking note of what they have in their refrigerators: “Curious Feast” edited by Naz Sahin Ozcan (Princeton Architectural Press, $19.95).

headline: Judi Dench Wins Eighth Olivier Award in London
abstract: Ms. Dench won the best supporting actress award for her performance in “The Winter’s Tale,” produced by the Kenneth Branagh Theater Company.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Judi Dench and Imelda Staunton were among the winners Sunday night at the Olivier Awards, the London equivalent of the Tony Awards for theater.

headline: Despite Meetings With Merrick Garland, Senate G.O.P. Sees Little Give in Stance
abstract: Mr. Garland is scheduled to meet with two Republican senators on Tuesday and met with another last week, but party leaders say they are holding the line on the nomination.
lead_paragraph: The Senate is back on Monday after a two-week break, and the Supreme Court vacancy, which dominated much of the recess, will return to center stage in Washington this week.

headline: Morning Agenda: Alaska Airlines to Buy Virgin America
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Hedge Funds', 'Legal Profession', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Venture Capital']

lead_paragraph: ALASKA AIRLINES TO BUY VIRGIN AMERICA | Alaska Airlines said on Monday that it would be buying Virgin America in a deal that values Virgin America at $57 per share, or $2.6 billion,  The Financial Times reports. As of Friday’s market close Virgin was valued around $1.5 billion,  Michael J. de la Merced and Leslie Picker report in DealBook.

headline: Alaska Air Sees Virgin America as Key to West Coast
abstract: Alaska Air Group is betting $2.6 billion that the airline industry is so consolidated after years of mergers that what it needs is another takeover.
lead_paragraph: In agreeing to buy Virgin America for $2.6 billion, Alaska Air Group is betting that the airline industry is so consolidated after years of mergers that what it needs is another takeover.

headline: Donald Trump Met Secretly With Interest Groups
abstract: Mr. Trump, who routinely denounces special interests in his stump speeches, held a private meeting in Washington on Thursday with nearly a dozen industry leaders, including a veteran lobbyist and the chief executive of a major airlines trade organization, attendees confirmed.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s private meeting in Washington on Thursday featured nearly a dozen industry leaders, including a veteran lobbyist and the chief executive of a major airline trade organization, attendees confirmed.

headline: Sicker Patients Seem at a Disadvantage With Medicare Advantage
abstract: The private insurance plans offer some benefits not available with traditional Medicare, but research shows they may not serve some people well.
lead_paragraph: New evidence suggests Medicare Advantage may not serve some sicker Medicare beneficiaries as well as it does healthier ones.

headline: Trump’s Troubles and Democratic Sparring Precede Wisconsin Vote
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s rough week was followed by a rough weekend, as he suffered potentially consequential losses at party events related to precious convention delegates in two states, and on the Democratic side, there were debates about debates and conflicts over how many donations from the fossil-fuel industry.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s rough week was followed by a rough weekend, as he suffered potentially consequential losses at party events related to precious convention delegates in two states.

headline: Drones Marshaled to Drop Lifesaving Supplies Over Rwandan Terrain
abstract: Zipline, a start-up based in California, raised $18 million and partnered with the small African country to shuttle packages of blood and emergency medicine.
lead_paragraph: HALF MOON BAY, Calif. — From a bluff overlooking the Pacific Ocean, a loud pop signals the catapult launch of a small fixed-wing drone that is designed to carry medical supplies to remote locations almost 40 miles away.

headline: China News Blackout as ‘Ten Years’ Takes Hong Kong Best Film Award
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Movies', 'News and News Media', 'Censorship']
abstract: The mainland state news media omitted mention of the film, which depicts a dystopian future for Hong Kong under Chinese rule.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In an Oscar-like spectacle on Sunday night, the Hong Kong Film Awards announced 21 movie prizes. Or 20 — if you consulted only reports in the mainland Chinese news media.

headline: Q. and A.: Xujun Eberlein on the Legacy of the Cultural Revolution
abstract: The writer considers the emotional complexity of reconstructing an era whose memories are painful to the victims and shameful to those who victimized.
lead_paragraph: Half a century has passed since Mao Zedong set in motion the Cultural Revolution, his chaotic attempt to purge the Communist Party and Chinese society of compromise and “capitalist” tendencies. The movement unleashed widespread violence, some of it led by “Red Guards,” young students who organized themselves into militant units to enforce Mao’s revolutionary vision. Some of the most intense fighting was in Chongqing, where in recent days some residents mourned at China’s only surviving sizable Red Guard cemetery.

headline: Could There Be a Terrorist Fukushima?
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)']
abstract: Nuclear facilities throughout the world are vulnerable to attack.

headline: Website Seeks to Make Government Data Easier to Sift Through
keywords: ['Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Archives and Records', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Census']

Acres of paper records on demographics, public health, traffic patterns, energy consumption, family incomes and many other topics have been digitized and posted on the web.

headline: Tamara Wilson Wins 2016 Richard Tucker Award

lead_paragraph: The prestigious Richard Tucker Award, which comes with a $50,000 cash prize and a starry gala concert in New York, will be given this year to the soprano Tamara Wilson, the foundation that administers the prize announced on Monday morning.
