keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Deportation', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: They had braved risks and hardships to get to Greece, but at least 202 migrants were sent back to Turkey on Monday, the first day of such deportations.
lead_paragraph: MYTILENE, Greece — They had braved risks and hardships to get to Greece, having crossed the narrow strait from Turkey in flimsy rafts like nearly a million others last year — with hundreds dying along the way.

headline: BATS Global Markets Plans to Price Shares at $17 to $19
abstract: The offering would be the second time in four years that the exchange has tried to go public, after technical issues scuttled its last attempt.
lead_paragraph: BATS Global Markets, the electronic exchange operator that tried to sell shares to the public four years ago, only to withdraw the offering after technical flaws halted trading, is at it again.

headline: False News From the Sisi State
abstract: As hundreds of young Egyptians continue to disappear, no one believes the government’s explanations.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — My friend Mostafa Massouny has one of the most eclectic music collections of anyone I know. I initially typed “had” and “knew,” because I fear Mostafa is dead.

headline: Valeant Is a Reminder of the Peril of Outsize Executive Pay
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Income Inequality', 'Boards of Directors', 'Stock Options and Purchase Plans', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)']
abstract: Compensation based largely on stock price performance probably played a role in the behavior that led to the drug company’s rise and stunning fall.
lead_paragraph: There is no shortage of reasons for the spectacular rise and fall of Valeant Pharmaceuticals International.

headline: Securing Airports While Protecting Democracy
abstract: The explosions in Brussels raise an old question: how to prevent suicide bombings without surrendering to fear.
lead_paragraph: It was inevitable in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks at the Brussels airport that security would be sharply increased at airports across Europe and tough questions would be raised about Belgian security precautions. There is no question that the Belgian government needs to improve its security procedures, especially with the growing evidence in recent weeks of jihadist plotting in some of the city’s neighborhoods. But the demands for greater protection also revive fundamental questions about the balance of security and freedom: How much security is achievable, affordable and bearable in a democratic society?

headline: 1941: Yugoslavia Mobilizes
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: King Peter II of Yugoslavia mobilizes his army in 1941.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE — All observers here agreed tonight [April 4] that the question was no longer whether, but when, Yugoslavia would be attacked. The official gazette published late tonight a royal decree issued last Tuesday but not made public at the time for fear of provoking Germany.

headline: Mets’ Yoenis Cespedes Takes the Good With the Ugly
abstract: On Sunday night against the Royals, Cespedes dropped an eminently catchable line drive, reminding many of his miscue in Game 1 of last year’s World Series.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Alex Gordon has played most of his nine-year career in left field at Kaufmann Stadium, catching hundreds of balls in the exact spot where Yoenis Cespedes dropped an eminently catchable line drive Sunday night, the latest of his numerous lightning rod moments.

headline: Gwyneth Paltrow Shares Beauty Advice, Even Though Her Daughter Is the Expert
abstract: Mama Paltrow likes bee-stinging, vodka and French fries, dislikes makeup and chemical sunscreens, and isn’t so sure about fragrance and sound baths.
lead_paragraph: These days, the actress Gwyneth Paltrow, 43, is perhaps better known for her website, Goop.com, where New Age meets wellness meets urban bourgeoisie. Not content with, well, just content, she has been developing makeup products with Juice Beauty and has introduced her Goop skin-care line. Ms. Paltrow, who is also mom to Apple, 11, and Moses, 9, lives in Los Angeles. Here, she shares beauty, hair and life advice.

headline: Yankees Get an Extra Day to Prepare for Dallas Keuchel

headline: As Pennsylvania Confronts Clergy Sex Abuse, Victims and Lawmakers Act
abstract: Residents say they have been stunned to read evidence that priests they knew were secretly abusing children — findings a grand jury report called “staggering and sobering.”
lead_paragraph: LORETTO, Pa. — By the age of 12, Maureen Powers, the daughter of a professor at the local Roman Catholic university, played the organ in the magnificent hilltop Catholic basilica here and volunteered in the parish office. But, she said, she was hiding a secret: Her priest sexually abused her for two years, telling her it was for the purpose of “research.”

headline: Book Review: ‘The Finest Traditions of My Calling’

headline: 1966: Beatniks Barred From France
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: France bars beatniks from entering in 1966.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — France has declared war on foreign beatniks, it was learned today [April 4]. With the arrival of Holy Week and the spring tourist season, the government has ordered French border police to turn back foreigners ‘‘presenting an incorrect appearance and lacking resources,’’ Agence France-Presse reported. The order is aimed at long-haired young visitors, mostly from the ‘‘Anglo-Saxon’’ and Nordic countries. They arrived and camped under the bridges of the Seine in force last summer. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 5, 1966

The decision was a major statement on the meaning of a fundamental principle of the American political system, that of “one person one vote.”

headline: A Trio of New Products for Soft, Natural Eyebrows
abstract: The season‘s wax-based formulas are firm yet pliable, to shape and thicken arches to the most natural effect.
lead_paragraph: This spring, new eyebrow products combine all the best qualities of traditional formulas — they’re matte like a powder, precise like a pencil and firm like a gel — but thanks to the addition of beeswax, have an added softness, too. Glossier’s Boy Brow, recently reintroduced alongside the brand’s new makeup collection, goes on like a creamy gel — its small, mascaralike applicator softly fills in arches with precision — without the goop. This month, Bobbi Brown unveiled Long-Wear Brow Gel, in eight different shades of buildable color that gets darker and bolder with each application. And Dior just released All-In-Brow 3D palettes, inspired by the fashion house’s backstage beauty. Each kit contains two shades of powder — to achieve organic-looking ombré color that tapers off towards the ends — and a soft wax topcoat to keep it all in place.

But all those characters still have something in common: athletic, even godlike bodies. Not so Faith Herbert, a plus-size heroine, who will be getting her own monthly series beginning in July, published by Valiant Comics.

headline: Holocaust Survivor Recalls ‘Brundibar,’ a Children’s Opera
abstract: The work from Terezin is being staged in Madrid, and a Holocaust survivor, Dagmar Lieblova, said: “‘Brundibar’ can now be used to remember the past in a way that children can understand. It can also be a warning for the future.”
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Dagmar Lieblova was 14 in 1943, when she sang in the children’s opera “Brundibar” at the Terezin concentration camp near Prague. The performance was part of a Nazi effort to present the camp as a model ghetto rather than a transit point to Auschwitz and the gas chambers.

headline: Best Team, in One View, May Not Be the Warriors
abstract: Believers in scoring margin as a predictor say that it pierces the perception of the Warriors’ historical greatness and that the Spurs are just as good, or better.

headline: Trump’s Very Predictable Problems
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why Trump’s delegate struggles should have already been priced in to his odds of being the nominee.
lead_paragraph: The conventional wisdom on Donald Trump’s candidacy is a strange thing to watch shift. Trump has had a rough two weeks, no question: Losing out in backstage delegate battles all over the map, saying a dozen contradictory things about abortion, seeing Ted Cruz rise past him in the Wisconsin polls, plus the daily drumbeat of strange statements and wildly-uninformed interview answers that we all now take for granted. But have the two weeks been so bad, compared to everything that we knew and could reasonably expect about Trump already, to justify this kind of plunge in his betting-market odds of being the nominee — from eighty percent to fifty percent in a matter of a week? Have they been bad enough to justify as perspicacious a pundit as E.J. Dionne arguing that “this time, it really is the end of Trump,” and that the Donald’s looming loss in Wisconsin could cascade into losses in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and even New York?

headline: ‘Horace and Pete,’ Keeping You on the Edge of Your Seat, Right Up to Last Call
abstract: The main surprise in this 10-episode drama from Louis C.K. was in service of the story about a family for whom the mistakes of history kept being repeated.

headline: Aggregate Supply and Depression Economics (Wonkish)
abstract: And Abenomics too.
lead_paragraph: Robert Waldmann follows up on the question of who got what wrong in the late 1990s analysis of Japan’s liquidity trap. As he says, the extremely stripped-down nature of the model I used may have led some readers — like, surprisingly, Brad DeLong — to suppose that I had forgotten about the supply side. Actually, though, I still don’t really understand the confusion — I explicitly began with a flexible-price model, then considered the effects of temporarily fixed prices, so how could that have been unclear?

headline: Joseph Medicine Crow, Tribal War Chief and Historian, Dies at 102

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Global warming could lead to an increase in allergies and asthma, deaths by extreme heat and the proliferation of insect-borne diseases such as the West Nile virus, according to a scientific report released Monday by the White House.

headline: ‘My Reservations About Hillary Are Real’: Readers on ‘Bernie or Bust’
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Some Sanders supporters explained why they will never vote for Mrs. Clinton, while others said they will support whoever is the Democratic nominee.
lead_paragraph: Some supporters of Bernie Sanders explained why they have pledged never to vote for Hillary Clinton if she becomes the Democratic nominee for president, while others implored die-hard Sanders voters to work with the party, in response to a column by Charles Blow.

headline: Flatiron Building, Admired but Rarely Copied, Inspires Developers
abstract: In a city that has largely stuck to its grid, builders in New York are turning to oddly shaped lots — and the buildings that fit on them.
lead_paragraph: New York is awash with architectural imitators: the rows of identical 19th-century brownstones, the spires and setbacks of the Art Deco era, the Seagram Building knockoffs strewn around Midtown Manhattan in the 1960s and ’70s, the luxury fishbowls rising now.

headline: Profile in Style: Olga of Greece
abstract: A private window into the colorful world of the artist, photographer, filmmaker and real-life princess.
lead_paragraph: A private window into the colorful world of the artist, photographer, filmmaker and real-life princess.

headline: Zayn Starts Off His Solo Career With a No. 1 Album
abstract: “Mind of Mine,” the new album by the former member of One Direction, debuted at the top of the Billboard 200.
lead_paragraph: Zayn, the first member of the superstar boy band One Direction to release a solo album, has reached No. 1 on the Billboard chart.

headline: Inside Princess Olga of Greece’s Colorful, Art-Filled World
abstract: The artist and filmmaker shares with T personal images of her greatest influences.
lead_paragraph: The artist and filmmaker shares with T personal images of her greatest influences.

headline: Hillary Clinton Roundly Criticized for Referring to the Unborn as a ‘Person’
abstract: Hillary Clinton faced criticism from both sides of the abortion debate after she waded into the argument about when life begins by describing the unborn as a “person.”
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton faced criticism from both sides of the abortion debate on Monday after she waded into the fraught argument about when life begins by describing the unborn as a “person.”

headline: A Jeweler’s Ode to His Glamorous Grandparents
abstract: Hanut Singh’s crystal and pearl earrings recall royal jewels, spinning tops and a maharaja’s turbans.
lead_paragraph: These brilliant orbs of hand-cut Jaipuri crystal atop 1920s Japanese pearls, held aloft by delicate talons of diamonds, represent the latest chapter in the designer Hanut Singh’s family’s obsession with jewels. His great-grandfather, a maharajah famous for his taste in stones, fancied ornate turban pins and ropes of pearls. His grandmother Princess Karam — a celebrated beauty photographed by Cecil Beaton and dressed by Mainbocher — was never without custom pieces made for her by Van Cleef & Arpels and Cartier. Singh, 43, who works between Los Angeles, Mumbai and his native New Delhi, recalls playing in her well-stocked jewelry box as a youngster. Thus inspired, these exquisite earrings, dubbed “The Emperors Cap,” take the form of his great-grandfather’s turbans, while also winkingly referencing the shape of toys — those spinning tops beloved by Indian children.

headline: 25th Anniversary of 1991 Kuwaiti Oil Fires
abstract: In April of 1991 following Iraqi military setting the Kuwait Oil Fields aflame, photographer Sebastião Salgado documented the environmental disaster
lead_paragraph: In April of 1991 following Iraqi military setting the Kuwait Oil Fields aflame, photographer Sebastião Salgado documented the environmental disaster

abstract: Two readers write that “marriage provides the most reliable arrangement through which children grow up with two committed parents.” Do you agree?

lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man who fatally beat a transgender woman after a chance encounter in Harlem in 2013 pleaded guilty on Monday to manslaughter in exchange for a sentence of 12 years in prison, prosecutors said.

headline: Six (Very) Funny Paintings From Tonight’s Tribeca Ball
abstract: An exhibition being mounted for the New York Academy of Art’s spring gala highlights works that use humor in a variety of ways.
lead_paragraph: Gala season in the New York art world can rightfully conjure thoughts of stuffy seated dinners, with dry chicken and even drier speeches. Not so at tonight’s Tribeca Ball to benefit the New York Academy of Art, where something new is on the menu: a little wit and whimsy. The works on display in “Funny Stuff,” a new exhibition of paintings being mounted for tonight’s festivities, involve humor in a variety of ways — from Monica Cook’s semi-grotesque “Extra Body,” which depicts the grooming rituals of a pair of Siamese twins conjoined at the head, to Jaclyn Brown’s riff on Tinder, “Tender,” to Ken Johnson’s “Untitled,” which sets up a joke — a duck and a sphere walk into a bar — but leaves its punch line unsaid. An exclusive preview of some of the canvases that will be on view runs here.

headline: Dave Eggers Journeys Into Alaska in ‘Heroes of the Frontier’
abstract: Dave Eggers’s coming novel, which Knopf will publish on July 26, is set in the Alaskan wilderness.
lead_paragraph: If there is anything resembling a pattern in Dave Eggers’s fiction, it is that he does not repeat himself much. Mr. Eggers’s eclectic body of work includes novels about a sinister, all-powerful technology company (“The Circle”); a Sudanese refugee’s flight from a war-torn village (“What Is the What”); an American salesman seeking to reinvent himself in Saudi Arabia (“A Hologram for the King”); and a boy who sails to a land full of wild, magical beasts (“The Wild Things”).

headline: Paying Library Fines
abstract: A librarian cites the classic book “All-of-a-Kind Family” to suggest a way for poor children to pay for missing or overdue books.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Officials React to Panama Papers
abstract: Many international officials who were listed in papers revealing the offshore accounts of wealthy individuals, including associates of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, defended themselves on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Many international officials who were listed in papers revealing the offshore accounts of wealthy individuals, including associates of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, defended themselves on Monday.

headline: Allen Iverson Stands Tall in New Hall of Fame Class
abstract: The Basketball Hall of Fame announced 10 new members, including Yao Ming and Shaquille O’Neal, but the attention seemed to fall most heavily on Iverson.
lead_paragraph: Some big names, and big men, were announced as the newest members of the Basketball Hall of Fame on Monday.

headline: A Jewel in Syria Where ‘Ruins Have Been Ruined’ by ISIS
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Assyrian Civilization', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Terrorism']
abstract: A Times photographer traveled to Palmyra, Syria, to see what remained of its archaeological treasures after almost a year of Islamic State control.
lead_paragraph: PALMYRA, Syria — As my Hezbollah escort and I entered the modern city around Palmyra, we were greeted by the mangled body of an Islamic State fighter left to rot in the sun. He looked as if dogs might have gotten to him after Syrian government forces, backed by loyal militiamen, routed him and his comrades from the ancient city after almost a year of Islamic State control.

headline: You Could Actually Snooze Your Way Through an Asteroid Belt
abstract: A crucial tension-creating plot point in many a movie and video game is based on a nonsensical premise.
lead_paragraph: Actually: If you were in the middle of an asteroid belt, you probably wouldn’t see any asteroids at all.

headline: ‘Panama Papers’ Leaks Put Iceland Prime Minister Under Pressure to Quit
abstract: Calls for the resignation of the prime minister were among the first repercussions of the leaks on secret tax shelters and offshore shell companies.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Iceland’s prime minister faced calls for his resignation and a large demonstration outside Parliament on Monday in one of the first repercussions of an enormous leak of documents about offshore shell companies and tax shelters from a secretive Panamanian law firm.

headline: Panama Papers: Why No Big Splash or Times Participation?
abstract: The Times did not treat the huge data leak prominently Sunday or as front-page news on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 2:19 p.m., Tuesday, to add comment from the consortium’s deputy director, Marina Walker, and The Times’s executive editor, Dean Baquet, at the bottom of the post.

headline: Hillary Clinton Raises Less Than Bernie Sanders for Third Month in a Row
abstract: The Clinton campaign said it raised $29.5 million in March, far less than the $44 million raised by Mr. Sanders during the same period.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton raised $29.5 million in March, her campaign announced on Monday, far less than the $44 million raised by Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont during the same period.

headline: Bernie Sanders Makes Progress Courting Nevada’s Delegates
abstract: Mr. Sanders is holding out hope that a strong showing at the Clark County convention in Nevada over the weekend could help him top Hillary Clinton in the race for the state’s delegates.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders is holding out hope that a strong showing at the Clark County convention in Nevada over the weekend could help him top Hillary Clinton in the race for the state’s delegates.

headline: Republicans and Voter Suppression
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'States (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The Supreme Court rejects a dangerous challenge to equal representation, but harmful voter-ID laws live on.
lead_paragraph: It’s become an accepted truth of modern politics that Republican electoral prospects go up as the number of voters goes down. Conservatives have known this for a long time, which helps explain their intensifying efforts to make it harder to vote, or to eliminate large numbers of people from political representation entirely.

headline: 1878 | Adolph Ochs’s First Times (The One in Chattanooga)
abstract: Few people, even at The Times, know that its roots can be traced not to “Newspaper Row” in New York, but all the way to Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider shares historic insights from The New York Times. In this piece, David W. Dunlap, a metro reporter, looks back at The Times’s Tennessean roots.

headline: Winston Moseley, Who Killed Kitty Genovese, Dies in Prison at 81
abstract: Ms. Genovese’s 1964 murder in New York, while neighbors failed to act on her cries for help, came to symbolize urban apathy in America.
lead_paragraph: Winston Moseley, who stalked, raped and killed Kitty Genovese in a prolonged knife attack in New York in 1964 while neighbors failed to act on her desperate cries for help — a nightmarish tableau that came to symbolize urban apathy in America — died on March 28, in prison. He was 81.

headline: Thomas Staggs, Disney’s Heir Apparent, Is Stepping Down
abstract: Mr. Staggs, the chief operating officer, will leave next month, handing Disney a distracting succession search for a chief-in-waiting.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Thomas O. Staggs, the favored contender to lead Disney after Robert A. Iger’s retirement, unexpectedly announced his departure on Monday, throwing succession at the world’s largest entertainment company into disarray.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers react to articles in Science Times.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Review: Grace McLean, Whose Songs Skip Across Boundaries
abstract: Ms. McLean and her band, Them Apples, closed this season of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: Metamorphosis: Everything is changing into something else in the music of Grace McLean, the phenomenal young singer, songwriter and actress, who closed this season of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series on Friday evening with a concert of pure joy. With her band, Them Apples, she transformed the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse into a playground for exploring musical connections in a fluid program of songs that gleefully skipped across traditional boundaries. Swing, hip-hop, electronica, jazz and modern theater styles flowed into one another in a musical stream of consciousness.

headline: Review: Vivian Reed, Serenading With Theatrical Power and Spirituality
abstract: In her new show, “Standards and More,” at the Metropolitan Room, the gospel-schooled Ms. Reed brings a semi-operatic drama to many numbers.
lead_paragraph: The pop-gospel singer Vivian Reed isn’t the first performer to explore the emotional extremes of the great Sondheim torch song “Losing My Mind,” from “Follies.” But she is the first I can remember to make it the platform for a flailing, semi-operatic mad scene. Ms. Reed is a fiercely elegant performer who holds nothing back. Like Lena Horne at her most imperious, she can be a little scary. On the few occasions she cracks a smile, you sigh with relief.

headline: Review: Joe Iconis and Family Join in Effervescent, Talky Tunes
abstract: Their show at Feinstein’s/54 Below suggests rowdy collegians having an uproarious time.
lead_paragraph: Time was when children, entranced by Barnum & Bailey magic, dreamed of running away and joining the circus. For those of us who were born with a musical-theater gene, the troupe known as Joe Iconis and Family exerts a similar allure. Their irresistibly jolly 90-minute revue, which opened at Feinstein’s/54 Below on Sunday evening, is the kind of show that deserves a long-term theatrical residency. The performers seem to be having such a good time that you want to jump onstage and join them.

headline: Review: Kronos Quartet Fosters Contemporary Works for Strings
abstract: The ensemble’s exploratory spirit was on display at Zankel Hall as it played selections commissioned through its initiative “50 for the Future.”
lead_paragraph: For over 40 years, the Kronos Quartet has been reimagining what a string quartet can be and fostering new music from diverse composers, more than 850 works and arrangements so far. So what is the quartet up to these days? Commissioning more pieces, naturally.

headline: What Do Millennials Want? Hotels Have Some Ideas
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Youth', 'Millennial Generation', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Web-Original Programming']
abstract: With Wi-Fi, craft beverages, concerts, ordering room service by emoji, hotel chains are trying to appeal to young travelers with a new playbook.
lead_paragraph: Hotels are concluding that millennial travelers want three things: customized experiences, digital convenience and relevant information on social media.

headline: People to Know: A Creative Couple that Does It All Together
abstract: Ellery James Roberts and Ebony Hoorn are releasing an album under the name LUH — but their working relationship encompasses more than just music.
lead_paragraph: Almost three years ago, a curious video appeared on YouTube. Called “Kerou’s Lament,” it featured strobing, mysterious footage of the ocean and of a little girl self-immolating, set against a sweeping postrock anthem that vowed resistance “to the powers of old, to the powers that be.”

headline: California Enacts $15 Minimum Wage
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown signed a bill that would raise the minimum wage statewide to $15 an hour by 2022.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jerry Brown of California signed a bill on Monday that would raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour by 2022, placing the state at the center of a closely watched economics experiment.

headline: Marshall Miller, Former Federal Prosecutor, Joins Wachtell Lipton
abstract: Mr. Miller, who oversaw several prominent Wall Street prosecutions, will reverse roles and defend white-collar defendants.
lead_paragraph: Marshall L. Miller, a former high-ranking Justice Department official who handled a number of prominent Wall Street prosecutions, has joined Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz as a white-collar defense lawyer, the firm said in a statement on Monday.

headline: Review: Royal Shakespeare Company’s ‘King and Country’ at BAM
abstract: This cycle presents four Shakespeare history plays, both parts of “Henry IV” bookended by “Richard II” and “Henry V.”
lead_paragraph: “Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown.”

headline: Yellow Fever Outbreak in Angola Strains Health Organizations
abstract: A crisis threatens other countries, including China, and exposes how poorly prepared the world is to fight two mosquito-borne epidemics at once.
lead_paragraph: Angola is experiencing a major urban yellow fever outbreak that threatens other countries, including China, and is exposing how poorly prepared the world is to fight two mosquito-borne epidemics at once.

headline: Gunfire Ends Post-Election Calm in the Republic of Congo
abstract: An armed group rampaged overnight in Brazzaville, the capital, shattering a relative calm since the re-election of President Denis Sassou-Nguesso.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Gunfire rang out for hours in Brazzaville, the capital of the Republic of Congo, early Monday as armed men attacked police stations and a mayor’s office.

headline: Review: ‘Wrestling Jerusalem,’ a Solo Show and Act of Faith
abstract: Aaron Davidman’s play about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict trusts in the power of the human voice and the capacity of the human heart.
lead_paragraph: Aaron Davidman’s “Wrestling Jerusalem,” at 59E59 Theaters, is an act of faith. A smartly written solo show about the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, it trusts in the power of the human voice and the capacity of the human heart. It believes that listening to one another’s stories can change the way we move through the world. That, really, is its reason for being.

headline: A Cloud Atlas Provides Clues to Life on Earth
abstract: Data from satellite photos of cloud cover allowed researchers to better predict the location of plants and animals on land.
lead_paragraph: After countless years of daydreamers being told otherwise, there’s now a good reason to keep your head in the clouds. Scientists combed through satellite photographs of cloud cover taken twice a day for 15 years from nearly every square kilometer of Earth to study the planet’s varied environments.

headline: Review: Suzanne Farrin’s Imaginative ‘La Dolce Morte’ at the Met
abstract: The countertenor Anthony Roth Costanzo and players from the International Contemporary Ensemble performed it as part of the MetLive Arts series.
lead_paragraph: Through its MetLive Arts series, the Metropolitan Museum of Art strives to present concerts in spaces that suit the music. That mission was accomplished over the weekend with the premiere of Suzanne Farrin’s “La Dolce Morte,” a dramatic cantata in the form of a song cycle for countertenor and small chamber ensemble. As a text, Ms. Farrin chose love poems by Michelangelo written to Tommaso de’ Cavalieri, a young Roman nobleman the artist met in 1532.

headline: Review: Roman Rabinovich Brings Melody to His Art, at Walter Reade Theater
abstract: The pianist performed “Surfaces,” written by Michael Brown, as part of Lincoln Center’s one-hour Sunday Morning Coffee Concerts series.
lead_paragraph: Mussorgsky’s “Pictures at an Exhibition” and Rachmaninoff’s “Isle of the Dead” are among the most well known examples of compositions inspired by visual art. More recently, the pianist and composer Michael Brown wrote “Surfaces” after studying the abstract art of the pianist and painter Roman Rabinovich. Mr. Rabinovich gave the premiere of the piece on Sunday morning at the Walter Reade Theater, part of Lincoln Center’s one-hour Coffee Concerts series.

headline: Review: Golf Channel Drama and Adult Swim Duffers
abstract: The Golf Channel features a documentary on Jack Nicklaus’s win at the 1986 Masters, and Adult Swim has a spoof of a ’60s televised charity match.
lead_paragraph: Attention, golf fans. For your viewing pleasure this week: something so right and something so very, very wrong.

headline: Breanna Stewart Is a Syracuse Fan but a UConn Star
abstract: Stewart, whose home was a five-minute drive from the Syracuse campus, said it was fitting that she would end her college career against the Orange in Tuesday’s title game.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Few players on the Syracuse women’s basketball team have as long a history with the program as Breanna Stewart does.

headline: Review: Eric Fair’s ‘Consequence,’ a Memoir by a Former Abu Ghraib Interrogator
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Torture', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mr. Fair’s book recounts modes of torture that he and others used at the Iraq prison in 2004, and his struggle since then to hold himself accountable.
lead_paragraph: The infamous photos of torture at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq that became public in the spring of 2004 — a pyramid of naked prisoners, a hooded man forced to stand in a crucifixionlike pose, a cowering man on a dog leash — were evidence not of just a “few bad apples” among the prison guards but, as an Army investigation found, documentation of a systemic problem: Military personnel had perpetrated “numerous incidents of sadistic, blatant, and wanton criminal abuses.” The abuses had roots in decisions made at the highest levels of the Bush administration, which asserted that the United States need not abide by the Geneva Conventions in its war on terror.

headline: 13 Noteworthy Watches from Baselworld
abstract: Despite a wobbly world economy, the appetite for luxury watches showed no signs of slowing at this year’s Baselworld.
lead_paragraph: Despite a wobbly world economy, the appetite for luxury watches showed no signs of slowing at this year’s Baselworld.

headline: Three Days at Baselworld, the World’s Biggest Watch Fair
abstract: Donning silk gloves (and sometimes watches on each wrist), the watch intelligentsia gathered in the Swiss resort town in March to inspect the splashiest new timepieces of 2016.

headline: Columbia Students Protest a Henry Moore Sculpture
abstract: A student op-ed piece says that the work, to be put in front of Butler Library, looks like “a poorly formed pterodactyl” and doesn’t fit in with the campus.
lead_paragraph: Sculptures by Henry Moore, one of the most influential and celebrated British artists of the 20th century, are on public display in parks and plazas around the world. They reside in major museums like the Tate and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. But plans to install one of Moore’s works at Columbia University has made students angry.

headline: Black Girls Rock! Holds Up an Unapologetic Mirror
keywords: ['Television', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: The organization, which is at the forefront of uplifting young women, is flourishing as they make gains and a national conversation shifts.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Shonda Rhimes held hands with Cicely Tyson. Kelly Rowland gushed over Tracee Ellis Ross. Rihanna doled out hugs and snapped photos with young girls.

headline: Wanted: Cruise Lecturers Who Mingle and Take Good Selfies
abstract: Social media and more demanding passengers have moved the cruise line lecture beyond a couple of talks made in exchange for a discounted cabin.
lead_paragraph: Mark P. Hertling, a retired three-star Army general, now gives speeches on corporate leadership. So when a friend suggested he try giving lectures to passengers on a cruise ship, it seemed like a good way for him and his wife to take an affordable vacation.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Bernie Sanders, Kansas City Royals, Donald Trump
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Man Who Stole Jazz Pianist Cecil Taylor’s Prize Money Is Sentenced
abstract: Noel Muir, who took nearly $500,000 awarded to Mr. Taylor, could spend up to three years in prison for larceny.
lead_paragraph: A Long Island contractor was sentenced on Monday to one to three years in prison for stealing nearly $500,000 in prize money awarded to his friend, the jazz pianist Cecil Taylor.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Brass Foundry Is Closing, but Debate Over Degas’s Work Goes On
abstract: The Valsuani foundry, near Paris, has been ordered to liquidate, again bringing attention to whether liberties have been taken with the Degas bronzes it has issued.
lead_paragraph: The Valsuani foundry, whose bronze sculptures by Edgar Degas have roiled the art market for more than a decade, is closing, by order of a French judge who ruled that its business, just outside Paris, should be liquidated to pay off creditors.

headline: Ethnic Conflict Between Armenia and Azerbaijan Flares Anew
abstract: A new round of fighting in the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region has killed at least 44 people.
lead_paragraph: STEPANAKERT, Azerbaijan — The old soldiers spilled out of buses into a square, fired up by a desire to fight, and to die if necessary, in a new war with an old enemy: the Azerbaijanis.

headline: New York Observer, Whose Editor Helped Donald Trump With Speech, Vows No More Such ‘Input’
abstract: The New York Observer’s editor helped the paper’s owner, Jared Kushner, write an important speech for his father-in-law — who happens to be the Republican presidential front-runner.
lead_paragraph: The New York Observer, which is owned by Donald J. Trump’s son-in-law, said Monday that its editorial staff would no longer aid or advise Mr. Trump’s presidential campaign, after a report that the paper’s editor had helped write a major foreign policy speech Mr. Trump gave two weeks ago.

headline: N.C.A.A. Championship: Villanova Beats North Carolina on Buzzer-Beater
abstract: “One Shining Moment”? You got it. Villanova beat North Carolina, 77 to 74. Villanova’s Kris Jenkins nailed a 3-pointer at the buzzer to give the Wildcats their first N.C.A.A. championship since 1985.

headline: Helicopter Crash Kills Five in Tennessee
abstract: A sightseeing helicopter crashed in east Tennessee on Monday afternoon, and was destroyed by a fire.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — At least five people were killed Monday when a sightseeing helicopter crashed in east Tennessee, the authorities said.

headline: Despite Fears, Affordable Care Act Has Not Uprooted Employer Coverage
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Employer-based insurance has held firm for the last five years, and federal officials predict it will continue to remain strong.
lead_paragraph: The Affordable Care Act was aimed mainly at giving people better options for buying health insurance on their own. There were widespread predictions that employers would leap at the chance to drop coverage and send workers to fend for themselves.

headline: Brooklyn Man Charged in Shooting and Robbery of Knicks’ Cleanthony Early
abstract: The suspect, Delvon Dowling, 22, was accused of being part of a group of masked men who surrounded Mr. Early’s Uber car when he left a strip club in Queens last year.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn man has been charged by federal prosecutors with taking part in the robbery and shooting of the New York Knicks forward Cleanthony Early late last year outside a strip club in Queens, court papers say.

headline: N.B.A. Games of the Week: Spurs vs. Warriors
abstract: To break the single-season win record, Golden State will need to beat San Antonio in at least one of the two games the teams are scheduled to play in the next week.
lead_paragraph: Longtime N.B.A. observers will tell you that Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich only cares about the regular season insofar as it affects his team’s chances in the playoffs. Individual accolades, particularly his own, seem to mean little to him. When he was asked, last February, about getting his thousandth career win, he responded in characteristic Pop fashion: “Give me a break,” he said.

headline: Crippling Strike in France May Have Been About More Than Labor Law
abstract: The walkout appeared to have less to do with proposed changes to labor law than disaffection with President François Hollande’s government.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was published several years ago, but a cartoon on the front page of the French newspaper Le Monde roughly summed up the situation across the country last Thursday when several hundred thousand public employees and students went on strike.

headline: Modern-Day Bullfighting
abstract: When Alex Quesada met a teenager who was training to become a bullfighter, he wondered why a child of privilege would embrace “a medieval blood sport.”
lead_paragraph: When Alex Quesada met a teenager who was training to become a bullfighter, he wondered why a child of privilege would embrace “a medieval blood sport.”

headline: The Marketing Power of Sports’ Stars
abstract: Public interest in top athletes routinely translates into advertising gold.
lead_paragraph: With only four months left before the start of the Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, marketing executives throughout the world are well along in their hunt for the next big stars in sports — and in advertising.

headline: Hedge Funds Sue to Freeze Puerto Rico Bank’s Assets
abstract: The group of funds, which own bonds on the island, based part of their suit on a confidential report that found the Government Development Bank insolvent.
lead_paragraph: A group of hedge funds asked a federal court in San Juan on Monday to freeze the assets of Puerto Rico’s powerful Government Development Bank, claiming it was insolvent and appeared to be spending what cash it had left to prop up other parts of the island’s troubled government.

headline: Ukraine: Conflict Brings Hunger Crisis
abstract: The two-year-old conflict in eastern Ukraine has left about 1.5 million people hungry, including nearly 300,000 in need of immediate help, the World Food Program said.
lead_paragraph: The two-year-old conflict in eastern Ukraine has left about 1.5 million people hungry, including nearly 300,000 in need of immediate help, the World Food Program, the main anti-hunger humanitarian agency of the United Nations, said on Monday. “As the conflict continues, we need to reach these people urgently,” the agency’s representative in Ukraine, Giancarlo Stopponi, said in a statement. The numbers of hungry Ukrainians have multiplied since the agency first intervened late in 2014 to help feed people upended in the conflict, distributing emergency rations and cash. Ukraine was historically known as Europe’s breadbasket for its rich soil and agricultural output. As of the first quarter of 2016, Ukraine is the only country in Europe to require and receive assistance from the World Food Program.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Set Date for Next Debate
abstract: After weeks of bickering, Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders have agreed to meet for a debate on April 14 in Brooklyn, less than a week before New Yorkers head to the polls for the critical April 19 primary.
lead_paragraph: The debate about the next Democratic debate is, finally, settled.

headline: Amtrak Trying to Determine if Workers Were Authorized to Be on Tracks
abstract: Determining who was at fault in the accident in Chester, Pa., will require further study of Amtrak’s records, the lead investigator for the N.T.S.B. said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Amtrak train that slammed into a backhoe on Sunday morning in Chester, Pa., leaving two workers dead on the tracks, was barreling along at 106 miles an hour seconds before the crash, federal investigators said on Monday.

abstract: The new rules take particular aim at companies that have completed multiple acquisitions of American companies in a short period.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department took new steps on Monday to further curtail a popular type of merger in which an American company buys a foreign counterpart, then moves abroad to lower its tax bill.

headline: What Are the Panama Papers?
abstract: A law firm’s leaked documents name international politicians, business leaders and celebrities involved in webs of suspicious financial transactions.
lead_paragraph: The Panama Papers have exposed how some of the world’s most powerful people may have used offshore bank accounts and shell companies to conceal their wealth or avoid taxes.

headline: After Petition, Greg Louganis Gets His Wheaties Box
abstract: Louganis, a four-time Olympic gold medalist as a diver, will begin appearing on boxes next month, along with two other overlooked Olympic champions: Edwin Moses and Janet Evans.
lead_paragraph: Eight months after a documentary about the diver Greg Louganis inspired an online petition asking that he be belatedly featured on the cover of a Wheaties box, the cereal’s maker is announcing that it will do just that.

headline: Supreme Court Is Working Hard to Avoid Deadlocks, Kagan Says

headline: Big East Finds Respect Is More Elusive Than Success
abstract: At Villanova, football is played only when basketball options have been exhausted, which makes it and its conference anomalies on the big-time college basketball scene.

headline: Ted Cruz Is Fuming Because John Kasich Won’t Bow Out
abstract: As Senator Ted Cruz looks beyond Wisconsin, where he is favored to win on Tuesday, his frustrations with the Ohio governor have increasingly been laid bare.
lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, eyeing a victory here that could reshape the race for the Republican presidential nomination, has appeared most vexed by a rival he views as more of a long-term nuisance than a short-term threat: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio.

lead_paragraph: A 63-year-old man was killed in Brooklyn on Monday after he pursued a man who had stolen his truck and then ran him over with the vehicle, the police said.

headline: Ted Cruz, Sensing Victory in Wisconsin, Strolls Through a Castle of Cheese
abstract: Mr. Cruz — joined by his wife, his two Cheesehead-wearing daughters and Gov. Scott Walker — visited the Mars Cheese Castle in Kenosha on the eve of the Wisconsin primary.

lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Donald J. Trump — he of the glamorous wives and high-profile romances — likes to boast of his prowess with women.

headline: U.N. Strives for Transparency in Picking New Secretary General
abstract: While the United Nations is trying to make the selection of a new secretary general more transparent, the world powers are, as usual, expected to exert undue influence over the process itself.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — For the first time in the history of the United Nations, those vying to be the next secretary general have to post their résumés, subject themselves to open hearings and declare publicly why they want this plummy — and thankless — job.

headline: ‘Our Young Man’ Reframes a 19th-Century Work in the 1980s
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Edmund White, novelist, memoirist and chronicler of gay life in New York, has a new book out this week.
lead_paragraph: Edmund White is one of the pre-eminent chroniclers of modern gay life, yet he often follows assured comments with self-deprecating caveats. Earned wisdom comes with “But why should you listen to my advice?,” and he is quick to say that plot isn’t his strong point.

headline: Review: ‘Antlia Pneumatica,’ With Voices in the Dark
abstract: Anne Washburn’s play, at Playwrights Horizons, brings old friends together for a funeral and blurs the borders between worlds.
lead_paragraph: Audiences for Anne Washburn’s “Antlia Pneumatica,” which opened on Monday night at Playwrights Horizons, could be excused for wondering if its title might be ancient Greek for “The Big Chill.” Like that popular Lawrence Kasdan movie from 1983, this brow-furrowing work from the author of “Mr. Burns” reunites a group of scattered friends on the cusp of middle age when one of their old gang dies abruptly.

headline: Celebrity Guest Solver Neal Pollack
abstract: Celebrity guest solver Neal Pollack joins us for Dan Schoenholz’s Tuesday puzzle.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — It’s not often that Wordplay acts as a trigger for solvers, so you can imagine my surprise to learn that crossword puzzles make author Neal Pollack sick. In his notes below you’ll learn why, but I’d like to publicly apologize to him for triggering any “sinking feeling, nausea and … fear of fiery death” this puzzle might have invoked.

headline: With a Stand-Alone App, Starz Looks Beyond the Cable Bundle

lead_paragraph: If prosecutors have their way, Dean G. Skelos, the former majority leader of the New York State Senate, will be sentenced to about 12 to 15 years in prison for his conviction on federal corruption charges in December.

headline: A Spot at Augusta, Finally, and a Comrade in Trump
abstract: After shooting a sizzling round in March with Donald J. Trump, who helped finance his career, Jim Herman earned his first PGA Tour win and a berth in his first Masters.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Donald J. Trump jumped at the opportunity to make Jim Herman’s game great. Trump, the front-runner for the Republican presidential nomination, peeled away from the campaign trail last month to play a round of golf with Herman, whose PGA Tour career he has helped finance.

headline: District Fight May Persist in Texas After Supreme Court Ruling
abstract: A Supreme Court ruling on Texas Senate districts is a setback for conservatives who want to limit that redistricting population to eligible voters, but it was probably not the final word.
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — With a long-running legal struggle raging over one of the nation’s strictest voter identification laws, Texas was already a prime battleground in a war between conservatives and liberals over voting rights. And on Monday, experts here and elsewhere say, the Supreme Court may have opened a second front.

headline: Islanders’ Offense Awakens After Coach’s Scolding

headline: Meeting Merrick Garland to Tell Him Why G.O.P. Won’t Hold Hearings

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Charles E. Grassley, the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, on Monday invited President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee to breakfast to explain, face to face, why Republicans have no intention of holding hearings on his appointment.

headline: U.S. Seeks Answers to Delays at Phoenix-Area Polls on Primary Day

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 2, Episode 8: Touch of Evil
abstract: It was arts and crafts week for both Jimmy and Mike.
lead_paragraph: Apparently, it was arts and crafts week on “Better Call Saul.” Jimmy deploys an X-acto knife, some glue and a pair of tweezers to sabotage legal documents stacked in his brother’s house. Mike uses a hammer, a hose and some nails to make — actually, I’m not sure what he’s making, but it sure looks as if it could inflict pain. Or destroy tires. It could inflict pain, then destroy tires.

keywords: ['Privacy', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Celebrities', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)']

lead_paragraph: HULK HOGAN’S lawsuit against Gawker Media, heard in a Florida courtroom last month, had the surreal quality of, well, a professional wrestling match. Mr. Hogan sued the company after Gawker posted a video clip showing the wrestler having sex with the then-wife of his then-friend, the radio personality Bubba the Love Sponge.

abstract: The social fabric needs to be rewoven for the 21st century.

Economic globalization is creating wider opportunity but also inequality. The Internet is giving people more choices over what to buy and pay attention to. A culture of autonomy valorizes individual choice and self-determination.

lead_paragraph: If the United States is going to get serious about cutting carbon emissions from oil and gas, it will have to find ways to scale up its use of renewable energy. Russia, still facing Western sanctions, cannot buy as much high-tech energy equipment.

Stanley Hall left his home in the tiny village of Ashfield, Mass., for Williams College, just 35 miles away, with a goal to “do something and be something in the world.” His mother wanted him to become a minister, but the young Stanley wasn’t sure about that plan. headline: Love in the Time of Monogamy
abstract: What happens when scholars take on the morally controversial question of polygamy?
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to say how many people in the United States practice polygamy — estimates vary widely, from 20,000 to half a million — but it’s clear most of their fellow Americans disapprove. In a 2013 Gallup poll about morally controversial issues, a mere 14 percent of the public said they accepted polygamy (only adultery and cloning humans had lower approval rates). An earlier poll found two-thirds of the public felt the government had a right to outlaw the practice, which typically takes the form of a married man also living in a marriage-type relationship with other women. So don’t read too much into the popularity of TV shows like “Sister Wives” and “Big Love.” The country is not ready for plural marriage.

headline: Gucci Calls for End to Separation of the Sexes on the Runway
abstract: The anchor brand of the Kering group will no longer hold different shows for men’s and women’s wear, but will combine them.
lead_paragraph: The move toward mixed gender fashion shows is getting a big-name boost — from Gucci. On Tuesday at The New York Times International Luxury conference in Versailles, France, Marco Bizzarri, chief executive of the brand, called for an end to separation of the sexes, or at least to their collections. From 2017, he said, the anchor brand of the Kering group will no longer hold different shows for men’s and women’s wear, but will rather combine the two into a single show, to be held each season.

headline: Morning Agenda: U.S. Moves to Restrict Foreign Deals Intended to Avoid Taxes
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Assets, Frozen', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Legal Profession', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Tax Evasion', 'Taxation']
abstract: ValueAct Is Accused of Violating Antitrust Law | Ruling on Freezing Assets Affirms Right to Lawyer
lead_paragraph: U.S. MOVES TO RESTRICT FOREIGN DEALS INTENDED TO AVOID TAXES | The Treasury Department took additional steps on Monday to discourage American companies from making foreign acquisitions so that they can move overseas for a lower tax rate,  Leslie Picker and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. The Treasury Department had issued rules in September 2014 and in November to restrict this type of acquisition, known as a corporate inversion, but the measures announced on Monday are aimed at what the government calls “serial inverters,” or foreign companies that have bulked up through multiple deals with American companies in a short period. The new rules threaten Pfizer’s proposed $150 billion takeover of Allergan, a drug maker based in Dublin. Though the Pfizer-Allergan deal is not structured as an inversion (technically Allergan is the acquirer and Pfizer is the target), it still achieves the same goal of a lower tax rate abroad.

headline: Why Germany Slips When China Swoons

headline: The C.E.O. of ‘Hamilton’ Inc.
abstract: The producer Jeffrey Seller struck gold with Lin-Manuel Miranda’s Broadway hit about the founding fathers. Now he has a new challenge — managing a runaway success.
lead_paragraph: As the lead producer of the hit musical “Hamilton,” Jeffrey Seller straddles a divide between art and commerce. In his appearance and manner, he takes pains not to come across as a suit, the money guy in a bohemian world of waiters and food runners who have scraped, sweated and auditioned their way onto Broadway. Trim and fit from a regimen of swimming and yoga, he naturally folds himself into his surprisingly small Midtown office, which has room for a desk, a couch and not much else. Most days, Seller shows up in jeans (or shorts in warmer weather) and an untucked button-­down shirt with a bicycle helmet clipped to his backpack. I told him once that it’s nice he doesn’t have to care too much about how he dresses for work. “Oh, believe me,” he said, “I do care.” At the musical’s opening night on Broadway and the over-the-top party that followed (live music by the Roots, fireworks over the Hudson River), he wore a whimsical black suit from the Band of Outsiders label; the white stripes on the jacket lapels made him look a little like a bellhop.

headline: The Dark History of Defending the ‘Homeland’
keywords: ['English Language', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: In other countries, the word calls to mind a warm, shared past. In the United States, it has come to signify a permanently endangered, fearful place.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, the screenwriter and producer Alex Gansa finished the script for a political thriller involving a deeply troubled C.I.A. agent and a soldier who had been turned by the Taliban, and began thinking about a title. He recalls that he wanted a word or phrase to conjure an atmosphere of “creepy subversion” — something sinister, xenophobic, un-American. “Shadowland”? No, not quite. “Homeland”? Perfect.

headline: Does My Family Own a Painting Looted by Nazis?
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: I’ve spent four years researching an artwork that passed through Nazi hands and now hangs in a relative’s home. The more I dig, the more I find murk.
lead_paragraph: For decades, it hung near the dining room inside a family home: a genre painting by a Dutch old master depicting an old man and his wife weighing and counting their gold coins. Judged a genuine work by Jan Steen and dated to the 1660s, it was once valued at $400,000.

headline: In Paris Bakeries, Liberté From Gluten
abstract: Paris bakeries and cafes are increasingly offering tantalizing alternatives for customers who can’t eat wheat.
lead_paragraph: Paris’s ubiquitous corner boulangeries have long been temples to gluten, with their baguettes, croissants and decadent patisseries. And yet, of all food trends, it is gluten-free that is taking hold. In Paris, you can now find bakeries selling breads and sweet creations made, as the French say, “sans gluten.” Specialized cafes offer gluten-free sandwiches, and gluten-free goods have taken over their own aisle at the supermarket.

headline: 1966: Premier Backs Down

lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — In 1971, Bengali nationalists and the people of what was then called East Pakistan waged a war of independence against the Pakistani Army. The conflict culminated in the birth of a new nation, Bangladesh. The war, which lasted nine months, was a brutal one: Depending on the source, some 300,000 to three million people were killed, and millions were displaced.

headline: Momosan Ramen & Sake Moves Into Murray Hill
abstract: Also, soul food from Butterfunk Kitchen in Windsor Terrace, Citi Field’s world beyond hot dogs, Anne Burrell returns to a restaurant, and more.
lead_paragraph: Momosan Ramen & Sake Masaharu Morimoto has used his nickname for this relaxed ramen restaurant, a new direction for the chef, who has a global empire of Morimoto restaurants. On the ramen front, he’s breaking new ground: There are four varieties on the menu, all available in two sizes. His long-simmered pork chashu, the basis of many ramen dishes, is cut into thin ribbons using a classic red Italian hand-cranked ham slicer on the bar. And with Sun Noodle, his supplier, he developed a noodle that does not become soggy as quickly as most. Some of the ramen bowls are classic, like the tonkotsu, though Mr. Morimoto’s executive chef, Jae Lee, is Korean, and was given the liberty to indulge his taste for chiles and kimchi in a number of dishes. “Morimoto likes the fusion approach,” Mr. Lee said. That means Peking duck tacos, and a complex take on bibimbap, called chashu bop, that comes sizzling in a stoneware bowl with crispy rice on the bottom. Sake, beer and wine are poured, and mixed into cocktails with Asian fruits. The white brick restaurant is simply furnished, with high and low dark wood tables and effective lighting. (Opens Friday): 342 Lexington Avenue (39th Street), 646-201-5529, momosanramen.com.

headline: A Writer’s Room: Mark Haddon
abstract: The novelist on his basement office in Oxford, England, where he wrote some of his forthcoming collection, “The Pier Falls and Other Stories.”
lead_paragraph: I BEGIN MOST WEEKDAY mornings circulating between cafes, writing on a laptop with the distraction-blocking software Freedom running. I need some outdoor air and the hubbub of strangers to give me a connection to the real world. I return home around lunchtime and retreat to my office in the basement. It’s sufficiently subterranean to give it a comforting burrow atmosphere, but with windows big enough to make it spacious and light.

It may be Hong Kong, and it may be only one campaign, but companies should be fearful.

headline: Can Economies Rise as Emissions Fall? The Evidence Says Yes
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: The question is whether what happened in 21 countries can be a model for the rest of the world.
lead_paragraph: Throughout the 20th century, the global economy was fueled by burning coal to run factories and power plants, and burning oil to move planes, trains and automobiles. The more coal and oil countries burned — and the more planet-warming carbon dioxide they emitted — the higher the economic growth.

headline: Thomas Jefferson, Neither God Nor Devil
abstract: The third president has had a tough time lately, and not just in “Hamilton.” A new book, by a scholarly “dream team,” strives to go beyond hero worship and caricature.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Jefferson has long been a lightning rod, but the past year has been tougher on him than usual. Protesters on college campuses have plastered Jefferson statues with Post-it notes reading “racist” and “rapist.” And on Broadway, the musical “Hamilton” has deliciously skewered him as a flamboyantly scheming hypocrite.

headline: A Team Sets a High Bar, and Then Surpasses It Yet Again

It demonstrated that Barrow — who has garnered positive attention since she debuted her line two years ago — has a strong interest in art.

headline: Don’t Send Your Kids to College. At Least Not Yet.
abstract: The gap year can be a launch pad.
lead_paragraph: In the past few weeks, anxious high school seniors across the country have received admissions decisions from colleges. Some might feel like they’ve won the lottery; others have dashed hopes and diminished confidence. Few in either category realize how little these outcomes matter in the long run; that, as Frank Bruni puts it, “where you go is not who you’ll be.”

headline: A Very Short Story by Lydia Davis — on a Bottle of Mouthwash
abstract: The Paris Review partnered with Aesop to create limited-edition party favors featuring the author’s “Spring Spleen” for its Spring Revel tonight.
lead_paragraph: “It hasn’t exactly been my dream to see my work printed on a bottle of mouthwash,” admits the writer Lydia Davis — but tonight, she’ll see just that. At its annual Spring Revel this evening, The Paris Review will honor Davis with the Hadada, its lifetime achievement award, and has partnered with Aesop to create a limited-edition bottle printed with Davis’s short story “Spring Spleen” for the event’s gift bags. “I wasn’t even aware there was such a plan in the works,” Davis said in an email. “I was very surprised and amused.”

headline: Photos from Carrie Mae Weems’s “Kitchen Table Series”
abstract: The project is now contained in a stand-alone book.
lead_paragraph: The project is now contained in a stand-alone book.

headline: Revisiting Carrie Mae Weems’s Indelible Series — Almost Three Decades Later
abstract: The artist’s iconic “Kitchen Table” pictures are now the subject of a stand-alone book.
lead_paragraph: When they think of Carrie Mae Weems, most people picture a black-and-white image of the artist seated under a hanging lamp playing solitaire or a snapshot of her swooping down to embrace her partner as he reads the newspaper, both from her “Kitchen Table Series” — some of her most iconic work. Photographed from 1989-90, “Kitchen Table” earned labels like “career-making” and is considered the moment when Weems, 62 — who has received the MacArthur “genius” grant and U.S. Department of State’s Medal of Arts — “found her artistic voice.” Institutions including the Museum of Modern Art, the Guggenheim, the Philadelphia Museum of Art, the Seattle Art Museum and the Los Angeles County Museum of Art have exhibited part of, or the entirety of, the 20 photos and 14 text panels during the last three decades. But, despite the series’ significance, and its total adaptability, it hadn’t been published on its own — until now. The idea came about when the graphic designer Takaaki Matsumoto approached Weems several years ago. “‘Kitchen Table’ has been printed many times, but never as a stand-alone book,” she says. “This is the first time that anyone has asked to focus on the series as its own entity. I am grateful to him for both designing and publishing the work, because it needed to stand on its own.”

headline: In Search of a New State Slogan
abstract: When Rhode Island announced its new state slogan, “Cooler and Warmer,” reaction was swift — and scornful. Readers can make their own suggestions.
lead_paragraph: When Rhode Island announced its new state slogan, “Cooler and Warmer,” reaction was swift — and scornful. Readers can make their own suggestions.

headline: Review: ‘Locusts Have No King,’ a Love Triangle Comedy
abstract: The four characters in J. Julian Christopher’s play consider this question: Is the priesthood a closet, a refuge or both?
lead_paragraph: Reading the script before I saw a performance of J. Julian Christopher’s “Locusts Have No King,” I wondered how big a spoiler it would be to mention in this review a central fact of the play that the publicity materials skirt. A love-triangle comedy with a supernatural streak, the show unfolds in the course of an evening at the home of Marcus and Jonathan, who have invited another couple, Lucus and Matthew, over for dinner.

lead_paragraph: Several tomes — on subjects including Issey Miyake and John Galliano — for your coffee table.

headline: Review: In ‘Tía Julia y el Escribidor,’ a Student Is Smitten
abstract: This Caridad Svich adaptation of Mario Vargas Llosa’s novel features romance and farce set in 1950s Peru.
lead_paragraph: Romance meets boisterous farce in “Tía Julia y el Escribidor” (“Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter”), Caridad Svich’s lively adaptation of Mario Vargas Llosa’s autobiographical novel, at the Gramercy Arts Theater. And in that intersection, it’s the romance that triumphs.

headline: Review: In ‘Love Und Greed,’ Mad Jenny Doffs Her Hat to the Have-Nots
abstract: This performer, a.k.a. Jenny Lee Mitchell, has brought a cabaret show to Pangea that draws comparisons between Weimar-era Berlin and today’s New York.
lead_paragraph: “History does repeat itself,” announces a postcard advertising “Love und Greed,” the provocative political and historical cabaret created by Mad Jenny, a.k.a. Jenny Lee Mitchell, who appeared at Pangea on Monday evening. Most of its songs, sung in a mixture of German and English, date from the Weimar era and are interspersed with modern pop standards whose sarcastic attitude echoes the cynicism of that period in Berlin, before Hitler took power.

headline: Documentary Film Festivals Feel Push on Accuracy
abstract: As the number of films grows, film festival programmers face more pressure to serve as judges of fairness and accuracy.
lead_paragraph: Doctors and other public health professionals may be relieved that the controversial documentary “Vaxxed,” about the long-discredited link between autism and vaccines, was yanked from the Tribeca Film Festival. But its expulsion has also highlighted consternation among other festival organizers, who have been feeling the burden of extra scrutiny. As documentarians multiply, pointing their cameras at ever more esoteric, provocative and sometimes contentious stories, there is increasing pressure on programmers to act not just as quality control but also perhaps as judges of fairness and accuracy. Especially since the films themselves are more picked apart.

headline: Review: In ‘Vita Activa: The Spirit of Hannah Arendt,’ a Thinker More Relevant Than Ever
abstract: This documentary examines the controversies over Arendt’s coverage of the Eichmann war crimes trial and her writings on totalitarianism.
lead_paragraph: Hannah Arendt, who died in 1975, was a prolific and unclassifiable thinker, a political theorist, moral philosopher and polemicist of unmatched range and rigor. At least outside academic circles, her posthumous fame — or notoriety — rests on “Eichmann in Jerusalem,” a piece of extended reportage she wrote for The New Yorker in 1963, and on a single phrase associated with it: the banality of evil.

lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders defeated Hillary Clinton in the Wisconsin primary on Tuesday, his sixth straight victory in the Democratic nominating contest and the latest in a string of setbacks for Mrs. Clinton as she seeks to put an end to a prolonged race against an unexpectedly deft and well-funded competitor.

abstract: The Rev. D. Alexandra Dyer, executive director of the Healing Arts Initiative in Queens, was severely burned when someone tossed drain cleaner at her. A co-worker was among three people arrested.
lead_paragraph: One evening in August, an executive director of an arts nonprofit in Queens was leaving her office for the day when a man holding a cup approached her, the authorities said. The cup was filled with a chemical drain cleaner, and he flung the liquid at her, severely burning her face.

headline: Noah Syndergaard Steadies Mets as Royals Temper Emotions
abstract: The Royals did not retaliate for a high and tight pitch Syndergaard threw to Alcides Escobar in Game 3 of last year’s World Series, and the Mets left Kansas City with their heads held high, having split the two-game series.
lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — As Noah Syndergaard took the mound in the first inning Tuesday at Kauffman Stadium, just the mere sight of him prompted Royals fans to boo. He dug his cleat into the dirt, and tried blocking it out, but he could not help hearing “American Woman” playing, presumably a nod to his long, blond hair.

headline: Pennsylvania: Bill Extending Deadlines in Abuse Cases Advances
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Legislators, under pressure after the release of a grand jury report documenting an extensive cover-up of clergy sexual abuse, took action on Tuesday to give victims more time to seek justice.
lead_paragraph: The State Legislature, under pressure after the release of a grand jury report documenting an extensive cover-up of clergy sexual abuse in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Altoona-Johnstown, took action on Tuesday to give victims more time to seek justice. Many child abuse victims do not speak up until later in life, citing shame or fear. The House Judiciary Committee passed a bill that would change the state’s statute of limitations in child sexual abuse cases, eliminating the time limit for bringing criminal charges and extending the deadline for victims to file civil lawsuits to age 50 from age 30. The bill was amended to include child sexual abuse cases against schoolteachers and government officials. The legislation is scheduled to be brought to the full House on Monday.

abstract: James A. Baker, the F.B.I.’s general counsel, said the bureau was still working on putting the extracted data to use.

He was 100.

Her agenda borders on a permanent ritual: Wear her Wings apparel and cheer for her beloved hockey team in the N.H.L. playoffs.

headline: Robert Iger’s Success at Disney Makes Him a Tough Act to Follow
abstract: As the conglomerate looks for a new leader, it’s having difficulty finding someone, even the heir apparent, who appears able to measure up.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On Monday night, as a stunned Hollywood scrambled to understand why Disney’s heir apparent, Thomas O. Staggs, had abruptly decided to step down, the company held a lavish premiere for its “Jungle Book” movie.

headline: The Panama Papers’ Sprawling Web of Corruption
keywords: ['Panama Papers', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Tax Evasion', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Tax Shelters', 'Editorials']
abstract: The leaked files reveal an industry that flourishes in the gaps and holes of international finance.
lead_paragraph: The first reaction to the leaked documents dubbed the Panama Papers is simply awe at the scope of the trove and the ingenuity of the anonymous source who provided the press with 11.5 million documents — 2.6 terabytes of data — revealing in extraordinary detail how offshore bank accounts and tax havens are used by the world’s rich and powerful to conceal their wealth or avoid taxes.

abstract: Ms. Hardison immortalized African-American historical figures as well as ordinary black citizens in her sculptures.
lead_paragraph: Inge Hardison, whose bronze sculptures immortalized black historical figures, innovators and ordinary people she characterized as “Our Folks,” died on March 23 in Manhattan. She was 102.

headline: A Wall Street Family’s Charmed Life Is Thrown Into Turmoil
abstract: Andrew Caspersen came from a world of privilege, blown apart by allegations that he conducted a fraudulent investment scheme.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Caspersen violated a circle of trust that included colleagues, a Princeton classmate and even his wealthy family when he raised tens of millions of dollars for what authorities have called a fraudulent investment scheme that has rattled Wall Street.

headline: In the Bleachers, Few Starry-Eyed Views
abstract: A sampling of opinions found bleacher fans more or less in agreement: The Yankees will win 85 to 88 games, which may or may not keep them close in an A.L. East race with Toronto and Boston.
lead_paragraph: Out beyond the right-field wall in Section 203, the Bleacher Creatures at Yankee Stadium believe they know the difference between a proper title contender and a mere placeholder.

headline: Italian Official Warns Egypt Over Inquiry Into Student’s Death
abstract: A slow-moving investigation into the killing, hampered by troubled cooperation between Italian and Egyptian police, has prompted Italian accusations of an Egyptian cover-up.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The foreign minister of Italy said Tuesday that his government would take “immediate and proportional” measures against Egypt if it failed to help uncover the truth behind the death of an Italian graduate student in Cairo two months ago.

headline: Armenia and Azerbaijan Halt Fighting on Border
abstract: A cease-fire between Armenians and Azerbaijanis has put to rest, for now, fears that the conflict over the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region might spiral into a wider war.
lead_paragraph: JABRAYIL, Azerbaijan — Armenians and Azerbaijanis agreed on Tuesday to a cease-fire after four days of fighting along the border of a disputed region, putting to rest, at least for now, fears that the outbreak of ethnic strife might spiral into a wider war.

headline: Yankees Lose on a Play They Couldn’t Have Prepared For
abstract: A squibber up the first-base line, and an obstructed pitcher lobbing an alley-oop far over the bag. Maybe it was just a freak way to lose.
lead_paragraph: Baseball is a funny game, said Joe Garagiola, the old catcher and raconteur who died last month. That was the title of Garagiola’s book, and it explains so much about this fascinating and frustrating show, now playing daily for the next six months at a ballpark near you.

headline: Jordan Spieth, Humbly, Gets Ready to Defend Masters Crown
abstract: Spieth, who won the first two majors of 2015 and ended the year by buying a sprawling estate, is still tiptoeing around Augusta.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The question posed Tuesday to the reigning Masters champion was about winning four majors in the same year. Is a men’s calendar Grand Slam achievable? With his response, Jordan Spieth humorously addressed how his life changed in 2015 when he became only the second golfer in the last 43 years to win the first two legs.

headline: Some Yankees Tickets Require a Long Walk
abstract: Hundreds of Yankees fans, having made online purchases from StubHub, had to walk seven-tenths of a mile south from Yankee Stadium to a StubHub outlet to pick up tickets instead of printing at home.
lead_paragraph: After Monday’s rainout, Tuesday’s rescheduled Yankees home opener had the look of perfect baseball weather. But the temperature was in the mid-30s, with a slicing wind that the Arctic would envy. This fact was felt most acutely by the numerous fans who had bought their tickets from StubHub, a website for ticket resales.

headline: Brazil’s Congress Must Consider Impeaching Vice President
abstract: A justice on Brazil’s high court ruled that an impeachment request made against Michel Temer must be considered by Congress while it holds hearings about removing the president.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A justice on Brazil’s high court ruled on Tuesday that an impeachment request made against the country’s vice president, Michel Temer — who had been expected to take over the presidency if Dilma Rousseff were to be ousted — must also be considered by the country’s Congress while it holds hearings about removing Ms. Rousseff.

headline: Rolling Stones to Release First Studio Album Since 2005
abstract: The Stones, after ending a stadium tour of Latin America with a Havana concert, told the BBC that they were in the studio recording new material and blues covers.
lead_paragraph: Since the Rolling Stones released their last studio album, “A Bigger Bang,” in September 2005, the group seems to have been working full throttle — mostly as a road act playing packed stadiums.

headline: What Is It?
abstract: Timothy Polin asks an important question.
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Music and Puzzle Lovers’ Alert! Pete Muller’s “Muller Monthly Music Meta” is a fun and free award-winning monthly crossword, published at noon Eastern time on the first Tuesday of each month. To finish the puzzle, solvers need to figure out the meta, which is usually a song or band. Solvers have until that Sunday at 11:00 p.m. Eastern time. to submit their answer to the meta. In addition to these metas, the 12 monthly puzzles include a mega-meta. The 13th and final puzzle of the year is published on the last Tuesday of December, and gives hints for the mega-meta. Click here for more information.

headline: Whitney Museum’s New Home Named After Leonard Lauder
abstract: Mr. Lauder has been one of the largest donors to the Whitney Museum of American Art, as well as its chairman emeritus.
lead_paragraph: Leonard A. Lauder, the Whitney Museum of American Art’s chairman emeritus, initially opposed the museum’s move downtown to its new home in the Meatpacking district from the Breuer building on Madison Avenue.

headline: For Masters, Waiting Is the Hardest Part
abstract: The first shot of this year’s Masters will be struck 235 days after the last putt of the P.G.A. Championship, rattling some players’ nerves.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Adam Scott had to go two extra holes of sudden death with Ángel Cabrera to become the first Australian to win the Masters. Scott said he was less nervous before the start of that 2013 playoff than he will be Thursday when he stands at the No. 1 tee box for the first drive of his 15th Masters.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Condominiums']
