lead_paragraph: For Donald J. Trump, it is a long-held legal strategy, if not a point of pride, to avoid knuckling under to plaintiffs in court.

headline: Mets Decide They Are Done Reliving October

lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Finally, after a second day of watching the Royals rub their World Series victory in the Mets’ faces with another pregame victory celebration, one Met took umbrage.

keywords: ['Basketball (College)', 'Records and Achievements', 'Coaches and Managers', 'NCAA Basketball Championships (Women)']
abstract: The Huskies claimed their sixth undefeated season in team history, and Coach Geno Auriemma secured his 11th championship to surpass the U.C.L.A. men’s coach John Wooden for the most titles in college basketball.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Before Breanna Stewart had even played a game for Connecticut, she said her goal was to win four national titles in her four years.

headline: The Breakout Star of ‘The People v. O.J. Simpson’ on the Emotional Finale
abstract: In Mr. Darden, one of the prosecutors in “The People v. O.J. Simpson: American Crime Story,” Mr. Brown has had a breakout role.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday’s finale of “American Crime Story: The People v. O. J. Simpson” on FX wrapped up an addictive, multifaceted look at “the trial of the century” and how its lessons on race, gender, celebrity and social class still haunt the country more than 20 year later. It also brought a blessed end to the weekly torments visited upon Christopher Darden, the co-prosecutor who, along with Marcia Clark, fails to convict Mr. Simpson of double homicide in the murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman.

lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, has opened an investigation into a series of transactions surrounding the lifting of a deed restriction on a Manhattan nursing home that enabled its purchase by a luxury condominium developer for $116 million.

headline: Police Leaders Questioned Amid Inquiry of Businessmen Linked to de Blasio
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Campaign Finance', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: Up to 20 senior members of the Police Department have been interviewed recently by federal agents focused on two businessmen with ties to Mayor Bill de Blasio, according to three people familiar with the matter.
lead_paragraph: The visits, unannounced and in the early morning hours, began several weeks ago at houses and apartments in and around New York City. They followed a pattern: Two agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation would approach the front door and ring the bell. They would be invited in. Then the questions would come.

headline: How Donald Trump Lost Wisconsin
abstract: He spent the week before the primary free-associating on everything from abortion to Hiroshima.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz thumped Donald Trump in Wisconsin’s Republican primary on Tuesday, beating him by 13 percentage points. On the Democratic side, Bernie Sanders, who has won seven of the last eight state contests, racked up an important win against Hillary Clinton, a native Midwesterner, in a heartland state known for its progressive traditions.

headline: Law School Renamed for Antonin Scalia, Again. Blame Acronym.
abstract: George Mason University’s first attempt yielded an unflattering combination of letters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Antonin Scalia could be caustic in his dissents, but he was also known for a sharp wit that often drew laughter from Supreme Court audiences.

headline: ‘The People v. O.J. Simpson’ Finale: Still Not Guilty
abstract: We all knew the outcome, but this episode made it tense nonetheless.
lead_paragraph: O.J. Simpson was found not guilty for the murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ron Goldman. Everyone knows that, but this episode found a way to infuse that fact with tension. The evidence against O.J. was overwhelming, but this country’s history of racism helped produce a complex cultural moment in which a man accused of murder was set free in order to condemn a corrupt police force. In this episode, Chris Darden told Johnnie Cochran that this was “the first time in history a black defendant got off because he was black.” The only problem is that the acquittal doesn’t feel like justice.

headline: ‘The People v. O.J. Simpson’ Creators on the Finale, the Kardashians and the Race Card
abstract: Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski did not hesitate when they were asked to develop a series about the O.J. Simpson trial.
lead_paragraph: Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski are not television writers — they’re known more for eccentric biopics like “Ed Wood,” “Man on the Moon” and “The People vs. Larry Flynt.” But they didn’t hesitate when they were asked to develop a series about the O.J. Simpson trial.

headline: A Quieted Donald Trump Quickly Turns on ‘Lyin’ Ted’

lead_paragraph: There was no news conference, there were no Twitter posts. There was no steak, no wine, no bottled water.

abstract: McDonagh, who was hit in the right hand with a slap shot Monday, will be out indefinitely, the team announced.

headline: Ferguson Voters Give Split Result on Funding Police Overhaul
keywords: ['Property Taxes', 'Police', 'Referendums', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Voters in the St. Louis suburb turned down part of a tax increase package that city leaders had described as essential for carrying out a legal settlement with the Justice Department.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Ferguson, Mo., the St. Louis suburb that became known two years ago as a focal point of racial upheaval, voted on Tuesday to reject part of a tax increase package that city leaders had described as essential for carrying out a legal settlement with the Justice Department. The voters turned down a proposed property tax increase, but they also voted to raise the sales tax, leaving city officials with a mixed, uncertain result.

headline: Architect of China’s ‘Great Firewall’ Bumps Into It
abstract: During a presentation on digital security, the architect, Fang Binxing, was forced to use location-masking software to reach websites in South Korea.

headline: From Occupy Wall Street to the Arab Spring
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Photography']
abstract: A chance encounter with young Egyptians during the Occupy Wall Street protests led Matthew Connors to Cairo, where he documented the uprising. His new book, “Fire in Cairo,” showcases that work.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Connors spent much of 2012 in Lower Manhattan making portraits of the protesters in the Occupy Wall Street movement. But a chance encounter during the course of that project made him do a 180-degree turn after meeting some Egyptian activists who had participated in a different uprising: the Jan. 25 revolution that led to the ousting of President Hosni Mubarak. They convinced Mr. Connors that there was a more important struggle worth covering.

headline: Mosquito vs. Mosquito in the Battle Over the Zika Virus
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'Mosquitoes', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A genetically modified mosquito might eradicate the mosquito species that carries the Zika virus but must first survive a cumbersome approval process.
lead_paragraph: GENETICALLY modified mosquitoes are in the news for good reason: They may be our best hope for controlling the mosquito-borne Zika virus. The Food and Drug Administration has issued a preliminary finding of no significant environmental impact and is seeking public comment on a plan to test them in a field trial in the Florida Keys.

headline: The Military’s Transgender Policy, Stalled
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Pentagon missed its six-month deadline to allow openly transgender troops to serve. It’s time to end the ban.
lead_paragraph: Defense Secretary Ashton Carter announced last July that the Pentagon intended to allow transgender people to serve openly in the military within six months, calling the decades-long ban “outdated” and an impediment to attracting and retaining top talent.

headline: A Better Way to Get to $15
abstract: California and New York are headed to a higher minimum wage, but they are taking different paths to get there.
lead_paragraph: To their credit as trailblazers, both California and New York are now headed for a minimum wage of $15 an hour, but they are taking different paths to get there. California’s is more direct and offers a better model for other states and the federal government.

headline: Why Upperclassmen Lose Financial Aid
abstract: After freshman year, grants and scholarships may disappear for any number of reasons — some justified, some not.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks before Ashley Hurst was supposed to commit to college, an email arrived that she thought would change her life. An honors graduate from a magnet high school, Ms. Hurst had been accepted into several colleges with a few good financial aid offers. But they included about $8,000 in loans, and she was dead set against borrowing any money. She kept hoping to snag a free ride somewhere at the last minute.

headline: A Twist in Her Plot
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: I came to understand that embracing my identity had more to do with genre than gender.
lead_paragraph: I arrived at the Writing Seminars at Johns Hopkins in September 1985, bearing a box of books, a Kaypro word processor and a long blond wig I kept hidden in a box in the closet. I wasn’t out as transgender in those days, not by a long shot, but I did have the tools I needed to slip out of the house, once in a while, and prowl around Baltimore en femme. Then I’d head home, wash off the makeup and get ready for the workshop, taught by the writer John Barth.

headline: Wisconsin Takeaways: Donald Trump Stumbles and Bernie Sanders Soars, for Now
abstract: Can a single state make any real difference in a chaotic and unpredictable presidential primary season? Tuesday night’s dual Wisconsin primaries suggest so.
lead_paragraph: Can a single state make any real difference in a chaotic and unpredictable presidential primary season? Tuesday night’s dual Wisconsin primaries suggest so. The Republican field was down to three candidates, and the Democrats’ down to two. All were focused on the same state on the same day. The result was a clarifying glimpse into where Trumpism falters, where Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont can succeed, and whether each party’s establishment has the power to steer its own nomination.

headline: Does Exercise During Pregnancy Lead to Exercise-Loving Offspring?
abstract: Our will to work out may be influenced by a mother’s exercise habits during pregnancy, and begin as early as in the womb, according to findings from a study in mice.
lead_paragraph: Mice born to mothers that run during their pregnancies grow up to be rodents that love to run as adults, according to a thought-provoking new animal experiment, while pups with sedentary moms had a less-enthusiastic attitude toward exercise. Though it’s a long way from mice to people, the study’s findings hint at the possibility that to some extent our will to work out may be influenced by a mother’s exercise habits during pregnancy, and begin as early as in the womb.

headline: ‘Customers First’ to Become the Law in Retirement Investing
keywords: ['Retirement', 'Financial Brokers', 'Financial Planners', 'Individual Retirement Accounts', '401(k), 403(b) and 457 Plans', 'Consumer Protection', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']

headline: F.A.A. Reauthorization Bill in Senate Could Snag on Unrelated Tax Provisions
abstract: Democrats are seeking to use a measure reauthorizing the agency as a vehicle to close the loop on some tax breaks related to renewable energy that they say were inadvertently left out of a tax package last year.
lead_paragraph: Senate Republicans must feel mildly giddy that they may have an actual bill to pass on the Senate floor, where activities have been a tad limited as of late. But a measure to reauthorize the Federal Aviation Administration and keep airports running and planes in the air may get gummed up by unrelated tax provisions.

headline: Edinburgh Festival to Feature Shakespeare and a ‘Menagerie’ Return
abstract: Among the offerings: “Richard III” and a 1970s riff on “Twelfth Night.”
lead_paragraph: The august Edinburgh International Festival is not immune to an epidemic of Shakespeare fever that seems to be erupting worldwide in 2016, the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare’s death. Productions in German, Russian and French (all presented with supertitles) are to be included in this year’s festival, a popular international cultural attraction since 1947. The program was announced in Edinburgh on Wednesday morning.

headline: Glencore Agrees to Sell Minority Stake in Agriculture Business

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Swiss commodities and mining company Glencore said on Wednesday that it had agreed to sell a 40 percent stake in its agriculture business to Canada Pension Plan Investment Board for $2.5 billion in cash.

headline: Morning Agenda: Pfizer Said to Call Off Merger With Allergan
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Hedge Funds', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Taxation', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Justice Dept. Said to Oppose Halliburton-Baker Hughes Deal | A World of Privilege Blown Apart
lead_paragraph: PFIZER SAID TO CALL OFF MERGER WITH ALLERGAN | Just a day after the Treasury Department announced tougher rules to discourage American companies from moving overseas for a lower tax bill, Pfizer decided to abandon its $152 billion merger with Allergan, a person briefed on the matter  told Michael J. de la Merced and Leslie Picker of DealBook late Tuesday. The two drug companies could announce their decision as early as Wednesday morning, said the person, who was not authorized to speak publicly.  CNBC earlier reported the news of Pfizer’s decision.

headline: Michael Botticelli Is Not in Favor of Legalization
abstract: The federal drug czar on how recovering from alcoholism taught him to reduce stigmas against addicts and focus on public-health strategies instead.
lead_paragraph: As the first drug czar who is himself in recovery from alcohol addiction, do you think your approach is different from those of your predecessors? Looking back over the history of the office, it has typically been led by generals and police officers. It was really geared toward supply reduction and interdiction. We want to focus on public-health strategies.

headline: Airports, Designed for Everyone but the Passenger
abstract: As big-name architects create airports with ambitious goals in mind, it’s the smaller things — like comfy seating and adequate heating — that are missing.
lead_paragraph: One morning in 1977, Brian Eno, the electronica pioneer and former synthesizer player for the band Roxy Music, was sitting in an airport in Cologne, Germany, and was deeply disturbed.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Opening Numerous Bottles of Wine
abstract: Unless it’s an orgy, don’t even think about it.
lead_paragraph: Andrea writes: My husband insists on opening numerous bottles of wine at one time. I think you should finish one bottle before you open another because it doesn’t taste as good after it’s been open for a couple of days.

headline: Should a Nephew Be Told Who His Real Father Is?
keywords: ['Art', 'Parenting', 'Families and Family Life', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Education (K-12)', 'ADULTERY', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on passing off your child with someone else as your husband’s, buyer honesty and the costs of long-odds surgery.
lead_paragraph: My sister has told me that her son is not the biological son of her husband. His sperm count was very low; she was having an affair and became pregnant. The son looks not like his father but like the other man. Her son (he is now middle-aged) doesn’t know, and her husband (they’re now divorced) doesn’t, either. Recently, when my sister had a health crisis, she told the other man for the first time, asking him not to tell anyone. He told her that was his decision. He has no other children. Now he knows he has a son and a grandchild.

headline: The Unbearable Whiteness of Baseball
abstract: The sport is no longer America’s favorite pastime. Is it because of the rise of the N.B.A. and the N.F.L., or because of a racially coded obsession with “tradition”?
lead_paragraph: By instinct, honed reflex and general contrarianism, I root for all “flashy” “showboats” who are “disgraces to the game.” It has been this way since I left Boston at age 10 to move to North Carolina, a state with no notable baseball team save the minor-league Durham Bulls, who, at least when I was growing up, seemed more a Hollywood relic than a ball club. Freed from having to like the Red Sox, I began to root for Rickey Henderson of the Oakland Athletics, mostly because I liked how deeply he squatted while taking a lead off first base. He seemed as if he were taunting the pitcher. As I grew older and started feeling alienated from my white classmates, I gravitated toward athletes who, in some way, flouted the white, stoic traditions of American sports — Allen Iverson, Ken Griffey Jr., Rasheed Wallace, Pedro Martinez. I felt as if this was a moral choice.

headline: A $1,000 Day in San Francisco for $100
abstract: The Frugal Traveler adapts a high-end itinerary from a San Francisco concierge to a more frugal budget of $100, while retaining the general spirit.
lead_paragraph: Tom Wolfe, chief concierge at the Fairmont San Francisco, greeted me in the lobby of the palatial hotel, which opened in 1907 atop the expensive Nob Hill enclave. Impeccably dressed in a three-piece suit festooned with decorative pins, Mr. Wolfe claims to be first concierge in the United States — the concept didn’t exist in American hotels until the 1970s, he said. Richard Swig, who was then the owner of the Fairmont, asked Mr. Wolfe to create a concierge program in the image of hotels he had seen in Europe, where the service concept of “one-stop shopping,” as Mr. Wolfe put it, already existed.

headline: The New Europeans
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: As refugees stream into Europe, and terror attacks spark security fears, one Bavarian village grapples with newcomers — and with the question of what it means to be German.
lead_paragraph: Read in German

headline: North Korea May Roll Out Rocket System With Greater Reach, South Says
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Weapons']
abstract: The weapon, which could be used as soon as this year, would expand the North’s ability to hit South Korean and American military forces in the South, the defense minister said.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea could deploy a new rocket system as early as this year that would expand its ability to strike South Korean and American military forces in the South, South Korea’s defense minister said on Wednesday.

headline: E.U. Migrant Proposals Aim to Overhaul Asylum Rules
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Asylum, Right of']
abstract: The European Commission has suggested a mechanism to help countries overwhelmed by an influx of migrants.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Days after a wave of deportations of migrants arriving in Europe from Turkey, the European Union’s executive arm proposed a new quota system for members accepting asylum seekers to ease the burden on the nations confronted with an overwhelming influx.

headline: Pfizer Faces Limited Options After Its Dead Deal With Allergan
abstract: The company has been growing steadily, but investors are certain to start agitating again to complete a bold move in order to push growth higher.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer needs a Plan C.

headline: Warriors Have No Room for Error, or Spectacle
abstract: The Warriors have spent the season demoralizing opponents. But too often, Coach Steve Kerr said, they seek the spectacular rather than the simple.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — The game was just minutes old when Coach Steve Kerr sensed that it was beginning to slip away from the Golden State Warriors. They had played so well through the first six minutes of the first quarter against the Minnesota Timberwolves on Tuesday, but Kerr observed some of the same problems that had hindered his team in recent weeks.

headline: Risk of Collapse at Jesus’ Tomb Unites Rival Christians
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Tombs and Tombstones', 'Churches (Buildings)']
abstract: Three branches of Christianity are undertaking a $3.4 million renovation of the shrine holding Jesus’ tomb in the Church of the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — It was a typical day at the shrine around what many believe is the tomb of Jesus in Jerusalem’s Old City. A Greek Orthodox choir sang inside a room facing the baroque structure. But the voices were drowned out when chanting Armenian priests and monks circling the shrine raised theirs.

headline: A Plan to Change a Beloved Stamp Is Ruffling Feathers
abstract: The Fish and Wildlife Service wants to allow many birds to be depicted on the annual license stamps, changing a long tradition of depicting only birds that are hunted.
lead_paragraph: BOMBAY HOOK NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE, Del. — Is it political correctness, or a shrewd way to clean the scales off an 82-year-old federal program? Will it secure more money for wildlife, or wreck one of the better things the United States government has going?

headline: A New Rhode Island Slogan Encounters Social Media’s Wrath
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Slogans and Mottoes', 'Social Media']
abstract: The new slogan, “Rhode Island: Cooler and Warmer,” left people confused, and a quick and merciless derision followed. Within days, the state’s chief marketing officer resigned.
lead_paragraph: The idea was simple enough — to create a logo and slogan that cast the long-struggling state of Rhode Island in a fresh, more optimistic light to help attract tourists and businesses. A world-renowned designer was hired. Market research was conducted. A $5 million marketing campaign was set. What could go wrong?

headline: Moshe Katsav, Jailed Ex-President of Israel, Loses Bid for Early Release
abstract: Mr. Katsav, who is serving a seven-year term for rape, had requested that his sentence be reduced by a third for good behavior.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — An Israeli prison parole board rejected a request on Wednesday by Moshe Katsav, the former president of Israel who is serving a seven-year term for rape, for a conditional early release from prison.

headline: Carnyx and Horn Duet: “Liadain and Cuirithir” by John Kenny
abstract: A duet between the Deskford carnyx and the 1st-century BC Loughnashade horn, found in a bog in 1794 in what is today Northern Ireland. The track is named after a doomed love affair between two Irish poets.
lead_paragraph: A duet between the Deskford carnyx and the 1st-century BC Loughnashade horn, found in a bog in 1794 in what is today Northern Ireland. The track is named after a doomed love affair between two Irish poets.

headline: Hummus Swirled With Harissa: A Poem
abstract: Verse inspired by a food column, for those who love baklava, tahini, shawarma, anthromorphic baba ghanouj and personified pita.
lead_paragraph: (Inspired by the line “hummus swirled with harissa” in an article by Sam Sifton, food editor at The New York Times.)

headline: Cambodia to Bring Wild Tigers From Abroad in Fight Against Extinction
abstract: A small number of the animals will be taken to the Mondulkiri Protected Forest, the last place in the country one was seen.
lead_paragraph: A plan to fight the extinction of wild tigers in Cambodia would require importing the big cats from abroad, in what conservationists say would be the first transnational tiger reintroduction.

headline: Barnaby Brown Plays the Vulture Bone Flute
abstract: Mr. Brown plays an ancient Scottish tune on a replica of a 30,000-year-old instrument. The wing bone for the four-holed instrument was supplied by a Spanish wildlife protection agency that conducts post-mortems of dead vultures.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Brown plays an ancient Scottish tune on a replica of a 30,000-year-old instrument. The wing bone for the four-holed instrument was supplied by a Spanish wildlife protection agency that conducts post-mortems of dead vultures.

headline: Improvisation on Hornpipe and Drums, by Åke and Jens Egevad
abstract: The Swedish instrument maker Åke Egevad plays a replica of a hornpipe — made of a cowhorn with fingerholes — from 1,050 and found near Lund. The tune is based on Swedish folk motifs.
lead_paragraph: The Swedish instrument maker Åke Egevad plays a replica of a hornpipe — made of a cowhorn with fingerholes — from 1,050 and found near Lund. The tune is based on Swedish folk motifs.

headline: Pedro Almodóvar Cancels Publicity for New Film After Link to Panama Papers
abstract: The Spanish director Pedro Almodóvar has canceled publicity events linked to Friday’s release of his latest movie, “Julieta,” after reports that he and his brother were named in the Panama Papers.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Oscar-winning Spanish director Pedro Almodóvar has canceled publicity events linked to Friday’s release of his latest movie, “Julieta,” after reports that he and his brother, a movie producer, were named in the so-called Panama Papers, leaked documents from a law firm that documented offshore bank accounts and corporations.

headline: What You Get for … $1,225,000
abstract: A beach house in Alabama, a Spanish colonial in Los Angeles and a compound in Vermont
lead_paragraph: A beach house in Alabama, a Spanish colonial in Los Angeles and a compound in Vermont

headline: $1,225,000 Homes in Los Angeles, Vermont and Alabama
abstract: This week’s properties include a beach house in Alabama, a Spanish colonial in Los Angeles and a compound in Vermont.
lead_paragraph: POINT CLEAR, ALA.

headline: Uber Driver Napped as His Passenger Led Highway Chase, Police Say
keywords: ['Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: After handing off the wheel, the Uber driver woke up during a trip from Philadelphia to central New York to discover troopers were chasing the car, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A passenger who got behind the steering wheel of an Uber car so that the driver could nap led the police on a highway chase in central New York, the State Police said.

headline: Signing Up Organ Donors in China Can Be an Uphill Battle
abstract: About 300,000 Chinese people require transplants each year, and voluntary donation, while growing, still falls far short of meeting that need.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When Cao Yanfang left her nursing job to become a full-time “human organ donation coordinator,” someone who asks families to donate their just-deceased relatives’ organs, she set herself the goal of persuading one in 100 families to give. That was in 2010, when China set up a nationwide voluntary donation system.

headline: Model in Gucci Ad Is Deemed ‘Unhealthily Thin’ by British Regulator
keywords: ['Models (Professional)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Weight', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The ruling by the Advertising Standards Authority fanned a perennial debate in the fashion industry about what constitutes underweight.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The model in the Gucci ad is young and waiflike, her frail body draped in a geometric-pattern dress as she leans back in front of a wall painted with a tree branch that appears to mimic the angle of her silhouette.

headline: If Cruz Keeps This Pace, Trump Won’t Get a Majority of Delegates
abstract: Ted Cruz’s gains among moderate voters in Wisconsin could signal a turning point in the race.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s loss in Wisconsin — his biggest defeat in a primary so far — is being interpreted as a sign that he lost ground after several prominent miscues on abortion and other issues.

headline: A Restored Farmhouse on Two and a Half Acres in West Cork
abstract: The property, with four bedrooms and two and a half baths, is on the market for $678,000.
lead_paragraph: The property, with four bedrooms and two and a half baths, is on the market for $678,000.

headline: House Hunting in ... Ireland
abstract: The West Cork housing market began to rebound last year after an extended downturn that stretched from 2007 to 2014.
lead_paragraph: A FOUR-BEDROOM RESTORED FARMHOUSE ON TWO AND A HALF ACRES IN WEST CORK

headline: F.B.I. May Have Put Down Sword, but Privacy Debate Goes On
abstract: The F.B.I. won’t say what it found on the San Bernardino gunman’s iPhone, and WhatsApp says it has encrypted all communications, as the push-pull over digital privacy continues.
lead_paragraph: The immediate fight between Apple and the Federal Bureau of Investigation over opening a locked iPhone used by one of the attackers in last year’s San Bernardino, Calif., rampage is over. But the effects of the case linger.

headline: Customizing Android Contacts With Photos
abstract: You can replace those generic image placeholders next to names in your Android address book with the photos of your choice.
lead_paragraph: Q. How do I add my own photos to the blank entries on the Android Contacts app?

headline: 1941: British Troops Now in Balkans
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: British troops arrive in the Balkans in 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As war swung south into the Balkans, Great Britain welcomed tonight [April 6] a new ally in the Yugoslavs and pledged to support them with the full strength of the British Empire by land, sea and air, and it was officially announced at Whitehall that a British army was already in Greece.

headline: ‘When Spring Comes,’ by Kevin Henkes
abstract: A new picture book from the author-illlustrator of “Waiting” has even more to say about the challenges and rewards of patience.
lead_paragraph: WHEN SPRING COMESBy Kevin HenkesIllustrated by Laura Dronzek40 pp. Greenwillow Books/HarperCollins Publishers. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 8)

headline: Phife Dawg Is Celebrated at Memorial at the Apollo
abstract: Hip-hop titans from almost every generation came out on Tuesday to celebrate Malik Taylor, known as Phife Dawg, who died last month at 45.
lead_paragraph: At its peak in the early to mid-1990s, A Tribe Called Quest was a bridge. It showed genre elders how hip-hop was capable of aesthetic evolution while reminding young people of the value of digging in the crates for inspiration. It placed bohemian spirituality and street-corner smack talk on the same level. It made music that was utterly modern and also flawlessly in step with the genre’s traditions.

headline: The Art of Reading Russian Obituaries
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Hate Crimes', 'Deaths (Obituaries)']
abstract: A man is found dead at home with no sign of forced entry? He was gay and was killed by someone he brought home.
lead_paragraph: A journalist was killed in St. Petersburg last week, but no one called for an immediate and full investigation. No one seemed to suspect that he was killed because of his work. In a country of frequent and varied violence, this was a different kind of crime, a murder that dare not speak its name.

headline: Matthew Bourne to Stage a New Version of ‘The Red Shoes’
abstract: This ballet — Mr. Bourne’s first new piece since his 2013 “Sleeping Beauty” — will be designed by Lez Brotherston, and set to music by Bernard Herrmann.
lead_paragraph: He has reworked all the Tchaikovsky ballets. Now the choreographer Matthew Bourne will stage a different kind of classic: the 1948 British film “The Red Shoes.” Mr. Bourne’s new version — his first new piece since his 2013 “Sleeping Beauty” — will be designed by his regular collaborator Lez Brotherston, and set to music by Bernard Herrmann, who composed scores for films by Alfred Hitchcock, Orson Welles and Martin Scorsese.

headline: Revamped Metropolitan Home Sets Its Sights on Millennials
abstract: Hearst will publish the “newly reimagined” magazine next week as a test.
lead_paragraph: It was the shelter magazine that asked Tom Wolfe and Alice Waters to design rooms for a show house, photographed an openly gay couple at home years before it was standard practice and covered the Milan Furniture Fair with the seriousness National Review brings to politics.

headline: Protests in Baseball Are Seldom Upheld
abstract: The Yankees are not pursuing their protest of Tuesday’s opener, but even if they were, the odds would be against winning it.
lead_paragraph: When Yankees pitcher Dellin Betances overthrew first baseman Mark Teixeira, allowing the Astros to score a run on Tuesday afternoon, Manager Joe Girardi was incensed. The Astros’ 6-foot-4 Carlos Correa had caused the errant throw by running on the field side of the first-base line, Girardi believed, and not in the running lane.

headline: Justice Dept. Sues to Block Halliburton-Baker Hughes Merger
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: In its lawsuit, the Justice Department argued that combining the two oil field services companies would slash competition in the industry to unacceptable levels.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department sued to block the pending merger of Halliburton and Baker Hughes on Wednesday, the latest instance of the Obama administration taking a tougher stance on big-ticket deals.

headline: ‘The People v. O.J. Simpson’: Why the Trial Matters Now
abstract: One side of the case was asking the jury, “Is O.J. guilty?” The other side was asking, “Are you going to stand up to racist cops?”
lead_paragraph: I was dubious, before I watched FX’s “The People v. O. J. Simpson: American Crime Story,” that I could find the mini-series anywhere near as absorbing as I did the trial, which I watched every chance I could over two decades ago. I’d seen this show already; I knew how it ended; I remembered how it got there.

headline: Verizon and AwesomenessTV to Form Mobile Video Service
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Youth', 'Web-Original Programming']
abstract: The telecommunications giant will acquire a 24.5 percent stake in the digital entertainment network for teenagers.
lead_paragraph: Verizon Communications is trying to get a little more awesome.

headline: A Deal That Puts Lives at Risk
abstract: The deportation of refugees from Greece violates international law and humanitarian standards.
lead_paragraph: It has begun. Despite condemnations from human rights groups and a warning from the United Nations refugee agency, the European Union is deporting people from Greece to Turkey as part of a deal it signed with Turkey last month. When Turkey takes back a Syrian who entered Europe illegally, the European Union, under the terms of the deal, is to accept one registered Syrian refugee.

headline: Nora Chipaumire Explores Identity in the Boxing Ring
abstract: The Zimbabwe-born choreographer learned a few moves for her latest project, “Portrait of Myself as My Father.”
lead_paragraph: As part of her research for “Portrait of Myself as My Father,” the Zimbabwe-born choreographer Nora Chipaumire learned to box, or at least picked up a few tips. In the new work, presented by Montclair State University’s Peak Performances series, she explores African masculinity and the black male body with a boxing ring as her stage and the Senegalese performer Pape Ibrahima Ndiaye, better known as Kaolack, as her opponent. Their relationship, while tangled — and further complicated by a third performer, Shamar Wayne Watt — is not just about winning or losing. A magnetic dancer and audacious thinker, Ms. Chipaumire is less interested in binaries than in the spectra along which we negotiate identity. Adding to this complex look at heritage, gender, language, religion and power, Ms. Chipaumire offers a new film, “Afro Promo #1: Kinglady,” created at Montclair State. (April 14- 17, Alexander Kasser Theater, Montclair, N.J.; peakperfs.org.)

headline: John Prine Endures, With a Half-Smile and a Song
abstract: Mr. Prine, closing in on 70 and after two bouts with cancer, is still on the road, singing heartfelt songs like “Paradise” and “Hello in There.”
lead_paragraph: A man in search of a pint found one in an Irish establishment in Midtown. He was short and everyday, save for his spikes of gray-white hair and a sizable indentation in his neck — the mark of something endured. He looked like a guy who’d been around, and was grateful to still be.

headline: On HBO’s ‘Girls,’ a Kitty Genovese Plot Proves Eerily Timed
abstract: On Sunday’s episode of Lena Dunham’s series, a play recreated the Genovese murder. On Monday, the world learned that Genovese’s killer had just died.
lead_paragraph: It was one of those rare moments on television when a sitcom anticipates the morning news.

headline: The Best Salmon Recipe Is Wild
abstract: Today, cook clams without a recipe. Tomorrow, cure your own salmon.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: A Cocktail Shot Company Looks Beyond Beer Pong
abstract: LIQS uses premium spirits, real fruit juices and low sugar in its premixed cocktails, which come in sealed plastic shot glasses.
lead_paragraph: Mention the word “shots” and visions of frat boys from the cult movie “Animal House” often come to mind, with the Delta Tau Chi boys chugging Jack Daniels. They didn’t care about quality, health or taste. The aim was to get drunk as quickly as possible at the cheapest price.

headline: Updating Tradition: Jackie McDowell, Tim Hecker and More
abstract: New music from those artists, as well as from Henry Threadgill and Marcus Strickland.
lead_paragraph: NEW BLOOD MEDICINE

headline: ‘The Girlfriend Experience’: Don’t Call It a Remake
abstract: Steven Soderbergh is an executive producer of this Starz series, which has the same title as his 2009 film but gives a new slant to its subject: high-end prostitution.
lead_paragraph: In his 2009 film “The Girlfriend Experience,” Steven Soderbergh focused his gaze on Chelsea, a high-end New York escort (played by the porn star Sasha Grey) grappling with the waning of her career during the financial crisis. But the new Starz series of the same title, on which Mr. Soderbergh is an executive producer, isn’t exactly a remake. Now, Chelsea (the alluringly dispassionate Riley Keough, Elvis Presley’s granddaughter) is a Chicago law student and intern who undertakes prostitution for money, control and, not incidentally, sex without attachment.

headline: Asaf Avidan, Folk-Rock and Pithy Poetry
abstract: The Israeli singer-songwriter will be appearing at Rough Trade NYC for four nights.
lead_paragraph: Asaf Avidan, a well-known musician in Israel, writes songs that pull together widely disparate impulses. He often leans toward American-style folk-rock, but he also has a streak of 1960s kitsch and a fondness for electronic loops: His most widely known song is “One Day/Reckoning Song (Wankelmut Remix),” an EDM-meets-folk concoction.

headline: ‘Gabriel Mascaro: Ebbs and Flows,’ a Young Director’s Views of Brazil
abstract: This retrospective at the Walter Reade Theater in Lincoln Center includes both documentaries and a dramatic feature by this major emerging talent.
lead_paragraph: Play and hard work among working-class people living close to nature is a dominant theme for the Brazilian filmmaker Gabriel Mascaro, whose second fictional feature, “Neon Bull,” a study of the rugged lives of Brazilian rodeo riders, opened on April 8. That sensual film, which shows couples making love outdoors among cattle, typifies the work of this documentarian turned feature film director, who is having a retrospective, “Gabriel Mascaro: Ebbs and Flows,” at the Walter Reade Theater in Lincoln Center, from April 15 through 19. It includes his 2014 film, “August Winds,” whose central love affair between a city girl and a country boy takes place on a coconut farm in coastal Brazil during stormy weather. For the documentary “Housemaids,” Mr. Mascaro gave seven teenagers cameras to film their live-in maids for a week. In “High-Rise,” he interviews residents of a modern building about class, privilege and inequality. This compassionate, socially conscious filmmaker is a major emerging talent. (filmlinc.org.)

headline: Janet Jackson Postpones ‘Unbreakable’ Tour Again, Citing Family
abstract: The singer said she and her husband are “planning our family” in a video statement posted on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Janet Jackson’s comeback has not gone exactly as planned.

headline: Orchestras From San Francisco and Baltimore Come to Carnegie
abstract: Michael Tilson Thomas and Marin Alsop bring their orchestras to New York.
lead_paragraph: It is a challenging time for classical music, with orchestras under pressure to shake things up. But two American conductors have been innovators for years, and both are leading their orchestras at Carnegie Hall.

headline: ‘Exit Strategy,’ a Theatrical Import From Chicago
abstract: Ike Holter’s play about the final days of a failing urban high school is in previews at Cherry Lane Theater.
lead_paragraph: Chicago has sent many theatrical gifts to New York over the years, including Tracy Letts’s “August: Osage County” and some great plays by the Chicago native David Mamet (in general, if not lately). A notable import of the moment is Ike Holter’s “Exit Strategy,” in previews in a Primary Stages production. Mr. Holter, named “Chicagoan of the Year in Theater” by The Chicago Tribune in 2014, received a rave from Chris Jones of The Tribune when “Exit Strategy” ran there. Mr. Jones described the play, about the final days of a failing urban high school, as “at once poetic, political, sad, funny, timely, complex and compassionate” and went on to compare the “linguistic excitement” with Mr. Mamet’s feisty early work. (Opens Tuesday, April 12, Cherry Lane Theater; primarystages.org.)

headline: Yael Kanarek Has Her Fifth Show at Bitforms
abstract: The artist looks back on her career, which explores life in the information age.
lead_paragraph: Composed of simple materials — steel, hand-drawn ink on parchment, a burning candle — Yael Kanarek’s “Feedback-Loop” might not seem to be the work of a new-media artist. But Ms. Kanarek has spent the last 20 years moving between digital and analog, virtual and real. Starting Tuesday, the Lower East Side gallery Bitforms will host “Kisses Kisses,” Ms. Kanarek’s fifth show there, which looks back at her career exploring life in the information age.

headline: At Paris Exhibition, Tracing the Roots of the Velvet Underground
abstract: A multimedia show at the Philharmonie de Paris explores the history of the rock band and the New York City art, music and film scenes of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Velvet Underground could have probably only come together in 1960s New York, where artists, musicians and filmmakers mingled in a freewheeling scene that went largely unnoticed by mainstream pop culture.

headline: 3 Things School Counselors Want You to Know About Their Jobs
abstract: Counselors: They’re not just for guidance anymore.
lead_paragraph: Over the years, this column has offered up “3 Things Students Wish Teachers Knew,” “3 Things Parents Wish Teachers Knew,” and “5 Things Teachers Wish Parents Knew.” Recently, it was called to my attention that I have never written about what school counselors might like readers to know about their profession.

headline: Meg Rosoff Wins Astrid Lindgren Children’s Book Prize
abstract: The American writer Meg Rosoff won the Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award for her wide-ranging oeuvre, which includes coming-of-age stories like “Picture Me Gone” and “How I Live Now.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The author Meg Rosoff has won the Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award, a children’s book award that comes with a prize of 5 million Swedish krona, or about $613,000.

headline: Interview With a Fed Dissident: The Sole Vote to Raise Interest Rates
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Recession and Depression', 'Credit and Debt']
abstract: Esther George has repeatedly cautioned that the central bank is trying too hard to stimulate growth.
lead_paragraph: Esther George is a dissident, at least by the standards of the Federal Reserve. Since becoming president of the Kansas City Fed in 2011, she has repeatedly cautioned that the central bank is trying too hard to stimulate growth, and that its policies may cause lasting economic distortions instead. Last month, at the most recent meeting of the Fed’s policy-making committee, she cast the sole vote in favor of raising interest rates. It was her 10th time voting on policy, and the eighth time she has opposed the consensus of her colleagues.

headline: Sidelined by Panama Papers Scandal, Iceland Premier Says He’s Not Quitting
abstract: Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson said he had stepped down amid the scandal only for an “unspecified” period.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Iceland’s already fragile coalition government was thrown into further uncertainty on Wednesday after the country’s prime minister said he had not formally resigned but had stepped aside for an “unspecified” period after leaked documents linked him to an offshore company.

headline: Obama Will Be Interviewed on ‘Fox News Sunday’
abstract: It is the first time that President Obama will be on “Fox News Sunday,” with Chris Wallace, since being elected president. He was last on the program in 2008, when he was a United States senator from Illinois.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will join Chris Wallace on “Fox News Sunday” this weekend for a televised interview from Chicago.

headline: 1966: Auto Industry Under Inquiry
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The U.S. Justice Department’s antitrust division investigates auto industry over antipollution devices in 1966.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department’s antitrust division revealed today [April 6] it was investigating charges that the nation’s auto makers conspired to suppress installation of antipollution devices on car engines.

headline: Donald Blankenship Sentenced to a Year in Prison in Mine Safety Case
abstract: The sentencing of the former chief executive of Massey Energy Company comes six years after an explosion tore through the Upper Big Branch mine, killing 29.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, W.Va. — Donald L. Blankenship, whose leadership of the Massey Energy Company catapulted him from a working-class West Virginia childhood into a life as one of the wealthiest and most influential men in Appalachia, was sentenced on Wednesday to a year in prison for conspiring to violate federal mine safety standards.

headline: Donald Trump’s Trial-and-Error Campaign
abstract: On abortion as on so much else, Mr. Trump makes comments seemingly at random, then backs off if he’s criticized.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Donald Trump said women should be punished for getting abortions. Then he said they shouldn’t. Now he appears to regret taking back his ill-considered (or, more likely, not considered at all) remark, because some people liked it.

headline: The Underrated Pleasure of Wearing Jewelry Made Just for You
abstract: Hanya Yanagihara, T’s deputy editor and the author of “A Little Life,” on the importance of custom pieces.
lead_paragraph: I am not embarrassed to say that one of the great benefits to publishing a book is jewelry. When my first novel, “The People in the Trees,” came out in 2013, I bought just one thing with my advance: a deep-blue enamel ring that I had lettered with the first line — Kaulana na pua a o Hawaii/Famous are the flowers of Hawaii — of one of the most resonant Hawaiian protest songs, “Famous Are the Flowers,” written in 1893 to voice support for the overthrown Queen Liliuokalani, the islands’ last monarch. My book was an allegory of Pacific colonialism, and it seemed right that I should wear this reminder of Hawaii, what it had been and what it had lost, on my hand.

headline: A Dead Child, a Ghostly Photo and a Mother Charged With Murder
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Photography']

Trump and Hillary Clinton work to regain their footing after stinging defeats.

headline: How to Switch to iPhone From Android: Patience and Persistence
abstract: Transitioning from one operating system to another should in theory be simple, but as one technology reporter learned, in reality, many things can go wrong.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Apple first released the iPhone in 2007, I wrote a blog post with the headline: “Why my phone won’t be an iPhone.” I laid out several reasons I would not be giving up my Palm Treo 700p for Apple’s gadget, including the poor voice and data service of Apple’s lone wireless partner, AT&T, and the lack of third-party apps.

headline: Panama Papers Tie More of China’s Elite to Secret Accounts
abstract: Leaked documents about offshore companies name family members of the country’s president, propaganda chief and vice premier.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — At least three of the seven people on the Chinese Communist Party’s most powerful committee, including President Xi Jinping, have relatives who have controlled secretive offshore companies, the organization that has publicized a trove of leaked documents about hidden wealth reported on Wednesday.

headline: An Old Paris Arcade, for Innovative New French Food
abstract: Passage des Panoramas has emerged as a culinary incubator of sorts.
lead_paragraph: Paris’s oldest covered passageway, Passage des Panoramas in the Second Arrondissement, has taken shape as a gastronomic incubator of sorts over the past decade. Stone-paved and glass-roofed, the pedestrian arcade opened in 1799 and has housed stationery stores, printers and specialty shops ever since. In 2007, the serial restaurateur Pierre Jancou put it on the map as an innovative food destination when he opened the still hugely popular Racines bistrot à vins there. At the time, Racines was one of the first tables to champion la bistronomie, as produce-driven contemporary French bistro cooking has come to be known, and was an early proponent of organic and vins nature, or unsulfured wines. “The Passage des Panoramas is a beautiful space with a very particular atmosphere. It’s also sort of an intimate time capsule,” says Jancou, who is well-known for bringing new life to forgotten corners of the city. “The passage was the sort of venue I was looking for: a place with history that tells a story.” (Today, Racines belongs to the restaurateur David Lahner.)

His 26-game point streak earlier in the season was the longest since 1992-93.

headline: Review: Rumer Willis Poignantly Makes the Lyrics Her Own
abstract: At Café Carlyle, Ms. Willis dug into the songs and made you feel that this child of privilege has known more than her share of woe.
lead_paragraph: The Billie Holiday classic “God Bless the Child” has inspired so many singers to trample over this wounded reflection on poverty, need and the humiliation of the have-nots that it was a shock to hear it persuasively delivered on Tuesday evening at Café Carlyle by the offspring of Hollywood royalty. That would be Rumer Willis, the 27-year-old daughter of Bruce Willis and Demi Moore, who refrained from the style of declamation that many pop singers nowadays adopt to demonstrate a bogus empathy. With an excellent band led by her musical director and pianist James Sampliner, Ms. Willis dug into its hurt feelings and made you feel that this child of privilege has known more than her share of woe.

Cute at first sight, then annoying, the birds are about to face “humane harassment” in the town of Teaneck, N.J., where officials plan to arm concerned residents with 20 air horns in self defense.

headline: Merle Haggard Through the Years
abstract: Mr. Haggard, one of country music’s most successful artists, died on Wednesday at 79.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Haggard, one of country music’s most successful artists, died on Wednesday at 79.

headline: Review: Ballet Hispanico’s Oldies but Goodies
abstract: For its 45th-anniversary season at the Joyce Theater, the company presents work by Ramón Oller, Pedro Ruiz and Gustavo Ramírez Sansano.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, Ballet Hispanico has been steadily commissioning new work, but for its 45th-anniversary season at the Joyce Theater, the company is focusing on existing repertory. Aside from a family-oriented matinee on Saturday, the Joyce season includes just one program, consisting of three tried-and-true pieces: Ramón Oller’s “Bury Me Standing” (1998); Pedro Ruiz’s “Club Havana” (1990); and Gustavo Ramírez Sansano’s “Flabbergast,” new to the troupe this year but created for the Luna Negra Dance Theater in Chicago in 2001.

headline: Stars With Publishing Imprints of Their Own
abstract: Stars are just like us. Except they’re richer, and now many of them have their own publishing imprints.
lead_paragraph: Stars are just like us. Except they’re richer, and now many of them have their own publishing imprints.

headline: Jacob Zuma, Under Siege, Finds Political Refuge in Rural South Africa
abstract: As urban South Africans call for his resignation, the president remains popular in the villages and towns that are his party’s stronghold.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — In his first public appearance after South Africa’s highest court found that he had breached the Constitution, President Jacob G. Zuma visited one of his rural strongholds, where he received a hero’s welcome.

headline: Gay Talese Goes Through the Twitter Wringer
abstract: Asked which ‘women who write’ had inspired him, the 84-year-old nonfiction writer said, ‘None.’ That’s when he started trending.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, April 1, the 84-year-old writer Gay Talese made his way from New York to Boston, where he was scheduled to speak at Boston University’s “Power of Narrative” conference.

headline: DeVotchKa Adds an Indie Touch to ‘Sweeney Todd’
abstract: The Colorado-based band with a fondness for accordion and mandolin has tweaked Stephen Sondheim’s diabolically crafted musical.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Seventeen performers stand in a half-ring behind a nine-piece orchestra in a rehearsal studio at the Denver Center for the Performing Arts. They are belting out the menacing notes of the opening number in Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler’s tale of revenge and madness, “Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street.”

headline: Tiger Woods Is Missing, but So Is Dominance in Golf
abstract: As Woods misses the Masters for only the second time in 22 years, today’s top golfers can only marvel at how long he was able to rule the sport.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Four of the six amateurs in the Masters field this week were born after Tiger Woods made his Augusta National debut in 1995. They grew up in a world in which Woods’s contending in a major was a given, like spring following winter.

headline: Facebook Groups Act as Weapons Bazaars for Militias
abstract: Facebook posts suggest evidence of large-scale efforts to buy and sell weapons as large as guided missiles in the Middle East and North Africa.
lead_paragraph: A terrorist hoping to buy an antiaircraft weapon in recent years needed to look no further than Facebook, which has been hosting sprawling online arms bazaars, offering weapons ranging from handguns and grenades to heavy machine guns and guided missiles.

headline: Here’s Why Bill Cosby’s Wife May Have to Testify in the Case Against Him
abstract: As Camille O. Cosby has found out, whatever the perception, the reality of so-called spousal privilege is considerably more complicated.
lead_paragraph: It is among the core perceptions that many Americans embrace about their legal system: Spouses never have to testify against spouses.

headline: Modern Love: The Podcast | ‘Maddy’ Just Might Work After All
abstract: The transgender activist Jennifer Finney Boylan on navigating marriage and parenthood while transitioning from “Daddy” to “Maddy.”
lead_paragraph: In the 13th episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, the transgender activist, author, New York Times Op-Ed writer, Barnard and Columbia English professor and, last but not least, “I Am Cait” co-star Jennifer Finney Boylan reads her own Modern Love essay, “‘'Maddy’ Just Might Work After All.”

headline: Not-So-Plain White Tees Are In for Spring
abstract: Plus: Two former Vogue editors introduce the La Ligne label; stylish protection from the elements from Blunt Umbrellas and watches from Uniform Wares have the right fit for women.
lead_paragraph: Plus: Two former Vogue editors introduce the La Ligne label; stylish protection from the elements from Blunt Umbrellas and watches from Uniform Wares have the right fit for women.

headline: Puerto Rico Passes Bill Allowing Halt to Debt Payments
abstract: No starting date was given for a moratorium on payments, but a $422 million payment is due May 1. The island is laboring under $72 billion in debt.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Alejandro García Padilla of Puerto Rico on Wednesday signed a bill that would allow him to declare a state of emergency and give him authority to halt payments on the island’s crushing $72 billion debt.

headline: A Roman Pasta Recipe for Long-Distance Runners
abstract: In advance of this Sunday’s Rome Marathon, an American in Italy shares how to make her pre-race pick: rigatoni alla carbonara.
lead_paragraph: After graduating from the University of Rome Tor Vergata, the writer, journalist and occasional New York Times contributor Katie Parla did what any sensible person with a with a master’s degree in Italian Gastronomic Culture would do: She devoted the next several years to delving deep into Rome’s culinary scene, from its marketplaces and artisans to the kitchens of some of the city’s oldest restaurants. “Even though I was not a particularly fluent foreigner, the context in which I adapted to my new setting was Roman — through food and beverage,” explained the New Jersey native during a recent visit to New York, who admits that assimilating to evening aperitivos and morning coffee bar rituals isn’t all hard work. She compiled her favorite recipes, customs and discoveries into a new book, “Tasting Rome: Fresh Flavors and Forgotten Recipes From an Ancient City” ($30, Clarkson Potter), a vivid portrayal of Roman food culture, both traditional and contemporary.

headline: Living the Barneys Life
abstract: Barneys New York returns to its ancestral space.
lead_paragraph: With shopping, as with many things, I get it from my mother.

headline: Executions Highest in 25 Years, Amnesty International Says
abstract: At least 1,634 people were executed in 2015, the group found, an increase of more than 50 percent over 2014 and the highest since 1989.
lead_paragraph: Despite a growing repudiation of the death penalty by governments around the world, at least 1,634 people were executed last year, the highest total in a quarter-century, Amnesty International said Wednesday in its annual report on capital punishment.

headline: Iran Plans Visit to Rival Saudis to Discuss Hajj Pilgrimage
abstract: It would be a rare official meeting between Iran and Saudi Arabia, which broke relations in January after protesters burned the Saudi Embassy in Tehran.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Iran announced on Wednesday that it intended to send a delegation to Saudi Arabia this month to discuss the hajj pilgrimage, a rare official meeting between the Middle Eastern rivals at a time of deep regional tensions.

headline: Why Trump Supporters Are Angry — and Loyal
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'United States Economy', 'Editorial Observer']
abstract: Republicans lash out at Donald Trump’s lower-middle-class backers, angry at the movement they created.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz’s big win in Wisconsin Tuesday was an important moment for the Never Trump forces that hope to keep Donald Trump from amassing the delegates he needs to win the Republican nomination outright. But Mr. Cruz’s supporters remain seriously frustrated anyway, to the point where they have begun denigrating and demonizing Mr. Trump’s supporters, a tactic that can do neither Mr. Cruz nor his party any good.

headline: Hayden Dunham Makes Art You Can Inhale and Drink
abstract: The 27-year-old artist is also known for her pop-star alter ego, QT.
lead_paragraph: Name Hayden Dunham

headline: Merle Haggard’s American Tales: A Critic’s Tour
abstract: Five tracks that capture the outlaw hero’s songwriting talent, including “The Bottle Let Me Down” and “Okie From Muskogee.”
lead_paragraph: Merle Haggard, who died on Wednesday, his 79th birthday, wrote some of the greatest songs in American music about drinking, working, prison, love, morality, memory and modernity. Here are five of his best:

headline: Review: In ‘Happily After Ever,’ a Couple’s Impossible Choice
abstract: Laura Zlatos’s play at 59E59 Theaters sets up a retro rom-com world of young marrieds and introduces a baby whose sex can’t be determined.
lead_paragraph: In the off-kilter, candy-colored world of Laura Zlatos’s “Happily After Ever,” at 59E59 Theaters, there’s a winking rom-com inevitability to the way girl meets boy: at a bus stop, where they fall for each other instantly. Janet — spacy and shallow but fetching in her dotted mint-green sundress — is a perfect fit for Darren, who’s equally shallow but also kind of perky and has that handsome cleft chin.

headline: Our Best Comments of the Week
abstract: The very best Times comments as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every submission.
lead_paragraph: The very best Times comments as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every submission.

headline: A Life-Changing Procedure
abstract: Two Pakistani twins, conjoined at the belly, traveled with their families to Saudi Arabia for a rare and risky separation surgery.
lead_paragraph: Two Pakistani twins, conjoined at the belly, traveled with their families to Saudi Arabia for a rare and risky separation surgery.
