headline: A Rowdy Roundtable Discussion With Three L.A. Art Legends
abstract: The longtime friends Ed Moses, Larry Bell and Ed Bereal gathered for dinner — and some reminiscing — in Hollywood last week.
lead_paragraph: The ’50s and ’60s were an explosive moment in the trajectory of Los Angeles art history. Now-legends like Ed Ruscha, Robert Irwin and Ed Kienholz were then just a dynamic group of artists fostered by the Ferus Gallery, Chouinard Art Institute (now known as CalArts) and a little dive bar called Barney’s Beanery. Far removed from the art establishment in New York, the crew was known for radical explorations in Pop Art, assemblage and the development of Light and Space — as well as a tight-knit social circle, with a reputation for womanizing and boys’-club debauchery.

headline: Helping Writers With a Windfall Avoid a Downfall
keywords: ['Personal Finances', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Grants (Corporate and Foundation)', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting']
abstract: A workshop teaches struggling writers how to deal with the emotions that a lump sum of money can inspire. It also shows them how to handle taxes.
lead_paragraph: “I might be close to solvent,” the poet and essayist Brian Blanchfield said, “but I still think like a deeply insolvent person.”

headline: Corruption Hampers the Fight Against Drugs and the Taliban
abstract: Helmand Province, the southwestern region that is the world capital of opium and heroin production, is also the deadliest province in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: Helmand Province, the southwestern region that is the world capital of opium and heroin production, is also the deadliest province in Afghanistan.

headline: Grace Coddington: The Fragrance
abstract: The Vogue creative director at large reveals a new perfume produced with Comme des Garçons.
lead_paragraph: Blanket, a longhaired Persian the color of steel wool, gave up his spot on the dining room table when a reporter came knocking, and made himself scarce. His owner, Grace Coddington, the longtime creative director of Vogue, shrugged and settled down in a chair to discuss her new project: her first perfume, which sat on the table like a rosy pepper mill, its long flaçon topped with a stopper modeled on the head of a cat.

headline: ‘The Little Mermaid’ to Be Performed Live in Los Angeles
abstract: The Disney movie will be performed at the Hollywood Bowl by a cast including Sara Bareilles, Tituss Burgess and John Stamos.
lead_paragraph: Before Tituss Burgess was a breakout star of the Netflix series “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt,” he played the crab Sebastian in the Broadway production of “The Little Mermaid.” He’ll return to the role in a live concert at the Hollywood Bowl in Los Angeles on June 4, flanked by a starry cast including Sara Bareilles, John Stamos and Rebel Wilson.

headline: Zola Holds a Party for Brides-to-Be
abstract: Celebrate National Pet Day, score cool sunglasses, buy smart new yoga wear and do good, and more.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m., the wedding registry site Zola will have a shopping party at its Zola Townhouse pop-up. Brides-to-be will receive free makeup touch-ups by Blushington, floral arrangements from BloomThat and custom lingerie from Negative Underwear, while adding items like a Jonathan Adler antique brass bar cart ($1,950) and a Waterford crystal decanter ($195) to their wish list. At 43 Crosby Street.

headline: ‘American Idol’ Ends, Eclipsed by Internet Democracy
abstract: The once-popular reality singing competition ends at the conclusion of its 15th season, superseded by a larger community than the one it was based on.
lead_paragraph: The early front-runner in Season 9 of “American Idol” was Andrew Garcia, an amiable pop-R&B singer with a smooth voice, a neck tattoo and a relaxed mien. He was also, by some measures, already something of a star.

headline: Rediscovering Southern Roots
abstract: Amanda Greene’s images of Southern life were inspired by her return home after 17 years in Los Angeles, where what passed for “authentic” was often nowhere near what she knew.
lead_paragraph: Amanda Greene’s images of Southern life were inspired by her return home after 17 years in Los Angeles, where what passed for “authentic” was often nowhere near what she knew.

headline: Ivanka Trump’s Chinese-Made Scarves Are Recalled
keywords: ['Americans Abroad', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Scarves']
abstract: Donald J. Trump often opines on the economic risks of manufacturing American products overseas. Now he can add his daughter’s line of Chinese-made scarves, which were recalled over flammability issues, to his list of concerns.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump often opines on the economic risks of manufacturing American products overseas. Now he can add his daughter’s line of Chinese-made scarves to his list of concerns.

headline: Review: ‘Love’s Refrain’ Has a Stargazer Looking Inward
abstract: The solo show, by Justin Sayre, finds the writer and actor offering up his passionate soul.
lead_paragraph: As a lonely, sleepless boy, the writer and performer Justin Sayre used to peer out of his second-floor bedroom in small-town Pennsylvania and up into the night sky. He has now twinned that longing and that starwatching into a poignant if occasionally strained solo show, “Love’s Refrain: A Confession by Justin Sayre,” directed by Matthew Placek, at the Club at La MaMa.

headline: Hedge Funds Are the New Venture Firms
abstract: Funds are pouring millions into start-ups, particularly financial tech companies using the Internet and automation to replace traditional banking.
lead_paragraph: In Silicon Valley, hedge funds with billion-dollar reserves are becoming the new venture capitalists.

headline: To Discourage Prostitution, France Passes Bill That Penalizes Clients
keywords: ['Prostitution', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Law and Legislation', 'Women and Girls', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: First-time offenders will pay a fine of about $1,700 if they “solicit, accept or obtain relations of a sexual nature.” The fine can rise to about $4,300 for repeat offenders.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — After a debate lasting nearly two and a half years, France’s Parliament on Wednesday approved a bill to discourage prostitution by penalizing those who pay for sex, following the example of Sweden and Norway.

headline: Teenage Driver Dies in Texas After Takata Airbag Ruptures in Crash
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Huma Hanif, 17, was driving a Honda Civic last week outside Houston when she was involved in a minor accident that “caused the airbag to explode,” an officer said.
lead_paragraph: A Texas teenager was killed last week when the Takata airbag in her Honda Civic ruptured in a crash, a local police official said Wednesday, bringing the number of deaths linked to the supplier’s defective airbags to 11.

headline: Shakespeare First Folio Discovered on Isle of Bute, in Time for an Anniversary
abstract: The 1623 edition turned up in a Scottish manor house stuffed with Old Masters, right on cue for the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare’s death.
lead_paragraph: Just in time for the global commemoration of the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare’s death, a stately home on a small Scottish island is announcing a surprise party gift: the unveiling of a previously unknown First Folio.

headline: How Donald Trump’s Squeeze on Immigrants Will Backfire
abstract: Trump wants to block remittances to force Mexico to pay for his wall. Here’s why that could hurt the U.S.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has finally provided some details on how he plans to make Mexico pay for his proposed border wall. Unless the Mexican government pays $5 billion to $10 billion to build it, he wants to restrict the money, or remittances, that Mexican immigrants send back to family and friends in Mexico.

headline: Garland Fight Overshadows Effort to Overhaul Sentencing Laws
abstract: Supporters of a bipartisan measure on sentencing are worried about its fate as the Senate’s attention has been consumed by the Supreme Court vacancy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of the Senate always expected to be consumed by a major court-related fight this year, just not the court-related fight they are having.

headline: Dutch Referendum Rejects Trade Deal Between E.U. and Ukraine
abstract: In a nonbinding election, voters in the Netherlands said no to a trade and cooperation pact. All 28 member countries must approve the deal.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Voters in a Dutch referendum on Wednesday overwhelmingly rejected a trade and cooperation agreement between the European Union and Ukraine, casting doubt over the future of the accord and delivering a new blow to supporters of European integration.

headline: A Corporate Tax Dodge Gets Harder
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Tax Shelters', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Tax Evasion', 'Corporate Taxes']
abstract: New rules from the Treasury Department take aim at inversions, but only Congress can fully stop the abuse.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer never tried to hide the fact that its proposed $152 billion merger with Allergan, based in Ireland, would cut its tax bill in the United States. But even as it rushed to complete the biggest tax-avoidance deal in the history of corporate America, it continued to promote the strategic and economic benefits of the merger.

headline: A Champions League Matchup of Elites Ends in an Ugly Tie
abstract: The most memorable goal of a first-leg draw between Paris St.-Germain and Manchester City was so ugly, so bizarre, that it was difficult to imagine anyone repeating it.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The quarterfinals of the Champions League — the world’s biggest and best club soccer tournament — should feature skill and polish, wonder and beauty. Presumably, the stars of the game should thrive in their showcase environment, overwhelming one another with acts of incomparable dexterity and nimble grace.

headline: Tensions Rise in the South China Sea
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States International Relations', 'Ships and Shipping', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: China’s neighbors are supported by the United States in opposing Beijing’s bullying tactics over territorial claims.
lead_paragraph: Asian countries are increasingly pushing back against China’s sweeping territorial claims and bullying tactics in the South China Sea. On Sunday, a Japanese submarine made a port call in the Philippines for the first time in 15 years, a sign of growing security cooperation. Last week, Vietnam seized a Chinese ship for illegally entering its territorial waters, and Indonesia threatened to defend its own claims with F-16 fighter jets.

headline: De Blasio Adding Money for Water Tunnel in Brooklyn and Queens
abstract: The $305 million is to pay for construction of two deep shafts that will connect with the supply tunnel.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Wednesday that he was going to add $305 million to New York City’s capital budget to speed up work on Water Tunnel No. 3 so that it would be able to serve Brooklyn and Queens.

headline: De Blasio Says Water Tunnel Delay Wasn’t ‘Explained Properly’ by His Staff
abstract: New York’s mayor addressed a New York Times report about postponed work on a supply line serving Brooklyn and Queens.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio was asked at a news conference on Wednesday about the delay in work on a portion of Water Tunnel No. 3 that is to serve Brooklyn and Queens, as reported by The New York Times:

headline: Mighty UConn Faces a Future of Rising Powers
abstract: Even Coach Geno Auriemma seems to be predicting that the Huskies will not go undefeated next season, saying his returning players “are in for a rude awakening.”
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, Connecticut (38-0), led by the three-time national player of the year Breanna Stewart, won its fourth straight national championship, 82-51, by beating Syracuse in a game that was close — only until it began.

headline: Owner of 3 VW Dealerships Sues Carmaker Over Diesel Scandal
keywords: ['Diesel Power', 'Air Pollution', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The lawsuit, rare in the auto market, reflects the extent of Volkswagen’s deception and the falloff in car sales that followed.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — An owner of three Volkswagen dealerships on Wednesday filed a lawsuit against the carmaker over its rigged diesel vehicles, seeking compensation for lost sales suffered by its more than 600 dealers in the United States.

headline: The Blankenship Sentencing: A Judge Finds an Abuse of Trust
abstract: Judge Irene C. Berger of Federal District Court, briefly addressed Donald L. Blankenship before sentencing him to a year in prison.
lead_paragraph: After a jury convicted Donald L. Blankenship, the former chief executive of Massey Energy Company, of conspiring to violate mine safety standards, Judge Irene C. Berger of Federal District Court in Charleston, W.Va., had to settle on a punishment. The law imposed strict limits on the sentence Judge Berger could impose: By statute, Mr. Blankenship could not be ordered to serve more than a year in prison or be fined more than $250,000.

headline: Seymour Lazar, 88, Dies; Flamboyant Entertainment Lawyer, and More
abstract: Mr. Lazar, a swashbuckling renegade, represented Lenny Bruce and Miles Davis, associated with Timothy Leary and Allen Ginsberg and became involved in a huge fraud case.
lead_paragraph: Seymour M. Lazar, a swashbuckling entertainment lawyer, stock trader and serial litigator whose lifetime of adventures took him from the legal tangle surrounding the estate of Howard Hughes to involvement in a colossal fraud case that threatened to bring down one of the biggest shareholder class-action law firms in the United States, died on March 30 at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Megamergers Face Deterrents in the United States
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Corporate Taxes']
abstract: The Obama administration took on two possible deals this week, and claimed a victory with one.
lead_paragraph: The drug giant Pfizer wanted to cut its taxes through a $152 billion takeover of the Dublin-based maker of Botox. And Halliburton sought to buy a major rival in the business of selling equipment to oil drillers for nearly $35 billion.

headline: F.A.A. Loosens United Airlines’ Grip on Newark Air Travel
abstract: United, criticized for underutilizing slots to preserve its leading position at Newark’s airport, has dropped plans to buy extra landing and takeoff rights from Delta.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department said on Wednesday that United Airlines had dropped plans to buy extra landing and takeoff rights at Newark’s airport from Delta Air Lines, a deal that antitrust regulators opposed last year.

headline: Queens Neighborhood Still Haunted by Kitty Genovese’s Murder
abstract: In Kew Gardens, where Ms. Genovese’s 1964 murder became symbolic of witness apathy, the old neighborhood has a problem with that.
lead_paragraph: The bartender at Austin’s Ale House in Kew Gardens, Queens, shook her head as soon as she heard the words Kitty Genovese.

headline: Yahoo Paints Grim Financial Picture as Deadline for Bids Nears
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The Internet giant warned potential bidders about a projected decline of $600 million in revenue this year, as it prepares to sell its core business.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As Yahoo asks potential bidders to submit first-round offers for its core business next week, it is also warning them about a troubling decline in revenue and profit while obscuring the costs and cash flow of various business units.

headline: Early in the Season, Players Are Still Figuring Out How to Run
abstract: On Tuesday, the Yankees lost after an Astro went on the grass as he headed to first, and the Rays won when a review resulted in a game-ending double play.
lead_paragraph: In his argument on the field during Tuesday’s opening day loss, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi indicated the Yankees would be playing under protest. As it turned out, Girardi said on Wednesday, the team never filed the paperwork.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: WEST

headline: Hillary Clinton Again Looks Upstate for Win in New York
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Voting and Voters', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s Senate victory was fueled by the unlikely support of white working-class voters there, but she faces new challenges in securing that kind of support again.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s political ascent can be traced to the time in 1999 when she expressed her support for dairy farmers in the upstate New York village of Endicott. And the summer that year when she shunned Martha’s Vineyard to vacation in Skaneateles, and promised voters in the depleted industrial city of Schenectady that as a New York senator she would revive the upstate economy.

headline: Meldonium Is the Suspect as Russia Loses Athletes
abstract: In recent weeks, a rash of withdrawals and substitutions in major competitions has wreaked havoc on Russian sports, including hockey, volleyball and even curling.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — On the eve of their trip to the world championships in the United States this week, Russia’s entire under-18 hockey team was suddenly replaced with younger players.

headline: It’s Official: Smokeless Tobacco Is Out
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio signed legislation prohibiting the use of the tobacco at New York City sports facilities that issue tickets, including Yankee Stadium and Citi Field.
lead_paragraph: Yankee Stadium got a new addition — or, more accurately, a subtraction — on Wednesday. Smokeless tobacco, long part of baseball’s backdrop, can no longer be used by players, coaches and managers while they are at the Yankees’ ballpark or at Citi Field, the home of the Mets.

headline: Donald Trump’s Rivals Home In on New York, Hoping to Bruise Him
abstract: The fight will be waged in places like the Bronx, where Ted Cruz’s team believes its organization can yield delegates in areas with few Republicans.
lead_paragraph: One day after Senator Ted Cruz’s decisive victory in Wisconsin, the Republican presidential race hurtled on Wednesday into conspicuously different terrain — New York City and its suburbs — with Republicans opposed to Donald J. Trump more hopeful than ever that the front-runner can be bruised anew, even in his hometown.

headline: Coach Has Long Association With Boston College and Success
keywords: ['Hockey, Ice', 'NCAA Ice Hockey Championships', 'Coaches and Managers']
abstract: Jerry York, a 1967 graduate of Boston College, has the Eagles back in the Frozen Four as he seeks to add to his 1,012 wins and five national titles.
lead_paragraph: CHESTNUT HILL, Mass. — The winningest coach in college hockey history works four miles from where he grew up with nine siblings, and at an institution where he went from walk-on as a freshman to captain and all-American center his senior year.

headline: Chris Hardwick: A Nerd’s Ryan Seacrest
abstract: Comedian and media personality Chris Hardwick has made a living as a professional nerd. Since the 1990s, he has mixed old and new media to spread his Nerdist brand.
lead_paragraph: Comedian and media personality Chris Hardwick has made a living as a professional nerd. Since the 1990s, he has mixed old and new media to spread his Nerdist brand.

headline: Carlo Mastrangelo, a Doo-Wop Voice for Dion and the Belmonts, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Mastrangelo, an original member of the Belmonts, provided baritone vocals for hits including “A Teenager in Love” and “Where or When.”
lead_paragraph: Carlo Mastrangelo, an original member of Dion and the Belmonts, whose baritone vocals undergirded the group’s harmonies on a string of doo-wop hits like “No One Knows” and “A Teenager in Love,” died on Monday in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 78.

headline: Samsung Profits Are Up, Thanks to Its Galaxy 7 Smartphone
abstract: In a return to form, the South Korean electronics maker benefited from sales of smartphones, its recent Achilles’ heel.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Samsung performed better than expected at the beginning of what it has said will be a tough year, thanks to a product that recently has been its Achilles’ heel: smartphones.

headline: Marginal Role for de Blasio as New York’s Primary Nears
abstract: A Manhattan rally showed what has become obvious in recent months: The mayor’s late endorsement of Hillary Clinton has cost him.
lead_paragraph: It appeared as if Mayor Bill de Blasio would finally get his moment: “Rally for Hillary in Manhattan,” the mayor’s announcement said.

headline: Hawks’ Thabo Sefolosha Files Suit Against New York Police Officers
keywords: ['Basketball', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Sefolosha accused five police officers who arrested him outside a Manhattan nightclub last year of false arrest and excessive force.
lead_paragraph: Atlanta Hawks forward Thabo Sefolosha filed a federal lawsuit Monday against five New York police officers who arrested him outside a Manhattan nightclub last year, accusing them of false arrest and using excessive force.

headline: ‘Empire’ Season 2, Episode 12: Hakeem’s Not a Very Good Leader, Is He?
abstract: This week, a Lyon family that looked irreparably divided mere days ago seems to have come together.
lead_paragraph: This week on “Empire,” a Lyon family that looked irreparably divided mere days ago seems to have come together. What’s different now is that Camilla and Mimi are gone, thanks in large part to a secret deal by Cookie and Lucious to use their sons to run their outside investors out of town.

headline: Ambitious Climbers’ Mecca
abstract: John Lieb is our kindred spirit today.

headline: In Miami, Cuban Culture, No Passport Required
abstract: On Calle Ocho, in the heart of Miami’s Little Havana, Cuban art, music and cuisine take center stage, especially on the last Friday of every month.
lead_paragraph: Just when I thought I’d had enough for one evening, an Afro-Cuban-American gentleman pulled me off the bustling Calle Ocho and into a room jammed with dancers bouncing up and down to the beat of congas. No, this wasn’t a ’90s-style rave; this was the normally unassuming lounge at Top Cigars, a cigar shop in Miami’s Little Havana. I recognized the owner, Cristobal Mena, from an exchange we’d had that morning at a Cuban restaurant across the street about what constitutes a classic Cuban dish. Now, I was hopping in a sea of his patrons on the famous boulevard that is the social and commercial hub of Little Havana.

That grim prospect is what makes a study published in March in The Journal of Alzheimer’s Disease so encouraging: It turns out that regular walking, cycling, swimming, dancing and even gardening may substantially reduce the risk of Alzheimer’s.

headline: Houston’s Culinary Bragging Rights
abstract: The nation’s fourth-largest city is no longer one gigantic steak platter for oil barons. Here are four restaurants that defy Houston stereotypes.
lead_paragraph: Texans like me brag about all sorts of outlandish things, from the ostentatious display of our firearms in public places to the awesome awfulness of our weather. Until fairly recently, we maintained a telling silence on the subject of our state’s fine dining scene. Our most famous restaurants (Tony’s in Houston, Mansion on Turtle Creek in Dallas) were more notable for their big-haired scene-makers and for their wallet-detonating entrees than for truly memorable food. Then there was that unfortunate little nouvelle-Southwestern cuisine craze back in the Nineties: quail and catfish trumped up as delicacies, everything jowl-deep in ancho chile sauce or afloat on a cactus pad we were assured was edible. It didn’t catch on, and we Texans went back to boasting about our brisket and tacos.

headline: Streamlined Handbags From a Fragrance House, of All Places
abstract: Maison Louis Marie launches four leather styles — two pouches, a shoulder bag and a tote — today.
lead_paragraph: Like the line of scented candles and range of personal fragrances that came before it, Maison Louis Marie’s just-launched handbag collection is unassuming and meticulously crafted. “I started the brand to pay tribute to and celebrate my ancestry,” says the founder and creative director, Marie du Petit Thouars. Her great-great-great grandfather Louis Marie Aubert du Petit Thouars, a French botanist at the turn of the 19th century, dealt mainly in orchids, and her mother kept a greenhouse on their property in Belgium — that doubled as a laboratory for the younger du Petit Thouars during her childhood.

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Packing on the Pounds
abstract: Can you figure out why a 59-year-old woman keeps gaining weight?
lead_paragraph: The Challenge: Can you figure out why a 59-year-old woman keeps gaining weight?

headline: Video Review: A Redesigned Malibu You Can Take to the Beach
abstract: With its graceful lines, power and balanced ride, 2016’s version of Chevrolet’s midsize sedan is an able competitor in an unforgiving market segment.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to exclusive addresses, Malibu ranks high in the public imagination. But when it comes to cars, Chevrolet’s namesake sedan is aimed squarely at the middle class. Prices start at $22,500 for this midsize sedan that is attractive enough not to look out of place in the California oceanside town.

headline: A.C.P.T. Roll Call
abstract: A few of the people you might meet if you attend the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — There are many people who still believe that crossword puzzles are made by computers, even with the presence of Wordplay and other crossword blogs, even with the spread of indie crossword puzzle websites and apps. Many people still believe that the crossword somehow magically appears in the newspaper every day. Nothing, as you and I know, could be further from the truth.

headline: Resigning From 76ers, Sam Hinkie Mounts a Defense as Shaky as His Team’s
abstract: Hinkie’s plan as general manager meant rolling out an atrocious team each season. For fans, the losing got to be too much.
lead_paragraph: Sam Hinkie went to the Philadelphia 76ers in 2013 with a novel idea.

headline: Malaysia Panel Calls for Investigation of Former Head of 1MDB Fund
abstract: Members of the state investment fund’s board of directors said they would offer their resignation after a parliamentary committee released its report.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A parliamentary committee in Malaysia on Thursday called for an investigation of the former head of the country’s troubled state investment fund and said that the fund’s advisory board, led by Prime Minister Najib Razak, should be abolished.

headline: Belgian Police Release New Video of Brussels Airport Suspect
keywords: ['Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Terrorism', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The footage provides a first look at how the “man in the hat” left the building right after the bombings, and where he went.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Belgian authorities released video footage on Thursday that retraced the steps of a man suspected of taking part in the March 22 bombing of the Brussels Airport and renewed their appeal to the public for help in identifying him.

headline: Learning and Exploring on 100% Day
abstract: When you hear “hackathon” you envision hoodied programmers hunched over laptops, coding without sleep or solid food. I assumed my first 100% Day would be similar; nothing could be further from the truth.
lead_paragraph: When you hear “hackathon” you envision a scene from “The Social Network”: bleary-eyed developers working into the early morning, slamming energy drinks, furiously typing away on keyboards; the end goal being to best your competition, and be showered in glory from your peers. When I joined The New York Times two years ago, I assumed my first 100% Day would be similar; nothing could be further from the truth.

headline: New Financial Investment Rules May Aid Robo Advisers
keywords: ['Financial Brokers', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The new rules are expected to encourage a rush of retirement savings money to low-cost investments, something the robo advisers claim as their hallmark.
lead_paragraph: Washington’s new rules for financial advisers may give so-called robo advisers a leg up in the battle for investor dollars.

headline: Pandora’s Box: Readers Respond to Meal Delivery Kits
abstract: Readers voice their opinions about meal kits like Blue Apron and Purple Carrot.
lead_paragraph: Readers voice their opinions about meal kits like Blue Apron and Purple Carrot.

headline: Panama Papers Continue to Shake Leaders, Including Cameron and Putin
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia dismissed the documents as an American plot, Iceland chose new leadership and Britain’s prime minister admitted to profiting from an offshore trust.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The reverberations from a leaked trove of Panamanian documents rippled through several nations on Thursday, with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia calling the exposure of a proliferation of shell companies and tax havens an American plot, while Iceland picked a new prime minister and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain admitted that he had profited from an offshore trust.

headline: Teaser Gives a Peek at ‘Rogue One: A Star Wars Story’
abstract: “This is a rebellion, isn’t it? I rebel,” says Jyn Erso, the protagonist played by Felicity Jones.
lead_paragraph: By now, you might think that every portion of the canonical “Star Wars” time line has been explored in cinema: the classic trilogy (“A New Hope,” “The Empire Strikes Back” and “Return of the Jedi”); the prequels (“The Phantom Menance” and others best left unmentioned) and a new continuing narrative set forth in last year’s blockbuster “The Force Awakens.”

headline: A.J. Tarpley Retires From N.F.L. at Age 23, Citing Concussions
abstract: Tarpley, an undrafted linebacker, played in 15 regular-season games for the Bills last season after four years at Stanford.
lead_paragraph: A. J. Tarpley, a linebacker with the Buffalo Bills, said Wednesday that he was retiring because of repeated concussions, the latest young player to walk away from football because of worries about his long-term health.

headline: 1966: H-Bomb Recovered Off Spain
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The U.S. Navy recovers a hydrogen bomb lost off the cost of Spain in 1966.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The U.S. Navy today [April 7] recovered the hydrogen bomb lost off the southeast coast of Spain almost three months ago in a midair collision of two U.S. Air Force planes.

headline: Blaming Policy, Not Islam, for Belgium’s Radicalized Youth
keywords: ['Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Discrimination', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']
abstract: For Yves Goldstein, a councilman in Brussels, allowing ethnic ghettos to grow unchallenged created the perfect recruiting ground for Islamists.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Yves Goldstein makes no excuses for Belgium’s failure to find Salah Abdeslam and the other Islamic State recruits who attacked Paris and then bombed  Brussels Airport and a subway station.

headline: Boko Haram Turns Female Captives Into Terrorists
abstract: Of all the many horrors of Boko Haram’s rampage, one of the most baffling has been its ability to turn captured women and girls into killers.
lead_paragraph: MINAWAO REFUGEE CAMP, Cameroon — Hold the bomb under your armpit to keep it steady, the women and girls were taught.

headline: Beyond Tribeca: New York’s Many Other Film Fests in April
abstract: There is Kino!, Art of the Real, Ivy, Havana and Independent film festivals going on this month.
lead_paragraph: In April, the New York City film festival scene often focuses on the popular Tribeca Film Festival (April 13-24), with its robust number of world premieres, celebrity appearances, red-carpet screenings and high-profile parties. But it isn’t the only festival in town: There are several others, with focuses ranging from acclaimed work by students to fresh takes on documentaries. We spoke to programmers and organizers of a handful of these events and asked them about their must-see films.

lead_paragraph: Editorial page editor Andrew Rosenthal on Ted Cruz’s victory, Republican efforts to write bigotry into state laws, and the Supreme Court’s decision on voting.

headline: Need to Hide Some Income? You Don’t Have to Go to Panama
abstract: Setting up a shell corporation in the United States is simple — especially in states like Delaware, Wyoming and Nevada.
lead_paragraph: For wealthy Americans looking to veil their assets and shield some of their income from taxation, there is no need to go to Panama or any other offshore tax haven. It’s easy to establish a shell corporation right here at home.

headline: Y.A. Crossover
abstract: New novels by Alwyn Hamilton, Louise O’Neill, Tommy Wallach and Peter Rock.
lead_paragraph: REBEL OF THE SANDSBy Alwyn Hamilton314 pp. Viking, $18.99.

lead_paragraph: Timepieces with intricate faces, framed in rose or yellow gold.

lead_paragraph: At a rally in Philadelphia, a newly invigorated Bernie Sanders took up Hillary Clinton’s challenge about who is qualified to be president.

headline: Cairo Gallery Forced to Shut After Building Collapse
abstract: The executive director of the Townhouse gallery said that the part of the building that collapsed contained unoccupied rooms, and that there was no damage to the main gallery.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A building collapse has forced the temporary closure of the Townhouse gallery, Cairo’s best-known contemporary art space, just over three months after Egyptian officials raided the gallery and suspended its activities as part of a crackdown on cultural institutions by the government of President Abdel-Fattah el-Sisi.

headline: Solve the Nagorno-Karabakh Conflict Before It Explodes
abstract: The recent eruption of violence is a reminder that a dangerous conflict is smoldering in the South Caucasus. It has the potential to spread.
lead_paragraph: For almost three decades, the most dangerous unresolved conflict in wider Europe has lain in the mountains of the South Caucasus, in a small territory known as Nagorno-Karabakh. In the late 1980s, the region confounded the last Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev. In the early 1990s, the conflict there created more than a million refugees and killed around 20,000 people. In 1994, after Armenia defeated Azerbaijan in a fight over the territory, the two countries signed a truce — but no peace agreement.

headline: Illuminating the Effects of Light Pollution
abstract: Unlike many environmental issues, light pollution is a problem researchers say could disappear with the flick of a switch.
lead_paragraph: Unlike many environmental issues, light pollution is a problem researchers say could disappear with the flick of a switch.

headline: Trying to Make a Movie With and About Merle Haggard
abstract: Recalling the quirks of a country music legend during an ultimately unsuccessful moviemaking journey.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the 1990s, I tried, without much luck, to produce a movie about Merle Haggard for United Artists.

headline: From Kitty Genovese’s Brother: ‘The Final Chapter’
abstract: “My family’s ‘better angels’ do now express our condolences to the Moseley family.”

headline: Ailey Season Has Premieres by Kyle Abraham and Mauro Bigonzetti
abstract: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater season, starting June 8, includes two premieres, and seven chances to see “Revelations.”
lead_paragraph: Kyle Abraham, the choreographer and MacArthur fellow, will present the second installment of his “Untitled America” trilogy as part of the coming Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater season.

headline: After Physical Therapy, Why Not Cancer Therapy?
abstract: My family and I would have given anything for the house calls of a creature we never imagined: an oncological therapist. And it might be less expensive than recurrent emergency room visits.
lead_paragraph: In mid-January, after a fall on invisible ice, I was informed by an emergency room doctor that my fractured pelvis would heal in six to eight weeks. To help me recover from the injury, therapists started coming to my house. Their ministrations posed a question that nagged at me: why aren’t trained professionals made available to cancer outpatients in the way occupational and physical therapists are routinely assigned to orthopedic patients?

headline: BroadwayCon to Expand to Javits Center Next Year
abstract: The convention, inspired by ComicCon, drew 5,000 people this year; organizers hope it will draw up to 15,000 next year.
lead_paragraph: BroadwayCon, the multiday gathering of theater fans that survived a record snowstorm during its first convention earlier this year, is getting bigger.

headline: Fleurie and Morgon: Greatness if Not Gravitas
abstract: The crus of Beaujolais have come a long way in 25 years. The wine panel finds excellent wines in the 2014 vintage of Fleurie and Morgon.
lead_paragraph: It’s no secret that the Beaujolais region is not what it was. But what it was depends on how far back you want to go.

headline: Hillary Clinton Rides the No. 4, and Her MetroCard (Eventually) Fits Fine
abstract: It took Hillary Clinton a few swipes (five, to be precise, but who’s counting?) of her MetroCard to go through the turnstile at 116th Street in the Bronx on Thursday, but at least she knew that the New York City subway no longer accepts tokens.
lead_paragraph: Call it the subway series of the Democratic presidential primary.

headline: For One Member of Famed N.H.L. Class, Reality Took a Different Path
abstract: In 1990, Scott Scissons was drafted in one of the best first rounds in N.H.L. history. The five players chosen before him have scored 1,990 goals. He scored none.
lead_paragraph: Every so often, Scott Scissons is asked to make a speech. He tends to begin the same way, with a moment of levity: Five players were chosen ahead of him in the 1990 draft, he says, but no one in the crowd is likely to have heard of them.

headline: The Enduring Power of Jaromir Jagr
abstract: After 22 years and eight teams, the Panthers’ Jagr is bound for another playoff appearance and seems unlikely to retire any time soon.
lead_paragraph: CORAL SPRINGS, Fla. — The day the Florida Panthers traded for Jaromir Jagr last year, some players told the team’s strength and conditioning coach, Tommy Powers, that his free nights were over. Powers wondered what they meant, until Jagr explained it later.

lead_paragraph: It’s a crime, but it’s not defined by the law. The Supreme Court will look at when you can be prosecuted for receiving inside information.

headline: Republicans Seize on Guantánamo Fears in Re-election Races
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Detainees', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: With control of the Senate at stake, blue-state Republican incumbents hope the issue will let them reprise Scott Brown’s 2010 win in Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Vulnerable Republican incumbents are increasingly raising fears about Guantánamo Bay detainees, following a campaign strategy used by Scott Brown before his surprise victory in a Massachusetts special election for a Senate seat six years ago.

headline: Jennifer Hudson to Exit ‘Color Purple’; Enter Heather Headley
abstract: Jennifer Hudson will leave the musical “The Color Purple” on May 8, and Heather Headley’s first performance in the show will be on May 10.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Hudson, the Oscar-winning singer making a sultry Broadway debut as the nightclub singer Shug Avery, is planning to leave the cast of “The Color Purple” next month, the show’s producers said Thursday.

headline: What an Overpass Collapse Reveals
abstract: Political corruption in India and its deadly connection to the construction business.
lead_paragraph: Witnesses said it sounded like a bomb going off. On March 31, a 300-foot section of a vehicle overpass in Kolkata, India, crashed down in a crowded neighborhood, killing 27 people and injuring at least 85 others.

headline: 1990: An N.H.L. Draft Class to Remember

headline: ISIS Abducts Workers From Cement Factory in Syria
abstract: If confirmed, the mass kidnapping reported by state media would punctuate the Islamic State’s penchant for brazen acts even in the face of recent defeats.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Islamic State fighters abducted at least 170 workers from a cement factory northeast of the Syrian capital, Damascus, when the militant group attacked the area this week, activists and the Syrian government said on Thursday.

abstract: The annual letter from the JPMorgan Chase chief addresses subjects like patriotism and the growth of financial technology.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'States (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']

abstract: As this high-tech capital marches steadily into the future, visitors should not forget the city’s regal past — nor its celebrated culinary offerings.

lead_paragraph: A New York City’s Metropolitan Museum of Art employee gives T an unprecedented behind-the-scenes tour of the most spectacular treasure trove of art in the world.

headline: Video Shows Texas School Officer Body-Slamming 12-Year-Old Girl
abstract: The officer was put on leave after a cellphone video showed him throwing the girl face first to the sidewalk to intervene in a confrontation at a San Antonio middle school.
lead_paragraph: The San Antonio school district is investigating an encounter captured on a cellphone video that showed a school police officer slamming a 12-year-old girl face first to the sidewalk.

headline: Matthew Broderick to Star in Revival of ‘Shining City’
abstract: The Irish Repertory Theater production of this work by Conor McPherson starts previews on May 17 and opens on June 9.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Broderick is to star in the new Irish Repertory Theater production of “Shining City,” which opens in previews in May. The play, which was written by Conor McPherson and explores loneliness in a big city, ran on Broadway in 2006 to critical acclaim and received two Tony nominations.

headline: Republicans Hire Veteran Strategists to Help With Conventions
abstract: The Republican National Committee, facing a suddenly unwieldy process as states begin to select delegates at their own conventions, has hired two veteran strategists to help out.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Committee, facing a suddenly unwieldy process as states begin to select delegates at their own conventions, has hired two veteran strategists to help out, officials said.

headline: Behind the Scenes at the Met
abstract: One employee gives T an unprecedented look at what happens just beyond the gallery walls.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Metropolitan Museum of Art is one of the world’s greatest treasure boxes, a two-million-square-foot vault with more than 5,000 years of visual splendors. Beyond its gallery walls, it is a place where time slips away and ghosts roam the stairways.

headline: With ‘Sing Street,’ John Carney Evokes His MTV
abstract: The Irish writer-director (“Once”) recalls the music videos of the 1980s that inspired him when he was making his new romantic comedy.
lead_paragraph: After making the music-themed dramas “Once” and “Begin Again,” the writer-director John Carney knew he needed to change his cinematic tune. “There are only so many ways you can show people creatively fashioning a song,” Mr. Carney said in a recent phone interview from his hometown, Dublin. “It seemed like maybe I should look at another dimension.”

headline: Framework of Settlement Is Said to Be Reached in Sumner Redstone Competency Case
abstract: An agreement would end the public spectacle that began in November when a former companion of Mr. Redstone filed suit challenging his mental capacity.
lead_paragraph: The framework of a settlement has been reached in the salacious legal battle over the mental competency of the ailing media mogul Sumner M. Redstone, two people with knowledge of the discussions said Thursday.

headline: At Least 17 Civilians Killed in U.S. Airstrikes, Afghan Officials Say
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Officials and elders in Paktika Province said 17 civilians were killed in American drone strikes, while a United States military spokesman said there was no evidence of such casualties.
lead_paragraph: KHOST, Afghanistan — American airstrikes in the southeastern Afghan province of Paktika killed at least 17 civilians, local officials and elders said on Thursday, differing from official American and Afghan claims that only militants had been killed.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘Demolition’
abstract: Jean-Marc Vallée narrates a sequence from his film featuring Jake Gyllenhaal.
lead_paragraph: Jean-Marc Vallée narrates a sequence from his film featuring Jake Gyllenhaal.

headline: Jean-Marc Vallée Narrates a Scene From ‘Demolition’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from his film featuring Jake Gyllenhaal.
lead_paragraph: In “Demolition,” Jake Gyllenhaal plays an investment banker who tragically loses his wife. He copes by destroying a lot of things. In this scene, his character comes across a demolition site and asks the construction workers to let him participate in the job. In an interview at the South by Southwest film festival in Austin, the director Jean-Marc Vallée discussed the scene and his film. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: 4 New York Police Leaders Reassigned Amid Corruption Inquiry
abstract: Two were placed on modified duty, and two others were transferred from their assignments in a first wave of discipline connected with a federal investigation.
lead_paragraph: Four high-ranking veterans of the New York Police Department were reassigned to desk jobs on Thursday in what is likely to be a first wave of discipline stemming from a wide-ranging federal corruption investigation.

headline: How Do You Change Voters’ Minds? Have a Conversation
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Voting and Voters', 'Research']
abstract: Going door to door, a Los Angeles-based activist group tries to reduce prejudice against transgender people. A new study finds that it works.
lead_paragraph: Dave Fleischer — a short, bald, gay, Jewish 61-year-old with bulging biceps and a distaste for prejudice — knocked on the front door of a modest home in a middle-class neighborhood on the west side of Los Angeles. It was an enthusiastic knuckle-thump, the kind that arouses suspicion from dogs in yards halfway down the block but, crucially, can also be heard by humans watching cable news at high volume.

headline: Doorstep Canvassing Can Shift Views on Transgender Rights, Study Finds
abstract: The study, a follow-up to a 2014 report, found that a type of face-to-face conversation, drawing out voters’ own experiences, could lead to a lasting change in opinion.
lead_paragraph: Door-to-door political canvassers can soften the attitudes of some voters who are resistant to transgender rights by prompting them to reflect on their own experiences of being treated differently, researchers reported on Thursday.

headline: Climate Models May Overstate Clouds’ Cooling Power, Research Says
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: If further research supports the findings of a new paper, it suggests that making progress against global warming will be even harder.
lead_paragraph: The computer models that predict climate change may be overestimating the cooling power of clouds, new research suggests. If the findings are borne out by further research, it suggests that making progress against global warming will be even harder.

headline: Myanmar to Free Political Prisoners, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi Says
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, the country’s state counselor, said releasing the prisoners was the top priority of the new government.
lead_paragraph: MANDALAY, Myanmar — Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, in her first act as Myanmar’s state counselor, said Thursday that she would seek to free political prisoners, including students, describing the issue as the top priority of her party’s new government.

headline: For Co-Workers, What’s in a (Nick)Name
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Names, Personal', 'Families and Family Life', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Marriages', 'Friendship']
abstract: Also, a desire to rescind “save the date,” languishing in the role of second banana and playing down appearances.
lead_paragraph: I am a woman in my 20s and work in a small, friendly office of 20 people. My given name is Andie. I have a male colleague, who goes by the nickname Andy. To cut down on confusion, my colleagues started calling me Andie Girl or Miss Andie, and him Andy Boy or Mr. Andy. I hate it! It’s infantilizing and condescending. But I didn’t nip it in the bud, and now everyone in the company uses these nicknames, including Human Resources and our C.E.O. Is there a way to address this that doesn’t seem as if I’m suddenly overreacting?

headline: The Achilles’ Heel of Too Many Golfers: A Bad Back
abstract: Phil Mickelson says proper technique can avoid injuries; Bryson DeChambeau, an amateur, believes in same-length irons.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — In his 24th Masters, Phil Mickelson is an evangelist spreading the gospel according to Ernest Jones, whose 1937 book, “Swing the Clubhead Method,” is Mickelson’s sacred text. He teed off Thursday at Augusta National Golf Club with a fourth green jacket in his sights and a message to spread about longevity in the sport.

headline: Immigrants for Donald Trump? Some in New York Show Their Support
abstract: Despite Mr. Trump’s inflammatory comments, some immigrants have come forward to praise, and even endorse, him as he seeks the Republican presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Along the campaign trail, Donald J. Trump likes to pick out the people who, despite his having insulted their ethnic group, support him in the race for the Republican presidential nomination. They love him, they really do.

headline: The Rocky Road of Insider Trading Law
abstract: While a securities fraud case awaits argument in the Supreme Court, a conflict remains over what is needed to prove a trading violation.
lead_paragraph: The law of insider trading has become even more unsettled since the Supreme Court agreed to hear the appeal of the securities fraud conviction in Salman v. United States.

headline: How to Make Home Renovations Pay Off
keywords: ['Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Home Equity Loans']
abstract: As remodeling season gets underway, here are some tips to keep in mind as you prepare to sell your home or make changes to a new purchase.
lead_paragraph: Despite recent snowy and chilly weather in some parts of the country, the calendar says it’s spring — and many homeowners are contemplating upgrades to their houses and yards. This year, remodeling activity is expected to accelerate at a brisk pace.

headline: The Soprano Ailyn Pérez Wins Beverly Sills Artist Award
abstract: The award comes with a $50,000 prize for Ms. Pérez, who made her Met debut last year in Bizet’s “Carmen” and returns to the Met on April 15.
lead_paragraph: The soprano Ailyn Pérez has won this year’s Beverly Sills Artist Award, which offers a $50,000 prize to help foster the careers of young singers who have appeared in solo roles at the Metropolitan Opera, that company announced on Thursday.

headline: John Colapinto Revives the Male-Centric Literary Sex Novel
abstract: A New Yorker writer receives 41 rejections on a novel that goes back to a territory once explored by Updike, Mailer and Roth.
lead_paragraph: There was a time when the great American male novelists took delight in writing about sex. Rebelling against a literary tradition that perhaps underestimated how much space animal urges take up in the male brain, many big hitters of the 20th century, like Norman Mailer, Vladimir Nabokov, Henry Miller, Philip Roth, John Updike and Saul Bellow, dived into the muck with the zeal of Rabelais or Cleland.

headline: It Didn’t Add Up

headline: John Kerry Confronts Concerns of Arab States After Iran Nuclear Deal
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Arms Trade']
abstract: In Bahrain for a meeting of the Arab states this week, the secretary of state found himself disputing arguments that Tehran was “as dangerous as ever.”
lead_paragraph: MANAMA, Bahrain — A year after he struck the outlines of a nuclear deal with Iran, Secretary of State John Kerry finds himself confronting a new challenge from Tehran: While it is observing the nuclear agreement to the letter, its missile launches, arms shipments to Yemen and involvement in Syria have, if anything, accelerated.
