headline: A ‘Flawed Story’ on Gay Talese, and ‘Clumsy’ Handling of Race and Gender
abstract: Times top editor says newsroom culture must change.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 6:20 p.m.

headline: Spotify Recommends a New Boyfriend
abstract: Reading too much into a person’s playlist.
lead_paragraph: Spotify: Hi, {NAME REDACTED}.

headline: Mets Receive Rings of Their Own, for Being N.L. Champions
abstract: The ceremony came on Thursday, two days after the Mets watched the Royals receive their World Series rings in their opening series.
lead_paragraph: After enduring two ceremonies in Kansas City, Mo., this week honoring the Royals’ World Series victory, the Mets gathered on Thursday at Citi Field for their own ceremony. It was a private, intimate affair to hand out their own rings, for being the National League champions in 2015.

headline: New York Moves on Restricting Costumed Characters in Times Square
abstract: A bill passed by the City Council would let the Transportation Department create rules for pedestrian plazas that could restrict the costumed characters and painted topless women to designated zones.
lead_paragraph: After a furor last summer over topless women and menacing superheroes, New York City is moving to rein in the performers who hustle for tips in Times Square.

headline: Make Museums Interactive
abstract: A reader writes, “The museum that leverages that desire for engagement will thrive.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Rudolph Giuliani to Vote for, but Not Endorse, Donald Trump
abstract: In an interview, the former mayor said that while he planned to vote for Mr. Trump in New York’s primary, he would have more influence at the convention if he did not endorse anyone.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani is not endorsing Donald J. Trump. But he is voting for him.

headline: Better Than ‘Yeoman’
abstract: A reader suggests a substitution, and another considers the possible consequences of changing the Navy title.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: 9 Strokes, Then What? For Ernie Els, On to 2nd Hole
abstract: Els’s 9 was the highest score on the first hole in the 80-year history of the Masters.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The first hole at Augusta National, a par 4 measuring 445 yards, requires players to hit from an elevated tee to a fairway that breaks right to left, then hit their second shots to an elevated green. It calls to mind a roller coaster, and it made a few stomachs drop during the opening round of the Masters.

headline: ‘Periods for Pence’ Campaign Targets Indiana Governor Over Abortion Law
abstract: The social media missives directed to Gov. Mike Pence have been frequent, pointed and unyielding in their descriptions of female physiology.
lead_paragraph: One woman invited Gov. Mike Pence to her gynecologist appointment. Another provided an update on her cramps.  Another tweeted that she had just changed her tampon.

headline: Standardized Tests
abstract: An education writer says “adoption of the SAT or ACT as a mandatory statewide high school exam is objectionable.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ah, Those Augusta Memories (of 2015): Jordan Spieth Races to Early Lead
abstract: After Arnold Palmer, Jack Nicklaus and Gary Player stirred nostalgia among the fans, Spieth, the defending champion, shot a six-under-par 66 in the first round of the Masters.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Nostalgia had its moments on the first morning of the Masters on Thursday.

headline: Egon Schiele Works to Be Returned to Descendant of Holocaust Victim
keywords: ['Arts and Antiquities Looting', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Museums']
abstract: The Leopold Museum in Vienna will return two works by Egon Schiele to a descendant of Karl Mayländer, a Jewish collector who was deported from Austria and killed during the Holocaust.
lead_paragraph: Two works by the Austrian painter Egon Schiele will be returned to a descendant of the paintings’ former owner, Karl Mayländer, a Jewish collector who was deported from Austria and killed during the Holocaust.

headline: Review: The Bold Voice of Rebecca Schiff, in 23 Stories
abstract: Ms. Schiff makes her debut in a collection of stories that takes aim at the disconnects of the connected society.
lead_paragraph: To read the novels and stories of Karen Russell, Sheila Heti, Rivka Galchen, Adelle Waldman, Alexandra Kleeman, Nell Zink, Ottessa Moshfegh and Rebecca Curtis, among others, is to notice we’re in a golden age of young female writers who, when they wish to be, are powerfully, cleansingly and sometimes bawdily funny.

headline: Review: Melissa McCarthy Takes Charge in ‘The Boss’
abstract: Playing a fallen investment guru, Ms. McCarthy employs her precision comedic timing in a film that’s mostly another rung on her big ladder up.
lead_paragraph: In her new laugh-in, “The Boss,” Melissa McCarthy plays Michelle Darnell, an investment guru with a motivational racket along the inspirational lines of Tony Robbins and Suze Orman. Wildly successful, Michelle fills stadiums with true believers who drink her snake oil by the tanker, cheering as she preaches the gospel of personal riches and the power of you you you, even if it’s really all about her her her. She’s peddling empowerment of a kind, as is this movie, gleefully silly froth that Ms. McCarthy sells with slapstick, you-go-girl uplift and a Kewpie doll smile that’s one twitch short of pure madness.

headline: Judge Prods Wildlife Service on Protection for Wolverines
abstract: The chief federal district judge in Montana said the reclusive mountain animal may fall victim to reduced snowfall related to climate change.
lead_paragraph: HELENA, Mont. — Because it depends on heavy spring snowpack to excavate dens and safely raise its young near the top of mountain peaks high in the northern Rockies, the wolverine is on the front lines of battles over the effects of climate change.

headline: First Draft Focus: Getting It Right in the Bronx
abstract: Surrounded by a news media crush, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio feasted on Italian food at Mike’s Deli on Arthur Avenue in the Bronx on Thursday. His culinary adventure went a lot smoother than a stop in Queens last week, when he ate pizza with a fork. “We love New York values,” he told reporters Thursday, adding that “great food” was part of what constituted those values.

headline: Joel Kurtzman, Economist of Gloom Who Shifted to Optimism, Dies at 68
abstract: Credited with coining the term”economic headwinds,” Mr. Kurtzman originally projected the crash of American markets but eventually predicted a bright future.
lead_paragraph: Joel Kurtzman, an economic Cassandra who gloomily calculated the impact of globalization and projected the crash of domestic markets, but who capped his career two years ago by predicting a “Second American Century” of unimaginable prosperity, died on Wednesday at his home in Concord, Mass. He was 68.

headline: Behind the Scenes at Disney as It Purged a Favorite Son
abstract: Thomas Staggs’s departure from the No. 2 position at the media giant leaves no clear successor for Robert Iger as chief executive.
lead_paragraph: Thomas O. Staggs, then the chief financial officer of the Walt Disney Company, was having lunch with Robert A. Iger and other high-ranking Disney executives in 2003 in the company’s boardroom when food lodged in Mr. Iger’s windpipe.

headline: E.C.B. Rules Out Free Money as Antidote to Falling Prices
abstract: “Helicopter money” is not on the table, a top central banker says, but officials at the European Central Bank acknowledge they are worried about deflation.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — With the eurozone economy still listless, despite the aggressive stimulus measures being taken by the European Central Bank, economists at a conference here on Thursday were full of advice on aggressive next steps.

headline: How to Train Like the Mountain From ‘Game of Thrones’
abstract: Julius Bjornsson doesn’t just play a strong man on TV.
lead_paragraph: “It’s my passion and my dream to become the world’s strongest man,” said Hafthor Julius Bjornsson, the Icelandic giant best known as Gregor Clegane, or the Mountain, on HBO’s “Game of Thrones,” which returns this month.

headline: The Revelations of the Panama Papers
abstract: Readers react to disclosures about the use of tax havens by prominent political figures and their families and associates worldwide.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘Look at Us Now, Mother!,’ a Documentary of a Family and Its Discontents
abstract: In a film that promises an “epic journey” to explore her family’s “long-buried suffering,” the director, Gayle Kirschenbaum, interviews her mother, now in her 90s.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to like everyone in “Look at Us Now, Mother!,” and that’s the death knell for this documentary. For a movie that promises an “epic journey” to explore a family’s “long-buried suffering,” it’s strangely unsatisfying, and eventually wearisome, to find that this clan is deeply troubled perhaps only in the eyes of its filmmaker.

headline: Review: ‘High Strung’ Finds a Dancer and Musician Colliding
abstract: The movie, in which two young artists fall for each other, is energized by Dave Scott’s choreography.
lead_paragraph: There’s really only one reason to see “High Strung” — Michael Damian’s wishy-washy nod to “Fame” (1980) — and that’s the ebullient choreography of Dave Scott, whose accelerated and witty hip-hop routines have long been highlights of movies and reality television shows.

headline: Don’t Cry for Merle Haggard. Cry for Country Music.
abstract: Today’s country airwaves are dominated by generic party tunes.
lead_paragraph: When you read all the tributes today to the late Merle Haggard, all the mournful praise about what a great songwriter he was, remember that a big part of country music today has no interest in Mr. Haggard’s big themes, the rage and sorrow of the working man. What you hear on the country airwaves today are generic party tunes by gym-toned guys singing about beer and fast cars and sex on pickup-truck tailgates. (Some call it “bro country” and even its major purveyors find it embarrassing. Whatever you call it, Mr. Haggard hated it.)

headline: See the Ramones as You’ve Never Seen Them Before: Smiling
abstract: A rarely seen image from the band’s early days reveals another side of its character.
lead_paragraph: For four decades, the affectless portrait on the cover of the Ramones’ self-titled debut album has proclaimed, “We don’t need you,” inspiring generations of young outsiders.

headline: Review: In ‘Hardcore Henry,’ a Semi-Robotic Soldier Has a Personal Mission
abstract: This Ilya Naishuller film has the look of a first-person-shooter video game.
lead_paragraph: The subjective camera is arguably as old as cinema itself, but films with an exclusively first-person-singular perspective are relatively rare. One such picture, “Lady in the Lake,” a 1947 detective picture (adapted from a Raymond Chandler novel) directed by and starring a largely unseen (save for mirror shots) Robert Montgomery, gets a nod of recognition in the much more frenetic and fantastical “Hardcore Henry.”

headline: What’s Going On in This Poem? Exploring Poetry Through Open-Ended Questions
abstract: We invite you to join us on April 14 when we will conduct a live “What’s Going On in This Poem?” discussion using the same three questions we use for images in our popular Monday feature.
lead_paragraph: Update, April 14: Here is our live “What’s Going On in This Poem?” discussion. Though the moderated segment is over, please continue to add comments and respond to others.

headline: Review: In ‘One More Time,’ a Dysfunctional Family Sings
abstract: In this Robert Edwards film, Christopher Walken plays a crooner seeking a comeback, and Amber Heard is his daughter, who has a voice but little drive.
lead_paragraph: How many more times will we have to watch a movie about a dysfunctional, overprivileged family whose self-absorbed members are the cause of their own problems? Apparently at least “One More Time,” which is the title of a new film by Robert Edwards that plows this tedious ground yet again.

headline: Review: ‘Havana Motor Club’ Explores Car Racing in Cuba
abstract: Bent-Jorgen Perlmutt’s documentary shows that Cuba’s automotive heritage feeds a racing culture, despite years of government limitations on competitions.
lead_paragraph: The vintage American cars that rumble through the streets of Havana have long served as four-wheeled emblems of Cuba and its roots in the past. Bent-Jorgen Perlmutt’s serviceable but slightly drawn-out documentary “Havana Motor Club” shows that this grand automotive heritage feeds a racing culture, despite years of government limitations on competitions.

headline: Judgment Day for Reckless Executives
keywords: ['Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Coal', 'Mines and Mining', 'Explosions (Accidental)']
abstract: Tougher penalties would deter bosses from ignoring safety laws.
lead_paragraph: Silver Spring, Md. — ON Wednesday, a Federal District Court judge, Irene C. Berger, sentenced Donald L. Blankenship, a former chief executive of the Massey Energy Company once known in Appalachia as the “King of Coal,” to one year in jail, with imprisonment to begin regardless of a pending appeal, and payment of a $250,000 fine. The judge’s decision sets a remarkable precedent: The first C.E.O. ever to be convicted of conspiring to violate industrial safety standards will soon take his place in prison.

headline: Review: ‘Mr. Right,’ With Anna Kendrick, Dips Into a Tricky Genre
abstract: This hybrid action thriller and romantic comedy follows Martha, who meets a blithe charmer and discovers that he’s a hit man.
lead_paragraph: Anna Kendrick’s star shows no sign of dimming. A nominee for a Tony Award (in 1998) and an Academy Award (in 2010), she can anchor a musical comedy franchise (both “Pitch Perfect” movies, with a third on the way) and indie character studies (Joe Swanberg’s “Happy Christmas” and “Drinking Buddies”). Now, with the slick, frenetic confection “Mr. Right,” she dips into that tricky genre, the hybrid action thriller and romantic comedy — and scores again.

headline: Tracking Down (Miserable) Mets Fans: Editors’ Notebook
abstract: Two editors on the Sports desk describe how they identified — and interviewed — the Mets fans featured in a photograph taken during last year’s World Series.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Christoph Fuhrmans and Jim Luttrell, two editors on the Sports desk, describe how they tracked down the Mets fans featured in a photograph taken during last year’s World Series.

headline: A Plea for Patience Probably Resonates With Phil Jackson
abstract: Jackson would have to agree with the points Sam Hinkie made in his 76ers resignation letter, given the critiques of his Knicks tenure so far.
lead_paragraph: It turns out that Jerry Colangelo has the job that many people thought or joked the Los Angeles-loving Phil Jackson was getting when he signed on with the Knicks in 2014.

headline: Ernst Tremmel, Nazi War Crimes Suspect, Dies Days Before Trial
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Mr. Tremmel, a 93-year-old former SS storm trooper who worked at Auschwitz, faced charges of complicity in the killings of at least 1,075 prisoners.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A 93-year-old former SS storm trooper who worked at the Auschwitz death camp in 1942 and 1943 has died, a week before the opening of his trial on charges of complicity in the killings of at least 1,075 prisoners transported to the camp.

headline: Review: In ‘The Invitation,’ Welcome to a Chiller Dinner
abstract: In this film directed by Karyn Kusama, there’s something off about the hostess, her lair of a house and some of the guests.
lead_paragraph: Dinner parties in movies tend to be overdetermined affairs, ideal settings for wit, wisdom and the breakdown of civilization. There’s nothing much amiss at first about the soiree in the low-budget chiller “The Invitation.” Most of the guests look as comfortable as the setting, a modernist lair wedged into a Los Angeles hillside. Still, there’s something off about the hostess, who’s slinking around barefoot wearing a vacant smile and a long white dress. It’s the kind of number that Joan Didion might once have slipped on for another beautiful-people night of anomie and booze.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Art in review, from Times critics.

headline: Free Pfizer! Why Inversions Are Good for the U.S.
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Shelters', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Federal Taxes (US)']
abstract: The new Obama administration rules will ultimately discourage companies from investing in the U.S.
lead_paragraph: DONALD J. TRUMP wants to build a bricks-and-mortar wall to keep immigrants out of the United States. President Obama wants to build a virtual wall to keep companies from leaving. Neither is likely to work.

headline: Review: In ‘Demolition,’ It’s Hammer Time for Jake Gyllenhaal
abstract: Mr. Gyllenhaal portrays a banker recovering from the loss of his wife, with Naomi Watts playing a customer service representative who draws his attention.
lead_paragraph: In “Demolition,” Jake Gyllenhaal diligently applies himself to playing a painfully familiar type in American movies that imagine having Something to Say: the Man Who Cannot Feel. His character, Davis Mitchell, is a Wall Street investment banker whose comfortably numb existence is jolted at the start of the film when his wife, Julia, dies in a car crash that leaves him physically and emotionally unscathed. In the weeks after the tragedy, Davis returns to work and acts as though nothing has happened but behaves erratically. His inability to display any grief infuriates his father-in-law, Phil (Chris Cooper), who is also his boss.

headline: Merle Haggard and ‘Okie From Muskogee,’ the Hit That Helped and Hurt Him
abstract: The song made Mr. Haggard the voice of a silent majority concerned by the rise of the counterculture and left him with a scar that never quite healed.
lead_paragraph: By the time Merle Haggard reached a certain age, it was clear that he had begun to fatigue of some choices, and songs, he made as a younger man. Chief among them was “Okie From Muskogee,” the No. 1 hit from 1969 that, through one lens, sent his career into overdrive and, through another, was more damaging.

headline: Review: ‘11 Minutes,’ a Whirl of Intersecting Tales Heading Toward Combustion
abstract: Jerzy Skolimowski’s film yields an illusion of simultaneous forward motion for events that are both extremely lucid and inscrutable.
lead_paragraph: What happens between 5 and 5:11 p.m. on a breezy Warsaw day to warrant 83 minutes of your attention? Everything and nothing. A young woman walks a dog. A hot dog vendor chats with a group of nuns. A sleazy filmmaker conducts an audition. A couple watch pornography on a laptop. A motorcycle courier speeds away from an adulterous liaison toward an appointment in a downtown high-rise. A young man rides a bus. An ambulance crew comes to the assistance of a woman in labor. An old man paints a landscape.

headline: Heather Evans Smith’s “Seen Not Heard”
abstract: The photographer’s series traces her own relationship with her daughter.
lead_paragraph: The photographer’s series traces her own relationship with her daughter.

headline: Photos that Capture the Intense Bond Between Mother and Daughter
abstract: Heather Evans Smith’s series “Seen Not Heard” chronicles her own child’s development — and how it changes their relationship.
lead_paragraph: In her series “Seen Not Heard,” the conceptual photographer Heather Evans Smith explores the relationship between mother and child, using herself and her daughter as the subjects. “I could see my daughter was starting to become her own person, developing her own personality,” Smith says. “I wanted to explore that shift in our relationship. How could I protect my daughter without possessing her? What traditions should I keep and which should we start anew?”

headline: In a Reversal, Lindsey Graham Says He Will Meet With Merrick Garland
abstract: The senator will meet with the president’s Supreme Court nominee out of “courtesy,” a spokesman said, even though Mr. Graham remains opposed to the nomination.
lead_paragraph: Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina, said on Thursday that he would sit down with President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee, reversing course after saying that he would not meet with him.

headline: Lessons in a Busy Week of Deal Busting
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The government’s crackdown on inversions and two lawsuits it filed this week offer some things for advisers, companies and shareholders to think about.
lead_paragraph: Corporate America fought the law and the law won.

headline: Going From Show to Show No More
abstract: Lisa Gajda has appeared in the ensembles of 18 Broadway musicals, including “Tuck Everlasting.” At 46, she says she’s ready to step off the stage.
lead_paragraph: At 46, Lisa Gajda is in her 18th Broadway musical, “Tuck Everlasting.” She expects it to be her last.

headline: Review: In ‘Louder Than Bombs,’ a Father and Sons Grieving
abstract: Gabriel Byrne, Jesse Eisenberg, Isabelle Huppert and Amy Ryan head the cast of Joachim Trier’s first English-language film.
lead_paragraph: “Louder Than Bombs,” the first English-language film by the Norwegian director Joachim Trier (“Reprise,” “Oslo, August 31st” ), is disarmingly quiet, not unlike the Smiths album that shares its title. Buried or deflected emotion — conveyed through mordant remarks, pregnant glances, long stretches of silence — can generate more impact than explosive drama. This counts as both an insight and a strategy: Mr. Trier’s direction is as restrained and tense as the behavior of his characters, who suffer without making too much noise about it until they seem ready to explode.

headline: The Next Best ‘Hamilton’
abstract: A lavishly illustrated new book is a companion to Lin-Manuel Miranda’s hit musical.
lead_paragraph: It used to be New Yorkers complained most about real estate, but lately the griping is about the scarcity of tickets for the hit musical “Hamilton.” (The show’s creator and star, Lin-Manuel Miranda, answers our By the Book questions this week.)

headline: Review: ‘Neon Bull,’ With Creatures Great and Small
abstract: Gabriel Mascaro’s film explores the connections between humans and animals played out against the setting of the Brazilian rodeo event known as vaquejada.
lead_paragraph: Because so few of us grow up close to stables and barnyards, the primal kinship between people and animals is easily taken for granted. But lest we forget, human beings, probably more than many would like to admit, are beasts. The connection between human and animal is intimate enough that we instinctively project our values and aspirations onto animals almost as though they were our children. At the same time, in our vanity, we need to distinguish ourselves from creatures on which we depend for food, livelihood and companionship. God forbid that we should smell like them.

headline: Art May Clash With Commerce in the Crown Building
abstract: Adrienne Edwards curates an exhibition about black monochromatic art at Pace Gallery, and a dreamy Frida Kahlo comes up for sale.
lead_paragraph: Hirschl & Adler expanded its current 13,000-square-foot space in the Crown Building on Fifth Avenue, near 57th Street, just five years ago. Needless to say, the gallery has no interest in leaving.

headline: Comedy Listings for April 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City. For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City. For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Correction Officer Charged With Beating Inmate in Bronx
abstract: Bradford Jones is accused of using a radio to attack a man in a holding cell at the Bronx County Courthouse.
lead_paragraph: A New York City correction officer has been arrested on charges that he used a radio to brutally beat an inmate in a holding cell at the Bronx County Courthouse, officials said on Thursday.

headline: Movie Listings for April 8-14
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.
lead_paragraph: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Start-Stop Technology Is Spreading (Like It or Not)
abstract: The system saves fuel by cutting the engine when the car comes to a stop, but many drivers find it disruptive and disable it.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Keith Tao, a radiologist in Danville, Calif., owns three late-model Mercedeses, each equipped with a fuel-saving technology called start-stop.

headline: Classical Music Listings for April 8-14
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

headline: The David Parr House’s Hidden Gem in Cambridge, England
abstract: This tiny rowhouse turned museum will allow small groups of visitors starting on April 18.
lead_paragraph: The David Parr House in Britain is a sort of time capsule: a tiny brick 19th-century rowhouse turned museum that has scarcely changed in the nine decades since its best-known owner died. A decorative painter who specialized in Gothic Revival designs, Mr. Parr started experimenting with artwork in his home in 1887. For 40 years, he embellished the walls with vines, flowers, simulations of wood grain and snippets of Victorian verse.

headline: John Kasich Attacks Ted Cruz for ‘New York Values’ Line
abstract: Mired in third place in the race for the Republican nomination, the Kasich campaign looks to make up ground in New York by attacking the Texas senator.
lead_paragraph: First, it was the “Lyin’ Ted” moniker. Now, it’s Senator Ted Cruz’s “New York values” comments. As the campaign of Gov. John Kasich of Ohio takes its turn aiming negative advertising at Mr. Cruz, it parrots attacks made by Donald J. Trump. The latest is an ad from the Kasich campaign titled “Values.”

headline: 12 Great Recipes for the Weekend
abstract: A weekend meal plan, suggested reading and Merle Haggard.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Review: FJK Dance Brings Its Fusion to New York
abstract: This New York-based troupe, led by the Iraqi-born dancer and choreographer Fadi J. Khoury, specializes in a melding of styles.
lead_paragraph: FJK Dance, led by the Iraqi-born dancer and choreographer Fadi J. Khoury, specializes in a fusion of styles. Imagine bits of Middle Eastern movement wedged between slices of ballet and ballroom. Yet beyond that, his New York-based group has loftier ambitions: to unite through the power of dance.

headline: G.E. Chief Executive Issues Ill-Advised Response to Bernie Sanders
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Tax Shelters']
abstract: Jeff Immelt appeared to take sides in the Democratic nominating contest with a recent op-ed.
lead_paragraph: Gee, G.E.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Bill Clinton, Heckled by ‘Black Lives’ Protesters, Defends Record on Crime
abstract: While campaigning for his wife in Philadelphia, Mr. Clinton was forced to defend his 1994 crime bill and said that Black Lives Matter protesters were misguided.
lead_paragraph: The interruptions came with a frequency and fervor usually seen at a Trump rally. But on Thursday it was former President Bill Clinton facing a barrage of protests from critics who disapprove of his record on overhauling the criminal justice system.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for April 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area. For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: G.M. Settles Ignition-Switch Case Planned as Bellwether Trial
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The automaker’s move was unexpected, but the case would have been the first of six advance trials to involve a fatal accident.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — General Motors on Thursday said it had settled a wrongful death case that was set to go to trial next month as part of ongoing litigation over the company’s defective ignition switches.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Opera Stars Come Out for a Gala Concert
abstract: Sondra Radvanovsky gave a heartfelt performance and Ben Heppner acted as master of ceremonies at a concert at the Morgan Library & Museum.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes a performer becomes so associated with a particular role that it takes a moment to adjust when they appear out of character. The soprano Sondra Radvanovsky has portrayed Donizetti’s Tudor queens with such fierce conviction at the Metropolitan Opera this season that I almost expected her to sweep onto the stage in full-skirted regal attire at Gilder Lehrman Hall at the Morgan Library & Museum on Wednesday evening.

headline: Jazz Listings for April 8-14
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City. Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City. Full reviews of recent jazz performances: nytimes.com/jazz. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Tesla’s Model 3 Already Has 325,000 Preorders
abstract: The depth of enthusiasm for the company’s first mass-market electrified model, as measured by reservations, has stunned industry analysts.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Orders keep rolling in for the forthcoming Model 3 from Tesla Motors, which said on Thursday that it had received $1,000 deposits for more than 325,000 of its newest electric cars.

headline: Robert Irwin’s Art Takes New Forms Right Before Your Eyes at the Hirshhorn
abstract: This is Mr. Irwin’s first major American survey outside his native California in nearly 40 years.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Early in the 1960s, Robert Irwin barred people from photographing his art. I suspect he wasn’t too thrilled to have it written about either. Self-identified as a painter at the time, he was in the process of refining his work to the point that it was accessible only through direct experience. To see it at all, you had to be there. In a way, he was proposing a new kind of “action painting.” The action in his version was generated not by the hand of the artist and embodied in frozen strokes of paint, but by the mind and eye of the viewer, approaching art, taking it in and reacting to it in real time.

headline: At Dance Theater of Harlem, Where’s the ‘Theater’?
abstract: The company’s gala program, which included two premieres, put performers through their paces but lacked theatricality.
lead_paragraph: Where is the “theater” in Dance Theater of Harlem these days? At its gala performance at City Center on Wednesday, its dancers showed plenty of charm, enthusiasm, style and bravura. The several happy speeches made us aware that the company is a worthy cause. Gladys Knight and Joyce Dinkins, a longtime supporter of the company (and the wife of David Dinkins), were honored. All four items of choreography, however, felt like end-of-year graduation exercises. Though they put their performers through their paces, they never seriously showed us how dance can become theater.

headline: Dance Listings for April 8-14

headline: The Art of Secret Societies, Filled With Codes and Glyphs
abstract: A new exhibition focuses on artifacts from 19th-century clubs and fraternities.
lead_paragraph: Knowledge may be power, but some kinds of knowledge are more powerful and potentially more dangerous than others. So people in the know may form secret organizations to protect themselves from inquisitorial authorities. To keep their intellectual property out of the hands of interlopers and evildoers, they may cloak it in coded texts, symbolic imagery and rituals. Two such groups were the Masons (or Freemasons), whose origins date to the formation of European stoneworker fraternities at least as early as the 15th century, and the Odd Fellows, a fraternity of men in various occupations that emerged in England in the late-18th century.

headline: Will You Sprint, Stroll or Stumble Into a Career? Readers Respond
keywords: ['Millennial Generation', 'Careers and Professions', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Readers shared stories about their journey into adulthood.
lead_paragraph: An Education Life article by Jeffrey J. Selingo describing the ways in which young people journey into adulthood touched a nerve with hundreds of New York Times readers. The article — “Will You Sprint, Stroll or Stumble Into a Career?” drew a wide array of anecdotes from our commenters. Here is a selection of their responses, which have been edited for clarity.

lead_paragraph: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: MoMA Takes On the ’60s in a Welcome Shakeup of the Permanent Collection Galleries
abstract: It’s great to see an experimental approach to these galleries, but putting everything in a blender also has a homogenizing effect.
lead_paragraph: Since reopening in its expanded building in 2004, the Museum of Modern Art has shaken itself up in numerous ways, some for better, others for worse. Worse includes a penchant for atrium-oriented spectacle, like Tilda Swinton sleeping in a vitrine; earsplitting music at seemingly every opening; and the debacle that was its halfhearted Björk retrospective.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for April 8-14
abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Tonys Committee Makes Eligibility Decisions
abstract: The Tony Administration Committee met Thursday to make decisions about awards eligibility for recently opened productions and the performers in them.
lead_paragraph: Two Academy Award winners now performing on Broadway saw their Tony Awards prospects clarified on Thursday, as the committee that determines eligibility worked to define the landscape for this year’s voting.

headline: This Week’s Movies | April 8, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Demolition,” “Louder Than Bombs” and “The Boss.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Demolition,” “Louder Than Bombs” and “The Boss.”

headline: European Union to Consider Requiring Visas for U.S. Travelers
abstract: The union is stepping up pressure on the United States to add more European countries to its list of those entitled to visa-free travel.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The European Union is stepping up pressure on the United States to add more European countries to the list of those whose citizens can travel across the Atlantic without a visa, holding out the threat of requiring Americans to get visas for trips to Europe if Washington does not agree.

headline: Letters: Every College Girl’s Dream
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Peggy Orenstein’s “Girls and Sex,” Olivia Laing’s “The Lonely City” and more.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Predicting the Staying Power of ‘The Jungle Book’
abstract: An 1899 essay in The New York Times got to the heart of how he would secure his place in the firmament of childhood.
lead_paragraph: You don’t have to agree with George Orwell to wonder about Hollywood’s long love affair with Rudyard Kipling. “A jingo imperialist,” “morally insensitive,” “aesthetically disgusting” and possessing “a definite strain of sadism” were among Orwell’s descriptions of him. On the other hand, “The Jungle Book,” whose stars are mostly animals, is at least somewhat inoculated against not only Kipling’s harshest critics but also the range of views about him that have emerged over the last century.

headline: Review: Kirill Gerstein Makes Sense of the Fantastical
abstract: This pianist’s program at the 92nd Street Y was organized around two genres: the sonata and the fantasy.
lead_paragraph: At 14, the pianist Kirill Gerstein became the youngest student ever to enter the Berklee College of Music in Boston, where he studied jazz. Now that two decades have passed, and he’s become one of the distinguished classical artists of his generation, it’s tempting to try to detect the influence of those early studies on his playing of the canon. The takeaway from his remarkable recital on Wednesday at the 92nd Street Y: It’s there, but not in any obvious ways.

headline: Ben Silverman, a Veteran TV Executive, Joins Propagate Content
abstract: Mr. Silverman will be Propagate’s chairman and co-chief with Howard T. Owens, his longtime collaborator who founded the studio.
lead_paragraph: The veteran television executive Ben Silverman announced on Thursday that he had landed at the entertainment studio Propagate Content as its new chairman and co-chief executive.

headline: Review: ‘That Physics Show,’ Where Newton Meets Nitrogen
abstract: Family theater in this case means graphic, high-speed and sometimes fiery demonstrations of the laws of physics.
lead_paragraph: Dave Maiullo may have developed the perfect deterrent to theatergoers who text and tweet during plays: threaten to dip their smartphones in liquid nitrogen.

headline: Ruling Behind MetLife’s ‘Too Big to Fail’ Reprieve Unsealed
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The ruling shows that Judge Rosemary Collyer was unimpressed with the analysis underpinning the MetLife designation as “systemically important.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The financial industry now has more information about why a court allowed MetLife to shed its “too big to fail” label last week, in a major setback for supporters of the Dodd-Frank Act.

headline: Week In Pictures: April 8
abstract: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

headline: With a New ‘Barbershop,’ Malcolm D. Lee Blends Comedy and Commentary
abstract: With “Barbershop: The Next Cut,” the director shares observations on the rising gun violence in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — In the 2002 comedy “Barbershop,” the most worrisome problem facing the shop owner Calvin Palmer (Ice Cube) is a duplicitous loan shark who wants to turn the neighborhood fixture into a strip club. Two years later, in “Barbershop 2: Back in Business,” Calvin’s biggest headache is competition from Nappy Cutz, a national franchise opening up across the street that, according to Calvin’s own clients, boasts “honeys in bikinis” serving wine to clients and live fish in the floor that customers can have fried, grilled or “fondued.”

headline: Magic Neorealism in World War’s Wake
abstract: “The Taviani Brothers Collection,” new from Cohen Media, gathers three films by the directors: “Padre Padrone,” “The Night of the Shooting Stars” and “Kaos.”
lead_paragraph: The brothers Paolo and Vittorio Taviani, now in their mid-80s, have had a long career in Italian cinema. Midway through, they enjoyed a relatively brief period in the international spotlight, following the success of “Padre Padrone” (“My Father, My Boss”).

headline: Yvette Fay Francis-McBarnette, a Pioneer in Treating Sickle Cell Anemia, Dies at 89
abstract: Dr. Francis was credited with successfully using antibiotics to treat children with the disease 15 years before the effectiveness of those drugs was confirmed.
lead_paragraph: Yvette Fay Francis-McBarnette, a Jamaican-born medical pioneer in treating children with sickle cell anemia, died on March 28 in Alexandria, Va. She was 89.

headline: In ‘Green Room,’ This Band Could Be Their Death
abstract: Two angry subcultures — hardcore punk and neo-Nazis — collide in Jeremy Saulnier’s thriller.
lead_paragraph: Blood, guts and punk rock are the accent notes in “Green Room,” a new thriller that brings throwback niches — the violent exploitation and siege films of the 1970s and the earnest, do-it-yourself hardcore punk bands of the 1980s — into the present day. Think a mash-up of “Straw Dogs” and “Our Band Could Be Your Life,” pitting low-level suburban musicians against white-supremacist skinheads, all in tight quarters.

headline: SpaceX Resuming Deliveries to International Space Station
keywords: ['International Space Station', 'Private Spaceflight', 'Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Freight (Cargo)']
abstract: A new mission comes nine months after a rocket disintegrated minutes after launch, leading to a revamped design and manufacturing process.
lead_paragraph: After a nine-month hiatus because of a rocket failure, the Space Exploration Technologies Corporation, or SpaceX, is to resume cargo deliveries for NASA on Friday.

headline: Rattled by Attacks, Many Belgians Still Want Nation Split in Two
keywords: ['Brussels Attacks (March 2016)', 'Terrorism', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Flemish Language']
abstract: The Brussels attacks have shaken Belgium, but many are asking whether the Flemish north would be better off becoming its own country.
lead_paragraph: ANTWERP, Belgium — Normally, Dieter Moyaert and his soccer-loving friends liked nothing more than hanging out at the Cafe Royal, a soccer bar dominated by hard-core fans of Royal Antwerp, watching a match, downing beers and, in a few cases, slipping into the bathroom for a stronger substance.

headline: John Kasich Plans New York Ad Arguing That Only He Can Beat Hillary Clinton
abstract: The governor’s team is also calling on Republicans eager to stop Donald J. Trump to supplement the campaign’s efforts with their own advertising boosting Mr. Kasich.
lead_paragraph: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio is going on the air in New York with a commercial that amounts to a preview of his message for a summer convention battle, arguing that he is the only Republican who can defeat Hillary Clinton in November if she is the Democratic nominee.

headline: Retirement Savings Made Safer
abstract: New rules will require financial advisers to act solely in a client’s best interests.
lead_paragraph: The road to retirement will be less rocky under new rules issued this week by the Labor Department. The rules require financial advisers to act solely in a client’s best interests when giving advice and selling investments for retirement accounts. The best-interest requirement, also known as a fiduciary duty, will be a big improvement on current practice, in which many advisers are free to steer clients into high-priced strategies and products even when comparable but cheaper ones are available.

headline: Amazon May Violate India’s New Rules on Foreign E-Commerce
abstract: The government added regulations related to pricing and the sourcing of sales on sites that Amazon and several rivals appear to break.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — For Amazon, no country is more important to its global growth ambitions than India, the second-most-populous nation in the world behind China, where online shopping is in its infancy and growing explosively.

headline: The Undoing of a Coal Baron
abstract: Donald Blankenship’s conviction and prison sentence over violation of mine safety laws brings a powerful message to a troubled industry.
lead_paragraph: It was the rarest of news in the coal mining hollows of Appalachia: A once powerful executive, Donald Blankenship, was sentenced Wednesday to a year in prison for conspiring to violate federal mine safety laws at the Upper Big Branch mine in West Virginia, where 29 workers died in an explosion six years ago. The very idea that a dominant baron of the industry called King Coal could be brought to justice and put behind bars shook the region, where miners have long complained that they face dangerous and illegal working conditions that routinely result in no punishment.

headline: Uber Settles Suit Over Driver Background Checks
abstract: The settlement brings to an end a long-running headache for Uber over whether it does enough to scrutinize its drivers.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber will pay as much as $25 million to settle a civil lawsuit with the district attorneys in Los Angeles and San Francisco over claims that the ride-hailing company misled people on its safety practices and the methods it used to screen drivers.

headline: Starboard Sets Sights on Board Seats at DepoMed
keywords: ['Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Starboard Value, a fund that took aim at Yahoo, has found another target for its activism.
lead_paragraph: Starboard Value, the hedge fund that has taken aim at Yahoo, has found another target for its brand of shareholder activism.

headline: Roma Poisoned at U.N. Camps in Kosovo May Get Apology and Compensation
keywords: ['Romani People', 'Lead', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Apologies', 'Compensation for Damages (Law)']
abstract: A panel found that the United Nations compromised the lives and health of inhabitants of the camps, which were built on a toxic wasteland and had high levels of lead.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of Roma families in Kosovo, who were forced to live for more than a decade in squalid United Nations camps built on toxic wasteland that leached lead and poisoned their children, have long become accustomed to frustration and despair.

headline: Bankruptcy Battle Threatens a Summer Chill in Atlantic City
abstract: Business owners worry that a standoff between Gov. Chris Christie and the city government may scare off vital business from tourists.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY — In a normal year, residents and business owners in this seaside resort would be making preparations for a summer-long influx of tourists and gamblers. But this is in no way a normal year in Atlantic City.

headline: Mark Teixeira Hits Them Where the Astros Aren’t, Bailing Out the Yankees’ Starter
abstract: Batting left-handed, Teixeira unexpectedly sent a single and a home run to left field, and Yankees starter Nathan Eovaldi avoided a loss despite allowing five runs in the first four innings.
lead_paragraph: Mark Teixeira’s first at-bat Thursday resulted in a jam shot that squeaked into left field because of the sharp shift to the right employed by the Houston Astros. The accidental single led to shocked applause from the sparse Yankee Stadium crowd, which had witnessed the rarity of Teixeira’s not pulling the ball for a base hit.

headline: A Treasury Secretary at the Center of Obama’s Most Pressing Policies
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'United States Economy', 'Corporate Taxes', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: From sanctions on Iran to regulations that helped foil a giant tax-dodging deal, Jacob J. Lew is at the center of some of the administration’s most prominent policies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jacob J. Lew, President Obama’s second-term Treasury secretary, has kept such a low profile in these relatively placid economic times, compared with his crisis-era predecessor, that it seemed he might end up best known for his pending decision to pick a woman for portraiture on the $10 bill.

headline: New Hire Signals a Reboot in the Donald Trump Campaign
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: After a primary loss in Wisconsin and amid reported infighting within his staff, Mr. Trump added a seasoned operative to aid his nomination effort.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is expanding his team and empowering his newly hired convention manager as he tries reboot his presidential campaign after the worst two-week stretch of his brief political career.

headline: Senate Takes Steps to Tighten Airport Security
abstract: In response to the attacks at the Brussels airport, senators added security measures aimed at addressing the fears of the American flying public.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate passed several provisions to bolster security throughout the nation’s transportation system Thursday, the first legislative response to the attacks on the airport and train station in Belgium last month.

headline: Education Overhaul Advocates Express Concern About Bill Clinton’s Remarks on Testing
abstract: Bill Clinton’s comments this week suggesting Hillary Clinton is not a fan of annual testing raised eyebrows in the so-called education reform movement.
lead_paragraph: Officials involved with what has become known as the education reform movement expressed concern over a statement this week by former President Bill Clinton about his wife’s view of mandatory testing.

headline: E.M. Nathanson, Author of ‘The Dirty Dozen,’ Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Nathanson’s novel, set in World War II, was adapted to film and became one of the most enduring of its genre.
lead_paragraph: E. M. Nathanson, whose best-selling 1965 novel “The Dirty Dozen” became the basis of one of the most enduring, if preposterous, World War II movies to come out of Hollywood, died on Tuesday at his home in Laguna Niguel, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s MetroCard Adventure: Swipe. Wince. Repeat.
abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s five swipes, something not unknown to veteran commuters, made her the latest candidate to stumble in a politically motivated subway ride.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton, the Democratic presidential front-runner, approached a Bronx subway turnstile on Thursday with the casualness of a regular commuter, MetroCard in hand.

headline: Ted Cruz Makes the Rounds, and Matzo, in Brooklyn
abstract: The Texas senator, wearing cowboy boots, joined a dozen children to make matzo at the Chabad Neshama Center in Brighton Beach. He just happened to mention Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas went to Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, on Thursday afternoon to make some matzo — the unleavened bread central to the Passover holiday later this month.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton Turn to Attacks on Credentials
abstract: In a change in tenor that may indicate difficulty in unifying Democrats, Mr. Sanders said Mrs. Clinton was unqualified to be president.
lead_paragraph: A Democratic primary campaign in which both candidates prided themselves on civility and debating the issues, rather than stooping to personal attacks, took a fractious turn on Thursday. After Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont called Hillary Clinton unqualified to be president, Democrats faced the prospect of an increasingly contentious nominating process hurting the party’s ability to unite against Republicans in the fall.

headline: De Blasio Supporter Convicted of Sexual Abuse Begins Jail Term
abstract: Ari Noe, one of the mayor’s backers in the Orthodox Jewish community, started a 15-day sentence nearly three years after his conviction for forcible touching.
lead_paragraph: One of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s leading supporters in New York’s Orthodox Jewish community surrendered in Manhattan Criminal Court on Thursday to begin a 15-day sentence for misdemeanor sexual abuse, after an appeals court rejected his request for a new trial, the district attorney’s office said.

headline: Judge Dismisses Suit to Halt Pier 55 Park on Manhattan’s West Side
abstract: The complainants said that the plan for a $130 million, 2.4-acre park extending over the Hudson River lacked transparency.
lead_paragraph: A judge in Manhattan dismissed a lawsuit on Thursday that sought to impede a plan led by the billionaire Barry Diller to build a 2.4-acre park, known as Pier 55, that would extend over the Hudson River.

headline: Janet Yellen and Fed Predecessors Find Common Ground Onstage
abstract: At a joint appearance by Janet Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, and her three living predecessors, the conversation quickly turned to their economic outlook.
lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said on Thursday that she did not regret the decision to start raising interest rates in December.

headline: Lang Lang to Deliver a Love Letter to New York, in Music
abstract: The pianist has planned a concert, “New York Rhapsody,” for May 3 at the Rose Theater and invited guests including Rufus Wainwright and Suzanne Vega.
lead_paragraph: The Chinese piano virtuoso Lang Lang, one of the few classical musicians to achieve pop-culture status, considers New York his adoptive home. And, as a kind of love letter, he is planning to gather fellow prominent singers and instrumentalists to celebrate the city’s rich musical history.

headline: It’s Not Common Knowledge
abstract: Friday fun with Patrick Berry.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Having a BAD DAY? Cheer up. It’s Friday and today’s crossword puzzle is by Patrick Berry. Those are always causes for celebration.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tom Wolf signed an executive order Thursday barring state contractors and grant recipients from discrimination based on sexual orientation or gender identity. Mr. Wolf, a Democrat, said he could not wait any longer for Republican lawmakers to move on legislation to ban such discrimination in employment, housing and public services. The move has the support of some of the state’s biggest businesses and advocacy groups. It comes amid a backlash over what Mr. Wolf has called a discriminatory law in North Carolina. The rules apply to entities that receive potentially tens of billions of dollars a year. (AP)

headline: Goalie Leads the Way as the Islanders Complete a Sweep of the Rangers
abstract: With the Islanders’ fourth straight win over the Rangers, both teams now have 99 points heading into the final weekend of the regular season.
lead_paragraph: The Islanders would probably look forward to an opening-round playoff series against the Rangers next week.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | tepid
abstract: This word has appeared in 239 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: tepid • \(ˌ)sə-ˈma-shən\ • adjective

headline: What to Watch Friday
abstract: “Catastrophe” starts Season 2 by finding Sharon and Rob coping with a second child. And Meryl Streep rocks out in “Ricki and the Flash.”
lead_paragraph: “Catastrophe” zooms ahead in Season 2 to find Sharon and Rob, those accidental parents, steering into the skid of life. Meryl Streep rocks out in a Bo Derek hairstyle in “Ricki and the Flash.” And Al Jazeera America presents its last documentary before going off the air on Tuesday.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Friday, April 8, 2016.
lead_paragraph: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 8, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not just, ‘Would you rather be shot or poisoned?’ Now it’s, ‘This isn’t so bad.’”

headline: The Week in Pictures: April 8
abstract: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

headline: The Lincoln Caucus
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Republican convention delegates should use their power and unite to bargain with candidates for a better Republicanism.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential campaign just changed. Until now this has been a candidate-centric process. All the different candidates were competing to get a majority of delegates to the G.O.P. convention. But now it’s likely no candidate will get that majority on the first ballot.

headline: A Mason-Dixon Line of Progress
keywords: ['States (US)', 'Minimum Wage', 'Discrimination', 'Family Leaves', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'State Legislatures', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: A Republican-controlled block has essentially decided that it’s better to be poor, sick and bigoted than prosperous, healthy and open-minded.
lead_paragraph: Inside the ancient town hall of Siena, Italy, the walls hold a series of magnificent 14th-century frescoes showing the effects of good government and bad. One side depicts a prosperous city-state, where justice and tolerance prevail in the Tuscan countryside. The other is ruled by a horned, fanged figure, the streets deserted and scary.

headline: Sanders Over the Edge
abstract: The revolutionary isn’t cute anymore.
lead_paragraph: From the beginning, many and probably most liberal policy wonks were skeptical about Bernie Sanders. On many major issues — including the signature issues of his campaign, especially financial reform — he seemed to go for easy slogans over hard thinking. And his political theory of change, his waving away of limits, seemed utterly unrealistic.

headline: Financial Secrecy in Panama and Beyond
keywords: ['Panama Papers', 'Tax Evasion', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Editorials', 'Tax Shelters']
abstract: While most nations have agreed to share information to root out tax havens, Panama has dragged its feet.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, leaders of the Group of 20 nations, distressed by the global financial crisis, pledged to dismantle the tax havens that have allowed the world’s richest people to avoid paying taxes. The United States and European governments were equally concerned about banks being used by tax cheats and criminals in a shadowy international financial system.

headline: News Q’s | Illuminating the Effects of Light Pollution
abstract: How do you think artificial lights affect plant and animal life on Earth?
lead_paragraph: The following lesson activities are based on the article “Illuminating the Effects of Light Pollution.”

headline: Tabloid Editor and Ex-Diplomat Square Off Over China’s Foreign Policy
abstract: Wu Jianmin, a former envoy to France, said Global Times often printed “very extreme articles” and suggested its editor was ignorant of global affairs.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — An unusual public spat between a Chinese ex-diplomat and the top editor of a well-known tabloid newspaper has set off debate on one of the paper’s favorite subjects: Beijing’s foreign policy.

headline: When Moving Forward Means Stepping Back
abstract: After a casual encounter goes terribly wrong, a young woman retreats from love.
lead_paragraph: My boyfriend knew he was losing me, which is why he sent me a box of books. It was a strategic move.

headline: U.S. History, Revised
abstract: Practice questions for the A.P. exam in American history.
lead_paragraph: Practice questions for the A.P. exam in American history.

headline: Ella Wendel Dies
abstract: The March 15, 1931 obituary of the last surviving member of the reclusive New York real estate family.
lead_paragraph: The March 15, 1931 obituary of the last surviving member of the reclusive New York real estate family.

headline: Before the Trumps, There Were the Wendels
abstract: The Wendel family, bygone real estate tycoons, avoided publicity and luxury. Their refusal to sell property drove the city crazy.
lead_paragraph: The most well-known developer in New York today may be a man with national aspirations and a propensity to talk off the top of his extravagantly coifed head, but a century ago, the headlines were commanded by a real estate family with an aversion to publicity and the trappings of wealth.

headline: After Bombing, Iraqi Player Hopes Soccer Holds the Power to Heal
abstract: Yaser Kasim, who plays for a club in the third tier of English soccer, visited the site of a deadly attack on a youth tournament in Iskandariya, Iraq.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — No one seemed interested in visiting Iskandariya, Iraq, after the bombing, even if this one stood out from so many others in recent months. In the attack on March 25, a bomber detonated a suicide vest during the trophy ceremony after a youth soccer tournament, killing 41 people, including 17 children. Some of the victims had just played in the event.

headline: Taking the Politics Out of American History (and Out of A.P.)
abstract: Perceived by conservatives as too progressive, Advanced Placement in United States history took a right turn and ended up in the middle.
lead_paragraph: On May 6, more than 470,000 students will sit for the Advanced Placement test in United States history. The exam distills 525 years of American history into 55 multiple-choice questions and six short and long essay questions. Much rides on the test beyond the potential for a high score. Events covered and questions asked will convey to impressionable, high-achieving high school students (and future national leaders) what is important, how to interpret it and, ultimately, how to feel about their country.

headline: Luka Sabbat, the 18-Year-Old Fashion Influencer
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Models (Professional)']
abstract: Advertisers envy his social media skills. Tom Ford provided him with a prom suit. “He’s the cool kid at the party we all want to be,” an admirer says.
lead_paragraph: Lil Yachty is fire. Astrud Gilberto and Hedi Slimane are sick. Playboi Carti is in this minute’s rotation, right there alongside Chet Baker, Bad Company, Kanye and the Germs. Call of Duty: Black Ops III is a dope game, though maybe not as dope as Tom Clancy’s Rainbow Six: Siege. Stéphane Ashpool’s pastel Pigalle cardigan is the latest score at retail — that, and a bomber from Alyx and a ring from Saint Laurent.

headline: They Survived a Brooklyn Fire. Then a New Ordeal Began.
abstract: The blaze put at least 35 families out of their homes, leaving many to deal with a maze of agencies and hotels as they sought to replace what they lost.
lead_paragraph: He was on the way to the shower when the shouts began. Jonathan Rondon turned and ran out of the building with his girlfriend and their baby daughter. His mother ran out, too. There was smoke in the stairway, getting thicker.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Bring Their Battle to Brooklyn
abstract: With dueling claims to home-court advantage, the fight for New York’s 291 Democratic delegates is being waged most fiercely in one particular borough.
lead_paragraph: In Brooklyn Heights, on the 11th floor of an office building, Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign headquarters was humming on Monday. Staff members and volunteers were working the phones in spacious offices with windows that look out on the Manhattan skyline. Photos of supporters, an array of campaign buttons and a hanging gong, with the names of states she has won scribbled onto it in marker, adorned the sleekly designed space. A retired New York police officer stood guard.

headline: Student Question | What Marketing Slogan Would You Use for Your Town or City?
abstract: What makes your community a worthwhile place to live or visit?
lead_paragraph: “I ♥ NEW YORK.” For a city and state tourist logo, it’s simple, memorable and iconic. But not every city and state has had similar success in developing its slogan.

headline: Kindred Spirits
abstract: Partners in real estate and real life, Tom Postilio and Mickey Conlon, were married on March 25 at the home of Michael Feinstein.
lead_paragraph: Partners in real estate and real life, Tom Postilio and Mickey Conlon, were married on March 25 at the home of Michael Feinstein.

headline: Off Broadway, Showmen Seal Their Biggest Deal
abstract: Tom Postilio and Mickey Conlon, stars of an HGTV real estate show, are signing the papers on a life of wedded bliss.
lead_paragraph: Like so many of the classic Manhattan love stories, this one involves real estate, and a Broadway tune.

headline: Fighting Heroin Addiction With My Mother on My Side
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Families and Family Life', 'Heroin']
abstract: When I was finally ready to stop drugs, my mother didn’t have to “accept” me back. She had never quit being a guiding force in my life.
lead_paragraph: When I was a young teenager, my mother would watch tales of addiction on her nightly TV programs. “Love the addict, hate the addiction,” she would say as she sipped her diet sodas. Little did she know that I would become just like the characters in the stories that played out on her screen.

headline: Learning to Play by Ear in Iran
keywords: ['Music', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Musical Instruments', 'Biological and Chemical Warfare']
abstract: A wounded veteran finds solace in music.
lead_paragraph: Years ago, during the Iran-Iraq war, Iraqi warplanes dropped mustard gas and nerve agents on my battalion. I was completely burned, with blisters all over my body. I couldn’t see anything for months (and since then I’ve had over 50 operations on my eyes). My lungs were severely damaged; they functioned at only 45 percent. I also had a lot of emotional problems. I was angry all the time. I just wanted to be alone. It was hard because, even after I was married, I didn’t know how to control this deep helplessness, fear and anger. I was taking a lot of medicine too — for all my injuries and for my anger.

headline: Bernie Sanders May Hear the Word ‘Socialist’ More, From Democrats

headline: The Awkward Charm of the Promposal
abstract: The act of getting a prom date — and subsequently going viral — has become a bigger deal than prom itself.
lead_paragraph: In “Daniels PromPosal,” a video posted to YouTube last April, an emotional scene unspools in the front seat of a minivan. The dashboard camera clicks on to find Daniel, a goateed teen, sitting solo in the driver’s seat. He is parked in a driveway bisecting a big green lawn with a white picket fence. We could be in any number of American towns. Blocks away, Daniel has set up an elaborate series of signs on the side of the road, each one spaced a few yards after the last. They say: Alex – Will – You – Marry — LOL J/K — Go to – Prom — With me. A ninth sign, a lone question mark, is tucked into the back seat of the van, awaiting a final reveal. Daniel waves out the window, musses his hair, hugs his arms to his chest and exhales. Alex, a moon-faced girl in a graphic T-shirt, gets in.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Jim Harrison, who died at 78 last month, has hit the print edition of the Times best-seller list for the first time.
lead_paragraph: In Memoriam: I don’t recommend it, but sometimes death is a good career move. Consider Jim Harrison, who was 78 when he died of a heart attack last month, with a poem unfinished on his desk and a pen in his hand. Extravagantly talented, critically adored, more famous than most literary novelists thanks partly to the movie version of his “Legends of the Fall,” Harrison in his lifetime never once hit the print edition of the Times best-seller list. (The closest he came was three years ago, when his novella collection “The River Swimmer” landed at No. 32 on the extended list.) But his death brought new attention to his raucous, earthy writing, and now Harrison’s latest book — another novella collection, “The Ancient Minstrel,” which David Gates reviewed on the cover of our March 13 issue — debuts at No. 14 on the hardcover fiction list.

headline: Yeast Infection Led to Removal of Transplanted Uterus
abstract: The infection inhibited blood supply to the transplanted uterus, the first in the United States, causing the need for its removal from a Texas woman.

headline: Even Trump’s Hollywood Walk of Fame Star Divides the Public
abstract: Mr. Trump’s Hollywood star, in a prime location on Hollywood Boulevard, draws fans and opponents and is often vandalized.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Over in Hollywood, the Donald Trump Walk of Fame straw poll was running 50-50 around noon on Thursday. One young man in a University of California, Santa Barbara, jacket took a selfie with his middle finger hanging over Mr. Trump’s star — an apparently popular pose — while a little girl, on her mother’s advice, scuffed it with her shoes. But a group of seven young tourists had themselves photographed in a smiling cluster around Hollywood’s minimonument to Trump, so things looked about even.

headline: ‘The Wild Robot,’ by Peter Brown
abstract: An illustrated novel about a robot among wild animals gives a fanciful view of interdependence and survival.
lead_paragraph: THE WILD ROBOTBy Peter Brown279 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $16.99. (Middle grade; ages 8 to 12)

headline: Simmered Beef with Horseradish
abstract: Make your own horseradish for this festive beef tenderloin.
lead_paragraph: Make your own horseradish for this festive beef tenderloin.

headline: The Cheating Politicians of Iceland
abstract: First Ashley Madison accounts, now offshore accounts?
lead_paragraph: SELTJARNARNES, Iceland — ICELAND, population around 330,000, is the most peaceful country in the world. This is a country where violent crime is rare and blackmailers give receipts. We are not used to seeing ourselves grouped with the most corrupt governments in the world. Yet here we are, in the foreground of every article about the Panama Papers.

headline: Fathered by the Mailman? It’s Mostly an Urban Legend
abstract: A number of recent genetic studies challenge the notion that mistaken paternity is commonplace, finding a rate of less than 1 percent.
lead_paragraph: Five days a week, you can tune into “Paternity Court,” a television show featuring couples embroiled in disputes over fatherhood. It’s entertainment with a very old theme: Uncertainty over paternity goes back a long way in literature. Even Shakespeare and Chaucer cracked wise about cuckolds, who were often depicted wearing horns.

headline: Bank of England Official to Head Prudential Regulation Authority
abstract: Sam Woods, the central bank’s executive director of insurance, will succeed Andrew Bailey as chief executive of the authority.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Bank of England said on Friday that its top insurance regulator had been named the next chief executive of the Prudential Regulation Authority, a financial regulator within the central bank.

headline: Fates Diverging, Afghan and Syrian Migrants Clash in Greece
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Deportation', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: A brawl at a detention center and a backlash against migrants reflect growing tension in a country where thousands are trapped while new E.U. rules try to stem migration.
lead_paragraph: CHIOS, Greece — Hani Alkhalaf had just fallen asleep at an overcrowded detention camp for migrants on this Greek island when angry shouts jolted him awake. As he rose from the dingy floor, a barrage of stones rained down on the flimsy plastic container where he and 14 other asylum seekers, mostly Syrians like him, were sheltered.

headline: “ ‘Most Blessed of the Patriarchs,’ ” by Annette Gordon-Reed and Peter S. Onuf
abstract: A fresh and layered analysis of Thomas Jefferson centers more on his interior life than his deeds for posterity.
lead_paragraph: “MOST BLESSED OF THE PATRIARCHS” Thomas Jefferson and the Empire of the ImaginationBy Annette Gordon-Reed and Peter S. OnufIllustrated. 370 pp. Liveright Publishing. $27.95.

headline: For Juicy Beef for Your Seder Table, Look Beyond Brisket
abstract: This Passover, try pairing beef fillet with beets, horseradish and aioli.
lead_paragraph: The problem with boiled beef has nothing to do with the dish itself, and everything to do with the translation.

headline: U.S. Presses Bid to Force Apple to Unlock iPhone in New York
abstract: In a letter to a federal judge, the Justice Department said it still required help despite its success in gaining iPhone data in a separate case.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the legal battle over one iPhone now behind them, lawyers for the Justice Department and Apple resumed their sparring in another case on Friday, as prosecutors told a federal judge in Brooklyn that they still needed the company’s help to unlock a drug dealer’s iPhone.

headline: A Napa Valley Resort Gets a Makeover but Keeps It Mellow
abstract: Indian Springs, a popular spa resort in Calistoga, expands in capacity but preserves its historic character.
lead_paragraph: Doubles from $229.

headline: Oh, So Now I’m Bangladeshi?
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Man Booker Prize']
abstract: Britain is my home. But some of my compatriots have trouble with that.
lead_paragraph: TWENTY years ago, when New Yorkers asked me where I was from, all I’d say is that I grew up in Britain. Mentioning that I was born in Bangladesh drew only more questions, and New Yorkers simply wanted confirmation of what was to them the distinctive cultural marker: my British accent.

headline: The N.F.L. Has Seen the Future, and It Is WWE Wrestling
abstract: With its recently announced Twitter deal, the N.F.L. seems to be following the lead of the WWE’s streaming app.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, WWE, the publicly traded company that operates professional wrestling, put on WrestleMania 32, which is essentially its Super Bowl. (Actually, WWE never uses the phrase “professional wrestling,” preferring “sports entertainment.”)

keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Innovation']

headline: Jets’ D’Brickashaw Ferguson Says He Is Retiring
abstract: The Jets had asked Ferguson, who in 10 seasons never missed a snap because of injury, to take a pay cut.
lead_paragraph: Across 10 seasons with the Jets, left tackle D’Brickashaw Ferguson never missed a snap because of injury. He never missed a practice, or even landed on the team’s injury report.

headline: Why Talented Black and Hispanic Students Can Go Undiscovered
keywords: ['Gifted Students', 'Education (K-12)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Children and Childhood', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Relying on teachers and parents to identify candidates for gifted programs appears to discriminate against minority and poor children.
lead_paragraph: Public schools are increasingly filled with black and Hispanic students, but the children identified as “gifted” in those schools are overwhelmingly white and Asian.

lead_paragraph: New picture books by Sergio Ruzzier, Kwame Alexander, Emily MacKenzie and others.

keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: The visit comes as Iraqi forces have been making notable progress on the battlefield, but the prime minister still faces a political crisis.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Secretary of State John Kerry made an unannounced visit to Baghdad on Friday, promising continuing American military and humanitarian aid in the fight against the Islamic State, and showing support for the country’s embattled prime minister, Haider al-Abadi.

headline: Virgins, Booze and American Elections
abstract: In the 19th century, young people flocked to the democratic process. Here’s how to get them back.
lead_paragraph: “Young people just don’t vote.” This has been America’s shrugging cliché for a century. Though Bernie Sanders has engaged millions, like Barack Obama before him, conventional wisdom holds that young voters are inherently unreliable.

headline: A Tiny Bronx Bakery Churns Out Carrot Cakes That Travel the World
abstract: Lloyd’s Carrot Cake began with a family recipe created in the Virgin Islands and has grown into a business baking about 1,000 cakes every week.
lead_paragraph: Betty Campbell-Adams has never made it to China, Nigeria or the Philippines — but her carrot cakes have.

headline: Uma Thurman’s Gramercy Park Apartment for Sale

lead_paragraph: The actress Uma Thurman is putting up for sale her duplex at 1 Lexington Avenue, the limestone and brick prewar co-op across from Gramercy Park where she lived for several years and that she affectionately calls “a very special building with special residents.”
