headline: Small, Piecemeal Mergers in Health Care Fly Under Regulators’ Radars
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Medicine and Health', 'Hospitals', 'Doctors', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: As “creeping consolidation” deals add up — a hospital here, a doctors’ office there — they raise questions on where antitrust officials should focus their attention.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials are expected to argue in court starting Monday that a large hospital merger in the Chicago area could hurt consumers and should be stopped. It would be the latest in a series of efforts by regulators to push back against a wave of consolidation among major health care providers.

headline: Manny Pacquiao, 37, Refuses to Retire, or Even Take it Easy
abstract: For his first fight since losing to Floyd Mayweather last May, Pacquiao has picked a tough opponent. He should know; they have fought twice before.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The last time Manny Pacquiao was preparing to fight, it was impossible to escape the hype.

headline: Deborah Zemke’s ‘My Life in Pictures,’ and More
abstract: In three new chapter-book series, a friend leaves the country, a cave girl seeks a loyal pet and young mice join the Scouts.
lead_paragraph: Could Edward Stratemeyer have possibly realized what he set in motion back in the early 20th century when he invented the modern machine-tooled juvenile book series with the Rover Boys, the Bobbsey Twins and Tom Swift? Today, the children’s shelves in bookstores, libraries and bedrooms are groaning with volumes that can seem to find more inspiration in the ordinal allure of wearing big, bright numbers on their spines than in the old exigencies of character, plot, perspective and suchlike. This is true for every category of children’s books, and especially so in the case of “chapter books,” written for early-grade students who have gotten the hang of picture books and are ready to move on to higher word counts and grayer pages.

headline: Surveillance Footage of Austin Murder Suspect
abstract: The police department in Austin, Tex., released video of a suspect in the murder of Haruka Weiser, a freshman at the University of Texas.
lead_paragraph: The police department in Austin, Tex., released video of a suspect in the murder of Haruka Weiser, a freshman at the University of Texas.

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Seven new paperbacks to check out this week.
lead_paragraph: WHEN THE FACTS CHANGE: Essays, 1995-2010, by Tony Judt. Edited by Jennifer Homans. (Penguin, $18.) As a marquee contributor to The New York Review of Books and other publications during the 1990s and early 2000s, Judt, a British essayist and critic, redefined the boundaries of the public intellectual. In this collection, Homans, his widow, has assembled essays that run the gamut of his interests: war, the Mideast crisis and, as he saw it, “the self-defeating decline of the American Republic.”

headline: The Dutch Message to the E.U.
abstract: A national referendum on the Ukraine trade agreement revealed one more crack in European solidarity.
lead_paragraph: It takes a bit of effort to take seriously Wednesday’s Dutch referendum, in which voters rejected the European Union’s trade and cooperation agreement with Ukraine. The turnout barely nudged past the 30 percent needed for the referendum to be legally valid; the vote was nonbinding; and the pact remains in force (it would take a unanimous vote by the 28 E.U. governments to suspend it).

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Nine new books recommended by the editors of The New York Times Book Review this week.
lead_paragraph: SPAIN IN OUR HEARTS: Americans in the Spanish Civil War, 1936-1939, by Adam Hochschild. (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $30.) A gifted historian tells a familiar tale of American fighters and writers in an unfamiliar and convincing way.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Life of Louisa Adams
abstract: This week, Louisa Thomas talks about “Louisa”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Hope Jahren discusses “Lab Girl”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Louisa Thomas talks about “Louisa”; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Hope Jahren discusses “Lab Girl”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Final ‘American Idol’ Draws 13.3 Million Viewers
abstract: “Idol” was the highest rated show on Thursday night in total viewers and in the 18-to-49 year old age bracket that is important to advertisers.
lead_paragraph: The final installment of “American Idol” closed with 13.3 million viewers, the highest viewership for the show in two years, according to Nielsen.

headline: An Herby Persian Frittata From Michael Pollan’s Chef Teacher
abstract: Samin Nosrat, currently on the road with Pop-Up Magazine, shares a recipe for kuku sabzi.
lead_paragraph: In the culinary industry, the teacher and writer Samin Nosrat is a go-to resource for matching the correct techniques with the best ingredients. The San Diego-born Iranian-American is at her best in the new Netflix documentary series “Cooked,” teaching Michael Pollan how to braise a pork shoulder. Pollan may be recognized for addressing the omnivore’s dilemma, but he turned to Nosrat to actually learn to cook — efficiently, properly and well. “The formula is liquid, meat and vegetables — it’s what really makes it delicious,” she tells him, in the second episode, before opening the oven door so her student can slide his covered clay pot into the oven. “It’s all about giving it the gentle heat it needs … the more tender and luscious, and melt-in-your-mouth rich, velvety yumminess. Yeah.” As she describes the tantalizing outcome, she breaks out into a hearty laugh, because she knows she’s just gotten that excited about a simple piece of pork.

headline: Sheriff’s Statement on Texas Shooting
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Military Bases and Installations']

lead_paragraph: A spokesman for the Bexar County Sheriff’s Department said a shooting at Lackland Air Force Base that left two people dead “does appear to be a murder-suicide.”

abstract: Russia’s sports minister said officials were unsure if the teams would test positive for meldonium they had taken before a ban on the drug.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s sports minister, Vitaly Mutko, confirmed Friday that the country was keeping entire teams from competitions over fears that they would test positive for meldonium, the newly banned drug that has been causing chaos in the Russian sports world.

headline: Three Wins From History, Warriors Are Reluctant to Slow Down
abstract: Golden State beat the Spurs Thursday night and now need three more wins to break the Bulls’ wins record.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — No one associated with the Golden State Warriors has been more vocal in recent weeks about the team’s all-out pursuit of 73 wins than Draymond Green.

headline: The Voter Support Agency Accused of Suppressing Votes
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Identification Devices']
abstract: The federal Election Assistance Commission was supposed to make casting ballots easier. Critics say it is trying to drive some would-be voters away.
lead_paragraph: The federal Election Assistance Commission was formed after the disputed 2000 election between George W. Bush and Al Gore and given an innocuous name and a seemingly inoffensive mission: to help state election officials make it easier to vote.

abstract: The French and Italian companies announced a share-swap deal that will give each a 3.5 percent stake in the other.
lead_paragraph: Europe’s media industry is going through another shake-up.

keywords: ['Whistle-Blowers', 'Airport Security', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Many cases have involved senior managers’ taking retribution against lower-ranking employees who had accused their bosses of misconduct.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Dozens of Transportation Security Administration employees in recent years have been reassigned, demoted, investigated or fired for reporting lapses or misconduct by senior managers, charges that were later upheld by whistle-blower protection agencies, records show.

headline: A West Village Duplex for $34.4 Million
abstract: A penthouse at 150 Charles Street with panoramic views that include the Statue of Liberty was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A spacious duplex penthouse at 150 Charles Street, the Witkoff Group’s 91-unit brick-and-glass condominium in the West Village that sold out just weeks after sales began three years ago, officially closed for $34,433,707.06, according to city records, and was the most expensive transaction of the week.

headline: Indiana State Trooper Is Fired for Proselytizing During Traffic Stops
keywords: ['Police', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The trooper, a 14-year veteran, had asked drivers about church and whether they had been “saved.”
lead_paragraph: An Indiana state trooper has been fired after drivers complained that he gave them more than tickets and a lecture about road rules after pulling them over — he also shared a little religion on the roadside, in one case asking a woman if she had “accepted Jesus Christ as her savior.”

headline: Alone on the Range, Seniors Often Lack Access to Health Care
abstract: Country life poses tough challenges for residents determined to “age in place.”
lead_paragraph: What’s it like to grow old in rural America?

headline: More Suspects in Brussels Attacks Arrested in Belgium
abstract: The police in Belgium have detained several men connected to the bombings, the prosecutors’ office said, and one is a fugitive connected to the Paris attacks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Belgian authorities said Friday evening that one of the five people arrested earlier in the day in connection with the March 22 attacks in Brussels was a fugitive who is suspected of playing a significant role in the Nov. 13 attacks in Paris.

headline: Continued Growth at the Bologna Children’s Book Fair
abstract: The fair holds a unique place in the world of books as a hybrid marketplace, conference, art show and prestigious prize-giving operation.
lead_paragraph: BOLOGNA, Italy — The Bologna Children’s Book Fair, the largest and certainly the most important international trade show and book fair dedicated to children’s books, wrapped up Thursday after four packed days of sales meetings, award ceremonies, art exhibitions, panel discussions and parties. Visitors thronged the long, light-filled halls of the city’s modern conference center, with the fair’s organizers reporting a 9 percent increase in attendance from last year, including 1,278 exhibitors from 74 nations, along with 856 journalists from 40 countries. In its 54th year, the fair holds a unique place in the world of books as a hybrid marketplace, conference, art show and prestigious prize-giving operation.

headline: In Science, It’s Never ‘Just a Theory’
abstract: When everyone has a theory, actual scientific theories like evolution take a hit.
lead_paragraph: We asked readers to share the misconception that frustrates them the most on The New York Times — Science Facebook page. People had an array of answers, a number of which we addressed earlier this week. Judging from all the likes it quickly accumulated — far more than any other submission — this was the standout in terms of mass frustration.

headline: In Time for Salone del Mobile, a Fashion and Art Explosion
abstract: The Milan-based fashion and design journalist JJ Martin debuts a pop-up installation featuring design objects, art and vintage pieces.
lead_paragraph: A little over a year ago, the Milan-based fashion and design journalist JJ Martin launched LaDoubleJ.com — an explosively colorful online shopping site that positions vintage clothes (Chanel, Saint Laurent, Missoni and loads more) alongside modern pieces. Martin’s goal was to breathe new life to old designs — and, as many items are shot on glamorous Italian women in their homes in Milan — to celebrate the creative people of her city in the process.

headline: Trained to Face Trauma
abstract: Lindsay Morris’s photographs capture what life is like for members of the volunteer ambulance corps in Sag Harbor, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Lindsay Morris’s photographs capture what life is like for members of the volunteer ambulance corps in Sag Harbor, N.Y.

headline: Trained to Face Trauma
abstract: Lindsay Morris, a photographer, got the idea for a project when some familiar faces rushed into her Long Island home as members of a volunteer ambulance corps.
lead_paragraph: Lindsay Morris, a freelance photographer, said she first got the idea for her latest project after a group of people rushed into her living room last year, twice. She recognized these people: mothers from her children’s school; faces she saw at the post office and other local places. On those two occasions, they were rushing to Ms. Morris’s house as members of the Sag Harbor Volunteer Ambulance Corps, to administer emergency care to members of her family.

headline: For Graduates, One Word: Plastics
keywords: ['Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Plastic Bottles', 'Textiles', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Plastics', 'Commencement Speeches']
abstract: Robes made from recycled plastic bottles are the latest trend in green commencement.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a rationale for drinking from plastic bottles: Consume six, and you can turn them into a nice new shirt; 50 will get you a spiffy fleece jacket; 42 the cloth seats in a Ford Fusion hybrid. And 10.5 million will outfit 400,000 graduating students in caps and gowns with seriously green overtones.

headline: The New SAT: A Survey
keywords: ['SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Education (K-12)', 'Tests and Examinations', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: A reading from students on the first administration of the test.
lead_paragraph: Students who are about to take the second administration of the new SAT, take note: Here’s what students who took it the first time thought, according to a Kaplan Test Prep poll of more than 520 test-takers (about 300 of them in Kaplan prep).

headline: Latex Expressions
abstract: Artistry in body paint at Brandeis.
lead_paragraph: A signature tradition at Brandeis University, “Liquid Latex” attracts a capacity crowd and showcases the artistry of hundreds of students.

headline: Textbook Highs/Lows
abstract: Books may cost more, but student spending is down.
lead_paragraph: When Kanye West tweeted about a friend’s financial burden buying books, he rekindled an age-old complaint: Textbooks cost too much. His message — “We have to lower the price of textbooks” — was retweeted more than 71,000 times, earning nearly 100,000 likes.

headline: A Brighter Job Market, for Some
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: Career specialists and economists are upbeat about prospects for this year’s graduates. But not all job seekers have reason to be optimistic.
lead_paragraph: New college graduates looking for their first full-time job have reason to be optimistic. After a string of dismal to lackluster years, the job outlook brightened considerably for the class of 2015. And despite uncertainty about the strength of the economy, recruiters, on-campus career specialists and economists remain generally upbeat about prospects for this year’s graduates.

headline: Job Hunting in the Digital Age
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Robots may be scanning your résumé for keywords, but that doesn’t mean you have to think like one.
lead_paragraph: Like many recent college graduates, Ben Kim felt he was casting his résumé into an abyss when he clicked “apply online” for the hundredth or so time. “The most common response was nothing,” he said.

headline: Waldan, a Storied American Watch Brand, Ticks Again
abstract: Founded by a Holocaust survivor, the boutique luxury company returns with the founder’s 23-year-old son at the helm.
lead_paragraph: Nobody knows when Oscar Waldan’s 100th birthday will take place. In fact, it may have passed. Such uncertainty about time is ironic for a man whom some regard as an unsung master American watchmaker of the 20th century.

headline: Study Abroad’s Seven Deadly Sins
abstract: How to live in a foreign country and learn very little.
lead_paragraph: We’ve all heard about the purported benefits of study-abroad programs, the most fundamental of which is the opportunity for personal growth. Proponents are often vague about precisely what they mean in this regard, but growth is generally said to be signified by a broadening of perspective, greater adaptability and confidence, and enhanced empathy. Along with having the opportunity to develop international networks and improve language skills, study-abroad students are set on the path to becoming “global citizens.” The full (international) monty!

headline: Angela Duckworth on Passion, Grit and Success
keywords: ['Parenting', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The MacArthur “genius” answers questions on the power of resilience.
lead_paragraph: Angela Duckworth was teaching math when she noticed something intriguing: The most successful students weren’t always the ones who displayed a natural aptitude; rather, they displayed something she came to think of as grit. Later, as a graduate student in psychology at the University of Pennsylvania, she defined the term — a combination of passion and perseverance for a singularly important goal — and created a tool to measure it: the “grit scale,” which predicted outcomes like who would graduate from West Point or win the National Spelling Bee. As a result of this work, Dr. Duckworth was named a MacArthur “genius” in 2013, and the notion of grit has become widely known. Her new book, “Grit: The Power of Passion and Perseverance,” will be available in May.

headline: Airbnb Becomes Dormbnb
abstract: Colleges are fine tuning their housing contracts to explicitly mention Airbnb. Here’s why.
lead_paragraph: When Benjamin Capitano moved into his dorm as a sophomore at the King’s College, a tiny liberal arts college in Manhattan, he realized he’d been given a gift: a couch. So he listed his bed on Airbnb for $99.

headline: Power Napping on Campus
abstract: How to catch some zzz’s.
lead_paragraph: WITH final exams approaching, sleep-deprived students are dozing off in library cubicles across the land. But some campuses are acknowledging the problem, investing in nap nooks and pods — those futuristic chaises that became insta-trendy when Google installed them at its Mountain View, Calif., headquarters back in the aughts.

headline: Once a Bright Spot, Afghan Telecoms Face Unsustainable Losses
keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Taxation', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Cellphone providers challenged by the loss of potential customers and hurt by new taxes are trying to expand services and bring more Afghans online.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Men thread their way through this city’s traffic jams, hawking streamers of phone cards. Others stand behind crude wooden tables selling cheap Chinese-made mobile phones. Throngs of people navigate the sidewalks and streets with cellphones pressed to their ears.

headline: A Glimpse at Sanders’s Brooklyn Base
abstract: A New York Times reporter, Yamiche Alcindor, captured a glimpse of the scene in Bernie Sanders’s headquarters in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A New York Times reporter, Yamiche Alcindor, captured a glimpse of the scene in Bernie Sanders’s headquarters in Brooklyn.

headline: Living With Very Hungry Caterpillars
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Puppets', 'Theater']
abstract: Jonathan Rockefeller, the creator of a show based on Eric Carle’s beloved children’s book, has a very grown-up home.
lead_paragraph: There are caterpillars crawling around the apartment of Jonathan Rockefeller. They’re hungry, but they don’t eat any houseplants or chew through the Hermès blankets. Rather, they are the caterpillars hatched by Eric Carle, the author and illustrator of the classic children’s book “The Very Hungry Caterpillar.” And then there are the plush caterpillar toys from “The Very Hungry Caterpillar Show,” a puppet extravaganza produced and directed by Mr. Rockefeller and now playing at the 47th Street Theater in Midtown.

headline: What I Love | Jonathan Rockefeller
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Puppets', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Theater']
abstract: Jonathan Rockefeller, the creator of “The Very Hungry Caterpillar Show,” lives in Manhattan
lead_paragraph: Jonathan Rockefeller, the creator of “The Very Hungry Caterpillar Show,” lives in Manhattan

headline: How Not to Explain Success
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Research', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Intelligence and Intelligence Tests (IQ)', 'Sociology', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The controversial ‘Triple Package’ theory of why some people thrive is finally rigorously debunked.
lead_paragraph: DO you remember the controversy two years ago, when the Yale law professors Amy Chua (author of “Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother”) and Jed Rubenfeld published “The Triple Package: How Three Unlikely Traits Explain the Rise and Fall of Cultural Groups in America”?

headline: A Glimpse at Clinton’s Brooklyn Base
abstract: A New York Times reporter, Yamiche Alcindor, captured a slice of life from Hillary Clinton’s headquarters in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A New York Times reporter, Yamiche Alcindor, captured a slice of life from Hillary Clinton’s headquarters in Brooklyn.

headline: The Daughters of Nigella
abstract: Focusing on healthful eating habits, a new crop of glamorous bloggers and cookbook writers has infiltrated the London food scene. Next stop: America.
lead_paragraph: “I’m buying up loads of ginger shots,” said Ella Woodward, the British food blogger turned author, on a recent dreary afternoon in New York. She was there to promote the publication of her second book, “Deliciously Ella Everyday,” in the United States, and she had caught a cold on the flight across the Atlantic. Her hotel was close to a juice store, though normally she prefers putting ginger through her own juicer and adding a squeeze of lemon.

headline: Bruce Springsteen Cancels North Carolina Concert Over Bias Law
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Saying “some things are more important than a rock show,” Mr. Springsteen sharply criticized the law, on gay and transgender rights, and the politicians who supported it.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Springsteen has canceled a concert in North Carolina this weekend in protest of the state’s new law on gay and transgender rights, becoming perhaps the most prominent cultural figure to speak out against it.

headline: Eight Highlights From Salone del Mobile
abstract: Projects to watch at the annual design fair.
lead_paragraph: Projects to watch at the annual design fair.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Virginia Inmate Freed After DNA Tests Refute Bite-Mark Evidence
keywords: ['Forensic Science', 'Teeth and Dentistry', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']
abstract: Experts said Keith Allen Harward’s release after 33 years in prison for a murder and rape he did not commit showed that bite-mark analysis was unreliable.
lead_paragraph: A man who spent 33 years in Virginia prisons for a 1982 murder and rape conviction based largely on bite-mark identification was released on Friday after DNA tests showed conclusively that he was innocent.

headline: Bill Clinton Says He Regrets Showdown With Black Lives Matter Protesters
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The former president says he wishes he had not drowned out the demonstrators, who he said were “just trying to get good television.”
lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton said Friday that he regretted drowning out the chants of black protesters at a rally in Philadelphia the day before, when he issued an aggressive defense of his administration’s impact on black families. His reaction thrust a debate about the 1990s into the center of his wife’s presidential campaign, one that has focused heavily on issues of race and criminal justice.

headline: Review: Paulo Szot, Rekindling the Flames of the Traditional Broadway Romance
abstract: Mr. Szot has brought his baritone to Feinstein’s/54 Below, where his performance of classic tunes evokes the virility of the old-fashioned leading man.
lead_paragraph: Who could resist That Voice singing Those Songs? Not I. That voice, a mighty baritone that insists on its romantic authority, belongs to Paulo Szot, the Brazilian opera star who made his Broadway debut eight years ago, playing Emile De Becque in a revival of “South Pacific” opposite Kelli O’Hara.

headline: Mets Win Home Opener Against the Phillies
abstract: Michael Conforto and Neil Walker combined to drive in five runs, and Jacob deGrom, on baby watch, struck out six batters and only allowed one run in six innings.
lead_paragraph: Jacob deGrom was dominating the Philadelphia Phillies in the Mets’ home opener on Friday when he yanked a few fastballs in the sixth inning and felt a muscle in his back tighten up. DeGrom allowed the first run of the day, finished the inning and retreated to the dugout, debating whether he should alert someone.

headline: Bronx Woman Convicted of Poisoning and Drowning Her Children
abstract: Lisette Bamenga researched methods on the Internet before she killed her son and daughter in 2012.
lead_paragraph: A Bronx woman who researched methods to kill her children on the Internet, tried to poison them and ultimately drowned her infant daughter and 4-year-old son in a bathtub was found guilty of manslaughter on Friday.

headline: Journalist, 9, Responds to Her Critics and Becomes a Media Star
abstract: Hilde Kate Lysiak’s reporting on a homicide in her town for her news website set off a wave of criticism that she responded to in a video that got widespread attention.
lead_paragraph: A 9-year-old journalist from Selinsgrove, Pa., became a media sensation this week, with articles in The Washington Post and The Guardian and an appearance on “Good Morning America,” with more to come.

headline: Review: ‘Broadway Premieres’ at Symphony Space
abstract: There were some very appealing numbers in this concert, which opened a 14-event program, Project-B-way/95.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible for a musical-theater lover to identify a future pop standard after one listening? Today, not so much. The so-called 11-o’clock-number that brings audiences to cheers still exists, especially in the scores of veteran Broadway composers. But the rules have relaxed, as the typical theater song has become wordier and expanded far beyond the traditional 32-bar form.

headline: After 24 Runs in 2 Games, Yankees Are Shutout by Good Pitching
abstract: The Detroit Tigers’ Jordan Zimmermann showed the Yankees what solid pitching could do, though the Yanks were down several of their best batters.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — If Hal Steinbrenner’s Yankees, the only team in baseball that did not sign a free agent over the winter, had been like his father’s Yankees, there might not have been such a calculated decision to refrain from adding to what is baseball’s second-highest payroll.

headline: What We’re Reading
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Surfing', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jodi Kantor, Jim Dwyer and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Italy Recalls Envoy to Egypt Over Inquiry Into Student’s Death
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: Italy said it was withdrawing its ambassador to protest what it called Cairo’s lack of cooperation in the inquiry into the death of an Italian graduate student.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Tensions between Italy and Egypt over the torture and death of an Italian graduate student in Cairo this year touched a new high on Friday, when Italy announced that it was withdrawing its ambassador to Egypt for urgent consultations to protest what it called a lack of cooperation in the joint investigation between the two nations.

headline: At Windy Masters, Jordan Spieth Stumbles, and Rory McIlroy Charges In
abstract: McIlroy shot a 71 to move into contention for the only major championship he is missing. He is one shot behind Spieth heading into the third round.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Reduce this year’s Masters to Jordan Spieth versus Rory McIlroy at your peril.

headline: Review: ‘Thunder,’ Through Body and Voice, at Brooklyn Studios for Dance
abstract: In Tatyana Tenenbaum’s program, six performers use body and sound.
lead_paragraph: Thunder isn’t always violent. It can erupt in hushed rumbles that build ominously, crash in the distance and then slowly dissipate. Those are the kinds of explosions that the choreographer Tatyana Tenenbaum creates using the body and the voice in “Thunder,” in which six performers embody what she calls the “simple theater of the singing body.” How does a sweeping arm reverberate through space? What does a two-footed turn sound like in tandem with Ms. Tenenbaum’s singing as she swirls across the floor?

headline: Review: Miró Quartet Looks to the Overlooked Ginastera
abstract: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented a program of quartets by the Argentine composer Alberto Ginastera.
lead_paragraph: Rose Studio

headline: Think Like a Doctor: Packing on the Pounds Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 59-year-old woman with unexplained weight gain.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday we challenged Well readers to take on the case of a 59-year-old woman who had not been able to stop gaining weight. I presented the case as it was presented to the doctor who made the diagnosis and asked for the final piece of data provided by the patient as well as the correct cause of her symptoms.

headline: Review: Hannah Lash and Her ‘Life Partner’ at Miller Theater
abstract: This harpist and composer presented her “Filigree in Textile” and other works.
lead_paragraph: Miller Theater

headline: Review: Orchestra of St. Luke’s, With Susan Graham
abstract: The program at Carnegie Hall included works by Henry Purcell, among them “Dido’s Lament.”
lead_paragraph: Carnegie Hall

headline: Review: Manfred Honeck Leads the New York Philharmonic
abstract: Mr. Honeck, conductor of the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra, visited the New York ensemble to offer works by Richard Strauss and Beethoven.
lead_paragraph: Repeats on Saturday and Tuesday

headline: Terence Winter Out as ‘Vinyl’ Showrunner
abstract: The heavily promoted HBO show, about the music industry in the 1970s, has struggled to find an audience.
lead_paragraph: As “Vinyl” wraps up its first season on HBO, this costly period drama about the music industry has already hit some worrisome bumps: on Friday it was announced that Terence Winter, the show runner and a co-creator of the series, was leaving and would be replaced by new producers. In a statement HBO said it had decided it was “an appropriate time to make a change in the creative direction of the show.”

headline: Musings From the Dalai Lama: Mosquitoes Are Ungrateful, for Starters
abstract: The Dalai Lama spoke to students at the American Embassy School in New Delhi, and a New York Times bureau chief shared a bit of what he said.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — On Friday, the students of the American Embassy School in New Delhi filed into the school’s auditorium to greet an unusual visitor: The 14th Dalai Lama, who will celebrate his 81st birthday this summer. They arranged themselves on the floor and gazed up at the Buddhist leader, who spoke for an hour and 40 minutes without notes.

headline: Bravo, Bruce: Springsteen’s Stand Against North Carolina Law
abstract: After North Carolina passed a law perpetuating discrimination against LGBT Americans, Mr. Springsteen canceled his upcoming concert in Greensboro.
lead_paragraph: When the forces of intolerance and bigotry prevail, as they have lately in Southern states that passed laws institutionalizing discrimination against gay and transgender Americans, it can be tempting to think they are impervious to argument. There is, however, one thing that lawmakers like those in North Carolina do heed – money.

headline: Review: ‘Jackie Robinson,’ on PBS, Covers More Than Race and Baseball
abstract: This latest documentary project from Ken Burns recounts the life of a pioneer and offers fresh dimension to a familiar story.
lead_paragraph: The core portion of Jackie Robinson’s story is so familiar that Part 1 of the new Ken Burns treatment of it may not seem like vital viewing. But Part 2 examines Robinson’s later, less celebrated years, completing a portrait of an eventful life that, in the popular mind, is often confined to the ball field.

headline: Suffering for Art in Greece and Matching the National Mood
abstract: Greek artists chipping rocks and curling up in boxes for hours at a stretch have found fans in Athens.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — One artist counts out loud in Greek for eight hours a day, transforming herself into a human metronome. Another subjects himself to intense low-frequency sounds and documents the effects on his mind and body. A third takes an ax to chip away at a large boulder, then flings plaster on top to build it up again in a loop of destruction and creation.

headline: Andrew Dice Clay Returns, With at Least Two Personalities Showing
abstract: On the eve of the premiere of Showtime’s “Dice,” Mr. Clay reflects on playing a character in his stand-up comedy career and what audiences thought.
lead_paragraph: With the exception of Bill Cosby, no comic has fallen further than Andrew Dice Clay. Less than two decades after selling out Madison Square Garden, he was performing in the back room of a sushi restaurant in Las Vegas. To critics, he was a joke, shorthand for hateful stand-up peddling sexism and homophobia. “He will always be vilified,” Chuck Klosterman wrote in his 2013 book, “I Wear the Black Hat,” arguing against the possibility of career rehabilitation, “and dying won’t help.”

headline: Brooklyn Museum Puts Artwork From Its Critics on Display
abstract: Artists have said that the museum plays a role in gentrification; some of their work is now included in a show of political art.
lead_paragraph: It has not taken much time for Anne Pasternak, the socially progressive new director of the Brooklyn Museum, to register her influence there.

headline: SpaceX Rocket Sticks Landing on the 5th Try
keywords: ['Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'International Space Station', 'Private Spaceflight']
abstract: While a capsule carrying NASA cargo continued into orbit, its rocket turned around and successfully landed on a floating platform off Florida.
lead_paragraph: For SpaceX, the fifth time was the charm in the impressive feat of landing a rocket on a boat.

headline: Review: ‘Doctor Foster: A Woman Scorned,’ an Infidelity Drama From Lifetime
abstract: This British import, using an extended title, stars Suranne Jones as a physician who thinks that her husband is having an affair.
lead_paragraph: “Doctor Foster” was recently nominated for a Bafta award as Britain’s best mini-series of 2015. You could take that as a national lapse in taste, but consider that we nominated “American Horror Story: Freak Show” for an Emmy in that category last year. Apparently, luridly melodramatic limited series constitute a universal language.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Pope Francis, Brussels, Bill Clinton
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: How Tituss Burgess, an Actor on ‘Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt,’ Spends His Sundays
abstract: A Sunday with the Emmy-nominated actor is a day of fun, food and entertainment with his partner, Pablo Salinas, and friends in their Harlem apartment.
lead_paragraph: When Tituss Burgess’s mother, Sandra Morse, tacked a second “s” onto his first name, it was simply a matter of balance: If there are two in Burgess, she figured, there should be two in Tituss, said Mr. Burgess, the Emmy-nominated actor on the Netflix comedy series “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt,” which returns April 15 for its second season. Besides a sense of balance, Ms. Morse gave her son a passion for music, a flair for Southern cooking and a devotion to family. On Sundays, he celebrates all three. Mr. Burgess, 37, a Georgia native, lives in Harlem with his partner, Pablo Salinas, 29, and their dogs, Micah and Hanz.

headline: Culture of Concealment Protects Police Officers
abstract: If the mail carrier arrested in Brooklyn in March had a prior record, we would be told of it, but information on those who inexplicably detained him was shrouded.
lead_paragraph: When Glen Grays was inexplicably handcuffed and hauled off by the police in Brooklyn on March 17 while delivering the mail on his route in Crown Heights, the world soon learned a bit about him. At a news conference given by Eric L. Adams, the Brooklyn borough president, at which a video of the encounter was made public, Mr. Grays’s mother explained that she had six sons and worried about all of them. In the days ahead, Mr. Grays spoke to reporters, telling them that he was, in fact, engaged to a New York City police officer, that he had worked hard all of his life, that he had never been arrested and that despite the indignities he had suffered at the hands of the four plainclothes police officers — who were supposed to be in uniform — he did not wish for them to be fired.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Malick Sidibé: Creative Force of African Culture
abstract: A current solo show of the influential Malian photographer features glimpses of nudes that suggest a concealed, sensual beauty rather than something explicit.
lead_paragraph: A current solo show of the influential Malian photographer features glimpses of nudes that suggest a concealed, sensual beauty rather than something explicit.

headline: Evening Hours | Spring Celebrations
abstract: Celebrating the arts, education and more.
lead_paragraph: Celebrating the arts, education and more.

headline: Miami City Ballet: Feeling That Warmth and Attack
abstract: The troupe’s artistic director, who took over in 2012, is bringing the company to New York for several performances.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI BEACH — Two blocks from the beach, overlooking a small patch of green, the home of Miami City Ballet rises like the prow of an ocean liner, all gleaming white curves. This is where the 51 dancers of this troupe, founded in 1985, spend their days, rehearsing in spacious studios bathed in Florida sunshine. “Ballet companies are different from each other, and I think a lot of it comes from the city you’re in,” Lourdes Lopez, the artistic director of the Miami City Ballet, said recently in her office, on the third floor.

headline: Getting a Student Loan With Collateral From a Future Job
abstract: An alternative financing arrangement will let students pledge some of their future income for monetary assistance now.
lead_paragraph: At Purdue University, some undergraduates will have a new option to help finance their degrees: pledging to pay a percentage of their future incomes in return for funds today.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Duality
abstract: The boldness of black and white showed up on the street, along with a surprise silver that resembled armored medieval suits.
lead_paragraph: The boldness of black and white showed up on the street, along with a surprise silver that resembled armored medieval suits.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Duality
abstract: The boldness of black and white showed up on the street, along with a surprise silver that resembled armored medieval suits.
lead_paragraph: The boldness of black and white showed up on the street, along with a surprise silver that resembled armored medieval suits.

headline: Choices for New York’s Special Elections
abstract: Voters in Nassau should choose Todd Kaminsky for the Senate, and those in Manhattan should choose Yuh-Line Niou for the Assembly.
lead_paragraph: New York voters seldom get the chance to take a real whack at cleaning out their scandal-rotted Legislature. That rare opportunity arrives on April 19, the state’s presidential Primary Day, which also features special elections to replace two once-mighty politicians who were convicted of corruption last year, Dean Skelos and Sheldon Silver. The winners’ terms last only until the end of 2016. For full terms, they and other challengers would have to run in the primary and the general election later this year.

headline: Zika Is Coming
abstract: If I were a pregnant woman living on the Gulf Coast, I would be nervous right now.
lead_paragraph: Houston — IF I were a pregnant woman living on the Gulf Coast or in Florida, in an impoverished neighborhood in a city like Houston, New Orleans, Miami, Biloxi, Miss., or Mobile, Ala., I would be nervous right now. If mosquitoes carrying the Zika virus reach the United States later this spring or summer, these are the major urban areas where the sickness will spread. If we don’t intervene now, we could begin seeing newborns with microcephaly and stunted brain development on the obstetrics wards in one or more of these places.

headline: My North Carolina State of Mind
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Books and Literature', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Law and Legislation', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Discrimination']
abstract: I moved back home in 1993 to fight bigotry. We are both still here.
lead_paragraph: HILLSBOROUGH, N.C. — “YOU can’t go home again”? If only!

headline: Archbishop of Canterbury Says DNA Test Shows His Father Was Churchill’s Private Secretary
abstract: In frank statements, the Most Rev. Justin Welby, the spiritual leader of 86 million Anglicans, and his mother talked of the shock of discovering the truth in the past month.
lead_paragraph: The archbishop of Canterbury, leader of the Church of England, said on Friday that a DNA test had revealed that his biological father was not the whiskey salesman who had married his mother, but the man who had been the last private secretary for Sir Winston Churchill.

headline: Why Apple’s Stand Against the F.B.I. Hurts Its Own Customers
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Computer Security', 'Terrorism', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Privacy advocates applauded the decision not to hack into a terrorist’s phone, but the iPhone is more vulnerable as a result.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, privacy advocates across the country celebrated as the Federal Bureau of Investigation backed off its request for Apple to help gain access into the iPhone of Syed Farook, one of the terrorists who killed 14 people in San Bernardino, Calif., in December.

headline: In Victory for Unions, Law on Dues Is Struck Down in Wisconsin
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The law, signed last year, had barred unions from requiring workers to pay the equivalent of dues. The state promised to appeal.
lead_paragraph: A Wisconsin law barring unions from requiring workers in the private sector to pay the equivalent of union dues was struck down late Friday after a judge deemed it a violation of the state’s Constitution.

headline: SpaceX Rocket Lands Successfully on Ship
abstract: After multiple failed attempts, SpaceX successfully landed a rocket on a drone ship.
lead_paragraph: After multiple failed attempts, SpaceX successfully landed a rocket on a drone ship.

headline: For Some Top Nonprofits, Changing the World Begins in Seattle
abstract: Philanthropic efforts of those who made billions in the tech industry have put the Pacific Northwest at the epicenter of a push to improve global health.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Inside the factory buildings at Cascade Designs, just south of downtown Seattle, camping and hiking gear for the rugged outdoor life of the Pacific Northwest has been manufactured since the early 1970s. But turn a corner and something new is coming off the shop floor: a compact, no-frills water purifier designed to bring clean water to struggling populations in rural Africa.

headline: Toni Grant, Psychotherapist, Dies at 73; Her Couch Was on AM Radio
abstract: Dr. Grant, who described her show as “a soap opera that educates,” was on the air for almost 20 years.
lead_paragraph: Toni Grant, one of the first nationally renowned radio psychologists, whose advice on relations between the sexes was celebrated as refreshingly traditional in some quarters and castigated as appallingly pre-feminist in others, died on March 27 in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 73.

headline: Bernie Sanders Highlights His New York Roots at Brooklyn Rally
abstract: Hundreds of people braved frigid weather in Greenpoint to watch Mr. Sanders deliver a fiery condemnation of Wall Street and urge voters across the state to vote for him in record numbers.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people braved frigid weather in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, on Friday to watch Senator Bernie Sanders deliver a fiery condemnation of Wall Street and urge voters across the state to vote for him in record numbers.

headline: Puerto Rico Rescue Bill Nears Completion in House Committee
abstract: Staff aides worked through a spring recess, hoping to get a bill on the House floor by Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Legislative staff members in Washington were said to be close on Friday to completing a revised bill that would give Puerto Rico extraordinary powers to wipe out debt under close federal supervision.

headline: Ogden Mills Phipps, Horseman From a Leading Racing Family, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Phipps, the longtime chairman of the Jockey Club, was an old-fashioned owner who resisted buying from commercial breeders.
lead_paragraph: Ogden Mills Phipps, the patrician owner and breeder of top thoroughbred horses, including Orb, the winner of the 2013 Kentucky Derby, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 75.

headline: In the New York Primary, Democrats Should Stick to Issues
abstract: Bernie Sanders is running strong on Hillary Clinton’s home turf in New York’s primary. This could get nasty, but it doesn’t have to.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, nobody imagined that Bernie Sanders could give Hillary Clinton a meaningful challenge in her home state. But on April 19, the two will square off in a competitive Democratic primary that will test the ideals of the party’s left against its more centrist impulses.

headline: Bernie Sanders Back in the Old Neighborhood to Make His Case
abstract: Mr. Sanders campaigned in front of the Brooklyn apartment building where he grew up, but some current tenants were unmoved by the association.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders returned on Friday once again to Brooklyn, the borough where he grew up and picked up his distinctive accent, as he squares off against Hillary Clinton in the New York Democratic primary.

headline: Mr. Trump Reopens the Wounds of a Hate Crime
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Discrimination', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Suffolk County Republicans have scheduled a fund-raiser, featuring Donald Trump, near the site of a fatal assault on an immigrant.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is scheduled to speak at a Republican Party fund-raiser on Thursday in Patchogue, a village on the south shore of Long Island, about 60 miles from Manhattan.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: A groundbreaking lawsuit filed on behalf of 21 young people demanding that the federal government take aggressive action against climate change can move forward, a federal judge ruled on Friday. Fossil fuel companies and the federal government had asked the judge to dismiss the suit, asserting that, among other things, the young people did not have standing and were presenting claims that were more suited to the political branch of government than the judicial. Thomas M. Coffin, a United States magistrate judge, wrote that the plaintiffs were pursuing a “novel theory,” but he declined to dismiss the case because “the nascent nature of these proceedings dictate further development of the record before the court can adjudicate whether any claims or parties should not survive for trial.” JOHN SCHWARTZ

headline: Tests Show Lead Persists in Some New York City Schools
abstract: Officials said that 140 buildings so far had shown elevated levels, but that the vast majority of those sites already have safeguards in place.
lead_paragraph: As New York City retests all public school buildings for lead in the water, 140 have had at least one water sample showing elevated levels so far. But city officials said on Friday that the vast majority of those sites were already protected by protocols meant to safeguard students and staff members.

headline: Hillary and Bernie Meet New York
abstract: There’s a glamour candidate and, uh, a former secretary of state.
lead_paragraph: Democratic presidential campaign news: Hillary Clinton just visited the Buffalo Transportation Pierce Arrow Museum. Meanwhile, Bernie Sanders announced he is going to the Vatican, where he hopes to meet with the pope.

headline: Rather Than Rules, Pope’s Document Gives License to Adapt
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Rather than dictating policy like a chief executive, Pope Francis effectively devolved power on family issues.
lead_paragraph: ROME — At 256 pages and 391 footnotes, the apostolic exhortation Pope Francis issued on Friday is a lengthy reminder of the importance he places on family, if also a puzzle. Some analysts are calling it revolutionary. Others describe it as tepid or opaque.

headline: Ted Cruz Wins Majority of Delegates in Colorado
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: By Friday night, Mr. Cruz had taken 21 of the state’s 37 national delegates. Donald J. Trump and Gov. John Kasich of Ohio had none.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Senator Ted Cruz captured a majority of Colorado’s delegates to the Republican National Convention on Friday, outmaneuvering Donald J. Trump, whose lack of an organized national campaign once again allowed Mr. Cruz to gain at his expense.

headline: Catholics Express Hope and Disappointment Over Pope’s Statement on Families
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Francis’ manifesto, “Amoris Laetitia,” is turning out to be a Rorschach test for members of the Church.
lead_paragraph: Wedding invitations. Empty nesters. In vitro fertilization. Children of divorce. Pope Francis’ new 265-page manifesto, “Amoris Laetitia,” Latin for “The Joy of Love,” covers so much territory that it is going to take some time for Catholics to read and reflect on it.

headline: A Mets Win on Opening Day Keeps Apprehensions on Ice
abstract: The ironclad rule of baseball: Conclude nothing from an April win or loss.
lead_paragraph: This opening day had a Rip Van Winkle feel to it, as if we’d fallen off to sleep in early November and awakened a day or two later.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Campaign Fund-Raising Scrutinized in U.S. Corruption Inquiry
abstract: The wide-ranging federal investigation involves a web of people, including businessmen and senior officials at the New York Police Department.
lead_paragraph: A wide-ranging federal corruption investigation centered on two businessmen with ties to Mayor Bill de Blasio is also examining some aspects of his campaign fund-raising, a person with knowledge of the matter said on Friday.

headline: Peggy Fortnum, 96, Dies; Illustrator Gave Shape to the Paddington Bear
abstract: Ms. Fortnum was the first to draw Michael Bond’s beloved fictional bear, giving the character his floppy hat and duffle coat.
lead_paragraph: He was an orphaned immigrant from “darkest Peru” who took his name from the Central London railway station where he was rescued by an agreeable English couple named Mr. and Mrs. Brown. They spotted him on the platform, sitting alone on an old leather suitcase and sporting an odd-looking hat and a handwritten label that implored, “Please look after this bear.”

headline: William L. O’Neill, a Historian Who Wrote About Radicals, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. O’Neill, a professor at Rutgers until 2006, was the author of books about Stalinism, World War II, the 1960s and the activist Max Eastman.
lead_paragraph: William L. O’Neill, an admired and provocative 20th-century historian who examined America’s political radicals and its not always wise behavior in war, died on March 29 in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 80.

headline: Ernie Els Awakens From His First-Round Nightmare at the Masters
abstract: Els took six putts from 3 feet for an opening nine Thursday, but rebounded in a strong round the next day.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — On the practice green before his round on Friday at the Masters, Ernie Els made 25 of 28 putts from inside 9 feet. The last one he struck before making his way to the first tee at Augusta National Golf Club was a 2-footer that dropped in the hole.

headline: Drinking Water in Newark Schools Known to Have Lead Problem at Least 6 Years Ago
abstract: About one in eight water samples taken from the city’s public schools at the time contained lead concentrations above the federal threshold.
lead_paragraph: Drinking water in Newark Public Schools was found to contain high levels of lead at least as far back as six years ago, according to data collected and analyzed then but released to the public for the first time on Friday.

headline: Friday Night Music: Pencils From Pennsylvania
abstract: And tents from Tentasee.
lead_paragraph: In Providence talking to the Organization of American Historians, and this came to mind:

headline: A Hard Act to Follow
abstract: A lively Saturday puzzle by David Phillips.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — David Phillips had me right off the bat by opening with the clue “Steven who co-created TV’s ‘Sherlock'” for MOFFAT. Mr. MOFFAT also was, until recently, the showrunner for the BBC’s iconic series, “Doctor Who.” Put either of those shows in a puzzle and I’m paying attention.

headline: Steven Van Zandt Calls Decision to Cancel Concert Difficult but Necessary
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Law and Legislation', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: The guitarist’s bandleader, Bruce Springsteen, called off the show in North Carolina because of its new law on gay and transgender rights.
lead_paragraph: Steven Van Zandt, a veteran member of Bruce Springsteen’s E Street Band, said on Friday that the group’s decision to cancel a concert in North Carolina in protest of a new law there on gay and transgender rights was not an easy one, because it punishes fans.

headline: New York State Police Leader Is Stepping Down
abstract: Joseph D’Amico, who was appointed the agency’s superintendent by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in 2011, said he wanted to “pursue other opportunities.”
lead_paragraph: The head of the New York State Police, Joseph D’Amico, abruptly announced his retirement on Friday, saying he wanted to “pursue other opportunities.”

headline: Johan Van Steen, Legal Expert and Photographer, Dies in Brussels Attacks
abstract: Mr. Van Steen, 58, was a legal adviser to the Belgian government, but it was his view of the world through the camera’s lens that defined him, his partner says.
lead_paragraph: Johan Van Steen, an adviser to the Belgian government who had a passion for photography, saw the world in light and shadow.

headline: Amateur Champion Brushes Off a Bad End at Masters
abstract: After carding his second consecutive even-par 72, Bryson DeChambeau did not rue the shots that got away.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Going into the final hole of his second round at the Masters, Bryson DeChambeau, an amateur, was poised to post the lowest round of the day. On 18, he tried a low stinger to keep the ball from getting caught up in the wind and hit over the top of it. His shot landed in a holly bush, and he had to take an unplayable lie, which led to a triple-bogey seven.

headline: Prosecutors Recommend Sentencing for Dennis Hastert
abstract: Illinois prosecutors said they believed the former speaker of the House should face up to six months in prison.
lead_paragraph: Illinois prosecutors said they believed the former speaker of the House should face up to six months in prison.

headline: Hastert Molested at Least Four Boys, Prosecutors Say
abstract: In a court filing, prosecutors said they believed the former speaker of the House should face up to six months in prison when he is sentenced on April 27.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Federal prosecutors on Friday for the first time provided details of sexual abuse allegations against J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House, asserting that he molested at least four boys, as young as 14, when he worked as a high school wrestling coach decades ago.

headline: Before and After the Panama Papers: David Cameron of Britain on Tax Avoidance
abstract: The prime minister has condemned offshore accounts used to avoid taxes, but leaked documents show that his family has profited from an offshore investment fund.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Since becoming the prime minister of Britain, David Cameron has condemned wealthy individuals who set up complicated offshore accounts to avoid paying British taxes, saying these tax evaders would have “nowhere to hide.”

headline: Robert MacCrate, Lawyer in My Lai Inquiry, Dies at 94
abstract: He served as civilian counsel for the Army panel investigating the 1968 massacre, and later oversaw a landmark report calling for an overhaul of legal education.
lead_paragraph: Robert MacCrate, a lawyer who served as a special civilian counsel on an Army panel investigating the 1968 My Lai massacre in Vietnam, and who oversaw a landmark report by the American Bar Association in 1992 calling for an overhaul of legal education, died on Wednesday at his home in Plandome, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 94.

headline: Corrections: April 9, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, April 9, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 9, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “A pastor cannot feel that it is enough to simply apply moral laws to those living in ‘irregular’ situations, as if they were stones to throw at people’s lives.”

headline: Patrik Elias, Link to Devils’ Glory Days, Contemplates an End
abstract: Elias will become a free agent after the season, and he might be making his final appearance for the Devils in their finale against the Maple Leafs on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Patrik Elias expects his wife and two young daughters to come to Prudential Center for the Devils’ season finale Saturday against the Toronto Maple Leafs.

headline: After His Induction, Steve Miller Rips Rock and Roll Hall of Fame
keywords: ['Music', 'Halls of Fame', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Records and Achievements']
abstract: The rock veteran said, “When they told me I was inducted they said, ‘You have two tickets — one for your wife and one for yourself. Want another one? It’s $10,000.’”
lead_paragraph: Steve Miller — of all people — brought some punk spirit to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony on Friday night at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: Jennifer Lawrence stars in “Joy.” Gloria Vanderbilt and her son Anderson Cooper talk about their lives in “Nothing Left Unsaid.” And “Outlander” is back.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Lawrence collaborates with David O. Russell to play a mop maven and soaks up another Oscar nomination in “Joy.” Gloria Vanderbilt and her son Anderson Cooper recount their lives in “Nothing Left Unsaid.” And — let those bodices rip, lassies! — “Outlander” returns.

abstract: Bruce Hornsby will perform on April 23 at Edgerton Center for the Performing Arts.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.
