lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: North Korea Says It Successfully Tested Missile Engine
abstract: An announcement was the latest claim of success in testing various technologies needed to build an intercontinental ballistic missile.
lead_paragraph: North Korea said Saturday that it had successfully conducted a ground test of an engine for an intercontinental ballistic missile, which it said would enable it to strike the United States mainland with a nuclear warhead.

headline: Aung San Suu Kyi Has Cataract Surgery, Her Doctor Says
abstract: The operation, which was successful, will be followed by a second later in April for the Burmese leader’s other eye, the doctor said Saturday.
lead_paragraph: YANGON, Myanmar — Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the de facto leader of Myanmar’s new civilian government, underwent successful cataract surgery on Saturday, her doctor and a party official said.

headline: ‘This Leak Is Big ... Heads Should Roll’
abstract: Our top 10 comments of the week: Readers react to the Panama Papers, the pope’s statement on the family, the death of Merle Haggard and more.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: No More Drugs or Gigolos: A Celebrity Hairdresser Comes Clean
abstract: For 17 years, April Barton cut hair at the Chelsea Hotel among junkies and artists. Now her star-studded clientele has followed her to Bond Street.
lead_paragraph: April Barton slipped into the back door of her hair salon, Suite 303, at 7 Bond Street in Lower Manhattan. “I’m late,” she said. “Which means Malcolm will be waiting.”

headline: Hollywood Celebrities Choose Sides in Presidential Race
abstract: Power players like Steven Spielberg are endorsing Hillary Clinton, but supporters of Bernie Sanders are vociferous, persistent and having fun.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders makes a point of saying that he is not running his campaign for the “millionaires and billionaires,” but an event for his presidential campaign at the Flash Factory on West 28th Street Monday night did cordon off celebrities in a V.I.P. area.

headline: When a Feminist Pledges a Sorority
keywords: ['Fraternities and Sororities', "Women's Rights", 'Colleges and Universities', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: College women are embracing — and rethinking — the Greek life experience. And not just on the campuses you’d expect: in the Ivy League.
lead_paragraph: It was a Thursday evening on the Columbia University campus, and a group from the Kappa Alpha Theta sorority was wedged onto couches eating takeout, some seated cross-legged on the floor. Two discussed an introductory Chinese language class. One thanked a sister for passing along her résumé for an internship. And then there were a few talking about spring break.

headline: Olympus Investigation Shows Ethical Lapses and a Caterer With Clout
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Cameras', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: Two years after admitting to accounting fraud, Olympus hired its cafeteria operator to handle a dispute with Chinese customs authorities. Soon after, the case was inexplicably dropped.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Managers at an Olympus factory in southern China struggled for years to resolve a thorny dispute with local customs authorities. The problem risked incurring millions of dollars in fines and harming a crucial manufacturing hub that churned out 50 million camera lenses a year.

headline: Looking for Signs of Life in Emerging Markets
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Commodities', 'Interest Rates', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Emerging-market stocks could again become one of the best-performing asset classes, but another “supercycle” may be years away.
lead_paragraph: For years, many investors have been pining for a rebound in emerging-market stocks, only to be frustrated by the slide in commodity prices, which still drive many developing economies.

headline: Financial Fables: All the Better to Teach You With, My Dear
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Personal Finances', 'Children and Childhood', 'Books and Literature', 'Firearms', 'Fairy Tales', 'Gun Control']
abstract: If the N.R.A. can use fairy tales to promote guns, then surely we can use them to make investing less boring to children.
lead_paragraph: Those people over at the National Rifle Association have some great ideas.

headline: Small-Cap Growth Funds: For Investors With Nerves of Steel
abstract: Fund managers find ways to manage the risks inherent in this volatile sector and maximize the benefits.
lead_paragraph: Investing in small-cap growth funds requires a strong stomach because this part of the stock market tends to lurch wildly.

headline: Junk Bonds: Never Stodgy and Steadier Than You Might Think
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Junk Bonds', 'Asset Allocation (Personal Finances)']
abstract: As part of the riskier stock side of a portfolio, high-yield bonds can deliver more income than dividend-paying stocks without so much volatility.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, high-yield bond funds had a strong start to 2016 with a first-quarter gain of 2 percent. But if you were paying closer attention, the ride was anything but smooth.

headline: ‘Brexit’ Vote Has Investment Experts Advising Caution in Europe
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'British Pound (Currency)', 'Euro (Currency)', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: Polls show no clear tilt for the June 23 referendum, but experts warn that the effects of a British exit from the E.U. have not been factored into prices.
lead_paragraph: The British are going! Maybe.

headline: Book Reviews: Behind a Powerful Portfolio, a Successful Career
abstract: Two new books on saving and investing discuss making career moves that raise the value of your labor, which in turn can help you save more.
lead_paragraph: Personal finance advice is often so focused on making sure our assets are properly diversified, taking every deduction we are entitled to and keeping investment costs low that it is easy to forget one important fact: When it comes to securing your financial future, the better you manage your career, the more money you are likely to have.

headline: Target-Date Funds Are Simple, but They Still Require Careful Aim
abstract: The popular vehicles don’t guarantee returns and may not provide the blend of investments that you want.
lead_paragraph: Target-date funds are intended to be all-in-one investing solutions capable of getting you all the way to retirement. They typically don’t try to produce market-beating returns, but can provide an appropriate mix of stocks and bonds based on your age and planned retirement date.

headline: Investors Look for Solid Footing After Market Recovery
abstract: The first quarter took investors on a wild ride, with stocks plunging into an abyss and then rocketing back out. But worries about earnings persist.
lead_paragraph: Stocks went nowhere fast in the first quarter, plunging into an abyss and rocketing right back out to end modestly above where they began. It’s as if traders concluded first that economic and corporate conditions were profoundly disappointing, and then, with equal certainty, that conditions were much better than they had come to expect.

headline: Taking Shelter in Old-School Dividend Stocks
abstract: The quarter’s top-performing mutual funds sought stock in companies that not only paid dividends, but that also had a durable business and a burly balance sheet.
lead_paragraph: Over the last several years, growth stocks, like Amazon and Netflix, have brought much momentum to the market. But in the first quarter, those kinds of stocks lost some of their sizzle, as old-school dividend payers came back into favor.

headline: The Week on Instagram
abstract: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took Instagram followers from a wildlife center in Indonesia to a hospital in Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted on @nytimes this week took Instagram followers from a wildlife center in Indonesia to a hospital in Saudi Arabia.

headline: (Legal) Moonshiner and University Battle Over Rights to ‘Kentucky’
keywords: ['Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Basketball (College)', 'ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES', 'College Athletics', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'States (US)']
abstract: When Colin Fultz opened a gourmet distillery and tried to trademark his business name, Kentucky Mist Moonshine, the University of Kentucky said, Whoa.
lead_paragraph: WHITESBURG, Ky. — Moonshine packs a punch in this corner of Appalachia, where making hooch is steeped in local lore. But when Colin Fultz, the grandson of a bootlegger, opened a gourmet distillery here last fall, he ran afoul of a spirit even more potent than white lightning: University of Kentucky basketball.

headline: The Week in Tech: Facebook Live, a More Civil Reddit and Yahoo’s Odd Deal-Making
abstract: Michael de la Merced, of DealBook, fills in for Farhad Manjoo and joins Mike Isaac for a discussion of all that and Twitter’s football deal.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry. Mr. Manjoo is off this week (again), so Michael de la Merced, a DealBook reporter, is filling in.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Big Win: Tickets to ‘Hamilton’
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders and his wife, Jane Sanders, scored two $167 “house seats,” the ones reserved for people like dignitaries and cast members’ families, for the Friday night show.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders snagged tickets Friday to one of the hottest Broadway shows in town, and of course, it featured a political revolution.

headline: Help, My Windows Are Sealed!
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Cooperatives', 'Building (Construction)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Access to air and light; nonrefundable co-op fees; and selling rights to build higher.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: A Familiar Pattern in a Spouse’s Final Act
abstract: After years of violence, Nadia Saavedra finally told her husband to leave their Bronx home. Soon after, the police say, he returned to kill her and then himself.
lead_paragraph: Leer en español

headline: From Tank to Shining Tank
abstract: Visitors to Manhattan Aquariums, on West 37th Street, enter another world: a sea of glowing corals and fish that resemble extras in “Finding Nemo.”
lead_paragraph: Visitors to Manhattan Aquariums, on West 37th Street, enter another world: a sea of glowing corals and fish that resemble extras in “Finding Nemo.”

headline: Dory and Nemo in Hell’s Kitchen
abstract: Manhattan Aquariums on West 37th Street draws fish lovers to the muffled hum of filters, the thrum of music and the psychedelia of coral.
lead_paragraph: Fish are America’s great starter pets — the goldfish brought home from a street fair that Mom and Dad allow in the house to teach responsibility before agreeing to a “real pet” like a dog or a cat.

headline: Getting Fit, Prison-Style
abstract: With few job prospects after leaving prison, a former drug dealer opened a gym to teach a workout regimen he developed behind bars.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago, at a park on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, Coss Marte took hold of a corroded metal pipe and felt the weight of his body as he lifted his feet off the ground for some pull-ups. With each heave, he watched the city’s skyline rise and fall through the early morning haze.

headline: Souvenir of Queen Victoria’s Wedding
abstract: The Brooklyn Museum boasts a rare confection: a paper-wrapped cube of wedding cake from Queen Victoria’s 1840 wedding, donated in 1998.
lead_paragraph: Now that wedding season is once again upon us, it’s worth noting that the Brooklyn Museum boasts a kind of nuptial-themed confection unavailable at even the trendiest of the city’s bakeries. Of course, it can never actually be seen.

headline: Man in Hat in Brussels Airport Attack Is in Custody, Belgium Says
abstract: Mohamed Abrini, who was detained Friday, confessed he was the suspect seen with two suicide bombers in a surveillance image, the Belgian prosecutor’s office said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The “man in the hat” who accompanied the two suicide bombers who detonated their explosives at Brussels Airport on March 22, and who was seen in a surveillance video walking away from the airport, has been identified as Mohamed Abrini, the Belgian prosecutor’s office said in a statement on Saturday.

headline: In Montevideo, a Restaurant Serving Old-School Recipes
abstract: Most of Tona’s dishes are slightly updated examples of what grandmothers have cooked for their families for generations.
lead_paragraph: Ask anyone who hasn’t spent time in Uruguay what they know about that country’s food, and you may hear mentions of asado, barbecue cooked over a wood fire, or chivito, a steak sandwich topped with bacon, cheese and vegetables. But you’ll often be met with a blank stare.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Mark Diehl offers us a lively Puns and Anagrams puzzle.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — I’m happy to see Mark Diehl’s byline under Puns and Anagrams again.

headline: As Britain Contemplates Exit, Boris Johnson Prepares His Entrance
abstract: Mr. Johnson, the mayor of London, is bucking his party by supporting Britain’s exit from the European Union, effectively announcing his bid to be prime minister.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Boris Johnson, the mayor of London, was in full spat mode with the television journalist Andrew Marr on a prominent Sunday news program.

headline: At the Masters and Tantalizingly Close to a Coronation
abstract: Someone on Sunday will experience the feeling of exiting stage left while his playing competitor basks in the spotlight and takes the final bow.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The par-4 closing hole at Augusta National became the Green Quarter-Mile for Brandt Snedeker in 2008. Playing his first Masters as a professional, Snedeker moved into a tie for the lead with his playing competitor, Trevor Immelman, with an eagle on the third hole on the final day.

headline: Scouring the Dark Web to Keep Tabs on Terrorists
abstract: Alex Kassirer, an analyst at Flashpoint in New York, helps government agencies and corporations by monitoring jihadists and criminals in hidden corners of the web.
lead_paragraph: Q. What types of clients do you work for, and what is your role?

headline: The Art and Science of Nit-Picking
keywords: ['Nursing and Nurses', 'Careers and Professions', 'Lice', 'Education (K-12)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Lice']
abstract: A retired school nurse, recalling the chore of dealing with head lice, considers a second career at a growing number of salons dedicated to the problem.
lead_paragraph: Back in the early 1980s, I was delighted when the elementary school in my town let me know that I had been hired as the school nurse. Not only would I have a new challenge, but after many years of working as a registered nurse in hospitals, I would no longer have to work evenings and nights.

headline: As Campaigns Seek Delegates, Ordinary Voters Feel Sidelined
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Democratic National Convention', 'Republican National Convention', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: As Americans flock this year to outsider candidates, they are suddenly waking up to the reality that the process for picking the parties’ nominees involves ordinary voters in only an indirect way.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When it comes to nominating presidential candidates, it turns out the world’s foremost democracy is not so purely democratic.

headline: The Female Viagra, Undone by a Drug Maker’s Dysfunction
abstract: Missteps by Valeant, along with aggressive accounting practices and unusual business relationships, derailed one of the most intriguing drugs in a generation.
lead_paragraph: Last August, Sprout Pharmaceuticals had a new pill on its hands that quickly captured the nation’s imagination. The Food and Drug Administration had just approved its drug Addyi to treat low sex drive in women.

headline: A Trucker’s Tale of a Rent-to-Own Runaround
keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'Consumer Protection', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Automobile Renting and Leasing']
abstract: A long-haul big-rig driver says he spent $40,000 on a rent-to-own vehicle and has nothing to show for it but frustration and heartache.
lead_paragraph: In this episode, we meet a man who says his life was irrevocably changed, for the worse, by a truck dealership.

headline: For Harry Truman, the Buck Stopped at a Brush With Bankruptcy
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Bankruptcies', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The 33rd president’s partnership in a failed haberdashery may have made him a more conservative steward of the nation’s finances.
lead_paragraph: This year, Donald J. Trump and Carly Fiorina have argued that candidates should not be disqualified from the presidency because of their business failures, which, in Mr. Trump’s case, have included multiple bankruptcies. Some Trump defenders have noted that one of the nation’s most important presidents, Harry S. Truman, was a partner in a haberdashery that ran aground. Truman’s business failure was a comparatively brief episode in a life that was mainly political, but it nevetheless offers revealing insights into his character and leadership.

headline: Bernie Sanders Wins Wyoming Democratic Caucuses
abstract: Mr. Sanders continued his string of victories in the West leading up to the major primary in New York on April 19.
lead_paragraph: Continuing a string of victories across the West, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont won the Wyoming caucuses on Saturday, a symbolic triumph, if not a race-altering one, in the last Democratic contest before the April 19 New York primary.

headline: When the Oil Fields Burned
abstract: In 1991, Saddam Hussein’s troops set off an inferno in Kuwait, creating an environmental catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: In 1991, Saddam Hussein’s troops set off an inferno in Kuwait, creating an environmental catastrophe.

headline: Austria Considers Law to Seize Home Where Hitler Was Born
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Hitler himself paid no attention to the town of Braunau, but the fate of the privately owned home there has been debated since World War II ended.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The fate of Adolf Hitler’s birthplace in the picturesque Austrian border town of Braunau has been fiercely debated at least since victorious American G.I.s stopped the Nazis from destroying the house at the end of World War II.

headline: Honoring an Islanders Father Figure
abstract: Al Arbour, who coached the team for two stints and led it to four Stanley Cup victories, could be caustic, but his former players recalled his caring side at a memorial service. Arbour died in August at 82.
lead_paragraph: HUNTINGTON, N.Y. — Al Arbour surely would have been proud to witness the gathering of his former players on Friday. Stories that followed his memorial service were the stuff of hockey legend. The joy of telling them on Long Island was especially poignant for his family, particularly his wife, Claire.

headline: A Hockey Bond for Father, Sons and Honorary Cousin
abstract: Brooks Laich assisted on Michael Nylander’s final N.H.L. goal and William Nylander’s first N.H.L. goal. Now a third Nylander, Alexander, is trying to forge a career in hockey.
lead_paragraph: MISSISSAUGA, Ontario — For the Nylanders, hockey is a family business, and Brooks Laich may have done enough to join it.

headline: Bernie Sanders Campaign Hopes an Endorsement Resonates in New York
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Advertising', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Political Action Committees', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Mr. Sanders’s first ad in New York features Erica Garner, the daughter of Eric Garner, the Staten Island man who died during an arrest after police officers placed him in a chokehold.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders’s campaign is featuring an endorsement from Erica Garner, the daughter of Eric Garner, the Staten Island man who died during an arrest after police officers placed him in a chokehold, in its first ad in New York before next week’s primary.

headline: Mike Hampton Relishes His Year as a Met
abstract: Hampton, the Mariners’ bullpen coach, calls his 2000 season with the Mets “the greatest year of my career.”
lead_paragraph: When the Seattle Mariners visit Yankee Stadium next weekend, their bullpen coach will be familiar with the city. He is Mike Hampton, the former Mets left-hander who lifted the team to the 2000 World Series with shutout pitching in the National League Championship Series.

headline: New Rock Hall of Fame Class Confronts a Familiar Identity Crisis
keywords: ['Music', 'Pop and Rock Music', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: The induction of N.W.A this year reignited a long-running debate: What exactly is rock ’n’ roll, anyway?
lead_paragraph: After 31 years, the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame is still debating what exactly counts as rock ’n’ roll.

headline: Ogden Mills Phipps: A King of the Sport He Helped Make Better
abstract: One of things that Phipps, who died Wednesday at 75, was most proud of was how his family had successfully handed down its love of horses through the generations.
lead_paragraph: Dinny Phipps was as much a part of the landscape of the Oklahoma training track at Saratoga Race Course as the oak trees that Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons planted nearly 100 years ago and continue to shade the family’s barn. Most August mornings, Phipps sat out front in a golf cart and talked horses with jockeys and exercise riders, clockers and fellow owners.

headline: In Afghanistan, John Kerry Seeks End to Bickering of Unity Government
abstract: The secretary of state meet with the leaders of the coalition government, which has struggled with infighting and a resurgent Taliban.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Kabul on Saturday with a message of support for Afghanistan’s struggling coalition government, which has been bogged down by infighting as it confronts an emboldened Taliban insurgency.

headline: Welcome, Visitors. Squeeze Right In.
abstract: Visiting locker rooms remain one of the great variables with divergent setups across the league. Some are rich in amenities while others are not — it all depends on the city.
lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO, Calif. — Ramon Sessions had already endured a long trip with the Washington Wizards before the visiting locker room at Sleep Train Arena ate his shoe.

headline: Baseball Is Injuring Too Many Kids
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Sports Injuries', 'Children and Childhood', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Surgery and Surgeons']
abstract: The majority of Tommy John surgeries in this country were performed on teenagers.
lead_paragraph: RYUSEI was just 11 years old. He was sitting in a chair and listening to a doctor, who stood in front of a computer screen showing an image of an elbow ligament damaged from repeatedly throwing a baseball. Ryusei smiled. He didn’t seem to realize the ligament was his.

headline: Judging Obama’s Record
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Readers appraise his successes and failures, and muse about what could have been.
lead_paragraph: Readers appraise his successes and failures, and muse about what could have been.

headline: The Race to Run the United Nations
abstract: For the very first time, people are openly vying for the organization’s top post.
lead_paragraph: For the past 70 years, each time the post of secretary general of the United Nations has been open, those interested in the job lobbied and cajoled the five permanent members of the Security Council behind closed doors. The Council chose the finalist, whose name was then presented to the General Assembly as a done deal. This obscure process for selecting one of the world’s most important leaders has gone unchallenged for decades.

headline: Gun Dealers Hiding on Facebook
abstract: The Internet giant must do a better job of enforcing its gun sale ban.
lead_paragraph: Facebook, with more than one billion users worldwide, is increasingly being used by shady gun dealers who find it easy to hide in this sprawling and lightly policed virtual marketplace. And they are not just individuals skirting gun-control laws to sell a pistol or rifle. Facebook groups have been used to trade antiaircraft weapons, grenades, heavy machine guns and guided missiles in battleground regions of the Middle East, according to a report in The Times.

headline: The New Catholic Truce
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Families and Family Life', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'ADULTERY']
abstract: On divorce, Pope Francis renegotiates his church’s liberal-conservative divide.
lead_paragraph: MODERNITY has left nearly every religious tradition in the Western world divided.

headline: A Fair Chance After a Conviction
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Financial Aid (Education)', 'Pell Grants', 'Education', 'Ex-Convicts']
abstract: The Obama administration has worked hard to ease the marginalization of millions of Americans with criminal records.
lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has worked diligently over the last five years to ease the marginalization of more than 70 million Americans with criminal records that can shut them out of jobs, housing, higher education or the consumer credit system — sometimes for minor offenses in the distant past or arrests that never led to conviction. By addressing this problem, Mr. Obama is pushing the country to re-evaluate longstanding policies that trap people with criminal records at the very edges of society, driving many of them right back to prison.

headline: Bipartisanship Isn’t for Wimps, After All
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Our political polarization leads to bigotry and contempt, and undermines our country’s place in the world.
lead_paragraph: THERE’S an old joke about two comedians sitting in a rowboat. One falls overboard. Not able to swim, he starts waving his arms and frantically screaming, “Hey! I’m dyin’ over here!” His friend calls back to him, “Go dirty!”

headline: Building a Better Father
abstract: When a man loses his reserve, he gains so much more.
lead_paragraph: AS a child I was schooled constantly in how different mothers and fathers were. TV shows spelled it out. So did examples and conversations all around me, including in my own home.

headline: Happy Birthday, Beverly Cleary!
abstract: The children’s author, who turns 100 on Tuesday, speaks about her characters, her life and her wisdom.
lead_paragraph: RAMONA drummed harder to show everyone how bad she was. She would not take off her shoes. She was a terrible, wicked girl! Being such a bad, terrible, horrid, wicked girl made her feel good! She brought both heels against the wall at the same time. Thump! Thump! Thump! She was not the least bit sorry for what she was doing. She would never be sorry. Never! Never! Never!

headline: Unlocking the Truth About the Clinton Crime Bill
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Law and Legislation', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Mandatory Sentencing']
abstract: It was the beginning of the end of the war on drugs.
lead_paragraph: AT a campaign event in Philadelphia last week, former President Bill Clinton was interrupted by protesters incensed about his 1994 crime bill. Mr. Clinton did not hold back: “Because of that bill we had a 25-year low in crime, a 33-year low in the murder rate, and because of that and the background-check law, we had a 46-year low in deaths of people by gun violence,” he said.

headline: Dinklage and Dragons: Will Tyrion Win the ‘Game of Thrones’?
abstract: April is the cruelest month, especially since the gory “Game of Thrones” is back.
lead_paragraph: I had many questions for Peter Dinklage.

headline: The Donald and the Veg-O-Matic
abstract: Bad arguments are bad arguments even when used against a bad guy.
lead_paragraph: I’ve written on a number of occasions about the Veg-O-Matic temptation — the urge to claim that your preferred policy solves all problems — it slices! It dices! It purees! It creates jobs! It raises productivity! It takes off weight without diet or exercise! There’s also the reverse version, in which a policy you dislike does everything bad — It’s inflationary! It’s contractionary! It causes acne!

headline: A Mentor’s Words Resonate With a New Mets Reliever
abstract: Jim Henderson learned about the game from the fiery pitcher Francisco Rodriguez when both played for the Brewers. The quieter Henderson leans on that knowledge in New York.
lead_paragraph: When the Milwaukee Brewers demoted their struggling closer, John Axford, early in the 2013 season, they decided to let two pitchers share the role: Francisco Rodriguez, a four-time All-Star who had once saved 62 games, and Jim Henderson, who until the previous season had spent almost a decade in the minors.

headline: Inside Saudi Arabia’s Re-education Prison for Jihadists
abstract: The Family House feels like a boutique hotel, if you can overlook the lack of windows, the towering walls outside and the location inside a high-security prison.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — The “guests” are issued key cards for their rooms, receive three catered meals per day and sleep in luxury suites outfitted with big-screen TVs, king-size beds and shiny wallpaper.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: Golf Swing Evolves Into a Pain In the Back

headline: From Bernie Sanders, a Challenge for Hillary Clinton
abstract: Bernie Sanders accused Hillary Clinton of being vague on economic justice issues/
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders, taking his campaign to Upper Manhattan and a crowd of about a thousand, on Saturday took issue with Hillary Clinton over economic justice issues like trade agreements and the minimum wage, and accused her of being “vague” on Social Security benefits.

headline: Review: ‘A Cambodian Lullaby,’ the Triumph of a Survivor and His Art
abstract: At Schoolhouse Theater, “A Cambodian Lullaby” is not about horror, but an American immigrant story that begins in a refugee camp in Thailand.
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that a show welcomes its audience with a shower of rose petals. And if that alone were not reason enough to check out Sokeo Ros’s endearing performance piece at the Schoolhouse Theater in Croton Falls, there are plenty of others.

headline: Why Teachers on TV Have to Be Incompetent or Inspiring
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Careers and Professions', 'Movies', 'Television', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: They’re heroes or buffoons. And they never actually teach.
lead_paragraph: ONE high school teacher runs a prescription drug ring. An elementary teacher rejects an assignment to work with gifted students because she “can’t relate to people with glasses.” And a Spanish instructor gives a lesson listing films in which Salma Hayek appears naked.

headline: Congratulations! You’ve Been Fired
abstract: Life in the new tech workplace is suspiciously like life in the old sweatshop.
lead_paragraph: AT HubSpot, the software company where I worked for almost two years, when you got fired, it was called “graduation.” We all would get a cheery email from the boss saying, “Team, just letting you know that X has graduated and we’re all excited to see how she uses her superpowers in her next big adventure.” One day this happened to a friend of mine. She was 35, had been with the company for four years, and was told without explanation by her 28-year-old manager that she had two weeks to get out. On her last day, that manager organized a farewell party for her.

headline: Two Projects Share a Goal: Challenge Stereotypes of Islam and Arabs
abstract: “Wondrous Worlds,” an exhibition at the Newark Museum, and the film “A Thousand and One Journeys: The Arab Americans,” fit together, and don’t.
lead_paragraph: Those who visit “Wondrous Worlds: Art and Islam Through Time and Place” at the Newark Museum may also be interested in a screening of “A Thousand and One Journeys: The Arab Americans,” an award-winning documentary currently on the festival and screenings circuit.

headline: At Montclair Records, a Bedroom Community With Verve
abstract: Founded in a basement by three friends, the recording studio doubles as living quarters. In addition to helping Long Island musicians, the partners began a concert series that meshes hip-hop and rock.
lead_paragraph: Billy Hanley is 26 and lives with his parents. But his bachelor pad in the basement, such as it is, does not reek of sneakers or Axe body spray, nor does its décor include empty pizza boxes or dirty socks. He keeps things clean and professional, as it is also his work space.

headline: Review: Guns N’ Roses, Partly Reunited, in Its First Arena Performance
abstract: Known in recent years for feuds more than music, Axl Rose, Duff McKagan and Slash reunited for the first time since the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — “You like my, my furniture?” the singer W. Axl Rose asked the screaming crowd at the T-Mobile Arena here on Friday night. He was on a throne made from guitars and amps, lent by Dave Grohl of the Foo Fighters, where he could keep his injured left foot immobile.

headline: Review: ‘Cymbeline’ at Yale Repertory Theater
abstract: The director Evan Yionoulis stages a production of a fine Shakespearean mess that bends genders in addition to twisting genres.
lead_paragraph: “Cymbeline” is a genre-twister of a Shakespeare play. In the production being staged at Yale Repertory Theater, it’s also a gender-twister.

headline: Peter Singer
abstract: A philosopher on humane treatment for animals, surfing, and baking bread.
lead_paragraph: Peter Singer is an influential and controversial Australian moral philosopher who approaches ethics from a utilitarian perspective and expounds on a wide range of issues including animal rights, the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, high-priced art and genetically modified food.

headline: Creating Intoxicating Brews at Coffee Labs Roasters, in Tarrytown
abstract: A Tarrytown coffeehouse works with local beer and whiskey producers to yield creative collaborations.
lead_paragraph: During its early years, written accounts and conversations about Coffee Labs Roasters on Main Street in Tarrytown invariably included an endearing annotation that the name of the shop was not a reference to a brewing workshop but to the owners’ dogs, two chocolate Labradors.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Wings Lose to Rangers but Make Playoffs
abstract: The Red Wings qualified Saturday afternoon for the Stanley Cup playoffs for the 25th consecutive season, the longest current streak in the N.H.L.
lead_paragraph: The grizzled Detroit Red Wings forward Brad Richards could not recall any of his first 16 N.H.L. regular seasons ending quite like this: with his teammates gathered in front of a television in a road team’s dressing room waiting for an also-ran squad playing 215 miles away to polish off a blowout.

headline: Review: Burg Fires Up Its Griddle in a Revitalized Newark Park
abstract: The restaurant, which opened in Military Park in November, offers whimsical burgers and sandwiches, crispy fries and floats.
lead_paragraph: The view from my ice cream float was of a white-spired Colonial-era church. In the park where I sat, the first warm day of spring had inspired an intense game of outdoor table tennis and coaxed daffodils to bloom near a statue of a Civil War general. If I hadn’t known better, I would have thought I was in Boston.

headline: Turbulent Race Could Mean Cash Crunch for Republican National Committee
abstract: With many big donors sidelined for now, the R.N.C. could have a tough time raising the cash it needs to pour resources into battleground states.
lead_paragraph: Confronted with a prolonged presidential nomination fight and two leading candidates whom donors are uneasy about, the Republican National Committee could be contending with a cash crunch that limits its ability to pour resources into battleground states.

headline: Review: Honig Grill in Woodbury Offers California With a Twist
abstract: The restaurant bills itself as “a taste of Napa Valley,” referring primarily to the wine list. A number of dishes are named for the region, too.
lead_paragraph: As we left Honig Grill in Woodbury, a 10-year-old boy in our party said, “I liked the food, but a lot of other things weren’t good.” His analysis was spot on.

headline: At Shu Restaurant in West Hartford, Dishes With a Kick of Heat
abstract: The menu may have a misspelling or two, but diners have reasons to overlook that.
lead_paragraph: A nondescript plaza in the commercial no-man’s land of New Britain Avenue, next to the A Dong Market, is home to Shu Restaurant, where you can sample authentic Sichuan cuisine in all its amplitude and punch.

headline: Chicago State, a Lifeline for Poor Blacks, Is Under Threat Itself
abstract: The university has received no state funding in months, and may soon close, shuttering a path forward for an underserved community.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The lack of a state budget in Illinois has been dismissed by many here as politics as usual, another protracted ego contest between the Republican governor and the Democrats who rule the Legislature.

headline: C. C. Sabathia, on a Short Leash, Contains the Tigers
abstract: The Yankees’ expensive starter — now No. 5 in the rotation — pitched out of trouble in his first start since entering an alcohol rehabilitation facility last year.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — The first sign of just how much of a leash the Yankees will give C. C. Sabathia — hint: it may be as short as Manager Joe Girardi’s closely cropped hair — arrived on Saturday in the fifth inning of his first start of the season.

headline: Civil Rights Activists Support Bernie Sanders in New Ad
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Harry Belafonte and Eric Garner’s daughter appear in a 30-second spot that is part of a multimedia campaign produced by Spike Lee.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has released a new television ad featuring several civil rights activists, including the actor Harry Belafonte, the daughter of Eric Garner and Linda Sarsour, who helped dismantle the New York Police Department’s program of spying on Muslims.

headline: Donald Trump, in First Visit to 9/11 Memorial, Praises ‘New York Values’ in Jab at Ted Cruz
abstract: The candidate donated $100,000 to the September 11 Memorial Museum, but canceled a planned discussion with reporters after his visit.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump paid his first-ever visit to the September 11 Memorial Museum on Saturday, a gesture on a rainy day that was unmistakably aimed at Senator Ted Cruz with the New York primary a little more than a week away.

headline: Something in the Water
abstract: Randolph Ross floats one by us.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Creating crossword puzzles is not just a matter of crossing words. Some crossword constructors are visionaries who enjoy incorporating visual elements into their grids. I think immediately of the Sunday puzzles by Liz Gorski and Kevin Der’s “Grid Iron” puzzle.

headline: Donald Trump’s Trial Balloons Are Catching Up With Him
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: None of Donald Trump’s tune changes seemed to matter much until recently. But his style — long on gut instincts, short on briefing books — has taken a toll.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two weeks ago, Donald J. Trump said he could live with a nuclear-armed Japan and South Korea if it meant they could defend themselves against North Korea without American aid. “I’m not sure that would be a bad thing for us,” he said.

headline: J. Dennis Hastert Is Sorry for Past ‘Transgressions,’ Lawyer Says
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Prosecutors say Mr. Hastert, awaiting sentencing for violating federal banking laws, sexually abused teenage boys as a teacher and wrestling coach.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A lawyer for J. Dennis Hastert, the former speaker of the House who is awaiting sentencing for a federal banking violation, said Saturday that his client acknowledged committing “transgressions” decades ago as a high school teacher and wrestling coach, but again stopped short of detailing those misdeeds.

headline: Tony Conrad, Experimental Filmmaker and Musician, Dies at 76
abstract: Mr. Conrad’s first film, “The Flicker,” warned audiences it could induce epileptic seizures, but it was still shown at the New York Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: Tony Conrad, an experimental filmmaker, avant-garde musician and university educator who in the 1960s was a central figure in a flowering Lower Manhattan art movement, died on Saturday at a hospice in Cheektowaga, N.Y., near Buffalo. He was 76.

headline: Three Post Record Times in a Race Rarely Run: The Indoor Marathon
abstract: The Armory NYC Indoor Marathon was a perfect event for runners seeking to break an unheralded world record.
lead_paragraph: On a memorable night in 1908, New York was the center of the running universe as Dorando Pietri faced off against Johnny Hayes in front of a capacity crowd at the old Madison Square Garden, an indoor rematch of their epic marathon race at the London Olympics that year.

headline: Jordan Spieth’s Lead Disappears
abstract: On the final two holes, Spieth hit wayward tee shots at Nos. 17 and 18, and compounded his misery with poor wedges. His lead all but disappeared.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The wind played through the Masters on Saturday, blowing sand out of the bunkers and debris onto the greens. It blew the ball of one competitor, Billy Horschel, off the 15th green and into a water hazard, costing him a penalty stroke. The wind was so fierce, it blew Jordan Spieth’s Masters crown askew.

headline: Argentine Prosecutor May Add Ex-President to Financial Inquiry
abstract: The decision to include former President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner in a widening investigation into money laundering was made after a financier gave lengthy testimony on Friday, according to the state news agency.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — An Argentine federal prosecutor is seeking to include former President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner in a widening investigation into money laundering, according to news media reports on Saturday.

headline: At Augusta and Wimbledon, Similar Auras of Tradition
abstract: Martin Blackman, a United States Tennis Association official, made his inaugural visit to the Masters. The sports may differ, but the clubs are similarly exclusive.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — Martin Blackman, head of player development for the United States Tennis Association, made his inaugural visit to the Masters on Saturday.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 2 Premiere Recap: Chasing Ghosts
abstract: Every time-travel story, at one point or another, has to address its stance on fate.
lead_paragraph: Every time-travel story, at one point or another, has to address its stance on fate. Is there grace to be found in accepting what we can’t change despite our deepest desires? Are certain people destined to be together? Can free will alter events we originally believed to be immutable? These questions simmer beneath the surface of the Season 2 premiere of “Outlander,” which juxtaposes two very different fates for Claire, represented by two very different men.

headline: Racing Around (and Around and Around) a Track
abstract: Six men and one woman aimed to shatter the world indoor marathon records by completing 211 laps on a banked 200-meter track in Upper Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Six men and one woman aimed to shatter the world indoor marathon records by completing 211 laps on a banked 200-meter track in Upper Manhattan.

headline: Only Hard Choices for Parents Whose Children Flirt With Terror
abstract: Hoping for an intervention, Sal Shafi cooperated with the government when his son showed warning signs of radicalization. A year later, his son was in handcuffs, facing 20 years in prison.
lead_paragraph: FREMONT, Calif. — The banging on the door jolted Sal Shafi awake. F.B.I. agents were looking for his son. “Where’s Adam?” they yelled. “Where’s Adam?”

headline: Fending Off the Taliban in an Afghan Province at Risk
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: Since Maj. Gen. M. Moein Faqir came to Helmand Province, the Taliban have taken over three more districts, including Now Zad and Musa Qala, both key agricultural zones
lead_paragraph: Since Maj. Gen. M. Moein Faqir came to Helmand Province, the Taliban have taken over three more districts, including Now Zad and Musa Qala, both key agricultural zones

headline: Afghan General Plants Flowers in Helmand, but Taliban Lurk
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Opium', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Maj. Gen. M. Moein Faqir is the top military man in Helmand Province, more than half of which has been overrun by the Taliban in the past year.
lead_paragraph: CAMP BASTION, Afghanistan — Generals tend to create a lot of excitement when they move around the battlefield, especially in a place as central to the Afghan war as Helmand Province. And so it was with Maj. Gen. M. Moein Faqir as he prepared to board his helicopter to fly back to Camp Bastion, the venerable British complex he now commands.

headline: Climate-Related Death of Coral Around World Alarms Scientists
keywords: ['Reefs', 'Coral', 'Global Warming', 'Oceans and Seas', 'El Nino Southern Oscillation', 'Fishing, Commercial']
abstract: Researchers believe that bleaching, which they attribute to heat stress compounded by climate change, is threatening more than a third of the planet’s reefs.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Kim Cobb, a marine scientist at the Georgia Institute of Technology, expected the coral to be damaged when she plunged into the deep blue waters off Kiritimati Island, a remote atoll near the center of the Pacific Ocean. Still, she was stunned by what she saw as she descended some 30 feet to the rim of a coral outcropping.

headline: At Harlem’s Apollo, Bernie Sanders Slams the Clintons on Poverty and Race
abstract: Backed by his top black supporters, the senator withstood an anti-Semitic heckler and criticized legislation that Hillary Clinton helped to pass when her husband was in the White House.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders on Saturday night called on former President Bill Clinton to apologize for drowning out protesters who confronted him about his administration’s role in incarcerating large numbers of black people and about Hillary Clinton’s use of the term “super predator.”

headline: Harrowing Trip for Chinese Trawler Before Bump in Territorial Tensions
abstract: A trawler’s seizure by Indonesia, part of a continuing dispute in the South China Sea, began with a crew mate’s warning: “A gunboat is coming.”
lead_paragraph: BEIHAI, China — In the darkness of the tropical waters of the South China Sea, the shabby, blue-hulled Chinese fishing trawler edged closer to what was almost certain arrest for Zhang Deren, the boat’s engineer. He was more than 1,000 miles from his home here in southern China.

headline: Bartolo Colon Adds to Highlight Reel, but Hitters Offer Little to Celebrate
abstract: The lone highlight for the Mets on Saturday night came when Freddy Galvis tried to surprise the infield with a drag bunt in the sixth inning.
lead_paragraph: The lone highlight for the Mets on Saturday night occurred when the Phillies’ Freddy Galvis tried to surprise the infield with a drag bunt on Bartolo Colon’s first pitch of the sixth inning.

headline: Isles’ Makeshift Lineup Takes a Loss, and a Playoff Path Is Still Unsettled
abstract: The Islanders came into the contest riding a three-game winning streak to ensure a postseason berth and will have to wait another day to determine their itinerary.
lead_paragraph: The Islanders knew they would be starting the playoffs on the road. The question heading into their next-to-last game of the season against Buffalo on Saturday night was whether they would travel to Pittsburgh or Florida.

headline: Warriors’ Pursuit of Record Remains Intact With Another Win
abstract: After defeating Memphis in a tight game Saturday night, Golden State can still top the 1995-96 Chicago Bulls for the best regular-season record in the annals of the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: The Golden State Warriors drew one victory closer to basketball nirvana by escaping Saturday night with a 100-99 victory against the host Memphis Grizzlies at FedEx Forum.

headline: Exaggerator Carries Brothers to Kentucky Derby
abstract: Trained by Keith Desormeaux and ridden by Kent Desormeaux, Exaggerator won the Santa Anita Derby on a day full of key Derby prep races.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — The trainer-jockey dynamic in horse racing can be volatile enough without the added variable of common parentage.

headline: Europeans’ Masters Title Drought Looms Large in Rory McIlroy’s 77
abstract: European golfers have continued to dominate the United States in the Ryder Cup and have won the other three major tournaments repeatedly. But the Masters has remained elusive.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The photos of past Masters champions are on a wall just inside the clubhouse entrance at Augusta National, and at this stage, you have to do some searching to find the last European champion.

headline: William Hamilton Dies at 76; New Yorker Cartoonist Lampooned the Comfortable
abstract: Mr. Hamilton’s densely drawn cartoons (more realistic than cartoonish) were a staple of The New Yorker for more than 50 years. He also wrote a handful of plays and novels.
lead_paragraph: William Hamilton, a cartoonist whose work for The New Yorker over more than 50 years was known for skewering the wealthy and the powerful, died on Friday in a car crash in Lexington, Ky. He was 76.

headline: Allison Bollert, Christian Torres
abstract: The bride and groom met on Match.com in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Allison Jean Bollert and Christian Alberto Torres were married April 9 at the Harold Pratt House in Manhattan. The Rev. Annie Lawrence, an interfaith minister, officiated.

headline: Spencer Cantrell, Andrew Kachor
abstract: The couple met through the How About We dating website in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Spencer Marlowe Cantrell and Andrew Saul Rebhan Kachor were married April 9 at the Jepson Center for the Arts in Savannah, Ga. Canon Frank Logue, an Episcopal priest, officiated, and Rabbi Rachael Bregman assisted.

headline: Alison Jonas, Robert Sullivan III
abstract: The bride is an executive with a footwear company, and the groom works for a Tokyo bank.
lead_paragraph: Alison Jonas and Robert Sullivan III were married April 9 at the Gramercy Park Hotel in New York. Rabbi Allen Block officiated.

headline: Ran Lee, Jeffrey Borja
abstract: The bride is the creative director for Hollywood.com. The groom works for Prudential Financial.
lead_paragraph: Ran Lee, a daughter of Kyung Hwa Chang of Bayside, Queens, and the late Sang Chul Lee, was married April 9 to Jeffrey Nguyen Borja, the son of Kim N. Borja and Jacinto Borja of Verona, N.J. The Very Rev. Thomas J. Ciba performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Czestochowa Roman Catholic Church in Jersey City, where he is the pastor.

headline: Corinne Snow, David Denton Jr.
abstract: The bride and groom met at Harvard Law School.
lead_paragraph: Corinne Virginia Snow, a daughter of Cynthia D. Snow of Houston and Philip F. Snow Jr. of Hockley, Tex., was married April 9 to David William Denton Jr., the son of Judge Reena Raggi of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Denton Sr. The Very Rev. Michael A. Carrano, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Paul’s United Methodist Church in Houston with the Rev. Gail Williford, a United Methodist minister, assisting.

headline: Lawson Caldwell, Curt Sowers
abstract: The couple were introduced by a mutual friend at a bar in Charlotte in 1990.
lead_paragraph: Lawson Harrill Caldwell and Daniel Curtis Sowers were married April 9 at their home in Charlotte, N.C. Eleanor C. Moore, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, led a ceremony incorporating Christian traditions.

headline: Reneau Skinner, Nicholas Piesco
abstract: The bride, who works for Warner Bros. Television, and groom, who is a computer software developer, met on OkCupid.
lead_paragraph: Reneau Elizabeth Skinner and Nicholas Austin Piesco were married April 8 at the Umlauf Sculpture Garden and Museum in Austin, Tex. Heather Davis, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

headline: Addie Downing, Marc Bidder
abstract: The bride and groom both went to Columbia, from which they each received an M.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Frances Adelaide Downing, a daughter of Frances von Stade Downing and John O. Downing of Green Pond, S.C., was married April 9 to Marc Adam Bidder, a son of Veronica Sweet Bidder and Steven R. Bidder of Parkland, Fla. Robert J. Lodge, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the home of the bride’s parents.

headline: Elyse Schoenfeld, Alex Moyer
abstract: The bride and groom met in law school at George Washington University.
lead_paragraph: Elyse Mara Schoenfeld, a daughter of Cindy R. Schoenfeld and Dr. Mark H. Schoenfeld of Woodbridge, Conn., was married April 9 to Alex Jason Moyer, the son of Dr. Gayle S. Moyer and Bruce S. Moyer of Ann Arbor, Mich. Rabbi Richard Berman officiated at the Willard InterContinental, a hotel in Washington.

headline: Julie Gordon, Jason Bleck
abstract: The bride is a New York Post editor, and the groom works at a creative agency.
lead_paragraph: Julie Gordon and Jason Ross Bleck were married April 9 at the Ryland Inn in Whitehouse Station, N.J. Rabbi Faith Joy Dantowitz officiated.

headline: Christina LoNigro, Patrick Butler
abstract: The couple met in 2013 through mutual friends at a Christmas party in New York.
lead_paragraph: Christina Marie LoNigro and Patrick Clifford Butler are to be married April 10 at the Caramel Room at the Bissinger’s Chocolate Factory in St. Louis. Michael Van Nimwegen, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the event, is to officiate.

headline: Bridget Coyne, Aaron Myers
abstract: The bride works for Twitter and groom works for the Aspen Institute, both in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Bridget Colleen Coyne, a daughter of Christine E. Coyne of Downers Grove, Ill., and Raymond F. Coyne III of Elmhurst, Ill., was married April 9 to Aaron Evan Myers, a son of Laurie L. Myers and Jack A. Myers of Philadelphia. Clare R. Palace, a Universal Brotherhood minister, officiated at Eastern Market in Washington.

headline: Gabriella Janowitz, Jonathan Widder
abstract: The bride graduated from Syracuse, the groom from Rochester Institute of Technology.
lead_paragraph: Gabriella Mara Janowitz, the daughter of Dr. Audrey Jane Woolrich and C. Michael Janowitz, both of Manhattan, was married April 9 to Jonathan Cooper Widder, the son of Barbara Cooper Widder and Kenneth H. Widder of Pleasantville, N.Y. Rabbi Robert Weiner officiated at the Roundhouse, a hotel in Beacon, N.Y.

headline: Mariloly Orozco and Michael Casas: A Roadside Attraction
abstract: Two Cornell students were brought together by a car stuck on the side of a road.
lead_paragraph: Mariloly Orozco and Michael Edward Casas were married April 9 at Epiphany Catholic Church in Coral Gables, Fla. Msgr. Jude O’Doherty, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony with the Rev. Nicholas Monco, also a Catholic priest and a cousin of the groom, taking part.

headline: Chloe Leavitt, Michael Fabiani
abstract: The bride graduated from the University of Michigan. The groom graduated from Tufts and Brooklyn Law School.
lead_paragraph: Chloe Gabrielle Leavitt, a daughter of Lauren L. Leavitt and Todd P. Leavitt of Santa Monica, Calif., is to be married April 10 to Michael S. Fabiani, a son of Marcy Sonneborn Fabiani and John V. Fabiani of White Plains. Rabbi Gordon Tucker is to officiate at Belmond El Encanto, a hotel in Santa Barbara, Calif.

headline: Jefferson McCarley, Gary Keener
abstract: The couple met in 2011 in Black Rock City, a temporary community erected for the Burning Man festival in Nevada.
lead_paragraph: Jefferson Scott McCarley and Gary Allan Keener were married April 7 at San Francisco City Hall. Thomas M. Reardon, a judge of the Alameda County Superior Court, officiated.

headline: Oladele Akinsiku, Abayomi Fabunmi
abstract: The bride is an internal medicine resident, the groom is an ophthalmology resident.
lead_paragraph: Oladele Sara Akinsiku and Abayomi Emmanuel Fabunmi were married April 9 at the Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Gainesville, Fla. The Rev. George Holston, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Christina Sumpio, Demian von Poelnitz
abstract: The couple met at the College of William & Mary, from which each received a law degree.
lead_paragraph: Christina Marie Sumpio and Demian Hieronymus Christoph Freiherr von Poelnitz were married April 9 at St. Patrick’s Cathedral in New York. Msgr. Robert T. Ritchie performed the ceremony.

headline: Jennings Culver, Ross Cameron
abstract: The couple was introduced in 2010 by a mutual friend at a Sunday brunch in New York.
lead_paragraph: Jennings Lee Culver, a daughter of Susan Chase Culver and Edward H. Culver Jr. of Wayland, Mass., was married April 9 to Ross Edward Kies Cameron, a son of Lynne H. Cameron and Peter B. Cameron of Reading, Mass. The Rev. S. Marshall Huey Jr., an Anglican priest, officiated at Lowndes Grove Plantation in Charleston, S.C., a historic site now used as an event space.
