abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, April 10, 2016.
lead_paragraph: SPORTS

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 10, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Mr. Hastert acknowledges that as a young man, he committed transgressions for which he is profoundly sorry.”

headline: Pacquiao Defeats Bradley by Decision, and Says Farewell to His Sport
abstract: It was clear that Manny Pacquiao’s illustrious career was winding down, but he delivered a victory by a unanimous decision.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Manny Pacquiao made a name for himself with a delicious mix of ferocious punching power and shifty speed.

headline: Fireworks Disaster at Kerala Temple Kills 106 in South India
abstract: A fireworks display during a religious festival set off a series of explosions, leveling buildings and injuring 383 people.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — A series of explosions early Sunday caused by a fireworks display during a religious festival at a temple left 106 people dead and hundreds more injured in the southern Indian state of Kerala, the local authorities said.

headline: Revelation on Brussels Attackers Fuels Fears of New Assaults
abstract: News that militants in Belgium had planned to strike in France was a reminder that much is still unknown about the Islamic State’s networks in Europe.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The announcement on Sunday that the plotters of last month’s Brussels terror attacks had originally intended to hit Paris again only heightened the concern among police and intelligence agencies that shadowy Islamic State networks could unleash new attacks at any time, not only in France and Belgium but in other European capitals.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing: Masters Tournament, Bernie Sanders, Pope Francis
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: 1941: Roosevelt Takes Steps to Head Off Hitler
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Greenland is placed under the protection of the United States in 1941.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a bold move to keep the Nazis out of the Danish colony of Greenland, President Roosevelt announced today that Greenland, the world’s largest island, had been placed formally under the protection of the United States government, which will establish air bases, naval facilities and other fortifications there as part of the system to protect the whole Western Hemisphere against invasion.

headline: 18 Philippine Soldiers Killed in Firefight With Militant Group
abstract: The 10-hour gun battle took place on the southwestern island of Basilan, the Philippines, and left more than 50 soldiers wounded, military officials said.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — At least 18 soldiers were killed and more than 50 wounded in a gun battle in the southern Philippines between government forces and the militant group Abu Sayyaf, military officials said Sunday.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: 1966: U.N. Authorizes Blockade of Rhodesia Oil
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Security Council authorizes Britain to blockade tankers carrying oil for Rhodesia in 1966.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS, New York — The Security Council last night [Apr. 10] authorized Britain to enforce a blockade against tankers carrying oil to Beira for pipelining to Rhodesia. Britain promptly took advantage of the authorization to board the tanker Manuela and divert it from Beira. The Security Council vote was 10-0.

headline: Before Dating Apps, There Was Lincoln Center
abstract: Walking through Lincoln Center, a man recalled his many dates there, including with his future wife, without the need for Tinder.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Despite Risks, G.O.P. Seeks to Stop Trump Before Convention
abstract: The rules and credentials committees can thwart Donald J. Trump, and the temptation to do so will be great, despite the havoc he could wreak.
lead_paragraph: When House Speaker Paul D. Ryan released a video laying out his familiar theme that politics should be fought on ideas and issues, the Drudge Report’s headline was: “Paul Ryan launches his first campaign ad.”

headline: Capturing, and Changing, the Breezes Blowing Through New York
abstract: Blaring sirens and car horns may punctuate the soundtrack of the city’s daily life, but one artist has designs on a far more ethereal noise: the one made by the wind in a Manhattan park.
lead_paragraph: In the last few weeks, 10 of the cast-iron lampposts in Madison Square Park in Manhattan have grown a bit taller. Micah Silver was responsible. He is the one who put the little thingamajigs on them, on the tippy-tops. The finials, to those in the know.

headline: Pint-Size Crystal Dunn Reaches New Heights With U.S. Soccer
abstract: Dunn, the last U.S. player cut before last year’s World Cup, has become a prolific scorer and looks like a lock to play in the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: In the 72nd minute of an exhibition game against England last month in Tampa, Fla., Crystal Dunn executed a sublime spin on the left side of the box, making her defender look as if she were clamped to the Raymond James Stadium grass.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Clear out the refrigerator for spring cleaning, and try your hand at stuffed calamari.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: On the Trail: The Week of April 3
abstract: The Wisconsin primary, and then the campaign descended on New York.
lead_paragraph: The Wisconsin primary, and then the campaign descended on New York.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
abstract: “The Girlfriend Experience” explores the concept of valuelessness. President Obama appears on “Fox News Sunday.” And “Togetherness” comes to an end.
lead_paragraph: “The Girlfriend Experience,” loosely based on the 2009 Steven Soderbergh film, explores the concept of valuelessness. President Obama appears on “Fox News Sunday” for the first time since he was elected to the White House. And “Togetherness” comes to an end.

headline: Review: In ‘Dice,’ Andrew Dice Clay Plays a Character He Knows Like Himself
abstract: In this Showtime series, Andrew Dice Clay joins the not-quite-me brand of television.
lead_paragraph: Note to whoever has custody of the red flag that is raised whenever a once-fresh television idea is in danger of being run into the ground: Another past-his-prime figure has turned up playing a fictional version of himself.

headline: Obama Says Hillary Clinton Wouldn’t Intentionally Endanger U.S. With Emails
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'E-Mail', 'E-Mail']
abstract: In his first interview with “Fox News Sunday” as president, Mr. Obama also said his administration would not interfere with the F.B.I.’s investigation of her private email server.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama said in an interview broadcast on Sunday that while Hillary Clinton had been careless in managing her emails as secretary of state, she would never intentionally do anything to endanger the country.

headline: Will Smith, Ex-Saints Player, Is Fatally Shot in New Orleans
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Football', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Smith, 34, was shot multiple times during a confrontation after the vehicle he was traveling in was rear-ended, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Will Smith, a former defensive end for the New Orleans Saints who played on their Super Bowl championship team in 2009-10, was shot and killed in New Orleans late Saturday, the authorities said.

headline: Billing by Millionths of Pennies, Cloud Computing’s Giants Take In Billions
abstract: This economics of tiny things demonstrates the global power of the few companies, including Amazon, Microsoft and Google, that can make fortunes from the small.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Imagine building an enormous beach resort, maybe the best in the world. Instead of renting the rooms, you charge guests based on the grains of sand they touch. You charge very little per grain, but if they lie on enough of them, it adds up.

headline: Murder Trial Plumbs Gang Violence, Adding to a Family’s Pain
abstract: After a Harlem family lost their daughter to a gang member’s bullet, they advocated to alleviate the violence. Then their son was charged in a gang killing.
lead_paragraph: In the Grant Houses, a public-housing project in West Harlem, he was known simply as Bam, short for the superstrong cartoon baby Bamm-Bamm in “The Flintstones.” He had a reputation as a fierce street fighter. At 15, he posted a video in which he knocks a man out cold in a hallway.

headline: Powerful Earthquake Strikes Pakistan, India and Afghanistan
abstract: There were no immediate reports of widespread damage from the quake, which shook buildings and houses and caused panic in several cities.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — A powerful earthquake rattled parts of Pakistan, India and Afghanistan on Sunday, shaking buildings and houses and causing panic in several cities.

headline: Arseniy Yatsenyuk, Ukraine’s Premier, Quits Amid Splits in Post-Revolution Alliance
abstract: Mr. Yatsenyuk, who came to power behind the Maidan street protests two years ago, announced he would step down.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk, the prime minister of Ukraine, announced his resignation on Sunday in a surprise move that opened a new period of political uncertainty here.

headline: Melissa McCarthy Is ‘The Boss’ at the North American Box Office
abstract: The comedian’s latest film edged out “Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice” with moviegoers.
lead_paragraph: Melissa McCarthy succeeded at the box office in “The Boss,” but just barely, with opening-weekend ticket sales for her latest vehicle on the low end of prerelease analyst expectations and audiences giving the film a C-plus grade in CinemaScore exit polls.

headline: Hillary Clinton Defends Bill Clinton on Criminal Justice
abstract: Hillary Clinton defended her husband, former President Bill Clinton, and his record on criminal justice, but said that if she was elected she would work to reduce unnecessary incarcerations.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton on Sunday played down the clash that her husband, former President Bill Clinton, had with protesters who criticized his record on criminal justice at a campaign event last week and said that if she was elected she would work to reduce unnecessary incarcerations.

headline: Gridlocked Jakarta Becomes Even Worse, at Least for a Week
keywords: ['Roads and Traffic', 'Commuting', 'Child Labor', 'Children and Childhood', 'Urban Areas', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The governor of Jakarta temporarily suspended its “three-in-one” car-pool system in part because it exploits children.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Even on the best of days, it looks like an invasion, though a very slow one: Troops of motorbikes, like a disorganized cavalry, try to slice through enormous, honking lines of buses, trucks, private cars and taxis that are locked in a crawling war of attrition on sclerotic highways and roads.

headline: Macedonian Police Use Tear Gas to Stop Migrants at Border
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Tear Gas', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Hundreds of migrants who tried to break through a border fence in a northern Greek town were dispersed with tear gas and rubber bullets.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — The Macedonian police used tear gas and rubber bullets on Sunday to disperse hundreds of migrants who tried to break through a border fence in a large refugee camp in the northern Greek town of Idomeni. It was the latest in a series of increasingly frequent uprisings by migrants stuck in Greece after countries sealed the main route they had been using to get to Germany.

headline: Bernie Sanders Says ‘Something Is Clearly Lacking’ in Hillary Clinton’s Judgment
abstract: Mr. Sanders continued his squabble with Mrs. Clinton over her qualifications to be president on Sunday, saying “I have my doubts about what kind of president she would make.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont continued his squabble with Hillary Clinton over her qualifications to be president on Sunday, saying “something is clearly lacking” in Mrs. Clinton’s judgment.

headline: In Minefield of Gifts, Some Police Leaders Tread More Lightly Than Others
keywords: ['Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Gifts to Public Officials']
abstract: Current and former New York Police Department precinct commanders describe cases in which they struggled to discern between acceptable and unacceptable gifts.
lead_paragraph: “Everybody wants to give you a plaque.”

headline: Donald Trump Aide Accuses Ted Cruz’s Campaign of ‘Gestapo’ Tactics
abstract: Mr. Trump’s new convention manager accused Mr. Cruz’s campaign on Sunday of employing “Gestapo” delegate-wrangling tactics.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s new convention manager accused Senator Ted Cruz’s campaign on Sunday of employing “Gestapo” delegate-wrangling tactics and said Mr. Trump still had several paths to winning the nomination before the July convention.

headline: Cheesecake and Turnstiles: Hillary Clinton’s New York Weekend
abstract: Hillary Clinton tried to highlight her New York City credentials this weekend before next week’s primary in her home state.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton tried to highlight her New York City credentials this weekend, bouncing from shaking hands at Junior’s Cheesecake in Brooklyn to holding a rally in the borough’s Sunset Park neighborhood and making a cameo at a black-tie roast with the city’s voracious press corps.

headline: Twyla Tharp to Present New Work at the Joyce Theater
abstract: The untitled work will be part of Twyla Tharp Dance’s season in July at the Joyce Theater, where Ms. Tharp, 74, is the artist in residence.
lead_paragraph: Less than a year after taking two new dances on tour for her career’s 50th anniversary, the restless choreographer Twyla Tharp is back to present her latest work: a dramatic piece set to a late Beethoven quartet.

headline: Bernie Sanders Did Not Disappoint at Coney Island
abstract: The Vermont senator arrived at Nathan’s Famous Sunday afternoon and spoke to supporters, took photos and indulged his appetite.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders came to Coney Island Sunday afternoon and did what 99 percent of people might have expected: He ate a hotdog at Nathan’s.

headline: At Paramount Pictures, the Family Tree Is Still Growing
abstract: It might be easier to trace the genealogy of an alley cat than of the typical Hollywood studio: Over the last century or so, most have accumulated a tangled list of owners and corporate forebears — and none more so than Paramount Pictures.
lead_paragraph: It might be easier to trace the genealogy of an alley cat than of the typical Hollywood studio: Over the last century or so, most have accumulated a tangled list of owners and corporate forebears — and none more so than Paramount Pictures.

headline: Matt Harvey and Mets Search for Answers During Uninspiring Homestand
abstract: Matt Harvey was the losing pitcher for the second time this young season, and Philadelphia’s pitchers held the struggling Mets lineup in check.
lead_paragraph: Fashionably, the Mets recalled 1986, wearing throwback jerseys on Sunday at Citi Field. Athletically, they more closely evoked their pre-trade-deadline 2015 incarnation, when runs were at a premium.

headline: Review: From Tease to Payback, ‘Skin Me’ Examines the Politics of Touch
abstract: Viktoria Danyi, Csaba Molnar and Zsofia Tamara Vadas’s dance program at Abrons Arts Center combines teasing, manipulation and payback.
lead_paragraph: Three dancers — two women and one man — scurry around the stage, circling one another and periodically striking poses. So far, so ordinary, except for their transitory points of contact: a hand on a breast, a face in a crotch. This touching of private parts receives no special emphasis, but it does escalate, along with everything else, until the three bodies join in a promiscuous pile.

headline: Uncertain Future, for Manny Pacquiao and Boxing
abstract: The boxing world has plenty to look forward to even if Pacquiao follows through on his promise to retire. But new stars have yet to show they have his marketability.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — He had stuck well to the script all night.

headline: Review: New Jersey Symphony Orchestra Gives Xian Zhang a Handy Introduction
abstract: Ms. Zhang, who will become the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra’s music director in September, led the ensemble on Friday in works by Tchaikovsky and Barber.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra began its concert on Friday at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center here by tuning, as usual, to a common A. But there was one other thing that needed fine-tuning before the performance, of music by Tchaikovsky and Barber, could begin: the audience’s intonation and diction.

headline: Review: ‘Six Characters (A Family Album)’ Excavates Past and Present, Inspired by Pirandello
abstract: This play, an investigation of family, creativity and home, takes its main inspiration from Luigi Pirandello’s “Six Characters in Search of an Author.”
lead_paragraph: Theodora Skipitares’s 25th play, “Six Characters (A Family Album),” a puppet-filled multimedia investigation of family, creativity and home, takes its main inspiration from Luigi Pirandello’s “Six Characters in Search of an Author.” But his orphaned little troupe has a lot of company onstage at La MaMa’s Ellen Stewart Theater.

headline: John Kasich and Ted Cruz Hunt for Votes in Upstate New York
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Donald J. Trump leads in polls ahead of the April 19 primary, but upstate demographics may offer his rivals a slight opening.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER, N.Y. — Gov. John Kasich’s first visit to upstate New York last week was moved twice to accommodate a crowd larger than anticipated.

headline: Review: Jason Jones Offers Clues to Bad Parenting on the Road in ‘The Detour’
abstract: In Mr. Jones’s new TBS comedy series, parents talk and behave inappropriately in front of their children, again and again.
lead_paragraph: “The Detour,” which begins Monday night on TBS, is a comedy for people who find one particular spectacle funny: parents talking and behaving inappropriately in front of their young children. It’s a joke that can be told a thousand different ways — Mom and Dad explain oral sex too graphically, Mom lectures about alcohol while drinking some, and so on — but it’s essentially the same punch line.

headline: Review: At Carnegie Hall, Brahms Piano Quartets, With a New Baby as a Coda
abstract: Leif Ove Andsnes, Tabea Zimmerman and Clemens Hagen were joined by James Ehnes on violin for a program after Christian Teztlaff was called to Germany.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes troubling events cause an artist to withdraw from a performance at the last minute. But last week the superb violinist Christian Tetzlaff pulled out of an important concert at Carnegie Hall for a “very happy reason,” as the pianist Leif Ove Andsnes, the violinist’s good friend and frequent collaborator, put it on his website.

headline: Review: Sarasota Ballet Blends Oddity and Englishness in a Double Bill
abstract: The company, in its 25th anniversary season, marvelously staged and danced Ashton’s “Enigma Variations” and Balanchine’s “Stars and Stripes.”
lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. — Florida has two excellent and endearing ballet companies that both visit New York this year as part of anniversary celebrations. Miami City Ballet — 30 years old and always one of America’s foremost exponents of the ballets of the Russian-American choreographer George Balanchine — opens at the David H. Koch Theater this week. Sarasota Ballet, which visits the Joyce Theater in August and has become an exemplary exponent of the ballets of Balanchine’s British contemporary Frederick Ashton, reached the climax of its 25th anniversary season this weekend with a double bill of the most English of all ballets, Ashton’s “Enigma Variations,” and the most American of all ballets, Balanchine’s “Stars and Stripes.”

headline: David Cameron Releases Tax Data After Panama Papers Uproar
abstract: Mr. Cameron, the British prime minister, admitted that he had bungled his response to questions about his inheritance from his father, who had an offshore investment company.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, admitting that he had made a mess of responding to questions about his inheritance from his father, who had an investment company offshore, on Sunday released information from his tax returns for the past six years.

headline: Pushing Myanmar Toward Full Democracy
abstract: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi’s challenge now is to bring about full civilian governance.
lead_paragraph: It has been a long, hard road, but Daw Aung San Suu Kyi is finally set to assume the role of Myanmar’s top civilian leader. Her National League for Democracy party won a landslide victory last November in the country’s first free election in a quarter century. But a provision in Myanmar’s military-drafted Constitution barred Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi, a Nobel Peace Prize laureate, from becoming president because her children are British citizens.

headline: Review: In ‘Hunters,’ Another Hero Roots Out Planetary Aliens in Our Midst
abstract: This earnest new Syfy series imagines the government has an Exo-Terrorism Unit, battling the malevolent fake humans in our midst. No one’s having fun.
lead_paragraph: Apparently the extraterrestrials-among-us problem is bigger than just one secret government agency can handle. The “Men in Black” people have been grappling with it for years, but on Monday night Syfy gives us the Exo-Terrorism Unit, which also has been battling the malevolent fake humans in our midst.

headline: Israel’s Unsung Protector: Obama
abstract: Of the last nine presidents, Obama is the only one who has completely shielded Israel from Security Council resolutions.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With the Obama administration in its final year, several officials have said that the president has grown so frustrated with trying to revive Middle East peace talks that he may lay down his own outline for an Israeli-Palestinian two-state peace agreement, in the form of a resolution in the United Nations Security Council.

headline: A Roomful of Funny Women, Bonding Over the New York Comedy Life
abstract: The idea was simple but novel: Take one picture of as many women in New York City’s varied comedy scenes as possible.
lead_paragraph: The idea was simple but novel: Take one picture of as many women in New York City’s varied comedy scenes as possible.

headline: Phylicia Rashad, Finding Joy in Tribulations of Her Role in ‘Head of Passes’
abstract: Ms. Rashad says the effort needed to portray the matriarch in this Tarell Alvin McCraney play leaves her “a little buoyant, to tell you the truth.”
lead_paragraph: Phylicia Rashad was hoping for Medea. Instead, she found Shelah.

headline: Review: ‘The Vanishing Velázquez’ Tells of Art Obsession
abstract: Laura Cumming’s book shows how a 19th-century bookseller let his infatuation with an artwork take over his life.
lead_paragraph: In 1845, a humble English bookseller named John Snare purchased a painting of King Charles I at an auction for 8 pounds, roughly the same cost as a horse. The painter was identified as Van Dyck, but Snare, with an art lover’s instincts and an autodidact’s ravenous literacy, was certain it was painted by Diego Velázquez. He became besotted with it in the way a monarch does his mistress. The difference is that this love affair lasted decades. Also, it destroyed his life.

headline: Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton Hold Strong Leads in New York and Pennsylvania
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton have struggled during a recent stretch of primary contests, but big wins could be in store for both candidates in New York and Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton have struggled during a recent stretch of primary contests, but big wins could be in store for both candidates in New York and Pennsylvania, according to two surveys released on Sunday that show them holding wide leads.

headline: Remembering Kitty
abstract: More than 50 years after the murder of Kitty Genovese became a symbol of urban apathy, her partner, Mary Ann Zielonko, remembers Kitty’s life and impact.
lead_paragraph: More than 50 years after the murder of Kitty Genovese became a symbol of urban apathy, her partner, Mary Ann Zielonko, remembers Kitty’s life and impact.

headline: Remembering Kitty Genovese
abstract: More than 50 years after the murder of Kitty Genovese became a symbol of urban apathy, her story still resonates, emerging again with her killer’s death.
lead_paragraph: In death, Kitty Genovese has cast a long shadow over America’s psyche, far more than she probably would have had her life not been brutally cut short at age 28. Across the decades since her murder in 1964, she has endured as a symbol of urban disconnection and apathy, a victim not only of a knife-wielding killer but of bystanders’ unwillingness to get involved in resisting evil.

headline: Keeps For Oneself
abstract: There really are 77 clues in this puzzle by Ron Toth and Zhouqin Burnikel. Go figure.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — As a public service to those of us still raising children, I’d like to pose a question: Why is it that when you do laundry that involves the clothing of small human beings, what comes out of the washing machine is often less about the clothing and more about wads of disintegrated paper, rocks, small toys, melted candy and other trinkets?

headline: Carli Lloyd: Why I’m Fighting for Equal Pay
abstract: A co-captain of the United States women’s national team writes about why she and four teammates filed a wage-discrimination complaint against U.S. Soccer.
lead_paragraph: I’ve worn a U.S. Soccer uniform for 12 years and have done so proudly. I’ve had some of the greatest moments of my life — winning two Olympic gold medals and the 2015 Women’s World Cup — wearing that uniform. So when I joined four teammates in filing a wage-discrimination complaint against U.S. Soccer late last month, it had nothing to do with how much I love to play for my country.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of April 11
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Danny Willett Wins Masters as Jordan Spieth Folds
abstract: Willett, a 28-year-old Englishman, took advantage of missteps by Spieth, who would have been the first player to repeat as champion since Tiger Woods in 2002.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — After 63 holes of the 80th Masters, Jordan Spieth was five strokes clear of the field. The last nine holes at Augusta National lay before him like a lush green carpet in a coronation ceremony.

headline: Michelle Obama’s Graduation Speeches Show Her Personal Side
abstract: The first lady has become more outspoken on issues like race, gender and class, and plans to expand on those themes in commencement addresses in the coming months.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michelle Obama, stung by criticism during her husband’s first campaign that she was too outspoken, arrived at the White House and took on a careful role promoting health and fitness as “Mom in Chief.’’ In the seven years since, she has slowly shed that early reticence and has been more forceful about issues of race, gender and class.

headline: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 2
abstract: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times weigh in on the contenders for the 142nd running of the Kentucky Derby.
lead_paragraph: Top contenders for the 142nd running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of preference, with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Churchill Downs has adopted a points system to determine the Derby field, with points being earned by the top four finishers in designated prep races. The odds are from the Churchill Downs futures pool, and the records are starts-win-place-show. An article on Saturday’s Santa Anita Derby, Wood Memorial and Bluegrass Stakes can be found here.

headline: Republicans Hijack an Election Agency
abstract: Instead of making it easier to vote, conservative ideologues unilaterally reversed longstanding policy to block voters from registering.
lead_paragraph: For 10 years, the Election Assistance Commission, the bipartisan federal agency created after the 2000 election debacle to help make voting easier and more standardized, has made it clear that prospective voters do not need to prove that they are American citizens before they may register.

headline: For Staff on ‘Naked and Afraid,’ Work Is Just a Blur
abstract: To make the Discovery Channel reality show suitable for family television viewing, five full-time visual effects artists labor behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: SHERMAN OAKS, Calif. — At first blush, it is a perfectly normal modern production office: standing desks, an indoor putting green, a casual dress code. There is a Whole Foods right around the corner.

headline: Paul Ryan, a Mirage Candidate, Wages a Parallel Campaign
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: The speaker of the House is already deep into a national campaign — one he calls “Confident America” — but it is not necessarily aimed at the presidency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Republican candidates for the White House battled in Wisconsin last week, Speaker Paul D. Ryan was conspicuously absent from his home state — but he was very much on the political stage.

headline: Behind Fake Degrees From Pakistan, a Maze of Deceit and a Case in Peril
abstract: Nearly a year after Axact, a software company, was accused of selling phony Internet diplomas, investigators have uncovered evidence of more fraud and the lead prosecutor has quit.
lead_paragraph: In the year since Pakistani investigators raided Axact, a Karachi-based software company accused of raking in hundreds of millions of dollars with a vast Internet degree scam, Pakistani and American investigators have been busy dismantling its operations.

headline: G.M. Begins Prevailing in Lawsuits Over Faulty Ignition Switches
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: After spending more than $2 billion settling claims, General Motors has started winning lawsuits related to the gravest safety crisis in its history.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — After two years of heavy legal and financial consequences, General Motors has finally turned the tide and started winning lawsuits related to the gravest safety crisis in its history.

headline: Spring Has Arrived, but the Yankees May Beg to Differ
abstract: Blustery weather ranging from snow to hail to rain scuttled a nationally televised game against the Tigers in Detroit.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — If the conditions the previous two days were not inhospitable enough for the Yankees, hovering around freezing with blasts of Arctic air, they awoke Sunday morning to snowflakes fluttering down from the gray skies. The weather warmed enough so that the snow turned to hail and then to rain, but it was miserable enough for long enough that their nationally televised game against the Detroit Tigers was postponed about four hours before the scheduled first pitch.

headline: Egypt Gives Saudi Arabia 2 Islands in a Show of Gratitude
abstract: The government of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi returned two islands in the Red Sea to King Salman of Saudi Arabia in recognition of his support.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Since King Salman of Saudi Arabia arrived in Cairo on Thursday for a five-day visit, the leader of the oil-rich kingdom has lavished his Egyptian allies with promises of aid and investment.

headline: Panama Papers Leak Signals a Shift in Mainstream Journalism

He was 83.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ and History: Are They in Sync?

More than one scholar has marveled at the show’s detailed presentation of the founding period’s complicated politics — not to mention the way Mr. Miranda’s dazzling rap lyrics pull off rhymes like “line of credit” and “financial diuretic.”

lead_paragraph: In the 10 years since he tested positive for H.I.V., David Goode has grown weary of the stigma and the ostracism that have accompanied his diagnosis. Among the most searing rejections were those from landlords and realtors, who told him time and again they would not accept rental subsidies from New York City’s H.I.V./AIDS Services Administration, in violation of city and state law.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 1 Finale Recap: A Wendy, Scorned
abstract: The first season of “Billions” has been a bare-knuckled brawl fought by men with manicured hands.
lead_paragraph: Francis Ford Coppola’s “The Conversation” ends with Harry Caul, the surveillance agent played by Gene Hackman, blowing his saxophone amid the wreckage of his own guilt and paranoia. He’s made a vocation out of inserting himself into other people’s lives — he’s the best at it, in fact — but now, the wall he’d so carefully maintained between the personal and the professional has been irrevocably breached. He took action intended to prevent a tragedy, but wound up duped by more powerful forces, who had turned the tools of his trade against him. And now, he’s torn through the walls and floorboards of his own apartment, searching for a bug that may or may not exist. He’ll never know for sure.

headline: Can Liberals Frack?
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Shale']
abstract: The American shale revolution has advanced three progressive causes.
lead_paragraph: AS the Democratic presidential campaign comes to New York, the candidates are competing to dance on the grave of fracking, even though the oil and gas extraction technique of hydraulic fracturing has been banned in the state since 2014. The anti-fracking rhetoric seems to be rooted in the assumption that liberalism is as inherently antithetical to fracking as it is, say, to the Defense of Marriage Act — or monarchy. That assumption, however, does a disservice to liberals’ claims to be on the side of empiricism and climate science.

headline: Philosophizing With Guns
abstract: Is it possible to learn freely in the presence of firearms? Fifty years after a massacre at our university, we are going to find out.
lead_paragraph: In a matter of months, the offices, libraries and classrooms where I work, study and teach at the University of Texas at Austin will become “concealed carry zones” — areas in which people with concealed handgun licenses may carry their weapons. The “campus carry” bill that brought about this situation represents a 50th anniversary gift of sorts from Texas state legislators. For when the law comes into effect on August 1, it will be 50 years to the day since a heavily armed young man ascended the clock tower on campus and shot 45 people, killing 14 of them, in the first mass shooting at an American college.

headline: These Two Guys Are Changing How We Think About Fashion
abstract: Alessandro Michele of Gucci and Demna Gvasalia of Balenciaga and Vetements are making clothes that capture the zeitgeist. T brought them together for the first time to have a little chat.
lead_paragraph: “RULE-BREAKING” IS A PHRASE thrown around in fashion a lot. But who makes these rules? And aren’t rules what fashion is based on? After all, fashion isn’t just the clothes on your back. ­It’s the form of those clothes at a given moment, adhering to certain codes that define them as forward-thinking, as now, as à la mode. Which often, as on a menu, translates simplistically to a lump of something fancy plopped on top of an existing offering, as opposed to tinkering about with the guts or really changing anything. Rules in fashion are made by the industry: the editors, the designers, the corporations who fund the whole thing. And so, genuine rule-breakers don’t come along that often. Fashion enjoys the status quo. It sells clothes, it makes money.
