headline: Fear of Crying: The Problem of Babies and Airplanes
abstract: Babies cry on planes because their ears hurt and they’re being made to stay in a certain position when they don’t want to or the air smells strange or they’re just plain cranky. As are we all.
lead_paragraph: First of all, nobody takes a small child on an airplane for the fun of it. I have been there and I know. Don’t get me wrong, I’m no airplane saint; you won’t generally catch me offering to hold someone else’s kid, or making friends around the seatback. I don’t usually admit to being a pediatrician, for fear of hearing a medical saga. But I have put in my time on airplanes with my own infants and toddlers and small children, and I certainly know how it feels.

headline: GE Capital’s Czech Business to Pursue I.P.O.
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: GE Money Bank will seek to list its shares in an initial public offering to institutional investors on the Prague Stock Exchange.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — GE Money Bank, a business of GE Capital in the Czech Republic, said on Monday that it planned to list its shares on the Prague Stock Exchange.

headline: Morning Agenda: How Valeant’s Missteps Derailed Female Viagra
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'News and News Media', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Daily Mail in Talks With Private Equity Firms for Yahoo Bid | Puerto Rico Rescue Bill Nearly Complete
lead_paragraph: HOW VALEANT’S MISSTEPS DERAILED FEMALE VIAGRA | In August, Sprout Phamaceuticals was flying high: It had finally received regulatory approval for its drug Addyi to treat low sex drive in women, and a day after the Food and Drug Administration approved the drug, Valeant Pharmaceuticals International bought Sprout for $1 billion, twice its value only two months earlier. But a series of missteps after the deal, combined with problems at Valeant that have depressed its stock by 85 percent, derailed what was once hailed as the “female Viagra,”  Katie Thomas and Gretchen Morgenson write in The New York Times.

headline: The Islamic State of Molenbeek
abstract: A district of Brussels had in effect seceded from Belgium. Europe must fight an ideological battle against Wahhabi Islam.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — There are military trucks parked in Molenbeek, and soldiers with submachine guns patrol the jittery streets of the Brussels district that has been the epicenter of European terrorism in recent months. On the Place Communale idle youths loiter, shooting glances at the police. This is where the Paris and Brussels attacks, with their 162 dead, overlap.

headline: Democracy Left Out in the Cold
abstract: Why is a fledgling democracy in Syria being left out of talks about the country’s future?
lead_paragraph: This week, United Nations talks meant to chart a path toward a peaceful, democratic future for Syria are set to resume in Geneva. But, in an absurd twist, the legitimate representatives of a large, democratically governed area in the country will not be invited to attend.

headline: Ted Cruz Sees Milk and Honey in Blue California
abstract: Nearly two months before the state’s primary on June 7, Senator Ted Cruz is heading west for two stops on Monday, holding rallies in Irvine and San Diego as most of the political class remains focused on a contest about 3,000 miles away.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has made clear his feelings about New York values. So he’s trying California.

headline: DeRay Mckesson Won’t Be Elected Mayor of Baltimore. So Why Is He Running?
abstract: A day with the most recognizable face of the Black Lives Matter movement.
lead_paragraph: DeRay Mckesson will not be the next mayor of Baltimore. He’s a 30-year-old with no experience in city government who registered less than 1 percent in a recent poll. He has no clear local support network and has been rejected by his most likely constituency — the city’s young black activists. At least one competing candidate has been embedded in Baltimore politics nearly as long as Mckesson has been alive.

headline: CaixaBank Set to Take Over Portugal’s BPI After Shareholder Drops Opposition
abstract: BPI said a deal had been reached between CaixaBank and Isabel dos Santos, the daughter of Angola’s longstanding president, after a yearlong dispute.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The Spanish lender CaixaBank is set to proceed with a takeover offer for BPI, a Portuguese bank, after reaching an 11th-hour agreement with an Angolan investor who had blocked its bid.

headline: Are Public Universities Neglecting In-State Students?
abstract: State schools are accepting more and more nonresidents to bridge budget gaps.

headline: The Obamacare Replacement Mirage
abstract: Republicans will never find it.
lead_paragraph: Hype springs eternal — certainly when it comes to Paul Ryan, whose media image as a Serious, Honest Conservative and policy wonk seems utterly impervious to repeated demonstrations that he is neither serious nor honest, and that he actually knows very little about policy. And here we go again.

headline: In California, Marijuana Is Smelling More Like Big Business
abstract: New rules are making it easier for cannabis farmers to operate, and voters are expected to legalize recreational use, drawing more commercial interest.
lead_paragraph: ADELANTO, Calif. — After decades of thriving in legally hazy backyards and basements, California’s most notorious crop, marijuana, is emerging from the underground into a decidedly capitalist era.

headline: Rural Water, Not City Smog, May Be China’s Pollution Nightmare
abstract: Over 80 percent of the water from underground wells across China’s plains is unfit for drinking because of contamination, according to statistics that alarmed many Chinese.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — More than 80 percent of the water from underground wells used by farms, factories and households across the heavily populated plains of China is unfit for drinking or bathing because of contamination from industry and farming, according to new statistics that were reported by Chinese media on Monday, raising new alarm about pollution in the world’s most populous country.

headline: Afghan ‘Sesame Street’ Introduces Zari, a Muppet and Role Model for Girls
abstract: The new character, a 6-year-old girl, will appear in the Afghan version of the children’s television show and address girls’ empowerment and health.
lead_paragraph: “Sesame Street” has introduced its first Afghan Muppet, and she has a mission. The hope is that the Muppet, called Zari, will become a strong role model for girls in a country with a poor record of promoting women’s rights, according to the production company Sesame Workshop.

headline: Howard Marks, Drug Smuggler Turned Author, Dies at 70
abstract: The Welshman wrote “Mr. Nice,” a best-selling autobiography, after his release from a United States prison.
lead_paragraph: Howard Marks, an Oxford-educated drug trafficker who at his peak in the 1970s controlled a substantial fraction of the world’s hashish and marijuana trade, and who became a best-selling author after his release from an American prison, died on Sunday. He was 70.

headline: Jordan Spieth Absorbs ‘a Tough One’ With Dignity
abstract: As the defending champion at the Masters, Spieth had to brave the trophy and jacket ceremonies and then answer questions, right after his collapse allowed Danny Willett to win.
lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — “More important than golf,” Jordan Spieth said Sunday night as a preamble to publicly congratulating the new Masters champion, Danny Willett. And with those words, Spieth showed that he would live to laugh about his Masters meltdown.

headline: 8 Taiwanese Are Deported to China After Trial in Kenya
abstract: Its Ministry of Foreign Affairs accused Beijing of blocking eight people from returning to Taiwan after they were deported to mainland China following a trial for fraud in Kenya.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The government of Taiwan criticized Beijing on Monday after eight people from the island were deported to mainland China following a trial for fraud in Kenya.

headline: The Incredible, Escalating Resort Game
abstract: Louis Vuitton is taking over a Rio art museum, Dior a palace and Gucci Westminster Abbey. Where could they go next?
lead_paragraph: The endless game of fashion show one-upmanship continues. On Sunday, Nicolas Ghesquière unveiled — via Instagram — the venue for the next Louis Vuitton Cruise show, to be held on May 28 outside Rio de Janeiro, in the run-up to the Olympics: the Niterói Contemporary Art Museum, designed by Oscar Niemeyer.

headline: Daily Mail Considering Bid for Yahoo Assets
abstract: The British tabloid newspaper and website confirmed that it had “very early stage” discussions with other buyers on a potential bid.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Daily Mail, a British tabloid newspaper and website, confirmed on Monday that it had discussed with other investors a potential bid for assets of Yahoo.

headline: Donald Trump and New York Tabloids Resume Their Elaborate Dance
abstract: For next week’s primary, Mr. Trump will return to the ink-stained caldron in which he and the media that he fed thrived in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: As New York City newspaper assignments go, this was a delicate one. Fly to Florida. Walk into Donald J. Trump’s hospital room. Witness the birth of his second daughter.

headline: The New Shape of Long Nails
abstract: After years of short and boyish manicures, women are growing their nails to make a fine point.
lead_paragraph: After years of short and boyish manicures, women are growing their nails to make a fine point.

headline: A Murder Taps Into Germany’s Conflicted Relations With Migrants
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The killing of a man by an Afghan migrant has left residents of a small town in the German heartland concerned about their community’s future.
lead_paragraph: CELLE, Germany — An immigrant from Iran, Mehdi Hushmand was a beloved high school science teacher known for his devotion, and for going out of his way to help settle some of Germany’s newer immigrants — the more than one million migrants and refugees who arrived en masse last year.

headline: Intuit, a True Survivor, Relocates to the Cloud
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Cloud Computing', 'Software', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The company, famous for its personal finance and tax programs, has sold off its traditional software business and reinvented itself as an online service.
lead_paragraph: Intuit is still one of the tech industry’s best-known names. Famous for its personal finance and tax software, the Silicon Valley company rose to prominence more than three decades ago as one of the first and most popular makers of PC software.

headline: Marking Up Web Pages in Windows 10
abstract: Microsoft’s Edge browser comes with a tool that lets you scribble, highlight and make other notations on your personal copy of an open web page.
lead_paragraph: Q. I see that Windows 10 now lets you “write” on web pages. How does this work, and who can see what you’ve written?

headline: The Paradox of Finding Motivation Through Fear
abstract: Stepping outside your comfort zone can be scary, but also exciting. After all, what doesn’t kill you makes you stronger.
lead_paragraph: I was driving with a friend recently and telling him about some projects that really excited me. I mentioned a new book I’m working on, an article I’m writing and this new hobby of adventure motorcycling in the desert.

headline: Navy May Charge Officer With Giving China and Taiwan Secrets
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: Lt. Cmdr. Edward C. Lin has been under investigation on suspicion of providing secret information to China and Taiwan, United States officials said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Navy is weighing charges of espionage against an officer who is a naturalized American citizen and has been under investigation since last year on suspicion of providing secret information to China and Taiwan, United States officials said.

headline: Liqueur From Rhubarb
abstract: Once scarce, this amaro is now being imported.
lead_paragraph: Rhubarb seems like a good fit for an Italian-style bitter liqueur, or amaro, a category that has taken off at trendy bars. Back in 1845, Ettore Zucca, an Italian industrialist, made rhubarb amaro from a tincture his wife’s doctor concocted to cure her indigestion. In 1919, a descendant, Carlo Zucca, refined the recipe and bottled and sold the amaro. It became scarce but now has been revived and is being imported: Zucca Rabarbaro, $31.99 at the new Morton Williams Wine & Spirits, 270 Park Avenue South (21st Street), 212-477-5490, mortonwilliamswine.com.

headline: A Sweeter Frog for Passover
abstract: Marzipan in the shape of matzos and paradoxical references to the plagues.
lead_paragraph: Very sweet and very cute: Such are the marzipan frog pops made by the confectioner Dahlia Weinman. Her Passover assortments include 10-plagues pops and marzipan matzos in various shapes and sizes. The marzipan is made with only ground almonds and cane sugar, no corn syrup: Passover assortments, $15 to $38, marzipops.com.

headline: The Texture Is Delicate. The Flavor Is Bold.
abstract: Cookies From Spain With Cocoa, or Apple, or Lime
lead_paragraph: Delicate is the word that best describes these Spanish cookies. The flavors, however, are anything but. Rich cocoa balanced with a touch of salt, apple seasoned with cinnamon, and lime with bits of candied peel are some of them. All the ingredients are organic: Paul and Pippa Biscuits, $7 for 5.2 ounces ($6 each for six or more containers), marxpantry.com.

headline: A Cookbook That Educates as Well as Inspires
abstract: Recipes for leek fritters and lamb tagine, and explanations of Jewish food culture.
lead_paragraph: “The New Mediterranean Jewish Table” by Joyce Goldstein not only inspires you to cook, it also educates. She dismisses the notion that there are two styles of Jewish food, one Ashkenazi, from Eastern Europe, and another Sephardic, from southern Europe and the Middle East. It’s not so simple, she says. She parses more than 400 recipes from her own repertoire and other sources and discusses how Jewish food has changed. Passover recipe inspirations include leek fritters, Italian soup with chicken dumplings and a lamb tagine with raisins, almonds and honey: “The New Mediterranean Jewish Table” by Joyce Goldstein (University of California Press, $39.95).

headline: Matzo Overseen From Harvest Through Baking
abstract: Yiddish Farm grows wheat and spelt in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: There’s supermarket matzo, and then there’s shmura, or guarded matzo, which is often preferred by observant Jews for Passover and which is supervised at every step, from before harvest to the baking. A new, organic shmura matzo is made from wheat and spelt grown on a Yiddish Farm in Goshen, N.Y. Yisroel Bass, the founder and director of the nonprofit farm and learning center, cultivates the grain on 40 acres, mills the flour and takes it to a kosher bakery in nearby Kiryas Joel: Shmura Matzo, $39.99 a pound (about 8 pieces), $42.99 for spelt from organicpassover.com and $50 a pound at Eli’s Manhattan, Eli’s Vinegar Factory and Eli’s Bread and Pastry at Grand Central Market, elizabar.com.

headline: Wines From the Loire and a Respected Sommelier
abstract: 18 chenin blancs and a four-course menu at Racines NY.
lead_paragraph: Pascaline Lepeltier, one of New York’s star sommeliers, has been somewhat out of the picture since Rouge Tomate, her restaurant base of operations, closed in 2014 and has yet to reopen in its new location. But you can enjoy her expertise at a wine dinner at Racines NY that will feature 18 chenin blancs from the Loire. The vintages will take you from 1989 to 2014. The chef Frédéric Duca’s four-course menu will include monkfish with white asparagus and chicken with morels: Chenin blanc dinner, April 19, 7 p.m., $175, Racines NY, 94 Chambers Street (Church Street), 212-227-3400, info@racinesny.com, racinesny.com.

headline: Will the Fervor of Bernie Sanders’s Legions Endure?
abstract: Few of the senator’s varied supporters seem interested in coming together to form a more expansive movement.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — People with lip rings, dreadlocks and tattoos; multitudes of clean-cut types; longhaired men clutching copies of the Marxist magazine Socialist Appeal or the Sartre play “No Exit”; black women intrigued by college-debt relief; gay and transgender supporters; young women in burlappy wear normally seen in Bali; and at least one older guy who said that until recently he had been a Republican.

headline: David Cameron Questioned After Panama Papers Uproar
abstract: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain spoke in Parliament about measures to curb tax evasion after admitting last week that he had profited from an offshore account.

headline: Vassar’s Powerhouse Season to Include Taylor Mac
abstract: Taylor Mac, Josh Radnor and Santino Fontana will present new works this summer.
lead_paragraph: Before “Hamilton” and “Bright Star” arrived on Broadway, they made pit stops at Vassar College as part of its 2013 Powerhouse Theater season of works-in-progress, organized with New York Stage and Film. A host of new projects hope to follow their path at this year’s event, from June 24 to July 31, which features Taylor Mac, Josh Radnor and Santino Fontana.

headline: Donald Trump Calls Colorado’s Process for Choosing Delegates ‘Crooked’
abstract: Donald J. Trump insisted that the system for selecting delegates in Colorado was created by “hacks,” but his own team did not provide adequate resources or preparations with seasoned hands over many weeks for some of these state contests.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump on Monday criticized the system for selecting delegates in Colorado, where he was shut out last week, insisting that people in the state were “marching” and “going crazy” over a “crooked” system.

headline: Portuguese Supreme Court Upholds Extradition of C.I.A. Agent to Italy
abstract: Sabrina De Sousa has denied involvement in the kidnapping of an Egyptian cleric in 2003, which took place while she was working undercover as a diplomat in Milan.
lead_paragraph: The Portuguese Supreme Court has upheld a decision to extradite to Italy a former C.I.A. officer who was convicted in absentia in connection with the kidnapping of an Egyptian cleric in 2003, as the administration of George W. Bush ordered renditions after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

headline: As Oil Nations Consider a Freeze, Looking for Tensions to Thaw
abstract: All eyes will be on this weekend’s meeting of OPEC members and Russia, watching for signs that they can cooperate enough to exercise market discipline.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When officials from OPEC, Russia and some other oil-producing countries meet this weekend in Doha, Qatar, to discuss freezing petroleum production at current levels, the session’s significance might have more to do with style than substance.

headline: Job Discrimination Case Raises Questions of Transgender Rights in China
abstract: In what is being described as the nation’s first such case, Mr. C, who was born a woman, said his former employer fired him for wearing men’s clothes.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A labor arbitration panel in the southern province of Guizhou held a hearing on Monday in what is being described as China’s first transgender job discrimination case. A ruling is expected this month in the case, brought by a man born a woman, who said his former employer fired him for wearing men’s clothes.

headline: Social Support of Marriage May Improve Cancer Survival
abstract: It may largely be the emotional support of marriage, rather than any economic advantages, that produces health benefits.
lead_paragraph: Several studies have found that being married improves survival in cancer patients. Now a new study suggests that it may largely be the social and emotional support of marriage, rather than any economic advantages, that produces the effect.

headline: People Who Avoided Illness Could Be Key in Treating Those Who Didn’t
abstract: Scientists hope to find answers in the DNA of people who have a mutated gene that should have made them ill or killed them, but did not.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere in the world are 13 incredibly lucky people. Although they do not know it, each inherited a mutated gene that causes a fatal or terribly debilitating disease in infancy or childhood — but these people are adults, and healthy.

headline: Scientists Unveil New ‘Tree of Life’
abstract: Most of the diversity outlined on the new tree has been hiding in plain sight.
lead_paragraph: A team of scientists unveiled a new tree of life on Monday, a diagram outlining the evolution of all living things. The researchers found that bacteria make up most of life’s branches. And they found that much of that diversity has been waiting in plain sight to be discovered, dwelling in river mud and meadow soils.

headline: Sesame Extends Its Sweet Reach Beyond the Middle East
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Nuts', 'Sesame Seeds', 'Desserts']
abstract: Tahini and halvah are refined and reborn in ice cream, doughnuts and semifreddo.
lead_paragraph: When the chef Danielle Oron was growing up in the New Jersey suburbs, she knew that her Israeli family’s habits of dousing vanilla ice cream with tahini and spreading halvah on toast would be considered odd. Sesame was for cold Chinese noodles, bagels and not much else.

headline: Virgin America Fans Ask if Alaska Airlines Takeover Will Mean Loss of Cool
abstract: Virgin America’s fiercely loyal fans are asking if the service they love will remain the same under its new parent, Alaska Airlines.
lead_paragraph: For younger business travelers like Nicole Bansal, Virgin America’s mood lighting, customer service and technology have filled a niche not found on legacy airlines.

headline: Shushu/Tong’s Fall 2016 Collection
abstract: The year-old brand debuts its “Adult Baby” collection.
lead_paragraph: The year-old brand debuts its “Adult Baby” collection.

headline: Fashion Brand to Know: The Year-Old Label Inspired by ‘Adult Babies’
abstract: The designers Liushu “Shushu” Lei and Yutong “Tongtong” Jiang met in high school in Chengdu, China.
lead_paragraph: Liushu “Shushu” Lei and Yutong “Tongtong” Jiang, the designers behind the new women’s wear brand Shushu/Tong, cite the Japanese singer Kyary Pamyu Pamyu as one of their greatest inspirations. For the uninitiated, she’s a star of the colorful J-pop scene — cartoonish, lurid, hyper-cute.

headline: Some Like Them Hot. She Likes Them Homegrown.
abstract: Chiles are a passion for Annie Novak, a rooftop farmer in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Working at a farm in upstate New York after college, Annie Novak was startled to see people carrying vials of hot sauce like lucky charms. “It was winter,” she said. “They were putting drops in their hands and licking them to stay warm.”

headline: Sometimes Pain Is a Puzzle That Can’t Be Solved
abstract: Opioids? Stretching? Doctors have no easy answers for chronic discomfort, but the tide has shifted away from the idea of removing all pain.
lead_paragraph: My elbow is killing me.

headline: Canadian Pacific Ends Bid for Norfolk Southern
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Facing opposition from its target and regulators, Canadian Pacific withdrew a resolution for Norfolk Southern shareholders to vote on merger talks.
lead_paragraph: After five months of pressure, three merger offers and one rejection from regulators, Canadian Pacific Railway said on Monday that it had abandoned efforts to combine with its American railroad counterpart Norfolk Southern.

headline: Ed Snider, Flyers Owner Who Made Philadelphia a Hockey Town, Dies at 83
abstract: In 1967, Mr. Snider and his partners introduced hockey to Philadelphia. Soon the Flyers turned the City of Brotherly Love into a town that loved bare-knuckle fights on the ice.
lead_paragraph: Ed Snider, who co-founded the Philadelphia Flyers of the National Hockey League and owned the team for nearly 50 years, and who was chairman of a sports management company that provided services to hundreds of arenas, stadiums and convention centers in North America, died on Monday at his home in Montecito, Calif. He was 83.

headline: Common Application Saturates the College Admissions Market, Critics Say
abstract: After a student was accepted to all the Ivy League schools, not everyone was cheering. Some say the Common Application system distorts elite college admissions.
lead_paragraph: As the news rippled across the web last week that a Long Island student had won admission to all eight Ivy League universities, thousands of people reacted with messages of praise.

headline: Is the World’s Best Croissant Made in Australia?
abstract: In a climate-controlled glass cube in Melbourne, a former engineer creates superlative pastries.
lead_paragraph: Kate Reid, the founder of Melbourne’s Lune Croissanterie, studied aerospace engineering and spent several years working for a Formula One racing team before apprenticing at the famed Paris boulangerie Du Pain et des Idees. Her background in precision machines might help explain why she recently moved production of her ethereal, exceptionally flaky pastries to a climate-controlled glass cube that looks straight out of a James Bond film, inside a brick warehouse in the Fitzroy section of the city. Here, Reid and her brother Cameron hand-laminate, shape, proof and bake as many croissants, kouign-ammans and “cruffins” as their obsessive devotion to the craft will allow — about 3,000 a week, sold Thursday through Sunday.

headline: The Wedding Ring
abstract: Test your powers of prediction with this probability puzzle by math educator Sunil Singh.
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge was suggested by regular Numberplay contributor Sunil Singh, a math consultant with Scolab, a creative and effervescent educational technology laboratory based in Montreal. The puzzle is a seemingly simple question about a would-be bride. Is marriage in her near future? Let’s find out. Here’s Sunil:

headline: A New Zealand Penguin, Hard to Spot, Is Harder to Preserve
abstract: The shy yellow-eyed penguin, threatened by human endeavors, natural predators and hot weather, faces extinction despite conservation efforts.
lead_paragraph: DUNEDIN, New Zealand — Only a keen-eyed observer can spot the rare yellow-eyed penguin in the impenetrable forest hills that hug New Zealand’s South Island beaches.

headline: How a North Pole Chat with Readers Led to an Online Sustainability Quest
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Global Warming', 'Journalism Schools', 'News and News Media', 'Newspapers', 'Social Media']
abstract: How a reader Q&A during a reporting trip to the North Pole sea ice started a journalist’s journey into online inquiry on climate change and other “wicked” problems.
lead_paragraph: The editors who run Times Insider, which offers readers a look behind the journalism process, recently asked me to recount a bit of my journey from conventional news reporting to this Dot Earth blog. I launched Dot Earth in October, 2007, as a way to explore complex, prismatic questions that didn’t fit well into conventional news coverage. When I left the staff for Pace University, the blog moved to the Opinion section, but my prime mission remains the same: examining ways to smooth the human journey and make information matter in a noisy age.

headline: Wall Street Earnings: A Grim Quarter for Big Banks
abstract: It is shaping up to be another grim year for the nation’s biggest banks. They were hit hard by a bad environment for trading and deal-making.
lead_paragraph: It is shaping up to be another grim year for the nation’s biggest banks. They were hit hard by a bad environment for trading and deal-making.

headline: Brooklyn Condo Inspired by a Gas Station
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The liberal use of glass will give the building in brownstone Brooklyn an open feeling from street level.
lead_paragraph: Can a former gas station inspire the design for a new home? It sounds far-fetched, but to those who drew the blueprints for a new condominium in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, it did.

headline: Cook With Passion
abstract: Embrace the drama of Bach, and try some sesame-based desserts.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: In Settlement’s Fine Print, Goldman May Save $1 Billion
keywords: ['Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mortgages']
abstract: Goldman is the last of the big American banks to settle an inquiry into how Wall Street worsened the mortgage bubble and ensuing financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: State and federal officials said on Monday that Goldman Sachs would pay $5.1 billion to settle accusations of wrongdoing before the financial crisis.

headline: Rutgers Student Killed in Shooting Near Newark Campus
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The university’s Police Department said that the shooting was not random and that the downtown campus, which serves about 12,000 students, was not under threat.
lead_paragraph: A Rutgers University student was killed and his roommate, a recent graduate, was seriously injured in a shooting at their apartment near the school’s campus in Newark, the authorities said on Monday.

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 12 Afghan Army Recruits on Bus
abstract: At least 26 people were wounded in the attack by someone riding a three-wheel motorbike, the Afghan Defense Ministry said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber struck a bus of army recruits in eastern Afghanistan, killing at least 12 people and wounding dozens, officials said on Monday.

headline: Marine’s Death in a Secret Iraqi Base Reflects a Quietly Expanding U.S. Role
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)']
abstract: New information from U.S. military officials after the death of Staff Sgt. Louis F. Cardin also raised questions about President Obama’s pledge to keep troops out of combat there.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On a Saturday morning three weeks ago, American radar detected rockets headed for a secret fire base of about 100 Marines in northern Iraq.

headline: It’s Probably Not the Cat Eating Too Much Fat
abstract: Are animals susceptible to cholesterol problems?
lead_paragraph: Q. Are animals susceptible to cholesterol problems?

headline: Panama Papers Show How Lawyers Can Turn a Blind Eye
keywords: ['Legal Profession', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Lawyers can help their clients engage in questionable transactions while avoiding any direct involvement, which allows them to claim ignorance.
lead_paragraph: During the savings-and loan-crisis in the early 1990s, the question “Where were the lawyers?” was asked about the wrongdoing taking place at numerous banks.

headline: John Kasich Sees Path to Nomination Despite Low Delegate Count
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Mr. Kasich’s rationale is that savvy Republican convention delegates will be more receptive to his electability argument than rank-and-file voters.
lead_paragraph: He received fewer votes in one state than a candidate who was no longer in the race. He has not added a single delegate since March 15. And outside of his home state — the only one he has won to date — he has been the top vote-getter in just four counties.

headline: 1916: German Offensive at Verdun
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Germany continues its offensive at Verdun in 1916.
lead_paragraph: The desperate German offensive against the French positions guarding Verdun continues with unabated vigor and on Monday night and yesterday General Pétain’s troops had to withstand a series of furious assaults supported by every deadly contrivance that the enemy could muster.

headline: Where to Find the ‘Fantastic Beasts’ Trailer? Here
abstract: Newt Scamander was kicked out of Hogwarts, but gets his own movie.
lead_paragraph: That suitcase that the magizoologist Newt Scamander brings to New York City isn’t just filled with scarves and waistcoats.

headline: Out of Left Field, Rookie Shortstop Sets a Home Run Record
abstract: Trevor Story’s seven homers in the Rockies’ first six games broke a record previously held by Willie Mays, Mike Schmidt and Larry Walker — and Story is a rookie.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Story was drafted 45th over all out of Irving High School in Texas in 2011. Baseball America ranked him just the eighth best prospect on his team, the Rockies, last fall.

headline: For Polio Vaccines, a Worldwide Switch to New Version
abstract: A new oral polio vaccine will be stocked in more than 150 countries and territories. Switching it out with the old one will be a logistical test.
lead_paragraph: Starting on Sunday, more than 150 countries and territories will switch to a new oral polio vaccine. It will be the first worldwide vaccine change ever attempted.

headline: Race and the Death Penalty
abstract: A former Texas prosecutor writes, “Racial bias should not play a role in death penalty cases, whether introduced by the prosecutor or the defense.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Isn’t All True. Got a Problem With That?
abstract: Readers discuss history and other aspects of “Hamilton.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Kanye West’s ‘Life of Pablo’ Is No. 1 on Billboard Chart After a Wild Ride
abstract: Kanye West put his album on the streaming service Tidal months ago but it was finally released widely on April 1; in its first seven days, it had 99.5 million streams.
lead_paragraph: The release of Kanye West’s “The Life of Pablo” has been the messiest and most fascinating album rollout in recent memory. And now, with a historic arrival on the Billboard chart, it has only gotten more interesting.

headline: Bernie Sanders Proposes Fracking Ban and Attacks Hillary Clinton on the Environment
keywords: ['Environment', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders, campaigning in Binghamton, N.Y., said Hillary Clinton had advocated for natural gas pipelines that would hurt the environment, and that as secretary of state she had rewarded companies through fracking expansions.
lead_paragraph: BINGHAMTON, N.Y. — Bernie Sanders, campaigning across New York State on Monday, called for a nationwide ban on fracking and pointedly criticized Hillary Clinton for her record and stances on environmental issues.

headline: Questioning America’s Role in Yemen
keywords: ['Arms Trade', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The United States may be complicit in war crimes in Yemen, a new report says.
lead_paragraph: Who is to blame when bombs kill civilians?

headline: Sentencing Delayed for Man Convicted in Gay-Bias Killing
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Hate Crimes', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Elliot Morales, who was convicted last month and is acting as his own lawyer, requested additional time to review a series of issues surrounding the case.
lead_paragraph: The sentencing of Elliot Morales, who was convicted last month of murder as a hate crime after shooting a gay man in the West Village, was delayed on Monday, as the defense requested additional time to review a series of issues surrounding the case.

headline: A Scottish Connection?
abstract: An American looking for ancestors in Scotland discusses the primacy of marriage records, needed to claim unclaimed property.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Saving Young Pitchers’ Arms
abstract: A writer advises, “Make the pitcher’s mound a classroom.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Canadian Pacific Demonstrates How Not to Pull Off a Merger
abstract: The unsolicited offer for Norfolk Southern managed to alienate nearly every ally the railway needed.
lead_paragraph: Canadian Pacific Railway’s $28 billion bid for its rival Norfolk Southern pushed all the wrong deal buttons. The offer, unsolicited and now abandoned, managed to alienate nearly every ally the railway needed: American regulators, the target’s board, customers, lawmakers and even the American military.

headline: The Next U.N. Leader
abstract: The historian Stephen Schlesinger says he fears that the “ultimate decision” will reside with the three major powers in the Security Council.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Defense of Catholic Marriage
abstract: What we talk about when we talk about “indissolubility.”
lead_paragraph: I hope to write something later this week rounding up the conflicted and conflicting reactions from conservative Catholics to Pope Francis’s apostolic exhortation on marriage and the family, Amoris Laetitia. (My own provisional reaction appeared in Sunday’s paper.) But first I thought I’d respond to my friend Alan Jacobs’s bafflement at conservative agita over the idea of giving priests formal discretion (informal, they will always have) to admit divorced and remarried Catholics to communion in the absence of an annulment.

headline: Mario Conde, Ex-Bank Chief in Spain, Arrested in Money-Laundering Inquiry
abstract: The authorities are investigating whether Mr. Conde repatriated nearly $15 million in hidden funds as he presided over the collapse of Banesto.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — A disgraced former Spanish banker, Mario Conde, was arrested here on Monday as part of an investigation into whether he fraudulently repatriated the equivalent of nearly $15 million in money he had hidden offshore while presiding over the collapse of one of Spain’s largest banks, Banesto, more than two decades ago.

headline: Number of Tigers in the Wild Is Rising, Wildlife Groups Say
abstract: The estimated rise, the first in over a century, was linked to conservation efforts, as well as new camera and DNA technology that has improved the accuracy of counts.
lead_paragraph: The estimated number of tigers living in the wild rose this year for the first time in more than a century, conservation organizations said. New technology, including hidden cameras, are helping to track and count the animals, which may account for some of the increase.

headline: David Cameron Clashes With Rivals Over Tax Havens and His Wealth
abstract: The British prime minister confronted the Labour Party in Parliament in a spirited debate over economic fairness that was set off by the Panama Papers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain clashed with the opposition Labour Party in Parliament on Monday over tax havens and his inherited wealth, and, in a spirited debate over economic fairness set off by the disclosures in the Panama Papers, defended the right of Britons to “make money lawfully” as long as they paid their taxes.

headline: New Evidence on When Bible Was Written: Ancient Shopping Lists
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Bible', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: An analysis of handwriting on ancient pottery suggests that literacy may have been more widespread than previously known in the Holy Land around 600 B.C.
lead_paragraph: TEL AVIV — Eliashib, the quartermaster of the remote desert fortress, received his instructions in writing — notes inscribed in ink on pottery asking for provisions to be sent to forces in the ancient kingdom of Judah.

headline: Chris Jackson to Lead One World Imprint at Random House
abstract: Mr. Jackson, who has been an executive editor at Spiegel & Grau, will officially restart the One World imprint in fall 2017.
lead_paragraph: The editor Chris Jackson, whose work with the author Ta-Nehisi Coates, the civil rights lawyer Bryan Stevenson and the hip-hop star Jay Z, among others, has made him a rare public star in the world of book publishing, has been named the vice president, publisher and editor-in-chief of the One World imprint of Random House.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Mixed Presidential Messages
abstract: After denying a presidential campaign, Speaker Paul D. Ryan on his website released a series of campaign-themed videos offering a message of unity between Republicans and Democrats.
lead_paragraph: After denying a presidential campaign, Speaker Paul D. Ryan on his website released a series of campaign-themed videos offering a message of unity between Republicans and Democrats.

headline: Annenberg Grants to Aid a Range of Emerging Artists
abstract: A violinist, actors and a dancer are among the recipients of grants from the Leonore Annenberg Fellowship Fund for the Performing and Visual Arts.
lead_paragraph: Robyn Bollinger made her debut playing the violin with the Philadelphia Orchestra at age 12. David Pegram was one of the actor-puppeteers in Lincoln Center Theater’s recent production of “War Horse.” Devon Teuscher became a soloist with American Ballet Theater in 2014.

headline: Some Warriors Are Happy to Pass Up a 3-Pointer. Really.
abstract: Golden State’s long-range marksmen have smashed 3-pointer records this season. Believe it or not, some Warriors still prefer dunking.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Amid their record-breaking march, the Golden State Warriors have made more 3-pointers this season than any other team in N.B.A. history. The ability to launch shots from intergalactic ZIP codes seems like a requirement for employment. Stephen Curry has gotten so good at it that he has somehow made the halfcourt heave look passé.

headline: The Trump Rally
abstract: Faces of the movement.
lead_paragraph: Faces of the movement.

headline: ‘Sweeter Off the Vine’: A Cookbook Made for Instagram
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Fruit', 'Bakeries and Baked Products']
abstract: Yossy Arefi incorporates Middle Eastern, Mexican and other flavors into beautiful fruit desserts.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes a cookbook comes along that seems designed specifically for the Instagram generation, a book that conjures a world of handsome ceramic platters, rustic linens and food that dances around the world, drawing inspiration from the flavors of the Middle East, Southeast Asia and Mexico. The dishes are perfectly imperfect, an edible “I woke up like this,” and easy to picture cropped square in your feed.

headline: Texas Officer, Caught on Video Throwing Girl to the Ground, Is Fired
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Bullies']
abstract: Officials at the San Antonio middle school said the officer’s report of subduing the 12-year-old girl was inconsistent with the cellphone video.
lead_paragraph: A law enforcement officer who was shown on a phone video slamming a 12-year-old student to the ground at a San Antonio middle school has been fired, an official said on Monday.

headline: Hormone Therapy for Prostate Cancer Tied to Depression
abstract: Androgen deprivation therapy, a widely used prostate cancer treatment, may increase depression risk.
lead_paragraph: Hormone therapy for prostate cancer may increase the risk for depression, a new analysis has found.

headline: Review: ‘Game of Silence,’ a Thriller, Grows Out of a Troubled Past
abstract: This new series on NBC follows five people who got into trouble as teenagers, which landed four of them in juvie: now they seek revenge.
lead_paragraph: Every story about a group secret needs a loose cannon, and the one in NBC’s “Game of Silence” is frighteningly loose. His name is Gil, and Michael Raymond-James’s portrayal of him injects a sense of ominous unpredictability into this well-made revenge thriller.

headline: Former Concacaf Chief Admits Guilt in FIFA Corruption Case
keywords: ['Soccer', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Racketeering and Racketeers']
abstract: Alfredo Hawit, who admitted to having accepted hundreds of thousands of dollars in bribes, was the 17th defendant to be convicted in the Justice Department’s case.
lead_paragraph: Alfredo Hawit, a top world soccer official until December, pleaded guilty on Monday to racketeering conspiracy, wire fraud conspiracy and conspiracy to obstruct justice.

headline: Highlights from “Spencer Sweeney”
abstract: The artist chose some favorite pictures from his new self-titled monograph, and told T their stories.
lead_paragraph: The artist chose some favorite pictures from his new self-titled monograph, and told T their stories.

headline: Two Decades of Downtown Art (and Club) Antics, in Pictures
abstract: In advance of a show at Gavin Brown’s temporary Paris space, Spencer Sweeney chose some favorite photos and paintings and told T their stories.
lead_paragraph: When the Swiss artist Urs Fischer couldn’t find a book on his friend Spencer Sweeney, he decided to take matters into his own hands: Fischer proposed the two work together on a retrospective monograph for his own publishing imprint, Kiito-San.

headline: What the Panama Papers Reveal About the Art Market
keywords: ['Art', 'Tax Shelters', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Auctions', 'Tax Evasion', 'Arts and Antiquities Looting']
abstract: The leaked documents show the many ways offshore shell companies are used to conceal the ownership of art. Here’s a look at three cases.
lead_paragraph: The so-called Panama Papers — the leak of 11.5 million files from the Panamanian law firm Mossack Fonseca — have given us a deep look into the many ways offshore shell companies are used to conceal the ownership of art. Leaked initially to Süddeutsche Zeitung, a German newspaper, the documents have been pored over by a consortium of journalistic outlets, which released a series of articles last week, several about the art market.

headline: Bernie Sanders vs. Hillary Clinton, New York-Style
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Paul Krugman criticizing Mr. Sanders.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Letting Patients Tell Their Stories
abstract: Doctors have many skills, but we often fail to appreciate people’s messy, beautiful lives.
lead_paragraph: Friday night in the emergency department is about what you’d think.

headline: A Tiny Home Takes Shape in Brooklyn, but It May Not Stay
abstract: In New York, the trend toward living small usually involves the micro-apartment, but one woman has joined the Tiny House Movement and is building a 160-square-foot one of her own.
lead_paragraph: Miko Mercer would seem to be a good candidate for a tiny house — single, tidy, 5-foot-3. And indeed she has joined the Tiny House Movement that has swept the country the last several years.

headline: The Park Service Maps America’s Natural and Human-Made Soundscapes and Silences
keywords: ['National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Noise', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas']
abstract: New maps by the National Park Service show levels of human and natural sounds around the United States.
lead_paragraph: I was drawn to a fascinating analysis by the National Park Service, “Mapping Sound on a National Scale,” by a pair of Twitter posts this morning from Max Roser, an Oxford University economist and director of the school’s invaluable “Our World in Data” project:

headline: In Mexico City, Exploring a Volcano Sacred to the Aztecs
abstract: The Hill of the Star, once one of the most important Aztec religious sites, has been lost to time. But a visit there can still be transportive.
lead_paragraph: At the end of each 52-year cycle that governed their calendar, the Aztecs would put out all the fires they burned for everyday use, and as night descended, priests would use a friction rod to ignite a new blaze atop a sacred volcano that soared over the surrounding shimmering lakes. The event involved the burning of a human sacrifice and culminated in runners carrying torches lit by the fire back down the mountain to relight hearths in temples and in every home.

headline: Review: Venice and Vivaldi, Center Stage at the Metropolitan Museum
abstract: The Venice Baroque Orchestra presented a Vivaldi program on Saturday, and another Italian group presents more Vivaldi on Wednesday at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: It almost amounts to a festival before the festival. The program “Venice Baroque Orchestra Performs Vivaldi,” presented in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday night, is to be followed on Wednesday by an evening of Vivaldi performed by another Italian group, Accademia Bizantina, at Alice Tully Hall.

headline: Dressing Up for the Met Opera
abstract: To attract a new generation of sophisticates, the Metropolitan Opera has a new series, Fridays Under 40, that offers tickets to people under 40 for $60 and $100. On March 18, young operagoers dressed up (and down) for the occasion.
lead_paragraph: To attract a new generation of sophisticates, the Metropolitan Opera has a new series, Fridays Under 40, that offers tickets to people under 40 for $60 and $100. On March 18, young operagoers dressed up (and down) for the occasion.

headline: Review: American Contemporary Music Ensemble at the Kitchen
abstract: The ensemble performed a program with songs from Charlemagne Palestine, Julius Eastman and Meredith Monk.
lead_paragraph: Despite the composer’s wishes, the Kitchen didn’t quite turn into an aquarium on Sunday evening when the American Contemporary Music Ensemble performed a new transcription of Charlemagne Palestine’s “Strumming Music.” In program notes for the event, Mr. Palestine, a minimalist composer known for immersive soundscapes and eccentric performance rituals involving stuffed animals and alcoholic libations, expressed his hope that his music would create a “liquid sonority” that would inundate this performance space in Chelsea.

headline: Light Turnout for Vote in Darfur on Region’s Future
abstract: The referendum on whether the Sudanese region should remain as five semiautonomous states or be made into one has been dismissed by some as a meaningless administrative exercise.
lead_paragraph: EL FASHER, Sudan — After years of crisis, displacement, turmoil and bloodshed, the people of Sudan’s Darfur region had a chance on Monday to participate in a referendum on their future.

headline: Talking with Dena Blizzard: How She Became ‘One Funny Mother’
abstract: Ms. Blizzard’s solo comedy show has come to New York City after a national tour. She’s not afraid to say: “Everybody’s kids are annoying.”
lead_paragraph: The day before beginning previews of her new Off Broadway show, “One Funny Mother,” Dena Blizzard was taking cold medicine and tending to her 11-year-old daughter, who had recently received nine stitches in her knee after falling in a creek.

headline: Review: ‘Wringer,’ a Musical Adaptation of Jerry Spinelli’s Book
abstract: This adaptation by New York City Children’s Theater stays true to the novel’s premise but, unlike the book, is full of comedy.
lead_paragraph: “Wringer,” Jerry Spinelli’s award-winning 1997 children’s novel, is suspenseful, poignant and sometimes disturbing. I wouldn’t call it fun. “Wringer,” the musical adaptation by New York City Children’s Theater, is fun from beginning to end. Is that a problem?

headline: Sierra Nevada Snow Won’t End California’s Thirst
abstract: Climate change and the proliferation of trees have led to less of a natural reservoir of melting snow coming down the mountains.
lead_paragraph: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. — Thanks in part to El Niño, snowpack in the Sierra Nevada is greater than it has been in years. With the winter snowfall season winding down, California officials said that the pack peaked two weeks ago at 87 percent of the long-term average.

headline: Curtis Sittenfeld’s ‘Eligible’ Updates Austen’s ‘Pride and Prejudice’
abstract: The novel, largely set in Cincinnati, is a “modern retelling” of the early-19th-century classic, commissioned by the Austen Project.
lead_paragraph: It is a truth universally acknowledged that many a writer in want of a good romantic comedy plot has turned to Jane Austen. “Pride and Prejudice” alone has countless progeny — from the classic 1995 BBC adaptation, to more fanciful variations like “Pride and Prejudice and Zombies” and “Twilight” (Pride and Prejudice and Vampires).

headline: Judge Orders Release of Gawker-Hulk Hogan Trial Documents
abstract: The papers had been sealed during the sex tape trial that resulted in a jury awarding Mr. Hogan $140.1 million.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. — A judge agreed on Monday to release a trove of previously sealed documents related to the Hulk Hogan sex tape trial against Gawker Media, which concluded in March with a jury awarding the former wrestler $140.1 million in damages after three and a half years of litigation.

headline: Humana Festival, Turning 40, Looks at Mortality, Dystopia and Change
abstract: This year’s Humana Festival of New American Plays includes “This Random World,” “Wellesley Girl” and Sarah Ruhl’s “For Peter Pan on Her 70th birthday.”
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — The Humana Festival of New American Plays, which concluded on Sunday, celebrated its 40th anniversary this year. But the plays themselves didn’t feature much in the way of cork-popping. Most offered dark views of our passage through life, perhaps appropriately. Once you’ve turned 40, the road forward has fewer forks, scars from the past have settled into the skin, and existence begins to feel more precarious.

headline: Stan Douglas’s ‘The Secret Agent’ Offers a Refracted Vision of History and Terrorism
abstract: The artist’s new film closely follows the plot of Joseph Conrad’s 1907 novel, but transposes the story to Portugal in 1975, after that country’s dictatorship fell.
lead_paragraph: Henry James once described Joseph Conrad’s writing as a “prolonged hovering flight of the subjective over the outstretched ground” of his stories.

headline: ‘All the King’s Men,’ Now 70, Has a Touch of 2016
abstract: This 1946 novel by Robert Penn Warren is eerily prescient about some of the dark uses to which language has been put in this year’s election.
lead_paragraph: “Southern political personalities, like sweet corn, travel badly,” the journalist A. J. Liebling wrote. “They lose flavor with every hundred yards away from the patch.”

headline: Arms Control Groups Urge Human Control of Robot Weaponry
keywords: ['Robots and Robotics', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Relations']
abstract: In a report issued at a United Nations meeting, the groups said technology that leaves killing decisions to machines was “profoundly disturbing.”
lead_paragraph: Two international arms control groups on Monday issued a report that called for maintaining human control over a new generation of weapons that are increasingly capable of targeting and attacking without the involvement of people.

headline: Racially Charged Joke by Hillary Clinton and Bill de Blasio Leaves Some Cringing
abstract: A skit by Mrs. Clinton and the mayor of New York during an annual sendup of New York politics drew criticism from several news media outlets.
lead_paragraph: In less than three minutes, a comedy routine between Hillary Clinton and Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York managed to cause a storm of controversy over a racially charged joke.

headline: Body Recovered 2 Months After Plane Lands in a Long Island Harbor
abstract: The body of Gerson Salmon-Negron, 23, of Elmhurst, Queens, was found on a beach, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two months after a single-engine plane made an emergency landing in Setauket Harbor, the body of the missing passenger was found on Monday, the Suffolk County Police Department said.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: John Kerry, Donald Trump, Will Smith
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Comedian’s Takedown of Turkish President Tests Free Speech in Germany
abstract: Turkey has asked Germany to prosecute a comedian in accordance with a little-known German law on insulting foreign leaders, placing Chancellor Angela Merkel in a bind.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Germany’s comics love President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey. Or at least to make fun of him mercilessly. And for Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany, that is no laughing matter.

headline: Henrik Lundqvist, Rangers’ Rock in Net, Has Been Wobbling
abstract: Lundqvist left practice with flulike symptoms, the latest odd turn in his meandering season, with a playoff series against the red-hot Penguins beginning Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The sight was surely unnerving to the Rangers, who have come to rely, tactically and psychologically, on Henrik Lundqvist at this time of year.

headline: Indonesia’s Library on Horseback
abstract: An Indonesian man who takes books to children in a remote village — on horseback — has become “the Don Quixote of literacy.”
lead_paragraph: An Indonesian man who takes books to children in a remote village — on horseback — has become “the Don Quixote of literacy.”

headline: After Loss in Colorado, Donald Trump Supporters Give State Chairman an Earful
abstract: Steve House, chairman of Colorado’s Republican Party, has been hearing from angry voters contending the state’s system of caucuses left the selection of its presidential nominating delegates to party activists.
lead_paragraph: It has been two days since Senator Ted Cruz of Texas swept Colorado’s delegates, and Steve House, the chairman of the state’s Republican Party, is feeling the wrath of Donald J. Trump’s supporters.

headline: Texas Attorney General Faces Federal Securities Fraud Lawsuit
abstract: Regulators have accused Ken Paxton, a Republican and former member of the State House, of misleading investors in a technology company.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Attorney General Ken Paxton of Texas, who was indicted last year on state securities fraud charges, faced a new round of legal troubles on Monday after federal regulators accused him of misleading investors in a technology company.

headline: Tesla Recalls Model X S.U.V.s
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Electric and Hybrid Vehicles', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: Tesla said that it was recalling the sport utility vehicles after testing revealed that the backs of the third-row seats could give way in a crash.
lead_paragraph: Tesla Motors said on Monday that it was recalling its Model X sport utility vehicles after testing revealed that the backs of the electric car’s third-row seats could give way in a crash.

headline: Chicago Set to Pay $6 Million in Deaths of 2 Men After Arrests
abstract: City Council members on Monday said the recurrence of such cases showed the need for urgent changes to police training and discipline.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — This city moved Monday toward paying more than $6 million in settlements to the families of two men who died after being taken into police custody, frustrating City Council members who said such cases showed the need for urgent changes to police training and discipline.

headline: Activists Push to Continue a Libel Suit Against Them
keywords: ['Libel and Slander', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: ChemRisk, a consultant criticized in a Huffington Post article, wants to drop its suit against the activists, but they want legal fees and an apology.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Paustenbach, a top consultant to companies facing lawsuits over products or environmental practices, has long been eager to put a stop to accusations that his company, ChemRisk, slanted scientific findings to suit its clients.

headline: New York City Combining Agencies for Homeless and Welfare Services
abstract: The Human Resources Administration and the Social Services Department will join under one commissioner, Steven Banks.
lead_paragraph: Citing duplication, inefficiency and the need for a “new vision” to combat homelessness, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Monday that the New York City agencies for homeless services and welfare will consolidate under a single commissioner.

headline: Zika Fight Requires More Money, Congress Is Told
abstract: Two senior Obama administration officials said the mosquito-borne virus posed a more serious threat to the United States than experts initially believed.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two senior Obama administration officials said on Monday that the government did not have enough money to effectively combat and treat the Zika virus, which they called a more profound threat to the United States than experts once believed.

headline: Puerto Rico Aims to Appease Congress With New Debt Proposal
abstract: The plan would cover $49.3 billion of Puerto Rico’s $72 billion debt, most of which is in the form of municipal bonds.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico proposed a new plan on Monday to restructure its debt, offering some creditors better terms than an earlier plan but falling well short of winning broad support.

headline: Suicide Attempts Plague Attawapiskat First Nation in Canada
abstract: Since September, 101 people in a remote aboriginal community have attempted suicide. That’s about 5 percent of its population.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — She was bullied relentlessly. She suffered from asthma, diabetes and other ailments. Her living conditions were unbearably cramped: 20 relatives taking refuge in a two-bedroom government nursing station for more than a year after a sewage backup made their home uninhabitable.

headline: Two Unions Set Strike Deadline for 36,000 Verizon Workers
abstract: The unions, representing employees in the East, say they have made little progress with management in the eight months since their contracts expired.
lead_paragraph: Two unions representing roughly 36,000 Verizon workers in the eastern United States have set a strike deadline of Wednesday morning, saying they have made little progress with management in the more than eight months since their most recent contracts expired. The announcement sets up what would be one of the largest strikes in recent years.

headline: For Indian Start-Ups, Tenacity Beats High Tech
keywords: ['Venture Capital', 'Entrepreneurship', 'Start-ups', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: Venture capitalists looking to fund start-ups in India place more emphasis on execution than on intellectual property.
lead_paragraph: BANGALORE, India — On a hot afternoon in a two-story house here, as dogs barked and auto-rickshaws sputtered outside, a venture capitalist grilled three entrepreneurs.

headline: Europe’s Urgent Security Challenge
abstract: Long after 9/11, attitudes and structures in Europe still impede counterterrorism cooperation.
lead_paragraph: It took two weeks after the devastating attacks in Brussels for officials to discover that the plotters originally intended to hit Paris again or that the two attacks were carried out by a single network. Even now, authorities don’t know the full scale of the Islamic State’s operations in Europe, which involve criminal elements as well as terrorists.

headline: Frequent Victories Can Make Room for Two Goalies
abstract: The Stars and a few other playoff teams relied on two established starters in net, a system that will be put to the test in the N.H.L. postseason.
lead_paragraph: Dallas Stars goaltender Kari Lehtonen admits he was not entirely thrilled when he first heard that his team had acquired his fellow Finnish goalie Antti Niemi last summer.

headline: The Mayor Offers Hope for the Homeless
abstract: Mayor de Blasio’s new plan will focus on preventing homelessness and putting people into permanent housing.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio announced an overhaul of New York City’s services for the homeless on Monday, the result of a 90-day review that he promised when the homelessness crisis reached a crescendo late last year.

headline: De Blasio Donors Took Pride in Connections With Top Police Officials
abstract: The donors, Jona S. Rechnitz and Jeremiah Reichberg, are the fulcrum of a sprawling federal corruption inquiry into police commanders and the mayor’s fund-raising.
lead_paragraph: Jona S. Rechnitz, the scion of a wealthy Los Angeles family, came to New York City about a decade ago to make his mark. A brash young man eager to fund philanthropic causes, he cultivated connections with the Police Department — posing with top officials, and once arranging for police bagpipes at a party — and became a fixture at fund-raising events for Mayor Bill de Blasio.

headline: For a Generalist, ‘Too Big to Fail’ May Be Too Tricky to Judge
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Law and Legislation', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The judge who ruled on MetLife’s designation as “too big to fail” is a legal rock star. But financial oversight isn’t her area of expertise.
lead_paragraph: About two years ago, I was speaking with an executive at MetLife who floated the idea that the company should sue the government to overturn its designation as a firm that was too big to fail. The company believed that it was being unfairly labeled, and that the regulations that came with the designation were hindering its business.

headline: Effort to Impeach Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff Clears Congressional Panel
abstract: Supporters of the Brazilian leader are now scrambling ahead of a floor vote in the lower house of Parliament.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The effort to impeach President Dilma Rousseff cleared a congressional panel on Monday, setting up a cliffhanger vote on her ouster in the coming days in Brazil’s Chamber of Deputies.

headline: Obama’s Latest View on Secrecy Overlooks Past Prosecution of Leaks
abstract: In defending Hillary Clinton’s email practices, the president offered a concession his administration has not always made with news organizations or security officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Obama defended Hillary Clinton’s email practices in a television interview over the weekend by saying, “there’s classified, and then there’s classified,” he was only repeating what critics of government secrecy have long contended: that most of what is classified is merely sensitive, a little embarrassing or perhaps a policy debate still in progress.

headline: Getatchew Mekurya, 81, Ethiopian Saxophonist With Global Reach, Dies
abstract: Mr. Mekurya, who had an imposing jazz sound and presence, collaborated with musicians from far beyond his home country.
lead_paragraph: Getatchew Mekurya, a saxophonist with an ardent, full-throated style who worked predominantly in Ethiopia for decades before being embraced by a worldwide audience, died on April 4 in Addis Ababa. He was 81.

headline: Rights Law Deepens Political Rifts in North Carolina
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Discrimination', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'State Legislatures']

headline: Thieves Take $280,000 From Brooklyn Bank After Carving Hole in Roof
abstract: Employees at an HSBC branch in the Borough Park neighborhood arrived at work to discover a tunnel had been cut from the ceiling into the vault.
lead_paragraph: In a scene more often seen in a Hollywood caper than in Borough Park, Brooklyn’s sedate shopping district, employees arrived for work at a bank on Monday morning to find a tunnel through the ceiling straight into the vault, with hundreds of thousands of dollars missing, the police said.

headline: National Briefing
keywords: ["Legionnaires' Disease", 'Polygamy', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: Two more deaths from Legionnaires’ disease in the Flint area were identified on Monday by health officials, bringing the death toll from the disease in 2014 and 2015 to 12. Eden Wells, the chief medical executive for the Michigan Department of Health and Human Services, said officials counted 91 cases of Legionnaires’ in Genesee County, which includes Flint, during those years. Most were not fatal. “We remain vigilant in identifying any potential case associated with the outbreak,” she said in a statement. Officials in Michigan suspected a link between a spike in Legionnaires’ disease, a form of pneumonia caused by bacteria that multiply in water systems, and the Flint water supply as early as 2014. The switch from Lake Huron water to water from the Flint River was made in April 2014. Flint residents are still using filters before drinking or cooking with their tap water. Marc Edwards, the Virginia Tech researcher whose testing identified lead in the water, plans on Tuesday to release results of an eight-month study of Flint’s water. JULIE BOSMAN

headline: Documents Detail Scene of Planned Parenthood Shooting in Colorado Springs
abstract: Documents unsealed on Monday suggest Robert L. Dear Jr. had long admired violent opponents of abortion, and offer a detailed account of the rampage.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Robert L. Dear Jr., his pickup truck loaded with rifles, handguns and propane canisters, had to stop several times to ask for directions to the Planned Parenthood center in Colorado Springs. Eventually, he found the clinic’s address after calling Planned Parenthood itself, and once there, the police say, he carried out an hourslong shooting rampage that left three people dead and nine people wounded.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 2 Episode 9: The Brothers McGill
abstract: Jimmy and Chuck, both kind of terrible in their own way, see how horrific consequences can flow from small deceptions.
lead_paragraph: If you have ever wondered what Shakespeare would sound like translated for a serialized television drama, circa 2016, wonder no more. The answer arrives 18 minutes into this gloriously fraught episode, when Chuck summons Kim to his home and accuses Jimmy of murder most foul. O.K., that overstates it. He accuses Jimmy of fraud, but we’re talking about the white-collar law part of the show, so that’s bad enough.

headline: What States Can Do on Birth Control
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'States (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Unplanned pregnancies hold women back and impose huge costs on society. We can help.
lead_paragraph: Dover, Del. — DURING my years of working in public life, I have witnessed countless ways in which unplanned pregnancy disrupts people’s lives. So one of the best ideas I’ve seen for how to help everyone reach the next rung on the ladder is providing access to effective contraception. Enabling women to become pregnant only when they want to is a shortcut to prosperity.

headline: Tensions at the Syrian Border
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Jordan borders Syria, Iraq, Saudi Arabia, Israel and the Palestinian territories. Patrolling it is a big challenge for Jordanian troops.
lead_paragraph: Today we traveled along the Syrian border to a security checkpoint with King Abdullah II and some of his military advisers. Jordan has many borders, all potentially porous: 365 kilometers (about 227 miles) facing Syria, 180 kilometers (about 110 miles) facing Iraq, and the rest facing Saudi Arabia, Israel and the Palestinian territories. Their vulnerabilities are clear and visible from the air. But the Jordanian military is vigilant, using very sophisticated surveillance equipment and poring over digital video feeds in real time to spot problems.

headline: Grieving My Patient’s Friend
abstract: It isn’t unusual for therapists to get emotionally attached to people we’ve never met.
lead_paragraph: Isabella left a package for each of her children to open after her death. Her youngest was only 5 months old, and the other three were ages 2, 4 and 7. She had always wanted a big family, and when she learned, after the birth of her third child, that she carried BRCA1, the so-called breast cancer gene, she and her husband decided to rush to have their last child. Then she would have the surgery that she believed would save her life, a double mastectomy.

headline: Bono: Time to Think Bigger About the Refugee Crisis
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Music']
abstract: It is time for a Marshall Plan to address the problem.
lead_paragraph: I’VE recently returned from the Middle East and East Africa, where I visited a number of refugee camps — car parks of humanity. I went as an activist and as a European. Because Europeans have come to realize — quite painfully in the past year or two — that the mass exodus from collapsed countries like Syria is not just a Middle Eastern or African problem, it’s a European problem. It’s an American one, too. It affects us all.

headline: A Home, but Not Home
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: About one in five people in Jordan is a refugee. Most live in communities outside camps where they depend on help from the U.N. — and their neighbors.
lead_paragraph: I arrived in Jordan, a country where about one in five people is a refugee. The Jordanian government’s figure is 1.2 million refugees, mostly Iraqis and Syrians — and the true number is probably larger. When we think of refugees at all, most of us think of people living in camps. But here in Jordan a vast majority of these transitory souls are living in the community.

headline: Refugees in ISIS’ Shadow
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Turkey is the largest host country of refugees. But its resources are being stretched, and there are reports it is forcibly returning some Syrians.
lead_paragraph: Turkey is the largest host country of refugees, with about three million people who have fled conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Afghanistan and elsewhere. But what is striking here in “old Anatolia,” where the prime minister says Irish people have their ancestry, is that while the Turkish people in and around the refugee camp I visited seemed incredibly welcoming of their neighbors, there was also a sense that something was not quite right.

headline: Rare Loan of Clyfford Still Paintings to Join Royal Academy Show
abstract: The Clyfford Still Museum in Denver will lend nine works to a European survey of Abstract Expressionism.
lead_paragraph: In his lifetime, Clyfford Still demanded that his stark, monumental Abstract Expressionist canvases be exhibited in museum shows only in a separate gallery, and explicitly restricted institutions from lending paintings he donated. But his will, bequeathing the vast majority of his output to an American city that would “retain” the works of art in exclusive and permanent quarters, “is somewhat ambiguous and doesn’t expressly prohibit loans,” said Dean Sobel, director of the Clyfford Still Museum in Denver, where the artist’s estate now resides. (Mr. Still died in 1980.)

headline: Morning Agenda: $5.1 Billion Fine for Goldman Sachs Less Than Meets the Eye
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Credit and Debt', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Hedge Funds', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: How to Judge ‘Too Big to Fail’? | Puerto Rico Proposes Debt Restructuring Plan
lead_paragraph: $5.1 BILLION FINE FOR GOLDMAN SACHS LESS THAN MEETS THE EYE | Goldman Sachs became the last of the big American banks to settle a government investigation into how Wall Street banks exacerbated the mortgage bubble and the financial crisis, with state and federal officials announcing that Goldman would pay $5.1 billion – but that’s just on paper,  Nathaniel Popper writes in DealBook. A closer look at the conditions of the settlement shows that the bank will be able to significantly reduce its bill through government incentives and tax credits. “The details in the various annexes suggest that Goldman could end up paying over $1 billion less than the $5 billion than was announced on Monday,” he writes.

And then, slowly, unstoppably, the plane nosed into view — a giant T, a giant R, a U and an M and a P, the plane swelling from its tip to its girth to its wings, filling completely the field of our vision.

headline: How ‘Empowerment’ Became Something for Women to Buy
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'English Language', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Corporations', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: The corporate vision of female strength profits from the same old power dynamics.
lead_paragraph: At my day job as an editor at a women’s website, I receive a daily mess of emails promoting random products and activities as “empowering.” Recent offerings include the Pure Barre workout, divorce, Miley Cyrus, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, ancient Egyptian sex rites, leggings, sending nude photos, receiving nude photos, declining to send or receive nude photos, doing stand-up comedy and purchasing full-bottomed lingerie. The mix of things presumed to transmit and increase female power is without limit yet still depressingly limiting.

It was among the latest and worst rounds of job losses to hit Wyoming.
