headline: James Taylor Retires From Cricket at 26 With Heart Condition
abstract: In December and January, Taylor was a part of the England team that won a Test series in South Africa. Now he will stop playing at any level.
lead_paragraph: The cricket star James Taylor retired on Tuesday at age 26 after he was found to have a serious heart condition.

headline: European Union Calls for Big Companies to Disclose More Tax Data
abstract: The proposed rules, in the works before the Panama Papers leak, are intended in some ways to lift the veil on similar types of corporate secrets.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union officials on Tuesday waded into the fight against international tax dodging, calling for the world’s biggest companies to disclose more data about their tax arrangements with the bloc’s member governments and to share information about offshore havens where they shelter money.

headline: The Reason for Public School’s Show Rethink: Not What You Expect
abstract: The fashion label is rearranging its shows, reflecting the difficulty of juggling two brands.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, the fashion label Public School joined the club and announced it was uniting its men’s and women’s wear shows, just like Gucci, Tom Ford and Burberry, and moving them to December and June from the traditional women’s dates of February and September, just like, well, nobody else.

headline: Belgium Charges 2 More Men in Inquiry Into Terrorist Attacks
abstract: There are now more than 20 people charged in connection with the assaults on Brussels, Paris or both, the federal prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Two more people were detained and charged on Monday as part of the investigation into the deadly attacks in the Belgian capital last month, bringing to more than 20 the number of people charged in Belgium in connection with the assaults in Brussels, Paris or both, the federal prosecutor said on Tuesday.

headline: Australian Mother and 8 Others Face Charges in Lebanon Custody Dispute
abstract: Sally Faulkner had tried to take her two children from her estranged husband, officials said. Four television journalists were among eight others facing charges.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A bitter custody dispute between an Australian mother and a Lebanese father. A crew of sympathetic Australian television journalists. A grandmother who was clubbed on the head as the children were put into an S.U.V. that sped off.

headline: Deutsche Bank Freezes North Carolina Expansion, in Protest of Bias Law
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Law and Legislation', 'Bathrooms and Toilets']
abstract: The financial giant said its decision was in response to the passage of a state law that eliminates antidiscrimination protections based on sexual orientation.
lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank, the German financial giant that has a significant business in the United States, said on Tuesday that it would freeze its plans to add jobs in North Carolina, a response to the passage last month of a state law that, among other things, eliminates antidiscrimination protections based on sexual orientation.

headline: Nomura to Shrink Its European and Americas Businesses
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The Japanese financial firm said it planned to close several parts of its overseas operations, and the changes are expected to include job cuts.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Nomura said on Tuesday that it planned to close several parts of its business in Europe and to shrink its operations in the Americas, as the financial firm looks to reduce costs and improve the profitability of its operations outside its home market, Japan.

headline: 1891: King Humbert Incensed
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The king of Italy is incensed at caricatures of him in U.S. papers in 1891.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — It is stated at Washington that it is untrue that the Marquis di Rudini demands a reply to the Italian protest within a specified time; but in spite of this denial persistent reports confirming the story come from Rome, and they gain credence in some quarters. King Humbert, it is alleged, is incensed at the caricatures in the American comic papers which have been sent to him by an Italian editor here. His Majesty is said to take exception to one notable caricature in which he appears as a monkey. — The New York Herald, European Edition, April 13, 1891

headline: Fannie ‘in a Sustainable Profitability’
abstract: In a deposition taken last July Susan McFarland, Fannie’s former chief financial officer, said she told high-level officials at the Treasury on Aug. 9, 2012, that the company was, in fact, “now in a sustainable profitability, that we would be able to deliver sustainable profits over time.”
lead_paragraph: In a deposition taken last July Susan McFarland, Fannie’s former chief financial officer, said she told high-level officials at the Treasury on Aug. 9, 2012, that the company was, in fact, “now in a sustainable profitability, that we would be able to deliver sustainable profits over time.”

headline: Documents Undercut U.S. Case for Taking Mortgage Giant Fannie Mae’s Profits
abstract: Government lawyers said they changed the terms of a bailout deal to protect taxpayers, but newly unsealed documents call that into question.
lead_paragraph: On a Friday in August 2012, the federal government changed the terms of its bailout of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, sending all the mortgage finance giants’ profits to the Treasury. The surprise decision prompted a lawsuit from shareholders, who argued that the collection of profits was an improper taking of private property without compensation.

headline: Taiwan Accuses Kenya of Illegal Deportations as More Are Sent to China
abstract: Taiwanese officials accused Kenya of violating international law, using tear gas on their citizens, and trying to curry favor with China, a heavyweight in Africa.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Usually prisoners want to get out of jail. But on Tuesday, a group of Taiwanese citizens did all they could to stay in — barricading themselves in a small cell as Kenyan police officers tried to storm in with assault rifles.

headline: Facebook’s Developer Conference Kicks Off
abstract: On Tuesday Mark Zuckerberg is expected to address Facebook Messenger and Facebook Live among other topics.
lead_paragraph: The event to watch in Silicon Valley this week is Facebook’s annual developer conference, which starts on Tuesday.

headline: Freeing Lonely iPad Apps From Almost Empty Folders
abstract: If the screen on your iOS device is cluttered with folders that contain just one app, you can clean things up with a simple drag and drop.
lead_paragraph: Q. After removing old apps I never use from my iPad, I find I have a few folders that contain only one app. How do I get rid of the folder enclosures and put the app back out with the others on the home screen, or move it to a different folder with other apps?

headline: Seeking Bold Tax Overhaul, Texas Lawmaker to Test Congress
abstract: Representative Kevin Brady has become chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee in an era of partisan imperatives.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Over two decades in Congress, Representative Kevin Brady has always been popular with colleagues. Now that the genial Texas Republican has become chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, Mr. Brady has got real power, too.

headline: The Composer Kate Soper and the Makers of ‘Life Is a Dream’ Win Awards
abstract: Legacies of Charles Ives and Virgil Thomson are behind two awards given to composers and a librettist.
lead_paragraph: The composer Kate Soper won the Virgil Thomson Award in Vocal Music, while the composer Lewis Spratlan and librettist James Maraniss won the Charles Ives Opera Prize for their work “Life Is a Dream,” the American Academy of Arts and Letters, which awards the prizes, announced on Tuesday.

headline: Alan Dershowitz and 2 Other Lawyers Settle Suit and Counter Claim
abstract: The settlement, in which the lawyers dropped a defamation suit against Mr. Dershowitz, included a financial payment but no details were disclosed.
lead_paragraph: The noted defense lawyer Alan M. Dershowitz and two lawyers who had sued him claiming defamation have dropped court actions against each side, ending  a prominent dispute that included accusations of sexual misconduct against Mr. Dershowitz.

headline: Haider al-Abadi’s Dangerous Gamble
abstract: Iraq’s prime minister is taking his country to the brink of political crisis. Now it’s up to the United States and Iran to save him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iraq is facing major financial pressure, and the war against the Islamic State grinds on. The last thing the country needs is a major political crisis. But that’s exactly what appears to be in the works — unless the United States and Iran work together to help the prime minister avoid it.

headline: International Monetary Fund Forecasts Slow Growth in Developing Nations
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: Such a trend, if it continues, would increase the likelihood of another round of financial shocks in the years ahead, the fund said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The International Monetary Fund warned on Tuesday about persistently slow growth in developing economies, highlighting a growing concern that these countries will not soon regain the high rates of growth that distinguished them in the past.

headline: 1941: British Destroy Nazi Column
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Royal Air Force destroys a column of Nazi tanks in Libya in 1941.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The British Royal Air Force, aided by Australian and ‘‘Free French’’ pilots, was reported in a British communiqué today [April 12] to have destroyed an estimated 100 Nazi tanks and motorized units on the road from Ain el Gazala to Tobruk, Libya, toward which the Germans are advancing.

headline: Which Subjects Are Underrepresented in Contemporary Fiction?
abstract: Ayana Mathis and Siddhartha Deb discuss joy, class and other subjects missing from too much fiction these days.
lead_paragraph: In Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Ayana Mathis and Siddhartha Deb discuss joy, class and other subjects missing from too much fiction these days.

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Season 2, Episode 17: Bachelorette Party
abstract: How does one have a bachelorette party when they don’t like to lose control?
lead_paragraph: If “Jane the Virgin” has one consistent flaw, it’s that the show’s writers seem to get so excited about introducing various plotlines that they have trouble spacing them out. Instead, episodes are packed to the brim — meaning that sometimes these plots don’t get as much time as they should. Fortunately, “Jane the Virgin” depicts such good stories that any one of its half-baked plots are better than many multi-episode arcs on other shows.

headline: Senator Grassley and Judge Garland Meet, and Rehash the Obvious
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Senator Charles E. Grassley restated what Judge Merrick B. Garland, the president’s Supreme Court pick, already knew: There will be no hearings this year on his nomination.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a balance-of-power breakfast.

headline: Is Staying In the New Going Out?
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Life in the golden age of creature comforts.
lead_paragraph: I first noticed it at work. On Monday mornings a deathless ritual unfolds in offices across the land: the posing of the question, “How was your weekend?” A few years ago, my coworkers and I exchanged happy highlight reels of ambitious urban activities before cracking open our laptops and pouring ourselves a tall, refreshing glass of work. One of us went to an off-Broadway play. One of us went to a Beyoncé concert. One of us went on a date. We had fun!

headline: How to Save Nigeria’s Economy and Stop Corruption
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Currency', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: President Buhari needs to give up the quixotic currency peg and let the naira’s value fall.
lead_paragraph: LAGOS, Nigeria — The collapsed price of oil is putting pressure on oil exporters around the world, from Canada to Kuwait. But perhaps no country is less prepared to survive prices at about $30 a barrel than Nigeria, which until a few years ago relied heavily on petroleum exports for its revenue. While countries like Saudi Arabia and Russia have saved past oil profits for rainy days, Nigeria has no such insulation. What’s worse is that Nigeria is especially dependent on imports of basic goods.

headline: Milk Jumps Onto the Small-Batch Bandwagon
keywords: ['Milk', 'Dairy Products', 'Local Food', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Agriculture and Farming']
abstract: Dairies are starting to market their wares as handcrafted, local, premium — and pricey.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Standing in the dim basement of a meatpacking plant in the West Loop neighborhood, a 35-year-old start-up founder named Travis Pyykkonen conjured up a wholesome vision that was almost bucolic.

headline: E.U. Delays Decision on Requiring Visas of Americans and Canadians
abstract: The proposal is a response to delays in granting visa-free travel to citizens of Romania and Bulgaria, among other countries.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — European Union authorities discussed a provocative proposal Tuesday to require that United States and Canadian citizens obtain visas to travel to Europe, but they delayed a decision on the matter until summer.

headline: Beverly Cleary Turns 100
abstract: A look back The Times’s coverage of the author and her work.
lead_paragraph: Happy 100th birthday to Beverly Cleary from The New York Times Book Review! Here’s a look at some highlights from our coverage of Cleary and her work over the decades.

headline: John Kasich Channels Ronald Reagan in New York Speech
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Speeches and Statements']
abstract: Mr. Kasich aimed to expand on promising poll numbers with an optimistic speech criticizing Donald Trump and Ted Cruz.
lead_paragraph: John Kasich, the Republican primary’s most moderate candidate, worked to expand on promising poll numbers in New York with a speech this morning sharply criticizing Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, without mentioning them by name.

headline: Warhol ‘Soup Can’ Prints Are Stolen From a Missouri Museum
abstract: The F.B.I. has offered a $25,000 reward for the seven prints, which were taken at night from the Springfield Art Museum. Three soup can prints in the set were left behind.
lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. is offering a $25,000 reward for the recovery of seven screen prints of Andy Warhol’s Campbell’s Soup cans after they were snatched from an art museum in Springfield, Mo.

headline: Chappatte on the Panama Papers Furor
abstract: The worldwide fallout from the leak of financial documents continues.
lead_paragraph: The worldwide fallout from the leak of financial documents continues.

headline: Swiss Widen Inquiry Into Malaysian Fund to Include 2 Emirati Officials
abstract: The officials were being investigated for suspicion of fraud, criminal mismanagement, money laundering, bribery and forgery, the Swiss attorney general’s office said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Swiss authorities said on Tuesday that they had started a criminal investigation into two officials in charge of a sovereign wealth fund in Abu Dhabi, in the United Arab Emirates, as part of an inquiry into the financial transactions of the troubled Malaysian state investment fund 1Malaysia Development Berhad.

headline: I Am Not the Decorator: Female Architects Speak Out
abstract: We asked women to share their experiences working in the profession, and some 200 replied.
lead_paragraph: “For a woman to go out alone in architecture is still very, very hard,” the architect Zaha Hadid said. “It’s still a man’s world.” Ms. Hadid often stated that she did not want to serve as a symbol of progress for women in her profession. But, inevitably, she did. A study on diversity in the profession released this year by the American Institute of Architects  found that “women strongly believe that there is not gender equity in the industry”; that women and minorities say they are less likely to be promoted to more senior positions; and that gender and race are obstacles to equal pay for comparable positions. Since Ms. Hadid won the Pritzker Prize in 2004, the percentage of female architects in the United States has barely grown, increasing to 25.7 percent from 24 percent, according the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

headline: Daniel Radcliffe to Star in ‘Privacy’ at the Public Theater
abstract: “Privacy,” inspired by documents leaked by Edward Snowden, is written by James Graham and will be directed by Josie Rourke of Donmar Warehouse.
lead_paragraph: As a onetime child actor who has lived much of his life in the public eye, Daniel Radcliffe knows a thing or two about privacy.

headline: Reaching for the Stars, Across 4.37 Light-Years
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Robots and Robotics', 'Solar System', 'Laser (Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation)']
abstract: Silicon Valley scientists and billionaires announced an effort to send probes to explore Alpha Centauri, an interstellar mission that could take decades.
lead_paragraph: Can you fly an iPhone to the stars?

headline: I Sodi
abstract: Rigorous devotion to tradition at the chef Rita Sodi’s Tuscan restaurant.
lead_paragraph: Rigorous devotion to tradition at the chef Rita Sodi’s Tuscan restaurant.

headline: The Laws of Tuscan Eating at I Sodi in the West Village
abstract: Rita Sodi, the chef and owner, taps into lessons learned from the farm north of Florence where she was raised.
lead_paragraph: Medium-rare is how I ordered my tagliata, a grilled sirloin that is, like almost everything else at I Sodi, prepared the way it would be in Tuscany. Right away I changed my mind and asked for it rare. I wanted the sliding smoothness of nearly raw beef.

headline: Brian Wilson Memoir Coming in October
abstract: Mr. Wilson, of the Beach Boys, worked on the book, “I Am Brian Wilson,” with Ben Greenman.
lead_paragraph: Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys is finally ready to tell his own complicated story.

headline: Shoes That Are Made for Walking
abstract: Travelers today have their pick of footwear that’s both comfortable and stylish.
lead_paragraph: A good pair of walking shoes is a must on vacations where sightseeing by foot is on the agenda, and travelers today have their pick of footwear that’s both comfortable and stylish.

headline: John Kasich Urges Republicans to Reject Rivals’ Negativity
abstract: Addressing the Women’s National Republican Club in Midtown Manhattan, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, without naming either of his two remaining opponents for his party’s presidential nomination, drew a sharp distinction with them, both in terms of tone and policy.
lead_paragraph: Presenting himself as an uplifting alternative in a Republican race filled with fear mongering and negativity, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio urged voters on Tuesday to reject what he called the “path to darkness” in this year’s election.

headline: Paul Ryan Rules Out Run for President
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With Republicans pressing Mr. Ryan to seek the nomination, the House speaker held an unusually formal news conference to dismiss the idea.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a month of speculation and pleas ranging from comic to mildly desperate, Speaker Paul D. Ryan held an unusually formal news conference Tuesday afternoon to rule out what he has always said he would not do: serve as the Republican nominee for president in 2016.

headline: U.S. and India Agree to Strengthen Military Ties
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The two nations said they would share logistics and defense technologies in an effort to counter China’s growing influence in Asia.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The United States and India on Tuesday agreed in principle to a series of initiatives between their militaries that the Obama administration hopes will strengthen American ties in the region as it seeks to counter China’s growing influence.

headline: Blanc Vermouth, a Third Party for Cocktail Lovers
abstract: Somewhere between dry white and sweet red, the blanc style is winning an audience in America.
lead_paragraph: For a very long time in America, choosing a vermouth was simple. Like political parties, there were really just two: the sweet red ones, which originated in Italy, and the dry white ones associated with France. You used the sweet in manhattans, the dry in martinis. Done.

headline: The Next Generation of Artists’ Studios
abstract: Gone are the days of working in a clean white space, alone. Now art is being made in office buildings, factories — and even an RV.
lead_paragraph: Once, an artist holed up in her paint-spattered loft and created in solitude. These days, the idea of where an artist makes her work has changed — and so, too, the very nature of art itself.

headline: Jazz at Lincoln Center Gala to Have a Broadway Theme
abstract: Jazz at Lincoln Center will hold the “Jazz and Broadway” gala on May 9.
lead_paragraph: More than a few jazz standards got their starts on the stages of the Great White Way, so it may be fitting that Jazz at Lincoln Center’s annual gala in May, which was announced Tuesday, will be called “Jazz and Broadway.”

headline: Why Stop at One Pop of Color?
abstract: Spring’s new face colors have moved from “no-makeup makeup” to brights balanced with pretty pastels.
lead_paragraph: Some of the spring 2016 fashion shows suggested a colorful counterpoint to “no-makeup makeup.” Chanel models wore dusted-on masks of icy blue. Makeup at Roksanda and Alexis Mabille relied on a sea-foam palette. And at Giambattista Valli, the makeup artist Val Garland popped neon pink, green and blue onto the brow bone.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Win in Missouri, Officially
abstract: Hillary Clinton pulled out a tight victory over Senator Bernie Sanders in the Democratic primary in Missouri on March 15, while Donald J. Trump was declared the winner on the Republican side. The state’s vote totals, in two close races for both parties, were not made official until now.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton pulled out a tight victory over Senator Bernie Sanders in the Democratic primary in Missouri, officially sweeping the states that held primary contests on March 15, while Donald J. Trump was declared the winner in a close race with Senator Ted Cruz on the Republican side.

headline: A Sky Tells a Story for ‘The Few’
abstract: A look at artwork for a Portland, Ore., production of Samuel D. Hunter’s play that is set in a rural Idaho newspaper office.
lead_paragraph: There is no scene in the play “The Few” that takes place in front of a giant truck in the middle of a field under a strikingly cloudy blue sky. But that’s the visual direction CoHo Productions, a theater company in Portland, Ore., took for artwork promoting its production of Samuel D. Hunter’s drama, which is set inside a trailer that doubles as the office of a newspaper in rural Idaho.

headline: As Lead Levels Dip, Flint Residents Are Urged: Run Your Water
abstract: Test results pointed to slight improvement, but researchers cautioned that virtually the whole city remains a high-risk zone for contamination.
lead_paragraph: The water supply in Flint, Mich., is showing signs of improvement, but is still not safe enough for its nearly 100,000 residents to stop using bottled water and lead filters for drinking, researchers said.

headline: Conflicting Conclusions Drawn After Officers Enter a Brooklyn Apartment
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Search and Seizure']
abstract: The officers, who did not have a warrant, questioned those inside the home; the Police Department’s Internal Affairs Bureau and the Civilian Complaint Review Board disagree about the matter.
lead_paragraph: After three police officers without a warrant entered a Brooklyn apartment in March 2013 and questioned those inside, two separate investigations of the matter arrived at starkly different conclusions.

headline: Cleaner Air Tied to Fewer Lung Problems in Children
abstract: Less air pollution in Southern California has been accompanied by a significant decrease in childhood lung problems.
lead_paragraph: Air quality regulations in Southern California have led to large reductions in air pollution over the past two decades. A new study reports that the cleaner air has been accompanied by a significant decrease in childhood lung problems.

headline: Goldman Should Expect Its Stock to Stay in a Rut
abstract: Though the bank’s book value has grown, shares trade about 4 percent below their level of five and 10 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Goldman Sachs executives once boasted of being long-term greedy: They would rather wait for riches than make a quick buck. They may no longer have a choice.

headline: New Plays From Baker and Eno to Be in Signature Theater Season
abstract: The 2016-2017 season is the last one under the Signature’s founding artistic director, James Houghton.
lead_paragraph: The Signature Theater’s final season under its founding artistic director will include new plays by Annie Baker, Will Eno and Branden Jacobs-Jenkins and feature the work of Suzan-Lori Parks in its yearlong playwright-in-residency program.

headline: Benefits of Study Abroad: ‘My Students Return Transformed’
abstract: A professor writes that the experience remains an important opportunity.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Short, Turbulent Life of Al Jazeera America
abstract: The network hit the air in 2013, won several prestigious awards, but never attracted a meaningful audience, often failing to draw 30,000 viewers in prime time.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-two months ago, Al Jazeera America made its debut with ambitious plans (and a big budget) to become a leading voice in cable news. And though the network has garnered a number of prestigious awards, it never attracted a meaningful audience, often failing to draw 30,000 viewers in prime time.

headline: Long Island Is Both Hostile Territory and Fertile Ground for Donald Trump
abstract: The candidate will be counting on Long Island, a power base for New York Republicans, in next week’s primary. But he also faces a test of his broader appeal to suburban voters.
lead_paragraph: BETHPAGE, N.Y. — On Long Island, many remember Donald J. Trump from before he was a reality television star, a presidential candidate or a serial provocateur. He was the builder of shining towers just west over the horizon in the city. The shrewd buyer of New Jersey casinos. The can-do tycoon who fixed up Central Park’s ice skating rink when the chuckleheads downtown could not.

headline: Loathe Gefilte Fish? Not After You’ve Tried This
abstract: It’s worth making the real thing, which bears little resemblance to the stuff sold in jars.
lead_paragraph: Next Thursday, the day before the annual ritual of our Seder, I celebrate what has become another annual ritual: our “gefilte fish-in.”

headline: Baltimore After Freddie Gray: The ‘Mind-Set Has Changed’
abstract: A year after the arrest of Freddie Gray, correspondents who have covered events in Baltimore since then took stock of the city’s mood and politics.
lead_paragraph: A year ago on Tuesday, Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man, was arrested in West Baltimore. His death a week later, from a spinal cord injury he sustained while in police custody, set off looting and violence, and political uncertainty. Now Baltimore is about to pick a new leader — the primary election in a crowded mayoral race will be held April 26 — and on May 10, the long-stalled trials of six police officers charged in Mr. Gray’s death are scheduled to resume.

headline: David Gest, Music Producer and Reality TV Star, Dies at 62
abstract: Mr. Gest, who was briefly married to Liza Minnelli, was a constant presence on British television, as a guest in a reality series and as the star of his own show.
lead_paragraph: David Gest, a concert promoter and television producer who gained fleeting fame for his brief marriage to Liza Minnelli and went on to become a reality television star in Britain, died on Tuesday in London. He was 62.

headline: When Campaigning for the U.N. Job Was Gauche
abstract: A former under secretary general writes about two cases in which the candidates for secretary general did not lobby for the position.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Facebook Bets on Bots for Its Messenger App
abstract: The social giant is opening up its messaging app so that any outside company, like Applebee’s or 1-800-Flowers, can create a bot capable of interacting with real people.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — To browse for a pair of brown loafers on Facebook Messenger, you can now text a message to the service to begin a conversation with the mobile shopping start-up Spring. Spring will ask you for a preferred price range for the shoes and show a smattering of what it thinks you might like. If the selection elicits yawns, Spring will try some different options.

headline: Yale Advances in Shaping Portfolio to Address Climate Change
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Endowments', 'Global Warming', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions']
abstract: Yale’s chief investment officer says overseers of its endowment have taken steps to assess companies’ steps in reducing greenhouse emissions.
lead_paragraph: Yale University has made progress in minimizing its endowment portfolio’s exposure to less environmentally sound investments such as stocks of companies that contribute to climate change, a letter released on Tuesday showed.

headline: At L’Appart in Battery Park City, You’ll Feel at Home
abstract: Also, Tim Powell offers food for delivery, Desi Galli opens a second location, Galen Zamarra is closing Almanac, and more.
lead_paragraph: L’Appart This well-upholstered 28-seat enclave within Le District, the sprawl of markets and restaurants in Battery Park City, is designed to suggest an informal dinner party — hence the name, a shortening of the French for apartment. When guests enter, the headwaiter, George Thomas, whom you may recognize from his many years at Bouley, offers an aperitif or a glass of Champagne. “It’s like what happens when you go to someone’s home,” he said. The room is fitted with an open kitchen where the chef, Nicolas Abello — who worked with Gérard Vié in France, Pierre Gagnaire in London and Daniel Boulud in New York — prepares a six-course French-accented tasting menu. (He has access to the more than 2,500 ingredients that Le District carries.) Jordi Vallès, Le District’s culinary director, oversees the restaurant. There are options for expanding the number of courses and matching them with wines. (Opens April 20): Brookfield Place, 225 Liberty Street (West Street), 212-981-8577, lappartnyc.com.

headline: Rembrandt Portrait Denied Export License Will Be Shown in Britain
abstract: The work was sold through Sotheby’s in a private sale in June 2015, and the buyer applied for an export license; last fall, the British culture minister barred its export, hoping to find a British buyer to match the price and keep it in the country.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — A Rembrandt portrait that the British government had temporarily prohibited from leaving the country after it was bought by a foreign collector will remain on display in Britain for three years.

headline: Rise of Institutional Investors Raises Questions of Collusion
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Big investors hold large stakes in many companies in the same industry, leading the Justice Department to scrutinize competition and pricing.
lead_paragraph: BlackRock, Vanguard and other big institutional investors own roughly 70 percent of the public stock market, according to some reports. People are starting to ask whether this allows companies — now having the same owners — to compete less and raise prices.

headline: N.C.A.A. Extends Basketball Deal With CBS Sports and Turner Through 2032
abstract: The eight-year deal extends the existing contract, which was set to run through 2024, for an additional $8.8 billion.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A. announced a new agreement on Tuesday with CBS Sports and Turner that extended the broadcast rights deal for the Division I men’s basketball tournament another eight years, through 2032, at a rate that will eventually increase to more than $1 billion per year.

headline: Wielding Paintbrushes, Not Spray Cans, at Bronx Housing Project
abstract: A mural program called Public Art/Public Housing is being conducted in five New York City low-income housing projects with high rates of violent crime.
lead_paragraph: Many residents of the Castle Hill Houses, a sprawling housing development in the Bronx, live with windows that are old and drafty, interior doors that no longer close and kitchen appliances that have seen better days.

headline: Mission to Alpha Centauri
abstract: The cosmologist Stephen Hawking and the entrepreneur Yuri Milner released a simulation that shows how a project called Breakthrough Starshot aims to send small robots to the nearest star system, Alpha Centauri.
lead_paragraph: The cosmologist Stephen Hawking and the entrepreneur Yuri Milner released a simulation that shows how a project called Breakthrough Starshot aims to send small robots to the nearest star system, Alpha Centauri.

headline: T’s Salone del Mobile Party at Palazzo Crespi
abstract: We celebrated the biggest week in design — and the 100th birthday of Renzo Mongiardino — Monday night in Milan.
lead_paragraph: We celebrated the biggest week in design — and the 100th birthday of Renzo Mongiardino — Monday night in Milan.

headline: T Celebrates Salone del Mobile in Milan
abstract: We fêted the biggest week in design — and the 100th birthday of Renzo Mongiardino — at the Palazzo Crespi.
lead_paragraph: What better way to spend a beautiful evening in Milan than on the terrace of a grand palazzo, taking in the scent of wisteria in full bloom? T was lucky last night to do just that, at a party hosted by editor-in-chief Deborah Needleman along with Roberto Peregalli and Laura Sartori Rimini of the design firm Studio Peregalli in celebration of this year’s Salone Internazionale del Mobile — the design world’s biggest week. Guests including Camilla Guinness, Tom Dixon, Teresa and Margherita Missoni, Francesco Bonami and Maurizio Cattelan milled about the Palazzo Crespi and its backyard, enjoying drinks, conversation, spring weather and a ballroom piano performance by Michele Sganga.

headline: Puerto Rico’s Prosperous D.C. Power Couple
abstract: Pedro Pierluisi, the commissioner to Congress from Puerto Rico, has introduced legislation that could benefit companies that have hired his wife.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Puerto Rico has spiraled toward possible bankruptcy, the island’s sole representative in Congress has seen his family wealth swell, thanks in part to Wall Street companies that have sought to capitalize on the island’s financial crisis and have hired his wife to advise them.

headline: Lawyers Again Question Prosecution’s Conduct in 2003 Murder Case
abstract: Lawyers for John Giuca, a Brooklyn man convicted of murdering a Fairfield University student, are claiming that evidence was withheld and jurors were misled.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for John Giuca, a Brooklyn man convicted more than a decade ago of murdering a 19-year-old college student, continued their assault against the verdict on Tuesday, filing papers that — again — claim prosecutors withheld important evidence and misled jurors at his trial.

headline: Maduro on Rejected Amnesty Law
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Political Prisoners', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela made a statement after the country’s Supreme Court declared unconstitutional legislation to free politicians who are foes of his socialist government.
lead_paragraph: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela made a statement after the country’s Supreme Court declared unconstitutional legislation to free politicians who are foes of his socialist government.

headline: Climate Change Hits Hard in Zambia, an African Success Story
keywords: ['Drought', 'Levees and Dams', 'Hydroelectric Power', 'Global Warming', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Power Failures and Blackouts']
abstract: Because of severe drought magnified by climate change, the Kariba Dam is generating so little juice that blackouts are hurting the nation’s businesses.
lead_paragraph: LAKE KARIBA, Zambia — Even as drought and the effects of climate change grew visible across this land, the Kariba Dam was always a steady, and seemingly limitless, source of something rare in Africa: electricity so cheap and plentiful that Zambia could export some to its neighbors.

headline: Wildfires, Once Confined to a Season, Burn Earlier and Longer
abstract: Increasingly, fire crews are making calculated decisions to let blazes consume the land, concentrating their efforts on safeguarding communities and watersheds.
lead_paragraph: The first Alaska wildfire of 2016 broke out in late February, followed by a second there just eight days later.

headline: Did Led Zeppelin Steal ‘Stairway to Heaven’? A Jury Will Decide
abstract: A federal judge in Los Angeles ruled that it will be up to jurors to determine whether the song stole elements of “Taurus,” a track from the band Spirit.
lead_paragraph: The Led Zeppelin song “Stairway to Heaven” is one of the most ubiquitous (some might say overplayed) songs on classic rock radio. Next month, a jury will decide whether the song’s opening was stolen from another band.

headline: How Men’s Bathing Suits Changed Over 100 Years
abstract: A new show at LACMA explores the evolution from cumbersome swimming costumes to the Gucci thong.
lead_paragraph: “Reigning Men: Fashion in Menswear: 1715-2015,” an expansive new show of men’s fashion through the years, opens at LACMA this week. The exhibition (which took the museum almost five years to produce) features everything from sans-culotte trousers of the French Revolution to mid-’50s Varsity jackets and the Jean Paul Gaultier men’s corsetry of the early 1990s. One section focuses on the development of men’s swimwear — from the cumbersome, two-piece bathing suits of the mid-19th century to Tom Ford’s skimpy thong for Gucci in 1997. As Kaye Spilker, curator of LACMA’s Costume and Textiles department, put it, men’s suits “go from totally dressed to almost totally nude — and then back to almost totally dressed again.” Roll over the images above and below to trace the evolution of men’s swimsuits over more than 100 years.

headline: Lifting the Patent Barrier to New Drugs and Energy Sources
keywords: ['Inventions and Patents', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Global Warming', 'Malaria', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Intellectual Property']
abstract: Strict patents on technology have had the effect of hindering global progress in some fields, especially in combating disease and climate change.
lead_paragraph: Malaria has preyed on humans for centuries. Hundreds of thousands of children die each year from the disease. Considering the market’s size, why haven’t pharmaceutical companies rushed to develop a vaccine against the deadly parasite that causes it?

headline: Settlement Talks Impeded in Redstone Mental Health Suit
abstract: The snag comes after a framework of a settlement was reached last week in the suit filed by Manuela Herzer, a former companion of Sumner Redstone, the media mogul.
lead_paragraph: Settlement negotiations have hit a snag in the lawsuit challenging the mental competence of the ailing media mogul Sumner M. Redstone, reviving the possibility that the case could proceed to a messy public trial.

headline: New York 101: Pulling Back the Curtain on What Powers the City
keywords: ['Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Water', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES']
abstract: How the multimedia, multi-platform series — about everything from the city’s water system to its public library — was conceived and brought to life.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, the Metro reporter Emily S. Rueb explains how the multimedia, multi-platform New York 101 series — about everything from how water gets to the city’s taps to how a single book moves through its public library system — was conceived and brought to life.

headline: North Carolina Governor’s Order Restoring Some Anti-Bias Protections
abstract: Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina signed an executive order altering the equal employment policy for state workers to cover discrimination claims related to sexual orientation and gender identity.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina signed an executive order altering the equal employment policy for state workers to cover discrimination claims related to sexual orientation and gender identity.

headline: Judge Rules Camille Cosby Must Testify Again in Civil Case
abstract: Magistrate Judge David H. Hennessy denied Mrs. Cosby’s request to cancel a second session of the deposition in a civil suit filed against Bill Cosby.
lead_paragraph: Camille O. Cosby will have to testify again in a civil case filed against her husband, Bill Cosby, by seven women who say he defamed them, a federal judge in Massachusetts ruled Tuesday.

headline: North Carolina Governor Tries to Step Back From Bias Law
keywords: ['Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Government Employees', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A provision limiting transgender people’s bathroom access stands, but Gov. Pat McCrory has signed an executive order to allow discrimination claims.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina, whose state has been the subject of withering criticism since he signed legislation limiting bathroom access for transgender people and eliminating anti-discrimination ordinances based on sexual orientation, announced Tuesday that he would strengthen workplace protections for state employees and urge the General Assembly to modify part of the law.

headline: Controlled Burn on the Rio Grande
abstract: One of the only ways to remove giant cane on the Rio Grande in Big Bend National Park in Texas is by intentionally burning it. A group of American and Mexican firefighters burned 110 acres of it in a remote stretch of the border, as part of a river conservation project.
lead_paragraph: One of the only ways to remove giant cane on the Rio Grande in Big Bend National Park in Texas is by intentionally burning it. A group of American and Mexican firefighters burned 110 acres of it in a remote stretch of the border, as part of a river conservation project.

headline: Shabab and East African Front Militants Compete for Notoriety
abstract: A new group called the East African Front has publicly insulted the Shabab. That group has fought back with a gruesome video of its battle tactics.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Apparently there is no brotherly love among East Africa’s Islamist militants.

headline: 2016 N.H.L. Playoffs: East to West, the Chase for the Cup Begins
abstract: The Washington Capitals dominated this season like few teams in history. But the team with the most regular-season victories rarely wins the Stanley Cup.
lead_paragraph: Few teams in the N.H.L. have had a more dominant regular season than the 2015-16 Washington Capitals. They were a juggernaut, posting 120 points and losing only 18 games in regulation. Braden Holtby tied Martin Brodeur’s N.H.L. single-season record for wins (48), and Washington’s lead atop the Metropolitan Division did not dip below 10 points after Dec. 26.

headline: Pope Francis’ New Teaching on the Family
abstract: Readers discuss the document and react to a column by Ross Douthat.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: In ‘The Last Panthers,’ Old-School Crime Is Breaking Out Across Europe
abstract: This SundanceTV mini-series is a grim study of the continent’s underworld, where the sun never shines, laughter is extinct, and everything is brown or gray.
lead_paragraph: Given that “The Last Panthers” involves the pursuit of criminals through back alleys and anonymous-looking apartment complexes all over Europe, the most striking thing about it initially is the word that it rarely, if ever, uses: terrorism. Recent headlines might make it seem, at least from the American perspective, as if terror were the only crime Europe deals with. But this intricate six-part mini-series, which starts Wednesday on SundanceTV, is grounded in old-school illegalities.

headline: Panel Calls for Major Changes at Texas Jail That Held Sandra Bland
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: A review committee formed after the death of the 28-year-old black woman has recommended reforms in the treatment and medical screening of inmates at the Waller County jail.
lead_paragraph: HEMPSTEAD, Tex. — A panel reviewing the Texas jail where a 28-year-old black woman, Sandra Bland, was found dead three days after being arrested in July has called for major changes in the treatment and medical screening of inmates.

headline: The Donald Trump Rally
abstract: The faces of the movement.
lead_paragraph: The faces of the movement.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Quentin Hardy, Steven Erlanger and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Graffiti Artist Defaces Fashion Ads, Fashion Embraces Him
abstract: Michael De Feo is making a name for himself by painting his graffiti flowers over fashion ads at local bus shelters.
lead_paragraph: On any given day in Manhattan, commuters will run into Michael De Feo.

headline: North Korea Threatens South Korea Over 13 Defectors
abstract: The North on Tuesday warned the South that it would “face unimaginable serious consequences and severe punishment” if it did not repatriate the group.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea on Tuesday accused South Korea of kidnapping 13 of its citizens who had been working in a restaurant in China, and it demanded their repatriation.

headline: The ‘Peace Pentagon,’ an Activist Office in NoHo, Is Forced to Move
abstract: Unable to pay for repairs, the Muste Institute sold its building in NoHo last year, and now groups like the War Resisters League are heading downtown.
lead_paragraph: For decades, members of left-leaning groups have used a pale brick building in Lower Manhattan as a base to work on campaigns and plan protest rallies. But a recent meeting concerned a different sort of logistics.

headline: How to Make Sense of the Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: Like many other 15-year-olds in New York, the festival is an unruly, hyperactive creature with an overstuffed schedule.
lead_paragraph: Like many other 15-year-olds in New York, the Tribeca Film Festival is an unruly, hyperactive creature with an overstuffed schedule. Five main categories including Spotlight (nearly 40 films), Viewpoints (25) and the documentary competition (12), a genre-film mini-fest, filmmaker talks, interactive storytelling experiences, a virtual reality bazaar, a new television section, a street fair — how can you possibly choose what to see?

headline: Romanian Ballet Company Loses Its Leading Lights
abstract: A series of missteps cost the Romanian national ballet company on Tuesday its artistic director, Johan Kobborg, and the dancer Alina Cojocaru.
lead_paragraph: Administrative tumult, a prominent snub on the Bucharest National Opera’s website and questions over artistic direction have cost the Romanian national ballet company its two biggest stars: Johan Kobborg and Alina Cojocaru. Mr. Kobborg resigned Tuesday as its artistic director and his fiancée, the dancer Ms. Cojocaru, said she would not dance under the current management.

headline: Bill Clinton Is Wrong About His Crime Bill. So Are the Protesters He Lectured.
abstract: Debating the 1994 law is, by and large, empty symbolism — and a distraction from real reform.
lead_paragraph: Last Thursday, at a rally for his wife in Philadelphia, Bill Clinton found himself confronted by Black Lives Matter protesters. Their signs and shouts focused on one of the former president’s own legacies: the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act, which he pushed through Congress in 1994, and which protesters argued helped drive mass incarceration. Clinton, at his lectern, responded to that notion vigorously, over 15 angry minutes of shouts, interruptions and retorts. “Because of that bill,” he argued, “we had a 25-year low in crime, a 33-year low in the murder rate, and because of that and the background-check law, we had a 46-year low in deaths of people by gun violence.” As more shouts rose from the audience, he went so far as to tell the protesters, “You are defending the people who killed the lives you say matter.”

headline: Review: ‘Maestra,’ a Novel of Sex, Murder and Shopping
abstract: L.S. Hilton’s thriller follows a young art world denizen as she hooks up with billionaires and commits the occasional killing in pursuit of empowerment.
lead_paragraph: Advances in publishing industry marketing have allowed G. P. Putnam’s Sons to bring forth “Maestra,” a pornographic shopathon travelogue thriller that has billionaires, art world scheming and a sociopathic heroine who can unfasten belt buckles with her tongue. It should go without saying that this book is part of a trilogy, is headed for the movies and has created a stir in countries where it has already appeared. As one reader reasonably put it on Amazon.uk’s website: “This book’s pomposity is unbelievable and the sex is ludicrous. Will sell millions.” Right now its sales on that site are sinking, and it’s selling only decently. But point taken.

headline: Asking Whether Copland’s Abstruse Works are the Exception or the Rule
abstract: This question will be raised once more on Wednesday, when Michael Tilson Thomas leads the San Francisco Symphony in a triptych of his thornier works at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: When Gustavo Dudamel and the Los Angeles Philharmonic visited “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” last month, it was only natural that they performed Aaron Copland’s “Fanfare for the Common Man” (1942). Is there any work more emblematic of the dean of American music than the stirring “Fanfare,” which Mr. Colbert called “one of the most powerful American melodies”?

headline: Review: David Gilmour Lays Claim to Pink Floyd Memories
abstract: At Madison Square Garden, Mr. Gilmour sang numbers from his latest album, “Rattle That Lock,” but the slow-tempo oldies were the audience favorites.
lead_paragraph: David Gilmour released an album last year, “Rattle That Lock,” that reached No. 5 on Billboard’s album chart. But that’s not why he could book three big New York City shows: two at Madison Square Garden, where I saw him perform on Monday night, and one at Radio City Music Hall. Mr. Gilmour is the proud custodian of the sound of Pink Floyd, in which he was the guitarist, main lead singer and — after Roger Waters, the main songwriter and bassist before him, left the band in 1985 — the full-fledged bandleader.

headline: How ‘Horace and Pete’ Made the Network Suits Look Good
abstract: Louis C.K.’s pay-per-episode series, set at a family-owned bar, is a riveting show with a stellar cast, but total freedom has its dangers.
lead_paragraph: Have we been too hard on the soulless network suit?

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing: Paul Ryan, North Carolina, Equal Pay Day
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: ‘Class Divide’ Shows the Extremes Hypergentrification Creates in a Neighborhood
abstract: This Marc Levin documentary centers on a single intersection in Manhattan: on one side, public housing; on the other side, an elite private school.
lead_paragraph: Gentrification is not usually the stuff of vivid, gripping documentaries. The impacts typically arrive too slowly, the changes too incremental to register on the lives they eventually affect.

headline: Pepsi-Cola Sign in Queens Gains Landmark Status
abstract: After nearly 30 years under consideration, the sign, a four-story reminder of Long Island City’s industrial past, is now protected.
lead_paragraph: The Pepsi-Cola sign in Long Island City — a dazzling swirl of red curlicue letters that evokes innocent days of summer, heavy industry in Queens and a spectacular disregard for the waterfront in the mid-20th century — is now an official New York City landmark.

headline: In North Carolina and Mississippi, Backlash Grows Over Rights Law
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Gov. Pat McCrory of North Carolina backed off some elements of a law seen as curbing gay rights, but corporations and politicians have taken action over the legislation.
lead_paragraph: When Bruce Springsteen canceled a concert in Greensboro, N.C., last weekend to protest a state law that many said curbed gay and transgender rights, it was only the latest fallout from the measure. Like similar legislation in Mississippi, it has drawn criticism across the country.

headline: D.E.A. Employees Facing Trial Seek to Bar Lap-Dance Video
abstract: Prosecutors want to use the evidence against an ex-official of the agency and a civilian worker accused of lying about their ownership of a New Jersey strip club.
lead_paragraph: It is not often that the government seeks to show a jury a video of lap dances.

headline: Oscar Murillo Says Flushing His Passport in Midflight Didn’t Start as a Protest
abstract: This Colombian artist, back in London after being detained in Sydney and deported to Singapore, said he wants “to engage different power structures.”
lead_paragraph: Was it art, protest — or both?

headline: Steve Earle: The Other Side of Merle Haggard
abstract: As a kid who got beat up to the sounds of “Okie From Muskogee,” I wanted to hate Hag. But I couldn’t.
lead_paragraph: In late 1969 and early 1970, when “Okie From Muskogee” was blaring from every jukebox in every beer joint, truck stop and restaurant in my hometown, San Antonio, I wanted, sometimes very much, to hate Merle Haggard.

headline: Hillary Clinton Puts Racially Charged Skit on Bill de Blasio’s Shoulders
abstract: “Well, look, it was Mayor de Blasio’s skit,” said Mrs. Clinton, who is courting black voters in the New York primary.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s response to a racially charged comedy sketch with Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York on Saturday night was simple: It’s all his fault.

headline: ‘We Shall Overcome’ Copyright May Be Overcome One Day
keywords: ['Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Music', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A nonprofit group is seeking to have the famous protest song declared in the public domain and licensing fees returned.
lead_paragraph: Last year, a federal judge ruled that the long-claimed copyright to the song “Happy Birthday to You” was invalid. Now the same could happen for another iconic tune: “We Shall Overcome.”

headline: Hollywood Discovers That It May Be Missing Out on Date Night
abstract: The Motion Picture Association of America’s annual report on the moviegoing public showed a sharp drop in per capita attendance among 18- to 24-year-olds.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Behind the big numbers in the Motion Picture Association of America’s annual report on moviegoing — global ticket sales grew 5 percent in 2015, to $38.3 billion — lie some surprising snapshots about who is, and is not, going to the movies.

headline: A Loving Look at Hispanic New Mexican Life
abstract: Soon after arriving in New Mexico in 1981, Kevin Bubriski was entranced by the generations-old culture and traditions of Hispano Nuevomexicanos, whose roots stretch back to the 1500s.
lead_paragraph: Soon after arriving in New Mexico in 1981, Kevin Bubriski was entranced by the generations-old culture and traditions of Hispano Nuevomexicanos, whose roots stretch back to the 1500s.

headline: Protests Erupt in Macedonia as President Halts Wiretapping Inquiry
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: A special prosecutor had been investigating allegations of widespread corruption in government, but President Gjorge Ivanov issued a blanket pardon.
lead_paragraph: SKOPJE, Macedonia — The president of Macedonia abruptly ended a far-reaching criminal investigation into corruption and abuse of power throughout the government on Tuesday, plunging the tiny Balkan country into a political crisis.

headline: A Clash of Old and New in a Manhattan Real Estate Prairie
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Evictions', 'Rent Control and Stabilization', 'Chinese-Americans', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Landlords']
abstract: Soaring real estate values have led to lawsuits by a developer who wants the residents out of 83 and 85 Bowery, claiming they are not protected by rent laws.
lead_paragraph: Stacked on the chipped tile floor of the vestibule at 85 Bowery were 59 boxes, each addressed to John Doe or Jane Doe.

headline: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York City.
lead_paragraph: $13.75 million

headline: Aid Groups Aim to Put Mental Health on World Agenda
abstract: The first global estimate of the potential returns on investing in treatments for depression and anxiety was released as conferees met in Washington this week.
lead_paragraph: Good mental health care is scarce in many parts of the United States, but it is nonexistent in most of the world. In developing countries, the ratio of mental health professionals to citizens is about one in a million — and that vast majority of people with treatable conditions like anxiety and depression are left to their own devices, or to the ministrations of local folk healers.

headline: Ford’s Planned New Headquarters Borrow Some Silicon Valley Sheen
abstract: Ford Motor tries to shed Rust Belt image as it makes over its headquarter buildings in Dearborn, Mich., into a high-tech campus.
lead_paragraph: Over the past year, Ford Motor has raced to develop self-driving cars, put down roots in Silicon Valley and backed ride-sharing start-ups — all in an effort to be seen as not just a car manufacturer but a “mobility company.” Its goal is to emulate the likes of Google and Tesla Motors as it aims to shape the future of getting from place to place.

headline: Nebraska Legislature Rejects Winner-Take-All Electoral Vote System
abstract: The current system allows for Electoral College votes to be split between candidates and parties, and gives Democrats a chance to win a vote in a conservative state.
lead_paragraph: LINCOLN, Neb. — For at least one more presidential election, this overwhelmingly Republican state will keep a system that allows it to split its Electoral College votes between candidates and parties, after a conservative-backed effort to adopt a winner-take-all system stalled in the Legislature on Tuesday.

headline: J. Thomas Rosch, Lawyer, Dies at 76; Fought for and Against Antitrust Actions
abstract: President George W. Bush made Mr. Rosch an F.T.C. commissioner after he spent years defending companies from government antitrust actions.
lead_paragraph: J. Thomas Rosch, a lawyer who spent years defending corporations from government antitrust actions before taking the other side as a member of the Federal Trade Commission, died on March 30 in Lake Forest, Ill. He was 76.

headline: Lower Growth Expectations Cloud World Finance Leaders’ Forum
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Taxation', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: As the International Monetary Fund and World Bank convened, the fund forecast a 3.2 percent global expansion, lower than it projected in January.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The world’s finance ministers opened their annual spring meeting here on Tuesday facing dampened expectations for global growth and warnings about financial risks and political movements toward nationalism and protectionism — in the United States and abroad.

headline: With Blistering Kick, Manchester City Rights a Choppy Season
abstract: City erased the French power Paris St.-Germain with a 1-0 home win, winning on aggregate, 3-2, and advanced to the cusp of the Champions League final.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, England — The coach already knows he will not return. One top player seems to have a foot out the door. Much of the rest of the team are, understandably, unsure who will have a job and who will not come summer. And, with the Premier League title long since out of reach, there has been a palpable turn of the head toward the future for many of those in and around Manchester City during the past few months.

headline: A Few Words About Vin Scully, a Storyteller Who Has Seen It All
abstract: As the Dodgers rebuild their team, Scully embarks on his final season in the broadcast booth.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The first baseball game played at 1000 Vin Scully Avenue began on Tuesday with a relay. One by one, hallowed members of the Los Angeles Dodgers passed an autographed ball from the pitcher’s mound to the plate. Magic Johnson, a co-owner, presented it to Scully, who has spent 67 seasons passing down baseball.

headline: Syria’s Partial Cease-Fire Shows Signs of Crumbling
abstract: Ground clashes and airstrikes intensified as the government promised a new offensive and prepared to hold controversial parliamentary elections.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — A fragile and partial cease-fire in Syria is coming under new strains, with ground clashes and airstrikes intensifying as the government promises a new offensive and prepares to hold controversial parliamentary elections on Wednesday.

headline: National Briefing
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Police Commission says the shooting of an unarmed homeless man last year in the Venice area was unjustified. The commission ruled Tuesday that Officer Clifford Proctor violated department policy when he shot 29-year-old Brendon Glenn in the back near the Venice boardwalk in May. Officer Proctor told investigators that Mr. Glenn had grabbed his partner’s holster as they struggled on the ground, but a report from Police Chief Charlie Beck said surveillance video from a nearby bar contradicted the account. Chief Beck has recommended that the officer face criminal charges — the first time he has made such a recommendation over a deadly officer-involved shooting. Mr. Glenn’s family is suing over the death. A lawyer for the Glenn family could not be reached for comment. (AP)

headline: Bill to Ease Puerto Rico Debt Crisis Introduced in House
abstract: Legislation that would grant certain powers normally available in bankruptcy is set for final amendments on Thursday before being sent to the floor.
lead_paragraph: Legislation to help Puerto Rico restructure its $72 billion in debt was introduced in the House of Representatives on Tuesday, as members sought to address the island’s financial crisis quickly without setting a precedent that troubled states might try to follow.

headline: National Weather Service: Forecasts ‘Will Stop Yelling at You’
abstract: The forecasts have long been issued in all capital letters, but in the Internet age, those messages can look hysterical. Next month, the service will adopt mixed-case lettering.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For as long as the federal government has been in the business of forecasting weather, it has done so in capital letters.

headline: British Minister Admits Dating Woman in Sex Industry
abstract: John Whittingdale, who as culture minister oversees the nation’s news media, said tabloid newspapers knew about the woman’s occupation before he did.
lead_paragraph: The British minister of culture said on Tuesday that he previously dated a woman who was working in the sex industry and that tabloid newspapers had known her true occupation before he did — raising questions about whether his role as a government minister with oversight of the nation’s news media had been compromised.

headline: Why Mrs. Clinton Needs to Say More About the Crime Bill
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Minorities', 'Youth', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Hillary Clinton should put the 1994 law in context, including its reflection of a pragmatic governing style that she would use with Congress.
lead_paragraph: In 1992, Bill Clinton ran on the promise of “two for the price of one”: If he was elected, Americans would also get Hillary Clinton, lawyer and activist Democrat, working for them in the White House.

headline: Venezuela’s Court Deals Another Blow to Opposition Lawmakers
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons']
abstract: The Supreme Court’s rejection of a bill freeing about 120 political prisoners left some wondering whether lawmakers who are pushing for change have any real power.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — When Venezuela’s opposition took control of the National Assembly this year, lawmakers vowed to use their powers to steer the country far from the legacy of former President Hugo Chávez.

headline: From Hiroshima to a Nuke-Free World
keywords: ['Editorials', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: President Obama can be the first American president to stop at the war memorial when he travels to Japan next month.
lead_paragraph: What Secretary of State John Kerry called his “gut wrenching” visit to the Hiroshima war memorial on Monday served several purposes. As the highest-ranking official in an American administration ever to visit the site, he paid respects to the victims of one of the most devastating acts of World War II and reflected on how Japan and the United States have forged a strong alliance over the past 70 years. He also emphasized that “war must never be the first resort” and urged a continued push for a world free from nuclear weapons.

headline: How Stephen Hawking Thought About Humanity’s Limits
abstract: The renowned physicist spoke of transcending humanity’s limitations through advanced technology, using robot spacecraft to reach the nearest star system.
lead_paragraph: The renowned physicist spoke of transcending humanity’s limitations through advanced technology, using robot spacecraft to reach the nearest star system.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, April 13, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “If no candidate has the majority on the first ballot, I believe you should only turn to a person who has participated in the primary. Count me out.”

headline: Donald Trump, Losing Ground, Tries to Blame the System
abstract: Mr. Trump and his allies are trying to compensate for organizational deficiencies by framing the Republican primary process as rigged and corrupt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump and his allies are engaged in an aggressive effort to undermine the Republican nominating process by framing it as rigged and corrupt, hoping to compensate for organizational deficiencies that have left Mr. Trump with an increasingly precarious path to the nomination.

headline: Bernienomics Might Not Be Feasible — But It’s Useful
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Inequality', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: From the perspective of traditional economics, Bernie Sanders’s ideas are wildly unlikely, but there’s value in his pie-in-the-sky vision.
lead_paragraph: Surprisingly, for such an odd and difficult man, Thorstein Veblen represented a high point in American optimism. Veblen was trained in economics but spent much of his career in the margins of the field, preferring instead to look at society more broadly, through the lens of anthropology and Darwinism. Social institutions, he argued, were like species; they evolved, following paths set down by previous generations. The economists of his day, like those of today, argued that wages and prices were determined by the corresponding desires of buyers and sellers to trade. Veblen largely rejected this idea, arguing instead that modern people still carried with them their barbarian past, in which violent warrior kings subjugated peasants. The warrior kings had become aristocrats and businesspeople, while the peasants were, of course, the workers.

headline: Questlove Is Feeling the Bern (Kinda)

headline: What’s a European Liberal to Do?
abstract: Among progressives in France, confusion reigns over how to balance secularism, tolerance and fear of fundamentalists.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Sunday, Air France will resume regular flights to Tehran. For its female flight attendants and pilots, there is a catch: On arrival, they will be asked to wear not only the most conservative version of their uniform, a pantsuit with a knee-length jacket, but also a head scarf to cover their hair, in line with Iranian law and with other foreign airlines’ practice. The unions have protested. “This is contrary to what I stand for as a woman,” an Air France flight attendant complained in Le Figaro Madame. The company quickly gave in. Only those comfortable with the requirements will fly the Paris-Tehran route.

headline: An Easy Way to Prevent Blisters? Try Tape
abstract: Applying ordinary paper tape, a common component of first-aid kits, can be an inexpensive way to prevent the blisters that can arise from running a marathon.
lead_paragraph: Exercise science today is exploring countless mysterious, exciting and poetic aspects of human physiology and performance. But sometimes you just wish that someone would tell you how to keep your feet from hurting. A wonderfully practical new study obliges, providing the first reliable, field-tested evidence about how to prevent blisters during prolonged exercise. Anyone running next week’s Boston Marathon, you’re welcome.

headline: Where’s the Magic in Family Dinner?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Regular meals serve as an easily measured proxy for one of longest-standing and sturdiest determinants of adolescent well-being: authoritative parenting.
lead_paragraph: Like many families, we strive to eat dinner together as often as possible. And when my husband and I meet our tween and her younger sister at the table, we sometimes have worthwhile conversations or manage to crack each other up. But, at least as often, dinner devolves into a failing effort to find out what happened at school or a nag-fest over mealtime manners. After an especially short or harried supper, I can find myself wondering how the family gathering that just transpired could possibly help to raise my daughters’ grades, improve their psychological well-being or lower their risk of substance abuse.

headline: Must a Mental Illness Be Revealed on a First Date?
keywords: ['Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Grading of Students', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on when to share a history of mental health problems with a prospective partner, whether it’s fair to hold a student whom you’ve taught before to a higher standard and outing a parent.
lead_paragraph: I have struggled with mental illness, off and on, for most of my life. It can be debilitating and has resulted in numerous hospitalizations. I also have extensive scarring on my arms from self-harm episodes. But I have a successful career and fully support myself; most people who know me have no idea that I am mentally ill. After ending a decade-long relationship, I am now thinking of dating again. My question is: At what point do I disclose my mental illness, its history and its effects? At what point do I “explain” my scars? Do I have an obligation to reveal this information on the first or second date, before any attachment forms, so that any potential partner can “opt out”? Name Withheld
