headline: Judge John Hodgman on Trolling Your Own Wedding
abstract: Do you take this doofus to be your husband?
lead_paragraph: Andrew writes: I am very fun, and I earnestly want to Jet-Ski into my wedding ceremony to the tune of “The Final Countdown,” possibly accompanied by pyrotechnics. I would also like to wear my pet lizard as a boutonniere. My fiancée rejects these ideas. Will no fun be had on this special day?

headline: Captivated by the Ganges, a River of Souls
abstract: On the sacred Ganges near Varanasi, the writer puts aside his camera and notebook, and is enveloped in the moment. “On this river I had no name.”
lead_paragraph: We started through narrow alleys at 5 a.m., moving past somnolent cows curled against doorways and gaunt dogs on steps and women in saris moving toward us through the gloom, a motorbike vrooming in the distance.

headline: News About Obamacare Has Been Bad Lately. How Bad?
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare']
abstract: Two Times reporters, Reed Abelson and Margot Sanger-Katz, talk about the Affordable Care Act’s recent setbacks and future.
lead_paragraph: Ever since passage of the Affordable Care Act, a fierce debate has been waged over whether the law would work as advertised. While advocates promised that the design of new insurance markets would transform the way consumers buy health insurance, critics warned that the new market would never succeed. Reed Abelson and Margot Sanger-Katz have had front-row seats to the debate, and the two reporters took a few minutes to discuss when — and if — the market would stabilize.

headline: After Two New York Flops, Cirque du Soleil Bets Big on Broadway
abstract: Determined to bring a long-running production to New York, the company mounts a $25 million musical called “Paramour.”
lead_paragraph: The dancer emerges from stage left, in white tails and top hat; from stage right comes a juggler in a black tuxedo. And then begins a choreographic throwdown — the dancer taps, the juggler balances a cane on his nose — a prelude to the best-of-both-worlds spectacle promised behind the Art Deco curtain.

headline: So Much for Britain’s Wage Increase
abstract: For many people, bigger paychecks will be canceled out by cuts in public spending for low-income households.
lead_paragraph: The minimum wage is going up in Britain, from 6.70 pounds an hour ($9.45) to £7.20 this month and £9 by 2020.

headline: Real Madrid’s Emergency Strategy: Leave It to Cristiano Ronaldo
abstract: It is impossible to imagine Real Madrid getting out of the hole it had dug for itself in the Champions League without its brightest talent, Cristiano Ronaldo.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The word superstar is too loosely used today in regard to team games, but it is impossible to imagine Real Madrid getting out of the hole it had dug for itself in the Champions League without its brightest talent, Cristiano Ronaldo. After losing the first leg in Germany, 2-0, Real Madrid had to beat Wolfsburg by three clear goals Tuesday at Santiago Bernabéu stadium in Madrid. Ronaldo, looking like he had ESP, scored all three goals in Real’s 3-0 victory.

headline: WADA Opens a Door for Athletes Who Tested Positive for Meldonium
abstract: Some athletes who tested positive might avoid sanctions because of a lack of certainty over how long the drug takes to clear the system.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The World Anti-Doping Agency issued new guidelines on Wednesday on the length of time the banned drug meldonium takes to leave the body, prompting celebrations from Russian sports officials, who said it seemed to open the way to clearing many of their athletes suspended recently for testing positive for the drug.

headline: 1941: Pope Deplores War’s Barbarity
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Pope Piux XII deplores the warring nations to treat civilians humanely in 1941.
lead_paragraph: Lamenting that the just peace for which he said he had labored seems still far away, Pope Pius XII implored the warring nations today [April 13] to use no weapons more terrible than those thus far employed and admonished military commanders in occupied countries to treat civilians humanely. — New York Herald Tribune, April 14, 1941

headline: I.M.F. Warns of Economic Risk of British Exit From E.U.
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Referendums', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Relations', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The fund said a withdrawal from the bloc — or “Brexit” — would pose “major challenges for both the United Kingdom and the rest of Europe.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A stark warning about the potentially negative economic impact of a British withdrawal from the European Union and a new report on immigration have galvanized debate over the country’s future in the bloc, a little more than two months before a referendum on whether to leave.

headline: Europe’s Privacy Watchdogs Call for Changes to U.S. Data-Transfer Deal
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The region’s national regulators say the so-called Privacy Shield agreement does not sufficiently protect their citizens’ rights.
lead_paragraph: Only two months after the European Union’s top policy makers agreed to a hard-won data-sharing pact with United States officials, the bloc’s national privacy regulators said on Wednesday that the deal did not go far enough to safeguard the personal information of Internet users in Europe.

headline: Regulators Warn 5 Top Banks They Are Still Too Big to Fail
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: In long letters this week, two regulators pointed to the dangers created by the global reach and complexity of the largest banks, which are bigger now than they were before the 2008 crisis.
lead_paragraph: The nation’s top bank regulators have added an unexpected voice to the growing chorus of critics worried that the biggest American banks, nearly eight years after the financial crisis, are still too big to fail.

headline: In Flint, Fears of Showering Bring Desperate Measures
keywords: ['Lead', 'Water', 'Bathing and Showering', 'Water Pollution', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: Many residents said they were bathing less frequently, but government investigators said it was too early to link skin problems to lead-tainted water.
lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — Near the top of the daily challenges that Flint residents face in a city without safe drinking water is how and where to shower.

headline: Art Dealer Says Painting Found in French Attic Is a Caravaggio
abstract: A painting of “Judith Beheading Holofernes” found near Toulouse in 2014 could be worth $136 million, a dealer says. But experts are divided over its authenticity.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It seems almost too good to be true: A long-lost Caravaggio worth millions is discovered languishing in an attic in France, unseen by the family that had lived there for generations.

headline: JPMorgan Chase Reports Lower Quarterly Profit
abstract: The bank said that both revenue and profit slid in the first quarter, from a year earlier, largely as a result of bad market conditions.
lead_paragraph: With investors expecting a weak first quarter for the banks, JPMorgan Chase delivered results that were slightly better than the forecasts.

headline: Tracey McDermott to Leave Financial Conduct Authority in July
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Ms. McDermott has served as acting chief executive since September and will leave when Andrew Bailey becomes the agency’s permanent C.E.O. in July.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tracey McDermott, the top executive of the British Financial Conduct Authority, will leave the regulator when Andrew Bailey, its new chief executive, takes over in July, the agency said on Wednesday.

headline: Razing Deucalion
abstract: A poem comparing a backhoe gathering the debris of demolition to a flood survivor in ancient Greek mythology.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Inky the Octopus Escapes From a New Zealand Aquarium
abstract: Tracks suggest he slipped through a small gap at the top of his tank, scampered across the floor, slid down a 164-foot-long drainpipe and reached the ocean.
lead_paragraph: It was an audacious nighttime escape.

headline: Iranian Parliament Cancels Cash Subsidies to 24 Million People
abstract: Analysts said the action was a stick in the eye for President Hassan Rouhani, forcing him to figure out how to put the unpopular measure into effect.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Iran’s lame-duck Parliament approved a bill on Wednesday canceling cash subsidies to 24 million Iranians, angering the government of President Hassan Rouhani, local news outlets reported.

headline: The ‘Animaniacs’ Voices Are Reuniting. Yes, There’s a New Verse to ‘Yakko’s World.’
abstract: The songs of the children’s cartoon from the 1990s will spring to life backed by a full orchestra, with a new verse for the nation-listing tune.
lead_paragraph: Twenty-three years later — yes, 23 years — Rob Paulsen is still often asked to perform the song that would remain the most memorable bit on “Animaniacs,” an after-school cartoon favorite for children of the 1990s.

headline: Kindle Oasis From Amazon Promises ‘Months and Months’ of Battery Life
abstract: The new $289 Kindle Oasis e-reader has an asymmetrical shape meant to mimic a book, and includes a case with a battery that extends charge time.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — When Amazon introduced Kindle, its pioneering e-reader, in 2007, society was on the cusp of being changed by mobile devices.

headline: What You Get for … $1,800,000
abstract: This week’s properties include a 1900 house in Kentucky, a renovated ranch in Atlanta and an adobe in New Mexico.
lead_paragraph: This week’s properties include a 1900 house in Kentucky, a renovated ranch in Atlanta and an adobe in New Mexico.

abstract: This week’s properties include a 1900 house in Kentucky, a renovated ranch in Atlanta and an adobe in New Mexico.
lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE, KY.

headline: Greece Holds Activists as Migrants and Police Clash Anew at Macedonia Border
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Tear Gas', 'International Relations']
abstract: The second outbreak of skirmishes in three days came amid protests over border closings, which have left more than 12,000 stuck in a makeshift refugee camp.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Clashes erupted at Greece’s northern border for the second time in three days on Wednesday, with the Macedonian police firing tear gas on scores of migrants as they protested border closings that have left more than 12,000 stranded in a makeshift refugee camp.

headline: 50 Years in a Cab: A Long, Winding Trip for One Driver, and His City
abstract: Over the decades, Alberto Tomassi has played tour guide, consoled abandoned wives, taken passengers to the emergency room — and had a front-row seat to a changing Rome.
lead_paragraph: ROME — From his front-seat perch, Alberto Tomassi, a Roman cabdriver for 50 years, has been both eavesdropper and confessor. He has played impromptu tour guide, thwarted muggings and rushed countless clients to the emergency room.

headline: A Six-Bedroom Estate With Water Views
abstract: The house, with two guest cottages and set on one and a half acres in Warwick Parish, is on the market for $5.65 million.
lead_paragraph: The house, with two guest cottages and set on one and a half acres in Warwick Parish, is on the market for $5.65 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Bermuda
abstract: The America’s Cup coming to Bermuda in June 2017 has helped invigorate the real estate market, which lost ground after the world financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: A SIX-BEDROOM ESTATE IN WARWICK PARISH

headline: Arnold Wesker, 83, Writer of Working-Class Dramas, Dies
abstract: Mr. Wesker, drawing on his childhood in a leftist Jewish family, was among British playwrights called the “angry young men,” though he disliked the label.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Arnold Wesker, a British playwright who came to prominence in the 1950s with stark dramas about working-class life, many of them influenced by his childhood in a leftist Jewish family in East London, died on Tuesday in Brighton, England. He was 83.

headline: Bots are Back, and They Might Even Be Welcome
abstract: These automated software critters are growing in popularity, especially now that they’re doing more than pretending to be a human in a call center.
lead_paragraph: Bots have a bad reputation.

headline: Finding Online Support for Your Android Device
abstract: Google’s own Android support pages are designed for its own version of the software, but help for other variations is usually not that far away.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why does Google’s website only seem to offer support for Nexus hardware and not any of the other brands of Android phones and tablets?

headline: Police Remove Bail Conditions on 5 Chinese Feminists Detained Last Year
abstract: However, the police said they were still investigating a case against them for “gathering a crowd to disturb public order,” said a lawyer for one of the women.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The Chinese police lifted bail conditions on Wednesday for five feminists who were detained in Beijing last year on the eve of International Women’s Day for planning to distribute leaflets warning of sexual harassment on public transit, according to the women and their lawyers.

headline: ‘12 Monkeys,’ on Syfy: It’s Complicated, but That’s O.K.
abstract: Season 2 of this time-traveling show — adapted from the 1995 movie starring Bruce Willis — starts on Monday, April 18.
lead_paragraph: Adapting a popular film into a television series is always a risky business, especially if that film attained cult status. Fans don’t like to have their touchstone cinematic experiences mucked with. But Syfy has navigated this difficult territory adroitly with its series “12 Monkeys,” which returns for a second season on Monday night, April 18. The 1995 film of that name, directed by Terry Gilliam and starring Bruce Willis, exploded a lot of moviegoers’ brains with its story of a time-traveling hero trying to stop a killer virus from destroying humanity. In the TV series, Mr. Willis’s character is played by Aaron Stanford, and he was put through quite a lot in Season 1, in several different time periods. The new season will include a story arc for Michael Hogan of “Battlestar Galactica.” In the first season, the writers wove a tale too complex to describe here, but Syfy has an droll primer video on the show’s website. In an inspired stroke, it’s narrated by Madeleine Stowe, who starred with Mr. Willis in the movie.

headline: Mozart’s Way With Singspiels
abstract: Juilliard updates “The Magic Flute,” while the Metropolitan Opera performs “The Abduction From the Seraglio.”
lead_paragraph: In Juilliard Opera’s new production of Mozart’s “Die Zauberflöte” (“The Magic Flute”), the director Mary Birnbaum examines the characters’ journey to enlightenment from a 21st-century perspective. David Stern conducts the Juilliard Orchestra; sets are inspired by the American artist Joseph Cornell, Carl Jung’s alchemical images and the Masonic lodges of New England. (Tuesday, April 19, and Thursday at 7:30 p.m. and Saturday at 2 p.m.; juilliard.edu.)

headline: ‘Small Mouth Sounds’ Returns to New York
abstract: Bess Wohl’s nearly wordless play about a group of people at a silent retreat will return to New York this summer.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers will again get to (quietly) see “Small Mouth Sounds.”

headline: Gilberto Gil and Caetano Veloso, Touring Again
abstract: The two musicians, pioneers of Brazil’s Tropicália movement, come to Brooklyn as part of their first tour together in more than 20 years.
lead_paragraph: Five decades ago, Gilberto Gil and Caetano Veloso shared quite a bit: They attended college together; pioneered Brazil’s Tropicália movement; went to jail at the same time after being labeled subversive by the government; and were forced into exile in London together. They were key in pushing Brazilian music toward the psychedelic and pushing Brazilian politics toward the more tolerant.

headline: In ‘The Long Goodbye,’ Altman Dissects Los Angeles
abstract: The director’s neo-noir take on Raymond Chandler’s novel is coming to the Museum of the Moving Image on Saturday, April 23.
lead_paragraph: In 1973, the tireless maverick Robert Altman was on a roll. His masterpieces “M*A*S*H” and “McCabe and Mrs. Miller” were behind him, and “Thieves Like Us,” “California Split” and “Nashville” lay ahead. It was time to dissect Southern California: its movie history and its casualties. His vehicle was “The Long Goodbye,” a neo-noir take on Raymond Chandler’s novel, coming to the Museum of the Moving Image as part of its series See It Big! Vilmos Zsigmond on Saturday, April 23.

headline: Can Donald Trump Win Every Delegate in New York?
abstract: To maximize his delegate haul, he needs big wins in every congressional district, and pockets of weakness could cost him.
lead_paragraph: Unless every poll is wildly wrong, Donald Trump is going to win in New York on Tuesday, and he’s going to win big. But exactly how he wins really matters. A few votes here or there could make the difference between a solid or shaky road to the Republican nomination.

headline: Why Monetarism Failed
abstract: Death by internal contradiction.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong asks why monetarism — broadly defined as the view that monetary policy can and should be used to stabilize economies — has more or less disappeared from the scene, both intellectually and politically. As it happens, I wrote about essentially the same question back in 2010, inspired by the more or less hysterical pushback against quantitative easing. I thought then and think now that this was fated to happen, that Milton Friedman’s project was always doomed to failure.

headline: Angelin Preljocaj’s Meditations on Movement
abstract: Ballet Preljocaj will perform, for the first time in New York, all three sections of “Empty moves (Parts I, II & III)” at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: As a choreographer, Angelin Preljocaj has two sides. There are his highly theatrical adventures like “Spectral Evidence,” which he created for New York City Ballet in 2013 and took inspiration from the Salem witchcraft trials. And then there are his more sedate, minimal works that calmly reveal the purity of movement without all the bells and whistles. In “Empty moves (Parts I, II & III),” Ballet Preljocaj returns to the Joyce Theater to perform, for the first time in New York, all three sections of this spellbinding work, set to a recording of John Cage’s “Empty Words” from a 1977 performance in Milan. Not all those in that audience reacted well to Cage’s reading of Thoreau’s journals; yet despite their insults and shouts, he carried on — just as the dancers do in Mr. Preljocaj’s hypnotic investigation of form. Here the dancers create a world of their own: quietly rigorous, sensuous in its constant flow and meditative. In other words, far from empty. (Wednesday, April 20, through Sunday, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, Manhattan; 212-242-0077, joyce.org.)

headline: Kay WalkingStick’s American History
abstract: The retrospective of this artist, now 81, at the National Museum of the American Indian in Washington conveys her merging of the personal and political.
lead_paragraph: “Kay WalkingStick: An American Artist,” at the National Museum of the American Indian in Washington, is an overdue career survey of a near half-century of work by an artist, now 81, for whom “American” has multiple and conflicted meanings.

headline: Q. and A. With Ellie Kemper: Talking Kimmy Schmidt, Jon Hamm and Tarantulas
abstract: The star of Netflix’s “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt” talks about the character’s future — and that time Jon Hamm was her ninth-grade acting teacher.
lead_paragraph: In Netflix’s “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt,” Ellie Kemper plays the survivor of a doomsday cult who, after being held captive underground in Indiana for 15 years, doggedly reinvents herself in New York City. But in Season 2, not everything goes swimmingly for Kimmy, who discovers that when you close the door on one problem, another opens.

headline: Citigroup’s ‘Living Will’ Passes Muster but Offers Few Insights
keywords: ['Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Bankruptcies']
abstract: The bank appears to have discovered the secret to a proper living will, but the public has no way of knowing why it passed and the others failed.
lead_paragraph: Section 165 of the Dodd-Frank Act requires large bank holding companies to submit “resolution plans” —popularly known as living wills — that show how these companies can be resolved if they fail in a bankruptcy court like every other business.

headline: Joseph Altuzarra’s New Collection of Crisp Shirtdresses
abstract: The designer teamed up with Matches Fashion to offer more of his signature silhouettes.
lead_paragraph: The designer teamed up with Matches Fashion to offer more of his signature silhouettes.

headline: 1966: France Bars Rites for G.I.
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: France government bars tribute for G.I. in 1966.
lead_paragraph: The French government has refused to permit a memorial ceremony at the Hôtel des Invalides in tribute to an American soldier mortally wounded in the liberation of Paris. It will be the first time in 20 years that the French Kelly Memorial Committee will not be able to hold the Invalides ceremony for Sgt. Lawrence R. Kelly, of Altoona, Pa., who was shot at the Saint-Cloud bridge, near Paris, on Aug. 25, 1944. The committee described the ceremony as a tribute to all Americans who died fighting in France. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 14, 1966

headline: Ride-Hailing Start-Ups Compete in ‘Uber for Children’ Niche
keywords: ['Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Children and Childhood', 'Start-ups']
abstract: Heavily vetted services cater to the needs of working parents to get children where they need to be when their parents can’t.
lead_paragraph: The juggle of work, school and myriad extracurricular activities is all too familiar to parents like Kelly Aluise of Los Angeles.

headline: Chief Executive for Serpentine Galleries in London Is Named
abstract: The longtime director of the galleries, Julia Peyton-Jones, announced in October that she would be stepping down.
lead_paragraph: LONDON —The Serpentine Galleries, the contemporary art exhibition space in London, said Wednesday that it had appointed Yana Peel as chief executive, a new position for the institution.

headline: Curfew Imposed in Jammu and Kashmir, India, After Deadly Clashes
keywords: ['Curfews', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Attacks on Police', 'Sex Crimes', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Three people were killed in Handwara and one in Kupwara, in Jammu and Kashmir State, as protesters clashed with soldiers and the police.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The authorities in Jammu and Kashmir State imposed a curfew on the northern Indian city of Handwara on Wednesday, a day after Indian soldiers fired on a crowd of angry protesters at an army camp, killing three people, officials said.

headline: Delicious Midweek Recipes
abstract: Want a no-stress dinner? Start with this no-recipe salad, and move on to an endlessly adaptable mushroom ragout.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Shopping Guide: Pendant Lights
keywords: ['Lighting', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: A veteran lighting designer offers some tips on finding the right fixture.
lead_paragraph: A veteran lighting designer offers some tips on finding the right fixture.

headline: Stephen Colbert’s CBS Show Gets a New Showrunner
abstract: Chris Licht, the executive producer of “CBS This Morning” will join the “Late Show” staff.
lead_paragraph: Less than eight months into his tenure as the host of “The Late Show,” CBS’s flagship late-night program, Stephen Colbert is getting a new executive to oversee the show. On Wednesday, the network announced that Chris Licht, the executive producer of “CBS This Morning,” will become the showrunner and an executive producer at “The Late Show,” a move that may reflect some discontent with how the program has started off under Mr. Colbert.

headline: E.U. Accuses Polish Government of Undermining Democracy
abstract: The European Parliament adopted a resolution urging the right-wing government in Warsaw to respect the decisions of a top court.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — The European Parliament accused Poland’s right-wing government on Wednesday of undermining democracy, overwhelmingly adopting a resolution urging it to respect the decisions of a top Polish court.

headline: A Look at the ‘Doctor Strange’ Teaser Trailer
abstract: Benedict Cumberbatch is in the title role, with a bald Tilda Swinton as the Ancient One.
lead_paragraph: “Might I offer you some advice? Forget everything that you think you know.” Those words are spoken to the character Stephen Strange in the new teaser for “Doctor Strange,” which went online Monday night. But could that advice also be given to Hollywood when considering new superhero movies? Marvel is certainly trying out a new direction for the studio with the more metaphysical Doctor Strange, played by Benedict Cumberbatch.

headline: Some Online Bargains May Only Look Like One
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'E-Commerce', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Discount Selling']
abstract: In the bizarre world of Internet “discounts,” inconsistent list prices can make it tough to figure out what a product is really worth.
lead_paragraph: Amazon has some unbelievable bargains on its virtual shelves.

headline: Bushwhacking Up Maine’s Baker Mountain
abstract: It’s not New England’s most impressive peak, but it is an extreme hiker’s delight and a challenge even for those with GPS. At least for now.
lead_paragraph: Baker Mountain in Maine doesn’t crack the top 100 list of New England peaks. But it certainly has stage presence. A full third taller than the two mountains on either side of it, and twice as wide, Baker looms large on its home turf.

headline: Ted Cruz Radio Ad Intensifies Feud With Mayor Bill de Blasio
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Radio']
abstract: The radio advertisement being put out by Senator Ted Cruz’s campaign, days ahead of next week’s New York primary, offers a list of negatives against Mayor Bill de Blasio, criticizing him for ending stop-and-frisk policing and for immigration policies that put out “the red carpet for illegals.”
lead_paragraph: Join us for New York primary live updates.

headline: Should a Jail Record Be an Employer's First Impression?
abstract: "Ban the box" laws prevent employers and others from asking on applications whether someone has been convicted of a crime.

headline: Who Could Save the G.O.P.? Republicans Weigh Some Ideas
abstract: Some Republicans believe there is at least a theoretical opening for someone not now running to offer the party a way out of a convention melee.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Paul D. Ryan’s categorical disavowal of interest in the presidential race on Tuesday appeared to extinguish a longstanding fantasy of Republican leaders: That Mr. Ryan might ride into the convention in Cleveland as a white knight to unite the fractured party and claim its nomination.

headline: The Mad Genius of Superstudio
abstract: A look back at the collective of rebel Italian students who defined the radical architecture movement of the ’60s and ’70s but never completed a single building.
lead_paragraph: A look back at the collective of rebel Italian students who defined the radical architecture movement of the ’60s and ’70s but never completed a single building.

headline: A ‘Big Science Guy’ Named Obama Hosts Young Innovators One Last Time
abstract: The president will host his final White House Science fair on Wednesday to emphasize the importance science, technology, engineering and math.
lead_paragraph: President Obama vowed early in his tenure to make science “cool” and decorated the Oval Office with patent models of groundbreaking American inventions.

headline: A ’60s Architecture Collective That Made History (but No Buildings)
abstract: The hallucinogenic visions of Italy’s legendary radical design group Superstudio are still making waves.
lead_paragraph: Italy’s legendary radical design group Superstudio never actually finished a building, and yet its hallucinogenic visions are still making waves.

headline: A Meltdown, on Deadline: Reporter’s Notebook
abstract: Jordan Spieth wasn’t the only one scrambling at the Masters on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Karen Crouse, a sportswriter, describes how she scrambled (on deadline) to cover Jordan Spieth’s unexpected meltdown at the Masters.

headline: Allen Toussaint’s Final Recordings to Be Released in June
abstract: The final recordings of Allen Toussaint, who died in November, will be released in June.
lead_paragraph: The final recordings of Allen Toussaint, the sage New Orleans songwriter, singer and pianist who died in November at age 77, will be released on June 10, in the album “American Tunes” (Nonesuch).

headline: Wall Street Scion’s Fraud Case Could Be Settled, Lawyer Says
abstract: The lawyer, Paul Shechtman, says his client, the former Wall Street financier Andrew Caspersen, may not face trial in the criminal case against him.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Caspersen, the former Wall Street executive charged by federal prosecutors and securities regulators with defrauding friends, relatives and a charitable foundation closely tied to a large New York hedge fund, is unlikely to face a trial.

headline: De Blasio Plays Down Contact With Men at Heart of U.S. Inquiry
abstract: Deputy Chief Andrew Capul, the executive officer of the Manhattan North Patrol Borough, has been transferred to an administrative position as part of an investigation into municipal corruption.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Wednesday that he had conversations “over the course of 2014” and into the next year with two financial backers who are now at the center of a federal investigation, acknowledging more extensive contact with the men than he had previously.

headline: Thousands of Verizon Employees Strike
abstract: Close to 36,000 Verizon workers on the East Coast have gone on strike after the company and two unions failed to reach an agreement on Wednesday. This is one of the largest strikes in recent years.
lead_paragraph: Close to 36,000 Verizon workers on the East Coast have gone on strike after the company and two unions failed to reach an agreement on Wednesday. This is one of the largest strikes in recent years.

headline: Jordan Shuts Down Muslim Brotherhood Headquarters
abstract: The group lost its official registration last year after it failed to comply with new government requirements. It had been operating in legal limbo since then.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — The Jordanian police closed down the headquarters of the Muslim Brotherhood in Jordan on Wednesday, the group said in a statement.

headline: Bataclan, Site of Terror Attack in Paris, Plans November Reopening
abstract: The concert hall has said on Twitter and on its website that the rocker Pete Doherty would perform on Nov. 16.
lead_paragraph: The Bataclan, the Paris concert hall where scores of people were killed in the terrorist attack of Nov. 13, on Wednesday announced its first slate of shows since then. The hall has not held a concert since terrorists opened fire during an Eagles of Death Metal concert.

headline: New Poll Shows Donald Trump Adding Delegates in Maryland
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: A survey from the Monmouth University Polling Institute finds that Donald J. Trump has the support of 47 percent of likely Republican primary voters in Maryland, where 38 delegates will be at stake on April 26. He is trailed by John Kasich, who has 27 percent, and Ted Cruz, with 19 percent.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has opened a wide lead in Maryland, according to a new poll that shows the leading Republican presidential candidate poised to sweep the state’s delegates later this month.

headline: Chip, Implanted in Brain, Helps Paralyzed Man Regain Control of Hand
abstract: A new study of a 24-year-old man who broke his neck five years ago is the first account of limb reanimation in a person with profound paralysis.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, a college freshman named Ian Burkhart dived into a wave at a beach off the Outer Banks in North Carolina and, in a freakish accident, broke his neck on the sandy floor, permanently losing the feeling in his hands and legs.

headline: Wall St. Banks Told to Stand Alone, Without Overseas Help
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: American banks were ordered to ensure that they had enough liquidity in a crisis without relying on assistance from their foreign units.
lead_paragraph: When the next financial crisis hits, big American banks will not be able to rely on their internal lifeboats.

keywords: ['Movies', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: “Speaking Is Difficult,” currently under 15 minutes long, pairs recent footage of sites of gun violence in the U.S. with 911 calls at the time.
lead_paragraph: A new film about gun violence has a simple concept and a brief running time, but its makers intend it to be nothing less than a living document of the cycle of violence.

keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']

headline: Alpha Centauri: A Destination for Star-Struck Explorers

headline: Teenager Who Used ‘Affluenza’ Defense Is Sentenced to Jail
abstract: Ethan Couch went to Mexico after a crash that killed four people. On Wednesday, a judge imposed a sentence of 180 days for each person killed.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — Ethan Couch, the teenager who used an “affluenza” defense in a drunken-driving crash that killed four people and then violated probation by traveling to Mexico with his mother, was sentenced on Wednesday to nearly two years in jail.

headline: Review: An All-Star Jazz Trio Explores Form and Freedom
abstract: David Murray, Geri Allen and Terri Lyne Carrington, on “Perfection,” range from articulate rhythm to expressionistic scrawl.

headline: Families of Germanwings Crash Victims File Suit in U.S.
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Pilots', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Lawyers contend that an Arizona flight school allowed Andreas Lubitz to pursue his training despite evidence that he had a history of mental illness.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Lawyers representing the families of dozens of victims of the crash of a Germanwings airliner in the French Alps last year filed a wrongful-death lawsuit in Phoenix on Wednesday. The lawsuit accuses an Arizona flight school that trained the plane’s co-pilot of negligence for allowing him to pursue his training, despite what they contend were multiple red flags in his medical records indicating a history of mental illness.

headline: On Penalty Kill, Islanders Turn a Weakness Into a Weapon
abstract: A season ago, the Islanders were 26th in the N.H.L. in killing penalties; this season, they were fourth.
lead_paragraph: EAST MEADOW, N.Y. — Three years ago, the Islanders’ inability to kill penalties cost them in the playoffs. Last season, their penalty-kill struggles may have cost them a happier closing of Nassau Coliseum.

headline: Milwaukee’s Appeals, Vibrant and Cheap
abstract: The Frugal Traveler found a small but vibrant city that balances its traditional Germanic origins with an embrace of contemporary art, great live music and more.
lead_paragraph: Full disclosure: I was already sold on Milwaukee before I arrived. I’m originally from outside Chicago, and spent some time in Wisconsin’s largest city around 10 years ago when I was performing in a local theater production. During my time there, I came to appreciate the city’s appealing mix of outstanding cultural institutions, fantastic food and dive bars.

headline: Is Cheap Oil Contractionary?
abstract: And if so, why?
lead_paragraph: Low oil prices were supposed to be a big boost for the world economy; but it didn’t happen. Maury Obstfeld, my long-time textbook co-author and now chief economist at the IMF, offers an interesting argument about why: he suggests that it’s because of the zero lower bound. Falling oil leads to falling inflation expectations, and since interest rates can’t fall, real rates go up, hurting recovery.

headline: How Donald Trump Tweets
abstract: “During the day,” he said, “I just shout it out to one of the young ladies.”
lead_paragraph: The exact source of Donald Trump’s tweets has long been a matter of speculation. The tweets are so consistent with his persona that it’s hard to imagine anyone else coming up with them. But where in his busy schedule of making America great again does Mr. Trump find time to tweet?

headline: Bernie Sanders Relishes Backing From a Fellow Senator and a Labor Union
keywords: ['Endorsements', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Subways']
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders, in addition to receiving the endorsement of Senator Jeff Merkley, a Democrat from Oregon, received the backing of the Transport Workers Union Local 100, which represents about 42,000 transit workers in the New York region.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders picked up his first endorsement from a fellow United States senator on Wednesday. Senator Jeff Merkley, a Democrat from Oregon, offered his official backing of Mr. Sanders.

keywords: ['Movies', 'Music', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Dancing']
abstract: The documentary “Strike a Pose” looks back at the men featured in the 1991 film, which aimed to be revealing but kept their secrets.
lead_paragraph: In footage shot during Madonna’s 1990 “Blond Ambition” tour, the star stops her concert to speak about the death, just a few weeks earlier, of her close friend Keith Haring. He “was a man who had the courage to tell the truth,” she announces. “The truth is, he was gay. The truth is, he had AIDS. And he said so to anybody who would listen.”

keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: The Peruvian writer, 80, whose romance has inspired gossip, accepted the Library of Congress’s Living Legend award this week.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Four years ago, Mario Vargas Llosa wrote a book that said the world was going to hell. Journalists were sleaze-mongers and politicians hopeless. Civilization had collapsed into spectacle.

headline: A Rookie Learns to Fly a Drone
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: There are many steps before you can get airborne, including finding a safe area and learning the federal and local regulations.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — My wife, Alexa, has made something of a profession out of getting me great birthday presents. Over the years, her gifts have included an old Sports Illustrated with a hologram of Michael Jordan on the cover and a photography tour of a particularly photogenic part of southern China.

headline: Megyn Kelly Meets With Donald Trump
abstract: The feud between the Fox News anchor and the leading Republican candidate for president has been a strange subplot in a confounding election year.
lead_paragraph: It was a high-level summit meeting above Midtown Manhattan, the latest twist in a story of public acrimony and private courtship.

headline: Brooklyn Principal Removed From Post Is Cleared of Charges
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Principals (School)', 'Graduation Rates', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Teachers and School Employees']
abstract: An arbitrator ruled that Kathleen Elvin, who was accused of improperly allowing students to make up courses, should be reinstated at John Dewey High School.
lead_paragraph: In a rebuke to the New York City Education Department and its investigative unit, an arbitrator has dismissed all charges against a high school principal who was removed from her post last July, after being accused of inflating the school’s graduation rate by giving makeup classes without content.

headline: A Trip to Courrèges’s Workshop in Pau, France — With its New Designers
abstract: A year into their jobs as the artistic directors of the 55-year-old brand, the young designers Arnaud Vaillant and Sébastien Meyer visit the company’s iconic factory.
lead_paragraph: A year into their jobs as the artistic directors of the 55-year-old brand, the young designers Arnaud Vaillant and Sébastien Meyer visit the company’s iconic factory.

headline: For Courrèges’s New Designers, a Trip to the Source
abstract: Sébastien Meyer and Arnaud Vaillant, the new creative team behind the 55-year-old brand, visited the house’s original factory in Pau — which was designed in 1972 by André Courrèges himself.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1970s, the French fashion designer André Courrèges returned to his hometown of Pau, at the foot of the Pyrenees, to build his company’s manufacturing hub. He was known at the time as the “Le Corbusier of Couture” — and had introduced a mod look of A-line miniskirts, peg pants and boxy jackets that combined what he learned during his decade as the assistant to Cristóbal Balenciaga and his love of all things futuristic, sporty and utilitarian. “You don’t walk through life anymore. You run. You dance. You drive a car. You take a plane,” he said. “Clothes must be able to move too.”

headline: Review: J. D. McClatchy’s Secret Autobiography, in Quotations
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Quotations and Proverbs', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Mr. McClatchy, a poet, gathers some of his favorite phrases, jokes, anecdotes and lovely sentences in a commonplace book.
lead_paragraph: The essayist Michel de Montaigne thought that quoting well, in a piece of writing, was akin to arranging other people’s flowers. It’s a skill; doing it well takes practice.

headline: Election 2016 | Comparing the Candidates on the Issues
abstract: In this lesson, students research the candidates’ stances on important issues and share their findings with the class. Then, we suggest a variety of activities to bring their research alive, such as holding a mock caucus or candidate debate.

headline: His Brother’s Keeper: A Ramones Tour of Queens
abstract: Joey Ramone’s brother, Mickey Leigh, revisits Forest Hills, the 1970s backdrop to the Ramones’ formation, and the Queens Museum offers an exhibition on the band.
lead_paragraph: MICKEY LEIGH walked up to a small house on an unremarkable street in Forest Hills, Queens. The teenager who answered the door was unsure what to make of the tall man with salt-and-pepper hair standing before him wearing black jeans, a long black coat and dirty yellow Converse sneakers.

headline: Poll Watch: Just How Competitive Is the New York Primary?
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: On the Democratic side in Tuesday’s New York primary, Senator Bernie Sanders has somewhat narrowed the gap on Hillary Clinton’s wide advantage, according to recent polls. For the Republicans, Donald J. Trump stands a chance to achieve an outright delegate sweep.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday will be the first time in decades that New York will hold two competitive presidential primaries in the same year. Well, it depends on how you define competitive.

headline: How to Get Better Returns on Savings
abstract: Consumers who have direct deposit and use debit cards a lot can benefit from nationally available high-yield accounts that have multiple restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Savers were encouraged last year when the Federal Reserve began raising rates. But interest paid on the lowest-risk federally insured accounts remains lackluster.

lead_paragraph: A task force assigned by Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago has found racism and systemic failures in the police force, validating complaints made for years by African- American residents.

headline: Authorities Raid Law Firm at Center of Panama Papers Leak
abstract: Officials said they were looking for evidence of “illegal activities” during the search of the headquarters of Mossack Fonseca, which specializes in setting up offshore accounts.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The Panamanian authorities have raided the offices of Mossack Fonseca, the law firm at the center of the vast leak of documents this month that exposed the global use of offshore tax shelters, and spent at least 16 hours combing through the company’s files looking for evidence of possible “illegal activities,” officials said on Wednesday.

headline: To Celebrate Tax Day (Really), 10 Travel Deals
abstract: It’s income-tax filing season and hotels and cruise lines are marking the occasion with discounts and packages (and cocktails).
lead_paragraph: In the world of travel, April 18 — this year’s deadline for filing tax returns — is an incentive for hotels to create packages to lure guests who might be feeling flush with extra cash. According to Nancy Millett, the global consumer business tax leader for Deloitte, many taxpayers get a refund because they don’t adjust their withholding to take into account their projected deductions and exemptions. “As a result, they get money back at the end of the year,” she said.

headline: Chicago Police Dept. Plagued by Systemic Racism, Task Force Finds
abstract: A panel assigned by Mayor Rahm Emanuel says police officers have mistreated people, operated without oversight and lost the trust of residents.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Racism has contributed to a long pattern of institutional failures by the Chicago Police Department in which officers have mistreated people, operated without sufficient oversight, and lost the trust of residents, a task force appointed by Mayor Rahm Emanuel has found.

headline: Russian Plane Flew Close to U.S. Ship in Baltic Sea, White House Says
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Ships and Shipping', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Washington accused Russia on Wednesday of violating professional military norms over the Baltic Sea when a plane flew close to an American ship and a Polish aircraft.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House said on Wednesday that Russia had violated professional military norms over the Baltic Sea when one of its planes flew “dangerously close” to an American ship and a Polish aircraft.

headline: Hillary Clinton Promotes Community Libraries as Crucial Link to Immigrants
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Saying community libraries were the “perfect platform” for immigrants to learn about citizenship initiatives or English classes, Mrs. Clinton said they would be a critical link to the White House if she were elected president.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton visited the Queens Library in Flushing a few years ago, she was amazed by the sheer number of immigrants who gathered there for help.

headline: Ruling to Dismiss Charges Against Principal
abstract: An arbitrator ruled that Kathleen Elvin, the former principal of John Dewey High School, should be reinstated after she was accused of improperly giving students credit for courses in which they received no instruction. The arbitrator said that an audit later conducted by the Education Department, which found that the courses met the department's guidelines, effectively exonerated her.
lead_paragraph: An arbitrator ruled that Kathleen Elvin, the former principal of John Dewey High School, should be reinstated after she was accused of improperly giving students credit for courses in which they received no instruction. The arbitrator said that an audit later conducted by the Education Department, which found that the courses met the department's guidelines, effectively exonerated her.

headline: City Worker Sold Drugs at Municipal Building in Manhattan, Police Say
abstract: Benjamin Henderson, an exam monitor, is accused of selling cocaine and heroin outside his office, as well as at a subway station and near a charter school in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: The Municipal Building in Lower Manhattan, a stately blend of Roman, Italian Renaissance and Classical architecture, would seem an unlikely place for a drug dealer to set up shop. Nearly as unlikely, then, is the man accused of the crime: a New York City employee who worked in the building.

headline: Donald Trump Campaign Hires Rick Wiley, an R.N.C. Veteran
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s campaign is in discussions to bring aboard Rick Wiley, the campaign manager for the unsuccessful presidential run of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, and a former political director for the Republican National Committee.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s campaign has hired Rick Wiley, who was the presidential campaign manager for Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, as its national political director as Mr. Trump, the Republican front-runner, expands his team, the campaign confirmed on Wednesday.

headline: Court Opens Way for Argentina to End Battle With Hedge Funds

abstract: Argentina is now poised to raise more than $12 billion through bond sales, the proceeds of which it will use to pay its holdout creditors.
lead_paragraph: The United States Court of Appeals paved the way on Wednesday for Argentina to raise billions of dollars to pay a group of New York hedge funds, bringing it one step closer to re-entering international markets for the first time in 15 years.

headline: Now You Can Write the Great American Novel on the Subway
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Writing and Writers', 'Android (Operating System)', 'iOS (Operating System)', 'Word Processing', 'Computer Keyboards']
abstract: Smartphone and tablet apps, some of them compatible with Microsoft Word and Scrivener, that can help writers craft their novels, screenplays or articles.
lead_paragraph: IT used to be that when a moment of inspiration struck writers, they would have to rush over to a stone tablet, or find parchment and ink, to record their thoughts. Later, writers had to find paper and a typewriter, or a laptop or desktop computer, to get busy with their storytelling.

headline: Loch Ness Monster Is Found! (Kind of. Not Really.)
abstract: Fine, it was just a long-lost movie prop. But the discovery by an underwater drone highlighted the enduring appeal of searching for Nessie.
lead_paragraph: After many decades of folklore and research, the Loch Ness monster has finally been found by an underwater drone.

headline: In Italy, Ryan Roche Learns About Knitwear
abstract: The designer went on a weeklong tour as part of the Fabric Program launched by the CFDA and Milano Unica.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the designer Ryan Roche found herself in the Willy Wonka Chocolate Factory of the textile world, as she describes it: Remmert S.p.A, the 140-year-old Italian company best known for its haute couture accessories like beautiful feathers and lacquered tapes. “The looms are massive,” she explained by email, “and out come the daintiest, fine ribbons.” Roche, along with the milliner Gigi Burris and the family behind Orley, also visited Teseo and Maggia (facilities that focus on bio-silks and luxury jersey, respectively) and the Tessitura di Crevacuore mill (where the “archive dated back to the ’40s and we touched original Chanel,” she notes) as participants in the inaugural Fabric Program trip coordinated by the CFDA and the international trade fair Milano Unica. The group took in more than just the craft’s heritage: Roche met a septuagenarian knit-master (who presented some of his latest innovations), brushed up on advancements in yarn technology and discovered fiber combinations, treatments and washes that she plans to work into her brand’s resort offering. Here, she shares exclusively with T photographs from her seven-day sojourn in Italy.

headline: Eight Games Into Their Season, Mets Have Something to Prove
abstract: Jeurys Familia earned a five-out save in a victory over the Marlins. Manager Terry Collins said the perception that his team was playing with “no energy” was untrue.
lead_paragraph: The video played before games at Citi Field presents a timeline of significant moments in Mets history. There’s Cleon Jones on one knee, catching the final out of the 1969 World Series, and the glories of last year’s National League championship run.

headline: Syrian Parliamentary Elections Highlight Divisions and Uncertainty
keywords: ['Legislatures and Parliaments', 'United States International Relations', 'Elections', 'International Relations']
abstract: Large parts of the country did not participate in the voting, which was held on the first day of a new round of diplomatic talks in Geneva.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria’s president and first lady cast their ballots on Wednesday in front of clapping crowds, as state television captured the moment and set it to a dramatic soundtrack. Across Damascus, government employees were delivered to the polls aboard packed buses. The electricity even stayed on for most of the day in the capital, a rarity in these days of civil war.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: ‘My First Lesson in Motherhood’
abstract: The actress Connie Britton reads the story of a woman’s challenges with a daughter adopted from China.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s episode of the Modern Love Podcast, the actress Connie Britton (“Nashville,” “Friday Night Lights”) reads Elizabeth Fitzsimons’s 2007 essay, “My First Lesson in Motherhood,” about a woman’s almost immediate challenges with a daughter adopted from China.

lead_paragraph: A new exhibition at David Zwirner in London includes images from the artist’s “Art & Beauty” publication series.

headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Tepid Response at Black Activist Conference
abstract: A week after her husband had a tense encounter with black protesters, Hillary Clinton received a smattering of applause as she gave a policy-laden speech before the National Action Network, the civil rights organization founded by the Rev. Al Sharpton.
lead_paragraph: A week after her husband had a tense encounter with black protesters, Hillary Clinton on Wednesday received a lukewarm response from a gathering of black leaders and voters in New York.

headline: An Art-World Prankster Goes Digital
abstract: For a new exhibition, the perennially controversial R. Crumb expands his homages to women — to include cellphone street photos and fans’ selfies.
lead_paragraph: The American cartoonist Robert Crumb’s first U.K. solo exhibition in over a decade opens to the public in London on Friday — and features pictures from the latest volume of his “Art and Beauty” magazine series, which has previously seen Crumb faithfully reproduce imagery of women taken from mass media or life studies. Now, he adds cellphone street photos and his fans’ selfies to his wellsprings of inspiration.

headline: Anne Jackson, Stage Star With Her Husband, Eli Wallach, Dies at 90
abstract: Ms. Jackson, half of one of America’s best-known acting couples, was nominated for a Tony for her performance in Paddy Chayefsky’s “Middle of the Night.”
lead_paragraph: Anne Jackson, a distinguished star of the stage who was half of one of America’s best-known acting couples, sharing much of a long and distinguished career with her husband, Eli Wallach, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 90.

headline: ‘JFK’ Envisions an Operatic Ending for Camelot
abstract: The composer David T. Little and the librettist Royce Vavrek had a theatrical challenge on their hands in the telling of John F. Kennedy’s last living hours in Texas.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — We learn about it. We might relate to it personally, recalling where we were when we heard about it. We could even have a theory about it.

headline: Zika Virus Causes Birth Defects, Health Officials Confirm
abstract: The finding is likely to increase pressure on Congress to allocate funds requested by the Obama administration to combat the epidemic.
lead_paragraph: Officials at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Wednesday that there was now enough evidence to definitively say that the Zika virus could cause unusually small heads and brain damage in infants born to infected mothers.

headline: In Photos, ISIS Shows How Brussels Terror Originated in Syria
abstract: The purpose of the latest issue of the magazine, Dabiq, is clear: to show the West that the attackers really were sent from the heart of the group’s terror machinery.
lead_paragraph: Somewhere, there is a digital archive containing the portraits of the Islamic State’s network of fighters in Europe. The image of each fighter was stored in this database months before last year’s attacks in Paris, and after each new terror strike, the group has reached into it and released the photographs. So it was on Wednesday.

headline: Atlético Madrid Eliminates Barcelona in Champions League
abstract: The 3-2 loss on aggregate kept Barcelona from reaching the semifinals for the second time in nine seasons.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Barcelona began the month of April looking, once again, to be the dominant team in Europe. It had comfortably dispatched Arsenal in the round of 16 in the Champions League and held a clear lead in the battle to win La Liga. It was on a 39-match unbeaten run, and Lionel Messi, the No. 1 player on its star-stuffed roster, was on the verge of scoring his 500th goal.

headline: Judge Says New York Times Reporter Can’t Be Compelled to Testify at ‘Baby Hope’ Hearing
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Justice Bonnie G. Wittner, in quashing two subpoenas ordering Frances Robles to testify and to turn over her notes, said Ms. Robles was protected by New York’s shield law.
lead_paragraph: A state judge ruled on Wednesday that a reporter for The New York Times could not be forced to testify at a pretrial hearing about her jailhouse interview with a man accused of killing the toddler known as Baby Hope.

headline: Changing of the Guard: The Designer Shakeup at Major Fashion Houses
abstract: A roundup of some of the designers leaving menswear labels and moving onto others.
lead_paragraph: A roundup of some of the designers leaving menswear labels and moving onto others.

headline: Why Is the Men’s Fashion Industry in Such Turmoil?
abstract: It’s no coincidence that big changes at Saint Laurent, Brioni and Zegna have come just as a casual generation reaches maturity.
lead_paragraph: Lately, the Chicken Littles of fashion are reading dire omens into a cluster of design world shake-ups. Coming soon after changes at the top at Dior, Lanvin and Balenciaga, startling personnel shifts at prominent men’s wear brands have left some in the industry wandering around dazed, waiting to be smacked with a piece of falling sky.

headline: The Vermont Product Every New Yorker Is Packing
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'States (US)']
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s comments on guns from Vermont don’t make much sense. Another import is far more prevalent.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s effort to lash Bernie Sanders to New York gun crimes was days in the making. She finally dropped her bombshell on Monday: “Here’s what I want you to know. Most of the guns that are used in crimes and violence and killings in New York come from out of state,” Mrs. Clinton told a panel in New York.

headline: Theranos Under Fire as U.S. Threatens Crippling Sanctions
abstract: It is the latest blow to the credibility of Theranos and Elizabeth Holmes, its chief executive, who seemingly became a self-made billionaire by promising to upend the blood-testing industry.
lead_paragraph: Federal regulators have threatened a series of stiff sanctions against Theranos, the embattled blood-testing company, including closing down its flagship laboratory and potentially barring its chief executive from owning or operating its labs for two years.

headline: Party of South Korea’s President Loses Majority in Parliament
keywords: ['Elections', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The vote was seen as a referendum on President Park Geun-hye, now a highly divisive leader, and, analysts said, it was a rejection of her style of government.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korean voters handed President Park Geun-hye’s party a surprising setback on Wednesday, stripping it of a majority in Parliament as her government faces a sluggish economy and a growing nuclear threat from North Korea.

headline: Ex-President of Argentina Attacks Her Foes at Court Hearing
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The former president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, testified as part of an inquiry into allegations of misdeeds at the Central Bank, and claimed that she was being persecuted.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Former President Cristina Fernández de Kirchner testified in a Buenos Aires court on Wednesday as part of an investigation into allegations of misdeeds at Argentina’s Central Bank during the last months of her administration.

headline: Review: Duran Duran, Seriously Light in Brooklyn
abstract: The synth-pop band recalled its 1980s heyday at Barclays Center, where it shared the bill with Chic.
lead_paragraph: Simon Le Bon promised a set of “politics-free entertainment” and “just pure fun” during Duran Duran’s concert at Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Tuesday night. But that was after the band had opened the show with “Paper Gods,” the title song of its 2015 album and an indictment of the power of money and how “all the fools in town are ruling today.” Lest anyone miss the message amid the dance beat, the video backdrop included lyrics.

headline: ‘Blood at the Root’ Draws Inspiration From the Jena Six Case in Louisiana
abstract: This work by Dominique Morisseau, directed by Steve Broadnax, has toured globally, bringing difficult discussions of race and justice along with it.
lead_paragraph: Dominique Morisseau knows where the truth lies, and it is rarely on solid ground. This fast-rising playwright takes on charged issues, from downsizing to drugs, without ever turning pundit or polemicist. Instead, in plays that include this season’s vibrant “Skeleton Crew” (which returns in May to the Atlantic Theater Company), she carefully uncovers shades of moral ambiguity among economically beleaguered African-Americans.

headline: Review: Indian Dance Amid a Luxury Store Backdrop
abstract: Malini Srinivasan, an excellent local dancer and choreographer in the classical Indian style Bharatanatyam, performs at the Brookfield Place mall.
lead_paragraph: “Where gods go to shop” is not the advertising slogan for Brookfield Place, a high-end mall in Lower Manhattan. But the phrase struck me as a possible caption for an incongruous sight there on Tuesday at 5 p.m., when five women in richly colored saris, laden with bangles and jewels, entered the mall’s vast Winter Garden atrium and waited. Bells on their ankles jingled each time their bare feet slapped the cold marble floor, as they proceeded to dance amid palm trees and otherwise-occupied consumers against the background of luxury stores.

The column prompted me to think about whether the battlegrounds in the never-ending abortion wars display a similar geographic concentration.

abstract: The festival of new music, now in its 18th season, featured a wide range of young composers from around the world at Scandinavia House.
lead_paragraph: I’ve heard contemporary music performed on all manner of instruments. But until Tuesday night at Scandinavia House, in the first full program of the 18th annual MATA Festival, I had never heard a vocalist belch, burp and stutter his way through a fractured recomposition of “I’m Forever Blowing Bubbles.”

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: The legislature sent a bill legalizing medical marijuana to the governor on Wednesday after parents of children with debilitating seizures circulated the Capitol urging lawmakers to act. The House vote, 149 to 46, capped several years of door-to-door lobbying by parents. Calling it historic legislation, Gov. Tom Wolf, a Democrat, said he will sign it Sunday. The bill sets standards for tracking plants, certifying physicians and licensing growers, dispensaries and physicians. Patients could take marijuana in pill, oil, vapor or liquid form but would not be able to legally obtain marijuana to smoke or to grow their own. The Pennsylvania Medical Society opposed the bill, and one opponent, Representative Matt Baker, warned that it violates federal drug laws and that the state would see a drastic impact on addiction and abuse. Meanwhile, in Ohio, lawmakers promised to legalize medical marijuana by the summer, before voters get a chance to decide a ballot question in the fall election. Pennsylvania would be the 24th state to legalize a comprehensive medical marijuana program, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures. (AP)

Emery, the chairman of the civilian agency that provides oversight of the New York Police Department, resigned abruptly on Wednesday amid complaints from police unions about his public comments and one day after two agency employees filed a lawsuit accusing him of making sexist remarks.

headline: Stronger Bond With Mother Helps Texas Star Follow in Her Footsteps

keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: At a hearing, lawmakers excoriated Secretary General Ban Ki-moon and said they may consider withholding crucial funding and aid.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Lawmakers on Wednesday used a rare hearing in the United States Senate to excoriate the United Nations secretary general for what they called his failure to stanch sexual abuse by his agency’s peacekeepers and threatened to withhold crucial funding not only for the United Nations, but also bilateral aid for countries that fail to hold their soldiers accountable.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Jury System']
abstract: A juror in the trial of Mr. Liang, who shot Akai Gurley in a stairwell, is said to have hidden the fact that his father had been imprisoned for an accidental shooting.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest police misconduct cases in recent New York history, a criminal proceeding that riveted the city this winter and was swept up in the national debate about race and law enforcement, was threatened on Wednesday by an unusual and unexpected question: Did one of the jurors, a retired carpenter, hide his father’s criminal past in order to be a panelist at the trial?

headline: F.B.I. Used Hacking Software Decade Before iPhone Fight
abstract: Newly declassified and released records show in new detail how F.B.I. hackers worked to defeat encryption over a decade before the agency’s recent fight with Apple over access to a locked iPhone.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In early 2003, F.B.I. agents hit a roadblock in a secret investigation, called Operation Trail Mix. For months, agents had been intercepting phone calls and emails belonging to members of an animal welfare group that was believed to be sabotaging operations of a company that was using animals to test drugs. But encryption software had made the emails unreadable.

Murray Abraham. Midway through the first act of this drama about clashes of faith and family, set in 12th-century Jerusalem, I found myself listing toward boredom.

Kerr was more concerned with chasing another championship.

headline: 2 Years After Boko Haram Kidnapping, the Search Goes On for Nigerian Girls

abstract: The mass abduction, on April 14, 2014, was just one of hundreds of acts of brutality that Boko Haram has rained down on West Africa in recent years.

headline: Why Should My Store Be Boycotted Over a Law I Despise?
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', 'Discrimination', 'Law and Legislation', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Boycotts']
abstract: We’re losing out on much needed revenue through book sales and authors’ appearances.
lead_paragraph: Asheville, N.C. — Malaprop’s Bookstore/Cafe is an independent bookseller in the center of Asheville, a beautiful, culturally diverse city surrounded by the mountains of western North Carolina. We host author events several nights a week, offer space to a dozen book clubs, set up forums on community issues, and welcome all kinds of folks through our doors. We’re a place away from work and home where a person can relax, feel safe and be inspired.

headline: The Real Welfare Cheats
abstract: The tax code is rigged to give America’s biggest corporations a free ride.
lead_paragraph: We often hear how damaging welfare dependency is, stifling initiative and corroding the human soul. So I worry about the way we coddle executives in their suites.

headline: Outrageous Sentences for Marijuana
abstract: An Alabama man is asking the Supreme Court to overturn a sentence that is the essence of cruel and unusual.
lead_paragraph: Lee Carroll Brooker, a 75-year-old disabled veteran suffering from chronic pain, was arrested in July 2011 for growing three dozen marijuana plants for his own medicinal use behind his son’s house in Dothan, Ala., where he lived. For this crime, Mr. Brooker was given a life sentence with no possibility of release.

headline: The Death of Liberalism
abstract: Authoritarianism is ascendant and with it anti-rational bigotry. History does not end. It eddies.
lead_paragraph: Liberalism is dead. Or at least it is on the ropes. Triumphant a quarter-century ago, when liberal democracy appeared to have prevailed definitively over the totalitarian utopias that exacted such a toll in blood, it is now under siege from without and within.

headline: Campaigns of Ultimate Disappointment
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: This country wasn’t designed to facilitate change. It took centuries to arrive at its current condition and will need time to shift away from it.
lead_paragraph: I’m already completely exhausted by this presidential campaign season. The candidates seem to share that fatigue. Nerves are fraying as story lines grow stale.

headline: In Paris, a Protest Movement Awakens
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Youth', 'Editorial Observer']
abstract: Students are rising up against the existing political and economic order.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A revolt over proposed labor-law reforms in France has set off an uprising among French youth, fed up, they say, over their government’s failure to tackle a host of problems and thus robbing them of their future. Calling itself Nuit Debout — roughly translatable as “Standing Up at Night” — the movement recalls Spain’s 2011 anti-austerity Indignados movement and the Occupy movement in the United States. But there are also echoes of France’s own history of popular revolt, including the student-led protests of May 1968.

headline: The Lessons of Kasich

lead_paragraph: We have reached, at last, the John Kasich moment. The next six Republican primaries are in his kind of territory: blue states, Northeastern, moderate, exactly the sort of places where his positioning as the electable, reasonable Republican is designed to pay off big.

headline: Motivated by the Spirit of Chris Hondros
abstract: Bryan Denton, who was transformed by his coverage of the Libyan conflict, has been named the recipient of an award honoring his fallen comrade, the photographer Chris Hondros.
lead_paragraph: Covering the chaos of the Libyan civil war in 2011 transformed Bryan Denton. He began the war as a promising 27-year-old photojournalist and provided some of the most vivid coverage of the conflict for The New York Times. But it’s not his personal successes that stick with Mr. Denton — it’s the victims he photographed, and the deaths of several colleagues, especially his friend Chris Hondros.

headline: America Hasn’t Gone Crazy. It’s Just More Like Europe.
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Youth', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders would be right at home here.
lead_paragraph: Sofia, Bulgaria — FOR most Europeans these days, traveling to America is like landing on Mars. Even the most sophisticated political analysts can’t make head or tail of what is happening in the country. They are offended by the rise of Donald J. Trump, puzzled by Bernie Sanders’s democratic socialist appeal to young American voters, and confused by President Obama’s unsentimental, risk-averse foreign policy that decided against punishing President Bashar al-Assad of Syria for crossing Mr. Obama’s own red line on chemical weapons.

headline: Upping the Pressure on Egypt
abstract: Italy says it will no longer tolerate President Sisi’s human rights abuses. Other Western nations should do likewise.
lead_paragraph: Human rights abuses in Egypt under President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi have reached new highs, yet the Western governments that trade with and arm Egypt have continued to pursue business as usual with the argument that regional security and economic interests trump all. Now, a stalled investigation into the abduction and murder of an Italian student has forced at least one of these countries, Italy, to reconsider its relationship. It is time for other Western democracies to reconsider theirs.

headline: For Women Who Run, the Bathroom Problem
abstract: When to relieve oneself and where to do it is a tricky issue for female runners.
lead_paragraph: On a recent weekend trip to Washington, I was running in Rock Creek Park when the water and coffee I’d had that morning caught up with me. I’d run there only once before so was unsure where relief lay. I’m also a woman, so I couldn’t just pull over to the nearest bush or tree and relieve myself discreetly, the way guys do, through the benefits of outdoor plumbing.

A nation in the balance as its officials contend with an arcane electoral system that varies from state to state. A proud republic debased by a presidential campaign fixated on minor gaffes and riddled with filthy language.

headline: The Architect Ma Yansong Blends East and West
abstract: Ma Yansong, 40, has become one of China’s best-known architects. He talks about how traditional Eastern values inform his perspective.
lead_paragraph: Ma Yansong, 40, has become one of China’s best-known architects. His curvilinear, free-form and futuristic designs are often compared to those of his mentor, Zaha Hadid, who died on March 31 at 65. Mr. Ma says his greatest inspiration is nature; his recently completed opera house in the northern Chinese city of Harbin resembles a snow-capped mountain, while his master plan for the city of Nanjing calls for sloping buildings covered with vertical louvers that look like waterfalls. While Mr. Ma’s firm, MAD, continues to land splashy projects in China, he is also expanding in the United States. He will soon open MAD’s second American office, after Los Angeles, in New York, and now has three stateside projects underway: a high-rise in Manhattan; an apartment and retail complex in Beverly Hills, Calif.; and George Lucas’s provocative museum project in Chicago, a tent-like design that has gotten mixed reviews — one local politician compared it to a “palace for Jabba the Hutt.” In this edited interview, Mr. Ma talks about how he deals with such criticism, how traditional Eastern values inform his perspective and what he thinks about China’s ban on “weird” architecture.

headline: Morning Agenda: Five Banks Seen as Too Big to Fail
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Bankruptcies', 'Company Reports', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment', 'Medicare', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: JPMorgan’s Results Beat Expectations | Health Regulator Threatens Theranos With Harsh Sanctions
lead_paragraph: FIVE BANKS SEEN AS TOO BIG TO FAIL | Nearly eight years after the financial crisis, five of the largest American banks are still seen as too big to fail,  Nathaniel Popper and Peter Eavis write in DealBook. The Federal Reserve and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation determined that JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, Wells Fargo, State Street and Bank of New York Mellon submitted plans for insolvency, also known as living wills, that were “not credible or would not facilitate an orderly resolution under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code.” Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley received passing grades from only one of the two agencies.
