lead_paragraph: LONDON — “Julieta,” a new movie by Pedro Almodóvar; “It’s Only the End of the World,” by the upstart Canadian director Xavier Dolan; and “The Last Face,” a Sean Penn movie set in Africa, are among the movies that will compete for the Palme d’Or at this year’s Cannes Film Festival, festival officials said on Thursday.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Squirrels
abstract: They are like us and right there with us, our honored frenemies.
lead_paragraph: The philosopher William James once posed the following problem: A squirrel runs around the trunk of a tree, and a man, trying to see the squirrel, chases it. But in the end, the man is unable to catch up to the squirrel; all he sees is bark and more bark. “He goes round the tree, sure enough, and the squirrel is on the tree,” the philosopher says, “but does the man go round the squirrel or not?”

headline: The Fresher the Spice, the Better the Chicken Paprikash
abstract: The essence of this Hungarian dish begins with paprika.
lead_paragraph: It was Christopher Columbus who brought the pepper to Europe, a souvenir of his travels in the New World, and the Ottoman Empire that brought it to Eastern Europe, dried and ground fine into crimson spice. Hungarians in particular went mad for the stuff, stirring the seasoning into their theretofore-plain stews and fricassees: paprika, they called it, from the Latin piper, or “pepper.”

headline: In the Hospital, Resisting the Urge to Do More
abstract: So often when a patient is dying, I must hold myself and my residents back and quiet our itchy fingers.
lead_paragraph: There was absolutely no way around it. She was dying. I gave her a few hours at best, with maximum pedal to the metal intensive medical care. Paramedics had picked up this homeless woman after she collapsed under a bridge in Oakland, Calif. Her heart had completely stopped. She had died under that bridge. But the paramedics had somehow pulled her back, with a jump-start to her heart. And then brought her right to my service in the intensive care unit.

headline: The Muzzling of the Malaysian Mind
abstract: The Najib administration’s assault on free expression is unprecedented.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — On Thursday the High Court here rejected yet another challenge to the Sedition Act, paving the way for the government’s record-breaking case against the political cartoonist Zulkiflee Anwar Haque, better known as Zunar, to proceed. Zunar faces up to 43 years in prison on nine counts of sedition — the most counts anyone in Malaysia has ever been charged with.

headline: California Surfers Look to Courts for Relief Against ‘Bay Boys’

headline: Taking a Trip, Literally, on Colorado’s Pot Trail
abstract: Weed purveyors are counting on tourists to toke up. But a race through the offerings on a long weekend is almost enough to harsh your mellow. Almost.
lead_paragraph: We were somewhere north of Denver, not far from the pot farm, when my neighbor on the party bus pulled hard on his pipe and said: “Know what it is I love about this country? Everyone gets stoned.”

headline: Where to Go in New Orleans
abstract: The once thriving Central City is coming back as a cultural and commercial destination.
lead_paragraph: Central City is far from the pandemonium of Bourbon Street. An area sandwiched between the French Quarter and the Uptown residential neighborhood, its main thoroughfare, Oretha Castle Haley Boulevard, was a thriving shopping and cultural district in the late 19th century and a hub of civil rights activism in the 1960s. But the area eventually became rundown. Now, thanks largely to investments from the New Orleans Redevelopment Authority and resolute entrepreneurs, Central City is re-emerging as a cultural and commercial destination.

headline: Targeting Beyond China
abstract: In an era of easy access to global news, Beijing is going after critics outside its borders.
lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — On March 27, Chinese police crashed my father’s 70th birthday party in China’s southwestern Sichuan Province. They accused my family of causing a forest fire the day before by lighting incense and burning paper as part of the annual tomb- sweeping festival to honor deceased relatives. Three of my siblings were summoned to the police station and found out quickly that they were not being detained over an arson charge.

headline: Capability Brown, the Master of the English Garden

lead_paragraph: Few people have had as large an impact on British gardens as the landscape artist Lancelot Brown, more often known as Capability Brown. His naturalistic style and gracious designs have proved timeless, and his gardens remain popular almost 300 years after he did his best work.

headline: How to Watch the Democratic Debate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders will meet in Brooklyn on Thursday night to discuss their differences before the New York primary on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Join us for live analsis of the Democratic debate.

headline: New York Times Plans International Digital Expansion
abstract: The company announced that it would invest $50 million on a strategy to increase its digital audience and revenue outside the United States.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Company will invest more than $50 million over the next three years to support an ambitious plan to expand its international digital audience and increase revenue outside the United States, the company said on Thursday. The Times has formed a new team, NYT Global, to lead the effort.

headline: Many Verizon Customers Not Likely to Notice Strike
abstract: The East Coast workers who walked off the job Wednesday are largely employed in the wireline business, though a handful of wireless employees joined them.
lead_paragraph: About 36,000 Verizon workers on the East Coast went on strike Wednesday. Did you notice?

headline: 1941: Mrs. Roosevelt’s Plea
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Mrs. Roosevelt pleads for tolerance in 1941.
lead_paragraph: A novice in the field of propaganda organizations, the three-week-old Women United filled Carnegie hall last night with 2,300 ardent peace-lovers. They came to the hall to hear speeches by Senator Bennett Champ Clark, Democrat of Missouri; Senator Robert R. Reynolds, Democrat of North Carolina; Mrs Robert A Taft, wife of the Republican Senator from Ohio, and Mrs Theodore Roosevelt Jr.

headline: Stopping OS X Apps From Automatically Starting
abstract: If you notice certain programs are open already when you log in to your Mac, you can change the settings to alter their behavior.
lead_paragraph: Q. When I turn on my Mac, I notice the Dock shows Google Chrome always open, even though the browser window doesn’t appear on screen and I’m not opening the program myself. Why is this and how do I turn it off?

headline: Wall Street Art Show Postponed
abstract: An ambitious pop-up exhibition in the former home of J.P. Morgan & Company will open in May, its organizer said.
lead_paragraph: A sprawling pop-up art show that was set to take over almost 150,000 square feet of 23 Wall Street has been postponed and shortened because of funding issues. Simon Birch, the show’s Hong Kong-based organizer and primary artist, has raised $3 million, including $1 million of his own money, but came up short on funds for the nonprofit putting on the show.

headline: Justin Trudeau Seeks to Legalize Assisted Suicide in Canada
abstract: The prime minister has introduced legislation to address the legal void left after Canada’s Supreme Court overturned a ban on doctor-assisted death.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The government of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau introduced legislation on Thursday to legalize physician-assisted suicide for Canadians with a “serious and incurable illness,” which has brought them “enduring physical or psychological suffering.”

headline: Jane Austen and Shakespeare, for the 21st Century
abstract: In two new series of books, writers like Margaret Atwood and Curtis Sittenfeld are reimagining the classics for a modern audience.
lead_paragraph: Great stories are timeless, but times have changed — and so two wonderfully irreverent new series of books are updating some of the classics. The Austen Project puts Janeite favorites like “Pride and Prejudice” in the hands of contemporary writers like Curtis Sittenfeld, whose “Eligible” (Random House, April 19) recasts Elizabeth Bennet and Mr. Darcy as a magazine writer and a neurosurgeon in modern-day Cincinnati. And for the Crown Publishing Group’s Hogarth Shakespeare series, novelists such as Howard Jacobson and Margaret Atwood are reimagining the Bard’s works in modern prose.

headline: Why Do Older People Love Facebook? Let’s Ask My Dad
abstract: Americans in their 60s and 70s are embracing social media enthusiastically, new research shows.
lead_paragraph: When Facebook was born in 2004, the oldest baby boomers were in their late 50s, and older members of the silent generation were reaching their early 80s. If you thought they were going to sit back and let gifs, emojis and status updates pass them by, you were wrong, according to new research.

headline: Donald Trump’s Allies Look to Make Friends in Congress
abstract: Members of Donald J. Trump’s House Leadership Committee will hold a meeting at a private club in Washington on Thursday with about a dozen House members, a mix of Trump supporters and those who remain uncommitted to a candidate.
lead_paragraph: While Donald J. Trump is busy barnstorming New York, his allies in Washington are busy trying to win the support of Republicans on Capitol Hill.

headline: Houston Deputy Is Shot in Ambush-Style Attack at Traffic Stop, Police Say
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A man shot and wounded a deputy constable in Houston late Wednesday in what the authorities described as an ambush-style attack.
lead_paragraph: A man shot and wounded a deputy constable at a traffic stop in Houston late Wednesday in what the authorities described as an ambush-style attack.

headline: Open Season on Jeremy Lin? In Video, Fan Highlights Hard Fouls
abstract: The video, showing the Asian-American player being fouled hard but never “flagrantly,” is meant to question fairness in the N.B.A., but much of the discussion has been about Lin’s race.
lead_paragraph: Hsiu-Chen Kuei waited until her husband and three sons had gone to bed one night recently before surreptitiously beginning work on an ambitious personal project.

headline: It’s Not Cancer: Doctors Reclassify a Thyroid Tumor
abstract: Medical experts reclassified as noncancerous a specific kind of thyroid tumor, sparing some patients aggressive treatments.
lead_paragraph: An international panel of doctors has decided that a type of tumor that was classified as a cancer is not a cancer at all.

headline: Tate Modern Announces Revamping of Collections for Opening of New Wing
abstract: The 10-story brick-clad extension, designed by the architects Herzog & de Meuron, will open on June 17.
lead_paragraph: LONDON —Tate Modern, the modern and contemporary art museum in London, on Thursday announced a reorganization of its collection displays that will be unveiled when a new wing opens on June 17.

headline: Tribeca Interview: Jason Sudeikis and Jessica Biel
abstract: “The Devil and the Deep Blue Sea,” which involved both as actors and Ms. Biel as a producer, took 10 years to make.
lead_paragraph: In “The Devil and the Deep Blue Sea,” having its world premiere Thursday at the Tribeca Film Festival, Jason Sudeikis plays a buttoned-down architect. When his extroverted and expectant wife, played by Jessica Biel, is killed in an accident, he finds it a struggle to cope. In his grief, he meets a homeless teenager (Maisie Williams), who has also experienced loss. The two build an unconventional bond and work through their trauma by building a raft meant to sail across the Atlantic.

headline: Automakers Revisit Tactics That Hurt Them Before Recession
abstract: Under pressure to maintain record sales, the industry is offering ever-increasing discounts, relying more on sales to rental fleets and bloating dealers’ inventories.
lead_paragraph: When the car industry collapsed in the recession, automakers pulled back sharply on aggressive leasing deals and other financial incentives that had artificially increased their sales for years.

headline: An Artist and a Poet Capture Death in a Hospice Room
abstract: Nari Ward responds to Carol Muske-Dukes’s poignant poem of grief.
lead_paragraph: For T’s ongoing series, the Rome prize-winning artist Nari Ward responded to a poem by Carol Muske-Dukes, the former poet laureate of California.

headline: 1966: Iraqi President Killed in Crash
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Iraqi president is killed in a helicopter crash in 1966.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — President Abdul Salem Aref and other top Iraqi government officials were killed last night [April 13] when their helicopter crashed during a violent sandstorm near the southern city of Basra. The other dead included Minister Abdul Latif Al-Darraji, Industry Minister Mustapha Abdullah and the governor of Basra district, Baghdad radio said. Premier Abdul Rahman Bazzaz immediately assumed presidential powers until a successor is elected. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 15, 1966

headline: U.S. Mideast Policy: The Israeli Ambassador’s View
abstract: The ambassador argues that American endorsement of a Security Council resolution would be a departure from United States policy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ringo Starr Cancels North Carolina Show, Also Citing Bias Law
keywords: ['Music', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Law and Legislation', 'Boycotts', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: The musician is among those canceling concerts after the state passed a law limiting bathroom access for transgender people.
lead_paragraph: Following Bruce Springsteen’s lead, Ringo Starr will not be performing in North Carolina any time soon. The former Beatles drummer announced that he was canceling a scheduled June 18 concert in Cary, N.C., in protest of a  law that limits bathroom access for transgender people and eliminates local anti-discrimination ordinances based on sexual orientation.

headline: Donald Trump Holding a Strong Lead in Pennsylvania
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Donald J. Trump has a 16-point lead in Pennsylvania, according to a new poll that shows moderate Republicans providing him a boost in the state ahead of its primary on April 26. There are 54 Republican delegates at stake in the state, but only 17 of them are bound to the winner.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump holds a double-digit lead in Pennsylvania, according to a new poll that shows moderate Republicans providing him a boost in the state ahead of its primary election later this month.

headline: Inglenook Focuses on the Long Term to Regain Its Glory
abstract: A new winemaker brought in by Coppola looks ahead 50 years, with ideas that run counter to Napa’s conventional wisdom.
lead_paragraph: RUTHERFORD, Calif. — When Philippe Bascaules arrived here in 2011 to take over as general manager of Inglenook Vineyard, one of the first things he did was to present the owners, Francis Ford Coppola and his wife, Eleanor, a plan for managing and renewing the grapevines. The plan covered the next 50 years.

headline: McCarter Theater’s Season to Include Nilo Cruz and Ken Ludwig
abstract: A new work from the author of “Anna in the Tropics” and a stage adaptation of “Murder on the Orient Express” will make their premieres.
lead_paragraph: A new work from the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Nilo Cruz (“Anna in the Tropics”) and a stage adaptation of Agatha Christie’s 1934 novel “Murder on the Orient Express” will make their premieres as part of the 2016-17 season at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton, N.J., the company announced on Thursday.

headline: Strong Earthquake Strikes Japan’s Kyushu Island, Killing at Least 9
abstract: The quake in the country’s southwest collapsed roads and buildings, knocked out power and was followed by a series of powerful aftershocks.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — A powerful earthquake struck the southwestern Japanese island of Kyushu on Thursday, killing nine people, collapsing roads and buildings, and knocking out power, officials said.

headline: It’s Probably Cheaper on the Web, Adobe’s Online Price Index Shows
keywords: ['Consumer Price Index', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'E-Commerce', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: The company’s monthly survey, released on Thursday, is meant to complement the Labor Department’s Consumer Price Index, which tracks fewer goods online.
lead_paragraph: Is the Internet making everything cheaper?

headline: Microsoft Sues Justice Department to Protest Electronic Gag Order Statute
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'E-Mail', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Electronic Communications Privacy Act', 'Cloud Computing']
abstract: The company is challenging the use of secrecy orders that prevent it from telling people when the government obtains a warrant to read their emails.
lead_paragraph: Big technology companies have usually played a defensive game with government prosecutors in their legal fight over customer information, fighting or bowing to requests for information one case at a time.

headline: Crabs Swarming on the Sea Floor
abstract: Thousands of red crabs swarmed the ocean floor off the coast of Panama.
lead_paragraph: Thousands of red crabs swarmed the ocean floor off the coast of Panama.

headline: Cuban Law on Cruises Prompts a Protest
keywords: ['Cruises', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Protesters outside Carnival Corporation headquarters demonstrated against a Cuban law that prohibits those born in the country from traveling by sea.
lead_paragraph: An estimated 50 protesters rallied outside the South Florida headquarters of Carnival Corporation this week, according to The Miami Herald, decrying the coming launch of its Cuba cruises from which Cuban-born travelers are barred.

headline: BP Shareholders Send ‘a Message’ Protesting Chief’s Pay
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: In a nonbinding vote that could affect Robert Dudley’s future pay, investors of the money-losing company protested his $19.6 million award for 2015.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a symbolic slap against high executive pay at a money-losing company, BP shareholders have voted against the $19.6 million compensation package for the chief executive, Robert W. Dudley.

headline: Iran’s President Is Squeezed by Opposition Leader’s Demand for a Trial
abstract: The request by the opposition leader, Mehdi Karroubi, who is under house arrest, highlighted a deepening rift in Iran’s reformist wing.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — An opposition leader long under house arrest has written a letter to President Hassan Rouhani demanding a public trial, putting the president in a difficult spot and highlighting a deepening rift in Iran’s reformist wing.

headline: How Regulators Mess With Bankers’ Minds, and Why That’s Good
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Not communicating to banks exactly what they need to do to get their bankruptcy plans to pass muster is frustrating, confusing and part of the plan.
lead_paragraph: Bank regulators on Wednesday sent a message that big banks are still too big and too complex. They rejected special plans, called living wills, that the banks have to submit to show they can go through an orderly bankruptcy.

headline: Alice Birch Speaks Softly and Writes Loud Plays
abstract: The British playwright’s American debut, “Revolt. She Said. Revolt Again.,” is a call for feminist revolution with a ferocity absent from her personal demeanor.
lead_paragraph: Arriving at the Metropolitan Museum of Art just as it opened one brisk April morning, the British playwright Alice Birch was on what she called a “morbid little trip” in pursuit of inspiration. Bunking on Wall Street in the run-up to her American debut at Soho Rep with “Revolt. She Said. Revolt Again.,” this 29-year-old had journeyed uptown to do research for a play she’s writing for the Royal Court Theater in London.

headline: Escaped Chimpanzee Captured in Japan
abstract: A male chimpanzee who had escaped from a local zoo was captured by city officials on Thursday in northern Japan. Zoo officials said the primate was not hurt during his capture.
lead_paragraph: A male chimpanzee who had escaped from a local zoo was captured by city officials on Thursday in northern Japan. Zoo officials said the primate was not hurt during his capture.

headline: Revelations From Panama Papers Are Old News for Africans
abstract: Many in Africa have long known that billions of dollars are being spirited away to tax havens every year, making their lives even more precarious.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — Outsiders have long claimed the moral high ground in accusing African elites of endemic corruption.

headline: Michelle Dorrance, the Tireless Ambassador of Tap
abstract: The MacArthur fellow is bringing her own company to the Joyce Theater with “ETM: Double Down,” a show that advances tap dance while honoring its heritage.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Dorrance talks like she dances: fast. Her sentences start in one direction, pause for a quick, somewhat related observation or a random aside — “On the horizon: Eliot Feld/Michelle Dorrance collaboration. I can’t wait to do that” — and pick up vaguely where they left off.

headline: Incense Ignited Bronx Fire That Killed 2 Girls, Officials Say
abstract: The girls’ mother told detectives she had left her apartment to get ice cream for the older daughter and then to attend to her laundry.
lead_paragraph: The mother of two young girls killed in a fire at a public housing project in the Bronx said she had just gone out to get ice cream for them and check on laundry when the blaze began, the police and her imam said on Thursday.

headline: The S.U.V. Arms Race Goes Upscale
keywords: ['Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks', 'New York International Auto Show', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Automobiles']
abstract: As the profits flow in from sport utility vehicles, automakers are aiming for the luxury market, with fancy new models in development or already in showrooms.
lead_paragraph: One of the last big profit centers for Detroit’s automakers, the sport utility vehicle, is under siege.

headline: Jed Bernstein Steps Down as Lincoln Center President
abstract: Jed Bernstein’s announcement came as a surprise; Katherine Farley, chairwoman of the board, will help keep things running until a successor is found.
lead_paragraph: After just two years in the position, Jed Bernstein is leaving as the president of Lincoln Center, the country’s largest nonprofit performing arts center. What in the world went wrong?

headline: Zika Threat in Miami
abstract: An immunology professor writes that local governments lack the resources and political will to monitor mosquito populations and limit their habitats.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why Can’t We Get Rid of Mosquitoes Entirely?
abstract: Sabrina Tavernise, a science reporter for The Times who has written about efforts to fight the Zika virus, considers the question.
lead_paragraph: Ask The Times, a Times Insider feature, draws on Times staff members’ expertise to answer questions about current events, science, sports, culture and whatever else is making headlines.

headline: Poll of British Muslims Reveals Startling Views, but Some Question Methodology
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: A new poll of British Muslims revealed attitudes on homosexuality and terrorism sharply out of step with broader public opinion.
lead_paragraph: A new poll of British Muslims revealed attitudes on homosexuality and terrorism sharply out of step with broader public opinion, but also set off a debate about the reliability of such surveys.

keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Law and Legislation', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Mandatory Sentencing']

headline: Send Us the Political Ads You See on Facebook
abstract: The Times wants to learn more about how political campaigns are targeting voters with online advertising. Install this tool to share with us the ads you see.
lead_paragraph: The Times wants to learn more about how political campaigns are targeting voters with online advertising. Install this tool to share with us the ads you see.

headline: No Time for Credibility
abstract: Gold bugs take over a fabled institution.
lead_paragraph: So, here we are with near-zero real interest rates on long-term government bonds; with a desperate need for infrastructure investment; with strong reason to believe that deficit spending in the current environment would actually improve the long-run fiscal picture, because the interest burden would be so low and higher growth would raise future revenues.

headline: Zika Virus Can Be Transmitted Through Anal Sex, C.D.C. Says
abstract: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention described a case of sexual transmission of the virus between two men in Texas.
lead_paragraph: The Zika virus can be transmitted by anal sex as well as vaginal sex, according to a report issued on Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: After O.J., ‘Confirmation’ Revisits Another ’90s Flashpoint: Anita Hill vs. Clarence Thomas
abstract: This HBO docudrama sticks studiously to the record, but it clearly sits on Ms. Hill’s side, attentive to the media spectacle’s toll on her.
lead_paragraph: The 1991 Supreme Court nomination hearings of Clarence Thomas, and the public accusation by the law professor Anita Hill that he had sexually harassed her years before, popularized the phrase “He said, she said.” (With some help from the Kevin Bacon-Elizabeth Perkins movie of the same year.) But for every he and she in such a case, there’s a “they”: the people who listen, who provide the soapbox, who control the microphone.

headline: Nanny Accused of Killing 2 Children in Manhattan Rejects a Plea Deal
abstract: The offer would have given Yoselyn Ortega a sentence of 30 years to life in prison for fatally stabbing the siblings in their apartment.
lead_paragraph: A nanny accused of killing two children under her care in their Manhattan apartment turned down an offer from a judge on Thursday that would have given her a prison sentence of 30 years to life in return for guilty pleas to both murders.

headline: Angela Merkel, Accused of Betraying Core Values, Faces a Balancing Act With Turkey
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Censorship', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Comedy and Humor']
abstract: The political costs of doing business with the Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, are becoming clearer by the week for the German chancellor.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Last September, Chancellor Angela Merkel was widely seen as an idealist, charitably welcoming hundreds of thousands of refugees to Germany in the face of stiff opposition at home and from European allies. But the influx swiftly became too much to handle.

headline: Curtis Sittenfeld Is No Jane Austen, but She’s O.K. With That
abstract: Ms. Sittenfeld discusses how she came to write her new novel, “Eligible,” an updated reimagining of Austen’s 1813 classic, “Pride and Prejudice.”
lead_paragraph: It takes confidence — some might even say hubris — to rewrite one of the most beloved novels in the English canon.

headline: In Milan, an Exhibition That Explores What It Means to Be Human
abstract: “Neo-Prehistory: 100 Verbs,” at La Triennale, traces the course of our existence through carefully chosen and symbolically represented words.
lead_paragraph: The annual Salone del Mobile fair, held in Milan this week, is a collection of the world’s biggest design objects in one place. But amid it all is a very different kind of show: “Neo-Prehistory: 100 Verbs,” which is on view at La Triennale, attempts to boil down the totality of life on earth today to its absolute essentials.

headline: Battery Charge Against Corey Lewandowski, Trump Campaign Manager, Is Dropped
abstract: The charge stemmed from an incident in Florida in which Mr. Lewandowski was accused of forcibly grabbing a female reporter.
lead_paragraph: Corey Lewandowski, the campaign manager for Donald J. Trump, will not be prosecuted on a battery charge, the Palm Beach County state attorney said Thursday.

headline: At the World Bank, a Shortage of Concrete (Language)
abstract: An analysis of decades of annual reports from the bank shows a steady decline in factual precision.
lead_paragraph: In his 1946 essay “Politics and the English Language,” George Orwell wrote that “the whole tendency of modern prose is away from concreteness.” He could have been writing about World Bank reports, it turns out.

headline: Belgian Court Lengthens Prison Term of Jihadist Recruiter
abstract: The sentence for Khalid Zerkani, convicted of recruiting young men to join the jihadist fight in Syria, was increased from 12 years to 15.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A Belgian appellate court on Thursday increased to 15 years, from 12, the sentence of a Muslim man who had been convicted of persuading dozens of young men in Belgium — including some who were involved in the terrorist attacks on Paris — to join the jihadist fight in Syria.

headline: When You Dream of Provence, You Dream of This Town
abstract: Saint-Rémy is still the platonic ideal of the Provençal village — only now there’s some nice modern design amid its cobblestoned streets and ancient ruins.
lead_paragraph: Like a pair of navy espadrilles, Saint-Rémy — a small Provençal town an hour’s drive north from Marseille — has always been fashionable ... but rarely trendy. With its gurgling centuries-old fountains, winding streets and shuttered sandstone houses, its beauty is of the timeless, low-key sort, remarkable for its unselfconsciousness. It’s where, looking out from the window of his asylum, Van Gogh painted “The Starry Night,” and not even the many fashion world denizens who have taken over the thick-walled farmhouses on the town’s outer edges (Pierre Bergé converted several tracts into a jungly Moroccan refuge) could disrupt its sense of serenity.

headline: Fracking: Weighing Risks and Benefits
abstract: Readers react to an Op-Ed’s writer’s argument that liberalism and fracking are not incompatible.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Issues New Rules on Offshore Oil and Gas Drilling
keywords: ['Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Oil Spills', 'Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The regulations are aimed at preventing the kind of failures that caused the disastrous 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico and come amid a proposal for Arctic drilling.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday unveiled a final set of regulations on offshore oil and gas drilling that are aimed at preventing the kind of equipment failures that caused the disastrous 2010 oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.

headline: China’s Growing Ardor for Overseas Shopping
abstract: A surge in Chinese buyers, many of them unknown in the West, requires a new level of due diligence because the logic of some deals is hard to follow.
lead_paragraph: Nelson Peltz sat on the board of Legg Mason, the $3.7 billion asset management company, for five years while his hedge fund, Trian Partners, scooped up 10 percent of the company’s stock.

headline: Vladimir Putin’s Vulnerable Side Is at Fore in Call-In Show
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'International Relations']
abstract: Domestic concerns, not international swaggering, dominated the choreographed call-in show, amid a second, punishing year of recession in Russia.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A somewhat humbled, or at least not swaggering, President Vladimir V. Putin held his annual, live call-in show on Thursday, with his answers to the choreographed calls intended to underscore his concern for the plight of ordinary Russians amid a second, punishing year of recession.

headline: Texting in Movie Theaters? AMC Backs Off After Criticism
abstract: Adam Aron, the chief executive of AMC, soon to be the largest theater chain in the country, had floated the idea as a way to attract younger viewers.
lead_paragraph: The chief executive of AMC Entertainment, which is about to become the biggest movie theater chain in the country, floated the idea of letting people text in theaters, but within a day had backed off the idea.

headline: Hot or Not: How to Sell ‘Sex With Strangers’
abstract: A look at art for six productions of Laura Eason’s play, with rankings of where they fall on a steamy scale.
lead_paragraph: Someone is not having “Sex With Strangers.”

headline: Driven | 2016 Porsche Macan S
abstract: Smaller than the company's Cayenne S.U.V., the Macan proves that compact crossovers can be more than just practical transportation. They can be a thrill to drive.
lead_paragraph: Smaller than the company's Cayenne S.U.V., the Macan proves that compact crossovers can be more than just practical transportation. They can be a thrill to drive.

headline: Video Review: The Macan, a Lively Crossover From Porsche
abstract: This is a small, practical all-wheel-drive S.U.V. that not only performs like a sports car, but like a Porsche sports car.
lead_paragraph: When Porsche added the Cayenne sport utility vehicle to its lineup in 2003, loyalists reacted as if Beelzebub himself would ride in to usher in doomsday. Funny how it became the best-selling vehicle the company makes.

headline: A Roommate Blabs About a Night Best Forgotten
abstract: Also, disparaging tattoos, how to resist a hugger, and a vegetarian at Passover.
lead_paragraph: I am a freshman in college. Last summer, my roommate and I went to a club, where I took some Molly (MDMA) and proceeded to pass out. It was terrible, but I learned a valuable lesson. Nearly a year later, my friend is still telling the story to everyone she meets. Thanks to her, practically everyone at school knows me as “the girl who passed out in the club.” I’ve asked her nicely to stop. Her response: “It was traumatic for me, too.” Can this friendship be saved?

headline: Harlem Man Found Guilty of Murder in 4-Year Gang War
abstract: Taylonn Murphy, 20, was also convicted of conspiring to kill members of rival gangs in the long-running dispute that was responsible for two murders, including the death of his sister.
lead_paragraph: A 20-year-old Harlem man was convicted on Thursday of conspiracy and murder for his role in a four-year gang war in West Harlem that was responsible for several shootings and two murders, including the death of his sister, a high school basketball star.

headline: How We Live-Chat a Presidential Debate
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Debates (Political)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: A major secret to success, according to the Times political correspondent Nicholas Confessore: “the right balance of caffeine and sodium.”
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Nicholas Confessore, a political correspondent for The Times, describes the adrenaline rush of real-time debate and election analysis (here’s tonight’s live chat).

headline: James Levine, Transformative at the Met Opera, Is Stepping Down
abstract: Mr. Levine, 72, has struggled to hold on to his position as music director because of health problems, including Parkinson’s disease.
lead_paragraph: He struggled with health problems and surgeries for years, and missed two full seasons after a serious spinal injury in 2011. But James Levine, whose name became virtually synonymous with the Metropolitan Opera since becoming its music director four decades ago, always seemed to battle back, even conducting from a motorized wheelchair in recent years.

headline: Letters: Facing Dark Times
abstract: Readers respond to a recent essay about memoirs by young authors, a review of James McBride’s “Kill Em and Leave” and more.

headline: CBS Hopes for a Stephen Colbert Bump From a New Leader at ‘The Late Show’
abstract: CBS executives are betting that Chris Licht can build the audience for Mr. Colbert’s late-night show, as he has for “CBS This Morning.”
lead_paragraph: In early February, Stephen Colbert got a valuable piece of television real estate that no other late-night host had ever received: The post-Super Bowl slot, and the benefit of a lead-in from the biggest viewing audience of the year.

headline: On the Hunt for Tasty Morel Mushrooms
abstract: Fungiphiles rejoice. It’s morel mushroom season in much of the United States, meaning it’s time to hunt down these tasty treasures.
lead_paragraph: Fungiphiles rejoice. It’s morel mushroom season in much of the United States, meaning it’s time to hunt down these tasty treasures. They look like sponges or Dali-esque brains, but for those who’ve ever fried them up or experienced them in pasta sauce, their unique earthly flavor can’t be topped.

headline: Reclaiming Territorial Waters
abstract: Many British fishermen see a boon in leaving the European Union: They will get Europeans out of their waters.
lead_paragraph: Many British fishermen see a boon in leaving the European Union: They will get Europeans out of their waters.

headline: In Brexit Debate, English Fishermen Eye Waters Free of E.U.
keywords: ['Fishing, Commercial', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: As the vote on “Brexit” nears, an English Channel port is leaning toward Britain’s leaving the European Union and regaining control of its fishing grounds.
lead_paragraph: BRIXHAM, England — Mike Walker, a retired fisherman here, sums up what many in this southern English port town think of the European Union.

headline: Jaromir Jagr vs. Islanders: A Long, Point-Filled History
abstract: Jagr, who has more regular-season points against the Islanders than any other player, leads the Panthers in scoring.
lead_paragraph: In his 22 N.H.L. seasons, Jaromir Jagr has played more than 1,600 regular-season games. He has played more of them against the Islanders (109) than any other team. He has more regular-season goals (61), assists (93) and points (154) against the Islanders than any other player.

headline: ‘Behave,’ by Andromeda Romano-Lax
abstract: A fictionalized look at the romance between two well-known behavioral researchers.
lead_paragraph: BEHAVEBy Andromeda Romano-Lax391 pp. Soho Press. $26.95.

headline: Review: ‘Barbershop: The Next Cut’: Let the Debates Resume
abstract: This movie revives the “Barbershop” franchise, bringing back Ice Cube as the owner of a haircutting establishment on Chicago’s South Side.
lead_paragraph: Movie sequels don’t need — and frequently don’t have — a good reason to exist, other than to take more money from fans. “Barbershop: The Next Cut,” which revives a popular comedy franchise, has plenty of commercial appeal, not least as a kind of hip-hop all-star acting revue, with Common, Tyga and Nicki Minaj joining Ice Cube and Eve, who anchored the original “Barbershop.” That movie was a hit in 2002, and it spawned two earlier sequels and a cable TV series. This comeback feels like the opposite of cynical, though. If anything, it seems unusually urgent. We’re back at the barbershop because there’s an awful lot to talk about.

headline: Suit Against Maker of Gun in Newtown Massacre Can Proceed, Court Rules
keywords: ['Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Firearms', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'School Shootings and Armed Attacks']
abstract: A Connecticut judge ruled against the manufacturer of the rifle that Adam Lanza used in the attack; it had argued that a 2005 law offered immunity.
lead_paragraph: A Connecticut judge declined on Thursday to dismiss a lawsuit brought against the maker of the assault-style rifle that a gunman used in the 2012 massacre at Sandy Hook Elementary School to fatally shoot 26 people before killing himself.

headline: Japanese Official Describes Earthquake
abstract: Japan’s chief cabinet secretary said a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the island of Kyushu, leveling buildings, but the nuclear reactors there are safe.
lead_paragraph: Japan’s chief cabinet secretary said a magnitude 6.4 earthquake struck the island of Kyushu, leveling buildings, but the nuclear reactors there are safe.

headline: The Winds From Washington Chill Wall Street’s Deal Making
abstract: Companies are abandoning the biggest mergers, largely out of concern over how the government might react in an election year.
lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, the phones have been a little quieter. The workload has been a little lighter. The happy hours have been starting earlier.

headline: African Migrants in Italy
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: As last year’s stampede of Syrians through Greece and the Balkans plunged Europe into a political crisis, Italy absorbed many migrants from sub-Saharan Africa.
lead_paragraph: As last year’s stampede of Syrians through Greece and the Balkans plunged Europe into a political crisis, Italy absorbed many migrants from sub-Saharan Africa.

headline: After Europe and Turkey Strike a Deal, Fears Grow That Migrants Will Turn to Italy
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: With an agreement reached to curb the flow of refugees into Greece, there is new focus on a dangerous sea route from Libya to Italy.
lead_paragraph: MESSINA, Sicily — The old music school is overflowing. The building is now a migrant shelter for unaccompanied minors, able to house 224 teenagers — except that it is overstuffed with 281. And it is only early April. Migrant season in Sicily is just beginning.

headline: Living Near Greenery May Help You Live Longer
abstract: A study found that women whose homes were surrounded by vegetation had lower death rates than those who lived in areas with less vegetation.
lead_paragraph: Living near greenery may help you live longer.

headline: Anna Wintour, Robert De Niro and Jane Fonda at the Tribeca Film Festival
abstract: “The First Monday in May,” a documentary about the making of the “China: Through the Looking Glass” spring 2015 exhibition and gala at the Met’s Costume Institute, had its world premiere.
lead_paragraph: “The First Monday in May,” a documentary about the making of the “China: Through the Looking Glass” spring 2015 exhibition and gala at the Met’s Costume Institute, had its world premiere.

headline: Putin’s Annual Q. and A. Highlights
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke on issues including the Panama Papers, the G.D.P. and sanctions, and the Syrian campaign.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia spoke on issues including the Panama Papers, the G.D.P. and sanctions, and the Syrian campaign.

headline: ‘Mothering Sunday,’ by Graham Swift
abstract: Boy loves girl in a novel set in a great house in 1920s Britain.
lead_paragraph: MOTHERING SUNDAYA RomanceBy Graham Swift177 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95.

headline: Pakistan’s Premier Leaves the Country Amid Panama Papers Scandal
abstract: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif left Pakistan to receive medical treatment in London in the middle of an unfolding scandal over his family’s offshore wealth.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Speculation about the political fate of Pakistan’s embattled prime minister, Nawaz Sharif, was swirling on Thursday after he left the country in the middle of an unfolding scandal over his family’s offshore wealth.

headline: New York to Expand Gifted Offerings as Disparities Remain
abstract: The number of students who scored high enough to qualify for the programs rose this year, but there continues to be a divide between richer and poorer districts.
lead_paragraph: The number of students who scored high enough to qualify for New York City’s gifted and talented programs rose this year, the Education Department said on Thursday. But the neighborhoods in which those children live continued along a familiar pattern: In wealthy districts, more children take the tests, and score well on them, than in districts where families are poor.

headline: When the Loch Ness Monster Was in The Times
abstract: There were at least 55 New York Times articles about the monster in 1934.
lead_paragraph: A ripple stirred the lore of Loch Ness this week, but it was not the monster. It was a movie prop monster. The prop sank in 1969 during the filming of “The Private Life of Sherlock Holmes.” An underwater robot in search of evidence of the “real” monster found it.

headline: E-Cigarette Use by U.S. Teenagers Rose Last Year, Report Says
abstract: Federal data of youths found that though more have reported using the devices, it does not appear that they have acted as bridges to traditional cigarettes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — E-cigarette use continued to rise among young teenagers and preteens in the United States last year, according to new federal data, but cigarette smoking overall did not increase, suggesting that, at least so far, fears that the devices would hook a new generation on traditional cigarettes have not come to pass.

headline: Every Day’s a Holiday (or Two)
keywords: ['Holidays and Special Occasions', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Smartphones']
abstract: Private rituals are now public. Communal events are worldwide. Everyone is invited, and please bring a smartphone.
lead_paragraph: Call me a party pooper, but I did nothing this year to mark Pi Day. I baked neither a sweet nor a savory pie. Perhaps worse, but without deliberate offense to STEM-loving peoples, I also failed to observe Albert Einstein’s birthday that day — no Instagrammed black-hole image or chummy post on Einstein’s official Facebook page wishing him an HBD.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Green Room'
abstract: Jeremy Saulnier narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Saulnier narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: Jeremy Saulnier Narrates a Scene From ‘Green Room’
abstract: The director discusses his film about a punk band who must battle with neo-Nazis.
lead_paragraph: The members of a young punk band face off against militant neo-Nazis in the thriller “Green Room,” the new film from the writer and director Jeremy Saulnier. In this scene, the musicians find themselves trapped in a rock club’s green room. A murder has just taken place there, but outside, the rock concert continues. During an interview at The Times, Mr. Saulnier discussed some of his ideas behind the scene and his film. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Where the Abused, and Their Pets, Can Be Safe
abstract: Some victims of domestic violence no longer have to make the agonizing choice between their safety and their pets.
lead_paragraph: Ms. H decided she had to move out of her mother’s apartment last spring after her drug-addicted sister held a knife to her throat and threatened to kill her.

headline: Ruling Juror Didn’t Lie, Judge Upholds Ex-Officer’s Conviction in Stairwell Shooting
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Jury System', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: The verdict against Peter Liang in the fatal shooting of Akai Gurley had been imperiled by the revelation that a juror withheld information about a similar family episode.
lead_paragraph: Finding that a juror had not lied to get himself impaneled at the trial, a judge denied a motion on Thursday to overturn the conviction of Peter Liang, the former New York City police officer found guilty in February of fatally shooting Akai Gurley in a housing project stairwell.

headline: An Artist’s Piercing Yet Playful Look at Race
abstract: The charismatic Los Angeles-based artist Rodney McMillian has two exhibitions in New York and one in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: A charismatic video performer and creator of metaphorically loaded paintings and sculptures, Rodney McMillian addresses the experiences of African-Americans with an imaginative, angry yet often playful spirit. Based in Los Angeles, where he teaches at U.C.L.A., he’s now having a well-deserved East Coast moment, with exhibitions running concurrently in New York at MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, and at the Studio Museum in Harlem; and in Philadelphia at the Institute of Contemporary Art.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, April 16 Through April 24
abstract: Emanuel Ax will perform Beethoven’s piano sonatas on April 25 at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: On Instagram, a Surfer’s Safari
abstract: The competitive surfer Evan Geiselman has been all around this great big world, and he’s seen all kinds of waves (Tahiti is his favorite place).
lead_paragraph: @evangeiselman

headline: Review: An All-Vivaldi Program, With a Twist or Two
abstract: Accademia Bizantina, an Italian period-instrument ensemble, toyed with the tempo of the works, heightening the music’s impatience, pathos or humor.
lead_paragraph: “Robin Hood.” “Savings and Loans.” Musicians have different terms for the practice of bending the tempo. Shorthands like these are reminders that the Italian term “rubato” — meaning “stolen time” — should not be applied in one direction only, slowing down a phrase to milk it for expression. As the example of Robin Hood shows, a thief can also give back.

headline: With Czechia, Czech Republic Hopes Vowels Will Solve Name Puzzle
abstract: While the moniker does not necessarily end the potential confusion with other countries, proponents hope it rolls off the tongue in English more easily.
lead_paragraph: The Czechs, pushed and pulled between East and West over the centuries, have long suffered from an identity crisis.

headline: Uncovering a Deep-Sea Swarm of Zombie Crabs
abstract: In the murky ocean depths, marine biologists witnessed what looks like a scene from ‘The Walking Dead’: A swarm of crabs marching like a zombie horde.
lead_paragraph: In the murky depths of Panama’s Pacific coast, marine biologists witnessed what looks like a scene from “The Walking Dead”: Thousands of crabs marching like a zombie horde.

headline: Baseball Has Yet to Deliver Greatest Tribute to Jackie Robinson
abstract: The sport celebrates Robinson every year, but with few blacks and Latinos in management, it has resisted the changes he hoped for.
lead_paragraph: For me, Jackie Robinson day is a celebration of struggle and perseverance, a reminder that hope and progress in civil rights are often mistimed allies.

headline: Review: ‘The First Monday in May’ Goes Behind the Scenes at the Met
abstract: This documentary looks at the creation of the 2015 exhibition “China: Through The Looking Glass” and the benefit that coincides with its opening.
lead_paragraph: Early in this ostensible documentary directed by Andrew Rossi, a title card comes close to boasting about the access the filmmakers had to the creation of the exhibition and the attendant gala that are the film’s subjects. “The First Monday in May” refers to a day every year on which New York’s Metropolitan Museum of Art closes to host a star-studded benefit that coincides with the opening of a special exhibition from its Costume Institute.

headline: Movie Listings for April 15-21
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.
lead_paragraph: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Paul Ryan on Foreign Policy Is Closer to Hillary Clinton Than Donald Trump
abstract: Declaring himself “not a neocon,” the House speaker laid out views that are less hawkish than those of virtually all of his party’s presidential contenders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “I am not a neocon,” House Speaker Paul D. Ryan said on Thursday, mapping out a series of foreign policy views that separated him from virtually all of the Republicans who have sought the presidential nomination this year.

headline: Review: ‘Rio, I Love You,’ Stories That Make Up a Mash Note to a City
abstract: The directors of this anthology film, a paean to Rio de Janeiro, include Paolo Sorrentino, Guillermo Arriaga and Im Sang-soo.
lead_paragraph: The assumption behind omnibus movies — features built out of shorts by various directors, generally on a common theme — is that the contributions will, on balance, add up to a satisfying experience. But this law-of-averages thinking rarely yields a full meal for filmgoers. Usually, the results are a few good shorts, a few terrible shorts and a frustrating lack of cohesion.

headline: A Preserved Kayak Floats an Exhibition in Alaska
abstract: An oiled sealskin kayak from around 1850 has been loaned to the Alutiiq Museum in Kodiak, Alaska, where it goes on display April 22.
lead_paragraph: An oiled sealskin kayak made around 1850 by Alutiiq artisans in Alaska spent decades largely forgotten in storage at Harvard’s Peabody Museum of Archaeology & Ethnology. The newly restored vessel has been shipped to the Alutiiq Museum in Kodiak, Alaska, for a 10-year loan. It goes on display next Friday.

headline: Review: ‘My Big Night,’ a Dark Farce Juggling Behind-the-Scenes Dramas
abstract: Álex de la Iglesia’s comedy, set at the filming of a New Year’s Eve television special, deals with murder, blackmail, riots, jealousy and a crane crash.
lead_paragraph: The show must go on in Álex de la Iglesia’s sprawling ensemble dark comedy “My Big Night,” and it does, like an express train. It begins when a camera crane fatally crushes an extra during the filming of a New Year’s Eve variety TV show in which dancers and singers perform before a seated audience clad in formal wear. A producer’s indifference and desperate haste to remove the body, avoid liabilities and proceed with shooting give you an idea of where this frenzied, Almodóvaresque backstage farce is going.

headline: Comedy Listings for April 15-21
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: Meeting With Merrick Garland, G.O.P. Senators Take Long Time to Say No
abstract: Many of his meetings with Republicans have lasted 45 minutes or longer, even though almost all oppose a vote on his Supreme Court nomination.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Republican senators meeting with Judge Merrick B. Garland seem to take quite a long time to simply say “no.”

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, April 16 Through April 24
abstract: Rhett Miller of Old 97’s will perform with Belle of the Fall on April 29 at Daryl’s House in Pawling.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

headline: Review: In ‘Green Room,’ a Scruffy Comic Flavor Turns Tense
abstract: A punk band booked at a roadhouse whose patrons are skinheads unleashes a cover of the Dead Kennedys’ anthem insulting “Nazi punks.” Trouble ensues.
lead_paragraph: In the opening scene of “Green Room,” the members of the Ain’t Rights, a punk band from the East Coast, wake up in a cornfield somewhere in the Pacific Northwest. The driver fell asleep at the wheel, the van is out of gas, and the hassles escalate after that. A promised gig falls through, a podcast interview becomes a little awkward, and the group’s corporate assets, not counting the van and the gear inside it, add up to around $25 and a few takeout containers of rice and beans.

headline: Review: ‘The Midnight Assassin’ Recalls Murderous Mayhem in Austin
abstract: In his first book, the journalist Skip Hollandsworth recounts a string of gruesome unsolved killings in 19th-century Texas.
lead_paragraph: Skip Hollandsworth knows his way around a crime scene. Since 1989, he has written about a wide range of subjects for  Texas Monthly, but his most memorable pieces — featuring bank robbers, disappearing teenagers, murdered prostitutes — are about the grim events that get cordoned off behind yellow tape.

abstract: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

abstract: This season, a handful of new purses pack a bright punch.
lead_paragraph: This season, a handful of new purses pack a bright punch.

abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

headline: Review: Recycled ‘Jungle Book’ Puts a Real Boy in a Forest of Pixels
abstract: This Disney redo, by Jon Favreau, is a live-action movie that’s heavy on C.G.I. and a sunny vibe borrowed from the 1967 original.
lead_paragraph: Disney’s new take on “The Jungle Book” is being touted as a live-action movie, though there’s scarcely anything alive in it. That goes for the gaudy and glorious flora, the gathering clouds and the wind stirring them, all of which were created, with various degrees of believability, via computers. The child playing Mowgli — the human orphan turned wolf child — is played by an actual kid, who frolics with computer-generated critters, a smart call, given that animals can be tricky to work with and that some of this menagerie’s real-life equivalents are (sorry to be a bummer) endangered.
