headline: Israeli Soldier to Be Charged With Manslaughter in Shooting of Palestinian Assailant
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Palestinians', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Military Tribunals']
abstract: The episode, captured on video, has pitted military and defense officials who say procedures were breached against those who see the soldier as a hero.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel’s military on Thursday said prosecutors intended to file a manslaughter charge against a soldier who fatally shot a Palestinian assailant in the head in the West Bank city of Hebron last month as he lay on a road, wounded and subdued.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Art in review, from Times critics.

headline: Review: ‘Our Last Tango’ Celebrates Two Virtuosos of the Form
abstract: German Kral’s documentary is a portrait of the dancers María Nieves and Juan Carlos Copes, leading tango performers for almost 50 years.
lead_paragraph: German Kral’s documentary “Our Last Tango” is a combination of things, all fascinating: a portrait of María Nieves and Juan Carlos Copes, a world-renowned pair of tango dancers, and their professional partnership of almost 50 years; a stylized staging of their romantic and artistic history, performed by young dancers; and a celebration of the tango itself, which continues to bewitch with its writhing, gently jagged grace and torrid suggestiveness.

headline: Bernie Sanders Laces Speech With Themes of Race, and Gets Warm Reception From Activists
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders wove issues of race and civil rights into his standard speech about income inequality and overhauling the campaign finance system as he sought to win over an influential crowd of black leaders.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders wove issues of race and civil rights into his standard speech about income inequality and overhauling the campaign finance system on Thursday as he sought to win over an influential crowd of black leaders.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, April 16 Through April 24
abstract: Katt Williams will perform on April 23 and 24 in the Grand Theater at Foxwoods Resort Casino in Mashantucket.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: The Week in Pictures: April 15
abstract: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

headline: Review: San Francisco Symphony at Carnegie Hall
abstract: Michael Tilson Thomas led the symphony in a program focused on overlooked Copland works.
lead_paragraph: With a series of enduringly popular works like “Appalachian Spring” and “Rodeo,” the gay, Jewish, Brooklyn-born Aaron Copland practically invented the sound we think of as American. Yet the composer of “Fanfare for the Common Man” could also be flinty, brash and radical.

headline: Review: Miami City Ballet, a Troupe at Home Outside Its Turf
abstract: The troupe made its Lincoln Center debut with a double bill of Balanchine’s “Serenade” and Alexei Ratmansky’s “Symphonic Dances.”
lead_paragraph: Bold, light, immediate, intensely musical, the dancing of Miami City Ballet flies straight to the heart. This company is now 30 years old; it’s long been of international stature, with successful seasons at the Edinburgh Festival (1994 and 1995) and in Paris (2011).

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for April 15-21
abstract: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

headline: For Edge in a Faster N.H.L., Players Turn to Figure Skaters
abstract: Hockey players are realizing that the attention to form and technique in figure skating can help increase their speed and fluidity.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO — Sam Reinhart was at a rookie showcase in Toronto two years ago, months after the Buffalo Sabres drafted him second over all. There to have his photo taken for the sports-card maker Upper Deck, he took part in a video promotion in which a figure skating coach put him and other teenage prospects through pirouettes and pairs routines while they were wearing hockey equipment.

headline: Review: The Return of ‘Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt’
abstract: Robert Carlock and Tina Fey’s Netflix series begins Season 2 with its tireless, formless, free-flowing pursuit of laughs intact.
lead_paragraph: Early in the second season of Netflix’s “Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt” comes this exchange between Jacqueline (Jane Krakowski), a financially embarrassed Manhattan socialite, and Kimmy (Ellie Kemper), her effervescent nanny and all-around helpmate.

headline: Review: Lea Salonga Puts on a Show, No Need for Wailing Pyrotechnics
abstract: Ms. Salonga mixed standards and contemporary songs, digging deeply into the lyrics in a most satisfying cabaret shows, at Feinstein’s/54 Below.
lead_paragraph: Forget the saccharine ballads wailed by Disney princesses and other kitsch associated with the Broadway singer Lea Salonga, who appeared on Wednesday evening at Feinstein’s/54 Below. Those songs were bunched into a medley that she performed near the end of her show, and fans of them cheered happily.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders, Boko Haram
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Los Sures’ Resurrects South Williamsburg in 1984
abstract: Diego Echeverria’s decades-old documentary opened a modest window on the neighborhood by focusing on five people who lived there.
lead_paragraph: White Adidas kicks, boomboxes, break dancing — the 1984 documentary “Los Sures” is an eye-popping New York time capsule. There are other signs of those times, too, like graffiti, boarded-up buildings and empty lots that blemish the neighborhood in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where the film takes place. This is the old Williamsburg, back in the day, before it was synonymous with white expansionism and became grist for trend stories about beards, brew pubs and organic toys for pets, specifically the Williamsburg known in Spanish as Los Sures — the Souths or Southside.

headline: Review: Katherine Jenkins, a Little Bit Classical, a Little Bit Pop
abstract: Ms. Jenkins brings her quasi-operatic show, “Viva la Diva,” to Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: The diluted highbrow music known as “classical crossover” is much more popular in Britain than in the United States, where a major promotional effort several years ago failed to establish the Welsh mezzo-soprano Katherine Jenkins as the female Andrea Bocelli. But if you don’t succeed, you can try again. And on Tuesday evening, Ms. Jenkins opened at Café Carlyle with her “Viva la Diva.”

headline: Review: ‘Echo Park,’ the Story of an Early Romance
abstract: A woman who is coming off a long-term relationship meets a man who has seen his American dream fade and has decided to return to his native England.
lead_paragraph: “I’m leaving in a few weeks’ time, so it’s a kind of a no-risk situation,” Alex (Tony Okungbowa) says when asking out Sophie (Mamie Gummer). Sophie replies, “I don’t think there’s such a thing.” She’s right, at least in this case, and the more involved these two become, the more bittersweet “Echo Park” grows.

headline: Review: In ‘Wedding Doll,’ Search, and Struggle, to Find Independence and Romance
abstract: Nitzan Gilady’s fiction feature debut centers on a young woman with a mild mental disability in search of her own way.
lead_paragraph: A young woman with a mild mental disability strives for independence in Nitzan Gilady’s drama “Wedding Doll,” and strives and strives against tribulations.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: ‘The Measure of a Man,’ a Tale of a Man’s Lost Labor
abstract: Vincent Lindon, who won a the best actor award at Cannes for his role, stars as an alienated security guard in this film from Stéphane Brizé.
lead_paragraph: Midway through the quiet emotional storms in the French drama “The Measure of a Man,” the hero, Thierry, begins working as a supermarket security guard. It’s a bitter victory. There is little that’s secure about the job, which requires Thierry to view not just every customer but also each employee as a potential thief. Supplemented with the trappings of the badly paid — a stifling tie, ill-fitting jacket, squawking walkie-talkie — he embodies 21st-century labor at its most heroically alienated. As he stands and watches, liberty seems a distant promise, as do equality and fraternity.

headline: Finding New Orleans Flavor Without Leaving Long Island
abstract: Seafood, sausages and plenty of spices entice patrons at four restaurants specializing in Crescent City flair.
lead_paragraph: For many fans of New Orleans, there is no better time to be in the Crescent City than late April. That’s when the 10-day Jazz and Heritage Festival cuts the swampy humidity with a cool blast of jazz, blues, zydeco and gospel. Food stalls serve Creole and Cajun snacks like alligator pie and fried oysters, transforming the open-air concert series into a movable feast.

headline: Spare Times for April 15-21
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: Review: ‘Colonia’ Looks at a Dark Period in South American History
abstract: A flight attendant is enjoying a glossy stopover in Chile with a German living there, when the 1973 Pinochet coup sweeps them up.
lead_paragraph: “Colonia” is set during a dark period in South American history, the early days of Gen. Augusto Pinochet’s dictatorship in Chile, but it somehow manages to feel more like a Hallmark Channel romance than like a serious film.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for April 15-21
abstract: ‘The Amazing Max’ (Saturday and Sunday) Max Darwin, a.k.a. the Amazing Max, may come across like the M.C. at a raucous bar mitzvah party, but he does know his craft, and now he’s bringing it back to New York City for another round of shows. In this hourlong magic performance, he performs feats like mind reading, making objects disappear and then reappear, and sending coins raining from various parts of the body. The show includes lots of audience participation. (Through May 1.) At 3:30 p.m., Theater at Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71st Street, Manhattan, 866-811-4111, theamazingmax.com.
lead_paragraph: ‘The Amazing Max’ (Saturday and Sunday) Max Darwin, a.k.a. the Amazing Max, may come across like the M.C. at a raucous bar mitzvah party, but he does know his craft, and now he’s bringing it back to New York City for another round of shows. In this hourlong magic performance, he performs feats like mind reading, making objects disappear and then reappear, and sending coins raining from various parts of the body. The show includes lots of audience participation. (Through May 1.) At 3:30 p.m., Theater at Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71st Street, Manhattan, 866-811-4111, theamazingmax.com.

headline: Authentic Mexican Food Amid a Nuevo-Taco Craze
abstract: Three restaurants in Connecticut draw fromgenerations-old family recipes and traditional methods.
lead_paragraph: As I’ve told friends for years, if I ever get to heaven, I hope to find that it’s a parking lot, right off a great surf-break beach, lined with taco trucks. If there’s one cuisine I could happily munch into eternity, it’s Mexican street food. I have been happy about the crop of upmarket taco restaurants sprouting around my home state the past few years, with their artisanal-tequila cocktail menus and chichi ingredients (crunchy kale, slow-roasted pork belly, spice-glazed duck breast).

headline: Review: ‘13 Cameras,’ Keeping a Watchful Eye and Then Some
abstract: A creepy landlord, a father-to-be with a wandering eye, and a lot more than a couple bargained for in renting a home.
lead_paragraph: Note to renters: If, at your initial meeting, your potential landlord gives you the creeps, it’s probably best to keep looking. That basic rule, alas, is not followed by Claire (Brianne Moncrief) and Ryan (P. J. McCabe) in the goosebump-inducing “13 Cameras.”

headline: ‘Matilda the Musical’ to Leave Broadway in January
abstract: The work, which won five Tony Awards, will close on Jan. 1; a national tour is underway and the show continues to run in London and Australia.
lead_paragraph: It’s time to bid farewell to those Revolting Children.

headline: Bernie Sanders Takes on Wall Street With ‘Art of the Steal’ Ad
abstract: The Democratic candidate comes after the financial industry in its home market — with a tongue-in-cheek tweak of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has made Wall Street banks public enemy No. 1 throughout his campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination, and he now comes after the financial industry in its home market — with a tongue-in-cheek tweak of Donald J. Trump — in an ad titled “The Art of the Steal.”

headline: Before Trump Campaign, Corey Lewandowski Rode Herd on a Town’s Leaders
abstract: Mr. Lewandowski monitored the government of Windham, N.H., even uncovering a fantasy football email scandal that brought down a prosecutor.
lead_paragraph: To Ross McLeod, a prosecutor and selectman in the town of Windham, N.H., it was a harmless hobby: running a small fantasy football league with a handful of friends and a pot of around $200 a year.

headline: Donald Trump Draws Protesters Outside Republican Dinner in Manhattan
abstract: Hundreds of people gathered Thursday in Midtown Manhattan to protest an appearance by the Republican presidential candidate Donald J. Trump at the New York State Republican Gala.
lead_paragraph: Demonstrators protesting the appearance of Donald J. Trump at a Republican Party event Thursday night reached a peak of around 1,000, but their ranks thinned and a splinter group of about 100 marchers headed into Midtown Manhattan.

headline: Review: In ‘Criminal,’ You Must Remember This
abstract: In Ariel Vromen’s action film, Kevin Costner plays a convict with an altered brain used to capture a C.I.A. officer’s memories.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood loves to muck with the human brain, and in “Criminal” the beneficiary is Kevin Costner, who gets to deploy a full range of tics and quirks, playing a convict neurally altered in the name of national security.

headline: At the Able Baker, Sugar, Butter and a Little Nostalgia
abstract: With its whimsical and wholesome treats, a bakery in Maplewood has found a devoted following.
lead_paragraph: I fell in love with Julie’s scone the minute I tasted it. It was hard on the outside, soft on the inside, not excessively sweet but shamefully rich. I had one, and then I went back the next day and had another. My scone-a-day spree at the Able Baker in Maplewood continued, as I worked my way through every one of the almost one dozen varieties (cranberry ginger, pumpkin walnut, vanilla bean, fig pine nut and cherry coconut, to name a few), each with a cup of strong cappuccino. I realized that I needed to start every morning at Julie’s.

headline: Chicago’s Racist Cops and Racist Courts
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Discrimination', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The Chicago Police Department isn’t the city’s only racist institution — the legal system is rife with bias, too.
lead_paragraph: AS a report by a panel commissioned by Mayor Rahm Emanuel of Chicago found on Wednesday, racism in the city’s Police Department is rampant: Blacks are disproportionately subjected to traffic stops, Tasers and street stops that do not lead to arrest; they also account for an appalling 74 percent of the 404 people shot by the Chicago police between 2008 and 2015.

headline: Review: ‘The Adderall Diaries,’ a Sprawl of Unreliable Memories
abstract: A narcissistic writer has a fraught reunion with his father and spins out of control in Pamela Romanowsky’s take on Stephen Elliott’s memoir.
lead_paragraph: A father and son duke it out over who is the bigger victim in “The Adderall Diaries,” Pamela Romanowsky’s misbegotten adaptation of the 2009 memoir by Stephen Elliott.

headline: Review: Homespun Flavors at Estancia Buenos Aires, in Larchmont
abstract: The Argentine steakhouse, which opened in August, has a traditional menu and rustic décor that honors the homeland.
lead_paragraph: Estancia Buenos Aires, a modest Argentine steakhouse in Larchmont, opened in August without the huffing and puffing that usually comes with social-media-fueled restaurant openings. Owned by Gerardo Pulega and Edelmira Ibarra-Pulega, it offers a welcoming air and homey cuisine that, except for an outlier Waldorf salad and an entree of orange-glazed salmon filet with couscous, honors the motherland. The basic underpinnings — red meat and red wine — will appeal to anyone on a Paleo diet.

headline: Review: In ‘An Eye for Beauty,’ Gorgeous People Suffer, Too
abstract: A married man succumbs to the charms of a predatory about-to-be-divorced beauty who bluntly propositions him within minutes of their meeting.
lead_paragraph: “Ugliness is a crime against humanity.”

headline: Muslim Students Report Burglaries and Hate Literature at Idaho State
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Hate Crimes', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: Numerous burglaries are being investigated at the university in Pocatello, where tensions have risen over an influx of Middle Eastern students.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials and the local police are investigating burglaries and hate literature that appear to be directed at Muslim students attending Idaho State University in Pocatello, where tensions have recently risen over an influx of students from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait.

headline: Review: ‘Above and Below’ a Study of People on the Margins
abstract: This documentary visits primarily transients in Las Vegas and the California desert, and a participant in an earnest Mars research project.
lead_paragraph: The outer limits and the lower depths loom before us in Nicolas Steiner’s voyage into extremes, “Above and Below.” Mr. Steiner’s tightly interconnected documentary, with transporting shots, visits people on the margins in the United States, primarily transients in Las Vegas and the California desert, but also a participant in an earnest Mars research project.

headline: Review: In ‘New York, New York,’ Job Opportunities Complicate a Relationship
abstract: In this film from Luo Dong, a man and a woman wrestle with the question of leaving China or remaining there.
lead_paragraph: “New York, New York” has the feel of Shanghai noir. Its tightly shot scenes never reveal much context, and the rather cryptic subtitles can lead a viewer to mistaken conclusions until the identities and motivations of the characters click into focus.

headline: Review: ‘Sing Street’ Is an ’80s Love Affair, Hair Gel Required
abstract: The film, directed by John Carney, who also directed ‘Once,’ is a tribute to the decade of hair gel and rock ’n’ roll.
lead_paragraph: If you were not a teenager in the 1980s, John Carney’s “Sing Street” is likely to beguile you with the sweet, universal energy of youth. By the same token, if you were a teenager in that much-maligned decade, the movie might make you feel old and a little cranky. Don’t get me wrong. As a 21st-century moviegoer, I was touched by this pop fable ofRR But as a grizzled survivor of the age of Duran Duran, I found myself picking nits about its musical choices (most of which are three or four years out of sync with the plot) and occasionally resisting its winsome, cheeky, post-punk spirit.

headline: Bernie Sanders Campaign Suspends Jewish Outreach Coordinator for Vulgar Remarks About Netanyahu
abstract: Two days after her hiring was announced, the Sanders presidential campaign suspended its national Jewish outreach coordinator, Simone Zimmerman, after revelations that she had posted vulgarities about Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: The Sanders campaign’s announcement on Tuesday that Simone Zimmerman would be its national Jewish outreach coordinator delighted her fellow left-wing Jewish political activists and encouraged their belief that public expressions of disgust with the Israeli government had edged into the acceptable mainstream of Democratic politics.

headline: Solving Mysteries at the American Museum of Natural History, Smartphone in Hand
abstract: On Sunday the museum will introduce MicroRangers, a mobile game for children that lets them help resolve one of nine possible MicroCrises.
lead_paragraph: If you visit the American Museum of Natural History on Sunday and see young people fixated on their smartphones, don’t assume that they’ve abandoned science for the joys of social media. These visitors are not absorbed in Angry Birds — though they may well be investigating bobtail squids or runaway bison.

headline: Review: In ‘Sky,’ a Woman Takes Refuge Among Strangers
abstract: A woman who lives in Paris and is visiting the United States with her husband flees to Las Vegas after he drunkenly tries to rape her in their motel room.
lead_paragraph: Nowadays, the Wild, Wild West, that barren, mythologized frontier where good guys and outlaws used to shoot it out, may not be as overtly violent and lawless a territory as depicted in countless westerns. But its modern incarnation, portrayed in the French director Fabienne Berthaud’s intriguing misfire, “Sky,” feels only marginally more civilized. Ms. Berthaud’s third film to star Diane Kruger, this expressionistic portrait of the American West is an oddity that only a director from another country could have conjured.

headline: Sumner Redstone Won’t Have to Give Deposition in Competency Suit
abstract: A judge reaffirmed the ruling ahead of a scheduled trial in a mental capacity suit filed by Manuela Herzer, the ailing media mogul’s former companion.
lead_paragraph: The ailing media mogul Sumner M. Redstone will not be required to sit for a deposition in the legal battle over his mental competency, a California judge ruled during a brief hearing on Thursday.

headline: ‘The Photography Show Presented by Aipad’ at the Armory
abstract: There are lessons amid the array of high-priced work for sale at the annual show of photograph dealers.
lead_paragraph: Walking through the souk of 86 stalls that constitutes Aipad, the annual show of photograph dealers, this visitor was struck (and not for the first time) by the way certain themes have persisted throughout the history of the medium. Toshio Shibata’s large color C-print “Okawa Village, Tosa County, Kochi Prefecture,” 2007, at the Laurence Miller Gallery, depicts the red steel trusses and cream yellow concrete guardrails of a bridge thrusting into a misty green forested hillside. Almost a century and a half before, Carleton Watkins photographed a rough-hewed wooden cabin alongside the Columbia River; a superb albumen print of “The Garrison, Columbia River,” c. 1867, is on view at Hans P. Kraus Jr. Fine Photographs. In both pictures, the care given to the lighting and to the composition manages to transform a man-made violation into something beautiful — a reminder of the camera’s insidious power to aestheticize almost anything.

headline: The Eye of the Trump Hurricane
abstract: An eerily quiet week, at least by the standards of the 2016 election.
lead_paragraph: Finally, an enterprising news outlet has persuaded Donald Trump to talk.

headline: Group Buys Mike Piazza’s 9/11 Jersey and Will Make a Gift of It
abstract: An agreement was reached to purchase the jersey the Hall of Famer wore during the first game held in New York after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
lead_paragraph: A significant Mike Piazza jersey that the Mets managed to let slip from their possession has been purchased by three minority owners of the team who intend to have it rotated on display at Citi Field, the 9/11 Memorial Museum and the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y.

headline: Reaching Peak Greek at the Met Museum
abstract: This grand exhibition of Greek Classical art shows the museum operating in truly epical form.
lead_paragraph: Seen from on high, history is a grand sorting machine, loading on events, parsing populations, dividing time into nameable, datable piles. No one captures this process more grandly than the Metropolitan Museum of Art. And in “Pergamon and the Hellenistic Kingdoms of the Ancient World,” which opens on Monday, April 18, it is operating in truly epical form.

headline: BATS Tries Again With I.P.O. on Its Own Exchange
abstract: The company is doing everything it can to avoid a repeat of the technical fiasco of March 2012, which caused shares to be halted and trades to be canceled.
lead_paragraph: BATS Global Markets, whose attempt at an initial public offering on its own exchange was botched four years ago, is trying again.

headline: Christie’s Auction: a Rock, a Basketball, Hitler on His Knees
abstract: At Christie’s, a rock head; a Cagnacci Magdalene heads for the Frick; and Basquiat’s paintings with words will be shown at Nahmad.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you were looking forward to seeing David Hammons’s 2006 rock head in the Mnuchin Gallery’s acclaimed exhibition of the artist and figured you had plenty of time to get there, because the show doesn’t close until May 27. Or maybe the head, with its tight helmet of dark hair, was something you had already admired and were planning to revisit.

headline: Ninth Democratic Debate: Analysis
abstract: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders met in Brooklyn for their latest debate, the last before Tuesday’s New York primary. Nick Confessore, Maggie Haberman and Alan Rappeport provided real-time analysis.

headline: Bear Stearns Emails Show Its Financing Breaking Away
abstract: In the summer of 2007 Bear liquidated two hedge funds, setting in motion a loss of confidence that ultimately decimated the firm.
lead_paragraph: Within weeks of the shocking collapse of Bear Stearns in March 2008, I started interviewing former executives of the firm to try to figure out what had just happened and why.

headline: The End for a Cleaners Where Little but the Name Has Changed
abstract: Anel, a family-owned dry-cleaning store at Columbus Avenue and West 70th Street, is shutting down after more than 50 years.
lead_paragraph: Originally, the name was “Chanel French Cleaners,” but that first C and H had to go.

headline: On Zika, Congress Is Failing to Do Its Job
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Birth Defects', 'Ebola Virus', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Zika Virus']
abstract: Making vague promises of funding to fight a mosquito-borne virus that causes birth defects is no way to address a public health crisis.
lead_paragraph: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has concluded that the Zika virus causes brain damage in babies born to infected women, which adds to the growing evidence that the virus is a major public health emergency. Yet Republicans in Congress are refusing to appropriate the money needed to respond to this crisis.

headline: House Democrats Call for Curbs on Required Arbitration
abstract: Legislators urged curtailment of a practice in which judges and juries are supplanted by arbitrators in disputes between companies and consumers.
lead_paragraph: A handful of House Democrats took to the floor of Congress on Thursday to call for an overhaul of arbitration, a private justice system for resolving disputes that is often slanted against consumers.

headline: The Sins of the Chicago Police Laid Bare
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Racial Profiling']
abstract: A new report showing that the department is plagued by systemic racism does not come as a surprise.
lead_paragraph: No one who is even passingly familiar with the history of the Chicago Police Department can claim to be surprised by a new report showing that the department is plagued by systemic racism and operates with utter disregard for the lives of the black citizens whom it batters, maims and kills.

headline: Retirees Rally at the Capitol, Protesting Pension Cuts
keywords: ['Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Law and Legislation', 'Organized Labor', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A little-noticed provision of a bill passed in 2014 will mean deep reductions for about 400,000, many of them members of the Teamsters union.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Some 400,000 retirees who worked in the trucking, parcel delivery and grocery supply industries face drastic pension cuts on July 1 as a result of a little-noticed measure attached to a huge end-of-year spending bill passed in December 2014.

headline: 69 Years Later, Philadelphia Apologizes to Jackie Robinson
abstract: The city extended an apology for racial slurs uttered by members of the Phillies during Robinson’s pioneering rookie season.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, the Anderson Monarchs, a Philadelphia baseball team that featured the Little League World Series star Mo’ne Davis, barnstormed through the South. They played baseball, and they also toured sites significant to the civil rights movement as a nod to the team’s heritage — it is named, after all, for the Kansas City Monarchs, the Negro leagues club for which Jackie Robinson once played.

headline: Col Allan, Longtime Editor of The New York Post, to Retire
abstract: The editor of The New York Post spent 42 years at News Corporation, the owner of the newspaper.
lead_paragraph: Col Allan, the longtime editor in chief of The New York Post, announced on Thursday that he would retire at the end of the month after 42 years at the News Corporation, the publication’s owner.

headline: Clinton and Sanders Campaigns to Sue Arizona Election Officials
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Presidential Elections (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The party and the campaigns of Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are set to file a suit seeking to increase polling places for November’s election.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The Democratic Party and the presidential campaigns of Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are expected to file a suit on Friday against officials in Arizona over last month’s chaotic primaries, when thousands of voters in the state’s most populous county waited up to five hours to cast ballots and countless others gave up or were barred because of errors and misinformation.

headline: Knicks Exit, as Phil Jackson Addresses What’s Next
abstract: After finishing exit interviews with the last of the Knicks, Jackson faced reporters, who had plenty of questions, including who the next coach will be.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — After finishing exit interviews with the last of the Knicks on Thursday, Phil Jackson ambled into the pressroom at the team’s headquarters, leaned against a lectern, looked out at a flock of reporters and let out a deep breath.

headline: Yahoo’s Suitors Uncover Few Financial Details
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Potential buyers for Yahoo’s businesses are wondering just what is for sale.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As Yahoo prepares to accept first-round bids for its core Internet business on Monday, potential buyers have found themselves facing one big problem: How do you value a company with a declining business when the company appears reluctant to share vital financial details?

headline: California Appeals Court Reverses Decision to Overturn Teacher Tenure Rules
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Organized Labor', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Decisions and Verdicts']
abstract: Judges ruled that the state’s job protections for teachers do not deprive poor and minority students of a quality education, or violate their civil rights.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A California appeals court ruled on Thursday that the state’s job protections for teachers do not deprive poor and minority students of a quality education or violate their civil rights — reversing a landmark lower court decision that had overturned the state’s teacher tenure rules.

headline: Fred Hayman, Whose Giorgio Boutique Led Gilding of Rodeo Drive, Dies at 90
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Luxury Goods and Services', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Perfumes and Fragrances', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Mr. Hayman realized a vision to transform Rodeo Drive in Los Angeles into a luxury shopping destination to rival New York’s Fifth Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Fred Hayman, whose luxury boutique, Giorgio Beverly Hills, led the way in transforming Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills into a shopping destination for the rich and famous, died on Thursday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 90.

headline: Dr. Peter J. Jannetta, Pioneering Neurosurgeon on Facial Pain, Dies at 84
abstract: Dr. Jannetta, a specialist in cranial nerve disorders, developed a microsurgery procedure to relieve facial pain associated with trigeminal neuralgia.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Peter J. Jannetta, a neurosurgeon who as a medical resident half a century ago developed an innovative procedure to relieve an especially devastating type of facial pain, died on Monday in Pittsburgh. He was 84.

headline: Health Officials Split Over Advice on Pregnancy in Zika Areas
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Birth Defects', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Microcephaly', 'Women and Girls', 'Mosquitoes']
abstract: Some experts say avoiding conception is the only sure way to prevent deformed babies; others say the government should not tell women what to do with their bodies.
lead_paragraph: As the Zika virus bears down on the United States, federal health officials are divided over a politically and ethically charged question: Should they advise American women to delay pregnancy in areas where the virus is circulating?

headline: Dilma Rousseff Targeted in Brazil by Lawmakers Facing Scandals of Their Own
abstract: Many of the legislators calling for President Rousseff’s impeachment are facing charges that some observers say are more serious than the accusations against her.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — Paulo Maluf, a Brazilian congressman, is so badly besieged by his own graft scandals that his constituents often describe him with the slogan “Rouba mas faz.” Translation: He steals but gets it done.

headline: Colombia Reports First Cases of Microcephaly Linked to Zika Virus
abstract: Though the two cases were the first confirmed in the country since the infection spread there, officials said they did not expect the birth defects to reach the same scale as in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Colombian health officials said on Thursday that they had discovered two cases of microcephaly linked to the Zika virus, the first to be confirmed in the country since the infection began to spread there late last year.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: A parole panel on Thursday recommended parole to a former Charles Manson follower, Leslie Van Houten, more than four decades after she went to prison. The decision, on her 20th parole hearing, is subject to an administrative review by the board. If upheld it goes to Gov. Jerry Brown, who has the final word on whether Ms. Van Houten, 66, will be released. Ms. Van Houten participated in the killings of Leno La Bianca and his wife, Rosemary, a day after other so-called Manson family members murdered the pregnant actress Sharon Tate and four others in 1969. (AP)

headline: Bankruptcy of TransCare Strains New York’s Emergency Services
abstract: The loss of a private ambulance company has left the city’s Emergency Medical Service scrambling to fill the gaps.
lead_paragraph: At every moment, the population explosion of New York rolls across the city in not-so-slow motion. Last year, nearly 1.7 million people called 911 for medical help, the most since humans started answering telephones. On average that’s about one call every 20 seconds.

headline: Despite Timing, Bernie Sanders Says, Accepting Vatican Offer Was a Must
abstract: The senator will head to Italy just hours after debating Hillary Clinton in Brooklyn as both candidates prepare for the New York primary on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders, in the midst of a contentious battle for the Democratic nomination, says he could not refuse an invitation to visit the Vatican and talk about the world economy and social justice — two issues at the core of his presidential campaign — even if it meant he would be out of the country for days leading up to Tuesday’s crucial primary in New York.

headline: Review: ‘The Father’ Examines the Lion’s Mind in Winter
abstract: Frank Langella stars as a man wrestling with dementia in this play, a hit in Paris and London.
lead_paragraph: He is a fortress unto himself, but a fortress under siege.

headline: Things With Round Numbers
abstract: Friday fun with David Steinberg.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — David Steinberg sure knows how to open a puzzle in a most surprising way. I would like to personally and publicly extend my thanks to Will Shortz and Joel Fagliano for re-cluing the entry FALSIES so that we are discussing eyelashes and not, well, you know. Even if I’m used to seeing cosmetic eyelashes as “fake eyelashes” or “false eyelashes.”

headline: James Cross Giblin, 82, Wide-Ranging Author of Books for Children, Dies
abstract: Knives and forks, windows, milk, Hitler, George Washington and AIDS were just some of Mr. Giblin’s subjects.
lead_paragraph: James Cross Giblin, an award-winning writer of nonfiction for children, whose books ranged from topics like cutlery and why we use it, windows and why we have them, and walls and why we need them to cleareyed biographies of Hitler, Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and John Wilkes Booth, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Go on the Attack in Democratic Debate
abstract: Both candidates are on the offensive, sometimes not even bothering to answer the question at play.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders jousted in a prime time debate, trading accusations about everything from guns to investment banks. Instead of offering a column or conventional analysis, I’ve collected my live tweets as the debate unfolded–and here goes!

headline: Civil Complaint in ‘Three-Quarter’ Houses Case
abstract: A civil complaint, filed by the New York State attorney general's office, seeks more than $1.9 million in damages plus penalties from a couple facing felony charges of Medicaid fraud and money laundering in connection to "three-quarter" homes they ran — unregulated flophouses that are seen as somewhere between a regulated halfway house and an actual home.
lead_paragraph: A civil complaint, filed by the New York State attorney general's office, seeks more than $1.9 million in damages plus penalties from a couple facing felony charges of Medicaid fraud and money laundering in connection to "three-quarter" homes they ran — unregulated flophouses that are seen as somewhere between a regulated halfway house and an actual home.

headline: Canada Extends Benefits to People of Mixed Aboriginal and European Ancestry
abstract: A ruling by the country’s Supreme Court will affect about 600,000 people who had been in a “jurisdictional tug of war” between the federal government and provinces.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — A unanimous ruling released Thursday by the Supreme Court of Canada opened up a wide range of benefits and rights to about 600,000 Canadians of mixed aboriginal and European ancestry, ending a dispute that stretches back to the country’s founding.

headline: Yankees’ Offensive Malaise Puts Scrutiny on Alex Rodriguez
abstract: Rodriguez’s surprisingly strong comeback last season after a yearlong drug suspension has given way to a feeble start.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — As baseball players age, the skills that got them to the big leagues gradually erode. Pitchers whose high heat abandons them must learn to make the ball dart and dance. Hitters whose reflexes no longer allow them to uncoil and strike like a viper must learn to make their decisions earlier, committing to swing at a fastball that may not be one.

headline: Donald Trump Seeks Help With West Bank Question During Meeting With Jewish Media
abstract: During the meeting, Mr. Trump turned to an aide from the Trump Organization for help answering a question about West Bank settlements, according to the publication The Forward.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump met with roughly 30 reporters for Jewish media outlets and with Orthodox Jewish activists in his office on Thursday afternoon. It did not go entirely smoothly, according to published reports.

headline: Hector A. Cafferata, 86, Dies; Given Medal of Honor for Korea Heroics
abstract: A Marine private, he single-handedly held off an enemy regiment, protected comrades from a live grenade and was felled by a sniper.
lead_paragraph: Hector A. Cafferata Jr., a former Marine private who received the nation’s highest military honor for single-handedly holding off an enemy regiment during the Korean War and safeguarding his comrades from a live grenade until he was felled by a sniper’s bullet, died on Tuesday in Venice, Fla. He was 86.

headline: In Democratic Debate, Clinton and Sanders Spar Over Judgment
abstract: Bernie Sanders repeatedly savaged Hillary Clinton’s ties to wealthy donors and Wall Street banks, while Mrs. Clinton countered with steely confidence.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders, seizing on potential vulnerabilities for Hillary Clinton in the coming New York primary, repeatedly savaged her ties to wealthy donors and Wall Street banks during their debate on Thursday night, delivering a ferocious performance that Mrs. Clinton countered with steely confidence and her own sharp elbows.

headline: First-Quarter Growth Slows a Bit in China, as Expected
abstract: China said its economy grew 6.7 percent, the slowest quarterly rate since the financial crisis in 2009 but also exactly what economists had forecast.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s growth rate slowed as expected in the first three months of the year, but a notable pickup in debt-driven industrial activity last month probably cushioned the slowdown.

headline: Former Rikers Inmate Can’t Identify Officer He Believes Ordered His Attack
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Assaults']
abstract: Jahmal Lightfoot’s testimony is at the center of the criminal case against nine officers in what prosecutors have described as an orchestrated assault and attempted cover up.
lead_paragraph: When Jahmal Lightfoot finally had the chance to confront the man who he believed had ordered his beating at Rikers Island in July 2012, he could not.

headline: Stephen Curry’s Season: In a Word, Golden
abstract: The excellence of the Golden State Warriors’ 73 wins was embodied by the record-shattering performance of their star, Curry.
lead_paragraph: The excellence of the Warriors’ 73 wins was embodied by their star Stephen Curry. Here are some of his notable 3-pointers from this season, when he made a record-shattering 402.

headline: Walter Rosen, Longtime Steward of Junior’s Restaurant, Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Rosen ran the restaurant, a New York City staple famous for its signature cheesecake, for around two decades before handing the reins to his sons.
lead_paragraph: Much of Walter Rosen’s life was spent on the corner of Flatbush Avenue Extension and DeKalb Avenue in Downtown Brooklyn.

headline: Five Big Questions After a High-Stakes Democratic Debate
abstract: On a Brooklyn stage, the two candidates tried to settle this once and for all.
lead_paragraph: Did Bernie Sanders successfully paint Hillary Clinton as a pawn of Wall Street?

headline: Highlights From the Democratic Debate
abstract: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton met in the Democratic presidential debate Thursday night in New York, where each has a major history.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton met in the Democratic presidential debate Thursday night in New York, where each has a major history.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, April 15, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “I’ve seen people die well and I’ve seen people die in misery. I want Canadians to have access to the best care possible.”

headline: North Korea Ballistic Missile Launch a Failure, Pentagon Says

headline: The End of Catholic Guilt
abstract: Pope Francis is merely acknowledging the obvious. As before, he’s using words to change hearts.
lead_paragraph: The comedian George Carlin used to say that he was a Roman Catholic “until I reached the age of reason.” For Carlin, that happened sometime in the eighth grade, when all his probing questions about faith were answered with, “well, it’s a mystery.” Of course, as a lifelong contrarian, Carlin also wondered if it was O.K. for a vegetarian to eat animal crackers.

headline: End Potential Conflict of Interest in de Blasio Administration
abstract: Mark Peters, the head of an agency involved in a corruption inquiry, should recuse himself.
lead_paragraph: A federal corruption investigation is reportedly looking into Mayor Bill de Blasio’s campaign fund-raising, among other things. The inquiry includes two businessmen who raised a lot of money for the mayor, several top officials of the New York Police Department and the mayor’s tax-exempt lobbying group, the Campaign for One New York. Where the investigation is going and what it will find is, for now, anyone’s guess. There are many unconnected dots.

headline: What Is Inspiration?
abstract: That moment when mind and spirit take flight stands apart from normal life.
lead_paragraph: For decades, Anders Ericsson has reminded us of the value of hard work. The Florida State psychologist did the research that led to the so-called 10,000-hour rule. In his informative new book, “Peak,” he and co-author Robert Pool downplay the importance of native-born genius (even in people like Mozart) and emphasize the importance of deliberate practice — painstaking exercises to perfect some skill.

headline: The Pastrami Principle
abstract: Beware politicians — Republican or Democratic — who sneer at voters.
lead_paragraph: A couple of months ago, Jeb Bush (remember him?) posted a photo of his monogrammed handgun to Twitter, with the caption “America.” Bill de Blasio, New York’s mayor, responded with a picture of an immense pastrami sandwich, also captioned “America.” Advantage de Blasio, if you ask me.

lead_paragraph: In all kinds of institutions, from universities to performing arts organizations, an emeritus position is a prestigious post. This understanding has sometimes been lost in recent years during the speculation over whether, and when, James Levine might step aside as music director of the Metropolitan Opera. “Music director emeritus” is an honor — the capstone of a career, and hardly its finale.

abstract: You know how the one-size-fits-all yoga pants technically fit everyone, but for some of us, they make your butt look like it’s been sculpted from a quesadilla? Parenting is like that.
lead_paragraph: Midseason, with plenty of New England cold stretched ahead of us, our 12-year-old daughter, Birdy, lost her winter coat. This was not a tragedy. Things are only things, after all.

headline: How to Surf a Crowd
abstract: Choose the right place. Steer with your shoulders.
lead_paragraph: “You have to let the fear go,” says Merrill Nisker, a musician and performance artist better known as Peaches. At some point in every show, she steps off the stage into the audience. Sometimes she’s upright, walking onto people’s upstretched hands; other times, she lies back, carried by the crowd. You must trust the throng, even knowing that things can go awry (once, an audience member clawed Peaches’s thigh with sharp fingernails). The surfer and the surfed share the same adrenaline. “It is the ultimate way to connect,” she says.

headline: A Sudden Breach in Uganda
abstract: Raised to believe in the perfection of white people, a Rwandan was bound to be disappointed.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, when I was still relatively new to the tour-guide business, a company hired me to show an American photographer around Rwanda and Uganda. Six days in, we had toured a rain forest in the southwest of Rwanda, spent two days with the mountain gorillas and crossed over the Ugandan border. Now we were in the town of Kabale, in the hills of Southwestern Uganda. Everything was going well.

Koch and Mario M. Cuomo sitting on a couch in a holding room for a mayoral debate in 1977, clearly sick of each other.

headline: A Detroit Restaurant That Shows Michigan Pride
abstract: James Rigato’s Mabel Gray, in the suburb of Hazel Park, is thoroughly of, by, and for Michigan.
lead_paragraph: Hazel Park, a Detroit suburb, is home to a wrestling supply shop, several family dentistry practices, and numerous Greek-American diners, but until last September, it had never seen a restaurant quite like Mabel Gray. With its artfully exposed plaster walls, perfectly mismatched vintage tableware, and a seasonal menu showcasing local ingredients and whole-animal butchery, the restaurant initially appears to have been airlifted from Brooklyn. But never mind appearances: Mabel Gray is thoroughly of, by and for Michigan.

headline: Among the Elephants in Thailand
abstract: Tim Bewer of the tour company Isan Explorer offers elephant activities that break with tradition — no rides or shows but plenty of walking.
lead_paragraph: Tim Bewer, 45, a Wisconsin native, has lived in Khon Kaen, Thailand, since 2007. Five years ago, Mr. Bewer, who contributes to Lonely Planet Thailand, and his wife, Suttawan Intarapanich, started Isan Explorer, a company that arranges private tours in the northeastern region. In 2014, the couple, inspired by the work of a Thai elephant advocate, changed the elephant portion of their tours to focus on the animals’ well-being. Following are edited excerpts from a conversation with Mr. Bewer.

headline: Belgium’s Transportation Minister Resigns Amid Outcry

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The transportation minister of Belgium resigned on Friday, after the publication of leaked reports from the European Commission warning of security deficiencies at Brussels Airport, the site of two deadly terrorist bombings on March 22.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Last month, the ancient castle of Matrera in southern Spain fell under siege by critics who mocked its unusual restoration as a barbarity. Now, an online architects’ community has returned fire, honoring the work this week with a preservation prize.

headline: In South China Sea Visit, U.S. Defense Chief Flexes Military Muscle
abstract: Ashton B. Carter’s tour sent a message that Americans would work with allies to counter Beijing’s expanding presence, but China may feel a need to speed up its own military buildup.
lead_paragraph: ABOARD THE U.S.S. JOHN C. STENNIS, in the South China Sea — Over the last week in Asia, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter has visited two aircraft carriers, revealed new military agreements with India and the Philippines, and generally signaled that the Obama administration had decided to lean more on military power to counter China’s territorial ambitions in the region.

headline: Reclaiming Fees When Airline Luggage Goes Astray
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Luggage and Packing', 'Personal Finances', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The frustrating struggle when you try to get your money back — and the new legislation that could help travelers.
lead_paragraph: Buried in the new bill reauthorizing the Federal Aviation Administration are a few sections addressing the fees that many of us pay to fly. And while the Senate and the House bills still differ a bit, one likely result is going to be this: The carriers are going to have to refund the fees you pay when your luggage isn’t on your flight and you have to wait a long time to get it.

headline: Taiwan Fears Fraud Suspects in Malaysia May Be Deported to China

headline: Celebrating Passover, With All the Comforts of a Resort
keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Passover', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: More and more, Orthodox Jews are balancing the rituals of Passover with the indulgences of beach-front hotels to accommodate what are often large family reunions.
lead_paragraph: Efrem Goldberg, a Modern Orthodox rabbi in suburban Miami, jokes that for the eight days of Passover, he gets to be a visiting scholar by just staying home. Half of his congregants go away, but many who remain have family members visiting. So the synagogue stays full, but many faces are unfamiliar.

headline: ‘Losing Ground’ Meditates on Art as It Examines a Marriage in Peril
abstract: Kathleen Collins’s 1982 drama is an examination of a husband and wife at odds, as well as a meditation on art and philosophy.
lead_paragraph: Barely released in 1982 and all but unseen for over three decades, Kathleen Collins’s “Losing Ground” is a lively movie — as well as a ghostly one. Ms. Collins and her two male leads, Bill Gunn and Duane Jones, died long before the film resurfaced at Lincoln Center in early 2015 as part of a survey of independent African-American cinema produced in New York between 1968 and 1986.

headline: Why Is This Matzo Different From All Other Matzos?
keywords: ['Wheat', 'Passover', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Kosher Foods and Products', 'Grain', 'Rabbis', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: An unintended side effect of kosher law: better tasting food.
lead_paragraph: SEVERAL years ago, at a family Seder, I tasted a matzo I actually liked. It was misshapen and lightly burned, distinguishing it from the machine-made matzo of my youth. And this one possessed something that I had never experienced with matzo: It had flavor. What can I say? Up until that moment, the best matzo of my life was not much better than the worst matzo of my life; you could taste the struggle in every bite. For the first time I ate matzo and thought, This is delicious.

headline: 1941: Roosevelt to Arm U.S. Ships
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Roosevelt plans to arm U.S. ships in 1941.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Roosevelt indicated this afternoon [April 15] that American ships delivering war supplies to the British and their allies, across the Atlantic and elsewhere, including the Red Sea route to the Suez Canal, would have armed protection.

headline: Ukraine Says Stolen Dutch Art Has Been Recovered
abstract: The four paintings that were retrieved have a total value of about $280,000. They were among 24 works of art and 70 pieces of silver taken in a nighttime burglary at the Westfries Museum in Hoorn, the Netherlands, in 2005.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — Four Dutch Golden Age paintings that were stolen from the Westfries Museum in Hoorn, the Netherlands, 11 years ago were recovered by the Ukrainian secret services, the Ukrainian government has said.

headline: When Dividing Assets, the Little Things Matter
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Wills and Estates', 'Personal Finances', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: Personal effects may have little monetary value, but decisions about those items often cause problems in families.
lead_paragraph: People often spend a lot of time crafting estate plans that lay out how their big assets — from cash to homes and securities — will be divided among their children, grandchildren and everyone else down the line. But they sometimes give far less thought to the other stuff — those personal effects that may have little monetary value but so much sentimental value. Yet it is the decisions about those items that often cause problems in a family.

headline: E.U.’s Five Biggest Economies Join Tax Crackdown After Panama Papers
abstract: Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Spain have agreed to share information on company ownership and that urged the Group of 20 Nations to do the same.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With political aftershocks still being felt after the leak of the so-called Panama Papers, the European Union’s five biggest economies, including Britain and Germany, have agreed to share information on company ownership to try clamping down on tax evasion.

headline: BlackRock Wields Its Big Stick Like a Wet Noodle on C.E.O. Pay
keywords: ['Executive Compensation', 'Bonuses', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The world’s largest investment manager has the power to change companies’ short-terms ways by voting to curb C.E.O. pay, but it rarely exercises it.
lead_paragraph: For several years, Laurence D. Fink, chairman and chief executive of BlackRock, the money management giant, has been on a crusade, exhorting corporations to change their short-term ways. Executives should forgo tricks that reward short-term stock traders, he argues, like share buybacks purchased at high valuations. Instead, corporate managers should focus on creating value for long-term shareholders.

headline: U.S. Cites Extramarital Affairs as Misuse of Power in Sheldon Silver Case
abstract: Two women were connected to Mr. Silver’s position as State Assembly speaker, according to newly unsealed papers from his federal corruption trial.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan have evidence that Sheldon Silver, the former speaker of the New York Assembly, engaged in extramarital relationships with two women connected to his position in Albany, according to newly unsealed court documents.

headline: Saudi Arabia Moves to Curb Its Feared Religious Police
abstract: The kingdom announced steps to overhaul the force, saying members could no longer detain or pursue suspects, and should be “gentle and kind,” rather than heavy-handed.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia announced steps this week to rein in its religious police, which is responsible for ensuring morality, piety and adherence with Islamic law but has become the target of mounting criticism in recent years.

headline: Artist Nurtures a Creative Oasis in Conservative Saudi Arabia
abstract: Abdulnasser Gharem has taken artistic aim at what he sees as the kingdom’s byzantine bureaucracy, religious dogmatism and dependence on oil.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Abdulnasser Gharem has exhibited his work in world-class museums and sold pieces at auction for hundreds of thousands of dollars, and is widely considered one of Saudi Arabia’s leading contemporary artists.

headline: How Orphaned Orangutans Messed With a Reporter’s Mind
keywords: ['Monkeys and Apes', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Wildfires', 'Poaching (Wildlife)']
abstract: “It was sort of like being one of the humans in the animated movie ‘Inside Out,’” The Times’s Indonesia correspondent recalls.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Joe Cochrane, The Times’s correspondent in Indonesia, shares the personal side of reporting on endangered animals in far-flung places.

headline: Microsoft Goes on Offensive Against Justice Department
abstract: The software giant argues in a lawsuit that law enforcement is too aggressive in seeking gag orders on its information requests.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, you have to go on the offensive. That appears to be the thinking behind a lawsuit filed by Microsoft on Thursday against the Justice Department, arguing that the government is wrongly preventing the software giant from letting customers know when investigators armed with a court order have obtained customer data.

headline: Putting Your Smartphone on a Data Diet
abstract: If you find your monthly data allowance is eaten away far too quickly, you can make some settings adjustments to keep hungry apps in check.
lead_paragraph: Q. Now that I know how to check my smartphone’s cellular data usage, what can I do to conserve more of my monthly allowance?

headline: Citigroup’s Profit Plummets, but Beats Expectations
abstract: Citigroup, like other big banks, was hammered by troubles in its oil and gas loan portfolio and difficult trading markets in the first quarter.
lead_paragraph: Citigroup’s profit and revenue plunged in the first quarter, as the bank became the latest large financial institution to report lackluster results.

headline: Kiki and Herb: Kitsch, With a Whisky Chaser
abstract: After nearly eight years, Justin Vivian Bond and Kenny Mellman’s failed septuagenarian lounge singers are making a return at Joe’s Pub.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, a Kiki and Herb cabaret show could come off as a bizarre and politically incorrect, yet addictive, mess. Kiki, with the faded glamour of Norma Desmond, sings deranged takes on Top 40 hits and slurs through tactless banter about current events. Herb, with sprayed-on gray hair and a kitschy suit, hammers a keyboard and sips Canadian Club. A medley might start with “Frosty the Snowman” and end with Patti Smith.

headline: Five Things I Won’t Miss at The Times — and Seven I Will
abstract: A few thoughts before packing up my Monocle Meter. . .
lead_paragraph: While preparing to leave the public editor’s office and move to Washington, I’ve been getting together in recent weeks with some people I’ve met while living in New York. One was Ben Smith, the editor in chief of BuzzFeed, who asked me over lunch what columns I planned to do before I left. I tossed it back to him, asking what he would like to read, and he suggested I take up “what I love and what I hate about The New York Times.”

headline: At Debate, Hillary Clinton Leaves Questions About Approach to Banks
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: She might have left viewers confused about how she might use two powers under the Dodd-Frank Act to break up big banks.
lead_paragraph: A jarring regulatory action this week against five large banks was bound to bring Wall Street to the fore in the Democratic presidential debate on Thursday. Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders differ on how to handle banks that are deemed “too big to fail.”

headline: Why I Haven’t Felt The Bern
abstract: It’s about attitude, not details.
lead_paragraph: Today’s column offers an opportunity to say, for the record, why I haven’t been the Bernie booster a lot of people apparently expected me to be. For the business about discounting Clinton support as coming from “conservative states” in the “Deep South” actually exemplifies the problem I saw in the Sanders campaign from the beginning, and made me distrust both the movement and the man.

headline: Clinton, Sanders and the Crowd Bring the Noise in Brooklyn Debate
abstract: The candidates blared at each other, and the audience was also loud at the Democratic debate in Brooklyn on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Thursday night, Democrats did what party people do in Brooklyn. They rented out a big space on the waterfront and held a rave. Along with a few rants.

headline: Angela Merkel Draws Criticism for Allowing Turkey’s Case Against Comic
abstract: Chancellor Merkel’s move to permit a court case against the comic, Jan Böhmermann, made clear that she does not want to antagonize President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, whom he lampooned.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Turkey’s president found himself in choice company when he fixed upon an obscure German law to attempt to punish a popular comic who had satirized him in crude terms. The same law, dating from 1871, had also been used to silence critics of the Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlavi of Iran and the Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet.

headline: As China’s Growth Slows, Banks Feel the Strain of Bad Debt
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Chinese lenders feel rising pain from souring loans in troubled industries — even as they face pressure to keep local companies afloat.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For Chinese banks, the decision to lend to companies like Bohai Steel was for years a no-brainer. Lenders took heart from its state backing, which appeared as solid as the millions of tons of steel pipes that rolled off its production lines each year.

headline: LVMH Executive Responds to Documentary Film
abstract: The executive, Bernard Arnault, spoke at a shareholders’ meeting.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Bernard Arnault, the head of the luxury giant LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, who is the subject of a satirical documentary that has been adopted by a movement protesting changes to the French labor code, spoke publicly for the first time about the film this week at a shareholders’ meeting.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Hope Jahren, whose memoir, “Lab Girl,” is No. 7 on the hardcover nonfiction list, has found a larger audience than many scientists partly through her use of social media.
lead_paragraph: Peer Review: The geobiologist Hope Jahren — her memoir, “Lab Girl,” hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 7 — has found a larger audience than many scientists partly through her use of social media. Jahren is prolific on Twitter, and since 2013 has maintained a lively free-range blog, “Hope Jahren Sure Can Write,” that is nominally about “interactions between men and women and academia” but is more accurately, and haphazardly, “about things” (as she puts it on her masthead). What sorts of things? A tribute to Leonard Nimoy, for one: “Nothing less than God himself . . . could take Spock away from us.” For another, a cheese recipe written in pitch-perfect lolcat dialect: “Ferst-thing ur going store to buyz 1 gallun hole milk.” And yes, there’s plenty about sexism in science, including a scathing reply Jahren wrote after a male colleague challenged her work in an email he mistakenly sent to her instead of their department head. “Why,” she asked, “are there any women in science at all? I keep asking myself. Is the price that I paid and keep paying worth it? I am sure that you believe that you’ve struggled during your career. . . . Did you ever spend a night in a Turkish police station trying to explain the concept of rape? No? Well, I did. It can really disrupt your field season, boy howdy.” She ended: “You didn’t ask for my advice, but I am going to give you some anyway: Learn to use your email. . . . But don’t be discouraged, you’re way ahead of me. You’ve already learned how to type out what you really think and send it out into the world. I am just now learning how to do the same.”

headline: Ireland vs. Empire
abstract: Several new books commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Easter Rising.
lead_paragraph: “Was it needless death after all?” Yeats asked that question in “Easter 1916,” his poem about the Easter Rising, the armed insurrection by Irish republicans against British rule. That event occurred 100 years ago this month, and a fleet of new and ­reissued books commemorates its centenary. Here’s a look at some of the most noteworthy titles on this history shelf:

headline: Corey Lewandowski Says He Reached Out to Reporter After Encounter
abstract: Corey Lewandowski, the campaign manager for Donald J. Trump, has not apologized for grabbing the arm of Michelle Fields, at the time a reporter for Breitbart News. Mr. Lewandowski said Ms. Fields never returned his call to discuss the matter shortly after the March 8 episode.
lead_paragraph: Corey Lewandowski, the campaign manager for Donald J. Trump, said on Friday that he had tried to contact the reporter who filed battery charges against him shortly after their altercation last month in hopes of clearing up the matter.

headline: ‘The Butcher Bird’ by S. D. Sykes, and More
abstract: In S. D. Sykes’s sequel to “Plague Land,” England is ruled by mob violence in the wake of a devastating pandemic.
lead_paragraph: How can you top the Black Death? In her first novel, “Plague Land,” S. D. Sykes presented us with a disturbingly credible view of the devastating pandemic that wiped out half the population of England in the 14th century. In her sequel, THE BUTCHER BIRD (Pegasus Crime, $25.95), the plague has passed, leaving the ancient feudal system in chaos and the rule of law degenerating in the face of mob violence.

headline: Tribeca Interview: Patton Oswalt on ‘Nerdland’
abstract: The actor-comedian plays an aspiring but overconfident screenwriter in this animated satire. He based his character on people he has met in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Chris Prynoski’s animated film “Nerdland,” which had its premiere at Tribeca on Thursday night, follows the exploits of two Los Angeles friends, one an aspiring screenwriter (voiced by Patton Oswalt) and one an aspiring actor (voiced by Paul Rudd), both hungry for fame but lacking in talent or much of a clue. The New York Times critic Mike Hale called it a “scatological Hollywood satire.” The movie, written by Andrew Kevin Walker (“Seven”) and produced by the animation company Titmouse, takes a piercing look at celebrity-obsessed culture and those misguided souls trying to achieve some level of fame at any cost.

headline: How Not to Reform Social Security
abstract: Ted Cruz supports raising the retirement age. It’s the wrong approach.
lead_paragraph: Study after study has shown that one of the ways the rich are different from everyone else is that they live longer. And while there is no one cause for their increased longevity, there is one undeniable effect. Rich, long-lived people are a double drain on Social Security. They collect bigger benefits and they do so for a longer time than non-rich, shorter-lived beneficiaries.

headline: A New Map for America
keywords: ['States (US)', 'Urban Areas', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy', 'International Trade and World Market', 'High-Speed Rail Projects']
abstract: The 50-state model is holding the country back. It needs a new system, built around urban corridors.
lead_paragraph: THESE days, in the thick of the American presidential primaries, it’s easy to see how the 50 states continue to drive the political system. But increasingly, that’s all they drive — socially and economically, America is reorganizing itself around regional infrastructure lines and metropolitan clusters that ignore state and even national borders. The problem is, the political system hasn’t caught up.

headline: In Venice, an Art Show to Combat Overstimulation
abstract: “Accrochage” features minimalist works — many of them quietly funny — that haven’t been exhibited since entering the Pinault Foundation collection.
lead_paragraph: “Accrochage,” a new show at the Pinault Foundation’s palatial Punta della Dogana in Venice, was plotted by guest curator Caroline Bourgeois according to a “game” she set for herself: “I decided only to show work that had not been exhibited since coming into the collection,” she says. “Secondly, work that speaks of minimal gesture; thirdly, work that questions the idea of emptiness, and finally, work that uses minimal colors — with white being the common element.”

headline: Fashion vs. Art
abstract: Fashion occupies a prime position in our culture and economy. But is it art?
lead_paragraph: Fashion occupies a prime position in our culture and economy. But is it art?

headline: Fashion vs. Art
abstract: Fashion occupies a prime position in our culture and economy. But is it art?
lead_paragraph: When I first discovered the power of documentaries, one film that truly inspired me was “Unzipped,” a quintessential fashion documentary. To make this film, the director, Douglas Keeve, followed one of the era’s most successful high-fashion designers, Isaac Mizrahi, as he planned his fall 1994 collection. Mr. Keeve’s romantic connection to his subject seems to inform every gorgeous black-and-white frame of 16-millimeter film. This type of character-driven story can make for a riveting movie, and as a filmmaker I am captivated by figures who can draw my camera’s lens in a similarly magnetic way.

headline: Taking On the Ph.D. Later in Life
abstract: As doctoral programs become more flexible and students seek to enhance or change their careers, enrollment of older adults grows.

Mr. Hevey earned a master’s in business and became a certified public accountant, working for accounting firms and businesses ranging from manufacturing to enterprise software and corporate restructuring.

lead_paragraph: Higher body mass index in adolescence, even in the normal range, is tied to an increased risk for cardiovascular disease in adulthood, according to a new study.

headline: Readers Respond: Airports That Work
abstract: Comfy couches, strolling musicians and a nearby curry stand are factors that make some airports stand out, readers say.
lead_paragraph: An article last week about airport design that prioritizes lofty architectural vision over comfort, “Airports, Designed for Everyone but the Passenger,” struck a chord with readers, who posted more than 400 comments in response to the piece. Among the many lamenting the awful state of airports were several comments lauding airports that get it right. Edited excerpts from their praise are below.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review Podcast: ‘At the Existentialist Café’
abstract: Sarah Bakewell discusses her new book about the existentialists, and Liesl Schillinger talks about a new biography of Blanche Knopf.
lead_paragraph: Listen to this week’s podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

lead_paragraph: Robert Carlock answered the questions here.

headline: 2 Sought by Police After Man Is Found Dead at a Manhattan Homeless Shelter
abstract: The victim, a 56-year-old man, had wire around his neck and a deep cut, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The 56-year-old man lay dead in his bed at a Manhattan homeless shelter on Friday with a deep cut in his neck, which was wrapped in wire. There was blood all over his mattress, and the police said they were investigating the death as a homicide.

headline: U.C. Davis Learns Downside of Trying to Scrub Search Results
keywords: ['Search Engines', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: It often backfires. Now images of students being pepper-sprayed in 2011 are back in the news, and legislators want the chancellor to resign.
lead_paragraph: In November 2011, after a police officer pepper-sprayed students who were sitting in the quad during a protest, the University of California, Davis, had to contend with an image problem as a video  rapidly spread.

headline: Spotted: Late-Blooming Urban Bird-Watcher
abstract: Confessions of a newly binoculared New Yorker impatiently awaiting the spring migration.
lead_paragraph: You could call me an unlikely bird-watcher.

headline: A Simple Triathlon Story, Until a Reporter Went the Distance
abstract: Reporting on the suspected cheating by a Canadian triathlete provided more of a story than Sarah Lyall had anticipated.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Sarah Lyall, a staff writer at The Times, describes how her reporting on  a Canadian triathlete suspected of cheating provided more of a story than she had anticipated.

headline: First Teaser for ‘The Birth of a Nation’ Is Released
abstract: Acclaimed at Sundance, Nate Parker’s biopic of Nat Turner will be released in October.
lead_paragraph: With a sweeping aerial shot of a cotton field and the sounds of Nina Simone singing “Strange Fruit,” the teaser trailer for the film “The Birth of a Nation” has an impact from the start. The drama caused a stir at this year’s Sundance Film Festival, winning both the Grand Jury Prize and the Audience Award, and selling to Fox Searchlight for a record $17.5 million. Now the film is being positioned for the Oscar race with this intense teaser.

headline: Taliban Attack Kunduz City, Alarming Afghans
abstract: Officials said they ended the assault on the city, but fear remained that lack of unity among the Army and the police could weaken security.
lead_paragraph: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan — Taliban militants on Friday attacked several districts surrounding the northern city of Kunduz, which briefly fell to them last year. But even as Afghan officials said the security forces had successfully fought off the assault, residents expressed alarm that the insurgents were again at the city’s gates.

headline: Ntozake Shange Archive Goes to Barnard
abstract: “I came of age as a feminist and an artist at Barnard,” Ms. Shange said.
lead_paragraph: Barnard College has acquired the archive of Ntozake Shange, the feminist poet and playwright best known for the experimental play “For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf,” which ran on Broadway from 1976 to 1978.

headline: SunEdison, Becoming So Big It Fails, Prepares for Bankruptcy
abstract: The filing signaled the potential end to SunEdison’s ambitions to become the world’s leading renewable energy development company.
lead_paragraph: SunEdison, which grew from making chemicals and components for solar modules to become a giant of the renewable energy business, is preparing for bankruptcy, according to a filing with regulators on Friday.

headline: Friday Night Music: The Wild Reeds at Mercury Lounge
abstract: An evening to remember.
lead_paragraph: Yes, it’s only afternoon. But I’m giving a talk, then there’s a reception, and anyway I’m taking a mental vacation for the rest of the day. So I hereby declare it wine-and-cheese-o’clock.

headline: Kerry Butler on Japanese Toilets and ‘Disaster!’
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Theater', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: The actress lives with her husband, Joey Mazzarino, and their children on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: One morning more than 30 years ago, Sister Mary Arlene, the principal of St. Frances Cabrini, a now-defunct parochial grammar school in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, commandeered the public address system on behalf of a very special student: “Everyone, please pray for Kerry Butler,” she urged, “because today she has her final callback to play Annie on Broadway.”

headline: What I Love | Kerry Butler
abstract: Ms. Butler, a star of the Broadway spoof “Disaster!,” lives in a duplex on the Upper West Side with her husband, Joey Mazzarino.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Butler, a star of the Broadway spoof “Disaster!,” lives in a duplex on the Upper West Side with her husband, Joey Mazzarino.
