abstract: John Carney shares his picks, from “A Star is Born” to “Saturday Night Fever.”
lead_paragraph: John Carney shares his picks, from “A Star is Born” to “Saturday Night Fever.”

headline: Southern Cities Split With States on Social Issues
keywords: ['Local Government', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Urban Areas', 'Discrimination', 'State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)', 'Flags, Emblems and Insignia', 'Minimum Wage']
abstract: Cities in the Deep South are increasingly at odds with their states on gay rights and other benchmarks, moving toward common ground with big cities on the coasts.
lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — It was not that long ago that Victoria Fortenberry figured she would mark her 18th birthday by getting on a bus and getting out of Mississippi. But here she was, blue-haired, tattooed and 19 years old, singing at a party for a new line of craft beer to a crowd that included her girlfriend.

headline: Jose Cuervo Said to Be Making Arrangements for an I.P.O.
abstract: The family-owned Mexican company is working with JPMorgan Chase and Morgan Stanley to prepare for the deal, according to people with knowledge of the matter.
lead_paragraph: Happy hour is coming to the initial public offerings market.

headline: Review: Vicky Shick at Danspace, Tough and Tender
abstract: “Another Spell,” Ms. Shick’s newest commission for Danspace Project, hints that the characters onstage have a shared past.
lead_paragraph: It’s not so much that Vicky Shick knows how to string together seemingly disparate movements — examples from her latest dance include snapping fingers, bent knees that open and shut rapidly, and a purposeful walk interrupted by a fall to the floor — but that she can shape them into a coordinated flow. Detailed and precisely rendered, her choreography has a crystalline clarity that can also, oddly, evaporate right before your eyes. It’s like spotting a shell sparkling in the sand before a wave carries it back into the ocean.

headline: A Party to Mark the Party of the Year
abstract: The fashion crowd takes over opening night of the Tribeca Film Festival for the premiere of “The First Monday in May.”
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, which draws millions of visitors every year, is closed only four days out of 365: Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day, New Year’s Day, and the first Monday in May.

headline: In Milan, Fashion Brands Embrace Salone del Mobile
abstract: Nike, Tod’s and more have created installations and pieces for the furniture fair.
lead_paragraph: The Salone del Mobile furniture fair, which wraps up Sunday in Milan, was the biggest yet — with hundreds of exhibitors setting up all over the city. And this year, a handful of fashion brands entered the fray: some showcasing luxurious collections for the home, others unveiling fashion pieces inspired by design, and others still presenting experimental ideas not for sale. Here, some of the most interesting fashion happenings at Salone del Mobile this week.

headline: Keurig’s New K-Cup Coffee Is Recyclable, but Hardly Green
abstract: Keurig’s effort relies on convenience-oriented consumers to take extra steps to deal with used pods, and it doesn’t address production waste.
lead_paragraph: Keurig Green Mountain last year sold more than nine billion of its traditional single-serve plastic coffee pods — or K-Cups. Precisely zero could be easily recycled.

headline: ‘Housewives’ at 10 Years Old
abstract: The Bravo franchise has grown into a cultural behemoth, fueled by feuds, scandals and bad behavior. On a bus tour, fans got to interact with members of the New York cast.
lead_paragraph: The Bravo franchise has grown into a cultural behemoth, fueled by feuds, scandals and bad behavior. On a bus tour, fans got to interact with members of the New York cast.

headline: 2016 N.B.A. Playoff Matchups
abstract: A look at the eight opening-round series, which all begin this weekend.
lead_paragraph: No. 1 Golden State Warriors vs. No. 8 Houston Rockets

headline: Modern Feminists, in Their Own Words
abstract: These seven feminists, from Tavi Gevinson to Beth Ditto, cite the poet Eileen Myles as inspiration. T looks back on their own words on feminism and womanhood.
lead_paragraph: These seven feminists, from Tavi Gevinson to Beth Ditto, cite the poet Eileen Myles as inspiration. T looks back on their own words on feminism and womanhood.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Eileen Myles
abstract: The poet shares the titles she’d most want with her on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the poet Eileen Myles, who shares her list exclusively with T.

headline: The Poet Idolized by a New Generation of Feminists
abstract: Long relegated to the fringes of American culture, Eileen Myles is suddenly hot.
lead_paragraph: For decades, it seemed as though Eileen Myles and her unflinching depictions of New York misfits and creatives would forever be relegated to the margins of the American canon. And then last year happened.

headline: Egyptians Denounce President Sisi in Biggest Rally in 2 Years
abstract: The demonstration was the largest in two years and the most significant challenge by protesters forced into the shadows by a violent state crackdown.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — More than a thousand people gathered in downtown Cairo on Friday, chanting slogans denouncing President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi and protesting his decision to transfer sovereignty of two islands in the Red Sea to Saudi Arabia.

headline: Citigroup Chief Faces a Predicament, Despite Recent Victory
abstract: Mike Corbat has done a lot to patch up Citi’s relationship with regulators, but earnings remain elusive.
lead_paragraph: Mike Corbat, the chief executive of Citigroup, is entangled in a banking Catch-22. He aced the living will and stress tests. He has also helped form an efficient operation, as shown by the bank’s latest quarterly results. Returns remain subpar, however. Improving on them requires leaning on tax breaks. And doing that will depend on finding more profit in tough times.

headline: The Right to Privacy for Children Online
keywords: ['Celebrities', 'Children and Childhood', 'Privacy', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', "Children's Online Privacy Protection Act", 'Social Media']
abstract: Young children can’t consent to having their images and words shared with thousands or more, often in the service of an adult’s personal brand.
lead_paragraph: This week, Beyoncé introduced an athleisure clothing line called Ivy Park. The brand’s name derives from a beloved childhood park she ran in, and from her 4-year-old daughter, Blue Ivy, a regular on her Instagram account and in her videos who also appears in the commercial, on her mother’s back and both wearing Ivy Park-logo headbands.

headline: An Artist at 100, Thinking Big but Starting Small
abstract: The painter Carmen Herrera demonstrates her process.
lead_paragraph: The painter Carmen Herrera, who turns 101 in May, was sitting in her wheelchair on a gray day last month, waiting and watching, catlike.

headline: Where Berkowitz Did Time and Cagney Spent Time
abstract: Ossining, N.Y., hopes to preserve the legacy of Sing Sing, in hopes of attracting hundreds of thousands of visitors to the infamous prison.
lead_paragraph: There’s something magical about Sing Sing, the maximum-security prison that sprawls over 75 acres on a bank of the Hudson River where it widens north of the Tappan Zee Bridge — if the word magical can be used to describe a place that in the late 19th century pioneered the use of the electric chair and that today houses about 1,600 inmates, many of them convicted of rape or murder.

headline: T’s New Culture Issue: Past Is Present
abstract: For something to be “in fashion,” it needs to be of the times, but that doesn’t mean that it can’t also be kept and treasured for a lifetime.
lead_paragraph: This issue of T, dedicated to culture — specifically, the culture of style — sprouted from a sentence in a book, “Roomscapes,” written by the Italian architect and set designer Renzo Mongiardino in 1992, a few years before he died. “I think it is a mistake,” he wrote, “to treat ancient and modern as if a barrier divided them.” The houses he created were imagined worlds full of layers — of color, pattern, artifice and history — and because they weren’t obviously wed to the fashions of the day in which they were made, they have succeeded at being timeless. In a sense, they feel as relevant and beautiful as ever.

headline: DOT's order
abstract: DOT's tentative order on approving Norwegian Air's application
lead_paragraph: DOT's tentative order on approving Norwegian Air's application

headline: Norwegian Airline Gets Initial Approval for More U.S. Flights
abstract: The move means Norwegian Air Shuttle’s Irish unit can soon fly between the United States and European Union countries under the open skies agreement.
lead_paragraph: Norwegian Air Shuttle, a low-cost European airline, won tentative approval on Friday to expand its no-frills operations into the United States.

headline: Phil Sayer, Voice Behind ‘Mind the Gap’ on London Underground, Dies at 62
abstract: Mr. Sayer, an English voice actor, first recorded messages for the London Underground in 2005. “Mind the gap” has been in use since 1969.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Phil Sayer, a voice actor whose admonition to “please mind the gap” has been heard by millions of passengers on the London Underground since 2005, died on Thursday at his home in Bolton, England. He was 62.

headline: Fox Announces Date for Megyn Kelly’s Broadcast Special
abstract: Her program will be a lead-in to a dating show called “Coupled.”
lead_paragraph: Megyn Kelly’s coming broadcast special has a new name, a new time and a new connection to her bête noire, Donald J. Trump.

headline: What’s Worse Than a Girl Being Kidnapped?
abstract: Abductions appeared to be just another great misfortune in a land beset by tragedy.
lead_paragraph: Abuja, Nigeria — WE were late getting to Chibok. Our driver was delayed. On the way to meet us, he explained, he had seen a mother carrying a sick child on her back and stopped to give them a lift to the hospital. By the time they arrived, the child had died.

headline: New Jersey Series Frees Some Playwrights From ‘Developmental Hell’
abstract: The new program NJPAC Stage Exchange commissions plays and promises staged readings and eventually full productions in Newark.
lead_paragraph: “Too many new plays get workshop readings but then end up lost in developmental hell and never see the light of day,” Andy Donald, a producer with the New Jersey Performing Arts Center, said in a recent telephone interview.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Randal C. Archibold, Michael Wines and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.

headline: The Many Periods of One Artist’s Life
abstract: A retrospective of Mort Künstler’s work, from illustrations for pulp magazines to historical paintings, is on display at the Long Island Museum.
lead_paragraph: The art exhibition at the Long Island Museum in Stony Brook contains works that span about 80 years — and they are by one artist, who is still working. That would be Mort Künstler, 88, the subject of “Mort Künstler: The Art of Adventure.”

headline: Review: Cecil Taylor’s Mysteries Don’t Resolve at the 88th Key
abstract: Mr. Taylor’s music, poetry and more are the focus of an exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
lead_paragraph: First things first: The pianist Cecil Taylor, one of the great American artists of the past century, is the subject of an imaginative exhibition and residency at the Whitney Museum of American Art for the next 10 days, called “Open Plan.” This kind of meticulous museum treatment is unusual for a musician, let alone an improvising or living one. You should go.

headline: Review: Camille O’Sullivan, Proclaiming Ferocious Truths at Irish Arts
abstract: Ms. O’Sullivan, with Feargal Murray on keyboards, Andrew Zinsmeister on guitar, and Dan Weiner on drums, is presenting an evening of rock and cabaret.
lead_paragraph: It isn’t enough to describe Camille O’Sullivan as merely a singer. During an appearance at the Irish Arts Center on Thursday evening, she made the cabaret and rock songs in her challenging international program a musical play, with dramatic lighting and props and a focal character, which she more than ably embodied. Tom Waits, Nick Cave, Jacques Brel and Leonard Cohen are among those whose works she inhabited with a ferocious commitment to unearthing their truths.

headline: Gothic to Goth: Exploring the Impact of the Romantic Era in Fashion
abstract: An exhibition in Hartford looks at a bygone era whose sensibilities echo to the present.
lead_paragraph: Visitors to the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art can wander through “Gothic to Goth: Romantic Era Fashion and Its Legacy” and admire the array of costumes and accessories from the first half of the 19th century. They might marvel at the sumptuous dresses with complicated sleeves and impossibly small waists, the shawls and aprons hand-embroidered with intricate designs and the delicate jewelry woven from human hair.

headline: Review: Les Arts Florissants in a Heady Mix of Cabaret and Miley Cyrus
abstract: William Christie directs this ensemble in Robert Carsen’s staging of André Campra’s “Les Fêtes Vénitiennes” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Springtime in New York: The trees are in bloom, eyes are itching, and sheep are feeling restless. Just a few weeks ago, 100 of them stole the show at the Park Avenue Armory, where they brought a note of docile pathos to a production of Louis Andriessen’s “De Materie.” And on Thursday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, distant cousins of theirs got randy during a pastoral scene in “Les Fêtes Vénitiennes,” mating in sometimes acrobatic positions.

headline: Asparagus Is Sweetest in Spring
abstract: Get them while they last. Fresh local spears are like no other — sweet, firm and enticingly green.
lead_paragraph: If you believe, as many do, that asparagus should be celebrated as a sure sign of spring and is best eaten only during its relatively short season, you know something about the joy of anticipation.

headline: A Different Light
abstract: John Chiara’s photographs of the city use an inverted palette: Bright sky becomes pitch black; trees glow as if lit from within.
lead_paragraph: John Chiara’s photographs of the city use an inverted palette: Bright sky becomes pitch black; trees glow as if lit from within.

headline: Big Town, Big Camera
abstract: The photographer John Chiara uses a throwback to the camera obscura, with modern light filters and the chemical reversal of colors.
lead_paragraph: At a time when taking photographs has never been easier, John Chiara shot New York City the hard way. Mr. Chiara, 44, who lives in San Francisco, built two box cameras the size of kitchen cabinets and loaded them with large sheets of photosensitive paper that produced negatives of the colors projected on it. “New York is a very challenging place to photograph, because it’s been photographed so much,” he said. “It was exciting figuring out what I had to bring to it.” The results are an alternate city that evokes the chaos and monumental architecture of the real thing but invites people to meditate on it rather than rush through. “I wanted it to feel like a fragment of a memory,” he said. “It’s like the visual you get when you’re staring into space, trying to reconcile what you remember with what you saw. You don’t get the whole thing at once. You have moments of clarity, but it’s elusive.” The cameras each took weeks to build; the shooting took the better part of a year. With any image, he never knew quite what he had until he saw the finished print.

headline: De Blasio’s Investigations Chief Recuses Himself From Fund-Raising Inquiry
abstract: The move by Commissioner Mark G. Peters, who served as campaign treasurer for Mayor Bill de Blasio in the 2013 race, was an abrupt turnaround.
lead_paragraph: The commissioner of New York City’s Investigation Department, in an abrupt turnaround, has recused himself from a federal inquiry into Mayor Bill de Blasio’s political fund-raising operation, the agency said on Friday.

headline: The Tragic Life of America’s First Supermodel
abstract: “The Curse of Beauty” by James Bone profiles Audrey Munson, a New Yorker who modeled for many statues. “Jackie Robinson in Quotes” covers the athlete’s fight for racial justice.
lead_paragraph: Like Helen of Troy (not the homely city in upstate New York), her visage inspired suitors and protectors, but Audrey Munson (who did hail from upstate) is more likely to be remembered as the face that launched a thousand quips.

headline: Supreme Court Immigration Ruling Won’t End Political Tussle
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Deportation', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: Regardless of what the justices decide on the legality of President Obama’s actions, the issue is sure to remain a volatile one on the campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Inside the Supreme Court’s chambers on Monday, eight justices will consider whether President Obama abused the power of his office by issuing executive actions to allow millions of undocumented immigrants to work in the country legally and protect them from deportation.

headline: N.B.A. Approves Ads on Uniforms
abstract: The N.B.A. has approved the use of sponsorship patches on all league uniforms. Commissioner Adam Silver said use of the patches could begin with the start of the 2017-18 season.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. has approved the use of sponsorship patches on all league uniforms. Commissioner Adam Silver said use of the patches could begin with the start of the 2017-18 season.

headline: Bookshelf: Poems for Kids of All Ages
abstract: New picture books by Judith Viorst, Julie Fogliano and Skila Brown.
lead_paragraph: New picture books by Judith Viorst, Julie Fogliano and Skila Brown.

headline: With Spring, the Rare Spotted Salamander Emerges
abstract: How these coldblooded New Yorkers have survived underground in the city is anyone’s guess, but the amphibians emerge during spring’s first rain.
lead_paragraph: A light rain was falling on Ellen Pehek and Susan Stanley of New York City’s Natural Resources Group where we agreed to meet at a quiet corner in Queens. Not normally an auspicious sign, the evening’s wet weather was ideal for our purposes. We were here to survey for one of the city’s rarest animals, the spotted salamander. Just beyond the street lamps, a rapidly darkening forest, already filled with a chorus of wood frogs and spring peepers, beckoned.

headline: Review: ‘Rhythm in Motion’ Explores the Many Definitions of Tap
abstract: The American Tap Dance Foundation’s program at the Theater at the 14th Street Y includes work by Samara Seligsohn and Caleb Teicher.
lead_paragraph: Apparently, tap dance is like outer space: There are worlds waiting to be discovered. For the American Tap Dance Foundation’s “Rhythm in Motion” program, a selection of choreography showcased tap as meditation, tap that flows like water and tap as tonic for an outcast. In all, it was a night spent hoping for more and, sadly and repeatedly, settling for less.

headline: A Bartender With a Magic Touch
abstract: Dave Cremin provides both the service and the entertainment at Cronin & Phelan’s in Queens, doing bar-top tricks while serving drinks and food.
lead_paragraph: The bartender delivered another round to the couple at the end of the bar, and then laid a small black mat in front of them.

headline: ‘A Hologram for the King’ Finds Tom Hanks in the Desert, Desperate to Sell Phantoms
abstract: The Dave Eggers novel comes to the screen, with Mr. Hanks in the lead role and Tom Tykwer, of “Cloud Atlas” and “Run Lola Run,” behind the camera.
lead_paragraph: Dave Eggers, once the wunderkind of American letters, has been writing books for close to 20 years. He has picked up a couple of screenwriting credits, including one for the movie version of Maurice Sendak’s children’s classic “Where the Wild Things Are,” which he wrote with the director, Spike Jonze, but somehow his own novels seemed to elude the big screen.

headline: ‘Elvis & Nixon’ Is Based on a Strange, Real-Life Meeting
abstract: Michael Shannon, as Elvis Presley, and Kevin Spacey, as President Richard M. Nixon, reimagine the bizarre — but true — story of how two American icons met.
lead_paragraph: The photograph, one of the most requested from the National Archives, has left generations of viewers scratching their heads: President Richard M. Nixon — wearing a gray suit with an American flag pin in his lapel — and Elvis Presley — in velvet bell-bottoms and cape, an enormous gold belt buckle at his waist — shaking hands in the White House.

headline: Hillary Clinton Falters on the Path to $15
abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s praise of New York’s minimum-wage law was self-serving.
lead_paragraph: The contest between California and New York to be seen as leaders in the Fight for $15 escalated this week when Hillary Clinton took sides, calling New York’s minimum-wage law “a model for the nation.”

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Bernie Sanders, Japan, Dilma Rousseff
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Path of $681 Million: From Saudi Arabia to Malaysian Premier’s Personal Account
abstract: Despite assurances from Malaysian and Saudi officials, suspicions persist surrounding the $681 million that was deposited into Najib Razak’s bank account last year.
lead_paragraph: How did $681 million end up being deposited in the personal bank account of Malaysia’s prime minister, Najib Razak, last year?

headline: Review: Martha Graham Dance Celebrates 90 Years
abstract: The troupe opened its 90th season at City Center with a film as well as some new and old works.
lead_paragraph: Compared with the mayfly life spans of most dance troupes, the endurance of the Martha Graham Dance Company suggests a geological time scale. At City Center on Thursday, this oldest of American dance groups opened its 90th anniversary season (90th!) with “90 Years in 90 Seconds,” a film by Justin Scholar. Hundreds of archival images and clips flew by in chronological order: the volcanic early decades, the embarrassing later ones and then, like the humbling sliver of human history in a chart of the earth’s existence, the blip of the past few years and its commissioned works.

headline: The Bar With a Chip on Its Shoulder
abstract: Liedy’s Shore Inn doesn’t get the kind of attention that its historic counterparts in Manhattan attract, probably because its address is remote, even for Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: Lois Angone has a favorite cracked-leather bar stool at Liedy’s Shore Inn, the oldest bar on Staten Island. She is known as Sparkles because she sparkles. She applies glitter to her body every morning and keeps a container with more just in case.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Tiger Kills Zookeeper in Florida
abstract: The keeper at the Palm Beach Zoo was performing a routine procedure when killed by the Malayan tiger, a zoo official said.
lead_paragraph: A zookeeper performing a routine procedure in Palm Beach, Fla., was killed Friday by a Malayan tiger, a zoo official said.

headline: ‘The Night Manager’ Brings John le Carré Back to the Small Screen
abstract: The author’s labyrinthine espionage novels haven’t been adapted to television for 25 years, until AMC’s six-part mini-series starring Tom Hiddleston and Hugh Laurie.
lead_paragraph: Writers, like spies, tend to have trust issues, and David Cornwell, 84, has been both a writer and a spy. Under his own name, he once worked for British intelligence. As John le Carré, he has for the past half-century written labyrinthine novels about espionage and other sorts of subterfuge and imposture, all of which suggest that in this world it’s best to be very, very wary.

headline: Group Backing Donald Trump Highlights His Role in Capturing Rapist
abstract: A group backing Mr. Trump has filmed an ad intended to air in New York during the primary that tells the story of his financing fliers to help the police capture a serial rapist in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Join us for New York primary live updates.

headline: How Krishna Andavolu of Viceland TV Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mr. Andavolu, host of the “Weediquette” series, treasures his Sundays at home in Brooklyn and visiting his parents for South Indian meals.
lead_paragraph: Krishna Andavolu had some explaining to do after he smoked a joint. With the president of Uruguay. On television. “My parents are coming to understand that the son that they’ve placed their hopes and dreams in can be successful and have it be a part of his life,” said Mr. Andavolu, 33, the host, on the brand-new Viceland channel, of the series “Weediquette,” which draws to a close this week. Between trips to explore pot culture from Eastern Congo to California, Mr. Andavolu, who previously edited a magazine about endings, “Obit,” spends his time in Brooklyn, where he lives in Clinton Hill with his wife, Emma Alpert, a public defender; their 21-month-old son, Kalyan; and their dog, Leela.

headline: At Columbia University, Daring to Back Clinton
abstract: On a campus where support for Bernie Sanders can seem unequivocal, a few students have come forward to rally around the other Democratic candidate.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Shailene Woodley, who, as the star of the “Divergent” films is a kind of living symbol of the millennial force field, was making her way around Columbia University, canvassing on behalf of Bernie Sanders. Campaigning for the Vermont senator’s presidential bid at a Northeastern university — or any university, for that matter — seems a little like walking into Peter Luger to persuade people to have the steak. Regardless of the advantages that accrue to Ivy League students, and whatever privileges might have landed them there in the first place, Columbia falls within the vast psychographic jurisdiction of Mr. Sanders, enemy of the indulged and fussed-over.

headline: With Gas Station’s Closing, a Fuel Desert Expands in Manhattan
keywords: ['Automobile Service and Charging Stations', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline']
abstract: The SoHo business, which is to be replaced by a luxury office building, was a lifeline for many looking to fill up downtown, especially cabdrivers.
lead_paragraph: The gas station at the corner of Lafayette and East Houston Streets in SoHo is an industrial outpost in a Manhattan neighborhood of luxury lofts and even more luxurious shopping. It has existed on the corner for decades — first as Gaseteria, later as BP, but nearly always selling gas. For cabdrivers, it was a way station in an unruly city, where they could fill up, use the restroom, or kneel for afternoon prayers on one of the communal kilims the owner let them keep stowed beside the convenience mart.

Power and Associates for $1.1 billion from McGraw Hill Financial, in what will be its biggest investment yet and its first in the United States.

Trump from becoming its nominee.

headline: What Needs to Come After the New York Primary
abstract: Hillary Clinton remains New York’s favorite in a nasty, exhausting slog that has exacted a toll on Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Barring another Michigan-style upset, Hillary Clinton is likely to win the New York presidential primary on Tuesday. But watching her and Bernie Sanders wage the Battle of Brooklyn on the debate stage on Thursday was to hear two candidates recycling familiar themes, albeit at a higher pitch, and to see the toll that these fractious months of combat have exacted on them and their party. Democrats are now so divided and dug-in that no matter who wins the nomination, it will take a considerable effort to heal and reunite them.

headline: Saudi Arabia Warns of Economic Fallout if Congress Passes 9/11 Bill
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Foreign Investments', 'United States International Relations', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The kingdom has bristled over a bill that would allow its government to be held responsible in American courts for any role in the Sept. 11 attacks.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Saudi Arabia has told the Obama administration and members of Congress that it will sell off hundreds of billions of dollars’ worth of American assets held by the kingdom if Congress passes a bill that would allow the Saudi government to be held responsible in American courts for any role in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

headline: Bernie Sanders Releases His 2014 Tax Returns

headline: Newtown Families Get a Court Hearing

A Connecticut state judge denied a motion to throw out their lawsuit against the manufacturers of the Bushmaster AR-15, a military-style assault rifle used to kill 20 children and six adults in the grisly siege.

headline: Bernie Sanders Makes Quick Transition From Brooklyn to Rome

headline: Malick Sidibé, Photographer Known for Social Reportage in Mali, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Sidibé’s 1960s black-and-white photos of young partygoers in his native country captured the exuberance of new freedom.
lead_paragraph: Malick Sidibé, whose black-and-white photographs of young partygoers captured the exuberance of newly independent Mali in the 1960s and ’70s and made him one of Africa’s most celebrated artists after his work was shown abroad in the 1990s, died on Thursday in Bamako, Mali. He was 80.

headline: Cuba’s Path to the Future Is Shrouded in Secrecy

Lew announced 10 months ago that he would choose a woman for a new $10 bill in development.

headline: The Case for Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Trump is more than a political outsider. He offers ideas that resonate with voters.
lead_paragraph: Clarence, N.Y. — AMERICANS are angry. I hear it from the former factory workers who lost their jobs to other countries because of bad trade deals, the veterans who wait months to see a doctor at a Veterans Affairs hospital and the small-business owners who are struggling to stay afloat because of the Affordable Care Act’s crippling regulations. The professional politicians they trusted and supported have repeatedly sold out our country in favor of special interests and the status quo. Finally, millions of Americans are saying, “Enough is enough.”

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: A 76-year-old man who a prosecutor says was wrongly convicted in the 1957 killing of a 7-year-old girl was released Friday after a judge vacated his conviction, meaning that one of the nation’s oldest cold cases to be tried has gone cold again. The man, Jack McCullough, a former police officer, was sentenced to life in 2012 in the death of Maria Ridulph in Sycamore, west of Chicago. A prosecutor found evidence last year that supported his alibi that he had been 40 miles away when she disappeared. Maria had been playing in the snow with a friend when a young man offered them piggyback rides. The friend dashed home for mittens, and when she came back, Maria and the man were gone. (AP)

headline: 1966: Students Sack Peking Embassy
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Indonesian-Chinese students wreck the Peking embassy in 1966.
lead_paragraph: DJAKARTA — About 2,000 screaming Indonesian Chinese sacked the Chinese embassy here today [April 14], smashing doors and windows and lighting vast bonfires of documents in the latest outburst of anti-Peking feelings. With a truck, they battered down the 15-foot red gate guarding the building and, once inside, smashed three cars, ripped the Chinese crest off the chancery, tore down the flag and replaced it with the Indonesian standard.

headline: The Return of Elasticity Pessimism (Wonkish)
abstract: Surprises from Europeanists.
lead_paragraph: I talked at the Council for European Studies conference in Philly last night, and was surprised by one aspect of the discussion. As you might expect if you’re into these things, my take on the euro was strongly informed by the theory of Optimum Currency Areas; I expected pushback. But I didn’t realize how many people now seem to believe that real exchange rates don’t matter for adjustment — that is, that even internal devaluation (downward adjustment of prices and wages relative to trading partners) isn’t necessary in the aftermath of unsustainable capital inflows.

headline: Richard K. Ransom, Founder of Hickory Farms Specialty Foods Chain, Dies at 96
abstract: From selling cheeses and meats at local fairs, Mr. Ransom went on to build an empire of specialty food stores, one sample at a time.
lead_paragraph: In 1951, finding specialty meats and cheeses could take some doing if you lived in small-town America and had no neighborhood deli. For Richard K. Ransom, this was an opportunity.

abstract: A well-paced acrostic from Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — A typically elegant acrostic today, just like the HORSES in Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon’s puzzle.

headline: A Conversation With Whales
abstract: They surrounded the divers and started clicking — they seemed to be saying hello. Read and then take a swim with whales in a virtual reality feature.
lead_paragraph: They surrounded the divers and started clicking — they seemed to be saying hello. Read and then take a swim with whales in a virtual reality feature.

headline: The Click Effect
abstract: Dive under the sea and listen to the language of dolphins and whales in virtual reality.
lead_paragraph: I’ve long been interested in the capacity of storytelling and journalism to transport an audience. Shooting my first documentary in North Africa 35 years ago, I used multiple projectors and screens to create an immersive experience. The approach at the time was experimental and while I moved on to more traditional storytelling in features, television and documentaries, I always held on to the idea of using immersive environments to transport viewers and allow them to experience an expanded vision of the world.

headline: Grumbling About Socialism, the Yankees Profit From It

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Campaign Past Reveals Willingness to Play Hardball
abstract: The Democratic presidential candidate with a reputation for being issues oriented has not shied away from mixing it up personally with opponents.
lead_paragraph: During the 1986 race for governor of Vermont, Bernie Sanders bristled at the popularity of the Democratic incumbent, Madeleine Kunin. Mr. Sanders, who was running against her as an independent, saw himself as a leader, and viewed Ms. Kunin as a lightweight.

headline: Families of Americans Held by Allies Say U.S. Is Keeping Its Gloves On
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Detainees', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Torture', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: Relatives have complained of a lack of high-level attention from American officials — stemming, they fear, from reluctance to confront Egypt and the United Arab Emirates.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — In the United Arab Emirates, a Libyan-American father and son detained since 2014 on political charges said security agents tortured them in prison, with beatings and electric shocks.

headline: Dilma Rousseff’s Former Supporters in Brazil Express Disillusionment
abstract: As the president faces a possible impeachment, working-class people who brought her party to power say they feel abandoned and want a change.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — They are at once ubiquitous and invisible here, the street cleaners, landscapers, hotel maids and traffic police who make sure Brazil’s meticulously designed capital stays true to the national flag’s slogan of “order and progress.”

headline: Kobe Bryant’s Finale a Triumph of Volume Over Value
abstract: Bryant’s final game provided in many ways a perfectly accurate portrait of a player whose game could never be described as efficient but who had a knack for relentlessly pursuing victory at all costs.
lead_paragraph: It would perhaps be forgivable for anyone glancing at the box score of Kobe Bryant’s final N.B.A. game on Wednesday to assume his point total was a typographical error. Somehow, a 37-year-old player closing out his 20th season, who had not scored more than 38 points in a game since November 2014, dropped 60 points on the Utah Jazz.

headline: Farmers in Arid India Share Camps With Their Cattle
abstract: In a nation where cows are both sacred and essential, camps have been set up to preserve them in a drought. But instead of dropping them off, the owners are staying.
lead_paragraph: KHILAD, India — The cattle camp, on a dusty back road lined with thorny babul trees that seem to thrive no matter how weak the rains, is just about impossible to miss.

headline: At the Boston Marathon, Leading the Way for Women Fifty Years Ago
abstract: Roberta Gibb, who broke the gender barrier at the Boston Marathon and is the grand marshal of this year’s race, is among the pioneers of women’s running.
lead_paragraph: In 1965, the year I first ran the Boston Marathon, there were no women in the field of about 400 participants. On Monday morning, more than 13,000 women will start the 120th Boston Marathon.

headline: John Ferrone, Editor of Eclectic Stable of Writers, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Ferrone counted among his authors Alice Walker, Anaïs Nin and James Beard.
lead_paragraph: John Ferrone, an editor who shepherded Alice Walker’s Pulitzer Prize-winning novel “The Color Purple” into print, encouraged Anaïs Nin to publish her erotic fiction, and served as James Beard’s dining and cooking companion and literary executor, died in Old Bridge, N.J., on April 10. He was 91.

headline: Mets’ Jacob deGrom to Stay in Florida With Sick Newborn
abstract: The Mets have placed deGrom on the family medical emergency medical list because of his son’s health complications.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Mets placed starter Jacob deGrom on family medical leave Saturday because of complications with his newborn son.

headline: More Than 40 in Japan Are Confirmed Dead in Earthquakes
abstract: Aftershocks were continuing on the island of Kyushu, and a warning that strong quakes were possible for several more days was issued.
lead_paragraph: MASHIKI, Japan — The death toll from two powerful earthquakes and a series of aftershocks on the Japanese island of Kyushu reached 41 on Saturday, the authorities said, as rescue workers searched for survivors under collapsed buildings and mountains of earth displaced by landslides.

headline: Stephen Curry’s 3-Point Record in Context: Off the Charts
abstract: This chart contains 752 lines — one for each N.B.A. player who finished in the top 20 in 3-point attempts made in each season since 1980. Sitting atop it is the Golden State Warriors’ Stephen Curry, who finished the regular season with a record 402 3-pointers.

lead_paragraph: THIS month a man in Orlando, Fla., dangled a dog by the scruff of its neck over a second-floor balcony, threatening to drop it 12 feet to the ground.

headline: When an Olympian Goes to College, Riches Stay Out of Reach
keywords: ['Swimming', 'College Athletics', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Olympic Games (2016)']
abstract: Katie Ledecky, who is a threat to win four gold medals at the upcoming Summer Olympics, cannot profit from her talent while she is in school, while other students who are not athletes are allowed to do so.
lead_paragraph: MESA, ARIZ. — In the third grade, a music teacher inspired Katie Ledecky to take piano lessons. She showed an innate talent for the chords, picking them up quickly. Her formal lessons were phased out in the eighth grade as her swimming took off. Roughly five years later, no one is questioning Ledecky’s harmony with the water. She has developed into the best female distance freestyler in history and a legitimate quadruple Olympic gold medal threat this summer in Rio de Janeiro.

lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

abstract: The Times’s fifth public editor is ending her tenure after four years. She offers some final observations.
lead_paragraph: “FASTEN your seatbelts,” goes the line from “All About Eve,” accompanied by a flash of those famous Bette Davis eyes. “It’s going to be a bumpy night.”

headline: Syria’s Future: A Black Hole of Instability
abstract: Peace talks have restarted, but Bashar al-Assad and the rebels are fighting over a state that is beyond salvaging.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — NOOR, who is a commander in a pro-government militia near Damascus, thinks that President Bashar al-Assad will prevail in Syria’s civil war. But even so, he thinks it will take his country a generation to recover. “After we finish this war, we’ll spend another 10 years cleaning up the thugs and warlords on our own side,” he told me when I met him in the Damascus suburb of Jaramana, in an apartment overlooking a highway where rebels and government forces clash nightly.

headline: How Getting High Made Me a Better Caregiver
abstract: While my wife fights Parkinson’s, marijuana gives me patience and stamina.
lead_paragraph: Santa Barbara, Calif. — I’M 74 years old, and I have smoked marijuana almost every day since dinosaurs roamed the earth in the early ’70s. When my awareness is heightened, I’m on my game — the best I can be at thinking creatively, making decisions, focusing on my work, seeing the big picture ... and caregiving.

headline: Why Americans Can’t Vote
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'States (US)', 'Voting Machines', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Discrimination', 'Minorities', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: Arizona’s primary problems are a good early warning of troubles to come in deeply flawed voting systems everywhere in the country.
lead_paragraph: The state of the nation’s underfunded, patchwork election system and obsolete balloting machinery may not arouse voters the way candidates can with charges of rigged elections. But voters in Arizona who lined up for the state’s presidential primaries last month learned just how difficult and unfair voting can be even without criminal malfeasance.

headline: Plenty of Passengers, but Where Are the Pilots?
keywords: ['Pilots', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Careers and Professions', 'Delays (Transportation)', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters']
abstract: Yet another reason air travel has become so frustrating.
lead_paragraph: DELAYS or cancellations because of bad weather or mechanical problems are exasperating but common occurrences in air travel, but increasingly, passengers aren’t making it to their destinations for yet another reason: not enough pilots. The gate agent may not tell you that’s why you’re grounded, but a dearth of qualified pilots is disrupting, reducing and even eliminating flights.

headline: Trumpism and Clintonism Are the Future
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: It doesn’t matter who the nominees are. The policy realignment Mr. Trump and Mrs. Clinton represent will dominate the two major parties for decades.
lead_paragraph: No matter who wins the New York primaries on Tuesday or which candidates end up as the presidential nominees of the two major parties, one thing is already clear: Trumpism represents the future of the Republicans and Clintonism the future of the Democrats.

headline: Tweaking Genes to Save Species
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Invasive Species', 'Zika Virus', 'Biodiversity', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)']
abstract: Genetic engineering may emerge as an important tool to avert extinctions. But ecosystems are complex, and this tinkering might not unfold as planned.
lead_paragraph: Boulder, Colo. — BIOTECHNOLOGISTS have engineered the mosquito that spreads the Zika virus to pass a lethal gene to its offspring. Another team of researchers has devised a way to spread sterility through the mosquito population, using a technique called gene drive to wipe out the offending insects.

lead_paragraph: Nera White, who as a Tennessee farm girl powered the first women’s national basketball dynasty and became the game’s first female superstar, a dominance that led her into the Basketball Hall of Fame as one of the first two women to be enshrined there, died on Wednesday in a hospital in Gallatin, Tenn. She was 80.

headline: Hillary Is Not Sorry
abstract: Being Hillary, or Trump, means never having to say you’re sorry. They have no reverse on their gears.

headline: 9 Guantánamo Prisoners From Yemen Are Sent to Saudi Arabia

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States on Saturday transferred nine Yemeni detainees from its wartime prison at Guantánamo Bay to Saudi Arabia, completing a long-sought diplomatic deal ahead of a planned visit to Riyadh by President Obama in the coming week.

headline: Is That Even a Thing?
abstract: What this language trend says about us.
lead_paragraph: Speakers and writers of American English have recently taken to identifying a staggering and constantly changing array of trends, events, memes, products, lifestyle choices and phenomena of nearly every kind with a single label — a thing. In conversation, mention of a surprising fad, behavior or event is now often met with the question, “Is that actually a thing?” Or “When did that become a thing?” Or “How is that even a thing?” Calling something “a thing” is, in this sense, itself a thing.

headline: Bangladeshi Editor, 81, Is Accused in Plot to Kill Leader’s Son
abstract: The arrest of the editor, Shafik Rehman, is the latest in a string of criminal proceedings against journalists in Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — The Bangladeshi police arrested a prominent magazine editor on Saturday, accusing him of being involved in a plot to kill the son of the prime minister. The arrest was the latest in a string of criminal proceedings against journalists in the country.

headline: Clutch Hitting Remains Elusive as Yankees Fall to the Mariners

headline: Donald Trump, in Upstate New York, Tries Another Label for Hillary Clinton

headline: U.S. Plans to Step Up Military Campaign Against ISIS

lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — President Raúl Castro of Cuba on Saturday offered a somber assessment of his nation’s economic advances and warned that the United States — despite the historic thaw in relations — was still intent on changing Cuba’s communist system.

abstract: Buildups by the United States, Russia and China unsettle the balance of destructive force that has kept the nuclear peace for more than a half-century.

The buildups threaten to revive a Cold War-era arms race and unsettle the balance of destructive force among nations that has kept the nuclear peace for more than a half-century.

headline: In Hillary Clinton Ad, a More Direct Swipe at Donald Trump
abstract: Until now, Mr. Trump’s name has not been uttered in a paid ad by a Democratic candidate. That changed this week.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has dominated this presidential campaign, but until now, his name has never been uttered in a paid ad by a Democratic candidate.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 2, Episode 2: The Wounds We Carry
abstract: Physically he may be healing, but Jamie is still reeling from what Randall has done.
lead_paragraph: Sex in pop culture often lacks variety. Usually its only tenor is unadulterated lust and pleasure or on the opposite end of the spectrum, disappointment. But in real life, sex has incredible variety. It can start out tentative or coy then sway into outright passions. Lovers can pause for laughter or switch positions when something is uncomfortable. Nothing in life, especially sexual encounters, is one note. One of the greatest strengths of “Outlander” is its keen, honest understanding of sex between men and women filtered through the relationship of Claire and Jamie. Their sexual chemistry has proved to be a cornerstone of their relationship providing a window into their loyalty for one another. While last week’s episode curiously didn’t touch on Jamie’s abuse and how it currently shapes their relationship with much depth, it takes center stage in “Not in Scotland Anymore.”

lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — A 7.8-magnitude earthquake shook the central coast of Ecuador on Saturday, killing at least 77 people, officials and news reports said. The effects could be felt as far away as the capital, Quito, which lies some 105 miles from the epicenter.

headline: 1891: German Silver for the German Emperor
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Plated brass is the source of a scandal in Germany in 1891.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — All Berlin is laughing at a story for which the Vossische Zeitung is responsible. Last year the Czar presented to the German Emperor a magnificent troika, together with three Russian horses and a Russian coachman. The equipage excited great admiration in the German capital, no portion of it more than the splendid silver harness, which, it was said, had cost no less a sum than 20,000 roubles, or considerably over £3,000 sterling.

headline: Nico Rosberg Rises Above Chaos to Win Chinese Grand Prix
abstract: Rosberg easily won in Shanghai, keeping him perfect through three races this Formula One season. His teammate, Lewis Hamilton, had another discouraging result, however.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — While the reigning world champion, Lewis Hamilton, had another discouraging result early in the Formula One season, his Mercedes teammate, Nico Rosberg, extended his dream start with a third victory in a row.

lead_paragraph: In an Op-Ed article this weekend, Parag Khanna, a Singapore-based analyst of geopolitical and economic trends, proposes a shift in the United States from state-focused policies and politics to regional planning:

headline: 1941: Roosevelt Tells Press He Wants No Censorship
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: President Roosevelt assures that freedom of the press is not in danger in the United States, in 1941.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Roosevelt, contradicting persistent reports that his Administration is planning some form of compulsory censorship of press and radio, gave assurance today [April 17] that freedom of speech and freedom of the press are not in danger in the United States. ‘‘As far as I am concerned,’’ the President promised, ‘‘there will be no government control of news unless it be of vital military information.’’

headline: Fry Cook, D.J., Janitor: Next Baltimore Mayor Had to Start Somewhere
abstract: A Baltimore storytelling group asked mayoral candidates to introduce themselves to voters by talking about their first jobs.
lead_paragraph: A Baltimore storytelling group asked mayoral candidates to introduce themselves to voters by talking about their first jobs.

headline: He Said His Car Had Been Stolen; the Police Say He Was Doing the Stealing
abstract: Not long after August Watkins reported the theft of his car, he was identified by the authorities as the suspect in a wave of robberies in Queens and Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: On April 1, police officers from the 108th Precinct were called to an address in Woodside, Queens, by a man named August Watkins. He reported that his car had been stolen. The timing of his call would become an issue in the days that followed.

headline: 2016’s Other Big Question Mark: The Senate
abstract: Both parties acknowledge that control of the upper house of Congress will inevitably be affected by the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: There is a second critical contest in America’s 2016 elections: the battle for control of the Senate.

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Explore our new guide to cooking beans and get inspired for a week of cooking.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Man Killed in Police Shooting in Queens, Authorities Say
abstract: The man had fled after he was approached by plainclothes officers, and reached for a gun in his waistband during the ensuing chase, the police said.
lead_paragraph: New York City officers shot and killed a 32-year-old man in Queens in the early hours of Sunday after the police said he reached for a gun in his waistband during a chase.

headline: Scenes of Ruin After Ecuador Earthquake Kills Hundreds
abstract: More than 2,500 people were injured, the government said, in an earthquake that devastated a large swath of the Ecuadorean coast.
lead_paragraph: QUITO, Ecuador — The strongest earthquake to strike Ecuador in decades left the Andean nation traumatized on Sunday, with collapsed buildings in a swath of destruction stretching hundreds of miles.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
abstract: “Girls” wraps for the season with a doubleheader,” and “The Good Wife” comes full circle as it nears the end of its run.
lead_paragraph: “Girls” wraps for the season with a doubleheader. “The Good Wife” comes full circle as it nears the end of its run. And give “Love” a chance.

headline: Axl Rose to Join AC/DC on Tour
abstract: The singer will take up frontman duties for AC/DC in Europe in between American gigs with his band Guns N’ Roses.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, Guns N’ Roses brought out the AC/DC guitarist Angus Young at Coachella. Soon, the exchange will be reversed: Axl Rose, the Guns N’ Roses lead singer, will take up frontman duties for AC/DC on its world tour next month.

headline: Disney’s Savvy Marketing of ‘The Jungle Book’
abstract: Disney used a variety of tactics to promote the movie to different audiences and tell them it was not just a film but a magical experience.
lead_paragraph: “All of this, honestly, is one big magic trick.”

headline: College Student Is Removed From Flight After Speaking Arabic on Plane
abstract: Khairuldeen Makhzoomi, a senior at the University of California, Berkeley, was taken off a flight after he called an uncle in Baghdad and a passenger overheard him.
lead_paragraph: A college student who came to the United States as an Iraqi refugee was removed from a Southwest Airlines flight in California earlier this month after another passenger became alarmed when she heard him speaking Arabic.

headline: Israel Will Never Give Golan Heights to Syria, Netanyahu Vows
abstract: During a cabinet meeting held in the Israeli-controlled portion of the territory, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called on the world to recognize Israel’s sovereignty there.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel led a cabinet meeting in the Israeli-controlled portion of the Golan Heights on Sunday, calling on the world to recognize Israeli sovereignty over the conquered territory and vowing that Israel would never give it back to Syria.

headline: ‘Jungle Book’ Captivates Moviegoers and Captures Box Office
abstract: The Disney remake exceeded expectations, with an audience that was mainly adult.
lead_paragraph: Mowgli lit a box office wildfire over the weekend.

headline: Are Earthquakes in Japan and Ecuador Related? The Science Says No
abstract: Although two powerful quakes struck on opposite sides of the planet over the weekend, there is no connection between them.
lead_paragraph: Earthquakes of magnitudes exceeding 7.0 struck Japan and Ecuador just hours apart on Saturday. Are the two somehow related?

headline: Bronx Needle Exchange, Once Dismissed, Finds Acceptance
keywords: ['Hypodermic Needles and Syringes', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Heroin', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs']
abstract: The program, which Joyce Rivera started after her brother died of AIDS, was initially spurned by a public that favored the incarceration of drug users.
lead_paragraph: When Joyce A. Rivera decided in 1990 to confront the AIDS epidemic that had claimed her brother’s life, she teamed up with unlikely allies: two drug dealers in the South Bronx. First, she educated them on how dirty needles and unprotected sex spread H.I.V., which causes AIDS. Then, she wound up distributing clean syringes to their customers in Mott Haven.

headline: A ‘Mockingbird’ Reopens in Alabama, and Drama Plays Out
abstract: The residue of a trademark fight hangs over the annual stage adaptation of Harper Lee’s novel in Monroeville.
lead_paragraph: MONROEVILLE, Ala. — The play unfolded here Friday at the Old Monroe County Courthouse pretty much as it has for the past 27 years. Atticus Finch defended Tom Robinson. The gospel choir sang. Scout used a slingshot to keep the boys in line and her curiosity to pose tough questions.

headline: New Sense of Fragility in Japanese Town Struck Twice by Quakes
abstract: People in Mashiki had known a network of fault lines ran under their town. But no major quake had struck in anyone’s lifetime, until two did last week.
lead_paragraph: MASHIKI, Japan — People here said they had known that a network of fault lines ran under their town like veins. But no major earthquake had struck in anyone’s lifetime. Even in Japan, the most seismically unstable country in the world, that fact had apparently created a false sense of security.

headline: Vineyard Theater Announces Season
abstract: The theater will host a new John Kander musical as well as a premiere from Nicky Silver.
lead_paragraph: John Kander’s newest musical, “Kid Victory,” will make its New York debut in September as part of the Vineyard Theater’s 2016-7 season.

headline: In Doha, Major Oil Exporters Fail to Agree on Production Freeze
abstract: The move would have involved little sacrifice on the part of oil producers, but they remained unable to reach an accord.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — Officials from 18 oil-producing nations failed on Sunday to reach a deal to freeze oil production at current levels.

headline: Labor Protesters to Resume Guggenheim Demonstrations
abstract: The museum had broken off talks with a group that advocates for workers in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.

headline: The Kentucky Derby Dartboard: Week 3
abstract: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times weigh in on the contenders for the 142nd running of the Kentucky Derby.
lead_paragraph: Top contenders for the 142nd running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of preference, with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Churchill Downs has adopted a points system to determine the Derby field, with points being earned by the top four finishers in designated prep races. The odds are from the Churchill Downs futures pool, and the records are starts-win-place-show.

headline: Bernie Sanders Courts Black Voters at Church Service in Harlem
abstract: After weeks of hosting packed rallies around New York State, Bernie Sanders on Sunday decided to do something that his Democratic rival had already been doing for weeks: He spoke at a predominately black church service.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of hosting packed rallies around New York State, Senator Bernie Sanders on Sunday decided to do something ahead of Tuesday’s primary that his Democratic rival had already been doing for weeks: He spoke at a predominately black church service.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Conservatism: The Pendulum Swings Consistently Right
abstract: Mr. Cruz’s policy views over two decades suggest that he would be the most conservative presidential nominee in at least a half-century.
lead_paragraph: On perhaps the defining issue of the 2016 Republican primary, Senator Ted Cruz falls well to the right of Ronald Reagan, who supported granting legal status to millions of undocumented immigrants.

headline: Donald Trump Says ‘Rigged’ Convention Should Not Be Met With Violence
abstract: Mr. Trump said on Sunday that he hoped the Republican Convention in July “doesn’t involve violence” as he pressed his case that the system is rigged against him.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said on Sunday that he hoped the Republican National Convention “doesn’t involve violence” as he pressed his case that the system is rigged against him.

headline: Brazil’s Lower House of Congress Votes for Impeachment of Dilma Rousseff
abstract: The vote sends the case to the Senate, which will decide whether to hold a trial on charges that the president illegally used money from state-owned banks.
lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — Brazilian legislators voted on Sunday night to approve impeachment of Dilma Rousseff, the nation’s first female president, whose tenure has been buffeted by a dizzying corruption scandal, a shrinking economy and spreading disillusionment.

headline: Review: ‘Mary Page Marlowe’ Traces a Woman’s Evolution in Phases and Fragments
abstract: This new drama by Tracy Letts follows the life of its title character at various stages, moving in a nonlinear progression.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — “It’s pretty fragile.” Those words, spoken by the title character in “Mary Page Marlowe,” the exquisite new play by Tracy Letts having its premiere at the Steppenwolf Theater here, refer to a quilt in need of some delicate dry cleaning. But they resonate with many meanings in Mr. Letts’s haunting, elliptical drama about the evolutions, reversals and resurrections in a woman’s life.

headline: For the Mets, It’s Just Sunny Enough in Cleveland
abstract: Steven Matz rebounded from a shaky season debut, shutting down Cleveland for seven innings as the Mets beat the Indians and their ace, Corey Kluber.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Mets arrived here with no series victories, a slumbering offense and a rookie starter, Steven Matz, with a 37.80 earned run average. They left with two wins in three games, a new No. 3 hitter and the dazzling version of Matz on display.

headline: In the Second Season of ‘12 Monkeys,’ Time Traveling Grows More Complex
abstract: This series, very loosely based on the 1995 movie of the same title, starts its second season on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The Syfy series “12 Monkeys,” very loosely based on the 1995 movie of the same title, starts its second season on Monday. As you might guess, whatever faint traces of the film that remained when the television show started are now just memories.

headline: Tech Companies Face Greater Scrutiny for Paying Workers With Stock
keywords: ['Stock Options and Purchase Plans', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Company Reports', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Stock-based compensation is largely unquestioned during boom periods, but tech companies’ rocky performance this year is prompting a closer look.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For the last few years, LinkedIn, the professional social networking company, has doled out increasingly large amounts of stock to pay its workers.

headline: Heng on North Korea’s Defectors
abstract: In April, thirteen employees of a North Korean restaurant abroad sought political asylum in South Korea.
lead_paragraph: In April, thirteen employees of a North Korean restaurant abroad sought political asylum in South Korea.

headline: Review: ‘Black Hole Blues’ Recounts the Quest to Find the Cosmic Kazoo
abstract: The astrophysicist Janna Levin investigates the politics and personal dynamics of the physicists involved in the journey to detect gravitational waves.
lead_paragraph: Just two months ago, scientists announced that they had heard, for the very first time, the sound of two black holes colliding in outer space.

headline: Yankees and Alex Rodriguez End Skids in Win Over Mariners
abstract: Rodriguez broke out of an 0-for-19 slump with a two-run homer for the Yankees, who ended a four-game skid with a sterling outing from Masahiro Tanaka.
lead_paragraph: If Manager Joe Girardi’s temperament is a weather vane for the Yankees’ fortunes, then his recent testiness — with a few dashes of sarcasm — may explain how the first two weeks of the season have unfolded.

headline: ‘Chocolat,’ a Biopic in France, Stirs a Discussion About Race
abstract: The film, directed by Roschdy Zem, stars Omar Sy in the title role as a former slave turned clown, and James Thierrée as the other half of a clown duo in Paris.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The clown known as Chocolat, a former Afro-Cuban slave, was a fixture of Belle Époque Paris. Toulouse Lautrec painted him — often in ugly caricature as a monkey — the Lumière Brothers filmed him and Jean Cocteau and Colette wrote about him. The first black performer to become a major popular hit in France and a key figure in its awakening as a multicultural nation, he died in poverty in 1917 and his memory faded.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of April 18
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Miami City Ballet, Dancing Balanchine, Raises the Bar in New York
abstract: Of all the companies to have visited the David H. Koch Theater in recent years, none feels so effortlessly right for New York as this troupe.
lead_paragraph: As Miami City Ballet — both heroic and sweet — went on dancing last week at the David H. Koch Theater, the extraordinary achievements of this company (founded 30 years ago) became newly clear. Of all the ballet troupes who have visited the Koch in recent years, none looks so truly and completely a company. None feels so effortlessly right for New York. None seems so satisfying a continuation of several trains of choreographic thought already known in this city. None gives us such warmth and energy.

headline: Review: ‘Knightlife’ Pokes Fun at Ballet With Silliness and Sophistication
abstract: The comic ballet from American Ballet Theater’s Studio Company at the Joyce Theater featured knights in plastic armor and sprightly maidens.
lead_paragraph: In dance, as in life, youth has its privileges: There are things you can get away with for only a limited time. An older group of dancers, for instance, probably couldn’t have pulled off Ethan Stiefel’s “Knightlife,” the comic ballet that opened a three-day run of American Ballet Theater’s Studio Company at the Joyce Theater on Friday.

headline: A Mahler Mini-Festival in New York
abstract: The San Francisco Symphony, the New York Philharmonic and the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra take on Mahler works in New York performances.
lead_paragraph: Mahler’s big salute to spring in “Das Lied von der Erde” (“The Song of the Earth”) is decidedly backhanded.

headline: Dungeons & Dragons: Satanic Panic
abstract: Dungeons & Dragons, introduced in 1974, attracted millions of players, along with accusations by some religious figures that the game fostered demon worship and a belief in witchcraft and magic.
lead_paragraph: Dungeons & Dragons, introduced in 1974, attracted millions of players, along with accusations by some religious figures that the game fostered demon worship and a belief in witchcraft and magic.

headline: When Dungeons & Dragons Set Off a ‘Moral Panic’
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Computer and Video Games']
abstract: Some religious figures cast the game, which was introduced in 1974, as corrupting enough to steer impressionable players toward suicide and murder.
lead_paragraph: Going back at least to the 1690s, when the elders of colonial Salem, Mass., executed 20 women and men for supposedly practicing witchcraft, there have been Americans who find the devil’s hand in all manner of human activity.

headline: Moolah
abstract: Janice Luttrell makes her New York Times Crossword debut.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — One of the nicest things about this job is the chance to welcome new constructors when their puzzles are published. It’s always fun to see a new byline, and another nice thing, if they submit additional puzzles, is that I get to watch them grow as constructors.

headline: After Long Silence, Indonesia Allows Talk of Anti-Communist Atrocities
abstract: The government has for the first time endorsed a public discussion of the purges that killed at least 500,000 in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — When Putu Oka Sukanta was awakened by knocking on his door late one night in October 1966, he says, he instinctively knew who was there.

headline: Civilian Casualties in Afghan War Are Unabated in 2016
abstract: The United Nations mission documented 600 civilian deaths and 1,343 wounded in the first three months, expected to be a bloody year.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — With nearly 2,000 civilians killed or wounded and more than 80,000 people displaced this year already, the Afghan conflict continues to affect lives in record numbers, the United Nations said on Sunday.

headline: Under English Garden, ‘Unparalleled’ Remains of Roman Villa
keywords: ['ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Roman Civilization', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Laying electric lines to a family’s barn in Wiltshire led to the discovery of artifacts from a lavish site that had barely been disturbed for more than a millennium.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The geraniums grew in an oblong stone vessel, and no one ever thought much about it. But when Luke Irwin, a rug designer in the county of Wiltshire, England, hired workmen to lay electric cables under his yard, so that his son could have light in a barn when the family played table tennis, they uncovered an intricate mosaic floor of red, blue and white tiles only 18 inches down.

headline: Nets Hand Reins to Kenny Atkinson, a Hawks Assistant
abstract: Atkinson, a native of Huntington, N.Y., was an assistant with the Knicks from 2008 to 2012. He has spent the last four seasons with Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: Working quickly to establish a new foundation, the Nets hired Kenny Atkinson, an assistant coach with the Atlanta Hawks, as their head coach on Sunday. Terms of the deal were not released.

headline: Spare a Swipe? New York City Eases Rules for a Subway Request
abstract: The urban version of hitchhiking — beseeching a swipe of a stranger’s MetroCard — no longer results in an arrest, but there’s still a fine.
lead_paragraph: It is New York’s own version of hitchhiking: asking for a swipe of a stranger’s MetroCard.

headline: Wall Street Veterans Bet on Low-Income Home Buyers
abstract: Goldman Sachs alumni are reselling foreclosed homes to people who didn’t qualify for traditional mortgages. Many of the transactions end in eviction.
lead_paragraph: As the head of Goldman Sachs’s mortgage department, Daniel Sparks helped make the bank more than a billion dollars betting against the market as housing prices began to crash in 2007.

headline: Brazilian Tennis Player’s Success Follows a Childhood of Obstacles
abstract: Teliana Pereira is the most successful female Brazilian player in decades, having overcome childhood poverty along the way.
lead_paragraph: When Gustavo Kuerten, the three-time French Open champion, refers to a “one-in-a-hundred-million” chance of making it in professional tennis, he is not referring to Novak Djokovic or Serena Williams, who have combined for 32 Grand Slam titles.

headline: Presidents and Kings
abstract: The leaders of the United States and Saudi Arabia have enjoyed close relations for more than 70 years.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of the United States and Saudi Arabia have enjoyed close relations for more than 70 years.

headline: New York Wineries Hope Palates Warm to Cold-Hardy Grape Varietals
abstract: Winemakers in the northern reaches of New York State are embracing specially developed varietals that can tolerate the region’s unforgiving winters.
lead_paragraph: EASTON, N.Y. — Gerry Barnhart named his new winery Victory View Vineyard because when he looks west from the top of a slope on his property, he can see the site where, in 1777, the Battles of Saratoga were fought.

headline: Deadly Attacks in Ethiopia Leave Victims Wondering Why
abstract: A series of raids from South Sudan killed an estimated 182 people. Survivors are asking: If the attacks were about cattle, why did so many people die?
lead_paragraph: GAMBELA, Ethiopia — In a bright green hospital room buzzing with flies, an older man’s eyes glazed over with pain. His hand was pressed to his collarbone, where blood seeped through a white bandage.

headline: Focus on Chief Justice as Supreme Court Hears Immigration Challenge
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Conservatives are worried that Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. may avoid a position on the divisive case and focus instead on the question of standing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. twice voted to save President Obama’s health care law, infuriating his usual allies on the right. Now, conservatives are nervous that the chief justice will disappoint them again in a challenge to another major Obama initiative, this one on immigration.

headline: Found Alive, Soldiers Are Told: You Owe Us for Burials
abstract: The families of two Afghan men experienced the trauma of their deaths, the joy of hearing they were alive, then the shock of a government demand that it get its money back.
lead_paragraph: BEHSUD, Afghanistan — The first time Noor ul-Haq died, his Afghan Army outpost was completely cut off by the Taliban on a bleak southern battleground. Hundreds of insurgent fighters swept in, and all that was left for the government to do was ship the corpses home.

headline: An Old Alliance Faces New Pressures as Obama Heads to Saudi Arabia
abstract: After close relations for more than 70 years, has President Obama ‘unfriended’ Saudi Arabia over issues such as Iran, Syria and oil? It’s complicated.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the last seven decades, photographs of American presidents side by side with the kings of Saudi Arabia have provided visual evidence of an enduring, strategic alliance between the United States and the oil-rich kingdom in the Middle East.

headline: Flyers Are Adamant That Soft Goal Won’t Spell Doom in Playoffs
abstract: Jason Chimera’s 101-foot second-period goal gave the heavily favored Capitals a 2-0 lead in a game they won to take a 2-0 series lead.
lead_paragraph: VOORHEES, N.J. — With arms crossed and a black baseball cap propped backward on his head, Philadelphia Flyers goaltender Steve Mason wearily took a few more questions Sunday about how he could have been beaten by a measly tip-in from, yes, 101 feet away.

headline: Prep Schools Wrestle With Sex Abuse Accusations Against Teachers
keywords: ['Private and Sectarian Schools', 'Education (K-12)', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Phillips Exeter Academy in New Hampshire fired two teachers over sexual misconduct. As more cases come to light, schools are changing how they handle abuse.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Phillips Exeter Academy, an elite New Hampshire boarding school whose prominent graduates include Daniel Webster and Mark Zuckerberg, disclosed last month that it had forced out a popular teacher in 2011 because of sexual misconduct in the 1970s and ’80s.

headline: For Yankees, Pursuit of Titles Requires Tough Decisions
abstract: The histories of franchises like the Yankees, suggest that titles are inevitable and come in cycles, but the Yankees’ cycles are particularly long.
lead_paragraph: I still have the baseball that Bob Watson, then the Yankees’ general manager, signed for me in October 1996 after the Yankees had defeated the Atlanta Braves to win the World Series, ending an 18-year World Series drought.

headline: New York Elections to Replace Silver and Skelos Offer Intrigue and Incivility
abstract: A great-nephew of Mel Brooks is taking on a personal-injury lawyer on Long Island, while a third-party candidate wages a well-organized challenge in solidly blue Lower Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The voice on the phone had a reminder for the voters of the South Shore.

headline: Obama Heads to Europe, Its Stability and His Priorities in Question
abstract: The president plans to deliver a message of solidarity as political events shake Britain and Germany, but his past statements could complicate his efforts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For much of his time in the White House, President Obama has labored to pull the United States out of the Middle East so he could pivot to more promising horizons in Asia. Now, as he winds down his presidency, it is Europe, another place where Americans have deep ties and a long history, that is exerting an unwelcome pull.

headline: Donald Trump Assails ‘Rigged’ Delegate System, Saying He Chooses Not to Exploit It
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
