headline: Immigrants, the Poor and Minorities Gain Sharply Under Affordable Care Act
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Minorities']
abstract: Hispanics — a demographic coveted by both political parties in this election year — accounted for nearly a third of the increase in adults with insurance, according to a New York Times analysis.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The first full year of the Affordable Care Act brought historic increases in coverage for low-wage workers and others who have long been left out of the health care system, a New York Times analysis has found. Immigrants of all backgrounds — including more than a million legal residents who are not citizens — had the sharpest rise in coverage rates.

headline: Quake’s Aftershocks Come to Ecuadoreans in Queens
abstract: As news of the 7.8-magnitude earthquake reached Queens, many locals were scrambling to get in touch with relatives in the South American country.
lead_paragraph: When news of the worst earthquake to strike Ecuador in four decades reached Corona, Queens, on Saturday night, the house of Assemblyman Francisco P. Moya there turned into a de facto Ecuadorean embassy.

headline: Apple to Testify Again, and VW Due Date Nears
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Apple and the F.B.I. will defend their positions on encryption. And Volkswagen faces a Thursday deadline to present its plan to fix 600,000 diesel cars in the United States.
lead_paragraph: This is what to expect from the week ahead:

headline: Even Before He Hit the Track, American Pharoah Offered a Glimpse of Magic
keywords: ['Horse Racing', 'American Pharoah (Race Horse)', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers']
abstract: When Pharoah arrived at the McKathan brothers’ farm, neither had seen a horse so talented. “It was speed!” Kevin McKathan said. “Speed! Speed! Speed!”
lead_paragraph: The McKathan brothers knew their horses. They might as well have been foaled in a stall themselves, seeing as how they spent the better part of their lives with runners in their backyards. Their father, Luke, trained horses at the long-gone Seminole Downs in Central Florida before deciding to chase bigger purses at racetracks from Florida to California. He did all right on the grits-and-hard-toast tracks of West Virginia and later at Tampa Bay Downs.

headline: Sperm Donor’s Profile Hid Mental Illness and Crime, Lawsuits Say
abstract: Donor 9623 was said to have a high I.Q. and other appealing traits. But families who used his sperm discovered he had schizophrenia and a criminal record.
lead_paragraph: When Angela Collins and her partner wanted to have a child, they reached out to a sperm bank in Georgia to look for potential donors. They thought they had found the perfect match in Donor 9623, described as a man with an I.Q. of 160 who was healthy and working toward his Ph.D.

headline: Media Websites Battle Faltering Ad Revenue and Traffic
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Social Media', 'Mobile Applications', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising']
abstract: Changes in technology like ad blocking, and the dominance of platforms like Facebook leave many publishers unsure of how they will make money.
lead_paragraph: The business of online news has never been forgiving. But in recent weeks, what had been a simmering worry among publishers has turned into borderline panic.

headline: For News Outlets Squeezed From the Middle, It’s Bend or Bust
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Newspapers']
abstract: Traditional media companies face the increasingly daunting task of hooking already-inundated audiences, but they also have more tools than ever to lure them.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, a couple of inventive young go-getters at BuzzFeed tied enough rubber bands around the center of a watermelon to make it explode. Nearly a million people watched the giant berry burst on Facebook Live. It racked up more than 10 million views in the days that followed.

headline: Discord Grows Among the Parties Over Greek Debt Talks
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: Greece may be pushed to the edge of bankruptcy again if its government, Europe and the International Monetary Fund cannot reach a compromise on its debt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Executives of the International Monetary Fund mutter darkly about Greeks tapping their phones in Athens. Greek government officials accuse the fund of torpedoing their economy via tough austerity measures.

headline: Seventh Generation Taps Maya Rudolph for Its Biggest Campaign Yet
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Cleansers, Detergents and Soaps', 'Sustainable Living', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Labeling and Labels (Product)']
abstract: This month, the company, which has focused on earth-friendly products for decades, began a $15 million campaign to attract new customers and reclaim those who may have strayed.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Seventh Generation began selling environmentally sustainable products almost three decades ago, it was dedicated to the relatively few consumers who were interested in recycled toilet paper and paper towels. These days, green is mainstream, and companies like Walmart and Clorox promote their natural lines.

headline: ‘Vinyl’ Season 1 Finale: As Confused as Ever
abstract: The HBO drama’s fundamental flaw is the amount of time it devotes to its Mafia subplot.
lead_paragraph: “Vinyl” ends its first season the same way it began: with dialogue name-checking Lester Bangs, a violent death and a 1973 New York Dolls concert. The final episode splits its time between two plots. In one, the Nasty Bits finally get their showcase gig opening for the Dolls. In the other, Richie gets further entangled with the mob boss Corrado Galasso — which proves to be more hazardous than the time an entire building collapsed on him.

headline: Amazon Challenges Netflix by Opening Prime to Monthly Subscribers
abstract: One new plan offers video streaming only, while another offers full Prime benefits. Both cost more than annual subscribers pay.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon is introducing new options to subscribe to its Prime membership service on a monthly basis, a change that could make the company’s video service a tougher competitor to Netflix.

headline: Connecticut Chooses to Cut Jobs Over Increased Taxes in Budget Crisis
keywords: ['Government Employees', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Income Tax', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Starting with a wave of layoffs last Monday, and despite union advertising, Gov. Dannel P. Malloy has focused on trimming overhead as taxable personal income has declined.
lead_paragraph: Like some other states, Connecticut is facing a budget shortfall. And in part because of its shrinking finance sector and dependence on personal income taxes for revenue, state lawmakers, a majority of whom are Democrats, are finding themselves in a fiscal pickle.

headline: ‘Girls’ Finale: Is It Just Us, or Did the Show Get Better?
abstract: It was a season of strong writing, frayed friendships and a flash of — whatever. Jenna Wortham, Amanda Hess and Margaret Lyons recap the series and discuss where “Girls” goes from here.
lead_paragraph: HBO aired the final two episodes of the fifth season of “Girls” on Sunday, which found Hannah (Lena Dunham) bonding with her college classmate and frenemy Tally (Jenny Slate), Marnie (Allison Williams) trying to understand her romantic impulses toward Ray (Alex Karpovsky), Shoshanna (Zosia Mamet) embracing her role as a marketer, and Jessa (Jemima Kirke) and Adam (Adam Driver) trying to make sense of their budding relationship. Amanda Hess, a staff writer, Margaret Lyons, the TV critic for Watching (the Times newsletter), and Jenna Wortham, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine, discuss the entire season, and where the show might be headed in its sixth and final season.

headline: Defenseman’s Overtime Goal Gives Islanders Edge in Series
abstract: Thomas Hickey scored at 12 minutes 31 seconds of overtime to lift the Islanders to a rousing victory.
lead_paragraph: There was another first at Barclays Center on Sunday night: an N.H.L. playoff game.

headline: In London, ‘Undressed’ Unveils the History of Underwear
abstract: The Victoria and Albert Museum exhibition ranges from whalebone stays to modern clothes with lingerie styling.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Enter any clothing store these days and you are likely to find yourself faced with the G.L.R.: the Great Lingerie Resurgence. White paneled silk slips trimmed with whispers of black lace at Céline, scallop-edged organza shorts and chemise tops at Dior and a seductive mishmash of boudoir and boardroom in the form of peek-a-boo bralets and power suiting at Givenchy and Balenciaga — we are in an underwear-as-outerwear moment.

headline: Putting a Humane, Dignified Face on Refugees
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Photography', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']

lead_paragraph: Refugee, migrant, asylum seeker: The words evoke images of uprooted people constantly on the move. “Just do a Google search for ‘refugee,’ ” says Omar Victor Diop, a photographer from Dakar. “There are far more pictures of refugees on boats or trains or who jump a fence.”

The findings could help local and state governments figure out what they can do, or do better, to help people live longer and healthier lives.

lead_paragraph: THE legal controversy surrounding the Obama administration’s immigration enforcement policies will soon come to a head when the Supreme Court justices hear the case United States v. Texas on Monday. Texas claims that the president’s executive decisions lack legal sanction by Congress and have injured the state.

lead_paragraph: When Verizon workers went on strike last week, they were mainly protesting efforts to outsource work to low-wage, non-union contractors. But they were also angry about the company’s unwillingness to invest in its own business. In particular, Verizon has shown a remarkable lack of interest in expanding its Fios high-speed Internet network, despite strong demand.

abstract: After reading so many hateful messages I began to feel sick, literally.

lead_paragraph: After the withering backlash against North Carolina for passing a discriminatory law against gay and transgender people last month, it would stand to reason that lawmakers and governors in other states would think twice before peddling bills that dictate which restrooms transgender people can use.

headline: What Should We Expect From the Supreme Court’s Showdown Over Immigration?
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Law and Legislation', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)']
abstract: Emily Bazelon and Eric Posner discuss the possible decisions, and their consequences, in United States v. Texas.
lead_paragraph: This morning, the United States Supreme Court will hear arguments in United States v. Texas, a challenge to President Obama’s attempts to grand relief from mass deportation to undocumented immigrants. Emily Bazelon, a staff writer for the magazine, and Eric Posner, a professor at the University of Chicago Law School, have been exchanging emails about what’s at stake in the case and how the court might approach its decision.

headline: Lyrid Meteor Shower Is Spectacular, Albeit Obscured
abstract: The annual celestial light show, a display of comet debris from several centuries ago, is not as clear as usual because of the waxing of the moon.
lead_paragraph: More than 2,700 years ago, Chinese astronomers observed a night in which “stars fell like rain.” Today, we call this celestial display the Lyrid meteor shower. The annual light show began Saturday, peaks this Friday, and ends April 25.

headline: China’s Vaccine Scandal Threatens Public Faith in Immunizations
abstract: The news that millions of faulty vaccines were given to children has reignited a widespread, often visceral distrust of China’s medical system.
lead_paragraph: HEZE, China — First the news rippled across China that millions of compromised vaccines had been given to children around the country. Then came grim rumors and angry complaints from parents that the government had kept them in the dark about the risks since last year.

headline: Obama Immigration Plan Seems to Divide Supreme Court
abstract: During an extended argument, the justices occasionally paused to acknowledge realities outside the courtroom in connection with the president’s plan to shield millions from deportation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday seemed sharply divided during an extended argument over a challenge to President Obama’s plan that would shield millions of undocumented immigrants from deportation and allow them to work in the country legally.

headline: Avoiding the Dreaded Middle Seat May Now Cost You
abstract: As planes fly a record capacity and try to squeeze in more passengers, it is becoming more difficult and costly to secure an aisle or window seat.
lead_paragraph: As flying goes, the only thing more uncomfortable than sitting next to a couple having a spat on an airplane, Maury Rogoff learned, is sitting between that couple — especially when one partner prefers bare feet.

headline: Among Travelers and Commuters, the Homeless Stop In and Stay
abstract: People live for years in New York City’s train, bus and airport hubs, creating an ad hoc shelter system that has endured for decades.
lead_paragraph: Wilson Silva said he knew the homeless situation at Pennsylvania Station had grown “out of hand” when he found a man in raggedy clothing sleeping on a couch inside the shop he manages, Drago Shoe Repair, in the rail terminal’s upper level.

headline: Our Woman in New York: Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders on Friendly Turf
abstract: New York votes Tuesday in the raucous presidential race. Here’s what our veteran reporter is watching.
lead_paragraph: Maggie Haberman, a New York Times political correspondent, has devoted her journalistic career to two irresistible subjects: politics and New York City. At age 7, her first byline appeared in The Daily News; it has now been published in all three New York dailies.

headline: Student Question | Should We Be Privy to the Lives of Celebrities’ Children?
abstract: Being born to famous parents: is it a dream, a burden or something else?
lead_paragraph: Blue Ivy, North West, Max Zuckerberg — the children of celebrities are often in the public eye, to the delight of their parents’ fans.

headline: Debunking the Viper’s Strike
abstract: Rattlesnakes are part of the venomous viper family, thought to have the fastest strikes of any snakes. That is, until researchers decided to run a few experiments.
lead_paragraph: Rattlesnakes are part of the venomous viper family, thought to have the fastest strikes of any snakes. That is, until researchers decided to run a few experiments.

headline: Vipers Aren’t the Only Kings of the Quick Strike
abstract: Vipers have been thought to strike faster than other snakes. But new research shows that the rat snake is just as fast.
lead_paragraph: Vipers were thought to have the fastest strike of all snakes until researchers at the University of Louisiana at Lafayette decided to test two different kinds of vipers along with the nonvenomous rat snake.

headline: ‘The Universe in Your Hand’ and ‘Seven Brief Lessons on Physics’
abstract: Two new books about physics address the science’s competing “rule books” for reality.
lead_paragraph: Have you heard the joke about the elderly rabbi who tries to settle a bitter dispute between two men? The rabbi listens to one man’s case and pronounces him right. Then he hears the second man’s case, and concludes the second man is right. At this point his eavesdropping wife steps in and points out that both men can’t possibly be right. To which the ­rabbi replies, “And you are right as well!”

headline: School Athletes Often Lack Adequate Protection
abstract: There are no nationwide guidelines to protect high school athletes from crippling or fatal injuries.
lead_paragraph: With all the attention on national rules to prevent and properly treat injuries to professional and college athletes, it may surprise you to learn that there are no nationwide guidelines to protect high school athletes from crippling or fatal injuries.

abstract: The actress, who is married to Johnny Depp, pleaded guilty to providing false information on her incoming passenger card after she and the dogs landed on the Gold Coast last year.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The actress Amber Heard avoided jail time after a court appearance on Monday over allegations that she had illegally brought two dogs into Australia last year, violating the country’s quarantine laws, while visiting her husband, the actor Johnny Depp.

abstract: Monday: Election Day preparation, exceptional weather and presidential homes.

headline: Wine From the Edna Valley With a Label From Jacques Pépin
abstract: Proceeds go to a nonprofit that wants to make healthful, affordable food available in poor neighborhoods.
lead_paragraph: Wholesome Wave, a nonprofit organization founded by the chef Michel Nischan to make healthful, affordable food available to underserved neighborhoods, is selling wine as a fund-raiser. Mr. Nischan had his friend the chef Jacques Pépin paint the label for the wine, which is being produced by One Hope, a winery in the Edna Valley of California. The 2012 pinot noir with scents of blueberry and lilac is complex and robust. It is making its debut at a benefit for the organization honoring Mr. Pépin on Wednesday in New York: One Hope 2012 Edna Valley Reserve Pinot Noir, $75, onehopewine.com/shop/2012-jacques-pepin.

headline: La Caravelle to Be Resurrected, in a Fashion
abstract: Alumni chefs will recreate the haute-cuisine classic’s dishes.
lead_paragraph: La Caravelle, one of New York’s classic haute-cuisine restaurants, closed in 2004. But for two days in May it will live again, as Rita and André Jammet, below, who owned it for almost half of its 44-year history, recreate the dining experience (though not quite the setting and maybe not the boldface clientele) at Chefs Club by Food & Wine. The event was suggested by Dana Cowin, the former editor in chief of Food & Wine magazine, who is now the creative director of Chefs Club. The three-course menu, prepared by the Caravelle alumni Tadashi Ono, Cyril Renaud and Laurent Richard, along with Chefs Club chefs, will include La Caravelle’s crab salad, quenelles de brochet, chicken in Champagne cream sauce and crème brûlée with raspberries: May 10 and 11; $110, not including beverages, tax or tip; La Caravelle at Chefs Club by Food & Wine, 275 Mulberry Street (Houston Street), 212-941-1100, chefsclub.com, prepaid reservations from chefsclubnyc.tocktix.com.

headline: The Dogs That Don't Belong to Anyone
abstract: We asked Times readers on many continents – both English and Spanish speakers – to share some of their experiences with street dogs, village dogs and other dogs sometimes called strays.
lead_paragraph: We asked Times readers on many continents – both English and Spanish speakers – to share some of their experiences with street dogs, village dogs and other dogs sometimes called strays.

headline: The World Is Full of Dogs Without Collars
keywords: ['Dogs', 'Books and Literature', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Breeding of Animals', 'Pets', 'Wolves']
abstract: Three-quarters of the billion dogs on the planet are not pets. A new book argues that they are more than strays and may tell us much about the nature of dogs.
lead_paragraph: MONTAGUE, Mass. — Think of all the dogs out there: labradors and poodles and labradoodles; huskies and westies and dogues de Bordeaux; pit bulls and spaniels and lovable mutts that go to doggy day care.

headline: Where Have All the Ear Infections Gone?
abstract: Improved preventive measures, healthier environments for young babies and more cautious use of antibiotics add up to a pediatric success story.
lead_paragraph: One way I knew my pediatrician was a good doctor was that he resolutely refused to diagnose an ear infection in my youngest child.

headline: An Education in Basque Cuisine
abstract: “The Basque Book” has compelling recipes, like for rice and cockles, or lamb meatballs and peas.
lead_paragraph: I have to love a cookbook that starts with recipes for mayonnaise. And Alexandra Raij and her husband, Eder Montero, go well beyond mayonnaise to explain Basque cuisine. (He is the Basque side of the equation.) Txangurro, the deviled crab meat gratin that is served everywhere in the region but is often disappointing, was a winner here, despite the demanding preparation of a couple of ingredients. (You can work around them.) There was nothing demanding, though, about the excellent rice studded with cockles, the butterflied trout slipcovered in ham and given a splash of garlic and parsley oil, and the springtime lamb meatballs tucked among peas. For dessert, the notion of marinating fresh pineapple in sherry is a keeper: “The Basque Book” Alexandra Raij with Eder Montero and Rebecca Flint Marx (Ten Speed Press, $29.99).

headline: New York Restaurateurs in the Big Easy
abstract: Kenton, like Maysville in the Flatiron district, has a bourbon focus.
lead_paragraph: A little piece of New York is thriving in New Orleans. Mani Dawes, below right, an owner of Tía Pol in Chelsea, and her husband, Sean Josephs, below left, who owns Maysville in the Flatiron district, have relocated their family to the Big Easy. Easier indeed: Ms. Dawes’s mother is there to help with babysitting. In a neighborhood west of the Garden District (I thought it was somewhat remote, but locals say not) they have opened a handsome sibling for Maysville, also with a bourbon focus and named for the founder of Maysville, Ky., a port town on the Ohio River. Burnished wood, marble and cast-iron arches that could evoke New York as much as New Orleans set the stage for a menu of oysters (raw, grilled, fried and served on vintage oyster plates), red snapper tartare, smoked trout and grilled pork: Kenton’s, 5757 Magazine Street, New Orleans, 504-891-1177, kentonsrestaurant.com.

headline: Chicky’s, a Specialty Grocery in Bedford-Stuyvesant
abstract: Cheese from Murray’s, meat from DeBragga and food prepared by the chef down the block.
lead_paragraph: It’s no surprise that organic produce, artisanal cheeses and grass-fed meats are infiltrating the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Bedford-Stuyvesant and Bushwick. The latest is Chicky’s, established by Tara Oxley, who owns the restaurant Eugene & Company just down the block. Products and ingredients come from Murray’s Cheese, DeBragga meats and Greenpoint Fish & Lobster Company. Prepared food to take home is made by Jeff Shields, the chef at Eugene & Company: Chicky’s, 406 Tompkins Avenue (Hancock Street), Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, 718-975-7646.

headline: Noshing at the Columbus Circle Subway Station
abstract: Take some dumplings or doughnuts along for the ride.
lead_paragraph: More than 90,000 commuters a day pass through the Columbus Circle subway station. As of April 19, those who have a few moments to linger, or are even just looking for lunch, can buy dumplings, minidoughnuts, vegan cookies, grilled cheese, a bottle of wine or a Bolivian turnover like the salteña made just for this location. More than 30 shops and kiosks, about half of them offering something to eat or drink, fill the 325-foot-long concourse on the station’s mezzanine level just south of the turnstiles. Above right, food from Ellary’s Greens. Susan Fine, the developer, made a point to seek out local entrepreneurs. “A lot of them are taking a big risk,” she said. Greyston, the social service organization that makes baked goods in Yonkers, will have its first store in the mall: TurnStyle, Columbus Circle station, turn-style.com.

headline: Argentine Team’s Frequent-Flier Miles Can’t Buy It Wins
abstract: Los Jaguares, the only team in Super Rugby based in the Western Hemisphere, will have flown more than 35,000 miles before their second bye in Week 11.
lead_paragraph: WELLINGTON, New Zealand — Los Jaguares Coach Raúl Pérez is quickly finding out about the need to rest and rotate players as his Argentine team circles the globe in its first Super Rugby season.

headline: Union Seeks Higher Tariffs on U.S. Imports of Raw Aluminum
abstract: Much of the United States aluminum smelting industry will soon be idled or shut down, according to the United Steelworkers union’s legal petition.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — An American labor union is pushing the United States to impose broad, steep tariffs on aluminum imports using a little-used but wide-ranging trade law that has riled the country’s trading partners in the past.

abstract: We asked readers to show us why parrots are more than just a pretty bird. Out of hundreds of submissions, these are some of our favorites.

headline: Parrots: The Highlight Reel
abstract: Hundreds of readers submitted charming videos of their avian companions. The Times wasn’t always so beguiled by parrots as we are now.
lead_paragraph: In March, Natalie Angier reported some of the latest findings about parrots, nature’s most colorful birds in more ways than one. Along with the article, we asked readers to submit videos of their feathered friends showing what makes them unique.

headline: Campaigns Are Long, Expensive and Chaotic. Maybe That’s a Good Thing.
abstract: If you were on the search committee to hire a C.E.O., you would want the hardest simulation you could get.
lead_paragraph: The election of a president of the United States isn’t just democracy in circuslike action. It also may be, at its core, the most elaborate and expensive recruitment and hiring process that mankind has ever created.

headline: Candidates Make Their Final New York Appeals
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont is holding an evening rally in Hunters Point, Queens, while Hillary Clinton will address supporters in Midtown Manhattan. The Republicans are campaigning in farther-flung locales, with Donald J. Trump in Buffalo and Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio visiting Syracuse and Schenectady.

headline: Bernie’s Israel Heresy
abstract: Sanders sets down an important marker for more open American debate of Israeli policies by expressing the consensus view in much of the world.
lead_paragraph: In New York, no less, days before a primary, a candidate for the Democratic Party presidential nomination declares that Israel used “disproportionate” force in Gaza in 2014, that “we are going to have to treat the Palestinian people with respect and dignity,” that the United States has to play “an evenhanded role” and that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel “is not right all the time.”

keywords: ['Medical Devices', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']

headline: Indonesia Rules Out Criminal Inquiry of Anti-Communist Purges
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Apologies']
abstract: An official said that the government would, over time, try to answer how hundreds of thousands were killed in state-sponsored violence from 1965 to 1966.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Indonesia’s security minister said on Monday at a symposium devoted to the mass atrocities committed half a century ago during anti-Communist purges in the country that the government had ruled out a criminal investigation of the period but would consider an unprecedented “expression of regret” to victims and their families.

headline: Chinese Parents Outraged After Illnesses at School Are Tied to Pollution
abstract: State TV said that nearly 500 students in eastern China had developed illnesses, a few as serious as leukemia, and that a nearby field had toxins far above limits.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Chinese families were in an uproar on Monday after a report in the state news media revealed that nearly 500 students at a school in eastern China had developed illnesses, a few as severe as leukemia, possibly because of pollution at a nearby field.

headline: 1941: St. Paul’s Is Bombed
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: St. Paul’s suffers a direct bomb hit in 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — St. Paul’s Cathedral, ‘‘mother church of the British Empire,’’ suffered a direct bomb hit on the north transept in a recent German air raid, it was revealed today [April 18] by officials who removed a ban on publication of news of the damage. The bomb destroyed the saucer dome of the transept, dropped into the inner portico and tore tons of masonry out of the floor, leaving a gaping hole to the crypt. Almost every pane of glass, some dating from the time of Sir Christopher Wren, St. Paul’s designer, was blown out. — New York Herald Tribune, April 19, 1941

headline: Shareholder Value as the Culprit
abstract: Business schools need accept their responsibility for promoting the primacy of shareholder value.

abstract: An 18-year-old in Ohio, who told police she filmed the sexual assault to gather evidence, faces charges as severe as those against the assailant.
lead_paragraph: When an Ohio teenager witnessed her 17-year-old friend being raped, according to officials, she not only failed to help the victim, she pointed her phone and streamed a live video of it on the Periscope app.

lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — Malaysia’s billion-dollar political scandal claimed another casualty on Monday when the prominent banker Nazir Razak announced that he would temporarily step aside while his bank examined his handling of nearly $7 million he received from his brother, Prime Minister Najib Razak.

headline: When Lies Are Allowed in a Business Deal
abstract: Appeals courts have ruled that it is not unusual for parties to conceal their true goals. In other words, no one tells the truth when negotiating a deal.
lead_paragraph: The French philosopher René Descartes wrote that “all deception or fraud involves some imperfection.” How much imperfection is required to be convicted of the federal crimes of mail and wire fraud has been clarified, at least a little bit, by recent appeals court decisions recognizing that some lying is acceptable, and even expected, in the business world.

headline: Challenge to Google Books Is Declined by Supreme Court
abstract: The project has been opposed by authors who argue that scanning millions of books and putting them in a database amounts to copyright infringement.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday refused to revive a challenge to Google’s digital library of millions of books, turning down an appeal from authors who said the project amounted to copyright infringement on a mass scale.

headline: ‘Fear the Walking Dead’ Season 2, Episode 2: The World Said Enough
abstract: The best laid plans often result in someone’s brains getting eaten.
lead_paragraph: Some people, after seeing “Jaws,” never swam in the ocean again. Some, after seeing enough depictions of the zombie apocalypse, got serious about their “What If?” plan. Emergency kits with water rations went into both cars and under beds. Families were emailed about disaster plans.

lead_paragraph: After one game was in the books in each of the N.B.A. first-round playoff series, there were few surprises. Seven of the eight home teams won, many by comfortable margins.

abstract: As the HBO series starts its sixth season, it enters unexplored territory, moving past the source material of George R.R. Martin’s fantasy novels.

headline: China Cracking Down on Children on Reality TV
abstract: In new guidelines issued by the State Administration for Press, Publication, Radio, Film and Television, children — especially children of celebrities — have been banned from participating in reality TV shows.
lead_paragraph: Children can be cute, giggly and prone to tantrums. But according to China’s top broadcast regulator, what they can no longer be is featured on Chinese reality television.

headline: 1966: Moscow-Paris Stowaway Dies
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The body of a stowaway is found in the landing-gear well of a plane from Moscow in 1966.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The body of a stowaway was found today [April 18] in the landing-gear well of a plane arriving from Moscow. The man, about 24, had apparently died of exposure. The finding touched off speculation that the man was a political refugee who had sneaked aboard in Moscow.

headline: The Most Important Primary Is ... Wait, Indiana?
abstract: It sounds strange, but Donald Trump’s quest to secure a majority of G.O.P. delegates may hinge on the Indiana primary.
lead_paragraph: Join us for New York primary live updates.

headline: Tribeca Interview: Viola Davis and Catalina Sandino Moreno
abstract: The actresses speak out about stereotypical roles, fulfilling ones (like their parts in the film “Custody”) and fan reaction to “Suicide Squad.”
lead_paragraph: In “Custody,” which had its premiere Sunday at the Tribeca Film Festival, the children of a young Colombian-American mother (Catalina Sandino Moreno) are put into protective custody after one child arrives at school with cuts and bruises. Viola Davis plays the judge who hears the case in family court. But the film, written and directed by James Lapine (the stage veteran whose credits include “Sunday in the Park With George”), doesn’t leave the drama in the courtroom. It also explores the home lives of both the mother and the judge, telling their stories from complex perspectives.

headline: Britons Will Be Poorer if They Leave E.U., Government Asserts
abstract: Under one situation, the annual economic output would be $6,100, lower per household if Britain left than if it stayed in the bloc, an estimate critics quickly disputed.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British government outlined the central argument on Monday it hopes will persuade voters to stay in the European Union, publishing a detailed economic analysis finding that Britons will be poorer if they quit.

headline: Appeals Court Affirms Landmark N.F.L. Concussion Settlement
abstract: The judges acknowledged criticisms of the deal, originally struck in 2013, but found it to be for the greater good of all retired N.F.L. players.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Nearly three years ago, the N.F.L. and lawyers for thousands of retired football players agreed on a deal to compensate all former players who had neurological diseases linked to repeated hits to the head, helping the league to move on from one of the most contentious issues facing the nation’s most popular sport.

headline: Bus Bombing in Jerusalem Wounds 21
abstract: The bombing on Monday afternoon started a fire that spread quickly from one bus to another. Two of the wounded were listed in serious condition, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A bomb exploded on a bus in Jerusalem on Monday, wounding about 21 people and feeding a sense of vulnerability among many Israelis after months of simmering violence.

headline: Court of Appeals Opinion

headline: Jo Boaler: Mathematical Mindsets
abstract: Rote memorization is said to be a terrible way to learn math — but what’s the alternative? Learn how the best schools teach math with Jo Boaler’s “Mathematical Mindsets,” and try an open-ended math problem.
lead_paragraph: The thing I love about Numberplay — the bit that really defines it — is that it’s not about correct answers. Instead, it’s about insight and exploration. During our weeklong discussion, did we discover something new — maybe a nice visual or analogy? Did we come up with a nice twist on the problem — something a bit different (and more interesting) than the original challenge? And did we bring out the best in each other?

headline: A Parisian Editor’s Best Natural Beauty Advice for Spring
abstract: Clémence von Mueffling, of Beauty and Well Being, on the virtues of lymphatic massage, clean eating and natural deodorant.
lead_paragraph: Clémence von Mueffling, 37, is a third generation beauty editor. Born in Paris, she was introduced to body creams, toners and fragrances at an early age — both her mother and grandmother served as beauty editors at Vogue Paris from the late ‘50s through the early ‘90s. “I remember them telling me that there was a code among the women who worked there — they were all incredibly elegant and polished,” says von Mueffling. Still, she didn’t immediately pursue the same career path: Instead she spent nearly five years on the marketing and communications side at brands like Clarins and Dior before moving to New York in 2007 and assuming the beauty editor role at Casas & Gente, an interiors and lifestyle magazine that’s since folded. But her six-year stint there sparked the idea to start a magazine-like website, Beauty and Well Being, which von Mueffling launched in 2014.

headline: Surprise Surge Completes Ethiopians’ Boston Marathon Sweep

headline: Bernie Sanders Gets the Celebrity Treatment in Midtown Manhattan
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders walked about 14 Midtown blocks, shaking hands, hugging people and waving as several cars honked horns. Many people he encountered froze with their mouths hanging open or locked in a smile, a day before voting takes place in the New York primary.
lead_paragraph: In a city packed with celebrities, Senator Bernie Sanders strutted around Manhattan on Monday causing some chaos as screaming fans, selfie-snapping supporters and surprised workers mobbed him.

headline: Donald Trump, Ted Cruz and the Stakes on the Republican Side
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Readers discuss Ted Cruz’s opposition to same-sex marriage and Donald Trump’s use of “coded language” to couch racist or sexist ideas.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Hope for Reversing Type 2 Diabetes
abstract: New research has raised the tantalizing possibility that the condition can be remedied by changes in diet.
lead_paragraph: Many experts believe Type 2 diabetes is an incurable disease that gets worse with time. But new research raises the tantalizing possibility that drastic changes in diet may reverse the disease in some people.

headline: The Best Sellers: Filed Under Sports
abstract: The best-selling sports books in March 2016, according to the New York Times best-seller list.
lead_paragraph: The best-selling sports books in March 2016, according to the New York Times best-seller list.

headline: In Towering Redwoods, an Abundance of Tiny, Unseen Life
abstract: Conducting a top-to-bottom inventory, researchers have found hundreds of species coexisting with their massive hosts.
lead_paragraph: More people are likely to have reached the summit of Mount Everest than have been to the top of an old-growth redwood tree, which helps explain why we know little about the biodiversity these giants harbor.

headline: Alexis Rockman Bridges the Gulf Between Art and Science
abstract: The New York artist who has made a career of portraying scientific themes discusses his work.
lead_paragraph: In 1959, the British writer C.P. Snow complained that scientists and artists lived in “two cultures” and that the gulf between them was one of “mutual incomprehension.”

headline: What You Should Watch This Week: ‘The Night Manager’ and ‘Better Call Saul’
abstract: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next several days.
lead_paragraph: From the Watching team, expert TV and movie recommendations for the next several days.

headline: Having a Mentor Is So Important: On Brett Ratner’s Instagram
abstract: The director’s Instagram, a love letter to old-school Hollywood masculinity, is almost beautiful in its guilelessness.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Social Capital, a series devoted to analyzing the social-media presences of celebrities.

headline: Europe Tried to Rein In Google. It Backfired.
abstract: Despite mining people’s data to earn billions of dollars, the search giant has been given the power to police some of the region’s tough privacy rules.
lead_paragraph: Google is a top target for European regulators and privacy watchdogs, who openly fear and distrust its dominance. The American tech giant’s search engine alone gobbles up roughly 90 percent of the European market.

headline: Man Arrested on Charges of Improperly Obtaining Handgun Licenses
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Firearms', 'Campaign Finance', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: The arrest of the man, a member of a volunteer security force, is the first to materialize from an inquiry into police corruption and Mayor Bill de Blasio’s campaign fund-raising.
lead_paragraph: A member of a volunteer security force in Borough Park, Brooklyn, was charged on Monday with offering bribes to New York Police Department officials to obtain handgun permits — the first arrest directly linked to the widening  federal investigation into police corruption and Mayor Bill de Blasio’s fund-raising efforts.

headline: Burundi Is Torturing Prisoners in Crackdown on Dissent, United Nations Says
abstract: Prisoners had been beaten or burned so severely by the security services that they could not walk unaided, agency’s human rights commissioner said.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Burundi’s security services are torturing and illegally detaining increasing numbers of people, the United Nations said on Monday, reinforcing international alarm over the government’s ferocious crackdown on political opponents.

headline: The Lumineers’ ‘Cleopatra’ Debuts at No. 1, No ‘Ho Hey’ Required
abstract: The folk band from Denver scores a big Billboard debut, proving the success of its breakout single wasn’t a one-off.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, the Lumineers, an earnest indie-folk band from Denver, scored a left-field pop hit with the song “Ho Hey,” which went to No. 3 with help from its placement on TV shows and commercials.

headline: 2 Captured Russian Men Sentenced to Prison in Ukraine
abstract: The Russians, captured on a battlefield last year, had been accused of fighting in the separatist war in southeast Ukraine as active-duty Russian soldiers — a claim Moscow denies.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Ukrainian court sentenced two Russian men to 14 years in prison on Monday for fighting against Ukraine as active-duty soldiers in the Russian military, a central issue in the separatist war in southeast Ukraine.

headline: Argentina Re-Enters International Bond Markets
abstract: The country was receiving offers for its sale of $10 billion to $15 billion of bonds, most of which will go to paying off creditors.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina returned to global bond markets on Monday after a 15-year hiatus, unveiling the biggest sovereign issuance by an emerging-market nation in two decades as the government ends a prolonged feud with hedge funds in New York.

headline: In IVF, Questions About ‘Mosaic’ Embryos
keywords: ['In Vitro Fertilization', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Birth Defects', 'Genetics and Heredity']
abstract: New technology more accurately reveals embryos with both normal and abnormal cells, raising tough questions for would-be parents.
lead_paragraph: The couple wanted a baby boy, but the male embryo they had chosen — the only one available after an expensive round of in vitro fertilization — received a troubling test result.

headline: Do Honeybees Feel? Scientists Are Entertaining the Idea
abstract: An Australian scientist and a philosopher propose that the structure of insect brains suggests they have the capacity for basic awareness.
lead_paragraph: Bees find nectar and tell their hive-mates; flies evade the swatter; and cockroaches seem to do whatever they like wherever they like. But who would believe that insects are conscious, that they are aware of what’s going on, not just little biobots?

headline: 2016 Pulitzer Prizes: A.P. Wins Public Service Award; ‘Hamilton’ Is Honored
abstract: The New Yorker received the prizes for criticism and feature writing; The New York Times won for international reporting and photography.
lead_paragraph: The Associated Press won the Pulitzer Prize for public service on Monday for a series that exposed slavery and vicious abuse in the Southeast Asia fishing trade, leading to the release of 2,000 captives and broad reforms in the United States and overseas.

headline: Tiny Motor Powers a New Threat to Cycling Races
abstract: Suggestions that riders are rigging their bikes have escalated, and a report by a French TV network suggested that motordoping had arrived at the sport’s top levels.
lead_paragraph: A grueling cycling race is somewhat less grueling if your bike is a motorcycle. Understanding this, some cunning cyclists may be turning the sport into Nascar on two wheels by surreptitiously giving their bikes a motorized boost.

headline: Atop the Met, a Haunting House
abstract: Cornelia Parker’s installation in the Metropolitan Museum of Art roof garden evokes the spooky mansion in “Psycho,” as well as an earlier America.
lead_paragraph: Cornelia Parker’s “Transitional Object (PsychoBarn),” which opens Tuesday on the roof garden of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, proves that this British sculptor best known for squashing and exploding things is much better at building them.

headline: Republican Consultant Cheri Jacobus Files Libel Suit Against Donald Trump
keywords: ['Libel and Slander', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Ms. Jacobus accused Mr. Trump and his campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, of libeling her after she criticized the candidate on television.
lead_paragraph: A longtime Republican consultant who has been harshly criticized by Donald J. Trump filed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit on Monday accusing him and his campaign manager, Corey Lewandowski, of making false statements that harmed her professionally and personally.

headline: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
abstract: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis.

headline: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
abstract: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. The Times’s team was comprised of Mauricio Lima, Sergey Ponomarev, Tyler Hicks and Daniel Etter. This is the newspaper’s fourth photo Pulitzer in the past three years.

headline: Old Houses From Canada Find a Home in Washington State
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Economic Conditions and Trends']
abstract: Houses from British Columbia have been taken by barge and restored in the San Juan Islands to help give struggling families an affordable way to stay.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY HARBOR, Wash. — Here in the San Juan Islands of northwest Washington State, where a severe shortage of affordable housing threatens the economy and the community, a small nonprofit group has found an unlikely way to help anchor families that are struggling to stay — by lifting up unloved houses in Canada, hoisting them onto barges and hauling them to where they are needed.

headline: AIDS Treatment in Haiti Promising for Developing Nations
abstract: A program providing free medicines has produced a survival rate comparable to that of gay men in the United States.
lead_paragraph: One of the first groups of H.I.V. patients in a poor country to get free AIDS drugs has about the same survival rate as their closest counterparts in the United States, according to scientists at Weill Cornell Medical College.

headline: Hillary Clinton Pushes Bill to Allow Families of Terror Victims to Sue Foreign Governments in U.S. Courts
abstract: By supporting legislation that would allow the families of victims of terrorist attacks to hold foreign governments accountable in American courts, Mrs. Clinton is opposing the Obama administration’s efforts to scuttle the bill.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton on Monday reiterated her support for legislation that would allow the families of victims of terrorist attacks, such as the ones on Sept. 11, 2001, to hold foreign governments accountable in American courts, putting her on the opposite side of President Obama on a bill that is popular with New Yorkers.

headline: Eileen Myles | A Reading of Her Poem “Milk"
abstract: Tavi Gevinson, Hari Nef, Beth Ditto and others read the feminist poet’s 1997 work, the meaning of which she explains in this video.
lead_paragraph: Tavi Gevinson, Hari Nef, Beth Ditto and others read the feminist poet’s 1997 work, the meaning of which she explains in this video.

headline: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
abstract: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
lead_paragraph: A foreign correspondent for about 15 years, Alissa Rubin is known for descending deep into some of the world’s scariest conflicts and returning with rare, often poignant glimpses into the plights of soldiers, survivors and victims.

headline: 2016 Pulitzer Prize Winners
abstract: The Pulitzers are in their centennial year, and the winners announced on Monday reflected in part the changes sweeping the media landscape. Here is the full list.
lead_paragraph: The Pulitzers are in their centennial year, and the winners announced on Monday reflected in part the changes sweeping the media landscape. Here is the full list.

headline: Reality vs. Ideology on Immigration at the Supreme Court
keywords: ['Deportation', 'Drivers Licenses', 'Executive Orders and Memorandums', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The challengers to President Obama’s executive actions keep trying to obscure one fact: The United States can’t deport all the undocumented immigrants living here.
lead_paragraph: As she often does, Justice Sonia Sotomayor got to the human heart of a complicated legal dispute at the Supreme Court Monday morning, in United States v. Texas, one of the most politically explosive cases to reach the justices in years.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in Operations Against ISIS
abstract: The Department of Defense has identified 13 American service members who have died supporting the operation to eliminate the Islamic State militant group.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Defense has identified 13 American service members who have died supporting the operation to eliminate the Islamic State militant group. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: 3 Things The Times Looks for in a Pulitzer Nominee
keywords: ['Pulitzer Prizes', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Glenn Kramon, a former assistant managing editor at The Times, divulges the secret formula.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Glenn Kramon, a former assistant managing editor at The Times, demystifies the Pulitzer nomination process.

headline: IBM Results Show Progress in Cloud and Data Analysis
abstract: The company reported a 21 percent decline in first-quarter earnings for the first quarter, though operating earnings per share were above estimates.
lead_paragraph: IBM delivered a quarterly performance that shows the steady headway it is making in new businesses led by cloud computing and data-analysis software, like its Watson artificial intelligence technology.

headline: Review: Arcane Collective Turns a Beckett Trilogy Into Physical Theater
abstract: “Return to Absence” and its companion, “Ebb,” at New York Live Arts, took a silent-movie approach to adapting “Molloy,” “Malone Dies” and “The Unnamable.”
lead_paragraph: A man in a ratty trench coat and a bowler hat slowly extracts a smooth pebble from his mouth, and then another and another and another. He holds the stones he’s been sucking in his right hand, but with his left, he finds more stones in one of his pockets. What to do with those? Thus ensues a little comedy in the transfer of stones between cupped hand, pocket and mouth, a little routine about desire and dissatisfaction and existential absurdity that evokes the laughter of self-recognition.

headline: Beyond the Trump Show? Two Political Plays in Chicago Give It a Try
abstract: James Earl Jones II plays a Republican lawyer in “Carlyle,” while “Hillary and Clinton” portrays a fictionalized Mrs. Clinton running for president.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Nobody would argue that this election cycle has been short on political theater. Granted, much of it could be compared to the kind of theater that sends you fleeing at intermission. But of drama, yes, there has been plenty.

headline: A Peppy Track by Atlanta’s Buzziest Female Musicians — and Best Friends
abstract: “Run Around,” a cut from D.J. Speakerfoxxx and Bosco’s new mixtape, “Girls in the Yard,” is pure, infectious fun.
lead_paragraph: On a recent night at New York’s Soho House, D.J. Speakerfoxxx and Bosco performed a handful of tracks off their new Fool’s Gold mixtape, “Girls in the Yard.” The songs are vivacious and fun: It is impossible not to bounce and body roll while they play. But equally infectious is their pure, unadulterated affection for one another, as collaborators and close friends: Throughout the performance, the duo grinned at each other as they tossed out lyrics and danced.

headline: Virtual Reality Movies Add Dimension to Tribeca Festival
abstract: With a helmet, anything is possible, and the Tribeca Film Festival offers a taste of the ways virtual reality can enhance the cinematic arts.
lead_paragraph: During two hours in the Virtual Arcade at the Tribeca Film Festival you can swim with whales, ride a dragon, become a rabbit, fly by Pluto and dodge spurts of blood unleashed by a machete attack. More exciting than any of those individual experiences, however, is the sense that you’re in a room full of possibilities and of creative people still in the early stages of figuring out what those possibilities are.

headline: Review: Gabriel Missé and Guillermina Quiroga Tango With Passion and Laughter
abstract: This Argentine tango couple danced four duets on Saturday at Dardo Galletto Studios — all improvised, and yet with feats that looked like formal choreography.
lead_paragraph: Tango, with the dramatic proximity it gives two dancers from brow to instep and its dramatically weighted walk, can be the most sexually charged of dance forms. It’s romantic, smoldering and very often tragic — as if destiny were steering the couple. But Gabriel Missé, who has been coming regularly to New York since 2008, is all laughter and song. On Saturday night, he was chuckling boyishly around the Dardo Galleto Studios as he prepared the recordings to which he was to dance.

headline: Review: Salut Salon Mixes Whimsy and Virtuosity
abstract: This German female quartet made its New York debut in “A Carnival of the Animals and Other Fantasies.”
lead_paragraph: In a classical-music-comedy market (yes, there is one) buoyed by social media, the German female quartet Salut Salon has developed a loyal following. The group’s performance style mixes the virtuosic silliness perfected by the duo Igudesman & Joo with the high-octane performance style of the rock-cover specialists Two Cellos, but adds lavish doses of whimsy and sex appeal. A video clip of the violinists Angelika Bachmann and Iris Siegfried, the cellist Sonja Lena Schmid and the pianist Anne-Monika von Twardowski engaged in competitive instrumental acrobatics during a medley of Vivaldi, Mozart and Weill has drawn over 20 million clicks on YouTube.

headline: Mark Bradford Will Represent U.S. at Venice Biennale
abstract: The abstract painter is only the fourth African-American to be featured in the United States pavilion at the international exhibition.
lead_paragraph: Mark Bradford, the highly regarded abstract painter, has been chosen as the United States’ representative to the next Venice Biennale, opening in May 2017. The United States pavilion, with Mr. Bradford’s work, will be organized by Christopher Bedford, director of the Rose Art Museum at Brandeis University, which was chosen by the Department of State’s Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs to be the commissioning institution for the exhibition.

headline: Filming Turns the Boston Marathon Finish Line Into a Set
abstract: Crew members filmed Mark Wahlberg in “Patriots Day,” the forthcoming movie about the 2013 marathon bombing, at the race’s finish line on Monday.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Hours before the first runners crossed the finish line of the Boston Marathon on Monday, a uniformed police officer ambled near the blue and yellow marker across Boylston Street. He seemed at first glance unremarkable, barely distinguishable from the legions of law enforcement officers keeping watch over New England’s biggest sporting event.

headline: Review: Christiane Karg and Yo-Yo Ma Revel in the Classics
abstract: Nuance, polish and intensity were displayed in separate shows by these artists in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Weill Recital Hall

headline: Review: A Dizzying and Dense ‘Portrait’ From Nora Chipaumire
abstract: Her dance-theater work, “Portrait of Myself as My Father,” had its premiere as part of Peak Performances at Montclair State University in New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Toward the end of Nora Chipaumire’s “Portrait of Myself as My Father” on Saturday, the dancer Shamar Watt stood face to face with Ms. Chipaumire, who was carrying a third performer, Pape Ibrahima N’diaye, on her back.

headline: Review: David Means’s ‘Hystopia,’ Not Your Average War Novel
abstract: David Means’s first novel is not just a meditation on war but also a portrait of a troubled America in the late 1960s and early ’70s.
lead_paragraph: “Hystopia,” David Means’s dark acid trip of a novel, reads like a phantasmagorical — and sometimes pretentious — mash-up of David Foster Wallace’s “Infinite Jest,” Charlie Kaufman’s screenplay “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind” and Michael Herr’s Vietnam classic, “Dispatches.”

headline: Photography Pulitzer: Thomson Reuters Coverage of Migrant Crisis
abstract: Thomson Reuters and The New York Times shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s migrant crisis.
lead_paragraph: Thomson Reuters and The New York Times shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s migrant crisis.

headline: Review: CW’s ‘Containment’ Joins the Killer-Virus Bandwagon
abstract: A viral outbreak cripples Atlanta in this new series, adapted from a Belgian show.
lead_paragraph: When the global pandemic comes it won’t be pretty, but at least we’ll know exactly how events will proceed. We’ll know this because of the — sorry — epidemic of virus shows and movies in recent years, which are all beginning to feel more or less the same.

headline: Review: Le Carré’s ‘The Night Manager,’ With Amoral Arms Dealing
abstract: Hugh Laurie and Tom Hiddleston go a little James Bond, a little “Against All Odds” in a six-part mini-series on AMC.
lead_paragraph: The novels of John le Carré are steeped in shadows and ambiguity. So it’s a little disconcerting that “The Night Manager,” the first television adaptation of a le Carré novel in 25 years, is so bright and straightforward and that, despite a few nasty but necessary killings, it’s so clear who we’re supposed to root for. If TV shows had jaws, this one’s would be square.

headline: Panel Would Make Insurers Help Contain Rising Drug Costs
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Elderly', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: A plan to pare the government share of reimbursement to insurers is part of a package of cost-controlling ideas that will be in a June report to Congress.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An influential federal advisory panel is calling for Congress to force private insurers to rein in rapid increases in prescription drug costs — by cutting some Medicare payments to insurance companies while shielding older Americans from higher out-of-pocket expenses.

headline: Michael Friedman to Be Artistic Director of Encores! Off Center
keywords: ['Theater', 'Encores! Great American Musicals in Concert (Series)', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Michael Friedman will take over from Jeanine Tesori, founding director of the program that presents concert performances of musicals every summer.
lead_paragraph: Michael Friedman, the composer and lyricist behind “Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson,” will be the next artistic director of Encores! Off Center, a City Center program that every summer presents concert performances of musicals previously staged Off Broadway and beyond.

headline: المجتمع المصري المكتوم
abstract: مقاضاة حكومة السيسي لجماعات حقوق الانسان، مثل منظمتي، علامة على اليأس وجنون العظمة.
lead_paragraph: مقاضاة حكومة السيسي لجماعات حقوق الانسان، مثل منظمتي، علامة على اليأس وجنون العظمة.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: You Don’t Like the Girls in ‘Girls’? That’s Its Genius.
abstract: Through 52 episodes, the show has never stopped looking for the grander, harsher psychological story. And, it never stopped looking for tough laughs.
lead_paragraph: Normally, you’d be confused. Why would HBO lower the curtain on Season 5 of “Girls” with two episodes on Sunday rather than the usual one at a time? Why not give the show’s 10 episodes a full 10 weeks? But there are the mysteries. Then there are the realities.

headline: Pulitzer for Feature Photography, Jessica Rinaldi
abstract: Jessica Rinaldi of The Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story about a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
lead_paragraph: Jessica Rinaldi of The Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story about a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Ecuador, Immigration, Dilma Rousseff
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Ad Agencies Need Young Talent. Cue the Beanbag Chairs.
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Youth', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Employee Fringe Benefits', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: To enhance their appeal, agencies are trying to make themselves look less like Madison Avenue and more like start-ups and tech companies.
lead_paragraph: At the headquarters of the McCann agency in Manhattan, the battle for the future of the advertising industry is being waged with piped-in electronic music and employee-brewed beer.

headline: United States Artists Picks Up $20 Million in Funding From Ford, Others
abstract: The money, which will serve as an operational endowment, is coming from several foundations and private donors.
lead_paragraph: The Ford Foundation, other philanthropic groups and some private donors have given nearly $20 million to United States Artists, an organization that makes grants to artists.

headline: Netflix’s Forecast for Growth Disappoints Wall St.
abstract: The streaming service says it expects to add two million subscribers outside America, less than the 3.5 million analysts had expected.
lead_paragraph: Netflix is now available in most countries around the world, putting more pressure on the company to continue its fast-paced growth abroad as well as at home.

headline: Farmers’ Markets Go From Sidewalk to Hotel Lobby
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', "Farmers' Markets", 'Eco-Tourism', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Local farmers are now setting up stands at hotels, selling fresh produce and conducting cooking demonstrations.
lead_paragraph: The hottest attraction at your hotel may be its farmers’ market. Properties around the country are increasingly hosting markets featuring local vendors. Most are open to the public, but a few, like the quarterly market at the Rosewood CordeValle in San Martin, Calif., are exclusively for hotel guests.

headline: Donald Trump Tries to Show Support of Blacks at a Chaotic Gathering
abstract: Donald J. Trump met Monday at Trump Tower with select members of a recently formed “diversity coalition,” the brainchild of his company’s adviser, Michael Cohen, who called on longstanding relationships with some black pastors to form a group to rebut questions about Mr. Trump’s attitudes about race.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump met Monday at Trump Tower with select members of a recently formed “diversity coalition,” the brainchild of his company’s adviser, Michael Cohen, who called on longstanding relationships with some black pastors to form a group to rebut questions about Mr. Trump’s attitudes about race.

headline: Obama Calls on Putin to Help Reduce Violence in Syria After Peace Talks Stall
abstract: Preparing for an overseas visit, President Obama urged President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to press Syria’s leader, Bashar al-Assad, to stop attacks against opposition forces.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama had “an intense conversation” with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday in which he expressed concern on the eve of his visit to the Middle East and Europe about the fragile Syrian peace talks and increased violence in Ukraine, White House officials said.

headline: Jacob deGrom Looks to Rejoin Mets
abstract: With his newborn son released from a hospital, deGrom will pitch a simulated game Tuesday and could start one of the Mets’ games at Atlanta later this week.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Mets starting pitcher Jacob deGrom moved closer to returning to the team when his newborn son was released from the hospital.

headline: ‘Tosca’ Pauses When a Diva Misses Her Cue on Vienna Stage
abstract: The Romanian soprano Angela Gheorghiu abandoned the tenor Jonas Kaufmann onstage at the Vienna State Opera.
lead_paragraph: Was it a stunning diva moment or an innocent mishap?

headline: L Train Tunnel Repairs Won’t Start Until 2019
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said the tunnel between Manhattan and Brooklyn required 2.7 miles of track repairs and miles of replaced cables.
lead_paragraph: Amid growing concern about a lengthy closing of the L train tunnel between Manhattan and Brooklyn, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said on Monday that a shutdown would not start until early 2019.

headline: Global Debate Over War on Drugs Heads to U.N. General Assembly
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Marijuana', 'Treaties', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: A growing insurgency against strict international antidrug treaties will help shape a historic debate at the United Nations this week among world leaders.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Canada has promised to legalize marijuana. Mexico’s highest court has allowed some citizens to grow cannabis for personal use. Colombia has reversed its decades-long policy of aerial spraying against coca, the raw ingredient in cocaine.

headline: Yemen Peace Effort Falters as Houthis Refuse to Attend Talks
abstract: The rebels accused government-allied forces of violating a truce and said delegates would not engage in negotiations until there was a cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — Peace talks aimed at ending Yemen’s civil war that were set to begin on Monday faltered before they could start, when delegates representing Yemen’s Houthi rebels refused to attend.

headline: A New York Primary That Actually Matters
abstract: Arthur C. Brooks and Gail Collins analyze an electoral phenomenon so unusual it resembles the infrequent return of cicada season.
lead_paragraph: Arthur: Hi, Gail. I hope you enjoyed our week off. Although American politics almost ground to a halt last week because we didn’t do The Conversation.

headline: At Last, a Box Henry Threadgill Fits Nicely Into: Pulitzer Winner
abstract: The composer and musician was awarded the prize for music for “In for a Penny, in for a Pound,” a suite-like composition released on two discs.
lead_paragraph: Henry Threadgill, who on Monday was awarded this year’s Pulitzer Prize for music, is a composer and bandleader of intense, unyielding originality, nobody’s idea of a compromise. An alto saxophonist and flutist with a distinguished career in the post-1960s American avant-garde, he has amassed a body of work with its own functional metabolism, perpetually humming in a state of flux. He has certain affinities with, but no particular allegiance to, the jazz tradition.

headline: Labor and Love in California’s Farmlands
abstract: Mimi Plumb’s rediscovered images of California farmworkers in 1975 chronicle the excitement, and struggle, of ordinary people caught up in the union movement.
lead_paragraph: Mimi Plumb’s rediscovered images of California farmworkers in 1975 chronicle the excitement, and struggle, of ordinary people caught up in the union movement.

headline: Rangers Welcome Sight of Ryan McDonagh in Practice
abstract: McDonagh, the team’s captain, who has been out since April 4 with a broken hand, participated in a full practice, but he remained doubtful for Game 3 against the Penguins.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Much to Coach Alain Vigneault’s surprise, the Rangers captain Ryan McDonagh practiced fully on Monday, wearing a white jersey that meant he was not off limits and gripping a stick with a right hand that was broken two weeks ago.

headline: Theranos Under Federal Criminal Investigation, Adding to Its Woes
abstract: In a note to outside partners, the company said that the Justice Department had requested documents and that the investigation was active.
lead_paragraph: Theranos, the embattled blood-testing laboratory, said on Monday that federal officials were conducting a criminal investigation into the company, adding to a series of questions from officials about its inner workings.

headline: Absences Weigh on Jets as They Gather
abstract: Questions about Muhammad Wilkerson and Ryan Fitzpatrick, as well as the retirement of D’Brickashaw Ferguson, left a confident team wrestling with uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: When Coach Todd Bowles addressed the Jets on Monday, his first time speaking to them since they left team headquarters dazed and numb the day after a season-ending loss ended their playoff hopes, he stood before a group yoked by uncertainty as much as optimism.

headline: Doris Roberts, Mother on ‘Everybody Loves Raymond,’ Dies at 90
abstract: The Emmy-winning character actress was best known for her role as Ray Romano’s tart-tongued, interfering mother on the hit CBS series.
lead_paragraph: Doris Roberts, the Emmy-winning character actress best known for her role as Ray Romano’s tart-tongued, interfering mother on the hit CBS series “Everybody Loves Raymond,” died on Sunday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 90.

headline: New York City Council to Review 5 Bills Reining In ‘Three-Quarter’ Homes
keywords: ['Group Homes and Supportive Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: The legislation seeks to help addicts and others living in the flophouses get stable housing and prevent fraud and other problems in an unregulated industry.

headline: Bill Campbell, Coach of Silicon Valley Stars, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Campbell, who advised the likes of Steve Jobs at Apple and Larry Page at Google, helped shape the technology industry.
lead_paragraph: Bill Campbell, one of the most influential background players in Silicon Valley, who was known as “coach” there for his work advising technology industry stars like Steve Jobs at Apple and Larry Page at Google, died on Monday at his home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 75.

headline: Michigan Governor to Drink Flint Tap Water for a Month
keywords: ['Lead', 'Water', 'Water Pollution', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Elections, State Legislature']
abstract: Gov. Rick Snyder said he hoped to “alleviate some of the skepticism and mistrust” that has left many Flint residents too scared to drink or even shower.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan, facing persistent criticism of his handling of the water crisis in Flint, on Monday took home five jugs of filtered tap water from the city and said he planned to drink it and cook with it for at least the next month.

headline: Harold Wood, Westchester County Legislator and Justice, Dies at 96
abstract: As the county’s first black supervisor, Justice Wood warned of racial unrest and called for better opportunities for blacks.
lead_paragraph: Harold L. Wood, the first black member of the legislative body of Westchester County, N.Y., and later the first black State Supreme Court justice in the county, died on Thursday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 96.

headline: Obama Will Meet With Gulf Leaders. Here’s a Probable Agenda.
abstract: The president is set to meet with leaders from Saudi Arabia and five other countries to discuss Iran, the Syrian civil war and other regional issues.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will meet with leaders from the Gulf Cooperation Council this week in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia.

headline: Obama to Visit a Saudi Arabia Deep in Turmoil
abstract: As the kingdom prepares to greet the president, it faces low oil prices, rising Iranian influence and fears of a widening rift with the United States.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — The images of the past year have been deeply unsettling for the people of Saudi Arabia, long accustomed to oil-fueled prosperity and regional clout: militants firing at communities along the country’s southern border; protesters storming the Saudi Embassy in Tehran; civil wars raging in three nearby states.

headline: Facing Impeachment, Dilma Rousseff Fights for Political Survival
abstract: If she is to survive the effort to oust her as president, she must make a compelling case that she can root out corruption and fix Brazil’s economy.
lead_paragraph: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil is likely to be kicked out of office based on allegations that she used money from state banks to balance the budget. But that fundamental issue appeared almost an afterthought as lawmakers in the Chamber of Deputies cited a litany of grievances before resoundingly supporting a motion to impeach her by a vote of 367 to 137.
