headline: Ramsay Bolton of ‘Game of Thrones’ Is the Most Hated Man on TV
abstract: The sadistic character, played by Iwan Rheon, gleefully flays, rapes and gelds. Who knows what dark impulses he will follow in Season 6.
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY HILLS, CALIF. — Like many successful actors, Iwan Rheon, better known as the blithely malicious Ramsay Bolton on “Game of Thrones,” arguably the most hated man on television, admits he’s concerned about being narrowly defined by an indelible character. But ask a logical follow-up question — what else are you working on? — and the scale of his challenge becomes clear.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Hitting the Catnip
abstract: A little experimentation is perfectly normal for a young cat.
lead_paragraph: Cole writes: My roommate, Alex, refuses to let his cat, Luna, consume catnip, even though Luna clearly has a desire to experiment with it. After over two years of adorably meowing and grooming Alex’s beard, I believe that Luna should at least be allowed to try catnip.

headline: Chicago After Laquan McDonald
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: In the wake of a shocking video that showed a black teenager shot 16 times by a police officer, the city is rocked by revelations of police brutality and misconduct — and by activists determined to upend the political order.
lead_paragraph: On St. Patrick’s Day in Chicago, in the auditorium of the city’s public-safety headquarters, the members of the Police Board sat at tables at the front of the room, beneath a framed genealogy: “Chicago Police Generations — a Proud Family Tradition.” Officers lined the perimeter of the hall, two dozen of them, bulked up in body armor. All eyes were trained on the young black protesters filling the room’s center, who had commandeered the board’s monthly meeting just 10 minutes after the call to order.

headline: A New Leaf
abstract: That lettuce in your fridge — why not try cooking it?
lead_paragraph: I like lettuce cooked.

headline: Can a Young Woman Vote at Her Swing-State College?
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Crowdfunding (Internet)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Insurance', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)', 'Elections']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what makes a vote valuable and whether the money donated for a co-worker’s experimental cancer treatment should be returned when it turns out he’s too sick to try it.
lead_paragraph: Our daughter just celebrated her 18th birthday and is excited about being able to vote. She is active politically and has strong opinions about many social and political issues. She is considering majoring in political science at the college she will attend later this year. She believes her vote may be more valuable in the swing state where she will attend college than in her home state, which is considered a lock for national and state elections. Is it ethical for her to register to vote at college? Kate H.

lead_paragraph: Even if you lack health insurance, you’ll probably be able to get treatment at a hospital in the event of a catastrophe — if you’re struck by a car, say. But having insurance can mean the difference between financial security and financial ruin.

headline: How Medicare Penalizes Hospitals for Being Too Careful
abstract: High rates of infections and other complications are prompting lower payments from Medicare, as well as protests from some elite hospitals.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The puffiness along Carol Ascher’s left leg seemed like normal swelling, probably from the high dose of chemotherapy Dr. Karl Bilimoria had injected the previous day. But it could have been a blood clot. He quickly ordered an ultrasound.

headline: 5 Hotels and 5 Tours for the Eco-Conscious Traveler
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Eco-Tourism', 'Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Foraging in Belize, biking in Iceland and other trips help you commune with nature.
lead_paragraph: It’s the rare hotel that doesn’t engage in sustainable practices like encouraging guests to reuse towels, but many hospitality companies and tour operators go much greener than that. Eco-tourism companies, which put a priority on sustainability as well as profit, cover everything from conservation-focused wildlife safaris to community-sustaining lodges and properties that grow their own food. Descriptions of some of the new and improved eco-lodges follow, along with those of new tours offering emissions-free bike trips, carbon-offset cruises and glimpses of rare wildlife.

headline: With ‘Les Blancs,’ Yael Farber Resurrects a Rebuke of Colonialism

headline: 1941: Joint U.S. and Canada Defense
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: U.S. and Canada coordinate defense against Axis powers in 1941.
lead_paragraph: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y. — President Roosevelt and W. L. Mackenzie King, Prime Minister of Canada, announced late tonight that they had reached an agreement under which they would coordinate their productive facilities for complete defense of the Western Hemisphere and extended aid to the British Empire in her war against the Axis powers. The outstanding feature of the statement was the unofficial estimate that Canada would supply the United States between $200,000,000 and $300,000,000 worth of defense articles needed most by this nation. — New York Herald Tribune, April 21, 1941

headline: France Seeks to Extend Emergency Powers as It Prepares for Sports Events
keywords: ['UEFA European Football Championship', 'Tour de France (Bicycle Race)', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)']
abstract: The government is aiming to bolster security before the country hosts the European Championship soccer tournament and the Tour de France this summer.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French government will seek a two-month extension of the state of emergency it declared after the attacks in and around Paris that left 130 people dead in November, Prime Minister Manuel Valls said on Wednesday.

headline: Chinese Feminism’s Long Journey Takes Two Paths at Bookstores
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Books and Literature', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: The Lady Book Salon offers philosophy and career guidance, as well as cookbooks and advice on finding a husband.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Inside a shopping mall near Financial Street, past the home décor stores and mannequins dressed in hot-pink lingerie, the two friends sipped lattes and debated whether women should shave their armpits.

headline: Credit Suisse Hires Former Deutsche Bank Executive
abstract: Henrik Aslaksen, the former global head of mergers and acquisitions at Deutsche Bank, will join the Swiss bank as head of strategic client coverage.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Credit Suisse has hired Henrik Aslaksen, a former top banker at Deutsche Bank, as the Swiss bank continues to reshape its investment banking business.

headline: Pope Francis' Message to Ecuador
abstract: In his weekly address at the Vatican, Pope Francis mentioned those affected by the recent earthquake in Ecuador, calling for all of Latin America to unite in solidarity and prayer.
lead_paragraph: In his weekly address at the Vatican, Pope Francis mentioned those affected by the recent earthquake in Ecuador, calling for all of Latin America to unite in solidarity and prayer.

headline: ‘Whole Foods Effect’: When Small Food Makers Get the Call to Go Big
keywords: ['Entrepreneurship', 'Local Food', 'Small Business', 'Supermarkets and Grocery Stores', 'Organic Foods and Products']
abstract: Elation can quickly turn to fear as small companies must suddenly learn how to produce at larger volumes while maintaining quality and consistency.
lead_paragraph: Cowgirl Creamery, a small food producer in Marin County, Calif., was elated when Whole Foods came calling to buy Cowgirl’s organic triple-cream cheese for 45 of its stores. After five years of selling shop to shop, the entrepreneurs behind the company finally had their first big order. To meet the new production demands, they borrowed $200,000 to build new aging rooms for the cheese.

headline: A Busy Queen Elizabeth II Pencils In a 90th Birthday
abstract: Befitting a workhorse who carried out 341 engagements last year, Elizabeth kicked off celebrations on Wednesday in a dutiful display.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — She has been served by 12 prime ministers, starting with Churchill; navigated the decline of the British Empire; braved the tragedies of her family and the nation; and, on Sept. 9, edged out Queen Victoria as the longest-reigning monarch in British history: 64 years now. And she is lauded for having the stiffest upper lip in the realm.

headline: Queen Elizabeth II Turns 90
abstract: She kicked off birthday celebrations on Wednesday, having remained enigmatic for seven decades of rule.
lead_paragraph: She kicked off birthday celebrations on Wednesday, having remained enigmatic for seven decades of rule.

headline: With ‘Keanu,’ Key & Peele Break Into Feature Films — Kittens in Tow
abstract: Their Comedy Central series ended in September, but Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele return in a comic movie about a drug lord and his kitten.
lead_paragraph: There is no longer “Key & Peele,” the razor-sharp Comedy Central sketch series that ended in September. There are only Keegan-Michael Key and Jordan Peele, the comic actors and writers who used the five seasons of that show to shine a satirical spotlight on racial stereotypes and injustice (not to mention the increasingly distinctive names of college football players). And so the two men started pursuing their individual career paths.

headline: Blackhawks’ Andrew Shaw Is Suspended for Anti-Gay Slur
keywords: ['Hockey, Ice', 'Playoff Games', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity']
abstract: Shaw, who leads Chicago in points during the playoffs, will miss Game 5 against St. Louis, after he shouted the slur while in the penalty box Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L. suspended Chicago Blackhawks forward Andrew Shaw for one game for shouting an anti-gay slur while in the penalty box during his team’s Game 4 playoff loss to the St. Louis Blues on Tuesday night.

headline: Fancy Juice Doesn’t Cleanse the Body of Toxins
abstract: There is no scientific basis to support undergoing juice detoxification or colon cleanses, as trendy as they may be.
lead_paragraph: Actually: To say that drinking juice detoxifies the body isn’t quite the same as claiming leeches suck out poisons, but it’s fairly close.

headline: Abuse in the Catholic Church: What’s New? Plenty.
abstract: Laurie Goodstein recently reported on Pennsylvania grand jury revelations about Church abuse i. She’s covered similar stories for years and talks about how it has — and hasn’t — changed.
lead_paragraph: Laurie Goodstein recently reported on Pennsylvania grand jury revelations about Church abuse i. She’s covered similar stories for years and talks about how it has — and hasn’t — changed.

headline: 1966: Selma Sheriff Woos Negroes
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Selma sheriff fights for his re-election bid in 1966.
lead_paragraph: SELMA, ALA. — Big Jim Clark, fighting for his political life, has discarded his ‘‘never’’ buttons and taken on the Communists in his campaign for re-election as Dallas County sheriff. Actually, says Mr. Clark, those buttons, which he constantly wore in his coat lapels until recently, never meant anything anyway except ‘‘The Communists shall never take over.’’ Last year he was saying the buttons were an answer to the Negroes’ cries of ‘‘We shall overcome.’’ ‘‘I’ve switched to a ‘law and order’ slogan because I think my campaign should be run on a positive rather than a negative basis,’’ the sheriff said. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 21, 1966

headline: House Hunting in ... Ontario
abstract: Toronto’s housing market is performing well, with the number of sales up 16 percent in the first quarter. A weak Canadian dollar has helped create foreign demand.
lead_paragraph: A FOUR-BEDROOM VICTORIAN NEAR TORONTO

headline: A Four-Bedroom Victorian in the Toronto Suburbs
abstract: The house, in the village of Unionville, is on the market for $1.17 million.
lead_paragraph: The house, in the village of Unionville, is on the market for $1.17 million.

headline: Watching the Clock on That Windows 10 Deal
abstract: Microsoft’s free offer for Windows 7 and Windows 8.1 users expires in July, but the company has not announced what will happen next.
lead_paragraph: Q. I keep getting Windows 10 upgrade messages on my Windows 7 system. I don’t want to leave Windows 7 yet, but I’ve heard the upgrades are not free later on. Is this true and how much will it cost?

headline: ESPN’s Curt Schilling Criticized Again After Post About Transgender People
abstract: Schilling posted an apparent response to backlash over a recent North Carolina law on transgender people’s use of bathrooms.
lead_paragraph: Curt Schilling, a baseball analyst for ESPN whose outspoken social media presence has led to his suspension from the network before, is defending himself again after making comments on Facebook about transgender people.

headline: Google Remains Stuck in Europe’s Regulatory Cross Hairs
keywords: ['Search Engines', 'Privacy', 'Android (Operating System)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: In the second set of charges in consecutive years, the search company was charged with breaking the region’s competition rules.
lead_paragraph: Google’s regulatory issues in Europe have gotten more complicated.

headline: Q. and A. With T.J. Miller: ‘Silicon Valley’ and the Mucinex Phlegm Ball
abstract: Mr. Miller, who plays Erlich Bachman on the HBO comedy series, discusses satire, marijuana and articulate mucus.
lead_paragraph: There is cringe-worthy humor, and then there is the comedian and actor T. J. Miller, whose specialty might be called wince-inducing. On the HBO series “Silicon Valley,” which returns on Sunday, April 24, he’s Erlich Bachman, the status-obsessed, invective-flinging, bong-ripping ringleader of a start-up crew. In Season 3, there is even “more sad depth,” Mr. Miller said, to “this poor guy, who has really fallen from grace. This season, it gets bad, and I don’t know how it can get better.”

headline: Choosing to Skip the Upgrade and Care for the Gadget You’ve Got
abstract: As part of a movement against consumerism, more people are maintaining their electronics instead of constantly buying the newest, fastest model.
lead_paragraph: Vincent Lai was working at a recycling facility in New York and sorting through a bin of used cellphones a few years ago when he dug up a Palm Treo, a smartphone that was discontinued last decade.

headline: Papo Vazquez, Still Going Strong After 40 Years
abstract: A concert at the Hostos Center for the Arts in the Bronx will recognize the jazz trombonist’s career.
lead_paragraph: If you examine the signal moments of Afro-Latin music in New York since the mid-1970s, you’ll often find the trombonist Papo Vazquez in the picture, brash and precise, helping to drive the music, giving it snap and ferocity. When still a teenager, he played on Héctor Lavoe’s album “De Ti Depende,” which included the bitter masterpiece “Periodico de Ayer.” He worked with the Fania All-Stars, Jerry Gonzalez’s Fort Apache Band, Manny Oquendo’s Conjunto Libre, the great Puerto Rican band Batacumbele; he played in bands led by Hector Lavoe, Eddie Palmieri, Tito Puente and Chico O’Farrill; he was a member of Arturo O’Farrill’s groundbreaking Afro-Latin Jazz Orchestra in the aughts. But Mr. Vazquez’s work as a bandleader, pushing post-Coltrane jazz and Puerto Rican traditional rhythm to the front of a gnashing ensemble sound, deserves all the recognition it gets. On Saturday, April 30, a concert will recognize Mr. Vazquez’s 40 years on the scene, with his band Mighty Pirates Troubadours. (7:30 p.m., Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture Repertory Theater, 450 Grand Concourse, Bronx; hostoscenter.org.)

headline: Heather Kravas’s Choreography Heads to the Chocolate Factory
abstract: Ms. Kravas’s latest work, featuring duets among six women, grapples with life’s disorder.
lead_paragraph: “An architecture of desire” is what Heather Kravas calls the duets among six women divided into three couples in her piece “play, thing.” But before this convergence takes place, they’ll evoke states of fear, anxiety, playfulness, power and eroticism through symmetrical floor patterns, rhythmic shifts, and precise and repetitive dance steps. And these movements, based on quotidian activities, will be combined with simple words.

headline: ‘Team Foxcatcher,’ a Wrestler’s Life and Death
abstract: The Netflix documentary, directed by Jon Greenhalgh, explores the life of Dave Schultz, who was murdered by John Eleuthère du Pont 20 years ago.
lead_paragraph: John Eleuthère du Pont was supposed to be the future of USA Wrestling when he built, in the 1980s, a magnificent training center on his Foxcatcher Farm in Newtown Square, Pa., and invited some of the country’s best wrestlers to live there. But, on Jan. 26, 1996, he shot and killed Dave Schultz, the seven-time World and Olympic medalist who coached the Foxcatcher team. It’s a story familiar to anyone who saw “Foxcatcher,” Bennett Miller’s 2014 fictionalized account (Mark Ruffalo played Schultz).

headline: Film Groups Threaten Boycott of South Korean Film Festival
abstract: The boycott threat is the latest development in a conflict between the festival, the South Korean film industry and the Busan city government.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Nine South Korean film organizations said this week that they would boycott the Busan International Film Festival, one of the top events in Asia, if organizers did not address their concerns about government interference in the festival.

headline: The Utah Symphony, Blossoming Again
abstract: A revitalized orchestra, under its new music director, Thierry Fischer, finally returns to Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Forty years have passed since the Utah Symphony last visited Carnegie Hall. This concert celebrates a comeback in more than one way: After sustaining an artistic slump and financial difficulties in the intervening decades, the orchestra can take pride in how it has blossomed under its new music director, Thierry Fischer — just in time for the current 75th anniversary season. An ambitious overhaul of personnel and programming is bearing fruit, as evidenced by an excellent new recording of commissioned works by Nico Muhly, Augusta Read Thomas and Andrew Norman.

headline: The Play ‘Daphne’s Dive’ Begins at Signature Theater
abstract: Quiara Alegría Hudes’s story takes place in a cheap corner bar in North Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: So many great, poetic plays take place in bars that you could program an entire season of them and save money on the set. A natural start would be “The Iceman Cometh,” but my dream lineup would then include Stephen Adly Guirgis’s portrait of Manhattan in transition, “In Arabia We’d All be Kings,” which would provide a nice contrast with the rural Irish pub in Conor McPherson’s “The Weir.” Joining this genre, packed with monologues of uncommon beauty and gradually escalating inebriation and conflict, is “Daphne’s Dive,” a new work by Quiara Alegría Hudes that takes place in a cheap corner bar in North Philadelphia. It centers on a relationship between the title character, who tends bar, and her adopted daughter. Ms. Hudes won a Pulitzer Prize for the drama “Water by the Spoonful” (part of an acclaimed trilogy) and wrote the book for Lin-Manuel Miranda’s musical “In the Heights,” which was directed by Thomas Kail, who also stages this new work. Vanessa Aspillaga (“Domesticated”) and Daphne Rubin-Vega (“Rent”) fill out this ensemble. Begins Tuesday, April 26, at Signature Theater; 212-244-7529, signaturetheatre.org.

headline: Senate Passes Legislation Tailored to a Modern Energy Landscape
keywords: ['Energy and Power', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans and Democrats united around a measure to better align the nation’s energy infrastructure with the changing ways that power is produced.
lead_paragraph: The Senate on Wednesday passed the first broad energy bill since the George W. Bush administration, a bipartisan measure to better align the nation’s oil, gas and electricity systems with the changing ways that power is produced in the United States.

headline: How to Explain Mansplaining
abstract: Why do men feel so entitled to hold forth? Because they assume women will listen.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — It was on a recent trip to Indonesia that, as a male bureaucrat sounded forth on a vast span of subjects without being asked to do so, I realized that the English language was in need of a new addition: the manologue. This otherwise perfectly charming man droned on and on, issuing a steady stream of words as I sat cramped in a tiny room with a group of fellow journalists and squinted at the labels on the soda cans hospitably placed on a table in front of us.

headline: ‘Disguise,’ of Masks and Global African Art
abstract: The exhibition, at the Brooklyn Museum, features more than 25 contemporary artists from Africa and of African descent from around the world.
lead_paragraph: In New York at least, the Brooklyn Museum has been a leader in the curatorial practice of juxtaposing art from disparate times, places, media and cultures. Its latest foray, which opens Friday, April 29, is at once wide yet focused, as its title attests. “Disguise: Masks and Global African Art” expands upon a show organized by the Seattle Art Museum, featuring more than 25 contemporary artists from Africa and of African descent from around the world, often representing them with several works each — photography, installation, drawing, sculpture and video.

headline: Surgery: The Neglected Stepchild of Global Health
abstract: 5 billion people around the world cannot access safe or affordable surgery.
lead_paragraph: During our visit last December to a rural hospital in southeastern Madagascar, a 14-year-old girl was rushed in, hemorrhaging after two days of unsuccessful labor. The only surgeon there — a Chinese doctor on temporary assignment — performed an emergency caesarean section, but two days had proved too long for the baby. She was stillborn, strangled by her own umbilical cord. The mom fared better, but just barely. No blood was available to replace the half-gallon she lost on her way to the surgical center.

headline: Norway Violated Rights of Anders Behring Breivik, Mass Killer, Judge Rules
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Solitary Confinement', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Terrorism']
abstract: Mr. Breivik had argued that the conditions of his confinement, including restrictions on communication, were a violation of the European Convention of Human Rights.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — Anders Behring Breivik, the Norwegian extremist who killed 77 people in a bomb and gun rampage in 2011, lives in conditions that would seem luxurious by American incarceration standards: a three-room suite with windows that includes a treadmill, a fridge, a television with DVD player and even a Sony PlayStation.

headline: Harriet Tubman Ousts Andrew Jackson in Change for a $20
abstract: Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew said that women and civil rights leaders would also appear on the $5 and $10 notes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew on Wednesday announced the most sweeping and historically symbolic makeover of American currency in a century, proposing to replace the slaveholding Andrew Jackson on the $20 bill with Harriet Tubman, the former slave and abolitionist, and to add women and civil rights leaders to the $5 and $10 notes.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Phony Concern for ‘The People’
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: When the senator talks about letting “the people” decide, he means nothing of the sort.
lead_paragraph: How can you tell when a politician like Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is lying? When he talks about the need to let “the people” decide. What he really means is “the game is rigged and the insiders get to decide.”

headline: France May Extend State of Emergency
abstract: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France said that the government would seek to extend the state of emergency declared after terror attacks in November.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Manuel Valls of France said that the government would seek to extend the state of emergency declared after terror attacks in November.

headline: Flint Water Crisis Yields First Criminal Charges
abstract: Two Michigan officials were accused of misleading other officials about the city’s water, and a city employee was charged with misconduct.
lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — Three government workers were charged with crimes on Wednesday for their roles in this city’s water crisis, accused in part of covering up evidence of lead contamination.

headline: Patricia Arquette Says She Lost Work Over Speech at Oscars
abstract: She had urged equal pay for women, and at a Tribeca event, she says producers “made it clear” she didn’t get roles because of those comments.
lead_paragraph: Advocating for equal pay in Hollywood takes its toll, as the actress Patricia Arquette said she learned the hard way. Ms. Arquette, who made her 2015 Oscar speech an impassioned plea for income equality, said she lost jobs as a result of her comments.

headline: Bernie Sanders Is Behind in Pennsylvania Poll
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: A Monmouth University survey found that 52 percent of likely Democratic voters in Tuesday’s Pennsylvania primary support Hillary Clinton while 39 percent back Senator Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders, fresh off a painful loss in New York, is facing a steep climb in the Pennsylvania primary next week, according to a new poll that shows him losing to Hillary Clinton by double digits.

headline: Should Bernie Sanders Call It Quits?
abstract: With the odds of his moving past Clinton in the delegate race growing longer, should Sanders drop out to avoid dividing the Democratic Party more before the general election in November?

headline: Reporting on Abuse in the Church: What’s New? Plenty.
abstract: Laurie Goodstein has reported on child sex abuse in the Catholic Church for years. Here, she and talks about how it has — and hasn’t — changed.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights from New York Times staff. In this podcast, Laurie Goodstein, the national religion correspondent, discusses her work covering sex abouse in the Catholic Church.

headline: Sex Abuse and the Catholic Church: Why Is It Still a Story?
abstract: The national religion correspondent Laurie Goodstein provides insight into her recent reporting on grand jury revelations about a Pennsylvania diocese.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this post, Laurie Goodstein, the national religion correspondent for The New York Times, provides personal insight into her recent article about a Pennsylvania grand jury report that the Diocese of Altoona-Johnstown engaged in an extensive cover-up of sex abuse by as many as 50 priests and church officials.

headline: E.U. Rules Will Chill Reporting
abstract: A new directive protecting corporate trade secrets could make it impossible to uncover business and industrial malfeasance.
lead_paragraph: The timing is troubling, if coincidental: Last Thursday, just 11 days after a trove of leaked documents now known as the Panama Papers reaffirmed the essential role of journalists and whistle-blowers in revealing illegal or unethical business practices, the European Parliament approved rules to protect corporate trade secrets that could put a chill on such efforts.

headline: How the Fiddle-Leaf Fig Became the ‘It’ Plant of the Design World
abstract: Every era has its trendy houseplant. In the ’70s it was the spider plant. In the ’80s, it was the potted ficus. This decade belongs to the fiddle-leaf fig.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Slatalla, the editor in chief of the blog Gardenista, has called it “the houseplant equivalent of a newborn.”

headline: ‘Bob the Artist,’ by Marion Deuchars
abstract: A beautifully produced picture book tells the story of a bird teased for his extra-long and extra-skinny legs.
lead_paragraph: BOB THE ARTISTWritten and illustrated by Marion Deuchars32 pp. Laurence King. $15.95. (Picture book; ages 4 to 8)

headline: Rainbow Nooses Cause Uproar on Tennessee Campus
abstract: The art project of colorful, crocheted nooses was taken down but was not intended to refer to gays or lynching, an official at the school said.
lead_paragraph: An art student hung six nooses, each a different color of the rainbow, from a tree at a university in Tennessee on Monday as part of a class project, the school said, provoking an uproar among students and staff members who saw them as a symbol of racism and homophobia evocative of the Ku Klux Klan.

headline: Sumner Redstone’s Granddaughter and Ex-Companion Form Alliance
abstract: Keryn Redstone has filed a petition to join the former companion, Manuela Herzer, in the legal fight over the media mogul’s mental competency.
lead_paragraph: In yet another twist to an already tangled case, a judge on Wednesday rejected a petition by the granddaughter of the media mogul Sumner M. Redstone to join his former companion in the legal battle over his mental competency.

headline: Raped at Off-Campus Frat Houses, Students Say, and Ignored by College
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Fraternities and Sororities', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Two Kansas State University students say the university, in apparent violation of federal guidelines, refused to investigate their rape complaints.
lead_paragraph: Has Kansas State University given fraternity members a free pass when it comes to accusations of rape?

headline: Apps to Build Your Understanding of the Environment
abstract: Programs to help you shop for food and skin care products, learn about wildlife and observe weather patterns and sea level changes.
lead_paragraph: EARTH DAY, which takes place on Friday, has become an increasingly well-known event as politicians, billionaires and others take part in building awareness about the environment. You, too, can participate in Earth Day with apps that remind you how to add a touch of green to your life.

headline: Yahoo’s First Quarter Adds Urgency to Sale Option
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Marissa Mayer needs to offload Yahoo’s core business before bidders like Verizon lose interest
lead_paragraph: Yahoo’s first quarter is the last straw. An 11 percent drop in revenue for the first three months of the year puts an exclamation point on the lack of progress in almost four years with Marissa Mayer as chief executive. Google and Facebook are cleaning up in digital advertising, especially mobile. It’s time to offload Yahoo’s core business before bidders like Verizon lose interest.

headline: 101 Boosterism
abstract: Even when it’s right, is it important?
lead_paragraph: I see that @drvox is writing a big piece on carbon pricing – and agonizing over length and time. I don’t want to step on his forthcoming message, but what he’s said so far helped crystallize something I’ve meant to write about for a while, a phenomenon I’ll call “101 boosterism.”

headline: Jerry Seinfeld Helps Margaret Cho With a Do-Over
abstract: After Ms. Cho bombed at a New Jersey club, Mr. Seinfeld proposed a return engagement. Now patrons are getting free tickets to see both comedians.
lead_paragraph: Last month, the stand-up comedian Margaret Cho had a bad set at the Stress Factory in New Jersey. It happens. O.K., it was worse than usual since a clip of Ms. Cho being booed by the crowd showed up on TMZ. But for a comic, bombing is part of the job. What’s less common is getting a second chance with the same audience.

headline: 500 Migrants May Have Died in Sinking of Boat in Mediterranean, U.N. Says
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Drownings']
abstract: Interviews with survivors helped clear a cloud of confusion around the humanitarian disaster, which, if confirmed, would be the largest in Europe’s migrant crisis in a year.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations refugee agency said on Wednesday that 500 people may have died in the choppy waters of the Mediterranean last week, when a large boat packed with migrants from Africa and the Middle East capsized in an unknown location between Libya and Italy.

headline: Is Conor McGregor Retiring? U.F.C. World Can Only Guess
abstract: A Twitter message from the U.F.C.’s biggest current star sparked speculation, but the fighter has been silent since his bombshell.
lead_paragraph: The Ultimate Fighting Championship is suddenly and unexpectedly in danger of losing one of its biggest stars, Conor McGregor. If he really is leaving the sport, the return of Jon Jones on Saturday after 15 months away from the Octagon becomes more and more important to the organization.

headline: Reader Idea | A Home-Schooled Teenager on Learning With The Times
abstract: For this Canadian home-schooled student, reading The Times is a “treasure hunt” for finding fascinating things. She provides inspiration for anyone — whether home-schooled, unschooled, traditionally schooled, or out of school — who wants to use The Times to learn.
lead_paragraph: On this blog, we often promote the idea that The Times can be your textbook, but in the case of Kathryn Rosnau, a home-schooled 17-year-old from Canada, it literally is one.

headline: ‘Walking Dead’ Digital Comic, The Alien, Is Pay What You Wish
abstract: The Walking Dead: The Alien is by Brian K. Vaughan and Marcos Martin of Panel Syndicate, not the usual team of Robert Kirkman and Charlie Adlard.
lead_paragraph: Name your price. That’s the proposition that fans of The Walking Dead comic book were facing on Wednesday as a new digital-only issue of the series was released. Visitors to Panel Syndicate will be able to decide how much, if anything, they want to spend on the comic, The Walking Dead: The Alien.

headline: Sheldon Silver Apologizes as Prosecutors Seek a Sentence of More Than 14 Years
abstract: The government said the former Assembly speaker’s sentence should be “greater than any sentence imposed on other New York State legislators convicted of public corruption offenses.”
lead_paragraph: Sheldon Silver, the former State Assembly speaker, offered an emotional apology to the judge who will sentence him next month, saying in a letter filed on Wednesday that he had “failed the people of New York.”

headline: #LaughingWhileBlack Wine Train Lawsuit Is Settled
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Social Media', 'Wines', 'Book Clubs']
abstract: A group of black women who accused a wine train company of racial bias settled the lawsuit in private mediation.
lead_paragraph: When the women in the Sistahs on the Reading Edge book club were thrown off a train touring Napa Valley wineries last August after they were laughing loudly, accusations of racial bias, a hashtag and headlines soon followed. So did a lawsuit, claiming millions in damages. Now the matter has been settled in mediation, and the women want to move on.

headline: Coloring Books for Adults Seeking Playtime
keywords: ['Hobbies', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Art', 'Books and Literature', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Grown-up fans say they are therapeutic, foster creativity and force them to put down their smartphones.
lead_paragraph: Kara Lacey, 33, does it after a long day of work, sometimes accompanied by a glass of wine. “It’s super-relaxing, fun and nostalgic,” said Ms. Lacey, a publicist who lives in Hoboken, N.J.

headline: Donald Trump, After Difficult Stretch, Shows a Softer Side
abstract: In an interview, the usually boastful Mr. Trump seemed magnanimous and even humbled as he reflected on his “evolving” campaign and looked to the challenges ahead.
lead_paragraph: It has been a rough few weeks for Donald J. Trump and his team: a bruising loss in Wisconsin, a public campaign shake-up, and some high-profile missteps and gaffes, including his reference to the attacks on the World Trade Center as occurring “on 7-11.”

headline: Supreme Court Rules Iran Bank Must Pay for Terrorist Attacks
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Law and Legislation', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A law making it easier for victims’ families to recover damages did not overstep constitutional bounds, the court said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Iran’s central bank must pay nearly $2 billion to victims of terrorist attacks, the Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday.

headline: Ted Cruz Scoffs at Donald Trump’s ‘Remarkable’ Win in His Home State
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: At a campaign rally in Pennsylvania, which votes on Tuesday along with four other Eastern states, Senator Ted Cruz criticized the news media for rushing to crown Donald J. Trump all but the presumptive Republican presidential nominee. Mr. Cruz finished third in the three-man New York primary.
lead_paragraph: HERSHEY, Pa. — The morning after a crushing defeat, Senator Ted Cruz dismissed Donald J. Trump’s garnering of about 60 percent of Republican primary votes in New York as the expected spoils of a home-state advantage.

headline: No Phones for You! Chic Businesses Are Abandoning Landlines
abstract: Many phone numbers these days merely lead to automated voice mail with directions to a website. And some businesses have abandoned phones altogether.
lead_paragraph: To New Yorkers, greater Mulberry Street is typically considered NoLIta, unless it’s northern Chinatown, or to those old enough to remember Sinatra at the Paramount, Little Italy.

headline: The Loophole That Could Cost Donald Trump the Nomination
abstract: Pennsylvania’s unusual delegate system makes it a wild card in the primary process.
lead_paragraph: Pennsylvania, which holds its primary next Tuesday, uses a nonbinding “loophole” primary — and that could cost Donald Trump the Republican nomination.

headline: Foreign Aid and National Security

headline: 7 Police Officers Guarding Vaccination Team in Pakistan Are Shot Dead
abstract: There was no immediate claim of responsibility, and officials said they were investigating whether the attacks were connected to the immunization campaign.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Seven police officers keeping watch over a polio vaccination campaign were gunned down in two separate attacks in a suburb of Pakistan’s southern port city of Karachi on Wednesday, government officials said.

keywords: ['Jews and Judaism', 'Palestinians', 'Israeli Settlements', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: The network was responsible for attacks on Palestinians, including the attempted arson of at least one home with people sleeping inside, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israel said Wednesday that it had uncovered a new network of Jewish extremists in the West Bank that was responsible for several recent attacks against Palestinians, including the attempted arson of at least one home as people slept inside.

headline: New Orleans Police Officers Plead Guilty in Shooting of Civilians
abstract: The five former officers were charged after six unarmed people were shot, two fatally, on the Danziger Bridge in the chaos after Hurricane Katrina.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — A legal journey that was set off more than a decade ago with the shooting of unarmed citizens by police officers in the desperate days after Hurricane Katrina wound toward a close on Wednesday when five former officers pleaded guilty in federal court to conspiracy, obstruction of justice and civil rights charges.

lead_paragraph: On a bright, warm day 50 years ago this week, three young men went out to have a drink that they hoped would make history.

headline: Grieving and Going Forward: How Zaha Hadid’s Firm Plans to Move On
abstract: Patrik Schumacher, who worked alongside Ms. Hadid before her recent death, says the architecture firm will remain a “vibrant address for major work.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — White flowers fill the design gallery, with commemorative portraits placed amid undulating furniture of burnished polyurethane and marble. A condolence book rests on a stand, a construction of memories. In the main studios, nearly 400 employees labor away, deadlines pressing.
