headline: In an Age of Terror, an Early Start on the Presidential Transition
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Terrorism', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: A meeting with Obama administration officials and those from the presidential campaigns is the official start of the handover process, likened to a giant corporate merger.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At a luxurious hilltop estate with sweeping vistas of the Hudson River, an adviser to President Obama began meeting on Wednesday with aides to the candidates vying to replace him to make the first, early preparations for the day when Mr. Obama leaves office.

headline: Group Backing Hillary Clinton Begins Reserving $125 Million in Ads for the Fall
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: With Mrs. Clinton’s nomination appearing increasingly likely, Priorities USA Action, a “super PAC” supporting her, said that it had begun reserving $125 million in television and digital advertising for the general election campaign.
lead_paragraph: A “super PAC” supporting Hillary Clinton said on Wednesday that it had collected $11.8 million dollars in March and had $44.7 million in cash on hand.

headline: Theranos Under Pressure as Inquiries Mount
abstract: Two federal investigations have added to a series of questions from officials about the company, but the area of scrutiny is unknown.
lead_paragraph: The news that the blood-testing company Theranos is being investigated by the Justice Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission brings to mind the adage that if something sounds too good to be true, it probably is.

headline: Airplanes and Babies: Readers Weigh In
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Children and Childhood', 'Crying', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: More than 600 readers wrote in about the issue of crying babies on airplanes, with responses ranging from compassion to indignation.
lead_paragraph: An article by Dr. Perri Klass about flying with small children, “Fear of Crying: The Problem of Babies and Airplanes,” touched a nerve with Well readers. More than 600 readers weighed in, with responses ranging from compassion to indignation. Here is an edited selection.

headline: Donald Trump Reaches Out to Gov. Mike Pence Before Indiana Primary
abstract: Mr. Trump’s meeting with the governor comes two weeks before the primary in a state that Senator Ted Cruz’s campaign sees as crucial to winning the Republican presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump met privately with Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana at his residence on Wednesday afternoon, two weeks before the primary in a state that Senator Ted Cruz’s campaign sees as crucial to its efforts to capture the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Hillary Clinton, With Connecticut Ally, Highlights Gun Control Stance
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Gun Control', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)']
abstract: The daughter of the principal killed in the Sandy Hook massacre expresses support in the ad, saying, “No one is fighting harder” than Hillary Clinton.”
lead_paragraph: As the primary calendar turns to Connecticut, the Clinton campaign has enlisted a powerful new surrogate who has cut both a 30-second and 60-second ad for the campaign: a daughter of Dawn Hochsprung, the principal killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Arizona’s Redrawn Legislative Map
abstract: Republicans had challenged the map drawn by an independent redistricting commission, saying it violated the principle of “one person one vote” and was infected by partisanship.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday unanimously upheld an Arizona state legislative map drawn by an independent redistricting commission, rejecting a challenge from Republicans who said the map was too favorable to Democrats.

headline: Mexico City’s Best Cocktail Bars
abstract: The densely populated capital has a lot more to offer than just mezcal and Modelo.
lead_paragraph: “We used to drink mezcal and beer, but now we’re really into cocktails,” says Mafer Tejada, a bartender at Mexico City’s Licorería Limantour, of the trend sweeping her hometown. Following in the footsteps of boundary-pushing chefs like Enrique Olvera of Pujol, the Mexican haute cuisine restaurant that currently occupies the 16th position on the list of the world’s 50 best, mixologists across Mexico City are also making their mark through artful presentations, unusual ingredients and unique bar design. Here, a shortlist of the city’s most exceptional places to imbibe.

headline: The Democrats’ Misguided Kasich Strategy
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A demand that the Republican underdog roll over comes from an unexpected source.
lead_paragraph: As Wednesday’s editorial predicted, New York’s presidential primary results brought renewed calls for Bernie Sanders and John Kasich, the Democratic and Republican underdogs, to withdraw from the race.

headline: Donald Trump’s Jet Is Grounded by the F.A.A.
abstract: The Cessna jet, which has been used to shuttle Mr. Trump to dozens of campaign events, has been flying with an expired registration since Feb. 1.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s Cessna jet has been grounded.

headline: Leader of Syria Rescue Group, Arriving in U.S. for Award, Is Refused Entry
abstract: Raed Saleh, of the Syria Civil Defense group, was to accept an award from InterAction, an alliance of international aid agencies. He was stopped at Washington’s Dulles International Airport.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The leader of a Western-backed rescue organization that searches for survivors of bombings in Syria was denied entry into the United States this week, where he was to receive an award recognizing his contributions to humanitarian relief.

headline: Down to Lunch Founders Pursue Less-Traveled Path to App Success
abstract: The creators of the popular app, which centers on meeting up with friends in person, refuse most interviews and have turned away potential investors.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Nikil Viswanathan and Joseph Lau have built the hottest new social app in America. Now the young men have to keep it from getting crushed by an anonymous slander campaign, overwhelmed servers and their urge to personally respond to thousands of messages from users.

headline: Katy Pyle and Her ‘Misfits of Ballet’
abstract: In the world of tutus and tiaras, Ms. Pyle’s troupe, Ballez, seeks to discover and display “what lives inside of us.”
lead_paragraph: Ballet is extreme. That’s exactly why the choreographer Katy Pyle loves it.

headline: After ‘Girls,’ Lil Freckles Raps About Life as a Brooklyn Millennial
abstract: The pixie-faced rapper is working on her next album, which she began writing on a recent trip to Mexico City.
lead_paragraph: Name Lil Freckles

headline: Review: How Streisand Became a Symbol, by Neal Gabler
abstract: Mr. Gabler, in a new book in Yale’s Jewish Lives series, explores how Barbra Streisand became one of modern culture’s defining women.
lead_paragraph: What a revelation it must have been to see Barbra Streisand for the first time in a nightclub or onstage. Her vowels were nasal, her patois unmistakably Brooklyn; she had a gorgeous, frankly Semitic face. Then she became a movie star. To families stocked with Barbras, including my own, the very sight of her on a huge screen was exhilarating. She represented the way we were.

headline: China’s Smaller Cities Struggle to Cultivate an Interest in Classical Music
abstract: To improve the public’s appetite for the performing arts, concert halls in China are promoting educational programs and offering discounted tickets.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — After more than a decade as the world’s great hope for classical music, China is suffering growing pains.

headline: A Math Biopic, With Dev Patel, Applies a Different Calculus
abstract: “The Man Who Knew Infinity” depicts the bond between Srinivasa Ramanujan (Dev Patel) and G.H. Hardy (Jeremy Irons) in the early 20th century.
lead_paragraph: As mathematicians go, Srinivasa Ramanujan isn’t exactly a household name. But his genius — the ability to divine formulas seemingly from thin air that, a century later, are informing computer development, economics and the study of black holes — has long captivated academics and artists alike.

headline: Boko Haram and ISIS Are Collaborating More, U.S. Military Says
abstract: A weapons convoy believed to be from Islamic State fighters seized in an area devastated by Boko Haram raises alarm that the two are working to attack U.S. allies in Africa.
lead_paragraph: NDJAMENA, Chad — American military officials say that two of the world’s most feared terrorist groups — the Islamic State and Boko Haram — have begun to collaborate more closely, raising alarm that they are working together to attack American allies in North and Central Africa.

headline: For Its Star, ‘Dheepan’ Was the Role of His Lifetime
keywords: ['Movies', 'Cannes International Film Festival', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Antonythasan Jesuthasan stars in a film whose protagonist, like him, is a refugee from Sri Lanka. It won the top prize at Cannes last year.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In “Dheepan,” the latest film by the French director Jacques Audiard, a migrant from a war-torn land borrows a passport and makes his way to France, where he seeks asylum. It is also loosely the story of the film’s star, Antonythasan Jesuthasan, a writer and former leftist militant from Sri Lanka, who arrived in France in 1993 with a fake French passport, eventually receiving refugee status.

headline: Russia Bolsters Its Submarine Fleet, and Tensions With U.S. Rise
keywords: ['Submarines and Submersibles', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin’s military modernization has the Pentagon responding by accelerating its own “undersea capabilities” and countermeasures.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Italy — Russian attack submarines, the most in two decades, are prowling the coastlines of Scandinavia and Scotland, the Mediterranean Sea and the North Atlantic in what Western military officials say is a significantly increased presence aimed at contesting American and NATO undersea dominance.

headline: An Energy Bill in Need of Fixes
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Global Warming', 'Law and Legislation', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: A Senate bill could boost solar and wind energy but would encourage the burning of trees to generate electricity.
lead_paragraph: The Senate voted Wednesday to approve an energy bill that contains provisions encouraging land conservation, renewable energy and improved efficiency. It also includes bad ideas that would harm the environment, particularly a provision that would encourage the burning of trees to generate electricity.

headline: Paulette Tavormina’s “Seizing Beauty”
abstract: The photographer’s carefully composed images are inspired by — and closely resemble — old master paintings.
lead_paragraph: The photographer’s carefully composed images are inspired by — and closely resemble — old master paintings.

headline: Vivid Images That Aren’t Old Masters — but Look Just Like Them
abstract: The photographer Paulette Tavormina’s carefully composed still lifes recall paintings from the Dutch Golden Age.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Paulette Tavormina began her professional career working with antiques, food styling and photographing works of art for an auction house. She’s also spent many years collecting bits and pieces — the insects, objects and flowers that fill her studio — from markets and little shops. Her new book “Seizing Beauty,” out next week, took six years to photograph and brings together all these experiences: It features 65 sumptuous color images inspired by old master still lifes. (The book’s release coincides with a show at the Academy Art Museum in Easton, Md., which opens April 23.)

headline: German Court Rules Antiterrorism Laws Partly Unconstitutional
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The country’s highest court demanded tighter control over surveillance, reflecting Germany’s desire to balance public safety against violations of privacy.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — At a time when Europe fears more terrorist attacks and the United States is urging European intelligence services to cooperate more closely, Germany’s highest court on Wednesday ruled that critical antiterrorism laws were partly unconstitutional and demanded tighter control over surveillance.

headline: Worth the Price of 92 Admissions: Entry Into a Stadium Fan Club
abstract: To be a member of the 92 Club, a soccer fan has to visit the stadiums of all 92 clubs in British soccer’s top four divisions, an ever-changing list.
lead_paragraph: The list includes ramshackle old stadiums, scented and scarred with century-old reminders of English soccer’s storied past, but also the gleaming cathedrals that testify to the Premier League’s rich new present.

headline: Bossy With a Punch: Jackets for the Office Get a Makeover
abstract: Plus: Workout leggings you can customize, from Alala; a new handbag label you should know about; a Walter Van Beirendonck "watch" that puts a cool spin on bling; and more.
lead_paragraph: Plus: Workout leggings you can customize, from Alala; a new handbag label you should know about; a Walter Van Beirendonck "watch" that puts a cool spin on bling; and more.

headline: 3 Other Mothers, My Intimate Network
abstract: For a mother in a demanding profession, allomothers, other mothers who help raise the children, are vital. China is a good place to find them.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — During the early morning tumult of getting the children ready for school, my gaze falls for a split second on a photograph on the refrigerator of three middle-aged Chinese women who have all helped raise my children over the last 13 years.

headline: Katie Holmes, Chloë Sevigny and Plenty of Chanel at Tribeca Film Festival Dinner
abstract: With celebrities in tow, the fashion house hosts its 11th annual dinner for the downtown film festival.
lead_paragraph: “We’re all whores,” Chloë Sevigny said Monday night, standing in Balthazar at a dinner Monday night for the Tribeca Film Festival, as she discussed her outfit.

headline: Paris’s First Concept Pastry Shop
abstract: The bimonthly French magazine Fou de Pâtisserie recently opened a new storefront where every sweet treat is delivered daily from chefs around the city.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Julie Mathieu and Muriel Tallandier opened a physical extension of their bimonthly French pastry magazine, Fou de Pâtisserie: a new, namesake sliver of a shop on the pedestrian rue Montorgueil, where nothing is made on site — the duo has tapped leading chefs all around the city to deliver their best sweets daily. As inconceivable as it may seem that a pastry-dense city like Paris wouldn’t already have its own concept store, Fou de Pâtisserie boutique is effectively an industry first.

headline: The Modern Love Podcast: Between the Bars
abstract: The actor Joshua Jackson reads an essay by Joshua Fattal, one of three American hikers held captive in Iran, about reuniting with his middle-school girlfriend after his release.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s episode of the Modern Love Podcast, the actor Joshua Jackson (“The Affair,” “Dawson’s Creek”) reads Joshua Fattal’s 2014 essay, “Reaching Out Between the Bars.” Mr. Fattal was one of three Americans, along with Shane Bauer and Sarah Shourd, who were detained in Iran for 26 months after unknowingly crossing over an unmarked border of Iraqi Kurdistan into Iranian Kurdistan during a hiking trip in 2009.

headline: Florida Says Firm Didn’t Illegally Try to Influence Attorney General
keywords: ['Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Attorneys General', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The state ethics commission said Dickstein Shapiro, a now-defunct law firm, didn’t violate lobbying laws in dealings with Pam Bondi, a rising G.O.P. star.
lead_paragraph: A former Washington law firm and one of its top partners did not violate Florida’s lobbying laws when appealing to the state attorney general, Pam Bondi, and her staff on behalf of corporate clients, the Florida Commission on Ethics has concluded after a 16-month investigation.

headline: A Legendary Fashion Photographer, Revisited
abstract: Louise Dahl-Wolfe, who worked for Harper’s Bazaar for many years, is the subject of a new book, out this month.
lead_paragraph: When the photographer Louise Dahl-Wolfe was hired at Harper’s Bazaar in 1936, fashion photography as we think of it today hardly existed. As she recalled years later, at the beginning of her career “there weren’t really fashion photographers, just artists like Steichen, who just happened to do fashion photography.” Dahl-Wolfe worked as a principal photographer at Bazaar — alongside its editor in chief Carmel Snow, the art director Alexey Brodovich and fashion editor Diana Vreeland — for 22 years, and played a large role in redefining the form: pioneering a shift away from stiff society portraits to a more natural and relaxed style of photography.

headline: The Work of Louise Dahl-Wolfe
abstract: The photographer is the subject of a new book, out with Aperture this month.
lead_paragraph: The photographer is the subject of a new book, out with Aperture this month.

headline: Proof & Gauge, a Long Island City Bar, Makes Its Own Gin
abstract: The neighborly bar is operated by Chris Murillo, a former corporate lawyer who wanted to open a craft distillery in Queens.
lead_paragraph: Chris Murillo, 36, was a corporate lawyer and a cocktail connoisseur when, four years ago on New Year’s Eve, he got the kind of idea that comes only after midnight and a few drinks. “I decided to start the first craft distillery in Queens,” he said. “After sitting in an office for nine years, I finally needed to do something where I worked with my hands and got out and interacted with people.”

headline: Six of Fou de Pâtisserie’s First Pastries
abstract: A look at some of the new Paris concept shop’s early offerings.
lead_paragraph: A look at some of the new Paris concept shop’s early offerings.

headline: Eyeing Tonys, ‘Shuffle Along’ Hopes to Be Classified a Revival
abstract: This Broadway musical, vastly revamped since it was originally staged in 1921, is hoping to be categorized in a way that won’t pit it against “Hamilton.”
lead_paragraph: The Music Box Theater on Broadway has been packing in the crowds for weeks, with theatergoers eager to see a starry but unfamiliar musical, “Shuffle Along,” even as that jazz-and-tap show is still being revised in previews.

headline: Don’t You Forget About Me! The Formerly Irredeemable ’80s Return
abstract: The 1980s, a decade often remembered with fondness and a shudder, finally gets some love.
lead_paragraph: Six nights and two afternoons a week, the synthesizers blare, the lights flash and the strains of Tears for Fears are heard over Broadway.

headline: Teenager Sentenced to 14 Years in Chinatown Rape
abstract: Eric Pek, 17, was one of three youths who had pleaded guilty to rape, robbery and burglary in the attack in June after they had slipped out of a group home.
lead_paragraph: One of three teenagers who slipped out of a group home and raped a woman in a Manhattan stairwell was sentenced to 14 years in prison on Wednesday after he gave a short apology in court.

headline: Former Journalist Steps In to Claim His Half of a Pulitzer
abstract: When he heard that his former employer, Sun Newspapers in Charlotte Harbor, Fla., had won for a series of editorials, Brian Gleason said he had written several of them.
lead_paragraph: Dude, where’s my Pulitzer?

headline: What Is Sanders’s Endgame?
abstract: What he has accomplished is miraculous. But having a meaningful impact does not necessarily create a sustainable movement, let alone a revolution.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s commanding victory in New York on Tuesday put yet another nail in the coffin of Bernie Sanders’s candidacy.

headline: Get to Know the Historical Figures on the $5, $10 and $20 Bills
keywords: ['US Dollar (Currency)', 'Women and Girls', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The Treasury Department announced new designs for several bills that will incorporate women, including Harriet Tubman, Susan B. Anthony and Eleanor Roosevelt.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Treasury Department announced Wednesday that women will be incorporated into new designs for the $5, $10 and $20 bills. Here is a look at the new lineup.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Day After Triumph, Donald Trump Struggles to Stick to a More Refined Message
abstract: Mr. Trump appeared restrained after winning the New York primary, but less than 24 hours later, he was back to his more familiar campaign self.
lead_paragraph: Basking in the glow of an overwhelming victory in his home state, Donald J. Trump on Tuesday night seemed — dare we say it — almost presidential, or at least a bit more refined.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Elizabeth II, Harriet Tubman
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: From Hollywood Son to Dean & DeLuca Investor
abstract: A gathering of New York foodies to mark Charles Finch’s efforts to upgrade a venerable New York institution.
lead_paragraph: “I can’t quite believe I’m involved in this,” said Charles Finch, standing before a shelf of imported olive oils at Dean & DeLuca in SoHo on a recent evening. He had the beaming face of a kid in a candy store. Or rather, a kid who runs the candy store.

headline: 5 Bridal Trends for Spring 2017
abstract: Victorian-inspired gowns, capelets, trousers, exposed shoulder and more
lead_paragraph: Victorian-inspired gowns, capelets, trousers, exposed shoulder and more

headline: In New Bridal Collections, Designers Look to the Runways
abstract: The spring 2017 collections mirrored recent runway looks with bared shoulders, boudoir inspirations and lots of pants.
lead_paragraph: This season, bridal designers plucked many of their most arresting ideas from the recent ready-to-wear runways. The spring 2017 collections, shown last week, mirrored a diversity of trends that first made a splash on the catwalks of New York, London, Paris and Milan.

headline: Some Good Credit News for the Met Opera
abstract: Standard & Poor’s affirmed the company’s “A” credit rating and revised its outlook to stable from negative.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera, which has been cutting costs in recent years to address its serious fiscal challenges, got a measure of good news on Wednesday when Standard & Poor’s affirmed the company’s “A” credit rating and revised its outlook to stable from negative.

headline: New York City Ballet Casts a Singular Luster in ‘Jewels’
abstract: This company opened its spring season by dancing this Balanchine tripartite.
lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet opened its six-week spring season at the David H. Koch Theater with George Balanchine’s tripartite “Jewels” on Tuesday evening. Nine of the company’s principals took part. The dancing of Tiler Peck and Amar Ramasar (“Emeralds”) and Sara Mearns, partnered superbly by Tyler Angle, (“Diamonds”) was lustrous, while that of the smaller-scaled Megan Fairchild and Gonzalo Garcia (“Rubies”) took them to fresh personal peaks of boldness. Teresa Reichlen, returning to the “Rubies” soloist role, achieved once more a standard that must make you wonder if the role has been better danced before or will be again.

headline: Artists Fight to Get Works Back From Ace Gallery
abstract: Dozens of artists could be affected by the decisions of a bankruptcy trustee appointed to run the Los Angeles gallery, founded in 1967.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Lawsuits by artists and collectors, seeking the return of consigned works, demanding profits, or both, have never stopped Douglas Chrismas, the founder of Ace Gallery, from doing business. An early champion of trailblazers like Robert Irwin, Richard Serra and Michael Heizer, Mr. Chrismas has spent nearly 50 years helping to start or jump-start the careers of artists here, even as he was scrutinized for sometimes failing to pay when works sold.

headline: Review: ‘American Visions,’ a Graceful Take on Race, Patriotism and Longing
abstract: A concert on Tuesday by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center featured collections of songs traversing a range of moods and serious themes.
lead_paragraph: “American Visions” was the title of the concert the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center presented at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday, the evening of the New York primaries. I don’t know if this was a result of shrewd planning or mere coincidence. But the program touched on hotly contested themes like patriotism, race and the legacy of slavery — and did so with a degree of subtlety and grace not often seen in politics.

headline: Obama in Saudi Arabia, Exporter of Oil and Bigotry
abstract: The Islamophobia festering in the U.S. is fed by extremism fostered by the Saudis.
lead_paragraph: A college senior boarded a flight and excitedly called his family to recount a United Nations event he had attended, but, unfortunately, he was speaking Arabic. Southwest Airlines kicked him off the plane, in the sixth case reported in the United States this year in which a Muslim was ejected from a flight.

headline: 2 Stars Rejoin Bucharest Opera’s Ballet Company After Clash
abstract: A Romanian government-brokered plan paved the way for the return of the company’s artistic director, Johan Kobborg, and the dancer Alina Cojocaru.
lead_paragraph: The crisis roiling the ballet company of the Bucharest National Opera in recent weeks rippled not only through the international dance world but through Romanian politics as well. And ultimately it was a government-brokered plan that paved the way for the return on Wednesday of the company’s two biggest stars: its artistic director, Johan Kobborg, and the dancer Alina Cojocaru, who both resigned this month after clashing with management over the direction of the company.

headline: Review: ASAP Ferg’s Big Heart Pulses on ‘Always Strive and Prosper’
abstract: The rapper’s second full-length album is chaotic and buoyant, moves at varying speeds and offers different textures.
lead_paragraph: “Always Strive and Prosper”

headline: Review: Ralph Peterson Jr. Powers a Runaway Freight Train
abstract: Mr. Peterson’s new album, “TriAngular III,” also features the brothers Zaccai Curtis, a pianist, and Luques Curtis, a bassist.
lead_paragraph: “TriAngular III”

headline: Review: The Strumbellas Show Off Roots Both Dark and Sunny on ‘Hope’
abstract: The Canadian band’s new album offers deep confessions and happy singalongs.
lead_paragraph: “Hope”

headline: Review: Exploring Women’s Lives in ‘When I Was a Girl I Used to Scream and Shout’
abstract: This play, by Sharman Macdonald, rides the waves of a turbulent mother-daughter relationship in a production by Fallen Angels Theater Company.
lead_paragraph: The Fallen Angels Theater Company’s revival of Sharman Macdonald’s 1984 play, “When I Was a Girl I Used to Scream and Shout,” deep-dives into the psyches of its largely female characters. And while you’ll feel cleansed by the healing conclusion, getting there requires immersion in a churning sea of teenage sexuality, parental expectations and maternal sacrifice.

headline: Observe Earth Day With a Nature Takeover in Times Square
abstract: “All day play” at Shen Beauty in Brooklyn, deals on cool sustainable fashion and jewelry, and more.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night, head to Times Square for a nature takeover from 11:30 p.m. to midnight. The electronic billboards will display “Jungle-ized,” a multisensory art installation directed by Stephan Crasneanscki of Soundwalk Collective and co-produced by the eco-adventurer David de Rothschild that promises to transform the concrete jungle into the heart of the Amazon. Mr. de Rothschild also has some nifty limited-edition items on The Lost Explorer website, including a palm-print market bag ($145) made from a World War II Royal Air force tool bag reworked with end-of-line vintage fabrics. At thelostexplorer.co.

headline: Tubman’s In. Jackson’s Out. What’s It Mean?
keywords: ['US Dollar (Currency)', 'Women and Girls', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)']
abstract: Harriet Tubman ascends to the $20, Alexander Hamilton gets to stay on the $10 — and nothing is actually happening for years. Three Times journalists discuss the changes to U.S. currency.
lead_paragraph: The United States is adding a few new faces to its currency. Harriet Tubman will appear on the front of a new $20 bill to be unveiled in 2020, and a pair of civil rights scenes, one featuring suffragist leaders, will appear on the backs of redesigned $5 and $10 bills, the Treasury Department said on Wednesday.

headline: Hearing Aid Prices Under Pressure From Consumer Electronics
keywords: ['Hearing Aids', 'Ears and Hearing', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Electronics']
abstract: Less expensive and widely available devices can assist with hearing, but the hearing aid industry contends these products differ greatly from theirs.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — At the Audiology Now! convention here last week, visitors stood next to blowing electric fans to experience how a new hearing aid could screen out wind noise. They donned goggles to attend a virtual reality dinner party to learn how new technology made it easier to hear conversations around them.

headline: Some Meteorites Are Million-Dollar Finds, Others Are ‘Meteorwrongs’
abstract: A meteorite found in Russia fetched a big price at auction, but most “space rocks” turn out to be just rocks.
lead_paragraph: This polished sphere was fashioned from a meteorite that crash-landed into a dry riverbed in Russia. On Wednesday it soared again, not through space but at an auction house, snagging $130,000 — nine times its asking price.

headline: After He Was Beaten, Rikers Inmate Was Sent to ‘the Box’
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Assaults', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: Jahmal Lightfoot said during the trial of nine correction officers accused of brutally attacking him that his suffering included 110 days of confinement.
lead_paragraph: Jahmal Lightfoot’s suffering did not end with a brutal beating at the hands of Rikers Island correction officers who wanted to teach him a lesson.

headline: Social Chatter: Tubman on the 20
abstract: The Treasury announced that instead of a woman replacing Alexander Hamilton on the $10 bill, Harriet Tubman would replace Andrew Jackson on the much more widely circulated $20 bill.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury announced that instead of a woman replacing Alexander Hamilton on the $10 bill, Harriet Tubman would replace Andrew Jackson on the much more widely circulated $20 bill.

headline: Viacom’s Woes May Deepen in Standoff With Dish Network
abstract: Viacom, already facing weak earnings and a legal battle over its leadership, may lose profits and have to cut costs if Dish permanently drops its channels.
lead_paragraph: On one level, the dispute between Dish Network and Viacom that brought the companies to the brink of a television blackout on Wednesday resembles others that have become relatively routine in the industry and a common annoyance for customers.

headline: Curt Schilling, ESPN Analyst, Is Fired Over Offensive Social Media Post
abstract: The former All-Star pitcher was fired from his position as an ESPN baseball analyst a day after he was criticized for promoting offensive commentary about transgender people.
lead_paragraph: Curt Schilling, a former All-Star pitcher and one of the highest-profile baseball analysts on ESPN, was fired from the network Wednesday, a day after he drew intense criticism for promoting offensive commentary on social media.

headline: Transgender Students Win on Restroom Rights
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Discrimination', 'Gender', 'Transgender and Transsexuals']
abstract: An appeals court affirms the right of transgender students to use restrooms based on their gender identity.
lead_paragraph: A federal appellate ruling on Tuesday protecting the right of transgender students to use restrooms according to their gender identity is an important marker in a national debate that has prompted battles in courtrooms and legislatures across the country.

headline: 2 New York Detectives Indicted in Beating of Mail Carrier
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Assaults', 'Postal Service and Post Offices']
abstract: The mail carrier, Karim Baker, said he had been repeatedly harassed by the police after he gave directions to a man who then killed two officers.
lead_paragraph: Two New York City police detectives have been charged with beating a uniformed Postal Service employee in Queens in October, according to an indictment released on Wednesday. The mail carrier has said that the police have harassed him since 2014, when he gave street directions to a stranger who then killed two police officers.

headline: Official Says ‘Reign of Terror’ Is Over for the Ninja Burglar
abstract: The authorities say that Robert Costanzo, who is in custody, is responsible for scores of burglaries on Staten Island and elsewhere over a decade.
lead_paragraph: He became known as the Ninja Burglar, an elusive figure who stoked fears in some of Staten Island’s most affluent neighborhoods by sneaking into homes, usually with his entire body covered, except for his eyes. He would grab jewelry, money and the occasional designer handbag, the authorities said, often while residents were still at home.

headline: For the Rangers or Against, Carl Hagelin Plays His Heroic Role
abstract: Hagelin was a leader for the Rangers last year in their playoff series against Pittsburgh. This year, he’s playing a crucial role on the Penguins’ penalty-killing unit.
lead_paragraph: Carl Hagelin was apparently too focused on carrying the puck up the ice for the Pittsburgh Penguins in the opening minutes of Tuesday’s playoff game at Madison Square Garden to notice that he was being booed — as if he were a villain.

headline: Kelly Ripa’s Absence From ‘Live’ Points to Rancor at ABC
abstract: Ms. Ripa, who was blindsided by the news of Michael Strahan’s departure from the show they co-host, said she will not appear on the show for the rest of the week.
lead_paragraph: It seemed like an innocent enough announcement: Michael Strahan, the former football player turned television personality, was shifting assignments on ABC’s morning lineup, the network said Tuesday. He would leave “Live With Kelly and Michael” in September to become a co-anchor on “Good Morning America.”

headline: Jackie Carter, Who Pushed for Racial Diversity in Children’s Books, Dies at 62
abstract: A publishing executive and writer, she devoted her career to editing and releasing books that might captivate minority children and also reflect their lives.
lead_paragraph: Jackie Carter, a publishing executive who promoted in children’s books the racial diversity she had missed growing up in a mostly white neighborhood, died on April 13 in Manhattan. She was 62.

headline: Bernie Sanders Has Trickier, Narrower Road in Democratic Race
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: The Vermont senator, after a loss in New York and with tough contests ahead, also faced calls from Hillary Clinton backers to take a less negative tone.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont grappled with tough and narrowing choices about campaign strategy and fund-raising on Wednesday after his crushing loss in the New York primary and with a series of difficult contests ahead.

headline: AEG Closer to Seizing New York Concert Industry With Bowery Deal
abstract: Industry executives said that the deal would effectively turn the New York market into a battleground between AEG and Live Nation Entertainment.
lead_paragraph: The booming concert industry, already dominated by two corporate powers, is getting even more consolidated.

headline: Volkswagen Deal on Emissions Cheating in U.S. Is Expected
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Diesel Power', 'Automobiles', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: A deal, if completed, is expected to include fines from regulators and compensation to owners that could cost Volkswagen billions of dollars.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen is close to completing a deal to resolve claims in the United States over its admission that it rigged vehicles to cheat on pollution tests, according to three people involved in the case.

headline: Library of Congress Nominee Gets Senate Hearing
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: If confirmed, Carla D. Hayden would be the first woman and the first African-American to hold the position.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A prominent Obama administration nominee was extended a courtesy Wednesday that has become increasingly rare this election year: a Senate hearing.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: Plans to build a $3.3 billion natural gas pipeline from New York into New England through western Massachusetts and southern New Hampshire have been suspended. Kinder Morgan Inc. of Houston announced Wednesday it had decided to stop work on the project, citing a lack of contracts with gas distribution companies. It also said New England states have not established needed regulatory procedures to allow it to move forward. The company said that given the market conditions, continuing to develop the pipeline is an unacceptable use of its shareholder funds. The project has been met with skepticism and opposition, both from residents along the proposed path of the pipeline and from environmental groups that welcomed Wednesday’s decision to halt work.(AP)

lead_paragraph: Nazik Armenakyan has made it her mission to document the dwindling number of people who survived the Armenian genocide a century ago.

headline: C.I.A. to Pay Death Benefits to Relatives of Terror Victims
abstract: The agency will pay death benefits to families of unmarried and childless federal employees or contractors killed in acts of terrorism overseas.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For almost two years, the family of Glen Doherty, a C.I.A. contractor and former Navy SEAL who was among four Americans killed in the 2012 terrorist attack in Benghazi, Libya, has fought to claim the government death benefits they believe Mr. Doherty deserved.

headline: Pearl Washington, 52, Dies; Dazzling Guard Put Syracuse on Basketball Map
abstract: A charismatic point guard who achieved legend status as a Brooklyn schoolboy, he helped lift Syracuse University to national prominence in basketball and went on to play in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: Dwayne Washington, better known as Pearl, a charismatic point guard who achieved legend status as a Brooklyn schoolboy before moving upstate, where he helped lift Syracuse University to national prominence in basketball, died on Wednesday in the Bronx. He was 52.

headline: A Guard Out of Brooklyn Inspired Wonder and Fond Memories
abstract: Pearl Washington, one of the most celebrated guards from the borough, became the face of Syracuse’s basketball program.
lead_paragraph: Elmer Anderson got the news early Wednesday morning. His former high school teammate, soul mate and friend, Dwayne Washington — known far and wide as Pearl — had died.

headline: Trending at Halftime: N.B.A. Players Checking Their Phones
abstract: Apparently, even the N.B.A. locker room (at halftime!) is no sanctuary from the practice of habitually checking texts and social media mentions.
lead_paragraph: The professional sports locker room is a sanctuary, a place that is supposed to be free of outside distractions. At halftime of an N.B.A. game, for instance, players sit attentively, absorbing the coach’s instructions. They rehydrate, and maybe even change into a fresh uniform. Their focus for those 15 minutes rests entirely on what must be done in the second half to win the game.

headline: Senators Consider Funding Plan to Address Zika Threat
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: An agreement would mark a reversal by Republicans who had been reluctant to approve more aid.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate may be nearing an agreement on emergency funding to respond to the growing threat from the Zika virus, marking a potential reversal by Republicans who had been reluctant to approve more aid.

headline: Speed Hurts: Jeff Passan Talks About Baseball’s Arm Troubles
abstract: In his new book, “The Arm,” Mr. Passan examines the crisis of elbow injuries among pitchers, and how baseball is (and isn’t) dealing with the problem.
lead_paragraph: Tommy John first pitched in the major leagues when he was 20. He retired at 46, having won 288 games, the seventh-highest total for a left-handed pitcher in baseball history. But he’s a household name today not for what he did on the mound, but for what was done to him on an operating table. In 1974, he underwent what is now known as Tommy John surgery, an experimental (at the time) procedure to repair his ulnar collateral ligament (UCL). The elbow injury is now so common that about a quarter of big-league pitchers have had the surgery — some returning from it more successfully than others.

headline: Who Controls the New York State Senate? It’s Complicated.
abstract: Even if the results of the election to replace Dean G. Skelos give state Democrats a majority, little, if anything, could change between now and November.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Democrats awoke on Wednesday tantalizingly close to having a numerical majority in the State Senate, claiming victory in the Long Island district vacated by Dean G. Skelos, the former Republican majority leader convicted of federal corruption charges in December.

headline: M.T.A. Spending Plan Restores Funding for 2nd Ave. Subway
abstract: The $29.5 billion plan, approved by the transportation authority’s board, also calls for hundreds of new train cars and buses and a new fare system to replace the MetroCard.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s board approved a new version of its long-delayed capital plan on Wednesday, allocating money for system upgrades and expansion projects and restoring funding for the next phase of the Second Avenue subway line.

headline: New York Attorney General Opens Inquiry Into Primary Day Complaints
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters', 'Elections']
abstract: Eric T. Schneiderman’s office said it had received more than 1,000 complaints from people across the state, many of whom tried to vote but were told they weren’t registered.
lead_paragraph: The New York State attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, announced on Wednesday that his office was opening an investigation into potential voting irregularities during the presidential primary on Tuesday, when New York City’s Board of Elections found itself besieged by complaints that it had dropped thousands of Democratic voters from the rolls in Brooklyn, among other issues.

headline: Not Sold on TV
abstract: Alex Bajcz returns to remind us that the English language is more forgiving than it seems.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — The English language is quirky, to say the least, especially when it comes to pronunciation. Today’s puzzle by Alex Bajcz highlights how forgiving it can be as well.

headline: Iran Not Seeking Entry to U.S. Financial System, Envoy Says
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif said American officials must do more to assure other countries that they could do business in Iran without risking penalties.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s foreign minister on Wednesday disputed suggestions that Iran now wanted access to the American financial system as part of the nuclear accord, which has not yet yielded the economic infusion that Iranians foresaw after the deal took effect in January.

headline: William M. Gray, Hurricane Predictor and Climate Change Skeptic, Dies at 86
abstract: Dr. Gray aggregated measures of atmospheric conditions, water current and water temperature to predict the number and intensity of tropical storms.
lead_paragraph: William M. Gray, whose pioneering research helped him make hurricane predictions for three decades and allowed the East Coast and the Caribbean to gird for their fury, died on Saturday in Fort Collins, Colo. He was 86.

headline: Circuitous Path Leads to a Higher Ground
abstract: Rich Hill, who left a stable job with a Nationals affiliate in Syracuse, wound up as a starter for the Athletics this season.
lead_paragraph: We think of the opt-out clause as an escape hatch, a way for a free agent to break one lucrative contract and seek another. At Class AAA, though, the opt-out clause is a ticket to opportunity — a lottery ticket, really, a gamble with uncertain odds.

headline: Frederick Mayer, Jew Who Spied on Nazis After Fleeing Germany, Dies at 94
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: Seven years after leaving Germany with his family, Mr. Mayer parachuted into Austria as an American spy and helped to hasten the Nazi surrender.
lead_paragraph: Frederick Mayer, who as a German Jew fled Nazi Germany for Brooklyn as a teenager in 1938, only to parachute back into Nazi-controlled Austria seven years later as an American spy on an improbable secret mission, died on April 15 in Charles Town, W.Va. He was 94.

headline: ‘The Americans’ Season 4, Episode 6: Can Anyone Be Trusted?
abstract: Trust is an oft-repeated theme in this episode, but Martha might have put hers in the wrong hands.
lead_paragraph: “The Americans” gave us what we wanted on Wednesday night — well, what a lot of us wanted, I suspect. The episode, “The Rat,” was the apotheosis of Martha Hanson. (Until next week, anyway.) The mousy secretary was the most important person onscreen. The F.B.I. sent bulletins across the country because of her while the Rezidentura prepared a sudden exfiltration to Moscow. She was so important, it turned out, that Arkady couldn’t even tell his people what she’d been doing. (Will the disaffected Oleg get involved, one way or another, in Martha’s fate?)

headline: Late Base-Running Blunder Adds to Yankees’ Frustrations on Offense
abstract: A gaffe by Didi Gregorius helped to end a threat in the seventh inning for the Yankees, who continue to struggle with runners in scoring position.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Eovaldi witnessed a series of unlikely events Wednesday at Yankee Stadium during his third start of the season, but one increasingly common occurrence — the Yankees’ failing to produce with runners in scoring position — left him on the wrong side of a 5-2 loss to the Oakland Athletics.

headline: Panthers Tie Series as Defenseman’s Goal Decides Game
abstract: Florida defenseman Alex Petrovic had the only goal of the final period, and the Panthers held on to knot their best-of-seven series with the Islanders at two games each.
lead_paragraph: The Islanders came into Game 4 with a chance to go up by three games to one on the Florida Panthers, a postseason situation the franchise has not experienced since 1993.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, April 21, 2016.
lead_paragraph: We are not quite back in a Cold War. But I sure can see one from where I’m standing.

headline: In Extras for the First Time This Season, the Mets’ Bullpen Falters
abstract: It took 14 games for the Mets to encounter extra innings, and when they did, they lost, 5-4, in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: It took 14 games for the Mets to encounter extra innings this season and when they did, on Wednesday night, the result was not a happy one. They lost, 5-4, in Philadelphia, with reliever Hansel Robles surrendering the winning run in the bottom of the 11th on a two-out infield hit by Peter Bourjos.

headline: Timberwolves Hire Tom Thibodeau as Coach
abstract: Thibodeau, who most recently coached the Bulls, will be in charge of an intriguing young roster while also serving as Minnesota’s president of basketball operations.
lead_paragraph: Tom Thibodeau, who spent the past season on a basketball sabbatical, agreed Wednesday to become the coach and president of basketball operations of the Minnesota Timberwolves, a team with one of the N.B.A.’s more intriguing and precocious cores.

abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, April 21, 2016.

headline: What’s On Thursday
abstract: Amy Schumer raps for Lin-Manuel Miranda. Pras Michel helps Michel Martelly become president of Haiti. And choose between leading men in two versions of “Pride and Prejudice.”
lead_paragraph: “Inside Amy Schumer” goes gutsy — and patriotic — as Ms. Schumer raps for Lin-Manuel Miranda. Pras Michel, of the Fugees, helps his friend Michel Martelly win election as president of Haiti. And take your pick of swoonworthy leading men in dueling versions of “Pride and Prejudice.”

headline: E.C.B. Stands Pat at Meeting, but It Explores Next Options
abstract: After a sweeping series of monetary moves in March, the European Central Bank paused to measure their impact before taking further steps.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank left its main interest rates and stimulus tools unchanged at its meeting on Thursday, with its president forcefully arguing that the bank’s aggressive monetary policy moves had bolstered economic growth and warded off negative inflation in the eurozone.

headline: Behind Mitsubishi’s Faked Data, Fierce Competition
abstract: The latest automaker scandal has focused attention on the company’s struggles in the brutally competitive Japanese microcar market.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — In most of the world, few consumers even know microcars exist. But in Japan, the tiny vehicles, whose fuel consumption is as small as their price tags, are a crucial battleground for domestic automakers.

headline: Survivors of the Armenian Genocide
keywords: ['Armenians', 'Photography', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Nazik Armenakyan has made it her mission to document the dwindling number of people who survived the Armenian genocide a century ago.
lead_paragraph: Nazik Armenakyan has spent the last decade in a desperate race against death: She has been scouring Armenia searching for survivors of the Armenian genocide. She is determined to photograph them and provide an enduring document of their experiences a century ago.

headline: Why Mass Incarceration Doesn’t Pay
keywords: ['Sentences (Criminal)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Mandatory Sentencing', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The costs of our tough sentencing laws have come to outweigh the benefits. It is time to reform them.
lead_paragraph: Washington — THE growth in the nation’s prison population has been nothing short of staggering. The United States’ incarceration rate is now more than four times the world average, with about 2.2 million people in prisons and jails. Of those, roughly 200,000 are federal inmates, double the number from 20 years ago. This substantial increase occurred even as violent crime was falling sharply.

headline: Overtime Pay: A Lifeline for the Overworked American
keywords: ['Overtime', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Working Hours', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Most laborers used to get paid extra for working extra. What happened?
lead_paragraph: THIS summer the Department of Labor is expected to introduce new rules to restore overtime pay to millions of Americans — rules that require no congressional approval. From the fearful protests coming from Republican leadership, you’d think the sky was falling. “This mandate on employers will hurt the lowest paid American workers the most, by reducing their opportunities for a promotion or a better job,” said Senator Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, the chairman of the Health, Education, Labor and Pensions Committee.

headline: The Democrats After Sanders
abstract: The next generation has ambitious ideas to stamp a thorough left-wing party. Can it build one?
lead_paragraph: Before the Bernie Sanders crusade, whose dream of victory was extinguished in New York’s primary on Tuesday, the future of the Democratic Party seemed likely to resemble the final six years of the Obama era, only more so: a party increasingly ideological and left-wing on social issues and more incrementalist and technocratic in the economic realm.

headline: The Pentagon Insults Its Afghan Victims
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Civilian Casualties', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Hospitals']
abstract: The American military has provided inadequate compensation, and few answers, to the victims of a hospital it bombed by mistake.
lead_paragraph: The American military has often put a price on the lives of civilians it has killed in Iraq and Afghanistan. By making so-called condolence payments — which range from a few hundred dollars to tens of thousands — commanders have sought to compensate victims’ families for dead relatives, injuries and damaged property.

headline: How Donald Trump Could Win the Nomination Outright
abstract: It’s still not easy, but is now clearly possible, to avoid a contested convention. How it might go.
lead_paragraph: After a forceful win in New York, Donald Trump has a narrow but real path to 1,237 delegates, the number required to avoid a contested convention.

headline: Bankers in the Age of Bernie: Do They Need Camouflage?
abstract: The stereotypical uniform of their profession may no longer exist.
lead_paragraph: He came, he lost, but his rhetoric continues.

headline: Fractured: A First Date
keywords: ['Bars and Nightclubs', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: It wasn’t my heart that he broke.
lead_paragraph: I was going out. I deserved it. I’d had lunch — one Diet Coke, two Marlboro Lights and a Chef’s Signature Lean Cuisine. I’d even done two luxurious miles in 24 minutes on the treadmill at the gym down the block. My stomach growled, angry for being empty, but I felt thin and attractive. There’s nothing more dangerous than a girl who feels thin and attractive.

headline: If Police Stairwell Shooting Was Accidental, Circumstances Around It Were Not
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Poverty', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Elevators and Escalators', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Now that former Officer Peter Liang has avoided prison for fatally shooting Akai Gurley, questions turn to the broken elevator, broken lights and police practice that made the deadly episode possible.
lead_paragraph: As Akai Gurley left his girlfriend’s apartment in a Brooklyn housing project one November night two years ago, he tried to take an elevator to the street, but found that it was broken. Had it been working, Mr. Gurley might never have set foot into the stairwell where he died.

headline: A Move to East Flatbush, Brooklyn
abstract: Sara Grace Cast and Dan Cast went house-hunting in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, when Sara Grace Rimensnyder met Dan Cast, she was living in a small one-bedroom apartment on the fifth floor of a walk-up building on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

headline: How Hillary Clinton Became a Hawk
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: Throughout her career she has displayed instincts on foreign policy that are more aggressive than those of President Obama — and most Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton sat in the hideaway study off her ceremonial office in the State Department, sipping tea and taking stock of her first year on the job. The study was more like a den — cozy and wood-paneled, lined with bookshelves that displayed mementos from Clinton’s three decades in the public eye: a statue of her heroine, Eleanor Roosevelt; a baseball signed by the Chicago Cubs star Ernie Banks; a carved wooden figure of a pregnant African woman. The intimate setting lent itself to a less-formal interview than the usual locale, her imposing outer office, with its marble fireplace, heavy drapes, crystal chandelier and ornate wall sconces. On the morning of Feb. 26, 2010, however, Clinton was talking about something more sensitive than mere foreign affairs: her relationship with Barack Obama. To say she chose her words carefully doesn’t do justice to the delicacy of the exercise. She was like a bomb-squad technician, deciding which color wire to snip without blowing up her relationship with the White House.

headline: With Seattle Shelter Effort, Amazon Shows Glimmers of a ‘Good Neighbor’
abstract: The tech giant is working with a nonprofit to temporarily house the homeless. City officials hope it’s not just a one-time act of civic-mindedness.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon’s new urban headquarters — more than 30 office buildings and three towers that, once completed, will dominate a low-slung section of the city — are a gleaming symbol of boom times here. The tech giant has added 20,000 new jobs in Seattle and attracted other tech companies that want to rub elbows. Google plans to expand here as well, with four new buildings and perhaps 4,000 workers. Smaller start-ups dot old brick neighborhoods like Pioneer Square, and newer developments like South Lake Union, where Amazon is building.

headline: Vancouver Prescriptions for Addicts Gain Attention as Heroin and Opioid Use Rises
abstract: Treatment known as heroin maintenance has helped keep users out of jail and away from emergency rooms, but concerns about drug abuse stymie such programs in the United States.
lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — Dave Napio started doing heroin over four decades ago, at 11 years old. Like many addicts these days, he heads to Vancouver’s gritty Downtown Eastside neighborhood when he needs a fix.

headline: Student Question | Is It Ethical to Genetically Engineer Animals?
abstract: Are the risks inherent in tinkering with animal DNA worth the potential rewards?
lead_paragraph: New technologies have made genetically engineering animals relatively easy to accomplish. Salmon can be modified to grow faster. Mosquito genes can be edited to combat diseases like malaria and the Zika virus. Pigs can be altered so their organs might some day be transplanted to humans.

headline: China’s President, Xi Jinping, Gains a New Title: Commander in Chief
abstract: The title reflects the president’s desire to have a more direct role over the armed forces, a professor said.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A camouflage-clad President Xi Jinping appeared on Wednesday at the joint battle command center of China’s Central Military Commission, where he urged officers to build a command system that was “capable of winning wars,” according to state news reports.

headline: Tracy Chevalier’s ‘At the Edge of the Orchard’ and Jane Hamilton’s ‘The Excellent Lombards’
abstract: Two novels center on the drama of the orchards.
lead_paragraph: It can’t be great, even for a best-­selling author, to find out that a second best-selling author has also written a new novel about a family’s obsession with its apple orchard. Think of the potential for confusion. Or all the weak “how do you like them apples” jokes that might have to be endured at readings. But the latest ­Tracy Chevalier and Jane Hamilton novels, stylistically distinct, respectively, as plot-heavy historical fiction and leisurely evocative contemporary literature, form a complementary double feature. Paired, they make the case that the beautiful lunacy of trying to earn a living from the land hasn’t changed all that much in the last two centuries.
