headline: Obama Reassures Persian Gulf Allies About Security
abstract: The president ended a meeting in Saudi Arabia with the leaders of six Persian Gulf nations after talks on the American commitment to the region amid a rapprochement with Iran.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — President Obama said on Thursday that the United States would continue to enhance security cooperation with its allies in the Persian Gulf, while encouraging them to carry out domestic reforms and bolster their ability to defend themselves.

headline: Hillary Clinton to Discuss Gun Violence in Connecticut With Sandy Hook Families
abstract: Two days after her victory in the New York primary, Mrs. Clinton, who regularly criticizes Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont for being weak on gun control issues, will discuss gun violence with the relatives of those who died in the 2012 elementary school shooting.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s focus on gun control will continue on Thursday when she heads to Connecticut to meet with families of victims of the Sandy Hook shooting before the state’s primary next week.

headline: A World of Flavor, Stuffed Into Tacos at El Molcajete
abstract: This restaurant in Soundview, the Bronx, excels at succulent meats.
lead_paragraph: At El Molcajete, the tacos look like bouquets, brimming with cilantro, loosely bundled in paper sleeves twisted tight at one end and gaping at the mouth. They are heavy with meat: hanks of shredded barbacoa, dark and caramelly cecina, cabeza more a stage of melt than flesh.

headline: Morning Agenda: Global Stock Rally
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Cheating', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: Change for a $20 | Volkswagen Deal Expected
lead_paragraph: GLOBAL STOCK RALLY  | Stock, oil and steel prices were all on their way up for a fourth day on Thursday, as Bloomberg reports. European shares were up slightly ahead of the European Central Bank policy meeting, while Asia shares reached a four-month high.

headline: Why Do Girls Tend to Have More Anxiety Than Boys?
abstract: The toxic effects of social media especially harm girls. Parents can make a difference.
lead_paragraph: The laid-back, underachieving boy; the hyperachieving, anxious girl. Over the three decades since I graduated from medical school, and especially over the past 10 years, this pattern has become increasingly common in my practice.

headline: Chyna, Pro Wrestler Turned Reality TV Star, Is Dead at 46
abstract: Born Joanie Laurer, she was initially not a fan of the sport but joined a wrestling school led by Killer Kowalski, a dominant figure from the 1950s to the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Joanie Laurer, who studied Spanish literature and trained with the Peace Corps before gaining fame as the professional wrestler Chyna and as a reality-television star, was found dead on Wednesday at her home in Redondo Beach, Calif. She was 46.

headline: Andy Cohen: By the Book
abstract: The talk-show host, producer and author of “The Andy Cohen Diaries” is a “Fountainhead” fan: “I like to think of myself as a Howard Roark type, but then I realize I’m the ‘Housewives’ guy.”
lead_paragraph: The talk-show host, producer and author of “The Andy Cohen Diaries” is a “Fountainhead” fan: “I like to think of myself as a Howard Roark type, but then I realize I’m the ‘Housewives’ guy.”

headline: Letter of Recommendation: AstroTurf
abstract: It remains an object strangely out of time, like a souvenir from an era when the domestic aesthetic was all ersatz nostalgia.
lead_paragraph: On a lawn drawn long by sunset, who is not intoxicated? That cut-grass scent, cis-3-hexanol, is called leaf alcohol. You don’t need to name it to know it, the wooziness of air strewn by a mower. Still, I love a lawn overgrown and skimmed by the wind. Liminal hours are the best to enjoy it: dawn, dusk. A great green floor, pinned by dandelion clocks.

headline: What Chatbots Reveal About Our Own Shortcomings
abstract: Silicon Valley has fallen in love with A.I. assistants, but so far they’re hardly impressive. Is it the industry’s fault, or is it ours?
lead_paragraph: Every so often, an idea comes along that mesmerizes Silicon Valley and convinces the most powerful people there that this innovation will irrevocably alter the course of humankind. Outsize proclamations are made, lavish events are held and millions of dollars in venture money are funneled into young, unproven companies. Right now, that fixation has landed on chatbots, little artificial-intelligence programs that work like personalized assistants.

headline: How (and Where) to Celebrate the Queen’s 90th Birthday
abstract: Britain turns up the pomp and circumstance with a parade in London, a traveling exhibition of the queen’s outfits ane performances at Windsor Castle.
lead_paragraph: London is a popular destination anytime, but this year there is even more of a reason to visit: the 90th birthday of Queen Elizabeth II. Though her birth date is April 21, the city is celebrating the occasion with events starting in May.

headline: Cindy Sherman Takes On Aging (Her Own)
abstract: The artist’s new photographs are more explicitly autobiographical than ever. But a move toward film may be next.
lead_paragraph: “Tell me what to do,” Cindy Sherman said, asking the photographer for guidance as she sat for her portrait. Her words seem almost comic, since she is posing in her own New York studio, staring out at her camera and the mirror she keeps perched beside it, and the one thing she has proved, across a career that turned 40 this year, is that she has known what to “do” in this setting.

headline: How to Travel the Earth And Protect It, Too
abstract: We asked leading environmentalists how to plan a trip that won’t wreck the earth. Here is what they told us.
lead_paragraph: We asked leading environmentalists how to plan a trip that won’t wreck the earth. Here is what they told us.

headline: Donald Trump’s Campaign Evolution Might Take Some Time
abstract: Mr. Trump was back to familiar form at rallies in Indiana and Maryland on Wednesday. He made references to Senator Ted Cruz of Texas as “Lyin’ Ted” and Hillary Clinton as “Crooked Hillary” and, when protesters interrupted, he urged security to “Get ’em outta here!”
lead_paragraph: Forcing change in Donald J. Trump’s message, as his new advisers are trying to do, is likely to take some time.

headline: First Draft Focus: Throwback Thursday — A Challenger Expresses His Gratitude
abstract: Senator Edward M. Kennedy went to Grand Central Terminal on March 26, 1980, to thank New Yorkers for his upset victory over President Jimmy Carter in the Democratic presidential primary the day before.

headline: China’s ‘Dangerous Love’ Campaign, Warning of Spies, Is Met With Shrugs
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Posters', 'Dating and Relationships', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Posters around Beijing are warning young women that handsome foreigners wooing them may be spies, but many seem unconvinced.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Clutching a bouquet of red roses from the auburn-haired foreigner who has also showered her with wine and compliments, Ms. Li thinks to herself, “Having a handsome, romantic, talented foreign boyfriend is pretty nice!”

headline: Brexit’s Threat to ‘the Special Relationship’
keywords: ['Referendums', 'United States International Relations', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The great trans-Atlantic alliance was premised on Britain’s commitment to European unity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On June 23, Britons will go to the polls in a nationwide referendum on a single question: Should their country remain in the European Union or leave it? Their answer will determine government policy.

headline: Leaders Roll Up Sleeves on Climate, but Experts Say Plans Don’t Pack a Wallop
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'International Relations']
abstract: Unless countries develop more ambitious plans, they say, the world could suffer profound consequences, including debilitating heat waves, food shortages and fast-rising seas.
lead_paragraph: An airport hangar outside Paris shook with cheers, toasts and foot-stomping in December as diplomats ushered a landmark climate agreement into existence. On Friday morning, world leaders will gather again at the United Nations for a grand ceremony to sign the document.

headline: North Korea Proposes Having 13 Defectors to the South Meet With Relatives
abstract: Seoul dismissed the offer as propaganda, reiterating that the 12 waitresses and a male manager from a restaurant run by the North Korean government in China had left of their own free will.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea proposed on Thursday to send family members to meet with 13 North Korean restaurant workers who arrived in South Korea this month in what was described by the South as a rare group defection.

headline: Pay Disparity in U.S. Soccer? It’s Complicated
abstract: The players on the U.S. women’s national soccer team earn less than those on the men’s team. After that, things are murkier.
lead_paragraph: The United States women’s national team sued U.S. Soccer for gender discrimination in federal court in March 2019, citing what the players said were pervasive inequalities in the treatment of their team and the men’s national team. On Friday, a judge dismissed the players’ equal pay claims. This primer, from 2016, explains in broad terms (and using numbers from that time) the differing pay structures under which the teams are paid by U.S. Soccer.

headline: Norman the Street Man
abstract: A former East Side resident recalls the panhandler who would keep regular hours on his corner, like a neighborhood watch.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: No Anonymity for Plaintiffs Suing Ashley Madison Over Hack, Judge Rules
abstract: Forty-two plaintiffs suing over a hacking attack that revealed the personal data of millions of users will have to be publicly identified to proceed.
lead_paragraph: Plaintiffs suing Ashley Madison, a popular online dating service, over a computer hacking attack that stole the personal data of millions of users will have to be publicly identified to proceed with the case, a federal judge ruled.

headline: Fierce Bidding War Erupts for French Retailer Darty
abstract: The French retailer Fnac and the French unit of Steinhoff International Holdings dueled on Thursday for Darty, the French electronics and appliance retailer.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A frantic bidding war for the French electronics and appliance retailer Darty erupted on Thursday as the French unit of Steinhoff International Holdings and the French retailer Groupe Fnac both announced a series of sweetened offers for the company.

headline: ‘Buddy Check on 22!’ Veterans Use Social Media to Fight Suicide
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Social Media', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: Facebook pages, video challenges, mobile apps and other tools engage the bonds forged on the battlefield as a platform for prevention.
lead_paragraph: “Buddy check on 22! Where are my warriors?!” That was how E. Michael Davis, a former Army sergeant, greeted his Facebook friends one afternoon last month.

headline: Blackstone Profit Plummets in First Quarter
abstract: Investors had expected a drop in results at Blackstone, the private equity giant, because of last year’s outsize performance.
lead_paragraph: The Blackstone Group, the private equity giant, suffered a sharp 77 percent decline in its net income for the first quarter, as volatile market conditions kept the firm from unloading assets and cashing in rich performance fees.

headline: Ted Cruz Was Wrong on Murders in New York, but Perception Is Hard to Shake
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Headlines based on small sample sizes and political opportunism could affect the path of criminal justice reform.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz’s campaign was wrong last week in saying that New York City murders were up 10 percent. But it wasn’t the first time, and surely won’t be the last, that crime statistics for the city and elsewhere are misunderstood and misrepresented.

headline: Lazard’s Revenue Declines in Quarter
abstract: The firm said revenue from its financial advisory business fell 12 percent because of fewer transactions closed compared with a year ago.
lead_paragraph: Last year’s record in mergers and acquisitions may not yet be trickling into the coffers of advisory shops.

headline: Damien Hirst’s Art May Have Leaked Formaldehyde Fumes, Study Says
abstract: The British artist is known for works that displayed animals suspended in the carcinogenic compound, but they may have exposed visitors or staff members.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British artist Damien Hirst shot to fame, in part, through works that displayed sharks and other animals suspended in formaldehyde. Now, a report from a British scientific journal has found that some of those works may have leaked formaldehyde fumes at levels much higher than allowed.

headline: Young Panthers, and Their Veteran Leader, Are on the Ascent
abstract: Florida evened its Eastern Conference quarterfinal against the Islanders at two games apiece.
lead_paragraph: The first bus was to depart Barclays Center in 20 minutes late Wednesday night, but Jaromir Jagr lingered at his locker. The Florida Panthers were not leaving without him, and besides, he had something else he wanted to say.

headline: Ownership Dispute Postpones Exhibitions of Nazi-era Dealer’s Art
abstract: Exhibitions at two museums planned for later this year of artworks amassed by a Nazi-era art dealer have been postponed because of a continuing legal dispute over the ownership of the 1,500-piece collection.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Exhibitions at two museums of artworks amassed by a Nazi-era art dealer planned for later this year have been postponed because of a continuing legal dispute over the ownership of the 1,500-piece collection.

headline: A Canopy Where Les Halles Once Reigned Gets Parisian Welcome
keywords: ['Shopping Centers and Malls', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: La Canopée, rising at the site of the storied market that Paris demolished in 1971, is greeted with resignation, relief and lamentation for what is no longer there.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Paris has never quite gotten over the destruction of Les Halles.

headline: Biden Looks Back, Aspirations Intact
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: In an interview, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. comments on the Democratic race and reflects on the span of his own career with satisfaction.
lead_paragraph: Having passed on the 2016 presidential race, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. watches the fight for the Democratic nomination with a mixture of longing and restlessness.

headline: A Hot App Discovers Virality, and Its Downsides
abstract: As the creators of Down to Lunch have discovered, immense popularity can lead to an array of problems.
lead_paragraph: Automating friendship may be a laudable goal, but that doesn’t mean it’s going to be pretty.

headline: Moving PDFs to a PC From an iPad
abstract: Common PDF reader apps for the iPad give you ways to transfer the files on your tablet to your computer
lead_paragraph: Q. I’d like to move all the PDFs on my iPad over to my Windows computer. How would I do that?

headline: Ecuadorean President on Quake Recovery
abstract: President Rafael Correa warned that the recovery from this weekend's earthquake would take years, calling it the country's worst natural disaster since the 1949 earthquake in Ambato.
lead_paragraph: President Rafael Correa warned that the recovery from this weekend's earthquake would take years, calling it the country's worst natural disaster since the 1949 earthquake in Ambato.

headline: Chinese Designer’s Haven
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Han Feng’s apartment is in the famous Jin Jiang Hotel complex, one of Shanghai’s premier residential addresses.
lead_paragraph: Han Feng’s apartment is in the famous Jin Jiang Hotel complex, one of Shanghai’s premier residential addresses.

headline: 1916: India Loyal to King-Emperor
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Indians prove loyal to the British Raj in 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Of all the miscalculations the Germans have made in the present war, none could have been more egregious than their conviction that India would seize the opportunity of Britain’s involvement in a European war to rise in revolt against the British Raj; no disappointment greater than the realization that the Indians, on the contrary, should prove so magnificently loyal to their King-Emperor. — The New York Herald, European Edition, April 22, 1916

headline: Truth and Reconciliation in Indonesia
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A symposium this week finally confronts the horrors of Suharto’s crackdown. But justice has yet to be served.
lead_paragraph: Indonesia’s symposium this week to discuss the mass killings that took place during anti-Communist purges in 1965 and 1966 marked an important first step toward national healing. The government of President Joko Widodo deserves praise for its willingness, at last, to confront the past. What needs to follow is a process that will bring the guilty to justice, encourage national reconciliation and ensure that such horrors never again occur.

headline: Utah’s War on Pornography Finds Skeptics
abstract: The governor signed new measures and cited a public health crisis comparable to smoking and alcohol abuse, but critics ask, where’s the science?
lead_paragraph: The governor of Utah signed two pieces of legislation in recent weeks in an effort to portray pornography as a public health crisis akin to alcohol and tobacco.

headline: Ruling on Pension Fund Debt Could Shake Up Private Equity Industry
abstract: A judge found that two private equity funds were liable for the pension fund debt of a company they acquired, a ruling that could affect other firms.
lead_paragraph: Libby Lewis is a journalist who has written about the private equity industry for the Edmond J. Safra Center for Ethics at Harvard.

headline: Tribeca Interview: Tom Hiddleston
abstract: The actor jokes that he apologizes for being in so many productions right now, including “High-Rise,” “I Saw the Light” and “The Night Manager.”
lead_paragraph: If you’re looking for a project with Tom Hiddleston in it at the moment, you don’t have to look far. Currently on the big screen, he’s playing Hank Williams in the biopic “I Saw the Light.” Currently on the small screen, he plays the hotel manager Jonathan Pine in the mini-series adaptation of John le Carré’s “The Night Manager.” And coming to screens both big and small, he’s playing Dr. Robert Laing in the film adaptation of the satirical J. G. Ballard Novel “High-Rise.” That film, which imagines an apartment building where the wealthy get the best views and services and the poor are relegated to lower floors, is at the Tribeca Film Festival now, and will be on demand April 28 and in theaters May 13.

headline: Anohni: Embracing a New Name, and Sound
abstract: The singer and songwriter once known as Antony Hegarty has become starkly political on her new album, “Hopelessness.”
lead_paragraph: Anohni — the songwriter and singer formerly known as Antony Hegarty — decided a few years ago to utterly transform the sound and message of her music. She had built an international career in the realm of art-pop as the leader of Antony and the Johnsons, singing sustained, vulnerable, imagistic chamber-pop ballads to an audience that hung on every vulnerable word. But in six years between studio albums, she not only renamed herself with what she calls her “spirit name” but also set herself on a stark new artistic course.

headline: Metropolitan Museum of Art Plans Job Cuts and Restructuring
keywords: ['Art', 'Museums', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Credit and Debt', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Finances']
abstract: The museum, facing a deficit and acknowledging that it has overreached in some areas, is changing course on construction and reducing programming.
lead_paragraph: The last couple of years have been ambitious ones for the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Perhaps too ambitious.

headline: Wondering What Caused the Cancer
abstract: Many of my patients ask what caused their cancer. I often wonder the same thing.
lead_paragraph: “But what caused it?” my patient asked, referring to the failure of her bone marrow to make the blood cells the rest of her organs craved. She was profoundly anemic and seemed to tire from even asking the question.

headline: SunEdison Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: The renewable energy development company, which grew rapidly in recent years, said it aimed to shed assets to streamline its business.
lead_paragraph: SunEdison, which started out making chemicals and components for solar modules but grew into a giant of renewable energy, has filed for bankruptcy protection, the company said on Thursday. The filing, under Chapter 11 in the Southern District of New York, brings to an end the company’s ambition to become the world’s leading renewable energy development business.

headline: Conor McGregor Says He Isn’t Retiring From the U.F.C. After All
abstract: The U.F.C. star released a statement saying he was frustrated with a heavy promotional load, but said he was willing to fight as scheduled in July.
lead_paragraph: Actually, Conor McGregor has not retired.

headline: Quiz: Is Your Shakespeare Sharper Than a Serpent's Tooth?
abstract: Shakespeare shuffled off his mortal coil 400 years ago this weekend. As the world prepares to celebrate the anniversary, test your knowledge of the Bard with this quiz.
lead_paragraph: Shakespeare shuffled off his mortal coil 400 years ago this weekend. As the world prepares to celebrate the anniversary, test your knowledge of the Bard with this quiz.

headline: In Spain, Catching Up With Cervantes
abstract: State-sponsored events to honor the writer on the 400th anniversary of his death fall short, critics say.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Two giants of Western literature, William Shakespeare and Miguel de Cervantes, are being honored this weekend in their native countries on the 400th anniversaries of their deaths.

headline: A Marriage Gone Bad: Walgreens Struggles to Shake Off Theranos
abstract: A 2013 deal between the besieged blood-test lab and the drugstore giant was intended to make Theranos wellness centers an integral part of Walgreens.
lead_paragraph: Many boldface names enabled the stratospheric rise of the blood-testing start-up Theranos: two former secretaries of state, a former secretary of defense, two former senators, a retired admiral, venture capitalists, scientific luminaries and a prestigious clinic.

headline: In Pennsylvania, Obscure Job of G.O.P. Delegate Is Suddenly a Hot Ticket
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: With Republicans facing their first contested convention in decades, the 54 unbound state delegates could decide the party’s presidential nominee.
lead_paragraph: HARRISBURG, Pa. — In any other election year, it would be a lot of trouble for very little payoff.

headline: Tinkering With Nature: Weighing the Benefits and Risks of Genetically Engineering Animals
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about the process of gene editing in animals and consider the ethical questions inherent in using this new tool.
lead_paragraph: Within the past few years scientists have revolutionized genetic engineering techniques so that now, with relative ease, they can precisely edit the genetic coding of animals more-or-less on demand. What once took decades or longer through selective breeding is now nearly instantaneous. Researchers have already produced salmon that grow faster and beef cattle with larger muscles (and therefore more meat).

headline: 20 Wines Under $20
abstract: Eric Asimov picks 20 spring bottles, all under $20.
lead_paragraph: Eric Asimov picks 20 spring bottles, all under $20.

headline: 20 Wines for Under $20: The Spring Edition
abstract: You can find great values at any price, but your hunt will be less anxious at the lower end of the scale.
lead_paragraph: Few things are more important to wine drinkers than value, but value can mean different things to different people.

headline: Donald Trump Says Transgender People Should Use the Bathroom They Want
abstract: Dipping into a contentious issue about a North Carolina law by taking a stand many Republicans oppose, Donald J. Trump told a town-hall-style event, hosted by NBC’s “Today” show in New York, that when people go to the restroom, they should “use the bathroom they feel is appropriate.”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said Thursday that transgender people should be allowed to use whatever bathroom they feel most comfortable with — including at Trump Tower in New York.

headline: 1966: Artificial Heart Works
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: An artificial heart gives life to a coal miner near death, in 1966.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Dr. Michael DeBakey today [April 21] successfully implanted an artificial heart in a 65-year-old coal miner near death and gave him a chance for life in a medical triumph. The famed surgeon resorted to hand massage of the exposed heart of Marcel L. De Rudder when his heart suddenly failed during the six-hour ordeal. A standard heart-lung machine also was used as technicians battled to adjust the flow of blood through the artificial heart. The patient was wheeled from the operating room with the artificial heart still working. Physicians said it could remain in him ‘‘a week or a month.’’ ‘‘The operation went much as I hoped and planned,’’ Dr. DeBakey said afterward. He looked tired in his white surgical smock. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 22, 1966

headline: 1968 | ‘We Need a Jewish Mother in the White House’
abstract: Two accomplished hoaxers fabricated an independent presidential candidate named Yetta Bronstein of the Bronx, and The Times bit. Twice.
lead_paragraph: “President Petro O. Poroshenko” of Ukraine was not the first political leader to briefly persuade The New York Times that he was who he wasn’t. In 2008, for instance, “Mayor Bertrand Delanoë” of Paris had a letter published in The Times.

headline: Foxes That Endure Despite a Lack of Genetic Diversity
abstract: The island fox has lived on the Channel Islands off California for several thousand years, surviving even though many of the animals are nearly identical.
lead_paragraph: The Channel Islands, off the coast of Southern California, are a natural laboratory for a particularly adorable experiment in evolution.

headline: $10 Billion Loan to Saudi Arabia Carries Risks
abstract: The Saudi kingdom is enmeshed in a global oil price war while opposing Iran in proxy conflicts in Yemen and Syria.
lead_paragraph: Bankers should be punching the air. Saudi Arabia is close to agreeing to terms on a $10 billion loan with a syndicate of banks including JPMorgan, HSBC and Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi. Normally, getting the nod to lend to Saudi Arabia, the Middle East’s largest holder of crude oil reserves, for the first time in 25 years would be easy money. But banks may be ignoring the risks.

headline: Volkswagen Reaches Deal in U.S. Over Emissions Scandal
keywords: ['Diesel Power', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Air Pollution', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Fines (Penalties)', 'Consumer Protection', 'Automobiles', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: Owners of hundreds of thousands of diesel vehicles in the United States will be eligible to have their vehicles bought back or fixed.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen agreed on Thursday to fix or buy back nearly 500,000 diesel cars in the United States that are equipped with illegal emissions software.

headline: Whole Foods Says Customer Faked Anti-Gay Cake Slur
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Discrimination', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The company says a man’s account of a slur written on his cake doesn’t match security footage, leaving online sleuths to examine the sugary evidence.
lead_paragraph: A public feud between Whole Foods and a customer who accused the store of scrawling an anti-gay slur on his cake escalated this week with dueling lawsuits, inspiring hundreds of online sleuths to debate the clues in security footage and in the hand-lettered icing.

headline: Dish Network and Viacom Sign a Deal, Ending a Standoff
abstract: A multiyear agreement for Dish to carry Viacom television networks like MTV is especially crucial for Viacom.
lead_paragraph: Dish Network wanted its MTV after all.

headline: Video Review: After Some Mud Wrestling, the Best S.U.V.s Emerge
abstract: Over two days at this year’s Mudfest in the Pacific Northwest, 26 journalists evaluated 27 vehicles, including crossovers, S.U.V.s and pickups.
lead_paragraph: Thinking about buying a sport utility vehicle or crossover? Get in line. According to IHS Automotive, the segment outsold sedans in the United States last year. Now, you could buy a station wagon (they handle more like sports sedans because of their lower center of gravity) or a minivan, but buyers have voted for crossovers with their checkbooks. Cheap gas helps.

headline: Drug-Smuggling Tunnel, Found in San Diego, Is Longest Yet
abstract: Federal officials say the tunnel began in Tijuana, Mexico, ran for half a mile, and had rails and ventilation. It is one of many found in the fight against drug trafficking.
lead_paragraph: For all the talk about a wall between the United States and Mexico, the problem with border security continues to be as much below ground as above. On Wednesday, officials in San Diego announced the discovery of another cross-border tunnel built by drug smugglers — the longest one found yet, at about half a mile.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘The Meddler’
abstract: Lorene Scafaria narrates a sequence from her film featuring Susan Sarandon and Rose Byrne.
lead_paragraph: Lorene Scafaria narrates a sequence from her film featuring Susan Sarandon and Rose Byrne.

headline: Wall St. Regulators Propose Stricter Pay Rules for Bankers
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Executive Compensation', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Bonuses', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The new rules would make executives wait at least four years to receive portions of their bonuses and force banks to find ways to claw back bonuses.
lead_paragraph: Regulators released long-awaited rules on Thursday morning that aim to restrict how big financial institutions can pay their top executives.

headline: Never Too Old to Hurt From Parents’ Divorce
keywords: ['Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Weddings and Engagements', 'Marriages', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Even children in their 20s, 30s and older are confused and upset when Mom and Dad break up.
lead_paragraph: In the room that would be the scene of Lisa George’s divorce in 2012, Ms. George, now 59, was seated on the same side of the table as her about-to-be-ex-husband. Each of their divorce lawyers slid into seats across from them.

headline: How Do You Say ‘Caucus’ in Spanish?
keywords: ['Spanish Language', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Elias Lopez, editorial director of The New York Times en Español, explains how his team in Mexico City translates U.S. politics for a Latin American and Spanish audience.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this article, Elias E. Lopez, editorial director of The New York Times en Español, explains how his team in Mexico City translates United States politics for a Latin American and Spanish audience.

headline: The Woman in Her Mirror
abstract: Geri Taylor didn't recognize the face looking back at her. It was just one sign that something was going wrong.
lead_paragraph: Geri Taylor didn't recognize the face looking back at her. It was just one sign that something was going wrong.

headline: Lorene Scafaria Narrates a Scene From ‘The Meddler’
abstract: The writer and director of “The Meddler” discusses a sequence from her film featuring Susan Sarandon and Rose Byrne.
lead_paragraph: The writer and director Lorene Scafaria tapped into her real-life relationship with her mother for the comedy “The Meddler,” starring Susan Sarandon as Marnie, a widow who moves to Los Angeles to be closer to her daughter (Rose Byrne). In this comic scene, the mother crosses one too many of the daughter’s boundaries. During a recent interview in New York, Ms. Scafaria explained how her relationship with her mother led to the film. Here are edited excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Online Media Is Tested When Social Platforms Come to Town
keywords: ['Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Online media is being abruptly transformed by social media platforms and centralizing apps. But Andrei Hagiu, an economist, sees familiar patterns.
lead_paragraph: Online media companies are, once again, bracing for change. Now, the prospect facing them is audiences that don’t just start on social media platforms — they never have to leave them.

headline: Review: Casting ‘Nina’ Was Controversial, but Is It a Good Movie?
abstract: This biopic of Nina Simone was criticized for its choice of Zoe Saldana in the title role, but its problems are greater than that.
lead_paragraph: One night, Nina Simone, the great jazz singer, composer and pianist, now semiretired on the French Riviera, calls up her old friend Richard Pryor. It’s the 1990s, and both of them have seen better days. His first words to her are “Can you imagine?,” and while he’s referring to his own struggles with addiction and illness, his question haunts “Nina,” a sincere and spectacularly misbegotten new biopic.

headline: A Bittersweet Passover: Cancer, Remission and Change
abstract: For me, living longer means getting old — which, my mother always told me, is not for sissies. As I welcome Elijah this April, my Passover will be a bittersweet mixture of redemption, grief and change.
lead_paragraph: Despite good news about my cancer treatment, it has been a hard winter, so I am looking forward to Passover. By retelling the story of the Jewish people’s escape from slavery in Egypt, the Haggadah — the text recited at the annual Seder — celebrates deliverance and springtime renewal. How would its rituals and prayers resonate for me this year, when cancer concerns were unexpectedly supplanted by other tribulations?

headline: Two Rising Chefs Enjoy a Busy Reunion at Houseman
abstract: Mashama Bailey and Ned Baldwin, who met at Prune, are swapping kitchens.
lead_paragraph: A Prune reunion took place downtown on Wednesday.

headline: A Revival in Pueblo, Colo.
abstract: The City Council president writes, “We are making great efforts to curb the drugs and violent crimes in our community.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Iran Accuses U.S. of Theft in $2 Billion Court Ruling for Terror Victims
abstract: Iran said the United States Supreme Court ruling, which ordered Iran’s central bank to pay nearly $2 billion to victims of terrorist attacks, was amounted to thievery.
lead_paragraph: Iran reacted furiously on Thursday to a United States Supreme Court ruling that Iran’s central bank must pay nearly $2 billion to American victims of terrorist attacks, calling the ruling thievery and a new threat to any improvement in relations.

headline: Virgin Mary Statue, Intact Among Ecuador’s Quake Ruins, Becomes a Beacon of Hope
abstract: Residents of Montecristi say the survival of the centuries-old Our Mother of Monserrate, even as the basilica cracked and crumbled around it, is a miracle.
lead_paragraph: MONTECRISTI, Ecuador — The earth shook and the steeple fell, taking most of the bell tower with it. A white facade gave way, leaving the pews open to the street.

headline: At Last, Jeremy Lin Settles Into Identity of His Own Making
abstract: Lin, the Hornets’ valuable reserve, seems to have broken a pattern in which he was overlooked, then overhyped and then left to deal with the backlash.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Over the past five years, Jeremy Lin has felt multiple disparate identities foisted upon him: undrafted underdog, franchise savior, overpaid mercenary. None quite fit.

headline: Newly Appointed N.J. Transit Chief Won’t Take the Job
abstract: State officials said William Crosbie, who had previously worked as chief operating officer for Amtrak, withdrew over concerns about relocating his family from Virginia.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two weeks after New Jersey Transit named a new executive director, state officials said on Thursday that the appointee, a former Amtrak official, had decided not to take the job.

headline: My Mother’s Make-Believe Boyfriend
abstract: My mother’s brain has been melting since she had a stroke, and now the major territories include pastrami, kittens and a man in her nursing home.
lead_paragraph: My mother’s brain has been melting since she had a serious stroke a year and a half ago, and if I had to map it, I’d say the major territories now are pastrami, kittens, egg rolls and, lately, a man in her nursing home unit we’ll call Sam.

headline: Speed Reading Does Work
abstract: A (speed) reader rebuts a skeptical Sunday Review article.

headline: Prince, an Artist Who Defied Genre, Is Dead at 57
abstract: The prolific songwriter and performer’s decades of music transcended and remade funk, rock and R&B with hits like “Purple Rain” and “1999.”
lead_paragraph: Prince, the songwriter, singer, producer, one-man studio band and consummate showman, died on Thursday at his home, Paisley Park, in Chanhassen, Minn. He was 57.

headline: Donald Trump’s Team Courts Members of Congress
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s top surrogates met with a group of about 10 members of Congress in Washington to provide an update on the coming state voting contests and help lawmakers who are up for re-election become more comfortable with the Republican presidential front-runner.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s campaign continued its outreach to Congress on Thursday, promising that the Republican candidate would become more presidential and organized as he lurches closer to the nomination.

headline: A Welcome and Overdue Change to the $20 Bill
keywords: ['Counterfeit Money and Financial Instruments', 'Currency', 'Native Americans', 'Slavery (Historical)', 'Underground Railroad (19th Century)', 'United States Economy', 'US Dollar (Currency)']
abstract: Putting Harriet Tubman on the $20 bill is the right call. The Treasury Department needs to make sure it happens as quickly as possible.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department’s new plan to place a portrait of Harriet Tubman on the new $20 bill and keep Alexander Hamilton on the $10 bill is the right call. Now it needs to make sure the change happens as quickly as feasible. The country has waited long enough to have a woman on the currency.

headline: A Wife’s Own Success
abstract: The wife of Puerto Rico’s representative in Congress asks, “Why do some still assume that a woman’s success depends on her husband?”

headline: Hillary Clinton Enjoys Commanding Lead in Maryland, Poll Shows

lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton is well positioned to win Maryland’s Democratic primary election next week, according to a new poll that shows her holding big leads with every voting group in the state.

lead_paragraph: David Geffen has again reached into his ample coffers to bestow $100 million on a cultural institution — this time the Museum of Modern Art for its $440 million expansion and renovation project — in a gift announced on Thursday.

headline: Shakespeare’s Deleted Scenes
abstract: Four contemporary writers envision lost and rebooted scenes from some of the playwright’s works.
lead_paragraph: To mark the 400th anniversary of Shakespeare’s death, The New York Times asked four contemporary writers to envision lost and rebooted scenes from some of the playwright’s works.

headline: Kurds and Syrian Forces Clash, Adding Wrinkle to War
keywords: ['Kurds', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Kurdish militias and President Bashar al-Assad’s forces tend to avoid clashes, but skirmished Thursday in the de facto Kurdish autonomous region.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Amid renewed fighting across Syria on Thursday, clashes broke out between Kurdish militias and Syrian government forces, potentially opening a new front in the already complex conflict.

headline: With Uncertainty at Top of Ticket, Republicans Back Off in Some States
abstract: The Republican National Committee’s decision to hold off on spending in some contested states shows how a divisive presidential race is threatening the entire ticket.
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — The Republican National Committee is scaling back its financial commitments to some of the most hotly contested states because of flagging fund-raising, the most concrete evidence yet of how the party’s divisive and protracted presidential race is threatening the party’s entire ticket in November.

headline: A High-Fat Diet May Lead to Daytime Sleepiness
abstract: Men who ate a diet high in fat were more likely to suffer daytime sleepiness and have sleep apnea than those eating a lower-fat diet.
lead_paragraph: Eating a high-fat diet may lead to daytime sleepiness, a new study concludes.

lead_paragraph: Jim Taylor onstage in “Henri.” He regarded the performance as a play, not a preview of what was to come for his wife.

abstract: Ms. Taylor speaks on her fear of forgetting names and faces, and the heartache it will cause her family.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Taylor speaks on her fear of forgetting names and faces, and the heartache it will cause her family.

abstract: Prince is dead at 57. We’re collecting tributes and reminiscences.

headline: Koch-Backed Group Breaks Up Its Intelligence Unit
abstract: The intelligence unit for the Koch brothers-backed political organization was broken up as the brothers have tried to refashion their public image.
lead_paragraph: The conservative political network created by the billionaire brothers Charles G. and David H. Koch has broken up its opposition-research unit in the last few weeks, a spokesman for the group confirmed on Thursday, describing it as an efficiency measure.

headline: Share Your Memories of Prince
abstract: What was your favorite Prince concert? Which of his songs cycles through your playlists?
lead_paragraph: What was your favorite Prince concert? Which of his songs cycles through your playlists?

headline: ‘Empire’ Season 2, Episode 14: Lucious the Schemer
abstract: “Empire” is beginning to address some of its biggest mysteries in the second half of Season 2.
lead_paragraph: “Empire” is beginning to address some of its biggest mysteries in the second half of Season 2. Last week dramatized the transformation of the innocent young Dwight Walker into the ruthless orphan tycoon Lucious Lyon, and this week we find out that this mother didn’t die as we’ve been led to believe. This is probably very bad news for Lucious, who is coasting into the hearts of the ASA voting board off the strength of a touching video about her death. We find out she is alive when Lucious’s henchman Thirsty Rawlings pays her nursing home a visit. Is Lucious keeping tabs to keep a lie about her death under wraps?

headline: Long Primary Carries Costs for Hillary Clinton: Money and Time
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Campaign Finance', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton has burned through tens of millions of dollars in states unlikely to be competitive in the fall and has had to slow a pivot to the general election.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has burned through tens of millions of dollars to counter Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont in states that are unlikely to be general election battlegrounds, delaying any pivot to the general election and shrinking her potential financial advantage over the eventual Republican nominee.

headline: Prince, Onstage and On the Town
abstract: Prince was known for his larger-than-life presence.
lead_paragraph: Prince was known for his larger-than-life presence.

headline: Prince in The Times
abstract: Prince was a prolific artist with a career that began in the late 1970s with the release of the album “For You.” He shattered stereotypes on race and sexuality throughout his career.
lead_paragraph: Prince was a prolific artist with a career that began in the late 1970s with the release of the album “For You.” He shattered stereotypes on race and sexuality throughout his career.

headline: New York Hospital to Pay $2.2 Million Over Unauthorized Filming of 2 Patients
abstract: NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital had allowed television crews to film two patients without their consent: one who was dying, the other in significant distress.
lead_paragraph: NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital has agreed to pay a $2.2 million penalty to federal regulators for allowing television crews to film two patients without their consent — one who was dying, the other in significant distress. Regulators said on Thursday that the hospital allowed filming to continue even after a medical professional asked that it stop.

headline: An Ode to ‘the Purple One’: Prince’s Most Memorable Albums
abstract: A look at the most influential works from an artist who defied genre.
lead_paragraph: Prince released music steadily from 1978 on, making for one of the most daring, radical and inventive catalogs in all of pop. Here are five of his finest albums, released at turning-point moments in his career, that show the artist, who was found dead, at 57, on Thursday, in his fullness: a cunning vocalist, a fiery musician, and a peerless songwriter and producer.

headline: The Key Players in Climate Change
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: World leaders are gathering Friday to sign the Paris Agreement on climate change. Here’s a status report on the key players and their efforts to slow greenhouse gas emissions.
lead_paragraph: World leaders are gathering Friday to sign the Paris Agreement on climate change. Here’s a status report on the key players and their efforts to slow greenhouse gas emissions.

headline: A Shakespeare Anniversary Brings Pomp and Plays to Stratford-upon-Avon
abstract: In the birthplace of William Shakespeare, where he is also buried, festivities are planned to commemorate the 400th anniversary of his death.
lead_paragraph: STRATFORD-UPON-AVON, England — George Bernard Shaw once mocked what he called “bardolatry,” but worship of William Shakespeare is in full swing here, as well it should be, since this pretty town pretty much exists on the Shakespeare industry.

headline: Muslims, Christians and Mozart: Seeking Harmony at the Met Opera
abstract: The revival of “Abduction From the Seraglio” offers a disturbing model for exploring reconciliation of cultural differences.
lead_paragraph: When the curtain goes up on Mozart’s “Die Entführung aus dem Serail” (“The Abduction From the Seraglio”), we are on the Mediterranean coast in the Ottoman Empire, at a palace where European captives are being held as slaves by a Muslim pasha. When the Ottoman Turkish overseer, Osmin, enters and sings about his rage against the Christian prisoners, he fantasizes about hanging them, impaling them on hot stakes and beheading them.

headline: ‘Veep’ and ‘Game of Thrones’ Echo Our Politics, as Farce and Tragedy
abstract: President Selina Meyer, the zealot High Sparrow, the 2016 presidential race — television comedy and fantasy aligns with real-life politics.
lead_paragraph: In Sunday’s season premiere of HBO’s “Veep,” Selina Meyer (Julia Louis-Dreyfus) is locked in a cliffhanger electoral-college tie, girding for a recount in Nevada and facing the possibility that Congress may give the presidency to her running mate and frenemy, Tom James (Hugh Laurie). But her more immediate problem is appearing in public with an enormous “stress pimple” on her face.

headline: Global Warming Feels Quite Pleasant
abstract: For most Americans, the weather has been improving. So why worry?
lead_paragraph: CHRISTMAS in New York was lovely this year — especially for those who prefer to spend the day working on their tans. It was the city’s warmest ever, with temperatures peaking at 66 degrees.

headline: Periods in Space Are Not That Different, Though a Bit More Complicated
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Women and Girls', 'Menstruation', 'Birth Control and Family Planning']
abstract: For future astronauts, who would rather not menstruate in space, researchers have written up some recommendations.
lead_paragraph: With more than 50 women having flown in space over the last 50 years and the ranks of women astronauts growing, one might assume that a basic physiological question has been answered: What’s the best approach to manage menstrual cycles in space?

abstract: The photographer has traveled the country photographing small, human moments amid big, charged events, like activist rallies and campaign stops.
lead_paragraph: The photographer has traveled the country photographing small, human moments amid big, charged events, like activist rallies and campaign stops.

headline: How Officials Distorted Flint’s Water Testing
abstract: Officials used flawed testing methods, making the levels of lead in the water supply appear far less dangerous than they were.
lead_paragraph: Officials used flawed testing methods, making the levels of lead in the water supply appear far less dangerous than they were.

headline: Review: Knausgaard Becomes a Writer in a Sick, Crooked World
abstract: The fifth novel in Karl Ove Knausgaard’s autobiographical “My Struggle” series closely tracks his literary apprenticeship.
lead_paragraph: Some writers, like locksmiths, wield a master key with which they attempt to open life’s mysteries. The Norwegian writer Karl Ove Knausgaard seems instead to carry a million tiny keys on a chain that does not oppress him. Patiently, with no pretense, he unlocks one safe deposit box of memory and emotion after another — safe deposit boxes you’d forgotten you’d owned.

headline: A Photographer Who Captures the Humanity in Politics
abstract: Pete Voelker’s recent work has taken him all over the country, documenting small, intimate moments amid rallies and the campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Pete Voelker has a widely diverse portfolio: He’s shot everything from portraits of musicians to still lifes to reportage, and his most recent work has taken him all over the country documenting political rallies and the presidential campaign trail. “Photography acts as a vessel for me,” Voelker says. “When I was younger, it was the only excuse I had to pack up and drive across the country or go on any sort of aimless adventure to see something new. Taking photographs is always the objective, but the journey to create photographs and the conversations with people along the way are what drive me as a photographer.”

headline: Four Days in Japan With the Designer Gabriela Hearst
abstract: She feted her latest offering at Barneys and stopped by local shops.

headline: A (Very Quick) Trip to Tokyo With Gabriela Hearst
abstract: The women’s wear designer recently spent a jam-packed four days in the Japanese capital.
lead_paragraph: When the designer Gabriela Hearst first went to Tokyo in 2007, she says she felt immediately at home. Since then, she’s returned to the city multiple times — especially since she launched her eponymous label last year. “My collection is about the construction and the quality of materials,” says Hearst, who was born in Uruguay and currently lives in New York. “It’s more than a flat image; the garments are beautifully made and this idea of educated and edited consuming is something that the Japanese appreciate.” She and Stephanie de Lavalette, her best friend and the brand’s director of operations, recently spent four days in Tokyo, celebrating the spring 2016 line’s arrival at Barneys Japan, eating their fill of fish and indulging Hearst’s paper obsession. Here, she shares photos from their adventures around town.

headline: Review: Donna McKechnie Explores Kander and Ebb
abstract: Ms. McKechnie, who is more a dancer than a singer, delivered an enlightening survey of that formidable Broadway team’s songwriting output.
lead_paragraph: “Money money, money, money, money …” ad infinitum: Donna McKechnie opened her show “A Visit With Kander and Ebb” on Wednesday evening at Feinstein’s/54 Below with the jangly “Money Song” from “Cabaret,” setting the tone for an enlightening survey of that formidable Broadway team’s songwriting output. “That clinking, clanking sound can make the world go round,” Fred Ebb’s lyrics chatter.

lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Cloud computing is seen by many investors as Microsoft’s salvation, the growing business that has convinced many there’s a bright future for the company beyond the troubled PC market.

headline: Damien Hirst Returns to Gagosian Gallery
abstract: An exhibition of Mr. Hirst’s past work; an auction of Duke Ellington’s items; and a rare painting expected to fetch at least $6 million.
lead_paragraph: Damien Hirst has a knack for arresting attention, as he did by encrusting the platinum cast of a human skull in 2007, by pulling off a $200 million all-Hirst auction at Sotheby’s in 2008 and by leaving the Gagosian Gallery in 2012, after he had been represented there for 17 years.

headline: Hitting the Road With His Mom
abstract: Plus, subway grooming, a landlord’s party rules and a friend’s restaurant quirk.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I have been married for 12 years. It is the second marriage for both of us. We have six grown children between us, but none together. My mother-in-law, an otherwise pleasant woman, has begun inviting my husband on trips for just the two of them, while I am sitting right there. It’s happened several times. My husband doesn’t take her up on these offers; he tells me that his mother is just a little odd. But I want these invitations to stop. Any advice for me?

headline: 6 Pakistani Army Officers, Linked to Corruption, Are Dismissed
abstract: The purge was seen as a signal to Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif that since the military was coming clean on wrongdoing, he should, too.
lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — The Pakistani Army’s top commander has dismissed six senior officers, including a three-star and a two-star general, for what Pakistani news accounts described on Thursday as smuggling and other corrupt acts.

headline: American Indian Narratives in Picture Form
abstract: Dealers, collectors and academics have been trying to restore order to ledgers used to record tribal history by reassembling loose book pages.
lead_paragraph: Tattered pages from 19th-century ledger books, which American Indians used to record tribal history in picture form, have been dispersed on the market. With the loose pages no longer in their intended sequences, the graphic narratives of battles, courtships, disease outbreaks, ceremonies and imprisonments have become unintelligible. The artists’ identities and the tribes depicted have also been obscured.
