keywords: ['ARABIC LANGUAGE', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Muslim Americans', 'Discrimination', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Language and Languages']
abstract: Let’s all embrace a perfect term for delusional hope and earnest yearning.
lead_paragraph: A COLLEGE student was recently escorted off a Southwest Airlines flight after a fellow passenger said she heard him making comments in Arabic that were “potentially threatening.”

headline: Review: At Chatterbox 54, Bustling Italian Space and Relaxed Italian Pace
abstract: The restaurant, which opened in December, offers dishes inspired by Arthur Avenue in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: The tables at Chatterbox 54 are a bit larger than is usual, making the typical balancing act at most restaurants, where space for both an entree and a bread plate can be hard to find, unnecessary. This creates more comfortable dining, but intimate chats aren’t easy. No matter. Calling out across the table, or even across the room, is part of the fun.

headline: Deal Is Reached to Return the Opposition Leader Riek Machar to South Sudan
abstract: The government of Salva Kiir said it was prepared to take a step toward ending a civil war that has left tens of thousands of people dead and two million displaced.
lead_paragraph: GAMBELLA, Ethiopia — After four days of delays, a deal has been reached to allow South Sudan’s opposition leader, former Vice President Riek Machar, to fly to the capital and be reinstated as deputy to President Salva Kiir.

headline: Jury Acquits Sing Sing Guard Seen on Video Beating Inmate
abstract: The verdict in the criminal assault case is a setback for the New York State corrections agency’s push to crack down on brutality in its prisons.
lead_paragraph: OSSINING, N.Y. — In a setback for the state corrections agency’s campaign to crack down on brutality in its prisons, a Sing Sing guard whose repeated punching of an inmate was captured on a security video was found not guilty on Friday of criminal assault.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jason Stallman, KJ Dell’Antonia and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.

headline: Review: Caetano Veloso and Gilberto Gil, Harmonic and Political Still
abstract: The two Brazilian musicians, Tropicália movement pioneers in the 1960s, performed with a gentle diplomacy Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Caetano Veloso and Gilberto Gil were the picture of unfussy enlightenment on Wednesday, in their first of two nights at the Brooklyn Academy of Music’s Howard Gilman Opera House. Each seated with an acoustic guitar, they brought an easy collegiality to their exchange, with the odd flicker of guilelessness. But their songs contained all manner of complexities: rhythmic and harmonic, as well as tonal, political, philosophical and metaphysical.

headline: Review: Songs of Exile With Matthias Goerne
abstract: The baritone, accompanied by the pianist Alexander Schmalcz, explored the psychology of human displacement.
lead_paragraph: The story of the German émigrés who poured into Hollywood in the 1940s fleeing Nazi persecution makes for compelling reading. To many of these artists and intellectuals — among them Thomas Mann, Arnold Schoenberg and Bertolt Brecht — California could feel like a picturesque purgatory in which they were left to idle among palm trees and swimming pools while Europe was being reduced to ashes.

headline: A (Mostly Men’s) Club for Cigar Aficionados on Long Island
abstract: New York State laws are strict on where a smoker can light up in public, but at Matador Cigars, a mini-chain shop on Long Island, cigar lovers can find a refuge.
lead_paragraph: Cigar smokers don’t get much respect. In movies and television, there is no prop so directly associated with villainy as the cigar. From Gordon Gekko to Tony Montana to Yosemite Sam, whenever a character fires up a stogie, you can be pretty sure you’ve found your bad guy.

headline: Review: A Kaleidoscope of Flavors at Pho Vietnam, in Danbury
abstract: The restaurant offers chandelier elegance and a casual paper-napkin, pay-at-the-register air.
lead_paragraph: Pho Vietnam Restaurant, in Danbury, is a study in contrasts. At 900 square feet, it could be considered a hole in the wall, but for the more than 40 seats squeezed in for guests. Crystal chandeliers and dentil crown molding suggest an elegance that is belied by the paper-napkin-casualness and the pay-at-the-register service. The quality of the food, too, is variable, ranging from exquisite some nights to so-so on others.

headline: University of Chicago Wrestling Coach Defends Hastert
abstract: This is a copy of a letter that Leo Kocher, the coach of the University of Chicago wrestling team, sent to the wrestling community nationwide urging coaches, parents and players to mobilize in 2006 to defend J. Dennis Hastert, then the House speaker.
lead_paragraph: This is a copy of a letter that Leo Kocher, the coach of the University of Chicago wrestling team, sent to the wrestling community nationwide urging coaches, parents and players to mobilize in 2006 to defend J. Dennis Hastert, then the House speaker.

headline: Wrestling Propelled Hastert’s Career, and Provided Opportunity for Abuse
keywords: ['Wrestling', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Interscholastic Athletics', 'Sex Crimes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As sentencing approaches for J. Dennis Hastert on charges of secret payments over sexual abuse, the wrestling community feels a sense of betrayal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When calls for his removal from office reverberated through the capital a decade ago, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert struggled to explain why he had not aggressively investigated allegations that a Florida lawmaker had sent flirtatious messages to a teenage boy who had served as a House page.

headline: Review: W. Kamau Bell Explores the ‘United Shades of America’
abstract: The comedian’s new CNN show opens with an episode that takes him to Ku Klux Klan country.
lead_paragraph: No one’s list of Television Outlets Most Likely to Surprise Us includes CNN, but on Sunday the network ventures into attention-getting territory with “United Shades of America,” in which a black comedian, W. Kamau Bell, explores places and subjects that are out of his comfort zone. The first stop is a doozy: Ku Klux Klan country.

headline: Better the Saudis We Know
abstract: Despite tensions, the U.S. cannot afford to cut adrift a key regional ally.
lead_paragraph: SAUDI ARABIA is dismayed by President Obama’s Middle East policy. Its leaders feel that he does not play by the rules that have governed the Saudi-American alliance for decades: The United States provides security guarantees in return for the Persian Gulf states’ reliable stewardship of their oil reserves and support for American regional dominance.

headline: A Second Look at a ‘Misconception’ on Exercise and Bones
abstract: A recent article received a lot of responses from readers. Here’s a follow-up.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, the Science staff published a series of short articles called “Misconceptions.” The idea: to debunk some common misconceptions about health and science that many people accept as truth in their everyday lives.

headline: A Mindful Path to Environmental Progress in a Noisy Media Environment
abstract: A psychiatrist and a journalist talk about communication, the mind and environmental progress.
lead_paragraph: Happy Earth Day, all. Apologies for the limited posting and comment moderation. I’m in Oslo at a meeting of the Anthropocene Working Group, which is in final face-to-face deliberations over evidence that the Holocene, the geological epoch that began at the end of the last ice age, has given way to a new age shaped by humans. In the meantime, here are some reflections on the merits of focusing within in trying to improve the world around you.

headline: Samuel Hunter, Award-Winning Playwright, Brings ‘Lewiston’ to Life
abstract: The world premiere of “Lewiston” at Long Wharf Theater in New Haven offers further evidence of the growth of Mr. Hunter, a “genius grant” recipient.
lead_paragraph: With the world premiere of his play “Lewiston” at Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, the playwright Samuel D. Hunter demonstrates his growing mastery of narratives that slowly, sometimes painfully, and ultimately sympathetically peel back the layers of struggles that define the lives of people who drift below the middle class.

headline: At the Katonah Museum, the Art of the Nest
abstract: An avian-inspired exhibition blurs the boundaries between nature and artifice.
lead_paragraph: They hang from the ceiling of the Katonah Museum of Art, fibrous pouches reaching down approximately four feet. Mysterious and elegant, woven from dried grasses and twigs, they are shaped like elongated teardrops and spin slowly in the air.

headline: Your Evening Briefing.
abstract: Your Evening Briefing.
lead_paragraph: Your Evening Briefing.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Prince, Donald Trump, Game of Thrones
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: ‘Silicon Valley’ Season 3: Everything Happens, and Nothing Happens
abstract: The HBO comedy returns for Season 3 with a new villain and an office move in the offing for the frantic Pied Piper crew.
lead_paragraph: As “Silicon Valley” begins its third season on HBO on Sunday night, the genius of its central metaphor for the American condition — intellectual, cultural, economic — becomes ever more apparent. The algorithm that drives Pied Piper, the MacGuffinish string of computer code around which the series revolves, has existed since the first episode. Yet this season, it is no closer to existing in the real world. The show’s young code-writing heroes are still running like gerbils from one white knight or black hat to another, generating lively misadventures but no revenue. Everything happens, and nothing happens.

headline: Fighting to Preserve a Chapter of Setauket History
abstract: An effort to commemorate a once-thriving mixed-race community reinvigorates a long simmering debate about the accuracy of local history.
lead_paragraph: An effort in Setauket to commemorate a once-thriving mixed-race community here is in its final stages. However, doing so reinvigorates a long simmering debate among friendly factions about the accuracy of local history.

headline: Review: ‘Old Love New Love’ Explores the Pain of Alzheimer’s
abstract: Poignant moments punctuate “Old Love New Love,” a play by Laura Brienza that is receiving its world premiere at Luna Stage Company in West Orange, N.J.
lead_paragraph: “Some days I actually wish my brain would fall apart so we’d be in the same boat,” remarks Gloria, a woman whose husband is drifting away in the middle stages of Alzheimer’s disease.

headline: Prince Knew What He Wanted: Sex, Soul and You
abstract: The pop star was not only sex, but also a sexual orientation. His own. And it was oriented toward you.
lead_paragraph: At work, propped against a wall, near piles of stuff, stands an Elvis Presley cutout. It’s made of cardboard, pretty beat up, taller than I am and not the greatest photo. (He looks drunk. So does his lamé suit.) But I pass that cutout almost every day, and every day I have the same thought. Elvis was hot. He was a musician, but he didn’t have to be playing music for you to feel this way. Cardboard would do.

headline: Obama Weighs In on Mississippi and North Carolina Bathroom Laws
abstract: Speaking at a news conference in Britain, President Obama criticized new laws limiting the rights of gay and transgender people.
lead_paragraph: President Obama said Friday that new laws in North Carolina and Mississippi curbing the rights of gay and transgender people were “wrong and should be overturned,” weighing in on measures that have prompted a backlash, including calls to boycott the states.

headline: Review: ‘A Girl Is a Half-Formed Thing’ Is a Ghostly Play
abstract: Aoife Duffin stars in this story of a rebellious Irish girl, based on the novel of the same name by Eimear McBride.
lead_paragraph: The body is barely there, more phantasm than person, and at first you might mistake it for a shadow. When the astonishing Irish actress Aoife Duffin makes her entrance in “A Girl Is a Half-Formed Thing,” drifting through a corridor of gray light, her features are indistinguishable. And though she soon starts to speak, the words that she says also seem curiously inchoate.

headline: Review: Riccardo Muti, the King of Verdi, Still Rules With a Firm Baton
abstract: The Chicago Symphony Orchestra conductor shows his ample gifts as Verdi’s protector and defender in “Falstaff” in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For more than 40 years, Riccardo Muti has been the king of Verdi conductors, the one who most makes you feel you are hearing the composer’s operas for the very first time.

headline: With Broadway Stars, ‘An American in Paris’ Will Play London Next Year
abstract: The show will open in the West End in March 2017.
lead_paragraph: “An American in Paris,” the Tony Award-winning Broadway musical, will open in London next year, starring Robert Fairchild and Leanne Cope, who originated the lead roles on Broadway.

headline: Review: From City Ballet, a ‘Peculiar Marvel’ by Ratmansky
abstract: Sergei Ratmansky’s “Pictures at an Exhibition” shares the stage with Justin Peck’s “Everywhere We Go” and Christopher Wheeldon’s “Estancia.”
lead_paragraph: Prodigal with its repertory as usual, New York City Ballet is opening its six-week spring season with four different programs on consecutive evenings at the David H. Koch Theater. Having begun on Tuesday with 1967 choreography by George Balanchine, it switched on Wednesday to 21st-century choreography. Other programs will follow. This kind of variety — the envy of the ballet world — stimulates both dancers and audiences.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review Podcast: ‘Old Age: A Beginner’s Guide’
abstract: This week, Michael Kinsley, Eric Fair and Viet Thanh Nguyen.

headline: Accidental Artistry
abstract: Leah Singer has been photographing “Post No Bills” signs around New York City for the past decade.
lead_paragraph: Leah Singer has been photographing “Post No Bills” signs around New York City for the past decade.

headline: The Writing on the Wall
abstract: Leah Singer is drawn to the “Post No Bills” notices that are ubiquitous in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The typefaces seem to belong to a bygone era, the words to a time before that. Leah Singer was first drawn to the ubiquitous “Post No Bills” signs about a decade ago, when she noticed one with squares for the O’s. The crudeness of the handmade stencil, and the anonymity of the artisan behind it, seemed to wink at the message it was meant to convey. It was more like an invitation than a warning, Ms. Singer, 53, said.

headline: Evening Hours | Events From the Week of April 18
abstract: This week’s events including The American Museum of Natural History’s annual spring lecture and luncheon at the museum, The Public Art Fund’s spring benefit and more.
lead_paragraph: This week’s events including The American Museum of Natural History’s annual spring lecture and luncheon at the museum, The Public Art Fund’s spring benefit and more.

headline: Costly Lapse by a New York Presidential Candidate

headline: Bill Cunningham | Freedom to Choose

lead_paragraph: The sheer madness of fashion reflected New York’s reality during primary week. Around Fifth Avenue and 57th Street, Secret Service agents leaned out the windows of the Trump motorcade, and dozens of RVs formed a caravan for Passover. Outside Trump Tower, there was a circuslike atmosphere

headline: The Baghdad Follies
abstract: Iraqi politicians seem to be squandering another chance to build a better future.
lead_paragraph: Iraq, engaged in a brutal war against the Islamic State, faces myriad other problems, including a depleted treasury and a weakening dam in Mosul that if not repaired could flood a huge strip of territory and kill thousands. None of these problems can be effectively addressed given the failure of governance and societal cohesion that has now produced another political crisis.

headline: 2,000 Ways to Say ‘Buenos Días’
abstract: Each day, the Mexican bakery in Sunset Park turns out rolls, muffins, doughnuts and items like conchas, buns topped with a butter-and-sugar paste.
lead_paragraph: Before sunrise on weekdays, minivans ferrying laborers from Brooklyn to New Jersey make a pit stop at Don Paco López Panadería, a Mexican bakery on Fourth Avenue near 47th Street, in Sunset Park.

headline: Rod Daniel, Whose Crowd-Pleasing Films Lined Pockets, Dies at 73
abstract: Mr. Daniel said he had no illusions of greatness as a filmmaker, but that he believed in his work.
lead_paragraph: Rod Daniel, who directed hit television sitcoms and moneymaking, family-friendly movie comedies like the Michael J. Fox film “Teen Wolf,” died last Saturday at his home in Chicago. He was 73.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Glimpse Housing Up Close
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Presidential Election of 2008']
abstract: Although most people live in cities, urbanism and the problems of urban poverty still get little attention during presidential election cycles.
lead_paragraph: In the days leading up to the presidential primaries in New York, both Democratic candidates visited public developments operated by the New York City Housing Authority. Hillary Clinton went to the Corsi Houses, a complex for older people in East Harlem, and Bernie Sanders traveled to the Howard Houses in Brownsville, Brooklyn, where two years ago a 21-year-old was shot to death, his body found outside an early learning center on the ground floor. Senator Sanders, who had been shocked to learn that the Housing Authority, the largest in the country, was in need of $17 billion in capital repairs, followed that visit with one to another complex, Twin Parks West, in the Bronx, where he observed an abandoned community center and lamented the general state of affairs that could lead to such decay.

headline: F.B.I. Says Killing Man Was Justified, but Not Shooting His Tire
abstract: The F.B.I. has faulted an agent who shot the tire of a suspect’s S.U.V. during an attempted arrest, but not two other agents who killed the man.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Jameel Harrison, a suspected drug dealer, attempted to escape from F.B.I agents trying to arrest him near a Baltimore shopping center two years ago, agents opened fire. Two bullets hit his Infiniti FX37’s left front tire. Six bullets struck him in the head and neck, killing him.

headline: Investigators Say Mexico Has Thwarted Efforts to Solve Students’ Disappearance
keywords: ['Missing Persons', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: International experts brought to Mexico to investigate the disappearance of 43 students say they have faced sustained harassment and stonewalling.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — An international panel of experts brought to Mexico to investigate the haunting disappearance of 43 students that ignited a global outcry say they cannot solve the case because of a sustained campaign of harassment, stonewalling and intimidation against them.

headline: Microsoft and Google Agree to Drop Mutual Complaints
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Inventions and Patents']
abstract: In withdrawing complaints with authorities worldwide, the companies said they would try to resolve future disputes before protesting to regulators.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Microsoft and Google agreed on Friday to withdraw complaints against each other with regulators around the world, as the two American tech giants continued recent efforts to settle the once-bitter conflicts between them.

headline: Brooklyn Gets a Superhero (and a Few Villains)
abstract: “New Brooklyn,” a web comics series, chronicles life in an anthropomorphized borough, with heroes and villains like the Red Hook and Benson Hurst.
lead_paragraph: All New Yorkers think their neighborhoods have personalities. But it takes the imagination of a comic-book artist to give them feelings and a soul.

headline: Prince and the Competition
abstract: Rivalry defined his career from the beginning — and drove some of his greatest displays of genius.
lead_paragraph: One of the more impressive artifacts making the Internet rounds in the last 24 hours is a video, recorded at the 2004 Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony, of an all-star band playing the Beatles’ “While My Guitar Gently Weeps.” The performance is a tribute to George Harrison, a posthumous honoree that evening, by a group that includes his son Dhani, along with old bandmates and collaborators like Tom Petty, Jeff Lynne and Steve Winwood. Then there’s another person on stage, too, standing a bit apart from the rest, bent over an electric guitar. He’s a small man, in a dark pinstriped suit, a scarlet red shirt and matching derby hat — a look that splits the difference between toreador and pimp. For a while, the guy hangs back in the shadows, strumming and looking a bit bored. But three and a half minutes in, he saunters into the spotlight to take a guitar solo.

headline: How the Artist Daniel Arsham Spends His Sundays
abstract: When Mr. Arsham, co-founder of the design team Snarkitecture, is not traveling, he is enjoying madeleines with his 3-year-old son or catching an art show.
lead_paragraph: The artist Daniel Arsham is one half of a design team called Snarkitecture, so it should come as no surprise that his work — which includes sculpture, movies, set design and collaboration on music videos — has a puckish sense of play. Walls seem to be melting, ceiling forms appear to be dripping down, stairways go nowhere. In a collaboration with the musician and producer Pharrell Williams, Mr. Arsham, 35, remade Mr. Williams’s first Casio MT-500 keyboard in volcanic ash, shattered glass, crystal and steel. On a recent morning, he was just back from a trip to Japan, where he had worked on a film about kendo (Japanese fencing) and mounted a gallery exhibition of his work. “I’m pretty good with jet lag,” he said, preparing for a busy day in New York, where he lives in Battery Park City with his wife, Stephanie, 38, and their son, Casper, 3. “I just ignore it. With the amount of travel I do, if I get into that feeling of ‘Oh, I’m tired all the time,’ I’ll just be that.” The Arshams are expecting their second child in July.

headline: National Park in Paterson, N.J., Ponders 2 Paths: Natural Wonder or Historical Site?
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: Rival plans have emerged for the Paterson Great Falls National Historical Park. One emphasizes its natural beauty, the other its role as an early industrial powerhouse.
lead_paragraph: PATERSON, N.J. — The young national park in this once-booming industrial city is unusual for its twin features — one natural, the other historical.

headline: Saving a New York Neighborhood From Gentrification
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Zoning', 'Gentrification', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s rezoning plan for East New York is an ambitious attempt to help provide more affordable housing.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Council on Wednesday approved Mayor Bill de Blasio’s plan for rezoning East New York. Those 190 blocks of Brooklyn are the first, and largest, of 15 neighborhoods across the city where the administration intends to harness the real estate market to help achieve its ambitious 10-year goal of building or preserving 200,000 affordable apartments.

headline: Reince Priebus Calls on G.O.P. to Back Nominee, Even if It’s You-Know-Who
abstract: The Republican National Committee chairman suggested party members ignore Donald J. Trump’s attacks because “we all need to get behind the nominee” in the fall.
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD, Fla. — The head of the Republican National Committee implored leaders of his sharply divided party on Friday to rally behind their eventual presidential nominee, suggesting that they ignore Donald J. Trump’s assault on the nominating process.

headline: Prince Tributes Include Purple Lighting and Broadway Performances
abstract: The musician, who died on Thursday, was remembered with public displays at buildings, subway stations and on the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Tributes to Prince, the singer and songwriter who died at 57 on Thursday, took on many forms.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: An Uber driver accused of killing six people during mass shootings in Kalamazoo is competent to understand the murder charges and assist his lawyer, a judge said Friday, a major step to putting the criminal case back on track. A mental exam of the driver, Jason Dalton, at a state hospital was not intended to determine whether he was insane at the time of the Feb. 20 shootings, but rather whether he understands the charges and can assist his defense. During a brief hearing, Judge Tiffany Ankley said Mr. Dalton is competent. Mr. Dalton, 45, is charged with murder and attempted murder. The police said he shot people outside an apartment building, a restaurant and a car dealership in between driving for Uber. Two victims, including a teenager, survived. (AP)

headline: Times Virtual Reality Film Wins World Press Photo Award

headline: A Cashless Society? Not Before Tubman’s $20 Arrives
abstract: Though Americans are relying less on paper money for transactions, the demise of greenbacks is expected to take a longer time than many imagine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After more than a century-long wait, women and African-Americans are finally going to be represented on the country’s paper currency. But with the new bills years away, how many people will even be carrying cash by the time they go into circulation?

headline: Fiat Chrysler Announces Recall of 1.1 Million Autos

lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Fiat Chrysler said on Friday that it was recalling 1.1 million vehicles that can roll away unexpectedly and cause injuries when the transmission is not used properly, adding to a spate of recent safety actions by carmakers.

headline: Invoking a Higher Power to Clean Up the Gowanus Canal

abstract: Friars and nuns gathered at the polluted Brooklyn waterway on Earth Day for what they call the annual Blessing of the Gowanus.

headline: Honduran Ex-Police Chief Says Government Faked Documents in Assassination Case
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Police', 'Drug Cartels', 'Organized Crime']
abstract: Ramón Sabillón Pineda, a police general, says that files implicating officers in the killing of two antidrug officials are part of a “crude setup.”
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A former chief of the Honduran national police says the government has mounted a “crude setup” by fabricating and leaking documents to implicate high-ranking officers in the assassination of two top antidrug officials, adding a new twist to a scandal that is peeling back the collusion between drug traffickers and the police.

headline: Fighting Back for Their Gunned-Down Children
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Newtown, Conn, Shooting (2012)', 'Gun Control', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Immunity from Prosecution', 'Editorial Notebook']
abstract: Parents from Sandy Hook Elementary are pursuing a lawsuit attacking the reckless marketing of assault rifles.
lead_paragraph: NEWTOWN, Conn. — As mass shootings scar the nation, it’s understandable that victims’ grief-stricken families often withdraw from sight, engulfed in relentless grief. But not Mark Barden and Nicole Hockley, two parents who lost young sons in the grisly massacre in 2012 in which 20 schoolchildren and six educators were murdered at Sandy Hook Elementary School.

headline: Clues to the Mystery of Prince’s Final Days

lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The 1988 Dassault Falcon 900 was about an hour into its flight from Atlanta in the wee hours of Friday, April 15, when the pilot made a distress call to air traffic controllers in Chicago.

headline: Whitewashing, a Long History

lead_paragraph: White actors playing Asian characters demonstrate how invisible Asian-Americans continue to be in Hollywood.

headline: Why Won’t Hollywood Cast Asian Actors?
abstract: Economics has nothing to do with racist casting policies.
lead_paragraph: HERE’S an understatement: It isn’t easy being an Asian-American actor in Hollywood. Despite some progress made on the small screen — thanks, “Fresh Off the Boat”! — a majority of roles that are offered to Asian-Americans are limited to stereotypes that wouldn’t look out of place in an ’80s John Hughes comedy.

headline: Lonnie Mack, Singer and Guitarist Who Pioneered Blues-Rock, Dies at 74

headline: Brazil’s Dilma Rousseff, at U.N. Climate Ceremony, Assails ‘Coup Mongers’
abstract: Ms. Rousseff used the international platform to assert that the campaign to oust her from office is little more than a coup d’état.
lead_paragraph: With the prospect of an impeachment trial nipping at her heels, President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil appealed for international support Friday during a visit to New York, broadcasting her claims that the campaign to oust her from office was little more than a coup d’état.

headline: Russian Military Buildup Near Aleppo, Syria, Threatens Truce, Kerry Warns

headline: Ideal Height For Some Contact
abstract: Paolo Pasco returns with a puzzle that made me happy, but not for the reasons you would think.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — After I solve a puzzle, I like to sit back and take the overall temperature of what I just experienced. I look over the entries, the clues, what I knew and what I didn’t know, but most of all, I look at how the puzzle made me feel.

headline: Suspect in Brooklyn Triple Homicide Is Charged After 7 Months

headline: Having Trouble Driving In Runs, Yankees Try Stealing One

headline: After Overtime Penalty Save, Islanders Prevail in a Goaltending Battle

headline: Cassandra Clare Created a Fantasy Realm and Aims to Maintain Her Rule

Yet she was not the first at the door.

headline: Bangladesh Police Suspect Islamist Militants in Professor’s Killing

lead_paragraph: LONDON — President Obama urged a roomful of young people in London on Saturday to support a new trade deal between the United States and the European Union, arguing that it can be written in a way that does not undercut the interests of unions, workers and the environment.

headline: North Korea Fires Ballistic Missile From Submarine, South Says

headline: 1888: Paris Honors Shakespeare

lead_paragraph: Today is the 400th anniversary of William Shakespeare’s death. In 1888, the European edition of The New York Herald wrote about a statue of the playwright that was unveiled in Paris. In 1941, the Vichy government ordered that the statue be removed and melted down to be used by the war industry.

headline: Why Trump Is Calling the G.O.P. Delegate System Rigged

headline: Boris Is Bad Enough
abstract: The mayor of London makes the case against Brexit, which would empower people like him.
lead_paragraph: Thank you, Boris Johnson. You’ve finally given me the moral courage to weigh in on a subject I’ve been avoiding: Brexit, Britain’s possible exit from the European Union. It’s not as easy a case as I’d like – but Johnson’s intervention makes it clear: Britain should stay in, lest it empower people like him.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: To Be or Not To Be an Uber Employee

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Pennsylvania Visit Is Another ‘Welcome Home’
abstract: Hillary Clinton, fresh off a win in her adopted home state of New York, recalled her family’s ties to Scranton, Pa., at a rally nearby on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: DUNMORE, Pa. — Three days after winning the primary in her adopted home state, Hillary Clinton sounded right at home again Friday in Pennsylvania.

headline: A Long, Slow Elevator Ride
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Elevators and Escalators', 'Cameras', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Condominiums', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: Sabbath elevators, creepy cameras and creaky condominium noises are this week’s topics.
lead_paragraph: Sabbath Elevators

headline: Yankees Turn to Platoons as They Try to March to October
abstract: With a losing record in April, the playoffs seem like a distant mirage, but understanding the calendar is essential.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees are most exciting when their best players go back in time. They can still do it now and then. Jacoby Ellsbury, who stole home against the Yankees in 2009, did it for them on Friday night.

headline: Inside Chernobyl’s Exclusion Zone
abstract: Some young Ukrainians have made a hobby of going to the zone, set aside in perpetuity after the nuclear plant catastrophe 30 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Some young Ukrainians have made a hobby of going to the zone, set aside in perpetuity after the nuclear plant catastrophe 30 years ago.

headline: Chernobyl’s Silent Exclusion Zone (Except for the Logging)
abstract: Thirty years later, there are signs of commercial clear-cutting in supposedly off-limits forests around the site of the nuclear disaster in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: PRIPYAT, Ukraine — The road through the forest, abandoned, is at times barely discernible, covered with the debris of fallen tree limbs, vines, leaves and moss pushing up through cracks in the crumbling asphalt.

headline: Hustling Away in Margaritaville
abstract: Forget the ville. This is a Margarita World. Jimmy Buffett has built an empire in lodging, alcohol, licensing and media.
lead_paragraph: Forget the ville. This is a Margarita World. Jimmy Buffett has built an empire in lodging, alcohol, licensing and media.

headline: Jimmy Buffett’s ‘Margaritaville’ Is a State of Mind, and an Empire
abstract: The singer’s company is expanding offerings in lodging, alcohol, licensing and media, and the appeal extends well beyond Parrot Heads.
lead_paragraph: His newest showstopper, a 17-story hotel near Miami, has three pools, a full-service spa and eight restaurants, including a seriously upscale steakhouse. That electric blue sculpture in the lobby? You’d swear it was by Jeff Koons.

headline: Variety Puzzle: Split Decisions
abstract: Fred Piscop offers us a Split Decisions.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Split Decisions puzzles are a great break after a week’s worth of crossword puzzles. You need to use your brain to solve them, but they’re easier and you use a different part of the brain than you use to solve a crossword. At least it feels that way.

headline: A Respite of Soccer for Qatar’s Laborers
keywords: ['Soccer', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'World Cup 2022 (Soccer)']
abstract: The players in the four-year-old Workers Cup are just a fraction of the thousands of migrant workers who are actively building Qatar into a modern state.
lead_paragraph: DOHA, Qatar — It was not yet 8 a.m., but already a fierce sun was beating down as the Taleb Group soccer team arrived at the technical committee building of the Qatar Football Association. As had been the case on Friday mornings for the past few weeks, even at such an early hour, the players who passed the white minaret at the center’s entrance on their way toward its state-of-the-art soccer fields were not the first to arrive.

headline: An Etsy Product Manager’s Do-It-Yourself Career Path
abstract: Hard work and a willingness to learn help an English major succeed at a tech start-up that helps artisans sell handcrafted goods online.
lead_paragraph: Jaime DeLanghe, 29, is a senior product manager at Etsy in Brooklyn.

headline: The High Fees You Don’t See Can Hurt You
keywords: ['Mutual Funds', 'Financial Planners', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans']
abstract: New rules will require some financial advisers to act in investors’ interests, but many will still be able to sell funds that cost you and enrich them.
lead_paragraph: High fees, often hidden from view, are still enriching many advisers and financial services companies at the expense of ordinary people who are struggling to salt away savings. The problem has persisted year after year. A new analysis of mutual fund data confirms its severity.

headline: Building a Better Breast Pump, Not a Milking Machine
abstract: Several new companies are designing more discreet, efficient, comfortable and technologically sophisticated breast pumps.
lead_paragraph: It resembles a piece of farm equipment. It’s cumbersome, heavy and noisy. Its users must be partly nude. It’s made of a web of tubes and funnels that could have been designed by Rube Goldberg. It’s the breast pump.

headline: Achieving Mindfulness at Work, No Meditation Cushion Required
abstract: An author explains how seeing problems from a different perspective may have a similar outcome as the Eastern approach of suspending thought.
lead_paragraph: In a recent seminar I gave for over 100 business professionals, I asked the participants to play a simple word association game with me: “I say mindfulness, you say ________.” The word that rang out in unison was, of course, “meditation.”

headline: Keeping the Thunder on Their Game
abstract: Amanda Green, who was a team manager for the Duke men’s basketball team, has numerous roles as Oklahoma City’s basketball operations coordinator.
lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Amanda Green knew precisely why she was having lunch Thursday in a 17th-floor restaurant accessible only to guests of the luxury hotel where she and the rest of the Oklahoma City Thunder organization were staying during their first-round playoff series against the Mavericks. In a sense, knowing why is part of her job.

headline: On the Trail: The Week of April 17
abstract: The New York primary was the week’s big event, though the candidates also moved through the Northeast and the mid-Atlantic states before the next primary contests on April 26.
lead_paragraph: The New York primary was the week’s big event, though the candidates also moved through the Northeast and the mid-Atlantic states before the next primary contests on April 26.

headline: Ireland Seeks Peaceful Path to Marking 1916 Easter Rising
abstract: A critical, deadly episode in the quest for independence remains divisive 100 years on. Some see undemocratic treachery; others, heroism.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — A century on from the 1916 Easter Rising, a critical moment in Ireland’s quest for independence from Britain, the event continues to polarize opinion in Ireland and beyond. Some regard it as undemocratic treachery, others as a heroic act of selflessness whose legacy remains unfulfilled.

headline: White Sox Turn a Triple Play Slow Enough to Savor
abstract: If you were keeping score at home, that was 9-3-2-6-2-5 in the Rangers’ half of the seventh inning. To put it simply, base-running mistakes were made.
lead_paragraph: Most triple plays happen so quickly that fans do not realize what they have witnessed until they see it on the scoreboard. A hard liner to third base, a step on the bag for a second out, a quick throw to another base, and suddenly a promising inning is over.

headline: Donald Trump Tones It Down
abstract: Mr. Trump dispenses with the ominous thing in his new ads, addressing the camera directly the way a more conventional candidate might.
lead_paragraph: Two new ads from Donald J. Trump running on television stations in Pennsylvania and Indiana show a more refined, controlled message from a presidential candidate who has shown an aversion to staying on script.

headline: Red Bulls Struggling to Reach Bar They Set Last Season
abstract: The tactics are the same, but the Red Bulls hardly resemble the team that finished tied for the best record in the M.L.S. last season.
lead_paragraph: WHIPPANY, N.J. — Nothing has changed, visibly, on the practice field. The Red Bulls still show up at their pitch-perfect facility for training, still under the calm tutelage of Coach Jesse Marsch, still instructed by his staff in the art of systematic, high-press soccer.

headline: Only Congress Can Rescue Puerto Rico
abstract: The federal government should act now, but a flawed House bill needs some serious fixing.
lead_paragraph: Puerto Rico is beset by problems. Its government is straining under a mountain of debt, the economy is deteriorating and the Zika virus is spreading. Only Congress has the power to help, but it is not moving fast enough.

headline: What Happens When Baseball-Stats Nerds Run a Pro Team?
keywords: ['Baseball', 'Statistics', 'Draft and Recruitment (Sports)', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: With data and a willingness to subvert orthodoxy, the Sonoma Stompers played an imaginative, weird game.
lead_paragraph: IN 2015, the Sonoma Stompers, the team with one of the lowest payrolls in the Pacific Association, a professional baseball league near San Francisco, did something desperate: It handed its baseball-operations department to a couple of stat-savvy writers with no baseball-management experience, Ben Lindbergh and me.

headline: The Reactionary Mind
keywords: ['Fringe Groups and Movements', 'Social Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Discrimination']
abstract: Is there room for a far-right renaissance in the world of ideas?
lead_paragraph: OVER the last year, America’s professional intelligentsia has been placed under the microscope in several interesting ways.

headline: Friendship in the Age of Trump
abstract: The success of his candidacy is breaking deep bonds among Republicans.
lead_paragraph: AT this stage in a presidential campaign, Republicans, generally a rather disciplined lot, have usually united and begun to train their fire on Democrats. Circular firing squads are for them, not us.

headline: Finding the Right College
abstract: Readers discuss how to make college admissions less stressful and ensure a good match.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss how to make college admissions less stressful and ensure a good match.

headline: Roger Michel
abstract: A high-tech archaeologist on London’s latest ancient arch, Hemingway’s chauvinism and the transformative effect of watches.
lead_paragraph: Roger Michel is the founder and executive director of the Institute for Digital Archaeology, an academic consortium that uses technology to conserve, study and even re-create ancient treasures, such as a two-thirds-scale marble reproduction of the Palmyra Arch of Triumph, which was unveiled last week in Trafalgar Square in London. Last October, the Islamic State destroyed the second-century original in central Syria.

headline: Aid in Dying in Canada
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Death and Dying', 'Law and Legislation', 'Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide']
abstract: It’s important to provide a humane option to the dying. It’s also essential that people have access to palliative and hospice care.
lead_paragraph: Canada has moved a step closer to allowing ailing people who are near death to end their lives with the help of a doctor.

headline: Finding Love Again, This Time With a Man
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: I lost my wife to cancer when I was almost 70. I never thought I would marry at 90.
lead_paragraph: AT age 70, I did not imagine that I would fall in love again and remarry. But the past 20 years have made my life a story of two great loves.

headline: Georgetown and the Sin of Slavery
abstract: The university is morally obligated to deliver reparations, including scholarships for descendants of the people it sold.
lead_paragraph: The reparations movement, which calls for compensating the descendants of generations of enslaved Americans going back 250 years, has failed to gain traction in this country for a variety of reasons.

headline: Tempest in a Toilet
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: If a pee-peeved plutocrat can see the light about transgender people and bathrooms, can’t we all?
lead_paragraph: OUT of the potty mouths of billionaires sometimes comes potty sense. This was the case last week with Donald Trump, who weighed in on which bathrooms transgender people should use.

headline: Lessons From Underwater Miami
abstract: Clues to the future from an era when hippos splashed in the Rhine.
lead_paragraph: IN Miami’s fashionable financial district, a slab of limestone juts out of the ground beneath the elevated tracks of the commuter rail line, across the street from a new apartment building. The pockmarked rocks sit about 25 feet above sea level. But 120,000 years ago, this limestone outcrop was part of a white sandy shoal beneath a sea that covered the lower third of Florida.

headline: An Island of Support for New York’s Police
abstract: What is behind the deep loyalty Staten Islanders hold for the city’s police force?
lead_paragraph: LAST week, on a visit to my childhood home on Staten Island, I took my 4-month-old son out for a walk in the stroller. I moved away 10 years ago, but return often. In all that time, it seems, the place hasn’t really changed.

headline: What Drug Ads Don’t Say
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: That expensive new medication might not work any better than an older, cheaper alternative.
lead_paragraph: DRUG companies are eager to tell you about their newest medicines. Turn on your TV or go online and there’s a new drug — with a hefty price tag — for whatever ails you, from antidepressants to painkillers to remedies for erectile dysfunction.

headline: Is Hillary Clinton Dishonest?
abstract: The “Crooked Hillary” narrative is fundamentally unfair.
lead_paragraph: AFTER the New York primary, the betting websites are giving Hillary Clinton about a 94 percent chance of being the Democratic nominee, and Donald Trump a 66 percent chance of ending up as the Republican nominee.

headline: Race and the Standardized Testing Wars
abstract: A growing number of minority parents and educators are joining the anti-testing movement.
lead_paragraph: WHEN the parents of more than 200,000 pupils in the third through eighth grades in New York chose to have their children sit out standardized state tests last spring, major civil rights organizations were quick to condemn their decision, along with similar movements in Colorado, Washington and New Jersey.

headline: This Is Our Country. Let’s Walk It.
keywords: ['Land Use Policies', 'Keystone Pipeline System', 'Hikes and Hiking', 'Walking', 'Fences and Property Barriers']
abstract: In much of Europe, walking wherever you want is perfectly legal. Not in America.
lead_paragraph: A COUPLE of years ago, I trespassed across America. I’d set out to hike the proposed route of the Keystone XL pipeline, which had been planned to stretch over a thousand miles over the Great Plains, from Alberta, Canada, to the Gulf Coast. To walk the pipe’s route, roads wouldn’t do. I’d have to cross fields, hop barbed-wire fences and camp in cow pastures — much of it on private property.

headline: Obama Says Movements Like Black Lives Matter ‘Can’t Just Keep on Yelling’
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Discrimination', 'Racial Profiling', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama, in London, offered a critique of young activists, saying they had to work with political leaders to craft solutions.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — President Obama offered an indirect critique of the Black Lives Matter movement during a town-hall-style event here on Saturday, encouraging activists to engage with the political process and cautioning them that social change can be a slow and incremental process.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Isaiah Thomas Extols Playing in Boston, Warming an Old Celtic
abstract: Thomas’s unbridled declaration of love for Boston was music to Tommy Heinsohn’s ears.
lead_paragraph: Typically given to fits of full-ranged emotion on the subject of his beloved Boston Celtics, Tommy Heinsohn, after reading a recent article published under the byline of Isaiah Thomas, said: “It made you want to cry.”

headline: Donald Trump Frowns on Idea of ‘Toning It Down,’ Despite Aide’s Comments
abstract: A couple of days after his newly installed campaign chief told Republican leaders that Mr. Trump would be “evolving,” the candidate told two Connecticut crowds that he had no plans of changing his campaign approach.
lead_paragraph: As Donald J. Trump, who leads his two Republican opponents in both votes and delegates, begins preparing his campaign for a general election, he told voters in Connecticut on Saturday that they should not expect him to start “toning it down.”

headline: Brooklyn Quick to Grasp Stanley Cup Playoff Frenzy
abstract: After a few regular-season bumps in moving from Nassau Coliseum to Barclays Center, the Islanders listened to the players, and the fans, to make the transition smoother.
lead_paragraph: Brett Yormark could not hide his glee as he spoke about the first Stanley Cup game ever played in Brooklyn, last Sunday’s 4-3 overtime win by the Islanders over the Florida Panthers.

headline: Comments on the Bay Area’s Building Tensions
abstract: Readers comment on “Build, Baby, Build” (April 17).
lead_paragraph: In “Build, Baby, Build” (April 17), Conor Dougherty wrote of a San Francisco activist group, the Bay Area Renters’ Association, or BARF, and its founder, Sonja Trauss. As the city’s tech boom clashes with tough development laws and resentment from established residents, Ms. Trauss’s group is pushing for more housing, of all kinds, to be built. Tactics have included speaking out at government meetings, counterprotests against those fighting new development and a lawsuit against one suburb, Lafayette.

headline: Indians Look to Follow Mets’ Lead
abstract: Mike Chernoff, who helped build a winning team in Cleveland, is counting on his young rotation pillars Corey Kluber, Carlos Carrasco and Danny Salazar.
lead_paragraph: When the Cleveland Indians hosted the Mets last weekend, they saw the kind of team they want to be. The Mets reached the last World Series with a group of young, hard-throwing, right-handed starters who have yet to reach free agency. If the Indians get there this fall, it will be for the same reason.

headline: Stephen Curry’s Injury Evokes Memories of John Havlicek and ’72-’73 Celtics
abstract: The experiences of that Celtics team, which won 68 games but came up short after Havlicek was hurt, suggest that the Warriors may have something to worry about even when Curry returns.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Celtics’ franchise record for regular-season victories does not belong to a team featuring Bill Russell, or one led by Larry Bird or by Kevin Garnett. And perhaps most relevant, especially in light of the 73-victory Golden State Warriors’ now having played two playoff games without their injured star, Stephen Curry, it did not come with a championship.

headline: Not a Moment Too Soon, Gardner Homers for a Yanks Win
abstract: A ninth-inning home run, coupled with strong outings by the relief pitchers, lifted the Yankees in front of the home crowd.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees and the Tampa Bay Rays were tied, 2-2, in the ninth inning on Saturday when Brett Gardner stepped to the plate and began assessing ways to score a third run.

headline: Nomentum and the Vindication of Political Science
abstract: Quantitative analysis beats horserace storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Back in November — which seems like a very long time ago — I noted that political scientists were having some trouble with the nomination process; the whole “party decides” framework led them, by and large, to expect convergence on a mainstream candidate like Jeb Bush or Marco Rubio, not a duel between Mussolini and Torquemada. At the time I put this down to “regime change”; at this point I’d be more specific, and say that the political science profession basically had a blind spot about the transformation of the GOP into an extremist party. That’s why Norman Ornstein, who did face up to that reality, was so much closer to the mark than most of his colleagues.

headline: Powerhouse Junior Program Becomes a Springboard Into the N.H.L.
abstract: With a development program that mimics the pros, the London Knights of the Ontario Hockey League have produced three No. 1 draft picks, more than any other team.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Ontario — Driving east along Highway 401 from this handsome old city of 366,000, tracing another Thames upriver, leads to Toronto in about two hours. Head west, through a landscape of flat, featureless farmland, and the Detroit skyline appears in even less time.

headline: Times Virtual Reality Film Wins World Press Photo Award
abstract: New technologies like virtual reality are creating new opportunities for reporters and visual journalists to explore and innovate.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times has been awarded the top two places in the Innovative Storytelling category of the 2016 World Press Photo Multimedia Contest for the virtual reality film “The Displaced” and for “Greenland Is Melting Away.” Made for The Times’s VR app, “The Displaced” tells the stories of three children from different countries who were uprooted from their homes by war and persecution.

headline: Stephen Curry Is Eager to Return, but Warriors Are Moving With Caution
abstract: Curry will be re-evaluated Sunday, Coach Steve Kerr said, but his return would be good news for the Warriors, good news for television viewers and bad news for the Rockets.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Stephen Curry packed light for his most recent business trip.

headline: ‘Tee’ Time
abstract: The return of Kathy Wienberg.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — A sound-addition crossword theme is one where the constructor takes a familiar word or phrase and adds a particular sound to part of the word or phrase in order to make a different entry. Bonus points are scored if the new entry is a real thing and fairly funny or clever.

headline: In College Roommate David Panton, Ted Cruz Finds Unwavering Support
abstract: For decades, Mr. Panton has been a source of unconditional camaraderie, the guy who extends a hand when the whole world seems to offer a stiff-arm.
lead_paragraph: On a break during a business trip to Washington last year, David Panton hailed a cab to take him to the Capitol. He told the driver he was going to see the Texas senator and presidential candidate Ted Cruz.

headline: Penguins Eliminate Nemesis Rangers in Game 5 Rout
abstract: Pittsburgh sent Henrik Lundqvist to the bench again in a 6-3 victory and won the series, four games to one.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — There would be no elimination-game magic for Henrik Lundqvist and the Rangers this year.

headline: Earthquake Jolts Ecuador Into Enacting Long-Avoided Fiscal Changes
keywords: ['Taxation', 'Earthquakes', 'Credit and Debt', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: After the country’s largest quake since 1979, its leftist leaders are turning to the kinds of measures they rose to power railing against.
lead_paragraph: PORTOVIEJO, Ecuador — Even before the earthquake struck, prospects were rough for this tiny Andean nation.

headline: Housing Bias Outlasts Ruling in a Long Island Village
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Affordable Housing', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Federal Aid (US)', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Minorities']
abstract: A federal appeals court said officials of Garden City, N.Y., gave in to “race-based animus” when they rezoned land to block multifamily homes.
lead_paragraph: GARDEN CITY, N.Y. — Mary Crosson, a housing activist, remembers moving to Long Island from Bayside, Queens, in the 1990s and being struck by the sharp divisions that seemed to keep blacks and whites apart.

headline: In Hudson Valley Schools, a Program Spreads Learning Through Gardening
abstract: An enterprising young woman skips college to create a program nurturing a love of gardening and fresh food in Hudson Valley children.
lead_paragraph: Few things are more inspiring than seeing a young person create a meaningful place in society from scratch. That’s the case with Ava Bynum, who grew up near our home in Philipstown, N.Y., and — setting aside the idea of college — created a program for local schools, Hudson Valley Seed, built around incorporating basic learning with gardening and nutrition. The program now serves about 1,500 students a week in schools in several Hudson Valley counties.

headline: With Jacob deGrom on Deck, Matz Gets Help From the Mets’ Offense
abstract: Concerns over his newborn son’s health kept deGrom away for 12 days. He returned as the Mets beat the Atlanta Braves, 8-2.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Jacob deGrom returned to the Mets’ clubhouse on Saturday, resuming the life of a major league pitcher with some typical worries, such as his mechanics, his command and his back muscles.

headline: An Amateur vs. ISIS: A Car Salesman Investigates and Ends Up in Prison
abstract: Toby Lopez, a Delaware man, spent nearly 14 months in federal custody after he repeatedly reported online exchanges with people he believed to be terrorists.
lead_paragraph: WYOMING, Del. — By his own account, Toby Lopez was a supremely ordinary guy. He sold Toyotas and lived with his mother in a tidy rancher here with a cherry tree out front. He was proud that he could connect with customers — anyone from a Superior Court judge to, as he put it, “Redneck Bill from down on the farm.” What passed for excitement was the time his young niece won a beauty contest and he chauffeured her in a red Corvette in a local parade.

headline: Egyptian Police Official Files Complaint Against Reuters
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Newspapers', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The news agency reported that Giulio Regeni, an Italian graduate student, was in police custody before his death, a claim that law enforcement officials have denied.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian police official filed a criminal complaint against Reuters after the news agency published an article last week connecting the police to the disappearance of an Italian student, Giulio Regeni, prosecutors said on Saturday.

headline: Failure to Share Data Hampers War on Boko Haram in Africa
abstract: American intelligence services have struggled at times to provide information quickly about militants without violating restrictions on what can be shared.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The military campaign by Nigeria and neighboring nations to combat the West African militant group Boko Haram has been hampered by a failure among those countries to share crucial intelligence — sometimes even within their own security services, American and other Western officials say.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 24, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “We are living much more cloistered lives in terms of class. We are doing a much worse job of living out the egalitarian dream that has been our hallmark.”

headline: After Cremation, Prince Is Celebrated in Private Funeral
abstract: His ashes’ location will stay private, his publicist said. Meanwhile, an inquiry into the musician’s death continues, and a group of ‘his most beloved’ laid him to rest.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Family and friends of Prince held a small, private funeral on Saturday after the music superstar’s body was cremated, his publicist, Yvette Noel-Schure, said in a statement.

headline: Carbon Pricing Becomes a Cause for the World Bank and I.M.F.
keywords: ['Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Poverty', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Global Warming', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: To ensure that the Paris agreement on climate change works, two global lenders have begun pressing national governments to ensure that polluters pay for the carbon dioxide they emit.
lead_paragraph: The World Bank and International Monetary Fund are pressing governments to impose a price tag on planet-warming carbon dioxide emissions, using economic leverage and technical assistance that institutions like the United Nations cannot muster.

headline: ‘Outlander’ Season 2, Episode 3: An Unusual Lady
abstract: While placing the current story line in Paris has given the show a richness, it has also introduced some problems.
lead_paragraph: The sophomore seasons of television shows often either evolve to build on their strengths or magnify their weaknesses in an attempt to best the first. One of the aspects of “Outlander” I admired in its first season was its ability to deftly blend a multitude of genres and moods, pivoting in a single episode from wartime drama to swooning romanticism to farce.

headline: Turkey’s Seizure of Churches and Land Alarms Armenians
abstract: The diaspora and rights groups have been unnerved by expropriations in Diyarbakir, where the government is fighting militants and where, it says, it will return properties after restoration is complete.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — The Turkish government has seized the historic Armenian Surp Giragos Church, a number of other churches and large swaths of property in the heavily damaged Kurdish city of Diyarbakir, saying it wants to restore the area but alarming residents who fear the government is secretly aiming to drive them out.

headline: Hillary Clinton Warns Voters About Donald Trump’s Evolving Image
abstract: At a rally in Rhode Island, she urged people not to believe Mr. Trump when he says he is softening his image and declared that he “wants to go after every one of the rights we have.’
lead_paragraph: CENTRAL FALLS, R.I. — If Donald J. Trump starts to soften his image, Hillary Clinton has a warning for voters.

headline: Beyoncé Releases Surprise Album ‘Lemonade’ After HBO Special
keywords: ['Music', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: In images accompanying the new album, the singer confronts rumors about her marriage to Jay Z, and features the mothers of black men killed by police.
lead_paragraph: She did it again.

headline: Donald Trump’s Aging Air Fleet Gives His Bid, and His Brand, a Lift
abstract: A look at Mr. Trump’s airplanes and helicopters suggests that their value rests chiefly in their marketing potential, with the candidate’s stamp of status masking an aging fleet.
lead_paragraph: Of all the things connected to Donald J. Trump, few have given him more mileage than his fleet of aircraft.

headline: Brian Asawa, Celebrated Countertenor and Pathbreaker at the Met, Dies at 49
abstract: Mr. Asawa was one of only a handful of countertenors to enjoy international renown.
lead_paragraph: Brian Asawa, one of the world’s foremost countertenors, whose repertoire ran from the Renaissance to Rorem, died on Monday in Mission Hills, Calif. He was 49.

headline: Obama Calls Meeting With European Leaders Over Shared Challenges
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The meeting comes amid a growing sense in the administration that Europe is faltering in the face of multiple challenges, undercutting the trans-Atlantic alliance.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — President Obama will meet with Western European leaders on Sunday and Monday amid a growing sense in his administration that Europe is faltering in the face of multiple challenges, undercutting the trans-Atlantic alliance at a critical time.

headline: Obama Joins Angela Merkel in Pushing Trade Deal to a Wary Germany
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Standing next to Chancellor Merkel in Hanover, President Obama said the benefits of a new trans-Atlantic trade deal were “indisputable.”
lead_paragraph: HANOVER, Germany — President Obama said on Sunday that he was confident the United States and the European Union would succeed in negotiating a new trans-Atlantic trade deal by the end of the year, saying the benefits of such an agreement were “indisputable.”

headline: Gennady Golovkin Defends Titles
abstract: Golovkin defended his middleweight titles in devastating fashion in Inglewood, Calif., stopping Dominic Wade with 23 seconds left in the second round for his 22nd straight knockout victory.
lead_paragraph: Gennady Golovkin defended his middleweight titles in devastating fashion in Inglewood, Calif., stopping Dominic Wade with 23 seconds left in the second round for his 22nd straight knockout victory.

headline: Morgan Muir, Michael Callahan-Dudley
abstract: The couple, both Bay Area lawyers, met at a bar in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Ashley Muir and Michael Ray Callahan-Dudley were married April 23 at Craneway Pavilion, an event space in Richmond, Calif. The Rev. J. Edwin Bacon Jr., an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Sylvana Hidalgo, David Wheelock
abstract: The couple met through their secret society at Yale.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Sylvana Marcela Hidalgo, a daughter of Sara C. Hidalgo and David J. Hidalgo of Altadena, Calif., was married on April 23 to David Smith Wheelock, a son of Candace S. Wheelock and Peter Wheelock of Darien, Conn. The Rev. John Stoeger, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Mary, Star of the Sea Catholic Church in San Diego.

headline: Tamima Mohammed and Ryan Crosner: Sharing Notes and Getting Ideas
abstract: The bride and groom met at the University of Pennsylvania, from which each received a law degree.
lead_paragraph: Tamima Azeeza Mohammed and Ryan Hamilton Crosner were married April 23 at their home in Redondo Beach, Calif. The officiant was Shaun H. Crosner, the groom’s brother, who became ordained through American Marriage Ministries for the event.

headline: Laura Thoren, Sebastian Podesta
abstract: The couple met on a tennis court after the bride’s mother encouraged the two to talk.
lead_paragraph: Laura Thoren, a daughter of  Lisa E. Thoren and Peter L. Thoren of Darien, Conn., was married April 23 to Sebastian Ariel Podesta, the son of Adriana L. Podesta and Dr. Augusto H. Podesta, also of Darien. The Rev. David Anderson, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. Luke’s Parish in Darien.

headline: Katherine Pielemeier, Wesley Thompson
abstract: The couple met in 2008 while working in Ohio for President Obama’s re-election campaign.
lead_paragraph: Katherine Lynne Pielemeier and Wesley Graham Thompson were married April 23 at Riverside on the Potomac, a wedding venue in Leesburg, Va. The Rev. Robert Maddox, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

headline: Peter Kukielski, Drew Hodges
abstract: The couple met in 2008 at an event at the New York Botanical Garden.
lead_paragraph: Peter Edward Kukielski and Jonathan Drew Hodges were married April 22 at City Hall in Portland, Me., where Teresa J. Bunn, a records clerk, officiated.

headline: Kathryn Swain, Daniel Marrs
abstract: The couple met at Wake Forest University, from which they graduated.
lead_paragraph: Kathryn Voorhees Swain, a daughter of Dr. Mary Early Swain and Jeffrey Voorhees Swain of Tallahassee, Fla., was married April 23 to Daniel Cole Marrs, a son of Elizabeth Gage Koch Marrs and Bradley P. Marrs of Richmond, Va. The Rev. Eric Dudley, an Anglican priest, officiated at the Pierre in New York.

headline: Jyoti Duggal, Kevin Kumar
abstract: The couple met at Cornell, from which they both graduated.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jyoti Duggal, a daughter of Sangeeta Duggal and Surinder M. Duggal of Staten Island, was married April 23 to Kevin Krishan Kumar, the son of Deomattie Kumar and Sanjeev Kumar of Seaford, N.Y. Pandit Acharya Arvind Shukla officiated at the Leela Palace, a hotel in New Delhi.

headline: Anna Steffens, Katharine Uva
abstract: The couple met on OKCupid.
lead_paragraph: Anna Marin Steffens, the daughter of Zita Ingham and Ronald E. Steffens of Bandon, Ore., is to be married April 24 to Katharine Elizabeth Uva, a daughter of Ken Uva of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Shelley Uva. Shannon Sun-Higginson, a Universal Life minister and a friend of the couple, is to officiate at the Gil Hodges Community Garden in Brooklyn.

headline: Andrea Riccio, Dustin Todd
abstract: The couple met in 2009 in Washington while working for Representative Paul Tonko, Democrat of New York.
lead_paragraph: Andrea Marie Riccio and Dustin James Todd were married April 23 at St. Mary's Catholic Church in Ballston Spa, N.Y. The Very Rev. Conan Timoney, a Roman Catholic priest and a great-uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

headline: Meredith Sheldon, Denison Hatch III
abstract: The bride, a social worker, and the groom, a writer, were introduced by a childhood friend of the groom in April 2011.
lead_paragraph: Meredith Julia Sheldon and Denison Hurlbut Hatch III were married April 23 at Greystone Mansion in Beverly Hills, Calif. The Rev. Peter Rood, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

headline: Dana Kinker, Keegan O’Brien
abstract: The couple was married at St. Mary’s Church in Annapolis.
lead_paragraph: Dana Ann Kinker and Keegan Collier O’Brien were married April 23. The Rev. Charles Hergenroeder, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary’s Church in Annapolis, Md.

headline: Stefani Johnson, Brett Myrick
abstract: The couple met at Harvard, from which they received law degrees.
lead_paragraph: Stefani Leigh Johnson and Brett Hunter Myrick were married April 23 by the Rev. Daniel J. Edwards at Covenant Presbyterian Church in Birmingham, Ala.

headline: Ashley Corbitt, Christopher Sweeney
abstract: The couple was married at the University Club of Chicago, where they met in 2013.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Taylor Corbitt, the daughter of Diane N. Corbitt and R. Ashley Corbitt of Atlanta, was married April 23 to Christopher Michael Sweeney, the son of Rebecca B. Sweeney and Terrence M. Sweeney of Indianapolis. The Rev. Hardy H. Kim, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the University Club of Chicago, where the couple met in 2013.

headline: Jessica Walter, Steve Xu
abstract: The ceremony took place on the 95th floor of the John Hancock Center in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Jessica Ruth Walter, a daughter of Dr. William J. Walter and Kathryn R. Walter of Kalamazoo, Mich., was married April 23 to Dr. Steve Xu, the son of Yi Xia and Dr. Peter Xu of Diamond Bar, Calif. David Hunter, a Universal Life minister, officiated at the 95th, a restaurant and lounge on the 95th floor of the John Hancock Center in Chicago.

headline: Justin Joy, Drew Kovacs
abstract: Justin Joy, a graduate of Boston University, and Drew Kovacs, a graduate of Haverford, are married in Miami Beach.
lead_paragraph: Justin Allen Joy, a son of Renee E. Drewry of Powell, Ohio, and Dan A. Joy of Massillon, Ohio, was married April 23 to Drew Simon Kovacs, a son of Gaye M. Kovacs and Stephen Kovacs of Boca Raton, Fla. Betsy Leonidas, a mutual friend who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Bath Club, an event space in Miami Beach.

headline: Michelle Jamison, Edwin Smith
abstract: The bride and groom met at Columbia, where she received a medical degree and he a doctor of dental surgery degree.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Michelle Sofia Jamison, a daughter of Aster M. Jamison and Charles W. Jamison of Upland, Calif., was married April 23 to Dr. Edwin Pierre Smith, a son of Lydie L. Smith and Dr. Pierre-Michel Smith of Miami. The Rev. Mark A. Bernthal, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at St. Armands Key Lutheran Church in Sarasota, Fla.

headline: Amy Dudley, Kip Wainscott
abstract: The couple met in March 2012 while working in Chicago at the Obama-Biden re-election campaign headquarters.
lead_paragraph: Amy Gamble Dudley and Kip Forrest Wainscott were married April 23 in Washington. Senator Tim Kaine, Democrat of Virginia, who received temporary officiant status from the District of Columbia, officiated at the Studio Theater.

headline: Shriya Paliwal, Gaurav Mahindra
abstract: The bride and groom met at New York University, where they each received two degrees.
lead_paragraph: Shriya Paliwal, the daughter of Ila S. Paliwal and Dinesh C. Paliwal of Greenwich, Conn., is to be married April 24 to Dr. Gaurav Mahindra, the son of Rainu Mahindra and Dr. Umesh Mahindra of Dix Hills, N.Y. Pandit Devendra Shukla, a Hindu priest, is to officiate at the Plaza in New York.

headline: Corrections: April 24, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Sunday, April 24, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Your Weekend Briefing: Hillary Clinton, President Obama, Golden State
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here are the week’s top stories, and a look ahead.

headline: 1916: Suspected Plotters Captured in Ireland
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Roger Casement is taken prisoner in Ireland in 1916.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Admiralty issued the following statement, ‘‘Between midday on Thursday and nine o’clock Friday morning, a vessel disguised as a neutral merchantman, but in reality a Germany auxiliary warship, acting in concert with a German submarine, attempted to land arms and ammunition in Ireland. The vessel was sunk and a certain number of prisoners was taken. Among the prisoners was Sir Roger Casement.’’

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: Poem for a Warm Spring Day
abstract: In no time at all, the chill of early March becomes the balminess of late May, and clothes undergo a change.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: 1966: Buddhists Would ‘Neutralize’ Key Areas
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Buddhist leaders in Vietnam intend to propose a political settlement in 1966.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — Powerful militant Buddhist leaders, some allegedly pro-Communist, are planning to propose a neutralist political settlement for the key northern province where the majority of American and Korean combat troops are based.

headline: Stakeouts, by the Cooler, at a Bus Terminal’s Den of Thieves
abstract: At a drugstore in a Manhattan transit hub, undercover guards say they face an onslaught of shoplifters with an appetite for cosmetics, condoms and alcohol.
lead_paragraph: He sipped from a bottle of iced tea, taking his position near a corner in the L-shaped Duane Reade. From there, he could see the cold medicine in Aisle 7A, the deodorants in Aisle 3, security videos on a screen above Aisle 5 and, most important, near the entrance, the beer cooler.

headline: Union Drops Effort to Restrict U.S. Imports of Raw Aluminum
abstract: The United Steelworkers withdrew its petition to a trade panel after an industry group agreed to work with the union to address concerns over Chinese production.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The United Steelworkers union has suspended indefinitely an unusual effort to push the United States government to restrict all aluminum imports after the campaign ran into opposition from aluminum companies, the Canadian government and even Canadian members of the union.

headline: What To Cook This Week
abstract: Keep it simple with three-ingredient recipes, and make a night of Cajun cooking.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Review: Beyoncé Makes ‘Lemonade’ Out of Marital Strife
abstract: The album, which probes betrayal, jealousy, revenge and rage, was released online on Saturday, immediately after an HBO showing of the “visual album” version.
lead_paragraph: Marital strife smolders, explodes and uneasily subsides on “Lemonade” (Parkwood Entertainment), the album Beyoncé flash-released on Saturday night. “You can taste the dishonesty/It’s all over your breath” are the first words she sings in “Pray You Catch Me,” and that’s just the beginning of an album that probes betrayal, jealousy, revenge and rage before dutifully willing itself toward reconciliation at the end. Many of the accusations are aimed specifically and recognizably at her husband, Shawn Carter, the rapper Jay Z. “Tonight I regret the night I put that ring on,” she talk-sings in “Sorry,” a twitchy, flippant song that’s by no means an apology. It’s a combative, unglossy track on an album full of them.

headline: Hillary Clinton Can’t Rely on Donald Trump’s Unpopularity
abstract: Mrs. Clinton, the likely Democratic nominee, has to overcome her own unfavorable ratings among voters, especially those who support Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Sherrod Brown of Ohio is a relatively accessible fellow, but when asked for an interview on the subject of the schisms in his Democratic Party, his schedule was full. Instead, he sent a statement that the Hillary Clinton-Bernie Sanders presidential primary battle was strengthening the party in contrast with the “divisive” Republican fight.

headline: Politico Pierces the ‘Brussels Bubble’ With U.S.-Style Coverage
abstract: The European outpost of the American political publication is bringing flood-the-zone reporting to the heart of the E.U., rankling some in the establishment.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The offices of Politico Europe, the Brussels outpost of the American political news organization, are less than a five-minute walk from the Maelbeek subway station where a suicide bomber killed more than a dozen people in the terrorist attacks here last month.

headline: What’s on TV Sunday
abstract: “Game of Thrones,” “Silicon Valley” and “Veep” begin new seasons. “Rebellion” soaps up the 1916 Easter Rising. And “Orange Is the New Black” awaits.
lead_paragraph: Set aside Sunday night for an HBO marathon of the new seasons of “Game of Thrones,” “Silicon Valley” and “Veep.” Tune in to a soapy historical drama based on the Easter Rising of 1916. Or catch up on unwatched episodes of “Orange Is the New Black” before a new season begins June 17.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Announces Audience Awards
abstract: The winners were “Here Alone,” directed by Rod Blackhurst, and “The Return,” directed by Kelly Duane de la Vega and Katie Galloway.
