lead_paragraph: The Tribeca Film Festival wrapped up on Sunday, and announced its Audience Award winners: “Here Alone,” directed by Rod Blackhurst, and “The Return,” directed by Kelly Duane de la Vega and Katie Galloway.

headline: Turning an Eye for Fashion on a Quiet Corner of a Hospital
abstract: After a stay at an Upper East Side hospital, the designer Dennis Basso decided that a nondenominational chapel there was in need of an update.
lead_paragraph: “The big reveal,” the fashion designer and high-end furrier Dennis Basso announced one afternoon last week, flinging open the doors leading to his latest redecorating project — a chapel.

headline: ‘The Huntsman: Winter’s War’ Can’t Topple ‘The Jungle Book’
abstract: Disney’s film remained at No. 1, while “The Huntsman” marked another misfire for Chris Hemsworth.
lead_paragraph: Leave the fairy tales to Disney.

headline: Review: ‘One Funny Mother’ Delivers One-Liners Without Depth
abstract: Dena Blizzard’s solo show about the travails of motherhood offers an evening of easy laughs but little insight.
lead_paragraph: “One Funny Mother,” Dena Blizzard’s solo show at New World Stages, is all about her and her family, but by the end of it you haven’t really learned anything specific about either. You’ve heard a lot of generic one-liners involving amusing children and clueless husbands, some of them pretty funny but none of them especially illuminating. It’s an evening of safe laughs for people, especially young mothers, who think that raising children is an impossibly demanding task.

headline: Charles Koch Says He Could Possibly Support Hillary Clinton
abstract: Charles Koch, the billionaire industrialist, suggested in an interview Sunday that he was open to supporting Hillary Clinton for president, saying it was possible she would make a better president than her Republican rivals.
lead_paragraph: Charles G. Koch, the billionaire industrialist, suggested in an interview Sunday that he was open to supporting Hillary Clinton for president and said it was possible she would make a better president than her Republican rivals.

headline: Was Your Dog Walked? Your Phone Can Show You
keywords: ['Maps', 'Mobile Applications', 'Delivery Services', 'Global Positioning System', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Smartphones']
abstract: On-demand businesses like Uber have changed customers’ expectations, and the kinds of real-time maps the ride-hailing company uses are spreading to other services.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Some parents find peace of mind in the location-tracking features in smartphones that let them keep tabs on their children. There are also the dog owners who can rest easy knowing that hired dog walkers are doing their job, and that the dogs are doing their business.

headline: Beyoncé’s ‘Lemonade’ Comes to iTunes
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Pop and Rock Music']
abstract: Tidal’s period of exclusivity for that new Beyoncé album appears to be quite short — just 24 hours.
lead_paragraph: When Beyoncé’s album “Lemonade” was released late Saturday night, it was available only on Tidal, a big win for that subscription streaming service, in which Beyoncé is a part owner.

headline: Bernie Sanders Avoids Addressing Rosario Dawson’s Comments on Monica Lewinsky
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders did his best on Sunday to avoid talking about comments made by one of his supporters, the actress Rosario Dawson, invoking Monica Lewinsky at a rally this weekend.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont did his best on Sunday to avoid talking about comments made by one of his supporters, the actress Rosario Dawson, who invoked Monica Lewinsky at a rally for Mr. Sanders this weekend.

headline: U.S. Cyberattacks Target ISIS in a New Line of Combat
keywords: ['Cyberwarfare and Defense', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The military has been told to mount computer-network attacks against the group, which has proved effective at modern communications and encryption.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The United States has opened a new line of combat against the Islamic State, directing the military’s six-year-old Cyber Command for the first time to mount computer-network attacks that are now being used alongside more traditional weapons.

headline: Michael Glasgow Expresses Concerns on Water Source Switch
abstract: This April 2014 email, sent by Michael Glasgow just days before Flint made the switch to a new water source, suggests that the system was not ready and that he had concerns. (Source: Michigan Senate Democrats)
lead_paragraph: This April 2014 email, sent by Michael Glasgow just days before Flint made the switch to a new water source, suggests that the system was not ready and that he had concerns. (Source: Michigan Senate Democrats)

headline: Jacob deGrom Gets Back to Business After Attending to Son and Himself
abstract: The pitcher had missed two starts to tend to tightness in his back and his newborn son, but effectively mixed in his curveball in a 3-2 win.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Starter Jacob deGrom and the Mets’ offense each demonstrated a capacity to adapt on Sunday, showing plucky sides that contrast with their emerging reputations for being overpowering.

headline: Review: Boogarins, a Psychedelic Pop Band From Brazil
abstract: This quartet’s Brazilianness comes through in the singing, with a set connecting to everything from the Beatles to early Pink Floyd to today’s neo-psychedelic bands.
lead_paragraph: Boogarins, a band from Goiânia, Brazil, with members barely into their 20s, is working an indirect angle on an old and grandiose idea. They’re making psychedelic pop, with steady and even drum grooves, guitars playing melodic repetitions through clouds of reverb, and hazy, slow-release, enlightened-sounding vocals.

headline: Stephen Busch Email Responding to E.P.A. Concerns on Corrosion Control
abstract: Here is an email from February 2015 in which Stephen Busch is responding to worries from the Environmental Protection Agency and stating that the city had a corrosion control program, or added chemicals that prevent leaching of dangerous metals like lead, in place. This turned out to be false. (Source: FlintWaterStudy.org)
lead_paragraph: Here is an email from February 2015 in which Stephen Busch is responding to worries from the Environmental Protection Agency and stating that the city had a corrosion control program, or added chemicals that prevent leaching of dangerous metals like lead, in place. This turned out to be false. (Source: FlintWaterStudy.org)

headline: L.A. Dance Project Takes On Merce Cunningham
abstract: The Los Angeles troupe has been dancing anthologies culled from Mr. Cunningham’s 1950s choreography.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At a time when his early work was attracting few believers, the radical choreographer Merce Cunningham and his dance company made a triumphant three-week tour of the West Coast in 1955, just two years after the company’s founding. Following their appearances in San Francisco, the Cunningham dancer Marianne Preger wrote to her parents, “And do you know, Margot Fonteyn did ‘Swan Lake’ the same night and we got all the critics!”

headline: Rays Knock Around Michael Pineda and Punch Out the Yankees
abstract: Tampa Bay recorded 10 hits and seven runs in five innings against Pineda. The Yankees’ offense, meanwhile, continued to struggle against left-handers.
lead_paragraph: Yankees Manager Joe Girardi was bewildered after his team fell to the Tampa Bay Rays, 8-1, at Yankee Stadium on Sunday. A left-handed starter had again neutralized his lineup, and the nine strikeouts that Girardi’s own starting pitcher, Michael Pineda, had registered were overshadowed by the 10 hits, seven runs and four home runs he had allowed in his five innings.

headline: Michael Prysby Email on Lead Levels at LeeAnne Walters's Home
abstract: Michael Prysby seems to play down federal concerns about some high lead readings at the home of LeeAnne Walters, suggesting that the sample was an outlier and that the tap should be flushed -- a method that lowers the appearance of lead -- before retesting. (Source: FlintWaterStudy.org)
lead_paragraph: Michael Prysby seems to play down federal concerns about some high lead readings at the home of LeeAnne Walters, suggesting that the sample was an outlier and that the tap should be flushed -- a method that lowers the appearance of lead -- before retesting. (Source: FlintWaterStudy.org)

headline: Review: Peck Adapts Andersen, and Good Fights Evil Amid Fine Plumage
abstract: Justin Peck’s adaptation of the fairy tale “The Most Incredible Thing” offers little in the way of a compelling story.
lead_paragraph: When Justin Peck unveiled “The Most Incredible Thing” in February, fans of this fast-rising choreographer were eager to see his first story ballet. Mr. Peck, New York City Ballet’s resident artist since 2014, has told subtle stories in his more abstract works for the company, through the inherent drama of form. But “Incredible” was his first adaptation of a narrative source, Hans Christian Andersen’s fairy tale of the same name, set in a kingdom where good forces meet evil.

headline: Review: Ginastera and Fauré, With a Nod to Prince
abstract: A Revolutionaries festival concert at Trinity Wall Street featured classical works but was dedicated to the rock star, who died last week.
lead_paragraph: Ludwig van Beethoven and Alberto Ginastera are the composers at the heart of Trinity Wall Street’s 15-concert festival, Revolutionaries. But Thursday’s lunchtime performance at Trinity Church inadvertently became a tribute to another musician who shook up conventions: Prince.

headline: Small Rhode Island Suddenly Has Big Role in Presidential Primaries
abstract: This unpredictable election season has turned even Rhode Island’s late primary and paltry pile of delegates into a valued prize.
lead_paragraph: WARWICK, R.I. — Most years, the presidential primary here is a drive-by affair, with candidates racing past the state like motorists taking the shortest route from Boston to New York. But this unpredictable election season has turned even Rhode Island’s late primary and paltry pile of delegates into a valued prize, putting this small state into the primary spotlight before its vote Tuesday.

headline: A ‘Super PAC’ Where Art Meets Politics
abstract: For Freedoms, an artist-run “super PAC,” is raising funds for national advertising, much of it based on original artworks, to “elevate and expand” the civic dialogue.
lead_paragraph: An unusual new “super PAC,” run by artists, has cropped up on the political landscape — and it’s one that says it won’t support (or oppose) candidates or parties.

headline: San Francisco Torn as Some See ‘Street Behavior’ Worsen
abstract: As property crimes rise and homelessness persists, the city is divided over whether to respond more aggressively to problems on its streets.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — From her apartment at the foot of the celebrated zigzags of Lombard Street, Judith Calson has twice peered out her window as thieves smashed their way into cars and snatched whatever they could. She has seen foreign tourists cry after cash and passports were stolen. She shudders when she recounts the story of the Thai tourist who was shot because he resisted thieves taking his camera.

headline: N.H.L. Teams Dream of a Title After a Good Night’s Sleep
abstract: Teams are paying closer attention to the quality and quantity of their players’ rest, which can improve their quickness, strength, reaction time and problem solving.
lead_paragraph: In hockey, a sport whose arena sound systems blare “Saturday Night’s Alright for Fighting” and “No More Mr. Nice Guy,” a competitive edge may be found in a lullaby.

headline: Review: In ‘Pumpkinflowers,’ a New Style of Middle East Combat
abstract: A top-notch account of the battles between Israel’s first Lebanon War and its second, at an outpost called “the Pumpkin.”
lead_paragraph: During the 1990s, Matti Friedman and his fellow Israeli soldiers fought in a string of conflicts that never collectively earned a name. These battles existed in historical parentheses, wedged between Israel’s first Lebanon War, in 1982, and its second, in 2006.

headline: Don’t Mess With Him
abstract: Betty Keller returns with some sage advice.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — When last we saw Betty Keller, she was giving us emotional support in the form of this puzzle, so it’s only fitting that she has more advice for us today.

headline: Beyoncé Unearths Pain and Lets It Flow in ‘Lemonade’
abstract: In daring to think beyond herself, the singer created something bolder and deeper and more uncomfortable than anything that could have been predicted.
lead_paragraph: Let’s see. Last thing she remembered was their beautiful bodies grinding up in that club. Drunk — as she sang in 2013 of a gritty tryst with her husband — in love.

headline: In Norway, a Victory for the Rule of Law
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Terrorism', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: A mass murderer sues and tests the country’s commitment to human rights.
lead_paragraph: Anders Behring Breivik is about as evil as a man can be, a far-right terrorist who murdered 77 people with bullets and a bomb in Norway in 2011. He was tried and sentenced to 21 years in prison, the maximum in Norway, but with the possibility of extending his term if he was found to still be a public threat. Then, in a galling reversal, the fiend became the accuser, charging that his isolation in prison violated his human rights. And he won. And with his victory, however shocking it may be, the rule of law also won.

headline: Review: ‘JFK’ Puts a Very Dark Day in an Operatic Light
abstract: This work uses dream sequences to revisit the hours leading up to the assassination of President Kennedy.
lead_paragraph: FORT WORTH — The last 24 hours in the life of President John F. Kennedy would seem an impossible opera subject. The tragic events of that time are too immense; Jack and Jackie Kennedy have become hopelessly mythologized by this point.

headline: Review: James Levine Opens Last Run as Metropolitan Opera Music Director
abstract: Mr. Levine was greeted with extended ovations during one of his final appearances at the opera house that he transformed during his four decades as music director.
lead_paragraph: A role debut and the start of a farewell run piqued attention on Friday when the Metropolitan Opera revived its Ottoman eye-candy production of Mozart’s “Abduction From the Seraglio.” For the Russian soprano Albina Shagimuratova, it was her first turn in the bravura role of Konstanze, the noblewoman whose fidelity is tested when she is abducted and sold into Turkish slavery. For the conductor James Levine, this run of performances marks his final appearances as music director of a house he profoundly transformed during the four decades he held that position.

headline: Turkey’s Crackdown on Critics of Erdogan Snares Dutch Journalist
keywords: ['Freedom of the Press', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The detention of Ebru Umar, who was taken from her summer home for questioning, was the latest action against writers and others who have insulted President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Ebru Umar, a Dutch journalist, wrote a column last week critical of Turkey’s president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, and his government’s growing crackdown on freedom of expression. She later took to Twitter, criticizing supporters of Mr. Erdogan and using a profanity.

headline: Review: Bryson Tiller Brings Fresh Success and Tart Sentiments to Radio City
abstract: The R&B singer has a modest reserve, which belies some of his lyrics’ more astringent observations.
lead_paragraph: “502 Come Up,” the best song on Bryson Tiller’s debut album, “Trapsoul,” begins at a woozy creep, inhales deeply, then bursts into a sunbeam-powered run. It’s the tale of his ascent — 502 is the area code for Louisville, Ky., where Mr. Tiller hails from — and it crackles with all the varied emotion of making something from nothing.

headline: Heng on Afghanistan’s Struggling Government
abstract: Afghanistan’s struggling coalition government has been bogged down by infighting as it confronts an emboldened Taliban insurgency.
lead_paragraph: Afghanistan’s struggling coalition government has been bogged down by infighting as it confronts an emboldened Taliban insurgency.

headline: Warriors Defeat the Rockets, but Lose Stephen Curry, Again
abstract: Curry returned for Game 4 of the playoff series after missing the last two games with a right ankle sprain, but he injured his knee on the final play of the first half and sat out the second half.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The first half of a ferocious game ended with bodies sprawled all over the place. At one end of the floor, Andre Iguodala of the Golden State Warriors rolled onto his stomach after a punishing fall so he could watch mayhem unfold at the other end: players scrambling at the buzzer, and then Stephen Curry emerging with a limp.

headline: A Nervous Biker’s Guide to Cycling in New York City
abstract: We asked experts for advice for the wary potential cyclist, for whom the idea of riding a bike is both tempting and anxiety-inducing.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you are visiting New York City, and that rack of Citi Bikes looks fun yet daunting. Or perhaps there is a bicycle leaning against a wall in your apartment, waiting, but the idea of joining those fixed-gear daredevils on city streets makes your stomach drop. And besides, the honking vehicles, jaywalking pedestrians and idling trucks are enough to drive anyone to call a cab.

headline: No Need for Holmes. Obama Sheds Light on a Winston Churchill Mystery.
keywords: ['White House Building (Washington, DC)', 'Art', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The president may have cleared up a subject of confusion: what happened to a bust of the British prime minister that was in the Oval Office.
lead_paragraph: HANOVER, Germany — It has been, perhaps, one of the most enduring mysteries of President Obama’s tenure: What really happened to the bust of Winston Churchill that was once displayed in the Oval Office?

headline: It’s a Stretch, but Mitch McConnell Is Reaching Across the Aisle
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Elections, Senate', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The Senate majority leader, under fire for his refusal to consider the president’s Supreme Court nominee, can point to several bipartisan legislative victories.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell has a ready comeback for Democrats who keep chanting “do your job” in hopes of pressuring Republicans to consider President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee. It is simply, “We are.”

headline: In Philadelphia, a Brash Ex-Mayor Draws Comparisons to Donald Trump
abstract: Frank L. Rizzo’s provocative words, aggressive law enforcement policies and passionate following seemed familiar to many in Pennsylvania before the state’s Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: His style has evoked polarizing political figures like Barry Goldwater, George Wallace and Edward I. Koch, but as the presidential campaign moves through Pennsylvania, Donald J. Trump is reviving memories of someone who stirred local passions like few others: Frank L. Rizzo of Philadelphia.

headline: Joe Johnson’s Escape From the Nets Leads to the Playoffs
abstract: Joe Johnson gave up $3 million to leave the Nets midseason. He was rewarded with a playoff berth with the Miami Heat.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Last September, when the Nets were beginning training camp for the 2015-16 season, Joe Johnson was asked what he thought about point guard Deron Williams’s decision to negotiate a buyout and leave the team during the off-season.

headline: Orphanage Founder From Africa Wins Prize in Memory of Armenian Genocide
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Orphans and Orphanages', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Hutu Tribe', 'Tutsi Tribe']
abstract: Marguerite Barankitse defied death threats and saw unspeakable violence as she saved thousands of children from ethnic slaughters in the 1990s.
lead_paragraph: The founder of an orphanage in Burundi who defied death threats and witnessed unspeakable violence as she saved thousands of children from ethnic slaughters in the 1990s is the winner of a new prize created in memory of the Armenian genocide a century ago.

headline: Founding Rules of ‘Base Ball’ Sell for $3.26 Million in Auction
abstract: In an online auction, the 1857 “Laws of Base Ball” drew one of the highest prices ever paid for a piece of sports memorabilia.
lead_paragraph: A group of documents from 1857 that set down some of the fundamental rules of baseball was acquired at auction Sunday by an unidentified buyer for $3.26 million, making it one of the highest-priced pieces of sports memorabilia.

headline: Vox Media Tries Something Old on Something New
abstract: The online news start-up will begin publishing Circuit Breaker, a “classic gadget blog,” on Monday, primarily as a Facebook page.
lead_paragraph: Vox Media, the ambitious online news start-up that runs Vox, a politics site; SB Nation, a network of sports sites; and The Verge, a site about technology, says its next new project will be reviving something old.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of April 25
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Israel Frees Palestinian Girl, 12, Who Tried to Stab Guard
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Dima al-Wawi, the youngest known Palestinian inmate, was released weeks early and greeted with a hero’s welcome in her West Bank hometown.
lead_paragraph: HALHOUL, West Bank — The Israeli prison service on Sunday released the youngest known Palestinian inmate, a 12-year-old girl who had tried to stab a security guard at a Jewish settlement.

headline: Theranos’s Fate Rests With a Founder Who Answers Only to Herself
abstract: Under criminal investigation and with skepticism about its core technology rising, a onetime Silicon Valley favorite’s future is largely up to its founder, Elizabeth Holmes.
lead_paragraph: It’s all up to Elizabeth Holmes.

headline: Past and Present Collide in Far Corner of China
abstract: A sliver of land on the rim of the Himilayas is seeing new roads, telecommunications and commerce, a jarring shift for a once isolated people.
lead_paragraph: A sliver of land on the rim of the Himilayas is seeing new roads, telecommunications and commerce, a jarring shift for a once isolated people.

headline: Chinese Modernization Comes to an Isolated People
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Wireless Communications', 'Poverty']
abstract: A pristine valley in Yunnan Province, home to the ethnic Dulong people, is seeing progress in the name of alleviating poverty and drawing tourists.
lead_paragraph: DULONG, China — The narrow valley is one of the most remote and pristine in China. Monkeys, Asian black bears and the rare goatlike takin roam through rain-soaked forests above a river the color of jade. In spring, hillsides are splashed with pink rhododendron blossoms. Until two years ago, snowfall on a mountain pass blocked vehicle access for many months each year.­

headline: Austrian Presidential Vote Gives Edge to Right-Wing Candidate
keywords: ['Elections', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: Norbert Hofer of the anti-immigration Freedom Party was the leader in the first round of voting, winning 35 percent of the ballots. A runoff is set for May 22.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A right-wing candidate emerged as the clear front-runner in the first round of the presidential election in Austria on Sunday, dealing a stinging blow to the country’s two mainstream parties, which failed to garner enough votes to make it into a runoff next month.

headline: A Celebration in Song and Dance of Ireland’s Independence and Culture
abstract: On the 100-year anniversary of the Easter Rising, a rebellion that put Ireland on a path to independence, people celebrated the country in an event in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: As the Irish fiddles began to play on Sunday afternoon, Fiona Kells strapped on her dancing shoes at a festival in Battery Park in Manhattan celebrating the 100-year anniversary of the Easter Rising, a rebellion that started Ireland on its path to independence. The celebration highlighted the inspiration those revolutionaries found in American principles of liberty and their connection to the Irish diaspora — like Fiona and her family — in America.

headline: Emails Deepen Criminal Cases in Flint, but Charges May Be Tough to Prove
abstract: Some legal experts suggested that the charges may have an effect on regulators beyond Flint or Michigan, raising a specter of heightened criminal charges for regulators.
lead_paragraph: As Bill Schuette, the attorney general of Michigan, announced criminal charges against three government workers in Flint’s water crisis, he pledged there would be more charges soon, saying, “We’ll go wherever the truth takes us — and, in this case, wherever the emails take us.”

headline: Bernie Sanders and Allies Aim to Shape Democrats’ Agenda After Primaries
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders and his allies are trying to use his popularity to expand his political influence, setting up an ideological struggle for the party’s soul.
lead_paragraph: Even as his chances of winning the Democratic presidential nomination slip away, Senator Bernie Sanders and his allies are trying to use his popularity to expand his political influence, setting up an ideological struggle for the soul of the Democratic Party in the post-Obama era.

headline: Technology and Banking Sectors Brace for Earnings Reports
abstract: First-quarter results are expected to be in for Facebook, Amazon, Apple and Twitter, as well as for some of Europe’s largest banks.
lead_paragraph: This is what to expect from the week ahead.

headline: Facebook Aims to Drive Down Tech Prices to Expand Its Reach
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Open-Source Software', 'Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Social Media', 'Telephones and Telecommunications']
abstract: The social network wants to triple its 1.6 billion global users, but to do that, it will have to make connecting to the Internet much less expensive.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s co-founder and chief executive, is clear about his vision for his company: He wants to triple the size of his social network, which now has 1.6 billion members.

headline: Kenyans Prevail in London Marathon After a Countdown From Outer Space
abstract: A British astronaut counted down the race’s start at the International Space Station. On Earth, Eliud Kipchoge of Kenya ran the second-fastest marathon ever, at 2 hours 3 minutes 5 seconds.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The London Marathon began from outer space Sunday and nearly finished with an otherworldly performance.

headline: Missing Mexican Students Suffered a Night of ‘Terror,’ Investigators Say
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Missing Persons', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Organized Crime']
abstract: An international panel has provided details of the night in 2014 when Mexican police and gunmen abducted 43 students who have not been seen since.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Municipal police officers encircled the bus, detonated tear gas, punctured the tires and forced the college students who were onboard to get off.

headline: Inquiry Challenges Mexico’s Account of How 43 Students Vanished
abstract: Five suspects whose testimony underpinned the government’s conclusions gave confessions “under torture or cruel, inhumane or degrading treatment,” a report by international experts found.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Since November 2014, the Mexican authorities, eager to close a dark chapter in the nation’s history, have insisted that 43 students from Ayotzinapa who disappeared two months earlier in the city of Iguala were killed by a drug gang that incinerated their bodies in a garbage dump and disposed of the ashes in a river.

headline: In This Snapchat Campaign, Election News Is Big and Then It’s Gone
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: In this election season, the photo- and video-sharing app acts as a reset button, allowing audiences to see and quickly forget misbehavior.
lead_paragraph: Every modern presidential election is at least in part defined by the cool new media breakthrough of its moment. In 2000, there was email, and by golly was that a big change from the fax. The campaigns could get their messages in front of print and cable news reporters — who could still dominate the campaign narrative — at will, reducing what had been a 24-hour news cycle to an hourly one.

headline: Review: Deborah Hay, Choreographer and Disrupter
abstract: In “An Evening With Deborah Hay,” Ms. Hay revealed how she gets dancers to relinquish their habits by posing questions that shift their performances.
lead_paragraph: “What if?”

headline: Officials in Ohio Link Marijuana Operations to Deaths of 8 Family Members
abstract: The growing operations were found on the premises of at least one of the four homes where eight members of the same family were killed, law enforcement officials said.
lead_paragraph: Three marijuana growing operations were found on the premises of at least one of the homes where eight members of the same family were killed in a small town in southern Ohio last week, law enforcement officials said Sunday.

headline: Yemeni Troops, Backed by United Arab Emirates, Take City From Al Qaeda
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The loss of Al Mukalla was a blow to Al Qaeda’s Yemeni branch, which had controlled the southern city for more than a year and used it as a base.
lead_paragraph: AL MUKALLA, Yemen — Yemeni troops in armored vehicles and backed by airstrikes advanced toward this city of 500,000 people on Sunday, intending to capture it from militants with Al Qaeda who had controlled the major stronghold for more than a year.

headline: Serbia’s Ruling Pro-European Party Appears Headed for a Win
abstract: Prime Minister Aleksandar Vucic has said he plans to use a victory to push through reforms needed for the country to join the European Union.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE, Serbia — The pro-European party that has led Serbia since 2012 appeared headed for a big victory in a snap election on Sunday, even as right-wing nationalists made gains.

headline: Made in NYC Looks to Give Manufacturing a Handcrafted Image
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Slogans and Mottoes']
abstract: A group’s promotion hopes to capitalize on the popularity of locally created items, urging customers to go beyond big-box stores for their daily shopping needs.
lead_paragraph: The image of the American factory floor is as classic as Henry Ford’s Model T assembly line and just as enduring in the popular imagination. For decades, manufacturing jobs have been the ladder to the middle class for Americans of modest means and education.

headline: Elton Spitzer, 84, Who Helped Turn WLIR Into a Radio Destination, Dies
abstract: Mr. Spitzer, who operated 92.7 FM on Long Island, dared to be different by introducing listeners to new wave music most Americans hadn’t heard before.
lead_paragraph: In 1982, Elton Spitzer, a former food stand operator who happened to like music, was running WLIR, a small rock ’n’ roll radio station on the outskirts of New York City that was struggling to carve out space for itself in a major market crowded with more powerful competitors. So he decided to take a risk.

headline: ‘Fear the Walking Dead’ Season 2, Episode 3: Plane Crash
abstract: This episode folds in another parallel “Walking Dead” story line.
lead_paragraph: Contemporary storytelling is increasingly all about expanded universes.

headline: Review: Jessie Mueller Serves a Slice of Life (With Pie) in Sara Bareilles’s ‘Waitress’
abstract: This musical, set in a diner and scored by Sara Bareilles, centers on a woman stuck in an unhappy marriage.
lead_paragraph: “Sugar. Butter. Flour.” The words are crooned like a lullaby intermittently throughout the musical “Waitress,” bringing a warm blanket of comfort to the troubled central character, stuck in an unhappy marriage and essentially working two jobs, baking pies for the diner where she also puts on an apron to wait tables.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ Season 6 Premiere: Picking Up the Jagged Pieces
abstract: How did they fit so many plots into one episode?
lead_paragraph: Our top story tonight: Lord Commander Jon Snow is still dead.

abstract: The actress returned on Sunday as Arya Stark in the season premiere of “Game of Thrones.”
lead_paragraph: This interview contains spoilers for Sunday’s episode of “Game of Thrones.”

headline: Banharn Silpa-archa, Former Prime Minister of Thailand, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Banharn’s brief tenure, in 1995 and 1996, was marked by allegations of corruption and economic mismanagement.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Banharn Silpa-archa, a former prime minister of Thailand whose scandal-ridden tenure preceded the country’s economic collapse in the 1990s, died here on Saturday. He was 83.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 25, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It’s pure psychological effect. Your pizza is not going to come any sooner. But it’s moving.”

headline: ‘Silicon Valley’ Season 3 Premiere: Holographic Mustaches
abstract: Season 3 of the HBO comedy picks right up where Season 2 left off.

headline: Draft of Press Release on Flint Water Source Switch
abstract: This draft of a Flint press release, about the switch to a new water source, is dated several days after Michael Glasgow's note of concern. No signs of concern are noted in the release. (Source: Michigan Senate Democrats)
lead_paragraph: This draft of a Flint press release, about the switch to a new water source, is dated several days after Michael Glasgow's note of concern. No signs of concern are noted in the release. (Source: Michigan Senate Democrats)

headline: In Johnny Manziel, Failure as Entertainment
abstract: At 23, the quarterback Johnny Manziel may never play pro football again. His downfall speaks to the propensity of fans — and the league — to treat young N.F.L. prospects like livestock.
lead_paragraph: It was intriguingly painful television, as it is intended to be. The first round of the 2014 N.F.L. draft was underway, and the dazzling college quarterback Johnny Manziel was in the green room, stuck in prime-time purgatory. Twenty-one teams came and went, each choosing someone other than Manziel. For nearly three hours, he fidgeted in front of unblinking cameras. He played with a bottle cap, drank from a cup, checked his phone and excused himself for the privacy of the restroom.

headline: A Middle School Cast of ‘Fiddler on the Roof’ Reunites on Broadway
abstract: More than four decades after a production at Shell Bank Junior High School, the cast members, now in their mid-50s, met up again to watch the latest Broadway production.
lead_paragraph: “Swiftly fly the years,” goes the poignant lyric in the song “Sunrise, Sunset” from the enduring musical “Fiddler on the Roof.”

headline: ‘Veep’ Season 5 Premiere: The Presidential Zit
abstract: Despite the departure of its creator, “Veep” returned this week as funny as ever.
lead_paragraph: For those of us who enjoy watching governmental incompetence reveal itself beneath a word cloud of caustic profanity, “Veep” has been the show we wanted for the past four seasons. But in Season 5, which begins during one of the more unsettled presidential elections in recent memory, “Veep” just might be the show we need. If laughing at fictional political chaos makes it easier to cope with actual political chaos, then this HBO series is the best therapy available to the primary-season-fatigued public.

headline: Grauer’s Gorillas May Soon Be Extinct, Conservationists Say
abstract: Over the last two decades, the population of the world’s largest primate has fallen 77 percent, a decline hidden by conflict in the region.
lead_paragraph: The Grauer’s gorilla, the world’s largest primate, has been a source of continual worry for conservationists for more than two decades. Longstanding conflict in the deep jungles of the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo left experts with no choice but to guess at how that gorilla subspecies may be faring.

headline: Islanders Advance With a Double-Overtime Victory
abstract: John Tavares scored to force an extra period, then put in the game-winner in double overtime as the Islanders clinched a playoff series on home ice for the first time since 1993.
lead_paragraph: The Islanders and their fans waited more than two decades for a night like Sunday. The team had not had a chance to clinch a playoff series at home since 1993, when its current captain, John Tavares, was 2 years old. That also was the last time the Islanders won a playoff series.

headline: Lawyer for Fund-Raisers Tied to de Blasio Fires Back at Elections Board
abstract: The response came after a report said a group of political fund-raisers linked to the mayor had violated campaign finance laws.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — In a strongly worded response to a New York State Board of Elections report alleging illegal fund-raising activities by a team of people with close ties to Mayor Bill de Blasio, a lawyer for several of the implicated parties has accused the board of “a shocking lack of understanding or a complete disregard of the most fundamental aspects of the state’s election laws.”

headline: How Argentina Settled a Billion-Dollar Debt Dispute With Hedge Funds
abstract: A six-week flurry of secret negotiations resulted in a deal that ended 15 years of contention between bondholders and government officials.
lead_paragraph: The Waldorf Astoria hotel in Manhattan has long been a location for secret diplomacy, but few meetings there would have seemed as unlikely as the one that took place one day in early December.

headline: Ted Cruz and John Kasich to Coordinate Against Donald Trump
abstract: The campaign rivals agreed to coordinate in future primary contests in a last-ditch effort to deny Mr. Trump the Republican presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz and Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio have agreed to coordinate in future primary contests in a last-ditch effort to deny Donald J. Trump the Republican presidential nomination, with each candidate standing aside in certain states amid growing concerns that Mr. Trump cannot otherwise be stopped.

headline: Britain Grapples With Enduring Questions of Religion and Race
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Referendums', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Elections, Mayors', 'ANTI-SEMITISM', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']

headline: What’s on TV Monday
abstract: Laurie Anderson remembers her husband, Lou Reed, and her rat terrier, Lolabelle, in “Heart of a Dog” on HBO.
lead_paragraph: Laurie Anderson remembers her husband, Lou Reed, and her rat terrier, Lolabelle, in “Heart of a Dog.” “Turn: Washington’s Spies” deals with the treason of Benedict Arnold — and eventually brings on Alexander Hamilton. And a French detective races through her job in towering heels in “Witnesses.”

headline: Australia Charges Teenager With Plotting Anzac Day Terror Attack
abstract: The boy, 16, was arrested the day before the veterans’ commemorations, after he was said to have tried to obtain a firearm, according to news reports.
lead_paragraph: A 16-year-old boy has been arrested in Australia on suspicion of plotting to carry out an attack during the country’s veterans commemorations on Monday, the police said.

headline: In Spas and Bathhouses, Epic Nudes
abstract: Ruth Kaplan spent a dozen years visiting bathhouses making pictures of “epic nudes” that plumb how people express themselves though their bodies.
lead_paragraph: If bathhouses date back to the Romans, the history of nudes in art goes back even further, to the Venus of Willendorf of the Paleolithic era. In “Bathers,” a 12-year homage to both themes, the Canadian photographer Ruth Kaplan traveled the globe to find and photograph bathhouses and, more important, the bodies that give them life.

abstract: Physicians for Social Responsibility and a historian discuss the perils of a new arms race.

abstract: An information security analyst writes that “an entire industry that sells malicious code has emerged that revolves around defeating encryption.”

headline: When Statehouse Politicians Make Things Worse
abstract: Budget battles in Illinois and Kansas point to the need for responsible decisions to restore the flow of revenue and provide needed services.
lead_paragraph: A 10-month budget standoff in Illinois has reached the point where the state comptroller, Leslie Geissler Munger, says she plans to delay the monthly paychecks of lawmakers and state officials because other bills and services deserve to be paid first. The comptroller, a Republican running for re-election, seems to think this will force the Democratic General Assembly and Gov. Bruce Rauner, a Republican, to compromise.

headline: Europe’s Web Privacy Rules: Bad for Google, Bad for Everyone
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Search Engines', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Restricting what search results users can see undermines the Internet’s promise of global access to information.
lead_paragraph: IT’S been a rough few months for Google in Europe. Not only has the European Union hit the company with a second  antitrust investigation, but — in a move that has received less press, but could have wider consequences — French regulators have pushed it to restrict search results all over the world to comply with their “right to be forgotten” privacy laws.

headline: The Slaves in Georgetown’s Past
abstract: Readers, including George Soros and Georgetown alumni, discuss ways in which the university can make amends.

headline: The 8 A.M. Call
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Some understanding of economic reality would be an asset to a presidential candidate, but only one of the three main contenders appears to possess it.
lead_paragraph: Back in 2008, one of the ads Hillary Clinton ran during the contest for the Democratic nomination featured an imaginary scene in which the White House phone rings at 3 a.m. with news of a foreign crisis, and asked, “Who do you want answering that phone?” It was a fairly mild jab at Barack Obama’s lack of foreign policy experience.

headline: Should Everybody Vote?
keywords: ['Voting and Voters', 'Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Conventional wisdom tells us yes. But maybe there is a better way.
lead_paragraph: At election time we inevitably hear earnest pleas for everyone to vote. Voter participation is a data point often cited in political studies, along with an assumption that the higher the percentage, the better: 100 percent participation is the goal. But we rarely question this belief, or objectively consider whether everyone who can vote ought to vote.

headline: Rethinking the Global War on Drugs
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States International Relations', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: A United Nations meeting didn’t deliver a direly needed overhaul, but it was a step in the right direction.
lead_paragraph: At the urging of Mexico, Guatemala and Colombia, world leaders met at the United Nations in a special session last week to discuss saner ways to fight the drug trade. They did not get very far toward a shift in approach. Nonetheless, there was a consensus that investing in health care, addiction treatment and alternatives to incarceration would do more to end the drug trade than relying primarily on prohibition and criminalization.

headline: A State Bucks the Trend on Voting Rights
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Ex-Convicts', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: The Virginia governor’s order giving 200,000 people with felony convictions the right to vote is an important rebuke to voter suppression efforts.
lead_paragraph: In a major executive order, Gov. Terry McAuliffe of Virginia on Friday restored voting rights to more than 200,000 people who have completed their sentences for felony convictions. Virginia was one of four states, along with Iowa, Kentucky and Florida, that placed a lifetime bar on voting for anyone convicted of a felony. All other states except Maine and Vermont impose lesser restrictions on voting by people with felony convictions.

headline: Clash of the Injured Titans
abstract: While the likely nominees each have big negative poll numbers, the math seems to favor Hillary Clinton at the moment.
lead_paragraph: If trends hold and the parties’ front-runners become the parties’ nominees, November is going to be an epic election: a hobbled titan (Hillary Clinton) versus a mortally wounded one (the real estate developer).

headline: The Mathematician’s 90th-Birthday Party
abstract: Young brains may be brasher, but some ideas emerge only with the deep insight of a long career.
lead_paragraph: I RECENTLY attended a conference in honor of Ivo Babuska, a professor at the University of Texas, with whom I have written several mathematical papers. There were toasts with a crowd-pleasing (if prudently priced) malbec and puns riffing on “singular value decomposition” that elicited much mirth. After all, it was also Ivo’s 90th-birthday party.

headline: Ardagh to Buy Assets From Ball and Rexam for $3.4 Billion
abstract: Ball Corporation and Rexam have been looking to sell assets in order to win regulatory approval for their pending merger.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Ball Corporation said on Monday that it and Rexam had agreed to sell a variety of assets in Brazil, Europe and the United States to the packaging company Ardagh Group for $3.42 billion to satisfy regulatory concerns about Ball’s takeover of Rexam, a British maker of aluminum cans.

abstract: GE Money Bank’s initial public offering would continue General Electric’s efforts to scale back on finance and focus on its industrial roots.

abstract: The Sanders campaign has produced nine versions of his “America” ad, reworking it with different footage to reach different audiences in different states.
lead_paragraph: For Senator Bernie Sanders, there are not just two Americas, there are at least nine.

headline: Thriving at Age 70 and Beyond
abstract: In “70Candles!,” older women explore the most important issues facing women as they age, and how society might help ease their way into the future.
lead_paragraph: A recently published book, “70Candles! Women Thriving in Their 8th Decade,” inspired me to take a closer look at how I’m doing as I approach 75 and how I might make the most of the years to come. It would be a good idea for women in my age cohort to do likewise. With a quarter of American women age 65 expected to live into their 90s, there could be quite a few years to think about.

headline: Philips ‘More Likely’ to Pursue I.P.O. of Lighting Business
abstract: The Dutch electronics giant has been pursuing a potential sale or public offering of the unit, which includes light bulbs and lighting systems.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, said on Monday that it was “more likely” that the company would pursue an initial public offering, rather than a private sale, of its lighting business.

headline: Book Review: ‘Hoping to Help’ Questions Value of Volunteers
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: The sociologist Judith Lasker expresses wonder that such global health programs seem uninclined to seriously evaluate the effects of their work.
lead_paragraph: Some do it to get into heaven, and some do it to get into medical school. Some do it because everyone else is doing it. Whatever the motivation, the number of health care volunteers heading from developed to developing countries has soared in recent years, with commentators straggling behind debating the merits of the stampede.

headline: Candidates Make Final Push in Five Northeastern States

headline: Four Ideas for Teaching and Learning (While a Few of Our Features Are on Vacation)

headline: Offering Kids a Taste of Alcohol
abstract: Parents may think that giving children sips of wine at holidays promotes a healthy, festive attitude toward alcohol, but some studies show it correlates with problem drinking later.
lead_paragraph: I discovered a new category for myself as a parent when I read a study published in March in the journal Pediatrics called “Parents Who Supply Sips of Alcohol in Early Adolescence: A Prospective Study of Risk Factors.” I confess I bridled a bit at the idea that the investigators might mean me: A ceremonial drop of Champagne on New Year’s Eve? A token “sip” of wine at Passover? Doesn’t this sound a little, well, puritanical?

headline: How Politics Influences the Stock Market: Not Very Much

abstract: Pundits of all partisan leanings are tempted to use big market movements as support for their favored policies, but the effort often backfires.

headline: Afghan President Demands Pakistan Take Military Action Against Taliban
abstract: President Ashraf Ghani dropped his conciliatory approach and threatened to go to the United Nations if Pakistan failed to strike the Taliban on its soil.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After courting Pakistan for more than a year, President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan changed course on Monday and warned that he would lodge a complaint with the United Nations Security Council if Pakistan refuses to take military action against Taliban leaders operating from its soil to wage an increasingly deadly insurgency across Afghanistan.

headline: ‘Game of Thrones’ and the Era of Elaborate Opening Titles

lead_paragraph: When “Game of Thrones” returned to HBO on Sunday night, many viewers probably had to rely on the map in the opening sequence to reorient themselves in the sprawling fantasy world. What’s the name of that sandy place in the south with the snakes? Oh, right, Dorne.

headline: U.S. to Increase Military Presence in Syria, Obama Says

headline: Avoiding Peanuts to Avoid an Allergy Is a Bad Strategy for Most

headline: 1916 Easter Rising in Ireland, a Milestone of Foreign Reporting
abstract: Intense coverage of the five-day rebellion, whose centennial is this week, reflected in part the growing clout of Irish America, historians say.
lead_paragraph: The Easter Rising lasted only five days. Yet the 1916 uprising by Irish rebels garnered more than 50 articles in The New York Times, which kept the story on its front page for more than two weeks.

headline: Economics and Self-Awareness
abstract: Models as an antidote to motivated reasoning.
lead_paragraph: Noah Smith has another interesting piece on methodology, inspired by the Friedman-Sanders economic projections controversy. His bottom line — don’t let your economic analysis be dictated by what you want to be true, or what you think would be good for people to believe — is exactly right. But I think there’s a bit more to be said about the process of using economic models, and why — in my experience — they can be especially helpful on politically or emotionally charged issues.

headline: From an Artist’s Studio, No Ordinary Cookbook
abstract: Recipes from Olafur Eliasson, who created the four waterfalls installation on the East River.
lead_paragraph: The artist Olafur Eliasson may be best known in New York for creating four waterfalls in 2008 on the East River, the most famous of which was off the Brooklyn Bridge. Now his studio has created no ordinary cookbook. Besides the mostly black-and-white photographs showing his dynamic headquarters in Berlin and the communal cooking and dining events there, the book includes vegetarian recipes to serve six or, as happens in the studio, 60. “It started smaller, but lunch was a time when we came together in the studio,” Mr. Eliasson said in an interview in New York last month. “It was also cheaper, better and healthier for us to cook.” Alice Waters, who Mr. Eliasson got to know at a Davos conference, also figures in the book. Home cooks may focus on the three-cheese quiche, a lemon pasta, a sublime version of egg-drop soup and the use of caramelized soy sauce: “The Kitchen” by Studio Olafur Eliasson (Phaidon $49.95).

headline: Uighur Activist in Germany Sees China’s Hand in Revocation of Indian Visa

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A prominent democracy activist said on Monday that he had been blocked from traveling to India to meet the Dalai Lama after the Chinese government urged Indian officials to rescind his visa.

headline: Mustard on Tap and Vinegar, Too
abstract: Maille opens a new store in Manhattan, its biggest, at 21st and Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Maille, the French mustard company with a boutique on the Upper West Side since late 2014, now has a bigger showcase. Like the first store, it’s outfitted with taps for dispensing mustard in various flavors, but here there is also vinegar on tap (Sauternes at first) in a black refillable bottle. This flagship store has a mustard tasting bar, and an area for classes about mustard that will start next month, including the opportunity to concoct a custom blend ($59) with an array of ingredients under the tutelage of the company’s mustard “sommelier,” Pierette Huttner: 927 Broadway (21st Street), 929-335-6610, maille.com.

headline: Chocolates from France for Mother’s Day
abstract: Mendiants with dried berries, nuts and other fruit.
lead_paragraph: Chocolates are an easy choice for indulgence on Mother’s Day, May 8. French-style mendiants, stunning large disks scattered with dried berries or other fruits and nuts, are from an artisanal French company: $25, Comptoir du Cacao, Bergdorf Goodman, sold only in the store, seventh floor, 888-774-2424, bergdorfgoodman.com.

headline: Make-Your-Own Ice Cream Bars in SoHo
abstract: Consider the ice cream a blank canvas for chocolate and toppings.
lead_paragraph: At a new seasonal store in SoHo, you can embellish your own ice cream pop, dipped in your choice of chocolate, then top it with any three of 20 ingredients like chopped nuts, rose petals, mint chips and sea salt, and finish it with another drizzle of chocolate. Magnum Ice Cream has been rolling out custom-dipping shops around the world, but this is the first in the United States. Unilever, which owns Magnum, is the world’s largest ice cream company, owning brands like Ben & Jerry’s, Fudgsicle and Klondike. Last year in the United States alone, it sold more than 100 million prepackaged Magnum ice cream bars on a stick. The ice cream is made with milk with no added hormones, and the chocolate is Barry Callebaut from Belgium: Custom ice cream bar, $7, at Magnum New York until mid-August, 134 Prince Street (Wooster Street), 646-395-7463, facebook.com/magnum.

headline: A Fly on the Wall at The Times: Live With Carolyn Ryan

headline: 1966: Munsinger Admits to Spying
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Gerda Munsinger admits to spying for the Russians in 1966.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — An inquiry into Canada’s sex and security case today [April 25] heard a secret police report that Gerda Munsinger had carried on ‘‘an illicit sexual relationship’’ with a former associate defense minister and that she had admitted having been a Russian spy.

headline: Traditional Spanish Sandwich Cookies, But Not Exactly
abstract: Alfajores for New Yorkers include a black and white version.
lead_paragraph: What macarons are to France, alfajores (ahl-fa-HOH-rehs) are to Spain and South America, especially Argentina, Uruguay and Peru. The butter cookies, usually sandwiched with dulce de leche, are based on a Moorish recipe that is said to have been introduced to Southern Spain in the eighth century. Now Alvaro and Joaquin Ormeno, brothers from Peru, have given them a New York spin with a black-and-white version, as well as adhering to tradition by filling them with manjarblanco, which is a kind of caramel, or lucuma, a Peruvian fruit. The brothers bake the cookies in New York using their grandmother’s recipe: $25 for 12, $14 for 6, limanjar.com.

headline: First Came the Coffee. Now, the Liqueurs.
abstract: Arabica coffee blended with brandy or Cognac.
lead_paragraph: The coffee culture has given rise to some classy new coffee liqueurs. From California, there’s Firelit, made by Jeff Kessinger using Blue Bottle’s method for cold-brewing single-origin coffee and blended with a California brandy. Each 1,000-liter batch uses a different Arabica coffee. The latest result, from Nepalese beans, has an earthy intensity and a dark chocolate aroma. The French entry, by Merlet, combines coffee brewed from Brazilian Arabica beans with Cognac, which definitely comes through on the palate. It also has a touch of sweetness: Firelit Coffee Liqueur, $34.99 for 750 milliliters from K&L Wine Merchants, klwines.com; Merlet C2 Café Liqueur, $17.99 for 375 milliliters, and $26.99 for 750 milliliters, from Ambassador Wines & Spirits, ambassadorwines.com.

headline: Forget Too Much TV. It’s Too Big TV We Should Worry About.

headline: The Best of Glasgow’s Ingram Street
abstract: It’s not even Scotland’s most famous road — but here, the old is seamlessly married to the new, style is never compromised and history runs deep.
lead_paragraph: It’s not even Scotland’s most famous road — but here, the old is seamlessly married to the new, style is never compromised and history runs deep.

headline: Glasgow’s Elegant Ingram Street
abstract: The writer Andrew O’Hagan revisits the stylish Scottish road that dazzled him in his youth — and still, today.
lead_paragraph: Scotland used to seem a long way from the world. We felt we lived secret lives there, informed by ancient sorrows and fresh delights, and the city of Glasgow, where I was born, seemed to us the manifestation of a true identity. I suppose people might say a similar thing about New York or Dublin, but in Glasgow the citizens’ common nature is made of stone. Our mothers would speak of a person being “pure Glasgow,” consisting of material you didn’t get elsewhere, a sort of sandstone or granite embedded in the soul. I grew up believing not only that streets had character but that buildings had voices. My grandmother once took me to buy rosary beads at a tiny shop on the High Street, just off the Trongate, near the Candleriggs. The shop, Carruth’s Grotto, was a place way out of time and its atmosphere could never have existed in Italy or Russia. It was a tiny palace of sweet-faced Marys and red candles, a glinting emporium of Catholic medals, but the building itself seemed to carry an indignant sense of faith, as if a history of survival clung to its plasterboard walls and shone from the old glass counter.

headline: An Architect’s Ties to Her Mixing Bowls: Metal Rings
abstract: Like everything in her spartan kitchen, Katherine Chia’s vintage Revere Ware is made to last.
lead_paragraph: A half-century of whisking has left faint spirals inside the stainless-steel mixing bowls, the only etch of time visible in the architect Katherine Chia’s otherwise unscarred, immaculately white kitchen.

headline: A Note on the Soda Tax Controversy
abstract: Progressive taxation isn’t all that.
lead_paragraph: So Sanders and Clinton are arguing about soda taxes — Clinton for, as a way to raise money for good stuff while discouraging self-destructive behavior, Sanders against, because regressive. I have no illusions that rational argument will make much difference in the short run; we’re in that stage where anything Clinton supports is ipso facto evil. It’s like that point in 2008 when Obama supporters hated, hated the individual mandate that eventually became, as it had to, a central piece of Obamacare.
