lead_paragraph: A longtime columnist for The Las Vegas Review-Journal has resigned, becoming the latest journalist to leave the newspaper since it was bought by Sheldon Adelson, the billionaire casino magnate and Republican donor, late last year.

headline: Alan Quine, an Islanders Newcomer, Introduces Himself as a Playoff Standout
abstract: Quine, 23, who only joined the team for the last two games of the regular season, has become a catalyst in the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: SYOSSET, N.Y. — Alan Quine is such a newcomer to the Islanders that he is still without a locker room cubicle at the team’s practice rink. A folding chair in the middle of the cramped room will have to suffice.

headline: Defending His Daffodils, an Eighth Avenue Gardener Keeps a Busy City at Bay
abstract: After two failed gardens, Donald Wolfe’s attempts to coax life into a tiny flower bed on Eighth Avenue in Manhattan have finally met with success.
lead_paragraph: The daffodils were in bloom, which meant the garden had to be watered. Donald Wolfe said he would walk there from his apartment on West 50th Street in Manhattan — 38 steps to the elevator, 54 steps through the lobby, 75 steps down the block to the corner and 37 steps across Eighth Avenue.

headline: Sons Make Marketing Deal to Perpetuate Yogi Berra’s Legacy
abstract: Yogi Berra’s three sons entered a new deal with Steiner Sports to market Berra’s name and likeness and sell remaining pieces of his collection of memorabilia.
lead_paragraph: A new deal between Yogi Berra’s estate and Steiner Sports Marketing raises a question often asked after a celebrity dies: How potent will his name continue to be?

headline: Warrantless Surveillance in Terror Case Raises Constitutional Challenge
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Terrorism', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)', 'Privacy']
abstract: Prosecutors have told an Iraqi refugee accused of traveling to Syria to help a terrorist group that he faces evidence derived from a program in dispute.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Prosecutors have told an Iraqi refugee who is accused of traveling to Syria to help a terrorist organization that he faces evidence derived from the government’s warrantless surveillance program, a disclosure that elevates the significance of the case by making the constitutionality of that program a central dispute.

headline: Donald Trump Sweeps 5 States; Hillary Clinton Takes 4
abstract: Mr. Trump won Pennsylvania, Maryland and three other states on Tuesday, decreasing the odds of a contested Republican convention. Mrs. Clinton won Pennsylvania, Connecticut, Maryland and Delaware.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton barreled toward a general election showdown on Tuesday night as they dominated primaries in Pennsylvania, Maryland and other Eastern states, piling up enough delegates to close in on their parties’ nominations.

headline: Mexico Runs Away From the Truth
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Missing Persons', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Torture']
abstract: The Mexican government is more interested in turning the page than in finding out what happened to 43 students who vanished en masse.
lead_paragraph: In December 2014, President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico traveled to the state of Guerrero, where months earlier 43 college students who were headed to a protest in Mexico City had vanished under murky circumstances and were presumed to have been massacred.

headline: Malian Man Who Killed U.S. Diplomat Is Sentenced to 25 Years
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Carjacking', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Terrorism', 'Extradition']
abstract: Alhassane Mohamed, who shot William Bultemeier during a carjacking in Niger in 2000 and twice escaped custody in Africa, will serve his term in the United States.
lead_paragraph: A Malian man who killed an American diplomat during a carjacking in Niger nearly 16 years ago and twice escaped police custody in West Africa was sentenced on Tuesday to 25 years in a United States prison.

headline: Shaun Livingston, Stephen Curry’s Fill-In, Takes a Far Different Approach
abstract: Livingston, who has assumed the starting point guard role for Golden State with Curry injured, has a more inside-out style. He had only 12 3-point attempts all season.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Postseason life without Stephen Curry resumed for the Golden State Warriors on Tuesday morning, and it was impossible for them not to sense his absence.

headline: Use of Motor Results in Ban and Fine for a Belgian Cyclist
abstract: Riding for her national team in a cyclocross race in January, Femke van den Driessche, 19, was found to have a small motor and battery in the frame of her bike that was controlled by a switch hidden under its handlebar tape.
lead_paragraph: The International Cycling Union imposed unusually severe sanctions Tuesday against Femke Van den Driessche, the first rider found to be enhancing her performance through the use of electric motors rather than drugs.

headline: After Missteps, U.S. Tightens Rules for Espionage Cases
abstract: Prosecutors in Washington will have greater oversight after the collapse of several cases led to allegations that Chinese-Americans were being singled out as spies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has issued new rules that give prosecutors in Washington greater oversight and control over national security cases after the collapse of several high-profile prosecutions led to allegations that Chinese-Americans were being singled out as spies.

headline: Given Chance in New Roles, Michael Conforto and Kevin Plawecki Show They Can Produce
abstract: Conforto, who hits well against right-handers, started against the Reds left-hander Brandon Finnegan, and Plawecki started in place of Travis d’Arnaud, who went on the D.L.
lead_paragraph: The Mets adjusted to irregular roles on Tuesday. One player, Michael Conforto, started, even though the left-hander Brandon Finnegan was on the mound for the Cincinnati Reds. A majority of Conforto’s success since he moved to third in the batting order April 15 — a .378 average with 10 runs scored, 3 home runs and 8 R.B.I. — has come against right-handed pitchers.

headline: Report on de Blasio Election Spending Is Full of Details and Holes
abstract: Risa Sugarman accuses Mayor Bill de Blasio’s team of flagrant violations with regard to gifts to county Democratic committees but ignores gifts to the state committee.
lead_paragraph: Now, bewilderingly, Mayor Bill de Blasio and his crew are said to be in an exotic pile of legal trouble faced by virtually no other politicians who have done just about the same thing.

headline: De Blasio Unveils New York Budget Focused on Savings and Fixes
abstract: The mayor’s $82.2 billion plan includes roughly $1 billion in savings and additional money to improve city agencies with recent problems, like the elections board.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio unveiled his $82.2 billion executive budget for New York City on Tuesday with a presentation focused on savings extracted from city agencies, and a few new programs intended to address problems that arose over the past year, from snarled snowplows in Queens to voting woes in the presidential primary last week.

headline: Aging Runners Find Help for a Question: How Slow Will I Get?
abstract: Thanks to Ray Fair, a professor in the economics department at Yale, runners have an exact schedule that will predict how their performance will decline as they age.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, a group of aging elite distance runners got together, and as they reminisced about old times, a familiar topic arose: No matter how much they train, no matter how much they push themselves, their best times are behind them.

headline: Ticket Brokers in Settlement With New York Over Scalping Laws
abstract: The New York attorney general took aim at brokers who use “bots” and other methods that keep tickets out of the hands of ordinary fans.
lead_paragraph: The office of the attorney general of New York announced on Tuesday that it has reached settlements worth $2.76 million with six ticket brokers as part of its continuing investigation into the online ticket scalping market.

headline: F.D.A. Urges Caution on Yeast Infection Drug During Pregnancy
abstract: The agency had previously warned that high doses of the drug, fluconazole, might be linked to birth defects. A new study suggests dangers at lower doses.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that doctors should exercise caution in prescribing to pregnant women an oral drug for yeast infections because of new evidence suggesting a possible link to miscarriage.

headline: St. Lawrence County Board Votes ‘No Confidence’ in District Attorney
keywords: ['District Attorneys', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: After a series of unflattering episodes, lawmakers in the northern New York county delivered a rare rebuke to Mary E. Rain and asked the governor to open an inquiry into her conduct.
lead_paragraph: For the residents of St. Lawrence County, a rural territory on the Canadian border in northern New York, the news out of the district attorney’s office in recent years has more often resembled a dark comedy than a courtroom drama.

headline: Queens Woman Charged With Animal Cruelty
abstract: Prosecutors cited “deplorable conditions” for the 55 cats, 12 dogs and two turtles that Elizabeth Grant, 48, kept at her Jackson Heights home.
lead_paragraph: A police officer went to a home in Queens because a resident had been the victim of a crime. But no one answered and the door was open, the authorities said. Inside, the officer found a home crawling with cats and dogs.

headline: Pulling Away From Bernie Sanders, Hillary Clinton Is Turning to the Fall
abstract: Stepping up fund-raising for the general election is among the priorities even if the Democratic nomination contest has yet to be settled.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — After months of trying to sideline an unexpectedly deft and well-financed liberal opponent, Hillary Clinton on Tuesday won a series of primaries that freed her to present herself as the de facto victor of the Democratic nominating fight and gave her the impetus to shift focus decisively toward the November election.

headline: Man Arrested in Fatal Stabbing at Harlem Subway Station
abstract: Julio Velasquez is accused of second-degree murder in the death of Herbert Burgess, who the police say argued with the suspect’s daughter over a MetroCard swipe.
lead_paragraph: A 48-year-old man was arrested on Tuesday on charges that he fatally stabbed another man last month during a fight in a subway station in Harlem, the authorities said.

headline: Colombia Confirms More Birth Defects Linked to Zika
abstract: Both mothers had the Zika virus during pregnancy, but Colombian health officials said overall cases of the mosquito-borne virus were decreasing there.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Colombian health officials said on Tuesday that they had confirmed two more cases of babies born with brain damage to mothers who had Zika during pregnancy, but said overall cases of the mosquito-borne virus were decreasing in the country.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, April 27, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “You try not to judge him, but it’s a pretty small brain.”

lead_paragraph: Barbaralee Diamonstein-Spielvogel, an author, preservationist and curator, was appointed chairwoman of the New York State Council on the Arts this week.

abstract: Casey Nicholaw’s Broadway musical avoids flashy tricks and easy sentiment, showing a natural feel for this story about a secret fountain of youth.
lead_paragraph: Family-friendly musicals on Broadway generally come in just one flavor: flashy.

headline: Venezuela Panel Clears the Way for a Process to Oust Nicolás Maduro
abstract: A decision by the country’s electoral commission lifted hopes of the opposition politicians, who have vowed to remove the president by the end of the year.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Venezuela’s electoral commission on Tuesday released documents that would allow opposition politicians to collect signatures and formally begin a process aimed at removing President Nicolás Maduro from office.

headline: Yogurt Buyers Send Dannon Back to the Farm
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Yogurt', 'Milk', 'Dairy Products', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Cattle']
abstract: Facing tough competition from newer yogurt makers, the company is establishing animal welfare and conservation standards for its milk suppliers.
lead_paragraph: The yogurt giant Dannon, looking to tap into the public’s growing concern about the source of its food, is establishing a direct pipeline to some farms that supply the company with milk, part of an ambitious plan to influence farm practices right down to the dirt.

headline: It’s a Gift

lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I do love a literary theme in my crossword puzzle. In a word puzzle, a theme about books reminds me of “Inception,” or one of those fun-house mirror rooms.

headline: Israel’s Vow to Keep Golan Brings ‘Deep Concern’ at Security Council
abstract: The Security Council president said Resolution 497, which described Israel’s annexation of the Golan Heights as ‘null and void,’ remains in effect.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s assertion last week that it will never give up the Golan Heights, captured from Syria in the 1967 war, drew a terse response on Tuesday from the United Nations Security Council, which said that a 35-year-old resolution rejecting Israeli sovereignty over the disputed land remains in effect.

headline: Maurice Kenny, Who Explored His Mohawk Heritage in Poetry, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Kenny gave voice in his verse to historical figures of New York State, both white and Native American.
lead_paragraph: Maurice Kenny, a poet who explored his Mohawk heritage in verse, often through the voices of historical figures in the forests and settlements of colonial New York State, died on April 16 in Saranac Lake, N.Y. He was 86.

headline: 5 Rescue Workers Are Killed in Northern Syria
abstract: Five rescue workers with a civil defense group were killed in aerial attacks on their headquarters in northern Syria on Tuesday as violence escalated in Aleppo Province.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Five rescue workers with a civil defense group were killed in aerial attacks on their headquarters in northern Syria on Tuesday as violence escalated in the critical battlegrounds of Aleppo Province, where government and insurgent attacks have killed dozens in recent days.

headline: Another Five States Cast Their Ballots
abstract: Voters in Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island went to the polls in the Democratic and Republican primaries.
lead_paragraph: Voters in Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island went to the polls in the Democratic and Republican primaries.

headline: Arm Woes Are Drawback of the Yankees’ Fast Pitches
abstract: Arm injuries are plaguing the current generation of pitchers, and the Yankees are no exception. “We never talk about it — it’s bad luck,” said Ivan Nova, who had Tommy John surgery two years ago.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — One end of the visitors’ clubhouse at Globe Life Park here contains the cubicles of all 12 of the Yankees’ pitchers. The setup allows them to pore over scouting reports together, make sure they do not forget about meetings and chat with like-minded souls.

headline: Why Donald Trump Is Probably Two States From Victory
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Republican National Convention']
abstract: After a big night on Tuesday, and given his polling leads in other states, he may need only victories in Indiana and California to avoid a contested convention.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is essentially two key states from the nomination.

abstract: A Canadian who originated the Broadway role of Abigail in Arthur Miller’s “The Crucible,” she also starred in stage and film versions of Tennessee Williams plays.
lead_paragraph: After Madeleine Sherwood, a Canadian actress, hitchhiked to New York in 1949, she slept on a stone bench outside the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue for two nights and subsisted on unbuttered rolls from the Automat.

headline: Rangers Pound Luis Severino and Yankees
abstract: Severino gave up five runs in the third inning, and the Yankees’ offense mustered only one run in a loss at Texas.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — If Yankees Manager Joe Girardi were instead the king of baseball, able to change the game on a whim, one of his edicts would be to outlaw defensive shifts.

headline: Chris Van Hollen and Katie McGinty Win Senate Primary Races
abstract: Two establishment Democrats prevailed in hard-fought contests in Maryland and Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — Two establishment Democrats — Representative Chris Van Hollen of Maryland and Katie McGinty, a former chief of staff to the governor of Pennsylvania — won key Senate primaries on Tuesday, ending a contentious primary season in both states.

headline: ‘The Night Manager’ Episode 2: The Mistress, Unveiled
abstract: But is Jonathan convincing as a tough guy? Given that he can’t seem to stop serving coffee?
lead_paragraph: Readers who chided me last week for having been too quick to dismiss Jed were right, of course: There’s a lot more to the arms dealer Richard Roper’s American mistress than first meets the eye. “The Night Manager” does a beautiful job this week of starting to unveil the character’s various dimensions, with a lingerie ad-like opening sequence (is it the drugs that make her put her red lipstick on before her white dress?) that ends abruptly with the nagging buzz of a phone call from home.

headline: Highlights of New York, From a Budding Journalist

lead_paragraph: A fourth-grade essay written by The Times's David W. Dunlap on his first trip to New York.

headline: Comcast Is Said to Be in Talks to Acquire DreamWorks Animation
abstract: If a deal goes through, it would value the studio at about $3 billion. Comcast is expected to merge it with its own animation unit, Illumination Entertainment.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After years of on-and-off flirtations, Comcast is in talks to buy DreamWorks Animation, the boutique studio run by Jeffrey Katzenberg that has struggled to move past the boom-and-bust cycle driven by its sporadic film releases.

headline: Barnes & Noble’s Longtime Leader, Leonard Riggio, Is Stepping Down
abstract: He purchased a struggling bookstore in 1971 and transformed the bookselling business — before an even bigger disruption came along.
lead_paragraph: When Leonard Riggio bought Barnes & Noble in 1971, it consisted of a single struggling store in Manhattan. Over time, with swagger and an unwavering belief in the value of physical bookstores, he turned it into the country’s largest bookselling chain.

abstract: Average performance dropped in math from 2013 to 2015 but held steady in reading, results from the National Assessment of Educational Progress showed.
lead_paragraph: The average performance of the nation’s high school seniors dropped in math from 2013 to 2015, but held steady in reading, according to results of a biennial test released Wednesday.

lead_paragraph: The history of the hair dryer.

headline: Dyson Wants to Create a Hair Dryer Revolution
abstract: James Dyson, the Steve Jobs of household products, wants to do for beauty and grooming what his company did for vacuum cleaners. Will consumers buy it?
lead_paragraph: WILTSHIRE, England — Sir James Dyson, the British designer and engineer, sporting sneakers, cobalt blue spectacles and a voluminous thatch of silvery hair, stood in his vast glass office in the depths of the English countryside one recent Tuesday afternoon. He was clutching a device that he contends could change the monotony of bathroom routines forever.

headline: The Complex Math Behind Spiraling Prescription Drug Prices
abstract: How much Americans pay at the pharmacy depends on a complicated system of list prices, discounts, fees and deductibles, with the sickest often paying the most.
lead_paragraph: The soaring cost of prescription drugs has generated outrage among politicians and patients. Some cancer drugs carry price tags of more than $100,000 a year, and health plans are increasingly asking people to shoulder a greater share of the cost.

headline: TAG Heuer Signs On With English Premier League
abstract: Luxury watch brands and sports have always been related, but the deal with the world’s richest soccer league signals something of a change in strategy.
lead_paragraph: TAG Heuer has designs on soccer. After signing on as the official timekeeper of Major League Soccer in the United States, the German Bundesliga and the Chinese Football Association Super League, the high-end watch brand announced its sponsorship on Tuesday of the English Premier League, the richest and most watched national soccer competition, which includes many of the sport’s most popular clubs, like Manchester United and Arsenal.

headline: A Teenage Photographer Witnessing Syria’s War
abstract: The flood of Kurdish refugees into Turkey compelled a young photographer to ditch school and travel to the border with Syria, where he documented Kurdish fighters clashing with the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: The Turkish photographer Furkan Temir was still a teenager as he watched his country’s Kurdish population swell because of civilians fleeing the civil war in neighboring Syria. Unable to ignore his urge to document the situation in 2014, he left home one day, telling his parents he was going to school. His real destination would provide an education of a different sort: a battlefield in the northern Syrian border town of Kobani where fighters from the Kurdish diaspora, along with the American-led coalition, were expelling Islamic State forces.

headline: North Korea to Convene Rare Party Congress Next Week
abstract: The congress, the first since 1980, is a likely platform for the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, to cement his authority.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said Wednesday that it would open the seventh congress of its ruling Workers’ Party next week. It will be the country’s biggest political convention in more than three decades and a likely platform for its leader, Kim Jong-un, to cement his authority.

headline: Don’t Blame Silicon Valley for Theranos
abstract: The troubled testing company dazzled the media, but Palo Alto investors were the first to see the potential flaws.
lead_paragraph: THREE years ago, Walgreens (b. 1901) arrived in Silicon Valley for the same reason many old economy companies do: to hurry and join the digital vanguard before it was left behind. Walgreens quickly made a deal with Theranos (b. 2004), the medical diagnostics company and media darling that promised a revolutionary approach to blood tests.

headline: Making a Cable Merger Safe for Consumers
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Television', 'Cable Television', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Wireless Communications', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: Regulators are right to seek important conditions before approving a deal that would combine three cable companies.
lead_paragraph: Telecommunications companies often use mergers to limit consumer choice and raise prices. That’s why federal regulators are right to seek tough conditions before approving a deal that would combine three cable companies.

headline: Voting Rights Lose in North Carolina
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Discrimination', 'Minorities', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: A federal judge upheld the most regressive new voting law in the country, despite there being no good rationale for it.
lead_paragraph: Late Monday, a federal district judge upheld one of the most regressive and restrictive voting laws in the country — a 2013  North Carolina law  that eliminated same-day voter registration and preregistration for 16- and 17-year-olds; cut back on early voting by a week; barred counting votes cast outside voters’ home precincts; and required voters to show identification at the polls.

headline: Obama’s Last Chance to End the ‘Forever War’
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'War and Emergency Powers (US)', 'September 11 (2001)']
abstract: The Obama administration has been fighting a semi-legal war for almost eight years. That’s not a power he should leave for the next president.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE United States is fighting an unauthorized war. Over the past 19 months, American forces have launched more than 8,800 strikes against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria and hit the group’s affiliate in Libya. The United States continues aerial assaults against Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula in Yemen, is going after militants in Afghanistan and Pakistan, and killed more than 150 suspected Shabab fighters in Somalia just last month.

headline: Out of Africa, Part III
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Global Warming', 'Television', 'Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Rap and Hip-Hop', 'Music']
abstract: In Senegal, a rap artist and a weatherman both worry for their nation’s future.
lead_paragraph: Dakar, SENEGAL — You can learn everything you need to know about the main challenges facing Africa today by talking to just two people in Senegal: the rapper and the weatherman. They’ve never met, but I could imagine them doing an amazing duet one day — words and weather predictions — on the future of Africa.

headline: SoHo: Chic Stores and Cobblestones
abstract: The neighborhood of former industrial buildings draws hordes to its stores and galleries, but residents still find a sense of community.
lead_paragraph: Brooklyn or SoHo? The choice “was a complete no-brainer,” said Tali Livni, who grabbed a one-bedroom co-op apartment in 2014 for $475,000 on Thompson Street in SoHo, though it was a sixth-floor walk-up. She had been renting in Brooklyn and was looking for apartments there, despite a long commute to work in the financial district, because she believed it would be easier to find a home within her budget.

headline: A Burst of Energy in Bangladesh
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Coal', 'Solar Energy', 'Nuclear Energy', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: The government has made great strides in increasing energy capacity. But it needs to give power to the people, too.
lead_paragraph: In Dhaka, we are used to the phenomenon called load-shedding. It’s when you’re sitting under the ceiling fan on a particularly hot day, the soles of your feet burning, hoping the evening will bring rain, or at the very least, a slight breeze … and suddenly the world goes quiet, the lights go out, and the fan’s revolutions slow, then stop.

headline: Salah Abdeslam, Suspect in Paris Attacks, Is Extradited to France
abstract: Salah Abdeslam, who is also believed to be connected to the attacks in Brussels, was handed over by Belgium and charged, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Salah Abdeslam, thought to be the only direct participant in November’s Paris attacks to have survived, was handed over to France by Belgium on Wednesday, prosecutors in both countries said.

headline: 1 Minute of All-Out Exercise May Have Benefits of 45 Minutes of Moderate Exertion
abstract: Sixty seconds of intense exercise provided the benefits of three-quarters of an hour of moderate cycling.
lead_paragraph: For many of us, the most pressing question about exercise is: How little can I get away with? The answer, according to a sophisticated new study of interval training, may be very, very little. In this new experiment, in fact, 60 seconds of strenuous exertion proved to be as successful at improving health and fitness as three-quarters of an hour of moderate exercise.

headline: Where Did the Government Jobs Go?
keywords: ['Government Employees', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Discrimination', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Long a ticket to the middle class, especially for African-Americans, they have become increasingly difficult to find.
lead_paragraph: On a muggy afternoon in April, Angelina Iles, 65, folded herself into my passenger seat and took me on a tour of her beloved Pineville, La., a sleepy town smack in the middle of the low, wet state. We drove past spaced-out, low-slung houses and boarded-up businesses — shuttered restaurants, a decrepit gas station — as Iles, an African-American retired lunchroom worker and community activist, guided me toward the muddy banks of the Red River. Near there stands the locked-up Art Deco shell of the Huey P. Long hospital, which once served the poorest of the poor in Rapides Parish — and employed more than 300 workers.

headline: Banco Santander Profit Falls Amid Turbulent Currency Markets
abstract: The Spanish lender said its profit was down 5 percent in the first quarter from a year earlier as the British pound and Latin American currencies affected results.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Banco Santander of Spain said on Wednesday that its profit declined 5 percent in the first quarter as fluctuations in the British pound and other currencies, as well as a deterioration in lending and fee income, weighed on its results.

headline: Is the U.S. Ready for Post-Middle-Class Politics?
abstract: A particular vision of the American dream has shaped elections for decades. What happens when people stop believing in it?
lead_paragraph: On April 12 last year, Hillary Clinton formally announced her run for the presidency by posting a two-­minute video on YouTube. For the first minute and a half, Clinton was nowhere to be seen. Instead, the video showed a montage of a dozen or so Clinton supporters: a ­middle-­aged white woman tending to her garden; two Hispanic brothers starting a business; a pregnant young black woman and her husband unpacking boxes in a sun-­dappled suburban living room; a burly, bullet-headed white man surveying an American-­flag-­draped warehouse.

headline: What Happened to Worcester?
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs', 'United States Economy', 'Genealogy']
abstract: A central Massachusetts city enabled the author’s ancestors to move into the good life of the middle class. That move is more complicated now.
lead_paragraph: The house existed, in my mind, as an idea, almost a dream, before I ever discovered the actual place: “Bumpa’s house,” the home of my father’s grandfather. It represented, in the telling of my father and other older relatives, the kind of place you’d get to live in if you worked hard. It was huge, on a hill, with a big yard, and every Christmas it was filled with toys: “Bicycles and skis and basketballs,” my dad, Jack, now 79, recalled. “And a croquet set.”

headline: TV’s Dwindling Middle Class
abstract: Money worries and striving were part of the mainstream sitcom. Now most characters exist in a classless world.
lead_paragraph: We tend to fetishize labor. Anybody who’s drooled over a sexy-firemen calendar knows that: Blue-collar dudes are hot. It’s a cliché. But the third episode of the 10-part, Brooklyn-bar web series “Horace and Pete” turns the cliché into a four-alarm tragedy. A middle-aged woman named Sarah (Laurie Metcalf) sits at a table confessing to something that mortifies her. She is deeply turned on by her father-in-law. His name is Roger, and he’s an 84-year-old ex-Navy man who drives a pickup truck and used to farm. He comes over to make repairs on Sarah’s country cottage, and as he does his thing — shirtless, indifferent to her — she just, you know, watches him.

headline: Lending a Library a Hand in Colorado
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Ranches', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A novelist becomes a HistoriCorps volunteer to help transform a dilapidated Colorado ranch into a live-in library. Safety ropes and hard hats are involved.
lead_paragraph: I am perched on a slippery roof ridge at the Buffalo Peaks Ranch in the rain, feet sliding on ancient asphalt shingles atop rotting plywood decking, tethered only by a rope. For fun.

keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Watches and Clocks', 'Restoration and Renovation']
abstract: The famed clock tower’s bells at the Houses of Parliament in London will not toll for a while, but when isn’t clear. The clock will keep ticking, most of the time.
lead_paragraph: Big Ben, the iconic clock in London that has kept time for 157 years, withstood two world wars and become a symbol of the British capital, will fall silent for several months as part of a much-needed refurbishment program that is projected to last for three years, the British government said on Tuesday.

lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Po, the wisdom-seeking hero of the “Kung Fu Panda” films, might recognize this temple in China where the world’s first robot monk dwells. For Po’s Jade Palace, there is Longquan (Dragon Spring) Temple, a place of Buddhist worship in the mountains northwest of Beijing, where gnarled gingko and cypress trees tower over red-walled buildings underneath rocky Phoenix Ridge.

headline: 1966: Hitler’s Favorite Soldier Buried
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Hitler’s favorite soldier is carried to his grave with great ceremony in 1966.
lead_paragraph: LUDWIGSBURG, WEST GERMANY — Former SS Col. Gen. Sepp Dietrich, Hitler’s favorite soldier, was carried today [April 27] by weeping ex-generals to a hillside grave in this town of baroque castles. More than 7,000 mourners, mostly men of the former SS fighting formations and their relatives, including many from the Belgian, Danish and Austrian Waffen SS, paid their last respects to one of the most dreaded Nazi generals. Dietrich, 74, who died of a heart attack Thursday, was a close friend of SS leader Heinrich Himmler. He served ten years of a life sentence imposed by the Nuremberg war-crimes tribunal. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, April 28, 1966

headline: ‘Daughters of the Dust,’ a Seeming Inspiration for ‘Lemonade,’ Is Restored
abstract: Julie Dash’s 1991 film was out of print but will be released in theaters this fall.
lead_paragraph: In its debut over the weekend, the new Beyoncé visual album mixed “Lemonade” with a little “Dust.” The film “Daughters of the Dust,” written and directed by Julie Dash, about a family of Gullah women living on the Sea Islands and their decision to migrate to the American mainland in the early 1900s, looked to be inspiration for some of the lyrical, historical imagery in Beyoncé’s latest project, "Lemonade.” Now, the film, which is on DVD only in an out-of-print version, will get new life on the big screen.

Justices across the ideological spectrum said the laws under which he had been convicted gave prosecutors too much power to say that routine political favors amounted to corruption.

headline: From Hell to Heaven in the Hometown of Bosch
abstract: As a Dutch city celebrates the 500th anniversary of the death of its legendary son, a search for the inspiration for his strange little monsters.
lead_paragraph: Hieronymus Bosch is a kind of populist superstar among the old-master painters. His fans relish his surreal, inventive images of the afterlife, but particularly his vivid visions of hell: sinners straddling giant knife-blades, egg-shaped machines churning miscreants into their bellies, cruel hybrid frog-devils and dog-faced lizard birds.

headline: Will Nigeria’s New Capital Be Old Soon?
abstract: Gleaming Abuja starts to feel more like teeming Lagos.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — A few weeks ago I sat in a taxi in Abuja, Nigeria’s capital. “I think I’ve driven you before,” the driver said. How long ago, I asked. Two years, he confidently replied. And then a claim that stunned me: “I’ve still got your number saved.”

headline: Political Confusion in Spain
abstract: The failure to agree on a government leaves the country in limbo at a time when Europe is under stress.
lead_paragraph: In the four months since national elections in Spain, a fractured and fractious Parliament has failed to agree on a government. After the failure of an 11th-hour effort brokered by King Felipe VI this week, Spain was compelled to call new elections for late June. Polls show that the next Parliament could be even more contentious, leading to more months of political limbo.

headline: ‘Ghostbusters’: Then and Now
abstract: The director and production designer of the new film explain their thinking behind what to change and what to leave alone.
lead_paragraph: Something strange in the neighborhood? Ever since 1984, when a giant Stay Puft Marshmallow Man menaced New Yorkers in the sci-fi comedy hit “Ghostbusters,” moviegoers have known who to call. Though there was a sequel in 1989 and there were animated TV spinoffs, all involving a New York City riddled with paranormal activity and those who battle it, fan anticipation soared when this summer’s reboot (due July 15) was announced. The biggest update — the female comedians Melissa McCarthy, Kristen Wiig, Leslie Jones and Kate McKinnon taking over from the original male stars, Bill Murray, Dan Aykroyd, Harold Ramis and Ernie Hudson — has been dissected so much on social media that the new filmmakers wanted to be careful how they executed any other changes from the original. They knew that certain elements of the “Ghostbusters” world, like proton packs and the Ecto-1, were essential to keep for the fans, but they also wanted to add their own spin. The film’s director and co-writer, Paul Feig, and the production designer, Jefferson Sage, explain their thinking behind the updated packs and other ghostbusting gear.

headline: 1891: Mme Bernhardt Causes Scene
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Sarah Bernhardt raises a tempest behind the scenes in 1891.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mme Bernhardt raised a tempest behind the scenes at San Francisco on Saturday night. A scene-shifter struck her Turkish servant for insolence and cut his face, whereupon Mme Bernhardt rushed to his assistance, and became perfectly frantic with rage, and her French expletives were of the most picturesque character. She screamed for a revolver, and the shifters, becoming angry, threatened to drop half a ton of scenery upon her. Her company came to the rescue, and a free fight ensued, in which many black eyes were made and some blood was spilt. — The New York Herald, European Edition, April 28, 1891

headline: Victor in Mayoral Primary Is Ready to ‘Get Baltimore Working’

Garland should get a vote by the Senate Judiciary Committee, going against his old colleagues who have staunchly opposed even considering President Obama’s Supreme Court nominee.
lead_paragraph: Dr. No seems to have become Dr. Yes. Kind of.

headline: Greece Pushes for Eurozone Summit Meeting to Unblock Debt Talks
abstract: Without new rescue funds by July, the country could default on its debts and throw the currency bloc into another period of chaos.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece asked on Wednesday for a summit meeting of eurozone leaders that would allow him to make his case for easier terms on sorely needed aid to help his country avoid bankruptcy.

headline: Review: New York Festival of Song Highlights Pieces by Latin American Women
abstract: The high point of this program, “Compositora,” was Odaline de la Martinez’s “Canciones de Lorca,” sung by María Valdés and Efraín Solís.
lead_paragraph: Performed without an intermission, the New York Festival of Song’s long program of pieces by Latin American women, “Compositora,” had flashes of interest near the beginning but settled into a gentle, sleepy groove.

headline: Get Your Flu Shot in the Morning
abstract: The immune response to the flu vaccine was stronger in those vaccinated in the morning than those who got the shot in the afternoon.
lead_paragraph: There may be a simple and cost-free way to improve the effectiveness of the flu vaccine: Get vaccinated in the morning instead of the afternoon.

abstract: A reader wonders “why any American arts organization would want to collaborate with the government of the United Arab Emirates.”

keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Nuclear Energy']
abstract: Democrats and the White House said the addendum, barring America’s purchase of Iranian heavy water supplies, would have undermined the arms accord.

headline: Review: Dorrance Dance, Where Tap and Computers Intersect
abstract: The troupe presents its new show, “ETM: Double Down,” at the Joyce, where dancers play the stage floor, conventional instruments and wooden boards.
lead_paragraph: Since the beginnings of tap dance, practitioners have been lugging around wooden boards, instruments used to drum upon with their feet. Now, in an era of electronic dance music, new possibilities beg to be explored. What if you plugged those boards into computers?

headline: Selling Surfers on a New Way to Ride Waves
abstract: Slyde, a handboard start-up, has tackled the added burden of inventing a market for a product and popularizing a sport.
lead_paragraph: Entrepreneurs face many obstacles in starting a new business, but the founders of Slyde Handboards face a particularly daunting one: how to create a market for a product most people have never heard of, and for a sport they know nothing about.

headline: The Balmain Army Steps Out

headline: Texting and Driving? Watch Out for the Textalyzer
keywords: ['Driver Distraction and Fatigue', 'Text Messaging', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Privacy', 'Smartphones', 'Police', 'Law and Legislation', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Tests (Sobriety)']
abstract: Policy makers and road safety experts are reaching back to tested strategies: They want to treat distracted driving like drunken driving.
lead_paragraph: Over the last seven years, most states have banned texting by drivers, and public service campaigns have tried an array of tactics — “It can wait,” among them — to persuade people to put down their phones when they are behind the wheel.

headline: Fed Keeps Rates Steady and Says Labor Market Is Improving
keywords: ['Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Inflation (Economics)']
abstract: While policy makers noted some weak points in the domestic economy, the central bank appears on course to increase rates later in the year.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve, determined to move cautiously, said on Wednesday that the American economy still was not ready for higher interest rates.

headline: Naz Shah, British Lawmaker, Suspended Over Anti-Israel Posts
abstract: Jeremy Corbyn, the Labour Party leader, suspended Ms. Shah for endorsing anti-Israel posts on social media before she joined Parliament.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the face of mounting criticism over inaction on episodes of anti-Semitism in the Labour Party, Jeremy Corbyn reversed himself on Wednesday and suspended a party lawmaker for endorsing anti-Israel posts on social media before she became a member of Parliament.

headline: The Wisdom of Prince, as Told by His Collaborators
abstract: Sheila E., King and more musicians talk about what they learned from working with an artist who so thoroughly mastered the stage and the studio.
lead_paragraph: In the days since Prince died at Paisley Park, many of his collaborators have reflected on his remarkable talents onstage and in the studio, and come to the same conclusion: The artist’s legacy is much greater than the public realizes.

headline: Suicide Bombing Near Historic Mosque in Turkey Wounds 13

headline: Romania’s Culture Minister Steps Down as Ballet Dispute Continues

lead_paragraph: PARIS — The culture minister of Romania tendered his resignation on Wednesday amid a crisis at the ballet company of the Bucharest National Opera involving its artistic director, Johan Kobborg, and the star ballerina Alina Cojocaru, which had led to the cancellation of several performances.

headline: Review: ‘The School for Scandal’ Is Full-Throated Satire
abstract: Red Bull Theater’s jaunty new production of Richard Brinsley Sheridan’s work is directed by Marc Vietor at the Lucille Lortel Theater.
lead_paragraph: They’re delectably venomous, these two: dear Lady Sneerwell, industriously inventing gossip, and her friend Mrs. Candour, so diligently spreading it around. The main trouble, always, with Richard Brinsley Sheridan’s spirited satire “The School for Scandal” is that we don’t get enough of them.

headline: ScienceTake | Shake a Tail Feather
abstract: Peacocks not only show their spectacular tails, or trains, they rattle them, and scientists are nailing down the physics of feather vibration.
lead_paragraph: Peacocks not only show their spectacular tails, or trains, they rattle them, and scientists are nailing down the physics of feather vibration.

headline: Peacocks Don’t Just Show Their Feathers, They Rattle Them
abstract: Researchers studied the physics of how peacocks shake their tail feathers and found they resonate like a guitar string.
lead_paragraph: Suzanne Amador Kane, a physicist at Haverford College, in Pennsylvania, was thinking about visual signals by animals — mostly come-ons and warnings.

headline: Tibetans in Exile Re-elect Political Leader
abstract: The leader, Lobsang Sangay, 48, said he would push for talks with China to secure Tibet’s future and that of exiled Tibetans around the world.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The current political leader of Tibet’s exiled government, Lobsang Sangay, won re-election by a decisive majority, the election commission announced Wednesday, and he pledged to push harder for a dialogue with China to resolve the future of Tibet.

headline: In Israel, Iraqi Jews Reflect on Baghdad Heritage
abstract: As the number of Jews in Iraq has dwindled to nearly none, Iraqi Jews in Israel are taking fresh interest in a heritage once considered unseemly.
lead_paragraph: GIVATAYIM, Israel — During a boisterous Passover Seder with her extended family, Sabiha Ziluf, 75, paused and said softly that she could still see the Baghdad streets of her childhood. “I would love to visit Bab al-Sharji,” she said, referring to an old neighborhood near where her aunt lived.

headline: Donald Trump, Laying Out Foreign Policy, Promises Coherence
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: “We’re going to finally have a coherent foreign policy, based on American interests and the shared interests of our allies,” Mr. Trump pledged.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump, exuding confidence after his resounding primary victories in the East, promised a foreign policy on Wednesday that he said would put “America first.” He castigated President Obama and Hillary Clinton, a former secretary of state and a possible opponent in the general election, for what he described as a string of missteps that have disillusioned the nation’s allies and emboldened its rivals.

headline: In ‘Dear Evan Hansen,’ an Outsider Is Upended
abstract: This musical, directed by Michael Greif, stars Ben Platt as a teenager whose life takes a sudden turn.
lead_paragraph: A letter that falls into the wrong hands and is misinterpreted drives the intricate plot of “Dear Evan Hansen,” a musical about unhappy teenhood and its consequences (good and bad) opening at Second Stage Theater.

abstract: A psychology professor’s suggestion that some dogs may feel distressed by being hugged ricocheted across social media.
lead_paragraph: The next time you want to hug a dog, consider this: You could be making the pooch miserable, an expert says.

headline: The ‘Women’s Card’? We Measured, and It’s Not Worth Much
abstract: Perhaps Donald Trump is playing the men’s card: The U.S. is positioned between Greece and Bangladesh in one metric of women’s success in politics.
lead_paragraph: As Donald Trump turns his attention to Hillary Clinton, he’s trying out new attack lines. In his victory speech Tuesday evening, it was that “the only card she has is the women’s card.” He said that “if Hillary Clinton were a man, I don’t think she would get 5 percent of the vote.”

headline: ‘The Creative Workplace’

lead_paragraph: Inspired and inspiring spaces around the world, which are also the subject of a new book.

headline: Some of the World’s Most Beautiful Workplaces, in One Book
abstract: In the latest title from ROADS Publishing in Dublin, creative agencies and design studios open their doors to their inspired (and inspiring) interiors.
lead_paragraph: The creative process can be as alluring as the final product — perhaps even more so. And, thanks in no small part to the standard set by Google headquarters, the work spaces carved out by creative types are becoming ever more imaginative, and are as inspiring as they are inspired.

headline: SpaceX Says It Plans to Send a Probe to Mars
abstract: Elon Musk’s company said it would dispatch its Dragon vessel to the planet, possibly as early as 2018, with a long-term goal of establishing colonies.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Wednesday said that President Obama would travel to Flint, Mich., next week to hear from residents affected by the water crisis there and get a briefing on federal response efforts.

headline: For Dusty Baker, a Life in Baseball Trying Not to Be Defined
abstract: Age? Race? Baker’s new job is to get the most out of the Nationals, period.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The two labels we affix to Dusty Baker say more about baseball than they do about him.

headline: How to Make a Mother’s Day Flower Arrangement
abstract: Eric Buterbaugh, the L.A.-based floral designer beloved by celebrities and fashion houses, teaches T how to expertly arrange flowers.
lead_paragraph: Eric Buterbaugh, the L.A.-based floral designer beloved by celebrities and fashion houses, teaches T how to expertly arrange flowers.

headline: How to Arrange Flowers (Because Mother’s Day Is Near)
keywords: ['Flowers and Plants', "Mother's Day", 'Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants']
abstract: Eric Buterbaugh, beloved by celebrities and fashion brands, is setting up shop in Bergdorf Goodman next week, and teaches T tricks of the floral trade.
lead_paragraph: Eric Buterbaugh, perhaps best known as the imaginative Los Angeles-based florist-of-choice for celebrities like Demi Moore and Gwyneth Paltrow (not to mention fashion labels from Louis Vuitton to Dior), is bringing his chic blooms to New York City with a one-week pop-up shop at Bergdorf Goodman. And he’ll be offering his line of eight luxury, flower-inspired fragrances, EB Florals, there too. “So many people have tried to get me to open a flower shop in New York over the years,” Buterbaugh says. “So to be launching with Bergdorf’s is a dream come true.” Open May 2 through Mother’s Day, the pop-up shop will stock hand-tied bouquets, and in typical Buterbaugh style, there will be a larger-than-life floral installation over the store’s Fifth Avenue entrance too. “This is the Eric Buterbaugh power invasion of New York,” he says. “It’s going to be flower city!” In the above slide show, he teaches T how to expertly arrange flowers — for Mother’s Day, or anytime.

headline: The Olympic Fashion Unveil Begins
abstract: Balancing fashion and function for the opening ceremony in Rio.
lead_paragraph: With only 100 days to go, the Olympic fashion unveil is picking up steam. First Australia revealed its opening ceremony looks at the end of last month — a green and white seersucker blazer and white shorts or skort. Canada followed suit a few wees ago with a maple-leaf-bedecked blazer a few weeks ago. And on Wednesday, just hours after team Great Britain showed off its Stella McCartney competition gear and team USA debuted its Polo Ralph Lauren closing ceremony style, France stepped up to the podium.

headline: Bernie Sanders to Cut Hundreds of Staff Members and Focus on California
abstract: A day after losing four of five states, the Vermont senator said he would remain in the race but needed to channel his resources into the states ahead.
lead_paragraph: WEST LAFAYETTE, Ind. — Battered by four defeats in Tuesday night’s primaries, Bernie Sanders is planning to lay off hundreds of campaign staffers across the country and focus much of his remaining effort on winning the June 7 California primary.

headline: Donald Trump and Caitlyn Jenner Star at the Time 100 Gala

lead_paragraph: At the Time 100 gala Tuesday night, Mia Farrow and Aziz Ansari chatted about not comedy or Darfur, but a Nicki Minaj performance in which the rapper wore an outfit that left little to the imagination.

headline: Facebook Plans New Stock Class to Solidify Mark Zuckerberg’s Control
abstract: The announcement came as Facebook announced a tripling in its quarterly profit to $1.5 billion, with sales up 52 percent.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Mark Zuckerberg nurtured Facebook from a dorm room idea into the world’s biggest social network. Now the company is taking steps to ensure its founder remains in charge.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Early Vice-Presidential Pick Has Echoes of Ronald Reagan

lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas often casts himself as the rightful heir to Ronald Reagan’s mantle of conservatism, and on Wednesday he took a page directly out of the former president’s playbook.

headline: Beyoncé’s ‘Lemonade’ Makes a Statement. Discuss.
abstract: In a conversation, writers for The New York Times put this superstar’s latest effort into a context wider than just the music.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, Beyoncé released her new album, “Lemonade,” and in an HBO special gave the premiere of an hourlong conceptual short film based on its music. In our Popcast, Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times; Wesley Morris, The Times’s critic at large; and Jenna Wortham and Nikole Hannah-Jones, both staff writers for The New York Times Magazine, discussed the album’s sound. They also talked about the personal nature of the film and the tracks (which focus on marital strife and, eventually, reconciliation) and the ways Beyoncé is developing into an increasingly political artist. Here are edited excerpts from their conversation:

headline: Brian Eno: Ambient Sounds, but Political, Too
abstract: The producer and musician discusses how he meshed music and words on his new album to evoke time, death and the tragic hubris of powerful men.
lead_paragraph: Brian Eno had no master plan when he started what became his new album, “The Ship” (Warp). In fact, he wasn’t even thinking about an album: just “sound in space,” he said in a telephone interview. “You set out to do one thing and you find that you’ve actually done something else completely different,” he said with a laugh. Then he explained the labyrinthine path to making the record, which will be released on Friday.

headline: For Margot Robbie, the Hustle Never Stops
abstract: Ms. Robbie, who is best known for “The Wolf of Wall Street,” stars in two movies this summer, “The Legend of Tarzan” and “Suicide Squad.”
lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, CALIF. — Margot Robbie came racing into the tucked-away bungalow she was renting here. She had returned from recording the voice of a talking dingo for a DreamWorks animated movie, and on an April afternoon was doing her best to clean up strewn clothes from overstuffed suitcases — evidence that an intended one-week visit to Los Angeles had stretched into a month.

headline: The Last Word: Inside The Times’s Obits Department
abstract: The editor of the Obituaries section, William McDonald, talks about “Obit,” the movie, and obit, the job.

headline: DreamWorks Deal Would Serve Comcast’s Entertainment Strategy
abstract: An expected acquisition would allow Comcast to build on its successful NBCUniversal entertainment business, which includes TV, film and theme parks.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, Comcast was licking its wounds.

headline: Review: With ‘Heat and Light,’ Jennifer Haigh Drills Below the Surface
abstract: This new novel is populated with a large, completely believable cast of characters who lock antlers over fracking in the fictitious town of Bakerton.
lead_paragraph: “Rural Pennsylvania doesn’t fascinate the world, not generally,” Jennifer Haigh writes in “Heat and Light.” “But cyclically, periodically, its innards are of interest.” They become of immense interest when Ms. Haigh writes about them, as she has in several novels set in the fictitious coal town of Bakerton, in the western part of the state.

headline: New Psychological Test for Man Accused of Killing Father

headline: Get Spring’s Easy Breezy Look With Floaty Clothes, Rainbow Accessories and Big Bows
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: Three design newcomers who specialize in effortlessly cool dressing — and none of it overly expensive. And sandals and rainbow jewelry that will make you smile.
lead_paragraph: It’s really not so much the floral prints as the floaty lightweight garments that make warm-weather dressing so enjoyable. Who needs button closures and form-fitting trousers when you can look just as good when you’re … well, unrestricted? Here are three new New York designers who are doing those shapes in a good way.

headline: Richard Lyons, 57, a Founder of the Subversive Band Negativland, Dies

lead_paragraph: Richard Lyons, a founding member of the subversive media-hacking, collage-minded band Negativland, died on April 19 in Seattle. He turned 57 that day.

headline: James Inhofe, Once a Merrick Garland Backer, Remains Opposed to His Nomination

headline: Coachella as a Jeremy Scott Fashion Playground and Muse

abstract: The fashion designer and creative director of Moschino goes to Coachella to see, sketch and get inspired.

You can meet the designer Albertus Swanepoel and choose a custom band to trim your hat ($280) or select from vintage fabrics brought over from the E. Marinella archives in Naples, Italy, and have a tailor hand-sew your tie ($280).

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: At 20, In Mo Yang Makes His New York Recital Debut
abstract: Thanks to a long-term violin loan, Mr. Yang played Beethoven, Biber, Schumann and Hertzberg on a Stradivarius at Weill Recital Hall.
lead_paragraph: Many young violinists with the talent and discipline for a promising career lack only one thing: a truly fine instrument. There is a limited supply of superb violins, and they tend to be terribly expensive.

headline: A Toddler, a Loose Gun in a Car, and a Mother Dies
abstract: Officials said that the 2-year-old, who was not in a car seat, “retrieved a firearm that slid out from under the driver’s seat and shot through the seat.”
lead_paragraph: No one can know for sure what was in the mind of the person who fired the shot that killed a woman as she drove through Milwaukee on Tuesday. The shooter was 2 years old.

headline: Pennies From Utah Revive a Symphony
abstract: As the orchestra returns to Carnegie Hall for the first time in decades, it has plenty of support back home from residents and government.
lead_paragraph: Like many orchestras, the Utah Symphony struggled during the Great Recession. But as it returns to Carnegie Hall on Friday for the first time in decades, it is an ensemble on the upswing, with rising ticket sales, new players and an energetic music director, Thierry Fischer.

headline: Your Evening Briefing

headline: A Brooklyn Bar With Inspiration From Marie Antoinette
abstract: Le Boudoir, a gilded cocktail den, is tucked under Chez Moi, a casual French bistro on Atlantic Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Though the Prohibition-inspired speakeasy trend has cooled in recent years, the desire to drink underground hasn’t. Take Le Boudoir, a gilded cocktail den that opened this winter under Chez Moi, a casual French bistro.

headline: Press Freedom Weakened Around the World in 2015, Report Says
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: A report by Freedom House added to evidence showing that assaults on members of the news media are spreading beyond chronically dangerous areas.
lead_paragraph: Press freedom suffered throughout the world in 2015, declining to its weakest level in 12 years because of attacks and intimidation by political, criminal and militant forces that sought to mute or control the news media, a prominent democracy advocacy group said in an annual report published Wednesday.

headline: Warsan Shire, the Woman Who Gave Poetry to Beyoncé’s ‘Lemonade’
abstract: Ms. Shire’s previously published verse forms the backbone of Beyoncé’s album and its exploration of family, infidelity and the black female body.
lead_paragraph: When the credits roll on Beyoncé’s new visual album, “Lemonade,” which had its premiere on Saturday on HBO, one of the first names to flash on screen doesn’t belong to a director, producer or songwriter. It belongs to a poet: Warsan Shire, a rising 27-year-old writer who was born in Kenya to Somali parents and raised in London.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Legacy
abstract: It’s over, but the cause lives. The issues his campaign has raised are likely to resonate with the progressive left for decades, if not forever.
lead_paragraph: At this point, Bernie Sanders is the figurehead of a living idea and a zombie campaign.

keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Food Trucks and Vendors', 'Ice Cream and Frozen Desserts']
abstract: His jingle, a herald of summer in the city, and of the ice cream man down the block, is the textbook embodiment of an earworm: once heard, never forgotten.

headline: After #OscarsSoWhite, Broadway Seeks a #TonysSoDiverse
abstract: The Tony nominations will be announced on Tuesday, and it’s possible that more African-American actors than ever will be among those chosen.

headline: Review: ‘Huang’s World’ Mixes Food, Travel and Attitude
abstract: This new Viceland series features the “Fresh Off the Boat” author Eddie Huang globe-trotting as he pursues cultural and culinary delights.
lead_paragraph: The first time Eddie Huang’s Florida childhood was memorialized on television, the results were mixed. ABC’s “Fresh Off the Boat,” based on his memoir of growing up Taiwanese-American in Orlando, Fla., was a critical and commercial success. Mr. Huang wrote and said unkind things about the show, however, and left his role as its off-camera narrator after one season.

headline: Review: ‘Team Foxcatcher’ Looks at a Millionaire’s Descent Into Murder
abstract: This Netflix documentary examines a case dramatized in the Steve Carell movie “Foxcatcher.”
lead_paragraph: The O. J. Simpson case isn’t the only sensational murder from the 1990s that has been mined lately by the film and television industry. The murder of the Olympic wrestler Dave Schultz by John E. du Pont in 1996 has also received multiple treatments, and Netflix joins the club on Friday with “Team Foxcatcher.” It’s a straightforward documentary and a good one for those who haven’t already spent enough time with this strange, unsettling story.

headline: André Esteves, Freed From Jail, Returns to BTG Pactual
abstract: The investment bank’s former chief executive will take no executive role, but will focus on partnership matters and strategy.
lead_paragraph: RIO de JANEIRO — André Esteves has rejoined the investment bank BTG Pactual as an adviser, a significant step toward a full return to finance after he was arrested and jailed less than six months ago as part of a corruption scandal that has shaken Brazil’s political and business elite.

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — When Capt. John Ellerbe introduced himself to his new students last year, he said, one of them seemed unable to believe her eyes.

headline: Carmen Cusack Puts ‘Her Pain and Her Joy’ Into a Leading Broadway Role
abstract: The actress, who made her Broadway debut in March, can relate to the emotional struggles of the character she portrays.
lead_paragraph: Edie Brickell and Steve Martin put that opening number into “Bright Star” just before their musical began performances on Broadway in March.

headline: Smokers Urged to Switch to E-Cigarettes by British Medical Group
abstract: The Royal College of Physicians summarized the growing body of science on e-cigarettes and found that their benefits far outweigh the potential harms.
lead_paragraph: Taking a stance sharply at odds with most American public health officials, a major British medical organization urged smokers to switch to electronic cigarettes, saying they are the best hope in generations for people addicted to tobacco cigarettes to quit.

headline: Donald Trump’s Strange Worldview
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States International Relations', 'Speeches and Statements', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: In his first formal foreign policy speech, Mr. Trump says he would tell global allies and foes that it’s his way or the highway.
lead_paragraph: After landslide Republican primary victories, Donald Trump delivered a speech on Wednesday in Washington intended to clarify his foreign policy positions. That was needed, because his views on America’s role in the world have until now been expressed in tweets, interviews and remarks at rallies that have alarmed nearly every foreign ally of the United States.

headline: Ford and Google Team Up to Support Driverless Cars
keywords: ['Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: The automaker and the tech giant formed the Self-Driving Coalition for Safer Streets, a group aimed at urging federal approval of autonomous vehicles.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — In an unusual alliance between a traditional automaker and a technology company, Ford Motor and Google on Wednesday joined to lead a coalition of companies that advocate federal approval of driverless cars in the near future.

headline: Yale Defies Calls to Rename Calhoun College
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Names, Organizational', 'Women and Girls', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The residential college, which is named for the white supremacist John C. Calhoun, will keep its name, and the university will open two new residential colleges next year.
lead_paragraph: Despite decades of fervent student protests that reached a peak last fall, the president of Yale announced on Wednesday that the university would keep the name of a residential college honoring the 19th-century politician and white supremacist John C. Calhoun.

headline: In the Heat of the Playoffs, Coach Challenges Start to Cool Off
abstract: N.H.L. coaches have grown gun-shy since the opening week of the playoffs, with only one coach’s challenge issued in 17 games, compared with 13 challenges in the first 30 postseason games.
lead_paragraph: Just past the midway point of a scoreless Game 4 on April 20, Florida Panthers forward Jonathan Huberdeau took a long pass from Jaromir Jagr and rushed toward the Islanders’ net, defenseman Ryan Pulock in hot pursuit.

headline: Carly Fiorina Pulls Out All the Stops, and Lyrics, in Joining Ted Cruz
keywords: ['Music', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']

lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Freshly printed signs, with both last names. Singing from the stage. The earnest use of the word “élan” at a rollicking political rally.

headline: Horace Ward, U.S. Judge Who Triumphed Over Bias, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Ward sued the University of Georgia after it rejected his law school application because of his race. He became Georgia’s first black federal judge.
lead_paragraph: Horace Ward was his high school valedictorian, graduated with honors from Morehouse College in Atlanta in only three years and earned a master’s degree from Atlanta University. But when he applied to the University of Georgia’s law school in 1951, he was reflexively rejected because of his race, his qualifications notwithstanding.

headline: Harry Wu, Who Told World of Abuses in China, Dies at 79
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Political Prisoners', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Mr. Wu was brutalized for 19 years in Communist labor camps, and later returned to his homeland undercover to expose prison conditions.
lead_paragraph: Harry Wu, who was brutalized for 19 years in Communist Chinese prison labor camps and who had ever since then refused to let the world overlook human rights violations in his former homeland, died on Tuesday in Honduras, where he was vacationing. He was 79.

headline: Man Wanted for Robbery Plunges to Death During Gang Roundup
abstract: Officers were looking for someone else at the Bronx apartment where Geovanni Martin tried to hide by hanging out a window, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A robbery suspect, apparently under the false impression that law enforcement officers rounding up suspected gang members in the Bronx were actually looking for him, fell from the sixth floor of a building to his death on Wednesday as he tried to hide, the police said.

headline: Hudson River Park Wins Clearance From Corps of Engineers
keywords: ['Restoration and Renovation', 'Parks and Other Recreation Areas', 'Environment']
abstract: Work on the project, which is being backed by the billionaire Barry Diller, could begin as early as this summer, but its critics vowed to keep fighting.
lead_paragraph: The Army Corps of Engineers has cleared the way for the creation of a 2.4-acre park on a pier in the Hudson River, with construction planned to begin as soon as this summer, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Flooded With Migrants, Germany Struggles to Integrate Them
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Deportation', 'Labor and Jobs', 'German Language']
abstract: More than a million migrants arrived in Germany. Now, the task is to decide who stays and who goes.
lead_paragraph: NUREMBERG, Germany — If the urgent challenge for Germany last year was sheltering the hundreds of thousands of people who descended on the country almost at once seeking asylum, then this year’s task is to integrate them.

headline: Angela Merkel Abruptly Fires Germany’s Spy Chief
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: The dismissal of Gerhard Schindler came when his job appeared safe, despite his agency’s links to carrying out searches at the behest of the United States’ National Security Agency.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Chancellor Angela Merkel on Wednesday replaced the chief of Germany’s foreign intelligence service. The move caught many by surprise as Europe faces growing pressure from Islamist terrorism and as the chancellor looks ahead to a general election next year.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Confessions', 'Sex Crimes', 'Police', 'Missing Persons']

lead_paragraph: The confession came in bits and pieces over two and a half hours. The suspect had been interrogated most of the night. Now a prosecutor and two detectives were asking him questions again with a video camera rolling.

headline: As Valeant Tumbles, So Does Bill Ackman’s Hedge Fund Herd
abstract: The crowding phenomenon comes amid a backdrop of turbulence for the hedge fund industry, where some of the biggest names have reported double-digit losses.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire investor William A. Ackman has become the unofficial leader of a thundering herd that has lost billions of dollars betting on Valeant Pharmaceuticals over the past year.

headline: Target Steps Out in Front of Bathroom Choice Debate
abstract: The retailer said transgender employees and customers could choose which restroom they preferred to use, a position that centered it in a national debate.
lead_paragraph: A new policy over bathroom choice has thrust the retailer Target into the center of a nationwide debate over gender identity, civil rights and privacy.

headline: Baltimore Officer Shoots Boy Who Police Say Had Replica Gun
abstract: The police commissioner said the boy, 13, was expected to survive the shooting, which occurred on the first anniversary of the funeral of Freddie Gray.
lead_paragraph: A plainclothes police officer shot and wounded a 13-year-old boy who was seen carrying a replica handgun as he walked down a Baltimore street on Wednesday, the city’s police commissioner said.

headline: Robert J. Cooper, 39, Creator of Popular Elderflower Liqueur, Dies
abstract: Mr. Cooper’s 2007 concoction, St-Germain, was so embraced by the cocktail crowd that it became known as “bartender’s ketchup.”
lead_paragraph: Robert J. Cooper, whose unusual elderflower liqueur, St-Germain, introduced in 2007, was so completely embraced by the cocktail community that it became known as “bartender’s ketchup,” died on Monday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 39.

headline: Rattner Drops Bid to Return to Investment Banking
abstract: He acted within weeks of the Securities and Exchange Commission’s order that cleared his path to affiliate with Guggenheim Securities.
lead_paragraph: Remember Steven L. Rattner’s return to investment banking? Never mind.

headline: Saluting Robert Shaw, a Conductor of Humanist Spirituality
abstract: On what would have been Shaw’s 100th birthday, the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and Chorus will honor him at Carnegie Hall with “A German Requiem.”
lead_paragraph: “I am not sure I ever have ‘heard’ Brahms’s ‘Requiem’ — strictly as a member of an audience,” the incomparable California-born choral conductor Robert Shaw wrote in 1997. “At this moment I can recall only performances in which I was a participant — the first, of course, as a singer.” For his many good efforts, Brahmsian and otherwise, Shaw, who died two years later, presumably now occupies some lofty angelic perch, where he can simply sit back and take in the performance of “A German Requiem” that Robert Spano will conduct with the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and Chorus at Carnegie Hall on Saturday, Shaw’s 100th birthday.

headline: Ozzie Silna, Savvy A.B.A Owner Who Got Rich Off the N.B.A., Dies at 83
abstract: A businessman who made millions off N.B.A. television contracts long after the team he co-owned with his brother, Daniel, was dissolved.
lead_paragraph: Ozzie Silna, who devised a plan that brought him and his brother more than $750 million in television money from the National Basketball Association without owning a team in that league, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 83.

headline: Baltimore Voters Choose Catherine Pugh — and Slash Her Tires
abstract: Thirteen Democrats appeared on the primary ballot for mayor. In a city in need of change, residents chose a longtime member of the political class.
lead_paragraph: Thirteen Democrats appeared on the ballot Tuesday in Baltimore’s mayoral primary elections. When the smoke cleared, Catherine Pugh, a 66-year-old state senator, had emerged as the winner, with 36.8 percent of the vote. Given the overwhelming Democratic vote in Baltimore, she’s all but guaranteed to be the city’s next mayor.

headline: After Losses, Ted Cruz Picks Carly Fiorina as Running Mate and Bernie Sanders Retrenches
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders and Senator Ted Cruz abruptly reordered their campaigns, aiming to preserve some hope of primary victories.
lead_paragraph: Reeling from their losses in Tuesday’s Democratic and Republican primaries, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas abruptly reordered their campaigns on Wednesday, aiming to preserve some small hope that the race might yet turn in their favor.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, April 28, 2016.
lead_paragraph: It’s dangerous, devastating, crippling, and it’s a killer, and still socially acceptable.

headline: Review: ‘Long Day’s Journey Into Night’ Is a Tempest in a Bourbon Bottle
abstract: The production, starring Gabriel Byrne, Jessica Lange, Michael Shannon and John Gallagher Jr., features some heavy-weather acting.
lead_paragraph: A violent storm front has moved into the American Airlines Theater, where Jonathan Kent’s static, star-packed revival of Eugene O’Neill’s “Long Day’s Journey Into Night” opened on Wednesday night, and like so much of our weather these days, it seems to be human-made. It may be the special-effects team that’s generating all that moody fog and wind. But it’s Gabriel Byrne, Jessica Lange, Michael Shannon and John Gallagher Jr. who are providing the thunder and lightning.

headline: Power Measures
abstract: Kurt Krauss points us in the right direction.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — No, you’re not crazy, especially if you’re a beginning solver. Yes, you are being asked to write backwards. And in a NORTHERly direction. But that’s O.K. You’ve been given a compass. (In most of the formats.)

headline: National Briefing
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Discrimination', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Bill Haslam signed a bill Wednesday that allows mental health counselors to refuse to treat patients based on the therapist’s religious or personal beliefs. The American Counseling Association called the legislation an “unprecedented attack” on the counseling profession and said Tennessee was the only state to ever pass such a law. Opponents say the legislation is part of a wave of bills around the nation that legalizes discrimination against gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgender people. Supporters say it protects the rights of therapists. The bill does not allow counselors to turn away people who are in imminent danger of harming themselves or others. It requires them to refer patients to other therapists if they decline to treat them.(AP)

headline: Winston Hill, Durable Lineman for ’69 Champion Jets, Is Dead at 74
abstract: Hill made eight All-Pro teams and protected the blindside of quarterback Joe Namath during the team’s only Super Bowl victory.
lead_paragraph: Winston Hill, a reliable Jets offensive lineman who made eight All-Pro teams and protected the blindside of quarterback Joe Namath during the team’s only Super Bowl victory, in 1969, died on Tuesday in Denver. He was 74.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Returns to Add Some Spark, but Yankees Fall to Rangers

lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Tex. — The Yankees did not take batting practice Wednesday, which is to say they spent only slightly less time hitting baseballs than they have in many games this season.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police']
