headline: Remembering Brooklyn Priest Who Took On City, and Ears of the Police
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A century ago, the Rev. William B. Farrell engaged in a battle with New York officials that exposed a widespread pattern of police wiretapping.
lead_paragraph: “One tough Brooklyn priest” was the subject of the day’s Mass, the Rev. Brian Jordan said, as he started his homily in the chapel of St. Francis College in Downtown Brooklyn, where he is the chaplain.

headline: N.F.L. Draft: Sometimes You Get Manning, Sometimes Ryan Leaf
abstract: With quarterbacks expected to go 1-2 in this week’s N.F.L. draft, a look at some other times that happened.
lead_paragraph: In the N.F.L. draft on Thursday night, the top two players are expected to be quarterbacks, Jared Goff of California and Carson Wentz of North Dakota State.

headline: Carl Icahn Says He Has Sold His Stake in Apple Over China Concerns
abstract: Mr. Icahn says he is worried the country’s government could make it difficult for the company to do business there.
lead_paragraph: Carl C. Icahn has sold his 45.8 million Apple shares since the start of the year, telling CNBC on Thursday that he was concerned about China’s policies regarding the technology giant while still calling the stock cheap.

headline: This Is Your Brain on Podcasts
abstract: Different people’s brains absorb a compelling story in the roughly the same complicated pattern, using many parts of the brain, researchers found.
lead_paragraph: Listening to music may make the daily commute tolerable, but streaming a story through the headphones can make it disappear. You were home; now you’re at your desk: What happened?

headline: With Errant Twitter Post, Ed Balls, a British Politician, Spawned a Holiday
abstract: Celebrated primarily in Britain, the unofficial Ed Balls Day commemorates a former member of Parliament’s tweet of his own name.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was one of the most celebrated Twitter posts in British political memory, one that has been retweeted tens of thousands of times, spawned an unofficial national holiday and inspired tributes in everything from verse to baked goods.

headline: Anatomy | ‘The Man Who Knew Infinity’
abstract: Matthew Brown narrates a sequence from his film.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Brown narrates a sequence from his film.

headline: Matthew Brown Narrates a Scene From ‘The Man Who Knew Infinity’
abstract: The writer and director discusses a sequence from his film featuring Dev Patel and Jeremy Irons.
lead_paragraph: The story of a mathematical partnership is told in the film “The Man Who Knew Infinity,” written and directed by Matthew Brown. It looks at the early 20th-century collaboration between Srinivasa Ramanujan (Mr. Patel), a shipping clerk who was in truth a mathematical genius, and G. H. Hardy, a lecturer at Trinity College at Cambridge University.

headline: Review: Rainer Werner Fassbinder’s Intense World and His Films
abstract: A fellow filmmaker examines the work of this German director from the close perspective of friendship.
lead_paragraph: “I’d like to be for cinema what William Shakespeare was for theater, Marx for politics, and Freud for psychology,” the German director Rainer Werner Fassbinder is quoted as having said in the Danish director Christian Braad Thomsen’s documentary study, “Fassbinder: To Love Without Demands.”

headline: Review: Ana Moura and Buika Negotiate Between Roots and Rules at Carnegie
abstract: The Spanish singer Buika followed the Portuguese singer Ms. Moura on Tuesday night in a double bill.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish singer Buika followed the Portuguese singer Ana Moura on Tuesday night in a double bill at Carnegie Hall, and during Buika’s set you could see something that doesn’t happen all that often: audience members walking out.

headline: Review: In ‘Viva,’ a Star Is Waiting to Be Born
abstract: A macho father released from prison decides to move in with the son he abandoned, who is a sweet-natured gay hairdresser and an aspiring drag queen.
lead_paragraph: An exhilarating hybrid of Social Realism and feel-good aspirational entertainment, Paddy Breathnach’s “Viva” is an oddity by its very pedigree: an Irish movie set in Havana, where it was filmed with a keen eye to that city’s dinginess in tropical light. It infuses a too-familiar story with so much heart that you surrender to its charm and forgive it for being unabashedly formulaic. Even its one big plot twist is hardly a surprise. At the same time, its portrait of Havana, an impoverished city of crumbling architecture, has a gritty neorealist pungency.

headline: Amazon’s Cloud Business Lifts Its Profit to a Record
abstract: Shares rose 12 percent after the company reported net income of $513 million, in contrast to last year’s loss of $57 million.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon delivered a blowout quarter on Thursday, joining Facebook as one of the rare bright spots in a technology sector that has recently produced a string of disappointing earnings reports.

headline: Why Mayor de Blasio Is Facing So Many Investigations
abstract: In recent weeks, no fewer than five separate inquiries involving Mr. de Blasio have come to light. At the heart of each of them is money.
lead_paragraph: Since the Office of the Mayor of New York was established in 1665, many of the 109 men who have served in that post have attracted their share of scrutiny from commissions, constables and prosecutors.

headline: Review: ‘Viktoria,’ a Family’s Atmospheric Voyage Through Change in Bulgaria
abstract: Maya Vitkova’s satirical film opens with the birth of a girl who is designated “baby of the decade” by the state because of her lack of a bellybutton.
lead_paragraph: Eastern Bloc decrepitude has rarely looked as lovely as it does in Maya Vitkova’s “Viktoria,” an offbeat allegorical satire that devolves into a cinematographer show reel. Shot in extra-wide screen by Krum Rodriguez, its story begins at the dawn of the 1980s in Bulgaria, where a girl is born without a bellybutton to a morose young woman against the backdrop of an infantilizing government.

headline: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, April 30 Through May 8
abstract: “Echo of Light,” oil on canvas by Doris Simon, will appear in the exhibition “Shimmering Lights” May 6 through 29 in Hudson, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: As Sharks Buckled, Goalie Martin Jones Announced His Arrival
abstract: Jones eliminated the Kings, his former team, in the first round of the N.H.L. playoffs, continuing to make the most of his first season with San Jose.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Two years of waiting for redemption came down to one moment for the San Jose Sharks.

headline: Review: ‘Transfixed,’ a Real-Life Love Story, With Complications
abstract: Alon Kol’s documentary tracks Martine and John, a couple with Asperger’s syndrome seeking to marry, as Martine hopes to undergo gender reassignment surgery.
lead_paragraph: You may need to adjust your definition of “normal” after seeing “Transfixed.” In this tender documentary, the loving couple at its center seems fairly ordinary — they’re dealing with money woes, weight gain, an impending marriage — until you step back and see that their other struggles also make them unique.

headline: Words Can Never Hurt Me? Bah!
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder', 'ADDERALL (DRUG)']
abstract: Also, baby matchmaking, a nonstop talker in the office and a tuned-out friend.
lead_paragraph: I have Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder and was prescribed Adderall, which has some side effects, including loss of appetite. My college roommate, who is one of my best friends, has made numerous comments about how “lucky” I am to be taking it because I don’t feel hungry and eat less. I know these comments come from insecurity. They started right before spring break, when she was wishing for a better body. Still, I have had a long struggle with A.D.H.D., and these comments hurt. What should I do?

headline: N.F.L. Draft 2016: Here’s What Happened
abstract: Picks, trades and analysis of the 2016 N.F.L. Draft in Chicago from New York Times reporters.

headline: Congress Opens the Door to Drafting Women
keywords: ['Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Requiring women to register for the draft would be the next step in bringing gender equality to the military.
lead_paragraph: An influential congressional committee has taken another step towards sanity and equality in military policy by voting to require women to register with the Selective Service, making them eligible for the draft if another one ever is required.

headline: Review: ‘Sacrifice’ Yields Corpses and Clichés
abstract: This thriller, directed by Peter A. Dowling and set in the Shetland Islands, relies overly on worn devices that are too often employed by the genre.
lead_paragraph: While the line “It’s quiet … too quiet” is never spoken in “Sacrifice,” this thriller trades heavily on a hoary genre convention. Directed by Peter A. Dowling, who also adapted the screenplay from Sharon Bolton’s novel, the movie features a physician, Tora Hamilton (Radha Mitchell), who moves from New York to the Shetland Islands in Scotland after a miscarriage. Her supportive partner, Duncan (Rupert Graves), hails from there, and with the help of some local residents, they intend to mend their hearts by adopting a baby in this pastoral setting.

headline: Review: ‘Ratchet & Clank,’ a Stale Tale Based on a PlayStation Game
abstract: The movie has little story to tell and few ideas to offer, but a great deal of product to sell.
lead_paragraph: Watching the generic computer-animated “Ratchet & Clank,” you’re flooded with reminders of familiar characters. The hero Ratchet — a lombax, a frisky creature with big ears and eyes, who aspires to join the Galactic Rangers, protectors of the galaxy evoking the Green Lantern Corps — has the small physique and intent expression of an evolved Sonic the Hedgehog. His brainy sidekick, the robotic Clank, resembles a diminutive take on the title character from “The Iron Giant”; his voice could be a bookwormish twist on Marvin the Martian’s.

headline: Routine Parts of de Blasio’s Day Aren’t Routine as Inquiries Swirl
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York can’t seem to escape questions about the state and federal fund-raising investigations.
lead_paragraph: He arrived through a back entrance, heading to the fourth floor for a prearranged event — on time, it might have been noted.

headline: Review: Emanuel Ax Weathers Beethoven’s Emotional Storms at Carnegie Hall
abstract: The pianist performed two popular sonatas — the “Pathétique” and the “Appassionata” — as well as three lesser-known works at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Describing a pianist’s performance as unhinged might seem like an unlikely compliment. But the adjective could be applied in the most flattering terms to Emanuel Ax’s engrossing interpretation of Beethoven’s “Pathétique” Sonata on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall.

headline: Review: Avishai Cohen Kicks Off Tour With a Set Both Turbocharged and Ghostly
abstract: Mr. Cohen, who performed at the Jazz Standard, has a new album, “Into the Silence,” created in memory of his father.
lead_paragraph: During a mesmerizing stretch of Avishai Cohen’s first set at the Jazz Standard on Wednesday night, his band fell quiet and he pointed the bell of his trumpet into the belly of the club’s piano. As he played a slow cadenza in a controlled high register, each note arriving as a clarion event, the sympathetic vibrations of the piano soundboard produced a shimmer of ghostly overtones, and a sort of pressurized hush.

headline: Good for Porzingis? Then Carmelo Anthony Is Good for the Knicks
abstract: Jeff Van Gundy, the commentator and former Knicks coach, has a good argument for not totally rebuilding around Kristaps Porzingis.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Van Gundy was speaking in his characteristically outspoken role as a television commentator, not as a reported candidate for the remaining N.B.A. head coaching vacancies, excluding the one in New York. He was in no way endorsing Phil Jackson as an accomplished Knicks president or Carmelo Anthony as a championship-level franchise player.

headline: Review: Jay Armstrong Johnson and Friends Wax Ebullient
abstract: His cabaret show united over a dozen musicians in a passionate generational camaraderie at Feinstein’s/54 Below.
lead_paragraph: The musical-theater world has always exhibited an enthusiastic community solidarity. But among Broadway aspirants in their 20s and early 30s, there’s an ebullient joie de vivre that has less to do with shared dreams of stardom than with generational camaraderie. That mood pervaded Wednesday’s opening night performance of Jay Armstrong Johnson’s cabaret show at Feinstein’s/54 Below, a sprawling musical potpourri that involved well over a dozen musicians, backup vocalists and guests.

headline: Review: ‘Pali Road’ Blends Romance and Suspense
abstract: Although the acting can be wooden at times, ‘Pali Road’ is a decent film set in a gorgeous locale.
lead_paragraph: “Pali Road” is a decent romantic thriller with an uncredited co-star: the state of Hawaii, where it was filmed. The acting is on the wooden side, but the scenery is gorgeous.

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic Presents a World Premiere
abstract: Franck Krawczyk’s “Après” pays homage to Bach, Mozart and Beethoven in a textured 18-minute work.
lead_paragraph: When the New York Philharmonic awarded the first Marie-Josée Kravis Prize for New Music to Henri Dutilleux in 2011, it became a gift that would keep on giving. Dutilleux, who was then 95 and died in 2013, decided to share the $200,000 proceeds with worthy younger composers of his choosing, in effect commissioning them to write for the Philharmonic.

headline: Review: ‘Papa: Hemingway in Cuba,’ a Mild Voyage With the Old Man and ‘the Kid’
abstract: In Bob Yari’s autobiographical film, a young Miami journalist’s fan letter leads to a fishing trip and a long friendship with his literary hero.
lead_paragraph: At first, it strains credulity. In the late 1950s, just as rebellion is smoldering in Cuba, a reporter in Miami is laboring over a letter to his literary idol. Then, before you can say “The Old Man and the Sea,” the reporter, Ed Myers (Giovanni Ribisi), is whisked away to Cuba for a fishing trip with his hero, Ernest Hemingway. His adventure begins on a dock as Papa himself floats into view, commanding the flying bridge of his boat like a Roman charioteer.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, April 30 Through May 8
abstract: The musician Nile Rodgers will appear with the author Elizabeth Gilbert and the choreographer Bill T. Jones in a conversation about creativity, moderated by the journalist Alison Stewart, on May 13 in Hartford, Conn.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Mother’s Day’ Is a Goopy, Glossy Sentimental Mess
abstract: Jennifer Aniston, Kate Hudson and Julia Roberts star in this holiday-themed film that generates inadvertent laughs and has predictable plotlines.
lead_paragraph: The unofficial conclusion of an unofficial trilogy of holiday-themed multistar comedy vehicles directed by Garry Marshall, “Mother’s Day” has its perfunctory heart exactly where any experienced viewer would expect it to be. That is, in a fantasy world where, among other things, one older mother’s lifetime of bigotry can be cured by half an afternoon spent with a mixed-race child.

headline: Review: Exploring Domestic Drudgery in ‘Play, Thing’
abstract: The choreographer Heather Kravas extends her passion for repetitive movement and simple props in this piece at the Chocolate Factory.
lead_paragraph: In January, the choreographer Heather Kravas presented her aggressively stringent solo “dead, disappears,” in which she walked on her toes with her head covered by a garbage bag, urinated in a bucket and beat a pillow, duct-taped to a chair, with a pole. For her new “play, thing,” she extends her passion for repetitive movement and simple props with more dancers — six in total — who execute three independent, converging duets. It has a twin theme. The pillow is back, but this time there are two.

headline: Review: ‘Dough,’ a Sweet but Pat Tale of Bridging Religious and Racial Differences
abstract: Jonathan Pryce and Jerome Holder star in this feature about an elderly Jewish baker in London who ends up hiring a young black Muslim as his assistant.
lead_paragraph: Take an aging white Jewish baker, add a young black Muslim immigrant, and what do you have? The ingredients for a pleasant but pat story in which bridges are built across religious, racial and generational divides in a way that happens far more often in feel-good movies than in real life.

headline: Picturing America in the Selfie Age, at the Whitney
abstract: The breadth and depth of what a portrait can be are explored in an exhibition that takes in a dazzling range of mediums and messages.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, the Whitney Museum of American Art inaugurated its new downtown home with a permanent-collection showcase called “America Is Hard to See.” Its successor, the even more immediately engaging “Human Interest: Portraits From the Whitney’s Collection,” is now on view. Astutely geared to the selfie age, it might well have been subtitled “Americans Are Strange to Look At,” which, in the 250 images here, we sure are: funny-strange, beautiful-strange, crazy-strange, dangerous-strange, inscrutable-strange.

headline: The Week in Pictures: April 29
abstract: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

headline: Obama’s Visit Casts ‘Brexit’ Vote in Stark Relief
abstract: Britain’s yes-no referendum on leaving the E.U. has created an existential choice that is dividing the nation at its core.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For travelers returning to London from distant places struggling for bare-bones survival, the portals of passport control sometimes resemble what a British writer likened to the looking glass in Lewis Carroll’s fable of Alice.

headline: Things to Do in New Jersey, April 30 through May 8
abstract: The saxophonist Boney James will perform on May 5 in Englewood, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: ‘Bourek,’ About a Group of Drifting Souls
abstract: Assorted characters on an island bicker and lounge against a backdrop of news reports heralding social and financial catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: “Bourek,” which takes its title from a flaky Mediterranean pastry, is described in the publicity notes, somewhat optimistically, as a comedy. Viewers, however, are unlikely to be more than marginally amused by its fair-to-middling acting, enervated plot and forcibly diverse group of drifting souls gathered on the fictional Greek island of Khronos.

headline: Dark Money and an I.R.S. Blindfold
abstract: A bill under consideration could open the doors for secret foreign contributions to American political campaigns.
lead_paragraph: It is plainly illegal for foreigners to contribute to American political campaigns. But reform groups are warning that the ban would be gravely undermined by a little-noticed bill advanced Thursday by Republicans on the House Ways and Means Committee.

headline: ‘The Bad-Ass Librarians of Timbuktu,’ by Joshua Hammer
abstract: The story of the man who defied Al Qaeda to protect his nation’s cultural heritage.
lead_paragraph: THE BAD-ASS LIBRARIANS OF TIMBUKTUAnd Their Race to Save the World’s Most Precious ManuscriptsBy Joshua Hammer278 pp. Simon & Schuster. $26.

headline: Review: ‘The American Side,’ a Hard-Boiled Noir Set in Buffalo
abstract: A private investigator, a murdered stripper, a mystery and a reverent throwback to the spirit of Mickey Spillane.
lead_paragraph: Judging from “The American Side,” detectives who say things like “that’s a gene pool screaming for chlorine” and “there’s a joker in every deck” have spent the past several decades hiding in Buffalo — not an obvious graveyard for the spirits of Raymond Chandler and Mickey Spillane.

headline: Review: ‘A Beautiful Planet’ Shows a Dazzling Earth From Space
abstract: Images of the planet, and even mundane tasks, take on a fascinating quality in this documentary shot by astronauts aboard the International Space Station.
lead_paragraph: You already know the big scenes will be awe-inspiring in “A Beautiful Planet” — how can your eyes not bug out when given 3-D views of Earth, taken from space, on a stories-high Imax screen? What’s surprising is how enjoyable the small moments are in this documentary, filmed aboard the International Space Station.

headline: MetLiveArts Series Features Podcaster as Artist in Residence
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art announces a season with Nate DiMeo of “The Memory Palace” and PubliQuartet as quartet in residence for 2016-17.
lead_paragraph: Podcasts have become fixtures of commutes and working hours, but they’re entering museums, too. Nate DiMeo, creator of the podcast “The Memory Palace,” will be the 2016-17 artist in residence at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: Ted Cruz, Donald Trump, N.F.L.
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: In ‘Older Than Ireland,’ Centenarians Recall Early and Latter Days
abstract: Thirty wry old-timers are impressive raconteurs in this documentary directed by Alex Fegan, released during the centenary of the Easter Rising.
lead_paragraph: “A terrible beauty is born,” Yeats wrote in his poem “Easter 1916,” about Ireland’s fight for independence from the British. But the 30 centenarians facing the camera in Alex Fegan’s delightful documentary “Older Than Ireland” are simply beautiful: frail, yes, but wise, wry, flinty, funny and sometimes very tender. All were born before the Easter Rising, an event widely celebrated this year that sparked the explosion in patriotism that ultimately led to the founding of the Irish Republic.

headline: Review: Ingenious Versatility in the Whitney’s ‘Open Plan’
abstract: Steve McQueen, the Oscar-winning director, is the fifth and final artist to inhabit the spacious fifth floor in the museum’s “Open Plan” exhibition.
lead_paragraph: For the last two months, the Whitney Museum of American Art has been highlighting the genius of the spacious fifth floor in its grand new downtown Renzo Piano building. The method of illumination is “Open Plan,” a rapid succession of five very different exhibitions ranging from four to 17 days long. In each case, an artist, working closely with a Whitney curator or curatorial team, was given the run of the space, unfettered by interior walls.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: ‘The Man Who Knew Infinity’ Gives a Mathematical Genius His Due
abstract: This film centers on Srinivasa Ramanujan, a brilliant mathematician from India, and his unlikely friendship with the Cambridge professor G.H. Hardy.
lead_paragraph: It’s time for Dev Patel to add fresh paints to his palette. This talented actor — who got his feature start in Danny Boyle’s “Slumdog Millionaire” — has largely specialized in handsome, earnest and well-meaning characters (in both “Best Exotic Marigold Hotel” movies and the canceled HBO series “The Newsroom”). Now comes “The Man Who Knew Infinity,” Matthew Brown’s respectful and, yes, earnest biopic about the early-20th-century mathematician Srinivasa Ramanujan, who found the divine in integers. Ramanujan, who was mentored by the Cambridge professor G. H. Hardy, eventually became the first Indian to hold a fellowship at Trinity College.

headline: Theater Listings for April 29-May 5
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.

headline: My Grandfather Was a Famous Artist. He Also Made Greeting Cards.
abstract: A show revisits a company that sold art to ordinary Americans — and sheds light on a writer’s family history.
lead_paragraph: TWO brawny construction workers perch on a plank dangerously suspended hundreds of feet off the ground in “Men of Steel,” a print that hangs in an exhibition at New York University’s Grey Art Gallery. The men are heroic figures intent on their task — bolting a horizontal beam to a column.

headline: Review: Sex, Death and Little Subtlety
abstract: The artist Andra Ursuta connects competitive masculinity and death in an ambitious and heavy-handed exhibition at the New Museum.
lead_paragraph: Sex, death, sports and feminism animate “Alps,” an ambitious exhibition by Andra Ursuta occupying the New Museum’s fourth floor. Despite the potential metaphorical heat, these themes are muffled by a heavy-handed, academic intellectualism.

headline: Comedy Listings for April 29-May 5
abstract: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to stand-up, improv and comedy shows in New York City.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Shifting Tone, Takes On Democratic Party
abstract: The Vermont senator laid out in more detail than usual his views for shaping the Democratic Party’s agenda and the need for elected officials to focus on more progressive politics.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders spent Thursday afternoon laying out in more detail than usual his views for shaping the Democratic Party’s agenda and the need for elected officials to focus on achieving progressive political goals.

headline: Unpaid Annual Taxes Rise to $458 Billion, I.R.S. Reports
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Tax Evasion', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The agency attributed the increase to better estimates, but Senator Orrin G. Hatch called for it “to get smarter about guaranteeing tax compliance.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Potentially giving congressional Republicans new ammunition in their crusade against the Internal Revenue Service, the agency on Thursday said that annual unpaid taxes had increased to nearly half a trillion dollars.

headline: Review: ‘L’Attesa’ (‘The Wait’) Turns Life Into a Ghost Story
abstract: Juliette Binoche stars as the mother of a young man who has just been killed, and Lou de Laâge plays his girlfriend, who doesn’t know.
lead_paragraph: “L’Attesa” (“The Wait”), Piero Messina’s debut feature, is an elegant melodrama of maternal grief with overtones of horror, a psychological rather than a supernatural ghost story. Set in Sicily around Easter, the film partakes freely of religious imagery to add gravity and mystery to its domestic tale of loss, longing and deceit. The landscape — volcanic rock and quiet forests surrounding a sparkling lake — is captured in long, wide takes, a beauty surpassed only by close-ups of the two lead actresses, Juliette Binoche and Lou de Laâge.

headline: Movie Listings for April 29-May 5
abstract: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.
lead_paragraph: A guide to movies playing at theaters in the New York City area, as well as select festivals and film series.

headline: MoMA Galleries to Change Their Focus
keywords: ['Art', 'Museums', 'ARMORY SHOW, THE INTERNATIONAL FAIR OF NEW ART (NYC)']
abstract: The Modern reworks its second-floor galleries; a new vision for the Armory Show; a 450-medal gift to the Frick; and a School of London show.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art is changing things yet again. After reinstalling the fourth-floor permanent collection — devoted to works from 1940 to 1980 — MoMA, beginning in June, will radically rework its second-floor contemporary galleries by dividing them into three distinct spaces, each with a major installation from the collection focused on a single artist.

headline: Review: Kidman and Bateman Face Childhood Scars in ‘The Family Fang’
abstract: In this adaptation of Kevin Wilson’s novel, siblings grapple with memories of an upbringing spent being used as artistic props by their parents.
lead_paragraph: The drama of the gifted child is, at least in movies, a gift that keeps on giving. That’s particularly true in American independent cinema, with its stories of suffering children, monstrous mothers and abusive fathers. There are moments when it feels as if the movie you’re watching was written on a laptop propped up by a Syd Field screenwriting book and “The Drama of the Gifted Child,” Alice Miller’s 1979 book about children and parental narcissism. Act 1: Set up the wound. Act 2: Confront the wound. Act 3: Resolve the wound.

headline: Dressed to Kill: The Power of Leopard Prints
abstract: Jo Weldon, a longtime observer of people who wear clothes made of big-cat patterns, will discuss her research in a lecture at the Morbid Anatomy Museum.
lead_paragraph: For three decades, the burlesque performance expert Jo Weldon has studied why people wear clothes made of leopard patterns. She has concluded that in the last few centuries spotted-cat motifs have been used to attract attention and exude power, ferocity, independence, sophistication, sensuality and sometimes outright debauchery.

headline: Impurity in the Pursuit of Salvation Is No Vice
abstract: More about carbon taxes.
lead_paragraph: David Roberts continues his carbon tax series. First he argued that such a tax isn’t the be-all and end-all of climate policy; he concludes with a discussion of the political economy, and argues that a carbon tax should be sold as part of a package, with the revenue dedicated to things like clean energy promotion.

headline: Classical Music Listings for April 29-May 5
abstract: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to performances of classical music in the New York City area.

headline: Returning to Their Cuban Roots
abstract: Young Cuban-Americans try to bridge generational and geographical gaps.
lead_paragraph: For decades, many exiles refused to set foot on Cuba while the Castros were in power. Increasingly, though, their children want to explore their roots and play a constructive role in a homeland that loomed large during their upbringing but was relatively inaccessible until recently.

headline: Things to Do on Long Island, April 30 Through May 8
abstract: The musician and producer Nile Rodgers presents a master class on songwriting, guitar playing and the music industry, on May 7 in Riverhead, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: Review: Eugene Von Bruenchenhein, ‘King of Lesser Lands’
abstract: Now considered one of America’s great self-taught artists, Mr. Von Bruenchenhein created diverse works that remained largely unknown until after his death.
lead_paragraph: Eugene Von Bruenchenhein (1910-1983) made doughnuts in a Milwaukee bakery. Otherwise he lived and worked in an enchanted world of art and fantasy that he ruled with his wife, Marie, in a small, clapboard house. There he produced a large and varied oeuvre of paintings, drawings, sculptures and photographs that remained unknown to all but his family and friends until a few months after his death. Now he’s considered one of America’s great self-taught artists. This inspiring exhibition at Andrew Edlin samples his diverse efforts.

headline: Review: David Claerbout’s Video Art via Video Games
abstract: Five moving-image works by Mr. Claerbout are featured in the exhibition “Light/Work,” at Sean Kelly.
lead_paragraph: Video games emerged in the early 1980s, a decade after video art, but the games’ impact on the form has been moderate, compared with their powerful influence on feature filmmaking. David Claerbout, though, is among the artists who have adopted gaming techniques, which you can see clearly in “Light/Work,” this Belgian-born artist’s first exhibition at Sean Kelly.

headline: Pop & Rock Listings for April 29-May 5
abstract: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to concerts in the New York City area.

headline: Review: Ryan Nord Kitchen: Small Abstracts, Big Impact
abstract: The 28-year-old artist’s first solo show in New York, “Winter Paintings,” features works that have wonderful palettes and exude a tossed-off charm.
lead_paragraph: Modernism has a substantial tradition of small abstract paintings — paintings that normal people, those lacking private museums or vast real-estate acreage — can live with. This tradition includes many artists, among them, Paul Klee, Wassily Kandinsky (late), Alice Trumbull Mason and Myron Stout. The painter Bill Jensen revived it in New York in the early 1970s, as did, it seems, the Belgian Raoul De Keyser in Europe. Some current practitioners include Tomma Abts, Ann Pibal, EJ Hauser and Etel Adnan.

headline: Review: ‘Special Correspondents’ Stars a Fumbling Ricky Gervais
abstract: The movie, on Netflix, also stars Eric Bana and is an adaptation of a French comedy about a radio reporter and his sound engineer.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you’ve been waiting for Ricky Gervais to write and direct a completely conventional comedy, the kind that begins with slow-motion nighttime pans of the New York skyline and ends with the nebbishy hero and his nerdy love interest walking off toward the horizon. In that extremely unlikely event, you’ll want to check out “Special Correspondents,” available Friday around the world on Netflix.

headline: Jazz Listings for April 29-May 5
abstract: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to jazz performances in New York City.

headline: Baltimore Police Wound Costumed Man After TV Station Standoff
keywords: ['Bombs and Explosives', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The police shot an unidentified man carrying a mock explosive device that included candy bars connected by wires.
lead_paragraph: The police on Thursday shot and wounded a costumed 25-year-old man after a standoff at a Baltimore television station, where the man said that he was carrying a bomb and demanded that a message be broadcast. The police opened fire on the man, officials said, because he refused to comply with the instructions of officers.

headline: Lincoln Center Drafts Children as Detectives for Its Meet Me at the Fountain Series
abstract: Young people will be invited to help foil a would-be saboteur of a musical sound system as part of the center’s immersive Meet Me at the Fountain series.
lead_paragraph: An internationally renowned soprano is about to make her operatic debut at Lincoln Center. But a determined enemy of artistic excellence wants to destroy her voice. He would render her singing so awful that you’d probably rather listen to Gilbert Gottfried.

headline: Review: Attraction and Repulsion in ‘Les Vaisseaux’
abstract: Kimberly Bartosik’s new work, at Gibney Dance: Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center, evokes the distance between two lovers close enough to touch.
lead_paragraph: “Étroits Sont les Vaisseaux,” the title of Kimberly Bartosik’s new dance, means “Narrow Are the Vessels” in French. And the ground-level studio of Gibney Dance: Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center, where the work made its debut on Wednesday, is indeed a narrow space. Entering it, audience members brush past the piece’s two striking performers, Joanna Kotze and Lance Gries, who are never farther than a few steps from the ring of seats and often close enough to touch.

headline: Dance Listings for April 29-May 5
abstract: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.
lead_paragraph: A selected guide to dance performances in New York City.

headline: Two Momentous Occasions in New York History
abstract: The opening day of the New York World’s Fair and what would be Lou Gehrig’s last game at Yankee Stadium (though the crowd didn’t know it yet).
lead_paragraph: It was April 30, 1939, a sunny Sunday, and New Yorkers were out in force for two history-making occasions.

headline: Museum & Gallery Listings for April 29-May 5
abstract: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.
lead_paragraph: A critical guide to exhibitions and installations in the New York area.

headline: Review: Tillie’s Brings Farm to Table in Short Hills
abstract: The menu is built around local ingredients with some rare finds like a filet of Long Island sea trout.
lead_paragraph: Luckily for all, reviewers get to return to a restaurant before they render a verdict.

lead_paragraph: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.

headline: Review: Nikkei of Peru Offers Dishes Inspired by a Japanese Diaspora
abstract: The restaurant, in Port Washington, offers light, fresh and inventive Japanese cuisine with Peruvian flair.
lead_paragraph: Some younger readers will find it hard to believe, but there was actually a time when sushi restaurants were considered exotic and chic. By now, though, the formula has grown tired: the black-lacquered furniture, the kitschy music, the watery miso soup (free!), the obligatory tuna roll. It’s a blueprint in need of a swift kick.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for April 29-May 5
abstract: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.
lead_paragraph: A select guide to cultural events for children, teenagers and families.

headline: Review: In Mount Kisco, Kebabs With or Without the Shish
abstract: The décor isn’t fancy, but the Turk offers a wide range of kebabs and other Mediterranean delights.
lead_paragraph: After a complete renovation of an old corner spot in Mount Kisco, the Turk restaurant has emerged, adding a menu of kebabs and other Middle Eastern items to the city’s roster of international cuisines.

headline: Review: Harlan Publick in Norwalk Offers New Tastes With an Old Flavor
abstract: A gastro pub offers modern fare in a building that has the feel of an old brewery.
lead_paragraph: Although the building housing Harlan Publick, off Washington Street in Norwalk, is relatively new, its interior has the feel of an old brewery, with its exposed pipes and high industrial ceilings.

headline: Obama Lobbies for an Appreciation of His Legacy
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: In interviews, the president stresses big achievements without big mistakes. But a low-key approach and public perceptions are hampering him.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama eases into the stocktaking stretch of his presidency, he has begun to unburden himself to select journalists. But the president’s tone is less reflective than frustrated that the American public does not see his achievements the way he does.

headline: National Briefing
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Law and Legislation', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: The longtime girlfriend of the Boston gangster James “Whitey” Bulger was sentenced on Thursday to an additional 21 months in prison for refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating whether other people had helped him while he was a fugitive. The woman, Catherine Greig, 65, was already serving an eight-year sentence for helping Mr. Bulger while he was a fugitive. She spent 16 years on the run with him before they were captured in Santa Monica, Calif., in 2011. Prosecutors said Ms. Greig refused to answer questions before the grand jury even after she was given immunity and was ordered to testify. Mr. Bulger, 86, is serving a life sentence after being convicted in 2013 for playing a role in 11 murders. (AP)

headline: Robert Linton, Steadfast ’80s Wall Street Banker, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Linton’s Drexel firm pioneered the junk bond industry and came to symbolize the era’s “greed is good” mentality, until it was swept into a federal inquiry.
lead_paragraph: Robert E. Linton, a prominent Wall Street executive who led the swashbuckling investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert in the years before it imploded in scandal but who was largely untainted himself, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 90.

headline: Iran Hints at Retaliation Over U.S. Use of Seized Assets
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Assets, Frozen', 'United States International Relations', 'Reparations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A letter to the United Nations secretary general by Iran’s foreign minister was among the most strident yet in a steadily increasing display of anger.
lead_paragraph: Iran escalated its invective against the United States on Thursday over the court-ordered use of nearly $2 billion in seized Iranian central bank assets to compensate American victims of terrorist attacks overseas, calling the action “an outrageous robbery” and threatening unspecified retaliation.

headline: Rams Select Jared Goff With No. 1 Pick in N.F.L. Draft
abstract: The selection of the quarterback from California is the latest move by a team trying to re-establish itself in Southern California after two decades in St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Los Angeles Rams chose quarterback Jared Goff of California with the first overall pick in the N.F.L. draft, the latest move by a team trying to re-establish itself in Southern California after two decades in St. Louis.

headline: Obama-Netanyahu Rift Impedes U.S. Offer of Record Aid Deal for Israel
keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama has proposed the largest package of military aid ever provided by the United States, but Israel has insisted on more generous terms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama has proposed granting Israel the largest package of military aid ever provided by the United States to another nation, but he and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu remain deeply at odds over a figure for the assistance despite months of negotiations.

headline: The Chrysler 200, Symbol of a Comeback, Slowly Fades Away
abstract: Production of a midsize car that once starred in a Chrysler commercial is winding down, and the plant where it was made will soon be making pickups.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — IT was the car that symbolized Chrysler’s comeback from bankruptcy, and the star of its iconic Super Bowl ad five years ago that played up vehicles “imported from Detroit.”

headline: Street Homelessness Fell 12% in New York City, Survey Finds
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio attributed the decrease to progress in moving homeless people into shelters, but advocates have long questioned the count’s credibility.
lead_paragraph: Citing progress in moving homeless people off the street and into shelters, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Thursday that an annual survey had found a 12 percent drop in the number of people living without shelter in New York City compared with 2015.

headline: University in Turmoil Over Scalia Tribute and Koch Role
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Law Schools', 'Names, Organizational', 'Grants (Corporate and Foundation)']
abstract: The planned renaming of a law school after Justice Antonin Scalia is creating worries among faculty and students that the public university is becoming an ideological outpost.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For years, students and faculty at George Mason University paid little attention as Charles G. Koch and other conservatives helped transform their once sleepy commuter school in the suburbs of the nation’s capital into a leading producer of free-market scholarship. The effort, after all, was focused on a few specific departments like economics and law and attracted little attention outside conservative circles.

headline: Video Review: Hyundai Elantra Offers Fewer Curves, but a Better Ride
abstract: The 2017 model addresses problems with steering, road noise and a lack of structure in its 2016 counterpart.
lead_paragraph: AROUND six years ago, Hyundai figured a 10-year warranty was not enough to attract shoppers and conjured up daring design for more attention. Sonata was the first to get the Fluidic Sculpture makeover, but the fifth-generation Elantra ended up being the swoopiest of the fleet. Hyundai’s newest gamble? Toning down those curves.

headline: Faulting de Blasio for Walking a Beaten Path in Elections
abstract: A state election official has accused the mayor and his allies of “willful and flagrant” campaign finance violations, but the illegality she suggests doesn’t necessarily exist.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio, currently in the Pigpen phase of his mayoralty, with clouds hovering everywhere he goes, did not lay the pipes that carry unlimited cash to candidates for the State Legislature.

headline: Out of Office, Ex-Speaker John Boehner Gleefully Releases Mute Button
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: As a former House speaker, Mr. Boehner can go public with insults he usually leveled behind closed doors, as he did in talking about Senator Ted Cruz.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John A. Boehner never minced words as House speaker, but he usually leveled his insults behind closed doors. Now a private citizen, Mr. Boehner is going public, and the results can be spectacular.

headline: Suit Accuses New York Times Executives of Bias
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Age, Chronological', 'Women and Girls', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: Two women in the advertising department accuse the chief executive of The Times and a vice president of race, age and gender bias.
lead_paragraph: Two women filed a federal lawsuit on Thursday against The New York Times, its chief executive and its chief revenue officer, saying that the company “has been engaging in deplorable discrimination.”

headline: Company Behind ‘American Idol’ Files for Bankruptcy Protection
abstract: The company, Core Media Group, cited declining ratings and the loss of broadcasting fees and sponsors as among the reasons for the Chapter 11 filing.
lead_paragraph: Core Media Group, the company behind the television shows “American Idol” and “So You Think You Can Dance,” filed for bankruptcy protection on Thursday.

headline: Julie Johnston Takes On the World, and the Fight Over Pay
abstract: Johnston, the young United States soccer star, is among the players pushing to see pay disparities between the men’s and women’s national teams addressed.
lead_paragraph: Julie Johnston had made only a dozen appearances for the United States women’s national team when she started its opening game at the Women’s World Cup last summer. She wound up starting all seven as the Americans won the title. Less than a year later, Johnston is a world champion, an Olympic gold medal favorite and as much of a fixture on the national team as Carli Lloyd, Alex Morgan and Hope Solo. Johnston, who turned 24 earlier this month, spoke with The New York Times on Thursday about equal pay, the responsibilities that fight entails and her future on the team.

headline: Donald Trump’s Gender-Based Attacks on Hillary Clinton Have Calculated Risk
abstract: Mr. Trump, the Republican favorite, has already proved willing to attack Mrs. Clinton in ways that many women find sexist and that her supporters consider out of bounds.
lead_paragraph: With the nation on the verge of a presidential election between the first woman to lead a major party and an opponent accused of misogyny, Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump are digging in for a fight in which he is likely to attack her precisely because she is a woman.

headline: Ford Doubles Profits for the Best Quarter in Its History
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Automobiles', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks']
abstract: Low gasoline prices are helping automakers sell more large, higher-profit vehicles, and Ford’s redesigned F-150 is a big hit.
lead_paragraph: The combination of low gasoline prices and record auto sales in the United States is making for good times in the auto industry, and nowhere is that more evident than at Ford Motor.

headline: Health Care Companies See Scale as the Only Way to Compete
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Deals worth over $40 billion were announced Thursday as companies teamed up to become leading providers and gain clout to negotiate with hospitals and insurers.
lead_paragraph: A spate of deals on Thursday showed that health care companies are convinced, regardless of tax benefits, that bigger is not only better, it is necessary.

headline: Jason Terry’s Last Lesson in Chemistry for Distracted Rockets
abstract: With the Rockets’ dysfunctional season teetering on a cliff, Terry rallied the Rockets to prolong their series against the Warriors, if only a couple of days.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Jason Terry had learned enough from 114 career playoff games and had seen enough in 17 N.B.A. seasons to know that his teammates could use a motivational boost against the Golden State Warriors. More than anything, he realized that he and his teammates had nothing to lose — nothing, that is, except another game.

headline: DreamWorks Animation’s Hits — and Misses
abstract: DreamWorks Animation is selling itself to Comcast, putting an end to an independent creative endeavor that brought “Shrek,” “Kung-Fu Panda” and “Madagascar” to the big screen — but also had its share of flops.
lead_paragraph: DreamWorks Animation is selling itself to Comcast, putting an end to an independent creative endeavor that brought “Shrek,” “Kung-Fu Panda” and “Madagascar” to the big screen — but also had its share of flops.

headline: New Jersey Representative, Citing Fraud, Calls on Congress to Investigate FEMA
abstract: Representative Tom MacArthur said the agency’s process to re-examine insurance claims from Hurricane Sandy, following allegations of fraud, was itself plagued by fraud.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A representative from New Jersey called on Thursday for a congressional investigation into the Federal Emergency Management Agency’s flood insurance program, alleging that wrongdoing by the agency had prevented thousands of victims of Hurricane Sandy from receiving the payouts they were entitled to in order to rebuild.

headline: Jenny Diski, Author Who Wrote of Madness and Isolation, Dies at 68
abstract: Ms. Diski’s novels included “Skating to Antarctica,“ “Stranger on a Train: Daydreaming and Smoking Around America With Interruptions” and “Rainforest.”
lead_paragraph: Jenny Diski, a British writer who channeled the turmoil of her early years, which included suicide attempts and confinement in mental hospitals, into a stream of richly observed and mordant novels, memoirs and essays, died on Thursday at her home in Cambridge, England. She was 68.

headline: Willie L. Williams, Head of 2 Police Forces in Turmoil, Dies at 72
abstract: Mr. Williams was the first African-American to lead the police in Philadelphia, where he made progress, and in Los Angeles, where he faced conflicts.
lead_paragraph: Willie L. Williams, the first African-American to lead the police forces in Philadelphia and Los Angeles, cities in which hostilities between the police and black citizens had recently flared into violence, died on Tuesday at his home in Fayetteville, Ga. He was 72.

headline: Laremy Tunsil Falls in N.F.L. Draft After Apparent Drug Video Surfaces
abstract: The Mississippi offensive tackle was expected to be a top-five pick before a video of him smoking what might have been marijuana was posted on his Twitter account.
lead_paragraph: It was the bong hit that sent N.F.L. teams running.

headline: Review: ‘Shuffle Along’ Returns to Broadway’s Embrace
abstract: It shares its name and most of its song list with a landmark musical from 1921, so is it old or new?
lead_paragraph: So just what is it, this tart and sweet, bubbly and flat, intoxicating and sobering concoction being dispensed from the stage of the Music Box Theater? “Shuffle Along,” which opened with a whoop and a sigh on Thursday night, has been suffering from an identity crisis in the weeks leading up to the announcement of the Tony Award nominations.

headline: Shot Putter’s Supply
abstract: Andrew Kingsley makes his New York Times debut.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — Now this is a fun way to enter our solving weekend. This Times debut puzzle by Andrew Kingsley has some great stuff in it. The price you will have to pay to see that great stuff is that you will have to be more careful and think more about what you enter.

headline: White Powder Mailed to Donald Trump’s Campaign Office Deemed No Threat
abstract: The substance, which investigators were still trying to identify, had been mailed to Trump Tower, where a campaign staff member immediately called the police after discovering it.
lead_paragraph: A white powder that was discovered at the campaign office of Donald J. Trump at the Trump Tower in Midtown Manhattan on Thursday night was not a threat, the authorities said.

headline: Planned Parenthood Gunman Mentally Unfit for Trial, Experts Testify
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'ABORTION']
abstract: Psychologists told a Colorado court on Thursday that Robert L. Dear Jr., on trial for the Nov. 27 clinic attack, is delusional. The judge delayed his ruling.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo. — Robert L. Dear Jr. thought “the feds” had been after him for 20 years, cutting holes in his clothes and planting a listening device in his pickup truck. He believed President Obama was the Antichrist, and that the Planned Parenthood center he admitted firing on in November was the most evil place in the world.

headline: Vijay Mallya, Indian ‘King of Good Times,’ Dethroned by Debt
abstract: The beer-and-airline magnate left the country ahead of creditors, as bad corporate loans hurt the economy and Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s agenda.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Three months before he left India with $1.4 billion in unpaid bills hanging over his head, the man who called himself the King of Good Times gave a party for himself.

headline: In Eli Apple, Giants Add a Defensive Force With 10th Pick
abstract: Every N.F.L. team endlessly plans for the first night of the league’s draft. They consider numerous possibilities for how teams picking before them.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Nearly every N.F.L. team ceaselessly plans for the first night of the league’s draft, trying to anticipate every possible outcome of the teams picking before them. Teams also assess any conceivable off-the-field issue besmirching a top prospect’s worthiness, just in case that player is available when it is their turn to make a first-round selection.

headline: Jets Take Darron Lee, the Latest in a Long Line of Defensive Picks
abstract: The Jets’ draft philosophy, as explained by General Manager Mike Maccagnan, is not to let decisions be swayed by needs.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets’ draft philosophy, as explained by General Manager Mike Maccagnan, is not to let decisions be swayed by needs. If he were to factor them into his evaluations, it could skew the process, and so, Maccagnan has said, he adheres to his board and does not deviate.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The White House on Friday moved to bar federal agencies from asking applicants for tens of thousands of government jobs about their criminal histories until the very end of the process.

headline: John Kasich Tells Oregon Voters His Wife Agreed: Keep Going

lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Gov. John Kasich was helping his wife carry some clothes to the basement of their home in Ohio on Wednesday when they broached the subject that many Republicans have been wondering about.

headline: Pick-by-Pick Analysis of the N.F.L. Draft's First Round
abstract: The first round of the 2016 N.F.L. Draft started the way most people expected it to — with quarterbacks going Nos. 1 and 2 — but turned into a surprising mix of controversy, trades and questionable picks. Here’s what happened.
lead_paragraph: The first round of the 2016 N.F.L. Draft started the way most people expected it to — with quarterbacks going Nos. 1 and 2 — but turned into a surprising mix of controversy, trades and questionable picks. Here’s what happened.

headline: North Korea Sentences American to 10 Years for Spying, Reports Say
abstract: Kim Dong-chul is the latest United States citizen to receive a harsh sentence in North Korea, which often uses the fates of held Americans as leverage.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — An American who has been held in North Korea since October was sentenced to 10 years of hard labor on Friday for spying and other offenses, news agencies reported from Pyongyang, the North Korean capital.

abstract: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.
lead_paragraph: Photos from The New York Times and photographers from around the world.

headline: The Racist Roots of a Way to Sell Homes
abstract: An unfair and predatory practice has made a comeback.
lead_paragraph: From the 1930s through the 1960s, most African-Americans could not get mortgages because the government had deemed neighborhoods where they lived ineligible for federal mortgage insurance, the Depression-era innovation that made mortgages widely affordable.

headline: Don’t Abandon America’s Afghan Helpers
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Translation and Interpreters', 'Visas', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Thousands of Afghan interpreters who have applied for resettlement in the United States could be left in the lurch if a defense bill is not amended.
lead_paragraph: The House Armed Services Committee approved a version of the 2017 defense spending bill on Thursday that would leave thousands of Afghan interpreters who worked for the American government in Afghanistan in the lurch.

headline: A Summer Vacation That Lasts a Lifetime
abstract: The Fresh Air Fund offers New York City children a chance to get away. Here’s how you can help.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1983, 8-year-old Darryl Rattray boarded a bus to Schenectady, N.Y., not knowing what to expect. At the time, he lived in a Bronx neighborhood plagued with drugs and violence. At home, his mother was undergoing treatment for breast cancer. The Fresh Air Fund provided a much-needed break.

headline: Wrath of the Conned
abstract: The divergent outcomes of the presidential nominating processes is a tale of two very different parties.
lead_paragraph: Maybe we need a new cliché: It ain’t over until Carly Fiorina sings. Anyway, it really is over — definitively on the Democratic side, with high probability on the Republican side. And the results couldn’t be more different.

headline: If Not Trump, What?
abstract: It’s time to step back, take the long view and begin healing the pain that the campaign has illuminated.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump now looks set to be the Republican presidential nominee. So for those of us appalled by this prospect — what are we supposed to do?

headline: Working-Class Fraud
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Trump is a traitor to the people he professes to speak for. We know this because he‘s already betrayed them.
lead_paragraph: He descended from the sky last Sunday in a helicopter that could have come from heaven, landing outside a hangar in Hagerstown, Md. He would talk for little more than an hour, mostly about himself, how he is “a smart guy” and “I look really good” and “I equal love.”

headline: There’s No Such Thing as a Free Rolex
keywords: ['Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: The Supreme Court weighs whether pay-to-play politics is a constitutional right.
lead_paragraph: THIS week, the Supreme Court heard McDonnell v. United States, the case of Bob McDonnell, the former governor of Virginia who is appealing his 2014 conviction for public corruption. Although the court’s ruling is not expected until June, in Wednesday’s hearing several justices seemed set on undermining a central, longstanding federal bribery principle: that officials should not accept cash or gifts in exchange for giving special treatment to a constituent.

headline: How to Prepare for the Next Recession
keywords: ['Recession and Depression', 'Unemployment Insurance', 'Medicaid', 'Food Stamps', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Economy', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A downturn is inevitable, and America isn’t ready — yet.
lead_paragraph: Washington — DESPITE solid job numbers, America’s gross domestic product grew by just 0.5 percent during the first three months of 2016, the slowest pace in two years. The current expansion is already longer than the postwar average, so it will be no surprise if policy makers begin asking, Is a recession lurking around the corner?

headline: R.B.S. Losses Widen After Payment to British Government
abstract: The bank paid $1.7 billion in March to fulfill a condition of its bailout package, which gave the government dividend priority.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Friday that its losses widened in the first quarter compared with a year earlier, after it made a payment of 1.19 billion pounds, or about $1.7 billion, to the British government to fulfill a condition of its bailout package.

headline: The Remarkable Rise of Leicester City
abstract: A year after narrowly avoiding relegation, the Foxes beat 5,000-to-1 odds to win the Premier League title.
lead_paragraph: For casual soccer fans, it may be difficult to fully understand the absurdity of Leicester City winning England’s Premier League title. To say it is an upset or a shock or a stunner seems wholly inadequate, particularly when one considers that those words are so often used to describe one-time results (the United States over the Soviet Union in the 1980 Olympic hockey tournament, for example) as opposed to the feat of endurance that is required for a relative minnow like Leicester to dominate the sharks of English soccer for a nine-month season.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Offers to Sell More SABMiller Assets in Europe
abstract: On the block would be SABMiller’s assets in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, Romania and Slovakia as it seeks approval for their merger.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Anheuser-Busch InBev said on Friday that it had offered to sell the Central and Eastern European operations of SABMiller in order to win approval from European regulators for their more than $100 billion merger.

abstract: As a May 1 deadline nears, terms of a bill to rescue the island are unresolved, risking greater injury to its ailing economy.

headline: The Entire Netflix History of Us
abstract: When a shared account is all that’s left of a relationship, the connection can both comfort and annoy.
lead_paragraph: Rob and I broke up on a Monday. It was the first warm day after an impossibly long winter, which made the whole thing feel that much more cruel. I was in line at Starbucks when I got a text that read, “Hey, you around? I think we need to talk.”

headline: Plan to Turn Sony Building Into Luxury Apartments Is Abandoned
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: In the latest example of a market’s slowdown, the developer Joseph Chetrit is selling the tower to companies that will turn it into an office building.

headline: When the Landlord Is a Friend
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Landlords', 'Friendship']
abstract: Members of the new guard of landlords are just as likely to come in for an after-work beer as they are to stop by at midnight to fix a clogged sink.
lead_paragraph: With New York City real estate prices soaring, the only way for some city dwellers to achieve the American dream of owning property is to become landlords. And these days, many landlords are their tenants’ contemporaries — learning on the fly how to manage property and relying on YouTube for how-to tutorials on home repairs. Still others are filling their homes with friends-turned-tenants.

headline: Debt Collectors Adopt Mob Tactics as Russians Struggle to Pay Bills
keywords: ['Debt Collection', 'Credit and Debt', 'Organized Crime', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Assaults']
abstract: A culture of violence and threats flourishes as growing numbers of Russians turn to borrowing at astronomical interest rates amid a recession.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — They have stripped and sexually abused a woman, severely burned a toddler by firebombing a house and broken a woman’s pinkie as a warning. Gang members, bandits, mobsters? Not exactly. These are debt collectors, a peculiarly Russian variety that is flourishing amid the country’s economic turmoil.

headline: The Professor Has a Daring Past
abstract: Justus Rosenberg, 95 and still teaching at Bard, worked on a secret team to help intellectuals flee Nazi-occupied France.
lead_paragraph: Prof. Justus Rosenberg pulled a tattered, marked-up copy of Voltaire’s “Candide” out of a mushroom-brown soft zippered pouch emblazoned with the old Channel 13 logo. “We have an existential problem,” he said, waving the paperback at a seminar of 10 students at Bard College. “The concept of the El Dorado. What does it mean, the El Dorado?”

headline: Seeing the Cycle of Life in My Baby Daughter’s Eyes

I remember a day not long ago when I rocked my daughter, Eva, in my arms, and her eyes stopped and steadied as they looked back into mine. Her arms and legs ceased to rock and her entire body just relaxed. A chill went down my spine.

headline: How to Deliver a Baby
abstract: Radiate calm. Trust the mother’s instincts about pushing.
lead_paragraph: “You don’t want the baby to fall on the floor,” says Dr. Paulo Alves, a medical director for MedAire, which provides 136 airlines with medical training, logistics and a telephone service that connects flight attendants all over the world to emer­gency-room doctors in Phoenix. If a woman goes into labor somewhere far from a hospital — 37,000 feet above the Pacific Ocean, say — ask if anyone in the vicinity has medical training. If not, help her into a comfortable place. On a plane, that’s usually a reclining first-class seat or the galley floor. Make sure blankets support her body so that when the baby arrives, it lands gently. “Babies are slippery when they’re born,” Alves warns.

headline: Hunger Games in South Africa
abstract: Raising eyebrows in Durban with the mention of a traditional dish.
lead_paragraph: I was never among the who’s-who in Durban, the beautiful city on the Indian Ocean coast of South Africa, where I live. But a few years ago, after some success as a writer, I became a person to invite. I loved it, make no mistake: the parties with the intellectual set, the politicians and anti-apartheid heroes, the serious journalists and entertainers. It seemed I had arrived.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: ‘The Rabbit Who Wants to Fall Asleep’
abstract: The children’s book makes explicit the hypnotic intentions most bedtime stories keep hidden.
lead_paragraph: Putting our 3-year-old son to bed isn’t a task my wife and I undertake lightly. On a typical night, there will be actual physical struggles and a great deal of bitter haggling over the particulars — over whether it will be she or I who keeps vigil as he bravely contends against his own fatigue, over how many stories will be read to him and which ones. There will also, typically, be a series of increasingly hostile demands for glasses of water, and at least one trip to the toilet that will eventually be exposed as a cynical diversionary tactic. One night, his claim that he needed to go was revealed as spurious, and I let him know that I was onto his hustle. “I’m not a fool,” I said.

headline: ‘Eat, Pray, Love’ and Travel
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Writing and Writers']

lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Gilbert has written several best-selling books of fiction and nonfiction, but she is best known for “Eat, Pray, Love,” her 2006 memoir of travel and personal discovery in Italy, Indonesia and India. To celebrate the book’s 10th anniversary, Riverhead Books has published “Eat, Pray, Love Made Me Do It,” a collection of 47 essays written by people inspired by the book. Following are edited excerpts from a conversation with Ms. Gilbert.

At least five or six people could hear this, as well as a subsequent call he made to his supervisor telling him or her that he was passing on the candidate, in part because the requested salary ($180,000) was too high.

headline: Better Aging Through Practice, Practice, Practice
keywords: ['Tennis', 'Age, Chronological', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Longevity', 'Exercise', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: I can’t promise this will prolong your life. But it will improve it.
lead_paragraph: SIXTY is not the new 40. Fifty isn’t either. Your lung capacity in late-middle age is in steady decline, as are the fast-twitch muscle fibers that provide power and speed. Your heart capacity has been ebbing for decades. Your sight has been getting worse, your other senses, too, and this, along with a gradually receding ability to integrate information you are absorbing and to then issue motor commands, means your balance is not what it used to be. (Your flattening arches aren’t helping.) Your prefrontal cortex — where the concentrating and deciding gets done — has been shrinking for some time, perhaps since you graduated from college. More of your career (more of your life) is behind you than in front of you. Do not kid yourself about this. You are milling in the anteroom of the aged.

headline: The Brilliant Red Salmon That’s Worth the Splurge
abstract: Wild Pacific salmon has an exquisite flavor and velvety texture — and it’s sustainable.
lead_paragraph: At the Pike Place Market in Seattle, it’s the glistening, freshly caught salmon piled high that you’ll notice first. The fishmongers are jolly, and sales are brisk.

headline: Flights of Memory (Not Just Birds) at the Barclay Hotel
abstract: A news column in The New York Times inspired fond recollections of a hotel in the Grand Central area of Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The InterContinental New York Barclay — or the Barclay, as any New Yorker would call the hotel — is to reopen Friday in the Grand Central area of Midtown Manhattan after a 20-month renovation. It is not one of the most famous hotels in the city, but to judge from readers’ responses to a Building Blocks column about the renovation, it is among the most fondly regarded.

headline: ‘Detroit Resurrected,’ by Nathan Bomey
abstract: Detroit stages a comeback after years of corruption and financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT RESURRECTEDTo Bankruptcy and BackBy Nathan Bomey297 pp. W.W. Norton & Company. $27.95.

headline: Shopping Guide: Outdoor Furniture
keywords: ['Chairs', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Porches, Patios and Decks', 'Furniture', 'Gardens and Gardening']
abstract: The interior designer Samuel Amoia suggests chaise longues for outdoor use.
lead_paragraph: The interior designer Samuel Amoia lives in Manhattan, but these days his thoughts often stray to the beach. That’s because one of his largest projects is Itz’ana, a resort and residential development in Belize opening later this year.

headline: ‘Sports Detectives’ Tracks Down Famed Memorabilia
abstract: An episode focusing on Jim Brown’s 1964 championship ring and the Immaculate Reception.
lead_paragraph: Fans who gorge on TV coverage of the National Football League draft can turn to the Smithsonian Channel for a digestif on Sunday, May 1: a football-themed episode of a new series called “Sports Detectives.” Each installment tries to track down or determine the authenticity of sports memorabilia, and here the objects in question are the 1964 championship ring that belonged to the Cleveland Browns running back Jim Brown and the football that ricocheted into the arms of the Pittsburgh Steelers’ Franco Harris in the 1972 play known as the Immaculate Reception. The findings by the “detectives” — Lauren Gardner, a sports reporter, and Kevin Barrows, a private investigator — aren’t always definitive, but the fun is in the revisiting of these moments. (The series premiere on April 24 concerned the flag that draped the goalie Jim Craig after the United States hockey team’s gold medal victory at the Lake Placid Olympics in 1980.) And, especially in the segment on the ring, a story that involves a divorce and a possible burglary, the quests provide a window into the sometimes murky sports-memorabilia world.

headline: The Artist Ken Price, in Two Dimensions Instead of Three
abstract: Mr. Price was best known as a sculptor, but he liked to draw, too, as an exhibition at Matthew Marks Gallery shows.
lead_paragraph: The sculptor Ken Price’s celebrated, oozy abstract pieces in glazed or painted clay can bring to mind Kurt Vonnegut’s description of little green aliens: “The creatures were friendly, and they could see in four dimensions. They pitied Earthlings for being able to see only three.”

headline: Román Díaz to Open the Afro-Cuban Inspired Source Project
abstract: The Symphony Space series also includes the singer Xiomara Laugart, the tenor saxophonist Yosvany Terry and the percussionist Pedrito Martínez.
lead_paragraph: The percussionist and singer Román Díaz opens his spirited recent album, “L’ó dá fún Bàtá” (Motéma), with a vocal invocation to Eleguá, the Yoruban lord of the crossroads. For Mr. Díaz, it’s an elegant way of flying his colors as one of the leading stewards of the Afro-Cuban tradition in New York. On some level, it also sets a tone for a concert and film series like the Source Project, running during the first week of May at Symphony Space.

headline: Shortages in Venezuela Spark Looting
abstract: A lack of basic goods led to protests and looting in Venezuela’s second-largest city of Maracaibo.
lead_paragraph: A lack of basic goods led to protests and looting in Venezuela’s second-largest city of Maracaibo.

abstract: A Clinton supporter says, “On my college campus, I might as well be Pat Buchanan.”
