headline: Everyone Wants to Get Tough on Antitrust Policy, but Not Really
keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Markets are now so concentrated and ripe for abuse, and the political will for enforcement so lacking, that our antitrust laws seem increasingly hopeless.
lead_paragraph: The White House recently issued an executive order, supported by a report from the Council of Economic Advisers, discovering that monopoly is on the rise and directing federal agencies to look for ways to bolster competition and control specific anti-competitive abuses.

headline: Timothy Levitch, a Beat-Poet Tour Guide
abstract: Mr. Levitch, known as Speed, gives experiential tours of New York City that are replete with his trademark free-form soliloquies.
lead_paragraph: New York City is bursting with tours, of landmarks and neighborhoods and less predictable destinations, historical or gastronomical or criminal.

headline: This Week’s Movies | April 29, 2016
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Keanu,” “The Family Fang” and “L’Attesa.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Keanu,” “The Family Fang” and “L’Attesa.”

headline: Aid in Dying: A Good or a Harm?
abstract: Advocates on both sides of the issue respond.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Andrew Bolton of Met Costume Institute Spends His Sundays
abstract: Mr. Bolton says getting a dachshund a year ago has drastically changed his weekend habits, but some constants, like champagne in the evening, remain.
lead_paragraph: If you are Andrew Bolton, the curator in charge of the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, or the fashion designer Thom Browne, what do you wear on a leisurely Sunday? “Thom still gets dressed in his usual uniform,” Mr. Bolton, 49, said the other day, during the final preparations for an exhibition called “Manus x Machina: Fashion in an Age of Technology,” which opens on May 5, after a fund-raising gala on May 2. “I tend to be more casual. I just wear jeans and sneakers and a shirt or sweater. His usual uniform is literally a suit. So he’ll wear his gray suit and a tie and a tiepin.” What they do not wear are little stickers bearing the Met’s new logo. “It’s very polarizing,” Mr. Bolton said. Did that mean he had met anyone who liked it? “No,” he said. The couple, who have been together for five years, live on Central Park West with a miniature wire-haired dachshund named Hector who dominates their lives. “We’re obsessive,” Mr. Bolton said.

headline: It’s a Beaver! It’s a Big ‘Water Rat’! No, It’s a Muskrat
abstract: The gentle rodents, found in at least four of the city’s five boroughs, are eager foragers frequently mistaken for beavers and giant rats.
lead_paragraph: Muskrats are equally at home in freshwater ponds or brackish bays, swimming their way through at least four of New York City’s five boroughs. Though I have never seen one in Manhattan, I’d be surprised if a muskrat hadn’t shown up in Inwood or perhaps even Central Park.

headline: A Penthouse on the Hudson for $20 Million
abstract: A full-floor at One Riverside Park was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A full-floor penthouse at One Riverside Park, the Extell Development Company’s glassy tower overlooking the Hudson, sold for $20,063,525 and was the most expensive closed transaction of the week, according to city records.

headline: A Few Miles From San Bernardino, a Muslim Prom Queen Reigns
keywords: ['San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Proms', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Zarifeh Shalabi received the ultimate symbol of teenage acceptance when her non-Muslim friends campaigned for her by wearing hijabs in solidarity.
lead_paragraph: FONTANA, Calif. — In the days after the December terrorist attack in San Bernardino, Calif., when pictures of the hijab-wearing suspect filled television screens and newspapers, Zarifeh Shalabi’s mother and aunts stayed at home.

headline: New York’s First Public Advocate Reflects on a Liberal Epoch
abstract: In “Bright, Infinite Future,” Mark Green assesses his political life and influence. “Gordon Bennett and the First Yacht Race Across the Atlantic” recounts the flamboyant publisher’s sailing experience.
lead_paragraph: Mark Green, who was the city’s first public advocate, more or less admits that by 2009, the last time he sought elective office, New Yorkers were suffering from Green Fatigue.

headline: Review: On ‘Views,’ Drake Is Still His Own Genre
abstract: On his fourth solo album, Drake is fending off attacks, maintaining his grip on turf he controls and wondering what might be next.
lead_paragraph: Drake’s career has been built on collapsing walls, and “One Dance,” one of the early singles from his new album, “Views,” is a vivacious fulfillment of his promise as hip-hop’s great syncretic hope.

headline: Watch Out! Summer Means Disaster Movies
abstract: And some of the biggest blockbusters — “Jaws,” “Speed” — have a dark heart.
lead_paragraph: Despite the sunshine and balmy breezes, movies released in the summer are often no vacation. From “On the Waterfront” in 1954 to “Rosemary’s Baby” (1968) to the first “Hangover” in 2009, some of the greatest cinematic struggles and calamities (the mob, a co-op full of conspirators, Mike Tyson’s stray tiger) have occurred in films released between Memorial Day and Labor Day. Maybe it’s primal? Do moviegoers secretly crave to be reminded each easeful season that life can be a hard scrape lest we become defenseless creatures of leisure? Here are a few films that give the lie to the lyric “summertime and the livin’ is easy.”

headline: After Pete Seeger, a Coffeehouse Tries to Carry On
abstract: A coffeehouse founded by Pete Seeger is scheduling younger acts, while remaining true to the folk mainstays.
lead_paragraph: Pete Seeger was a giant in politically progressive music circles, and when he died, in January 2014, the impact was felt around the world — nowhere more, perhaps, than in a lower-level hall of the Memorial United Methodist Church in White Plains. That is where a group called the Walkabout Clearwater Coffeehouse, which the folk singer established, had blossomed into a community of like-minded people who gather to hear music and promote their social causes.

headline: Rebecca Miller Is Brainy, and Very, Very Funny
abstract: Ms. Miller’s latest film, “Maggie’s Plan,” focuses on a young woman who wants to arrange her own pregnancy — hold the man.
lead_paragraph: Rebecca Miller’s new movie, “Maggie’s Plan,” is a screwball comedy, set in New York, about a young woman (Greta Gerwig) whose ditziness takes the form of hyper-rationality. She thinks she can plan everything, until she runs into a married couple (Ethan Hawke and Julianne Moore) who are professors of something called ficto-critical anthropology — a real academic discipline that, in the movie anyway, is every bit as nutty as it sounds. Ms. Moore, playing a Dane, speaks in an accent even furrier than the one she used in “The Big Lebowski.”

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s homes include a five-bedroom house in Fairfield, Conn., and a seven-bedroom Victorian in Yonkers, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties in the New York region:

headline: On the Market in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s homes include a five-bedroom house in Fairfield, Conn., and a seven-bedroom Victorian in Yonkers, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: This week’s homes include a five-bedroom house in Fairfield, Conn., and a seven-bedroom Victorian in Yonkers, N.Y.

headline: In ‘Pericles,’ a Dive Bar, the Blues and a Banjo Ukulele
abstract: A small band of artists at the theater in Red Bank puts a modern musical twist on one of Shakespeare’s wilder works.
lead_paragraph: One of Shakespeare’s wildest yarns, “Pericles,” receives an extremely imaginative production that delivers plenty of freewheeling entertainment at Two River Theater in Red Bank.

headline: Partial Truce Said to Be Restored in Syria, but Not Yet in Aleppo
abstract: The United States and Russia said they had won agreement for a new partial truce after a bloody week, but that it would not immediately include Aleppo.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As Syria convulsed from the bloodiest week there in months, the United States and Russia declared on Friday that they had won agreement for a new partial truce in several strategic areas, but that it would not immediately include Aleppo, the divided city where recent attacks killed more than 200 people.

headline: English National Opera Names New Artistic Director
abstract: The appointment of Daniel Kramer, an American theater and opera director with no experience running a major arts organization, to lead the troubled company was unexpected.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Kramer, an American theater and opera director, has been appointed the artistic director of English National Opera, one of London’s two major opera companies.

headline: A Condo to Rise in NoMad
abstract: Apartments at the 24-story Noma, coming to 50 West 30th Street, will have views of the Empire State Building.
lead_paragraph: There may be no better spot to consider how place names come and go than the Avenue of the Americas in the West 20s and 30s.

headline: ‘Look at Us Now, Mother!’ Presents a Family Journey to Forgiveness
abstract: Gayle Kirschenbaum’s documentary, “Look at Us Now, Mother!” chronicles her upbringing on Long Island, and how as an adult she learned to cope with the criticisms of her mother.
lead_paragraph: The filmmaker Gayle Kirschenbaum, whose documentary “Look At Us Now, Mother!” will have a one-week run on Long Island starting May 6, grew up thinking she had been born into the wrong family. And she wasn’t thrilled about growing up in Long Island’s Five Towns either.

headline: A Campaign for Change at a Boutique Wall Street Firm
keywords: ['Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: J. Daniel Plants, the founder of Voce Capital Management, is fighting to restore FBR & Company to its highly profitable roots.
lead_paragraph: It’s not so fun working on Wall Street these days. The hours are long, the pay is not nearly what it once was (though it is still very good, all things considered), and the public’s animosity toward the industry has become all too familiar. Even worse than working at an investment bank, however, is investing in one.

headline: Deaf Club
abstract: Scenes from a punk show for the hearing-impaired community.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from a punk show for the hearing-impaired community.

headline: In ‘Wit,’ an Actress Shorn of Hair Shines
abstract: Elizabeth Lande grapples nightly with the emotional challenges of a moving and funny play.
lead_paragraph: The brief nudity? “Nah, it’s not a problem.”

headline: TV Stations Agree to Sell Enough Spectrum to Meet F.C.C.’s Goal
abstract: The agency reached its maximum target for a giant airwave auction that will support the next generation of wireless Internet services.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The federal government is ready to set off a huge land grab for valuable spectrum, the last of its kind for the foreseeable future.

headline: Scenes From a Punk Rock and Storytelling Show, for Deaf People
abstract: Last night, the Knockdown Center in Queens hosted the Deaf Club, a performance and music event.
lead_paragraph: At its best, punk rock relies on an admixture of velocity, attitude and volume — which is exactly what made last night’s Deaf Club event a smash success. The show, held at the Knockdown Center in Maspeth, Queens, a former door factory turned interdisciplinary arts space, was curated by the Los Angeles-based artist Alison O’Daniel who, herself, is hard of hearing. The event was a live extension of O’Daniel’s “The Tuba Thieves” (currently a part of her “Room Tone” exhibition) — a film that explores the events surrounding an unlikely series of tuba thefts in Los Angeles schools.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: One Celebrated Brooklyn Artist’s Futuristic New Practice
abstract: Google teamed up with Dustin Yellin on the launch of its new Tilt Brush technology, which allows users to paint in three dimensions.
lead_paragraph: The process by which the artist Dustin Yellin creates his signature works — methodically collaging tens of thousands of tiny cutout images on multiple glass slabs, then stacking those layers to create intricate three-dimensional sculptures — doesn’t require much technological intervention. “I’m pretty analog,” he admitted earlier this week when I stopped by his studio in Red Hook, which is next door to his influential interdisciplinary arts space Pioneer Works.

headline: In Bushwick, Playing With Fire, Then Eating It
abstract: The Floasis in Bushwick, Brooklyn, is a hub for fire arts, where anyone with an appetite for heat can learn to spin fire.
lead_paragraph: It used to be that if you wanted to practice fire arts in the city, you had to do it in secret. But all that changed late last year, when the Fire Department granted a special permit for the first time to the Floasis, where anyone with an appetite for heat can spin fire.

headline: Friday Night Music: Tom Lehrer
abstract: Things haven’t changed that much …
lead_paragraph: I know, it’s only afternoon, but it’s been quite a week. And also not fresh indie stuff; somehow, especially given this, this oldie seemed appropriate.

headline: Bill Cunningham | All Aswirl
abstract: The springtime return of colorful pleated skirts.
lead_paragraph: Pleated skirts started showing up last autumn but were quickly hidden under winter coats. They are back now, in multiple colors, fabrics and lengths. They are not a major trend; more like a caprice of fashion that women clearly love wearing. So does the artist Timothy John who creates his own sophisticated combinations.

headline: Big City Book Club: American Psycho
abstract: The Big City Book Club discussed the novel “American Psycho,” an addictive satire of 1980s depravity in New York.
lead_paragraph: The Big City Book Club discussed the novel “American Psycho,” an addictive satire of 1980s depravity in New York.

headline: Protest Turns Rowdy as Donald Trump Appears at California G.O.P. Convention
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Republican National Convention', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Chants, signs and a human chain greeted the candidate, who is closing in on his party’s nomination and was set to address conservative activists.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGAME, Calif. — Furious protests erupted outside the California Republican Party convention on Friday as Donald J. Trump was set to address conservative activists in one of the most progressive regions of the country.

headline: Mister Softee’s Greatest Hit
abstract: The company’s famous jingle is part of a dying tradition of New York noise — from knife grinders and chimney sweeps to this summer’s ice cream trucks.
lead_paragraph: We are just one-third of the way through 2016, and we have already been so overwhelmed by the loss of musical heroes that it feels impossible to make room for more grief. But Les Waas, who died on April 19 at age 94, deserves a page in our Book of Lamentations. You may not have heard of Waas, but you’ve heard his music. He was the Philadelphia adman and prolific composer of jingles who in 1960 came up with the theme song for Mister Softee — that deceptively gentle singsong melody, rendered in tinkling music-box bells, that has blasted from the roof-mounted P.A. systems of Mister Softee ice cream trucks for decades. The song was originally a jingle, music and words, written for radio and television spots, with a lyric celebrating the deliciousness of Mister Softee’s desserts and the convenience of a mobile ice cream parlor:

headline: Former Auschwitz Guard Apologizes at Trial in Germany
abstract: The 94-year-old defendant, Reinhold Hanning, told a German court he was “ashamed I witnessed injustice and allowed it to continue” while serving at the Nazi death camp.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A 94-year-old former SS guard on Friday told a German court that he was “sincerely sorry” for failing to do anything to prevent the suffering and deaths of tens of thousands of prisoners at the Auschwitz death camp, breaking his silence after weeks of sitting motionless in the face of pleas by survivors for him to speak.

headline: Review: ‘Hopper’s Wife’ Imagines a Painter Married to a Gossip Queen
abstract: At Harlem Stage, City Opera gives this chamber work — about Edward, Jo and Hedda Hopper, and a nude model named Ava — its East Coast premiere.
lead_paragraph: Librettists often tweak facts for dramatic effect, but history has been radically rewritten in Stewart Wallace’s 1997 chamber opera “Hopper’s Wife,” presented by New York City Opera in its East Coast premiere on Thursday at the intimate Harlem Stage.

headline: N.H.L. Draft Lottery Promises a Bit More Excitement This Year
abstract: In a draft lottery similar to the N.B.A.’s, teams in the N.H.L. will compete for the top three picks, not just the first one as in past years.
lead_paragraph: It will be a big night for Canadian hockey on Saturday, with seven teams competing for a huge prize.

headline: Evening Hours | Events From the Week of April 25
abstract: Bill Cunningham covers events from the week.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cunningham covers events from the week.

headline: America's Election Mixtape
abstract: Singers write the song, but politicians — and the voters — decide the meaning.
lead_paragraph: Singers write the song, but politicians — and the voters — decide the meaning.

headline: Bernie Sanders Rails Against Relocation of Indiana Factory
abstract: Bernie Sanders, making a late push ahead of Tuesday’s primary voting, spoke out Friday against a company’s plans to move hundreds of local jobs to Mexico.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders spoke out Friday against an Indiana company’s plans to move hundreds of local jobs to Mexico, part of a last-minute push ahead of Tuesday’s primary, in which he hopes to win enough delegates to justify continuing his campaign.

headline: Carry-Ons Bristle With Loaded Guns At Airport Security
abstract: Packing a gun in your carry-on is illegal, but that doesn’t stop thousands of people from trying it every year.
lead_paragraph: Anyone annoyed at long airport security lines and picayune-seeming inspectors should be grateful that watchful agents of the Transportation Security Administration have been confiscating guns at an unfortunately record pace from travelers who mindlessly pack them in their carry-on bags.

headline: Permateen in the Making
abstract: Cassandra Giraldo began following the life of Brooklyn teenagers five years ago. In the process she became a better photographer and more aware of what makes adolescents tick.
lead_paragraph: Cassandra Giraldo began following the life of Brooklyn teenagers five years ago. In the process she became a better photographer and more aware of what makes adolescents tick.

headline: Brooklyn Teenagers Capture a Photographer’s Eye
abstract: Cassandra Giraldo began studying the youngsters’ world five years ago, concentrating on how they spent the time between school and home.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, the photographer Cassandra Giraldo fell into step with some teenagers on their way to the mall at Atlantic Terminal in Brooklyn. She spent the next several months documenting two of the girls, April and Desire, until their graduation from the eighth grade.

headline: Officer Convicted of Assault for Stomping on Suspect’s Head
abstract: Officer Joel Edouard faces up to a year in jail on misdemeanor assault charges stemming from a July 2014 arrest in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police officer was convicted on Friday of misdemeanor assault for stomping on the head of a suspect as he lay prone on a Brooklyn street while being arrested.

headline: For Mayor de Blasio, Police Dept. Is a Force to Be Reckoned With
abstract: As long as a culture in which obfuscation is regarded as entitlement continues to dominate the Police Department, Mayor Bill de Blasio is vulnerable to the accusation that little has changed.
lead_paragraph: Early in the evening of April 19, a few hours after a Brooklyn judge ruled that the former police officer Peter Liang’s shooting of Akai Gurley in 2014 was essentially an accident for which a prison sentence was not deemed necessary, Constance Malcolm received a call in her Bronx apartment. On the other end of the line was Valerie Bell, the mother of Sean Bell, who was killed by the police a decade ago outside a Queens nightclub, where he had been celebrating at his bachelor party. Four years ago, Ms. Malcolm’s son Ramarley Graham was shot and killed by a police officer, Richard Haste, in the company of several others, a few feet from where she was now standing. Her mother and her younger son, Chinnor Campbell, then 6, were at home when it happened.

headline: Trump Jokes About Entering G.O.P. Event
abstract: Donald J. Trump said he felt as if he were “crossing the border” after entering the California Republican convention through a back entrance to avoid protesters.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said he felt as if he were “crossing the border” after entering the California Republican convention through a back entrance to avoid protesters.

headline: Plan Ahead: 10 Things to Do in NYC
abstract: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here is a selection of cultural events taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: It’s a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. Here is a selection of cultural events taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead.

headline: Hitting all the Right Notes
abstract: Teenagers at a gospel quartet class in Harlem, taught by Eli Paperboy Reed, pour new energy and inspiration into an old tradition.
lead_paragraph: Teenagers at a gospel quartet class in Harlem, taught by Eli Paperboy Reed, pour new energy and inspiration into an old tradition.

headline: First U.S. Death Tied to Zika Is Reported in Puerto Rico
abstract: An elderly man from Puerto Rico succumbed after complications from an earlier infection caused by the disease-carrying mosquito.
lead_paragraph: A Puerto Rican man died from complications of the Zika virus earlier this year, the first reported death attributed to the disease in the United States.

headline: A Pop Life After ‘The Walking Dead’
abstract: Emily Kinney, an actress and singer, has an apartment filled with zombie paraphernalia sent by fans.
lead_paragraph: Name Emily Kinney

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Ashley Parker, Jan Hoffman and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Microsoft Will Not Donate Money to Republicans’ Convention
abstract: The tech giant will not provide cash donations to the Republican convention this summer, the company announced in a blog post on Friday.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft will not provide cash donations to the Republican convention this summer, the company announced in a blog post on Friday, following lobbying from liberal organizations that have sought to pressure potential event sponsors ahead of Donald J. Trump’s increasingly likely presidential nomination.

headline: Don’t Treat Young Adults as Teenagers
keywords: ['Juvenile Delinquency', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Research', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Brain', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: Raising the age of juvenile court jurisdiction to 21 is misguided.
lead_paragraph: OVER the past dozen years, the Supreme Court has issued several landmark decisions affirming that adolescents and adults are fundamentally different in ways that justify treating minors less harshly when they violate the criminal law. The court, drawing on psychological and brain science indicating that people under age 18 are not yet fully capable of controlling their behavior, abolished the juvenile death penalty and greatly restricted life without parole sentences for crimes by juveniles. As scientists and legal scholars who specialize in these issues, we have welcomed these changes with enthusiasm.

headline: Eli Paperboy Reed Lifts Young Voices in the Gospel Spirit
abstract: In Mr. Reed’s class, students are encouraged to explore their full vocal range, and sometimes they feel guided by a higher power.
lead_paragraph: There was a moment in Eli Paperboy Reed’s gospel quartet class recently, at the end of Blind Willie Johnson’s plaintive “Let Your Light Shine on Me,” when Asher Bethune, a reserved 19-year-old, hit a note so low, so unexpectedly, that the other students jumped and shouted. No one had heard Mr. Bethune sing like that before.

headline: Favorite Summer Movies From This Summer’s Stars and Directors
abstract: Top picks include “Independence Day,” “Thelma & Louise” and “Wet Hot American Summer.”
lead_paragraph: We asked stars and directors of this summer’s films about their own favorite summer films. Here’s what they said. (The answers have been edited and condensed.)

headline: In an Era of Streaming, Cinema Is Under Attack
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Our chief film critics, Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, consider the state of moviegoing in an era of omnipresent screens.
lead_paragraph: Seen any good movies lately? Seen any movies? Chances are you have — but maybe not in an actual theater. Americans used to adore going out to the movies, but that love has been on the rocks for decades. Once, the rival was television. Maybe it still is given that so much more of what’s produced specifically for the small screen seems so much more worthwhile (or at least watchable) than it once did. But the threat to movies appears more existential now, because the very digital revolution that has changed how movies are made has also changed how many of us watch them.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Afghanistan, Donald Trump, N.F.L.
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: A Mine vs. a Million Monarchs
abstract: A Mexican conglomerate wants to revive mining in a protected reserve for monarch butterflies.
lead_paragraph: THE national tourism agency calls the Mexican mountain town of Angangueo a “Pueblo Mágico.” If so, it is a dark magic.

headline: Review: Kelli O’Hara’s Operatic Turn in ‘Dido and Aeneas’
abstract: Ms. O’Hara, fresh from “The King and I,” assumed a throne herself at City Center, playing the tragic queen of Carthage.
lead_paragraph: Just 11 days after ending her Tony Award-winning run as Anna in Lincoln Center Theater’s acclaimed production of “The King and I,” Kelli O’Hara returned to a New York stage in another leading role. A surprising one.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Web-Only Series on Which the Viewer Wins With a Pair
abstract: “The Benefits of Gusbandry,” “Used People” and “Ask Mom Anything” are among shows with powerful stories built around two well-wrought main characters.
lead_paragraph: What was once a trickle of short-form video on the Internet is now well into flood stage, especially as so many web series are being turned into television shows (“Broad City,” “Drunk History”) or even feature films (“Ktown Cowboys”). Want to be a mainstream star? Shoot a few webisodes.

headline: Review: In ‘Anna Akhmatova,’ a Magical Interlude Reconjured
abstract: This music and theater piece at BAM Fisher evokes the historic 1945 night on which the poet Akhmatova stayed up discussing literature and life with Isaiah Berlin.
lead_paragraph: With “Anna Akhmatova: The Heart Is Not Made of Stone,” Eve Wolf, the founder and executive artistic director of the Ensemble for the Romantic Century, moves 180 degrees from her troupe’s dazzling, phantasmagorical April 2015 work, “Jules Verne: From the Earth to the Moon.” Which is not to say that the engrossing “Akhmatova” — having a five-day revival at BAM Fisher after its 2012 debut at Symphony Space — has any less merit.

headline: Who’s in Charge at the Brooklyn Museum? It Could Be You
abstract: When the museum set out to refresh its galleries, it got help from visitors who use its unique smartphone app.
lead_paragraph: When Juwan Stallings visited the Brooklyn Museum last weekend, he wanted more information about the subject of an oil portrait by Henri Fantin-Latour in the museum’s newly refurbished European galleries.

headline: Summer Movie Release Schedule 2016
abstract: A look at upcoming movie releases.
lead_paragraph: All dates are subject to change.

headline: Battle Over Bernie Sanders Team’s Use of Voter Data Is Over at Last
abstract: The battle between the Bernie Sanders campaign and the Democratic National Committee over the use of the D.N.C.’s voter data officially ended Friday, with the campaign withdrawing its lawsuit against the party.
lead_paragraph: The battle between the Bernie Sanders campaign and the Democratic National Committee over the use of the D.N.C.’s voter data officially ended Friday, with the campaign withdrawing its lawsuit against the party.

headline: Review: Crescendos and Decay in Juilliard Premieres
abstract: The Juilliard Orchestra performed premieres of works by the student composers Andrew Hsu, Will Healy, Anne Qian Wang and Will Stackpole at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: The pressures on young composers are enormous: Get into the right degree program, build your résumé, win grants, score commissions — oh, and on top of all that, have something to say that’s personal and fresh.

headline: Dole Knew About Listeria Problem at Salad Plant, F.D.A. Report Says
abstract: Four people died and 33 became ill in a listeria outbreak. The Justice Department is investigating.
lead_paragraph: The Dole Food Company, one of the largest processors of fresh produce, knew it had a listeria problem in one of its salad plants more than a year before it closed in January, according to a Food and Drug Administration report.

headline: Nissan Recalls 3.5 Million Vehicles for Airbag Problems
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The recall ends a two-year effort by regulators to get Nissan to fix problems in the sensing system of the airbags.
lead_paragraph: Nissan is recalling about 3.5 million vehicles, including almost 3.2 million in the United States, because the front-passenger airbag might not work properly in a crash, according to reports from the automaker posted Friday on the website of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: At Yale, a Right That Doesn’t Outweigh a Wrong
abstract: Putting Pauli Murray’s name on a building doesn’t magically erase the racist John C. Calhoun’s name across the campus.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — Yale made a grievous mistake this week when it announced that it would keep the name of an avowed white supremacist, John C. Calhoun, on a residential college, despite decades of vigorous alumni and student protests. The decision to name residential colleges for Benjamin Franklin and Anna Pauline Murray, a black civil rights activist, does nothing to redeem this wrong.

headline: Improvements on the Field and on the Mets’ Balance Sheet
abstract: Citi Field’s financial picture improved significantly with the Mets’ on-field success last year.
lead_paragraph: The Mets’ reversal of fortune last season — from years of losing at Citi Field to playing the Kansas City Royals in the World Series — provided a significant lift to the ballpark’s finances. That is not surprising, given that attendance rose 19.5 percent, to 31,725 a game.

headline: San Francisco Police Chief Releases Officers’ Racist Texts
keywords: ['Police', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Text Messaging', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Chinese-Americans']
abstract: San Francisco’s police chief on Friday ordered all officers to finish anti-bias training within the next month amid a racist texting scandal that has rocked the department.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Police Chief Gregory P. Suhr on Friday announced that all officers on the San Francisco force would be required to complete anti-bias training as he released nine pages of racist text messages between three officers that further tarnished the image of a department under federal investigation.

headline: Being Center of Attention Is Old News for Darron Lee, the Jets’ Speedy First-Round Linebacker
abstract: Darron Lee’s mother, Candice, is a weekend anchor for the NBC affiliate in Columbus, Ohio, and she says that her son always had a little swagger. “Some of that is me saying: ‘Be proud of who you are. You’re a good kid.”
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — When Darron Lee, the Jets’ No. 1 pick, showed up in a purplish suit for his first news conference on Friday, his mother, Candice, wearing glasses and with her hair pulled back after a sleepless night, quietly took a spot in the back of the room, behind the cameras.

headline: Ending Impasse, Irish Leaders Agree on a Government
abstract: The agreement, which follows an inconclusive election and two months of political deadlock, is likely to result in the re-election of Enda Kenny as prime minister.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The two biggest parties in Ireland on Friday overcame decades of enmity to cooperate on the creation of a minority government, ending weeks of deadlock after an inconclusive election in February.

headline: Philip Kives, Pitchman Who Perfected ‘As Seen on TV’ Infomercials, Dies at 87
abstract: Mr. Kives’s company, K-tel, saturated airwaves for decades with ads for gadgets like the Veg-O-Matic and compilation albums like “Hit Machine.”
lead_paragraph: Act now! Be the first on your block to read this obituary of the marketing guru who — as seen on TV — sliced, diced and polkaed his way to fortune!

headline: A Mockery of Justice for the Poor
keywords: ['Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Public defenders are starved for resources as they struggle to represent impoverished clients.
lead_paragraph: OVER the past year, everyone from the conservative Right on Crime project to the Black Lives Matter movement has pushed criminal justice reform to the forefront of political debates. Yet politicians at every level of government remain almost completely silent about one of the biggest crises facing criminal justice: the utter collapse of indigent defense.

headline: Mocking Critics, Donald Trump Says He Can Win Without Republican Unity
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Republican National Convention', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: After walking through a field to avoid protesters, Mr. Trump spoke at a meeting of Republicans in California and wavered on whether he wanted to heal the party.
lead_paragraph: BURLINGAME, Calif. — Donald J. Trump got a taste on Friday of what his next month of campaigning in California could be like. He was forced to exit his motorcade and walk through a field, climbing an embankment with Secret Service agents helping him, to avoid angry demonstrators on the street.

headline: Ex-Inmate’s Credibility Questioned as Rikers Guards Stand Trial
abstract: Jahmal Lightfoot, the witness in the trial of nine correction officers charged with beating him, has come under scrutiny while testifying in court.
lead_paragraph: It is not surprising that the victim of a brutal beating by a group of men is now the main witness against them in their trial.

headline: Friend of Dylann Roof Pleads Guilty in Charleston Case
abstract: Joseph C. Meek Jr. pleaded guilty on Friday to withholding his knowledge of Dylann S. Roof’s involvement in the attack on a Charleston church last June.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — With a series of subdued “Yes, Your Honors,” Joseph C. Meek Jr. pleaded guilty in United States District Court on Friday to lying to federal officials and withholding his knowledge of the involvement of his friend Dylann S. Roof in the massacre of nine black parishioners during a Bible study at the Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church here last June.

headline: How Ebola Destroyed Maternal Health Gains in Sierra Leone
abstract: What few gains had been made in maternal health in Sierra Leone have been undone by a health care system decimated by the Ebola outbreak.
lead_paragraph: What few gains had been made in maternal health in Sierra Leone have been undone by a health care system decimated by the Ebola outbreak.

headline: National Briefing
abstract: News and updates from around the country.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge sentenced a Navy commander to 78 months in prison for providing classified ship schedules in exchange for the services of a prostitute, theater tickets and other gifts from a Malaysian contractor who overbilled the Navy more than $34 million. The commander, Capt.-select Michael Misiewicz, 48, was sentenced Friday in San Diego on one count of conspiracy and one count of bribery. His sentence is the longest one in the bribery scandal. He pleaded guilty to providing classified information to Leonard Glenn Francis, whose Singapore-based Glenn Defense Marine Asia used it to beat out competitors and overbill the Navy by submitting fake tariffs and port fees. (AP)

headline: The One Thing Worse Than Trump
abstract: Ted Cruz has the distinction of being a presidential candidate who can make Donald Trump look good.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz continues to astound. Every time it appears he can’t get more awful, he finds a new avenue, like a ground mole sniffing out a beetle. Right now, he’s in Indiana, trying to save his presidential career by ranting about transgender people and bathrooms.

headline: A Moral Debt for Bombing the Doctors Without Borders Hospital
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Civilian Casualties', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Hospitals']
abstract: America should identify those responsible for the egregious blunder and do more to compensate the victims’ families.
lead_paragraph: The torrent of mistakes that led an American military gunship to obliterate a hospital in Kunduz, Afghanistan, last October, killing 42 innocent people and wounding dozens, resulted from gross negligence, judging from the findings of a report the Pentagon released on Friday.

headline: U.S. Rejects Iran’s Protest on Asset Ruling
abstract: The State Department said a Supreme Court ruling allowing use of Iranian assets to compensate victims of terrorist attacks comports with international law.
lead_paragraph: The United States on Friday rejected Iranian accusations that it had broken international law with a Supreme Court ruling that allows the use of seized assets from Iran’s central bank to compensate American victims of terrorist attacks.

headline: The House Votes Unanimously to Strengthen Email Privacy
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Search and Seizure', 'Cloud Computing', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'E-Mail', 'Electronic Communications Privacy Act', 'Privacy']
abstract: The House’s unanimous vote to strengthen email privacy should encourage the Senate to take up the measure and approve it speedily.
lead_paragraph: In a rare and remarkable display of bipartisanship, the House voted unanimously this week to strengthen a 30-year-old privacy law that governs how and when law enforcement agencies can obtain access to emails, photographs and other documents that people store online. If enacted, the changes will ensure that the law protects digital information as well as it does physical documents.

headline: Tommy Kono, Weight-Lifting Champion Raised in Internment Camp, Dies at 85
abstract: Kono learned to lift as a child in a Japanese-American detention camp during World War II and went on to win two Olympic gold medals in the sport.
lead_paragraph: Tommy Kono, who learned weight lifting as a frail youngster in a Japanese-American detention camp during World War II and went on to be recognized as one of the greatest lifters of all time, winning two Olympic gold medals and holding numerous records, died on Sunday in Honolulu. He was 85.

headline: Acts of a Scalawag
abstract: Why you should push yourself toward becoming a Saturday-level puzzle solver, and the return of Mark Diehl.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Confession time: I did not attempt to tackle a Saturday New York Times Crossword until I was hired to write Wordplay and had to do them as a condition of my remaining employed.

headline: To Sell New York, the City Calls on the Ninja Turtles
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Movies', 'Television']
abstract: New York City chose the crime-fighting reptiles as this year’s “family ambassadors” to woo visitors.
lead_paragraph: If you were selecting mascots to help draw tourists to a city, the first choice might not be a group of street-fighting reptiles who live in the sewer with a rat.

headline: U.N. Renews Mission in Western Sahara in Divisive Vote
abstract: A Security Council resolution renewed the peacekeeping mission but exerted little pressure on Morocco, which expelled dozens of United Nations workers last month.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council on Friday renewed its peacekeeping mission in the disputed Western Sahara region for a year with a resolution that placed only mild pressure on Morocco, which in a diplomatic flare-up last month expelled many of the staff members of the mission, crippling its ability to function.

headline: Crime or Not, Fund-Raising in New York Stinks
abstract: Current campaign rules offer no real controls or limits on the money sloshing through the system.
lead_paragraph: It’s been a rough couple of weeks for Mayor Bill de Blasio, who has been splattered by accusations and insinuations about shady-looking campaign fund-raising and is stuck with no better response than: Everybody does it, the law allows it, and why are you picking on me?

headline: Plan Proceeds to Convert Arcades in Lower Manhattan to Retail Space
abstract: The public, open-air walkways were constructed decades ago under an abandoned and discredited zoning theory, and the City Council will consider changing their use.
lead_paragraph: The de Blasio administration will give the owners of 17 enormous office towers in Lower Manhattan a chance to fill in the public arcades along their buildings’ ground floors and turn a shadowy, windswept realm into moneymaking retail space.

headline: Continuing Recent Trend, Jets Draft a Quarterback
abstract: The Jets selected Christian Hackenberg of Penn State in the second round of the N.F.L. draft. It was the fourth year in a row the Jets have drafted a quarterback.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets, whose starting quarterback remains unsigned, continued their annual tradition of restocking the position on Friday when they selected Christian Hackenberg of Penn State in the second round of the N.F.L. draft.

headline: In Round 2, Giants Snare Receiver With a Familiar Style
abstract: On Friday, with the 40th overall selection and the ninth of the second round, the Giants selected Oklahoma’s Sterling Shepard, giving Eli Manning another target.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — As the Giants’ scouts and front-office personnel surveyed the wide receivers available in the N.F.L. draft, a familiar name rang out when they assessed Oklahoma’s Sterling Shepard.

headline: Mets Beat Giants and Set Team Record With 12-Run Inning
abstract: Aside from the Mets’ one-inning run total, Yoenis Cespedes helped set franchise records for most R.B.I. in an inning (six) and most consecutive games with an extra-base hit (nine).
lead_paragraph: The Mets had been cruising through inferior competition, but on Friday, they had to jump up in weight class when the San Francisco Giants arrived at Citi Field.

headline: Blasts by Ortiz and Rodriguez Resuscitate a Dormant Rivalry
abstract: David Ortiz and Alex Rodriguez hit homers as Boston defeated the Yankees in the teams’ first meeting this season.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In New England, where professional sports are woven into the fabric of the culture as tightly as the seams on a baseball, the fortunes of the local teams are always monitored carefully.

headline: George Weymouth, Conservationist, Horse Enthusiast and Bon Vivant, Dies at 79
abstract: Mr. Weymouth, a member of the du Pont family, was a longtime fixture in fox-hunting, polo, steeplechase and carriage-driving circles.
lead_paragraph: In 1967, George Weymouth, a member of the du Pont family and a longtime fixture in fox-hunting, polo, steeplechase and carriage-driving circles, learned that the pristine meadowlands near his home in Chadds Ford, Pa., were going to be developed.

headline: Federal Inquiry Into Cuomo Project in Buffalo Focuses on Ex-Senior Aide
keywords: ['Subpoenas', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: The investigation into a former top aide, Joseph Percoco, strikes particularly close to Mr. Cuomo, who once described him as “my father’s third son.”
lead_paragraph: The federal investigation into one of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s signature upstate economic development programs has come to focus on one of his former top aides, several people familiar with the matter said on Friday.

headline: Review: ‘The Outgoing Tide’ by the Dreamcatcher Repertory Theater
abstract: Bruce Graham’s play employs both humor and a passionate anger in tackling the tough, emotional subjects of aging, memory loss and dementia.
lead_paragraph: “Rage, rage against the dying of the light,” Dylan Thomas wrote as he contemplated old age. Gunner, a character in “The Outgoing Tide,” is somewhat less poetic, yelling at his wife when she brings up the idea that they move into a rest home together: “You got a better chance of seeing Christ direct traffic with a cigar in his mouth.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, April 30, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “To you, clerk, literary man, sedentary person, man of fortune, idler, the same advice. Up!”

headline: Corrections: April 30, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, April 30, 2016.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY

headline: What’s on TV Saturday
abstract: Tom Hiddleston has real estate woes in “High-Rise.” Check out “Bloodline” before Season 2 lands. And HBO offers the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony.
lead_paragraph: Tom Hiddleston, who seems to be everywhere lately, moves into a building from hell in “High-Rise.” Catch up on “Bloodline” before a second season begins. And HBO presents the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony.

headline: Trail Blazers Eliminate the Gritty but Undermanned Clippers
abstract: Damian Lillard scored 28 points for Portland, which overcame a 2-0 series deficit and will next face the Golden State Warriors.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The game was only minutes old when Austin Rivers of the Los Angeles Clippers lunged for a loose ball, but all he caught was an accidental elbow from Al-Farouq Aminu, a forward from the Portland Trail Blazers. During the subsequent stoppage in play, Rivers left the court and disappeared to the locker room as a trainer held a white towel over Rivers’s face.

headline: ‘I Feel Ashamed Watching This’: Our Top 10 Comments of the Week
abstract: Readers react to abuse against female sports journalists, the Ted Cruz-Carly Fiorina ticket, texting while driving and more.
lead_paragraph: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: Fraying at the Edges: Her Fight to Live With Alzheimer’s
abstract: A withered person with a scrambled mind, memories sealed away: That is the familiar face of Alzheimer’s. But there is also the waiting period, which Geri Taylor has been navigating with prudence, grace and hope.
lead_paragraph: A withered person with a scrambled mind, memories sealed away: That is the familiar face of Alzheimer’s. But there is also the waiting period, which Geri Taylor has been navigating with prudence, grace and hope.

headline: What Is Alzheimer’s Disease?
abstract: Here are answers to some common questions about a disease that can seem frightening, mysterious and daunting.
lead_paragraph: Alzheimer’s disease can seem frightening, mysterious and daunting. There are still a lot of unknowns about the disease, which afflicts more than five million Americans. Here are answers to some common questions:

headline: Learn You Have Alzheimer’s, Then Invite a Reporter to Tail You? Really?
abstract: The reporter N.R. Kleinfield wanted to track a case of Alzheimer’s from right after a person’s diagnosis. First, he had to find a willing subject.
lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, Times reporter N.R. Kleinfield provides background on his work covering a woman living with Alzheimer’s.

headline: At 68, Maye Musk, the Mother of Elon, Is Reclaiming the Spotlight
abstract: A nutritionist who roamed the Kalahari desert and placed in beauty pageants has a career surge thanks in part to her eldest son, the technology titan.
lead_paragraph: The DVF Awards hosted by Diane von Furstenberg three weeks ago was filled with Botox blondes, crowding the bar in black cocktail dresses. Towering above them in stiletto heels and snugly fitting snow-white lace that matched her bobbed hair was Maye Musk, escorted by Marina Arsenijevic, a Serbian concert pianist.

headline: Brooklyn’s Wearable Revolution
abstract: The borough is becoming the East Coast’s Silicon Valley, with a new development in the Navy Yards and another in Sunset Park.
lead_paragraph: Monday is what for many in the fashion-Hollywood-business-celebrity nexus is considered the highlight of the social season: the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute gala. Before guests like Sarah Jessica Parker and Johnny Depp run the flashbulb gantlet to get to their Champagne and canapés, however, they will have to air-kiss the co-hosts Anna Wintour, Miuccia Prada, Taylor Swift, Nicolas Ghesquière, Idris Elba and Jonathan Ive, and at least pretend to pay attention to the nominal reason they are there: the opening of “Manus x Machina,” the Met’s annual fashion blockbuster exhibition.

headline: A Crusader in the Coal Mine, Taking On President Obama
abstract: The energy tycoon Robert Murray has fought the president all the way to the Supreme Court with a message: To keep America strong, keep mining coal.
lead_paragraph: ST. CLAIRSVILLE, Ohio — The rolling hills of eastern Ohio show few signs of the frenzied activity unfolding hundreds of feet underground. Inside the Powhatan No. 6 mine, a machine the size of a city bus is slowly slicing the earth, scraping out coal and sending it on a 40-minute ride to the surface.

headline: Hauling a Load of Breakdowns and Broken Hearts
keywords: ['Customer Relations', 'Trucks and Trucking', 'Consumer Protection', 'Automobile Renting and Leasing']
abstract: The Haggler follows up on the American Truck Group, whose rent-to-own program offered truckers a chance to be their own boss but left many angry and bitter.
lead_paragraph: In this episode, the Haggler takes a second and longer look at the American Truck Group, the company in Gulfport, Miss., that has been the focus of dozens of complaints from truckers in a rent-to-own program.

headline: The Week on Instagram
keywords: ['Photography', 'Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from Damascus, Syria, to Beyoncé‘s concert in Miami.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from Damascus, Syria, to Beyoncé‘s concert in Miami.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: A place to discuss your experience solving the “A Little Variety” suite of puzzles.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Insults and Ads: How Gender Hurts Trump but Doesn’t Lift Clinton
abstract: Research comparing two campaign ads, both on the theme of women, finds one far more effective at stirring up emotion and changing views of the candidates.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump thinks Hillary Clinton is playing “the women’s card.” But evidence suggests that if anything is making gender a potent issue in this campaign, it’s Mr. Trump’s words, not Mrs. Clinton’s.

headline: Dispatches From ‘Woodstock for Capitalists’
abstract: Warren E. Buffett oversees an empire at Berkshire Hathaway that touches everything from railroads to beer companies. His company held its annual shareholder meeting on Saturday, which has been dubbed “Woodstock for Capitalists,” in Omaha. This is what our reporter observed.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: The Unstoppable Facebook
abstract: The (relative) decline of Apple, the ascendance of Amazon and the continuing dominance of Mark Zuckerberg’s social network.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: As a Lease Ends, Open Houses Begin
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Evictions', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Porches, Patios and Decks', 'Condominiums', 'Landlords']
abstract: Dreading the foot traffic, dreaming of a sauna, and giving a tenant notice.
lead_paragraph: Obligatory Access

headline: Valerie Villarreal and Cesar Diaz: A Real Angel, Made to Wait
abstract: A confident suitor was rebuffed, but he eventually found his bride.
lead_paragraph: Valerie Rose Villarreal and Cesar Diaz were married April 30 at the Old Mission Santa Barbara in Santa Barbara, Calif. The Rev. Mark Martinez, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, with the Rev. Larry Gosselin, also a Catholic priest, taking part.

headline: Protesters Storm Baghdad’s Green Zone to Denounce Corruption
abstract: Hundreds breached the razor wire of Baghdad’s fortified Green Zone, long seen as a symbol of a government detached from ordinary Iraqi citizens.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Hundreds of protesters stormed Baghdad’s heavily fortified Green Zone on Saturday and entered the Parliament building, waving Iraqi flags, snapping photographs, breaking furniture and demanding an end to corruption. The episode deepened a political crisis that has paralyzed Iraq’s government for weeks.

headline: Remo Belli, Who Developed Synthetic Drumhead and Changed Music, Dies at 88
abstract: Mr. Belli’s Weather King, so named because it was impervious to humid conditions, largely replaced animal hides and helped feed rock ’n’ roll fever.
lead_paragraph: Remo Belli, a precocious musician who was credited with developing the first commercially successful synthetic drumheads — saving the hides of countless animals, turning millions of finger-tapping novices into accomplished percussionists and feeding rock ’n’ roll fever in the 1960s — died on April 25 in Pasadena, Calif. He was 88.

headline: Muslim’s Labour Party Candidacy Shapes London Mayoral Race
abstract: With Britain struggling to integrate minorities, Sadiq Khan is favored to win election on Thursday, which would make him the first Muslim to lead the city and give a boost to his opposition party.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The son of a London bus driver, Sadiq Khan has had a remarkable rise into the upper echelons of British politics. He grew up with seven siblings in a three-bedroom home in public housing and attended state schools before becoming a human rights lawyer and then a senior government minister.

headline: A Potent Side Effect to the Flint Water Crisis: Mental Health Problems
keywords: ['Lead', 'Water', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Water Pollution', 'Anxiety and Stress']
abstract: Health care workers are scrambling to help people cope with the consequences of contaminated water, including profound stress, worry, depression and guilt.
lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — Health care workers are scrambling to help the people here cope with what many fear will be chronic consequences of the city’s water contamination crisis: profound stress, worry, depression and guilt.

headline: Selling Bottled Water That’s Better for the Planet
keywords: ['Water', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Containers and Packaging', 'Sustainable Living', 'Plastic Bottles']
abstract: Companies like Just Water are addressing customers’ demand for convenience while working to make their bottles more environmentally friendly.
lead_paragraph: On a recent morning over avocado toast and world-renowned New York City tap water, Grace Jeon expounded on the virtues of public drinking water. Considering that the company she runs makes its money selling bottled water, her enthusiasm might have seemed a little strange. And in fact, she follows a decidedly odd business model.

headline: Who Might (or Might Not) Be Donald Trump’s Running Mate if He’s the Nominee?
keywords: ['Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Here are some names – according to Republican strategists, advisers and allies of potential picks, and some of the contenders themselves – and how they may be leaning.
lead_paragraph: Here are some names – according to Republican strategists, advisers and allies of potential picks, and some of the contenders themselves – and how they may be leaning.

headline: Run on a Ticket With Donald Trump? No, Thanks, Many Republicans Say
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: A remarkable range of leading Republicans have been emphatic publicly or privately that they do not want to be considered as Donald J. Trump’s running mate.
lead_paragraph: It’s a time-honored tradition for politicians to deny any interest in the vice presidency. But this year, with the possibility of Donald J. Trump as the Republican nominee, they really mean it.

headline: A Medieval Acrostic
abstract: A medieval acrostic by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — The historical novel “Wolf Hall” made waves in 2009 not only for its riveting tale of the rise of Thomas Cromwell in King Henry VIII’s court and its sheer weight (it’s 672 pages long), but also because it won the Man Booker Prize.

headline: ISIS Says It Killed Bangladesh Tailor Once Jailed for Blasphemy
abstract: Islamist militants claimed responsibility for the latest of several fatal attacks in Bangladesh, but officials said was too early to settle on a motive.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A Hindu tailor who had been briefly jailed several years ago over accusations that he made an unfavorable comment about the Prophet Muhammad was hacked to death on Saturday near his shop in central Bangladesh, the police said.

headline: An Electronic Umpire? Baseball Tried It (In the 1950s!)
abstract: The Brooklyn Dodgers trotted out a forerunner to modern technology during spring training: a machine designed to call strikes.
lead_paragraph: One day in March 1950, a batting cage at the Brooklyn Dodgers’ spring training camp in Vero Beach, Fla., became the setting for an event that looked as if it came out of the future: strikes being called not by a man in a mask, peaked cap and chest protector, but by a machine.

headline: Honduras Fires Over Two Dozen Police Commanders
abstract: A purge intended to clean up the force complemented an effort by President Juan Orlando Hernández to bypass the national police in favor of a militarized force.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — More than two dozen police commanders in Honduras have been fired as part of an effort to clean up a force that has long been infiltrated by organized crime.

headline: In Nod to a Bernie Sanders Ad, Hillary Clinton Seeks His Fans’ Support
abstract: Mrs. Clinton’s latest ad pays her rival a high compliment, in an unmistakable homage to the emotional message of Mr. Sanders’s “America” commercial.
lead_paragraph: As Hillary Clinton begins to look past Senator Bernie Sanders to a possible general election campaign, a new ad she began running this past week pays Mr. Sanders a high compliment.

headline: On the Ground in Aleppo: Bloodshed, Misery and Hope
abstract: The New York Times’s Cairo bureau chief reported from Aleppo, Syria, where inhabitants try to carry on despite a civil war’s inescapable reality.
lead_paragraph: ALEPPO, Syria — On the edge of Aleppo’s ancient citadel, Zahra and her family squatted in a once-grand apartment, now facing rebel lines. Plastic sheets covered its tall windows to shield the space from a sniper’s view; shelling boomed in the distance.

headline: One Top Taxpayer Moved, and New Jersey Shuddered
keywords: ['High Net Worth Individuals', 'Income Tax', 'States (US)', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: The hedge fund manager David Tepper’s relocation to Florida is a case study in how tax collection changes when income becomes concentrated in the hands of a few.
lead_paragraph: Our top-heavy economy has come to this: One man can move out of New Jersey and put the entire state budget at risk. Other states are facing similar situations as a greater share of income — and tax revenue — becomes concentrated in the hands of a few.

headline: Blackie Sherrod, 96, Who Wrote About Sports With a Texas Swagger, Dies
abstract: Mr. Sherrod, voted the state’s best 16 times, was admired for his lively style and for mentoring Dan Jenkins and other younger writers.
lead_paragraph: Blackie Sherrod, a sportswriter and editor who endeared himself to his Texas readers with a Southern strain of Runyonesque erudition, and to generations of younger reporters with his curmudgeonly mentoring, died on Thursday at his home in Dallas. He was 96.

headline: When Europe Stumbled
abstract: The errors of 2011-12.
lead_paragraph: Doing some homework on the European economy, and I found myself dissatisfied with many of the comparisons between the US and Europe since the crisis, including this one. Why? For the same reason I think you need to be careful when writing downbeat pieces about Japan: demography.

headline: Hackers’ $81 Million Sneak Attack on World Banking
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Computer Security']
abstract: Thieves used the Swift network to steal $81 million from Bangladesh’s central bank in February, raising concerns about vulnerabilities within the system.
lead_paragraph: Tens of millions of dollars siphoned from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. A shadowy set of casinos in the Philippines. A large bank in Bangladesh with creaky technology. An unknown — and perhaps uncatchable — group of anonymous thieves with sophisticated hacking skills.

headline: Samuel Billy Kyles, Witness to King’s Last Moments, Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Kyles was on the balcony of a Memphis motel with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. when the civil rights leader was gunned down.
lead_paragraph: In early 1968, the Rev. Samuel Billy Kyles and another local minister beckoned the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to Memphis to demonstrate support for a strike by 1,300 black city sanitation workers. The strikers were demanding a minimum 10-cents-an-hour wage increase, workplace safeguards and dignity. Their placards proclaimed, “I Am a Man.”

headline: Trump Plays the Man’s Card
abstract: Now he’s attacking Clinton and misses the point about a woman’s card: It’s less than worthless.
lead_paragraph: REPUBLICANS have often been indignant at being portrayed as waging a “war on women,” and the rhetoric sometimes was, indeed, a bit over the top. Until Donald Trump showed up.

headline: A Young Logger With Deep Roots in the California Timberlands
keywords: ['Careers and Professions', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Logging Industry', 'Family Business']
abstract: A newly graduated forestry technician enjoys the sense of continuity that comes from playing his part in the business his family started 70 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Webb, 22, is a forestry technician at Big Creek Lumber in Davenport, Calif.

headline: Fear of N.G.O.s, in Beijing and Beyond
abstract: Authoritarian governments are passing laws to drive out independent groups that are critical to fostering civil society.
lead_paragraph: The law that China passed on Thursday imposing stern controls on foreign nongovernmental organizations is deplorable but, sadly, not surprising. Illiberal and authoritarian governments are inherently allergic to civil society and, more broadly, to any institutions they don’t control.
